395
1
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Adelphella babingtonii  (Sacc.) Pfister, Matocec & I. Kusan^  Mycologia Montenegrina 11: 14 (2009) [2008];  == Pachyella babingtonii  (Berk. & Broome) Boud.;  == Peziza babingtonii  Berk. & Broome;  == Psilopezia babingtonii  (Berk. & Broome) Berk.;  = Peltidium  oocardii  Kalchbr.;  = Psilopezia myrothecioides  Berk. & Broome;  = Peziza depressa  W. Phillips in Cooke;  = Pelditium cookei  Hazsl.;  = Peziza saccharina  Bres.;  = Peziza bohemica  Velen.;  = Psilopezia albida  Kanouse;  = Pachyella dearnessii  Gamundi
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include flat to convex-cushion-shaped, yellowish brown to reddish brown fruiting body up to 1cm wide, growing flat on rotten logs, and microscopic characters.^ |A further 20 synonyms are given by Pfister. RANGE ^Adelphella babingtonii is found at least in WA, OR, ID, MT, and CO, (Larsen). Collections were examined from WA, OR, ID, and also ON, MA, MD, MI, MN, MT, OH, SC, VT, VA, Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Finland, France, Germany, Great Britain, Hungary, Italy, Sweden, Argentina, Costa Rica, Jamaica, Venezuela, India, Indonesia, and Japan, (Pfister).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 1cm, flat, convex-pulvinate [convex-cushion-shaped], appressed to substrate, attached at margin, drying to a thin film; hazel to umber, drying black^, (Pfister), up to 1cm, pulvinate, reddish brown (Dennis), 0.5-1(2)cm, disc-shaped to cushion-shaped, rounded; pale ocher to reddish-brown; uneven, shining when wet, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  translucent, gelatinous^, (Dennis), with firm outer layer, watery and gelatinous within, (Breitenbach)
UNDERSIDE  pale, ocher-brown; smooth^, (Dennis)
STEM  fruitbody rests broadly on substrate without stem^, (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on water-soaked rotten logs, sometimes underwater, or on leaves and woody debris or on encrusted algae^, (Pfister), single or gregarious, "On wet dead wood and spruce cones, also on other rotting plant parts (for example Carex), in drainage ditches and obstructions in streams", May to September (in Europe), (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17-23 x (9)10-16 um, smooth or with small puncta, 2 or sometimes 1 droplet (sometimes indistinct), deBary bubbles sometimes present, thick-walled, episporium highly cyanophilic^; asci 250-325 x 15-20 um, J+ or J-, sometimes golden in Melzer's; paraphyses extending beyond the ascus, expanded at tip to 7-15 um, apically pigmented with small dark highly cyanophilic granules, (Pfister), 19-21 x 12-13 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, containing 2 large oil droplets, in granular cytoplasm; asci up to 390 x 20 um; paraphyses "slender, simple, apex clavate, up to 8 um thick, brown", (Dennis), 21-22 x 13 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with two droplets, thick-walled, protoplasm granular; asci 8-spored, 300 x 17-19 um, weakly amyloid; paraphyses "slender, tips with slight clavate thickenings with brownish contents"; excipulum of rounded cells 50-60 um across in exterior part, medulla a very loose textura intricata, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  named for Mr. Babington, collector of type
SIMILAR  Pachyella adnata is up to 5cm across, flat, sometimes becoming convoluted, appressed to the substrate, when old sometimes becoming shallow cup-shaped, colored umber to sepia, black when dried; it has spores 18-20 x 10-12(14) um, that are elliptic, distinctly verrucose (with long blunt warts exceeding 1 um long), thin-walled, colorless, and with 1-2 oil droplets. Psilopezia nummularia was reported from WA and ID in Larsen(1) but not confirmed by either author. P. nummularia is barely distinguishable macroscopically, but has a negative iodine reaction in the asci and the excipulum has an exterior of radial, slender, interwoven hyphae and a medulla of textura intricata, (as opposed to A. babingtonii with rounded cells in exterior part, and the medulla a very loose textura intricata), (Breitenbach). Pachyella clypeata "is macroscopically nearly identical" to P. adnata - compared with A. babingtonii it has a larger (0.5-4cm) "reddish brown fruitbody, later tinted olive then greenish-black and without luster" but has smooth spores with 1-2 oil droplets that measure 25-35 x 12-14 um (Beug). It is included in Coulter(2) but presence in the Pacific Northwest needs to be established with herbarium specimens. 
SOURCES  Pfister(1) (as Pachyella), Breitenbach(1)* (as Pachyella), Dennis(1) (as Pachyella), Larsen(1) (as Pachyella), Beug(3) (as Pachyella), Coulter(2) (as Pachyella)
2
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Albotricha albotestacea  (Desm.) Raitv.^  Akad. Nauk Estonskoi S.S.R., Inst. Zool. Bot., Tartu: 40. 1970;  Trichopeziza albotestacea  (Desm.) Sacc.;  Lachnella albotestacea  (Desm.) Quel;  Lachnum albotestaceum  P. Karst.;  Dasyscyphus albotestaceus  (Desm.) Massee
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute fruitbody on grasses and sedges, a pinkish spore-bearing surface, whitish marginal hairs, brick red exterior, and microscopic characters including lanceolate paraphyses.^ | Haines examined 2 collections from Washington state, both of which "differed from the descriptions given by Dennis in being long-stipitate". Haines(1), probably referring to western Washington, said it is not uncommon on grasses and sedges. RANGE ^Albotricha albotestacea is found from NJ to WA, and also in Europe, (Seaver), WA (Kanouse), and Denmark, Finland, and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05cm across, at first rounded then expanding; spore-bearing upper surface flesh-colored^, (Seaver), fruitbody 0.05-0.1cm across, rose, with white hairs at margin, (Hansen), up to 0.05cm across, disc reddish pink, covered by hairs when dry, (Haines)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  brick-red, or reddish brown, fading when old^, (Seaver), "vinaceous-buff" when fresh becoming whitish when old; covered with "vinaceous brown" hairs, (Kanouse, colors from Ridgway), "white to reddish pink, sparsely covered with white or pink appearing hairs," (Haines)
STEM  without stem or with short stem^ (Seaver), stem covered with "vinaceous brown" hairs (Kanouse), 0.05cm x 0.01cm, "smooth or with a few hairs at maturity", (Haines)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered on dead grasses, Phragmites, Andropogon, and undetermined^, (Seaver), on grass, May, (Kanouse), on grasses (Hansen), collections examined on grass and on sedge (Haines)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-10 x 1-2 um, fusoid^; asci 8-spored, cylindric; paraphyses lanceolate; hairs slender, flexuous [wavy], reddish, colorless at tip, (Seaver), spores 7-10 x 1.5-2 um, narrowly fusoid; asci 38-53 x 4-5 um; paraphyses exceeding asci by 20-30 um, 3-4 um wide; marginal hairs 115-185 x 3-5 um, colorless to pale ochraceous, (Hansen), spores 6-9 x 1.5 um; paraphyses very long and sharply pointed, (Kanouse), spores 8-11 x 1.5-2.0 um, fusiform or naviculate [boat-shaped], colorless, "without conspicuous refractive inclusions", non-septate, "obliquely biseriate in the ascus"; asci 8-spored, 40-50 x 4-5 um, cylindric, "with a slightly narrowed stalk"; paraphyses 3.5-4.5 um wide at the widest part, up to 30 um longer than the asci, lanceolate with acute tips, colorless, "thin-walled, not septate or with one or two septa in the lower portion", usually with colorless, sparingly granular contents; hairs up to 150 um long, 5 um wide at the base, tapering toward the tip to 1.5-2.5 um, "often slightly tapered at the base", somewhat flexuous, finely granular the whole length, usually with 2 or 3 septa forming cells 25-40 um long, often brown in lower part, tips colorless, "walls very slightly thickened", (Haines)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'white-testaceous', 'testaceus' indicating an orangy pink or brick color
SIMILAR  The key in Haines(1) for western Washington differentiates Albotricha washingtonensis on the basis that its hairs are less than 50 um long whereas the hairs in A. albotestacea are over 75 um long. Albotricha washingtonensis is known from ferns and is not known to have a reddish color.
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Lachnum albotestaceum), Hansen, L.(1) (as Lachnella albotestacea), Kanouse(6) (as Lachnum albotestaceum), Haines(1)
3
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Albotricha washingtonensis  (Dennis) Raitv.^  Akad. Nauk Estonskoi S.S.R., Inst. Zool. Bot., Tartu: 42. 1970;  Dasyscyphus washingtonensis  Dennis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, translucent-white cups on fern stems, hairs on margin and exterior, absent or inconspicuous stem, and microscopic characters including small rod-like spores and lanceolate paraphyses.^ | Dennis(3) described Dasyscypha washingtonensis from part of the type collection of Hyalopeziza pteridis Kanouse Mycologia 39: 660. 1947 (= Lachnella pteridicola Seaver) - he emphasized the broadly lanceolate (not filiform) paraphyses which would not be consistent with Hyalopeziza, but he did not exclude the remote possibility of a mixed collection. Albotricha washingtonensis is not to be confused with Lachnella pteridis Phill., the name that forced the change of epithet to pteridicola when Seaver moved the species from Hyalopeziza to Lachnella. According to Haines(1), this is a common species in the spring in western Washington, "but it is easily overlooked due to its small size. It is only known from the fern Pteridium aquilinum.". RANGE ^A. washingtonensis was described from WA, and is found also in Europe. There are 2 collections by O. Ceska from BC at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  about 0.03cm across, slightly concave, margin fringed with hairs, (Dennis), 0.1-0.2cm across, "yellowish white, often with a green tinge, with distinctively hairy margin", (Hansen, L.(1))^, fruitbody about 0.02cm across, cup-shaped, translucent white, (Seaver), fruitbody 0.0175-0.02cm across, 0.0075cm high (including base), cup-shaped, translucent, (Kanouse), up to 0.02cm across, up to 0.025cm high, cup-shaped, white (even when dry); appearing bald except for a small fringe of hairs near margin, disc remaining exposed even when dry, (Haines(1))
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white, villose^, (Dennis), hyaline-white from hairs (Kanouse), 
STEM  substipitate^ (Dennis), without a stem to substipitate (Seaver), with a short stem (Haines(1))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  sparse, superficial, (Dennis), on Dryopteris fern (Hansen, L., for northern Europe), single on stems of Pteris sp. (a fern), (Seaver)^, on old stems of Pteris (in another part of the description on fern leaves), (Kanouse), only known from the fern Pteridium aquilinum (bracken fern) [at least in western Washington], common in spring, (Haines(1))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-7 x 0.75-1 um, bacillar, biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 33 x 5 um, cylindro-clavate; paraphyses 55 x 4-5 um, broadly lanceolate [wider in middle and tapered at both ends], apices acute, extending beyond the asci; hairs septate, tapering to an acute tip, thickening at the base to about 5 um, (Dennis), spores 6-8 x 1-1.5 um, clavate to fusoid; asci 27-35 x 4-6 um; paraphyses 4-5 um wide, up to 20 um exceeding the asci; marginal hairs up to 75 um long and 2-2.5 um wide, colorless, (Hansen, L.), spores 4-5.5 x 0.75-1 um, bacilloid; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 30-35 um and a width of 4.5 um; paraphyses filiform; hairs reaching a length of 75 um, and width of 6 um, hyaline-white, rough, (Seaver), spores 4-5.5 x 0.75-1 um, rod-like, straight, colorless, one-celled; asci 8-spored, 30-35 x 4.5 um, cylindric-clavate, spores obliquely arranged in the asci, ascus pore blue with iodine; paraphyses filiform; exciple composed of small prismatic cells from which arise long, rough, colorless, septate hairs 75 um long and 6 um wide at the widest (middle) part, (Kanouse), spores 4-8 x 1-2.5 um, "mostly clavate-fusiform, slightly curved, somewhat variable in shape, size and appearance of contents, often with a variable number of refractive droplets, non-septate or rarely with a single pseudoseptum, irregularly biseriate in the ascus"; asci 8-spored, 4-5 x 20-25 um, colorless, thin-walled, tip slightly conical, pore plug very large but visible only at maturity; paraphyses 30-40 x 3-4 um, exceeding asci by up to 5-10 um, "broadly lanceolate ending in a small slightly rounded tip, non-septate, thin-walled", colorless "with granular appearing contents"; hairs 10-35 x 4-5 um, scarce, "tapering to a fine point at the tip", colorless, sparsely covered with large, irregular granules up to 2 um in diameter, thin-walled, "usually adhering to one another, occurring only near the edge of the cup, multiseptate", septa forming cells 7-10 um long, "often with refractive, granular-appearing contents"; excipulum of thin-walled, colorless, short-cylindric to isodiametric cells up to 10 um long, (Haines(1))
NAME ORIGIN  'washingtonensis' means 'from Washington'; 'pteridis' means 'of Pteris' referring to host
SIMILAR  The key in Haines(1) for western Washington differentiates Albotricha albotestacea on the basis that its hairs are over 75 um long whereas the hairs in A. washingtonensis are less than 50 um long. Albotricha albotestacea is known from grasses and sedges and has a reddish brown fruitbody. On fern habitat, there are several other cup fungi in the Pacific Northwest. O. Ceska deposited Albotricha laetior from British Columbia at the University of British Columbia.
SOURCES  Dennis(3), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6) (Hyalopeziza pteridis), Seaver(2) (Lachnella pteridicola), Haines(1) (as Dasyscyphus washingtonensis)
4
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Aleuria aurantia  (Pers.) Fuckel^  Jahr. Nass. Vereins Naturkunde 23-24: 325. 1870
ENGLISH NAME(S)  orange-peel fungus, orange-peel, orange-peel fungus, orange fairy-cup, great orange elf-cup
NOTES  Aleuria aurantia has bright orange cup-shaped to flattened or distorted thin-fleshed fruitbodies with the exterior downy and paler or whitish, growing in ground especially in areas where the soil is disturbed. It is common in the Pacific Northwest.^ RANGE ^Distribution includes BC, WA, OR, ID, and also AZ and CA, (Larsen), NF to WA, CA, and WV, probably throughout temperate North America, and also Europe, (Seaver), AB, NT, YT, and AK, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), and MA (Perry).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-10cm, soon cup-shaped to saucer-shaped or flattened or wavy or irregularly contorted, margin often wavy or lobed; bright orange fading somewhat when old; more or less smooth^, (Arora), sometimes split so as to simulate an Otidea (Dennis), at first spherical, gradually expanding, finally reaching diameter 5-6cm, though often smaller, "shallow, cup-shaped and usually regular in form when young, becoming irregular and often variously contorted" when old or from mutual pressure, occasionally discoid and rarely one-sided and Otidea-like, (Seaver)
FLESH  thin, brittle or fragile^, (Arora), white (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  pallid or at least paler than upper surface; smooth or minutely downy^, (Arora), covered in fine white down (Phillips), whitish or orange-yellow (Ammirati), whitish, pruinose, (Seaver)
STEM  absent or rudimentary^ (Arora)
ODOR  no clear odor^ (Lincoff(1))
TASTE  no clear taste^ (Lincoff(1))
EDIBILITY  yes (Arora)
HABITAT  scattered to gregarious or in fused clusters on ground, preferring bare soil or sand along roads, paths, landslides, etc., but also in grass or moss^, (Arora), in groups or clusters on hard or disturbed soil in gardens, in grass, or along roadsides, (Phillips), on west coast fruits in spring and fall but most abundant in fall (McKnight), summer and fall (Bacon)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-24 x 9-11 um, elliptic, coarsely reticulate or ridged when mature, typically with 2 oil droplets^, (Arora), spores 14-16 x 10 um (not including ornamentation), elliptic, with distinct coarsely reticulate ornamentation, sometimes with thorn-like processes on ends of spore, colorless, with two small droplets, uniseriate; asci 8-spored, 185-200 x 10-13 um, inamyloid; paraphyses with slight clavate thickening at tip to 6 um, septate, with orange granulation that turns green in iodine, (Breitenbach), spores 17-24 x 9-11 um, elliptic, containing 2 oil droplets, surface ornamented with a coarse reticulum that often projects like an apiculus at each end; asci up to 220 x 13 um; paraphyses slightly clavate, up to 7 um thick at tip which is filled with orange granules that turn green in iodine, (Dennis), spores 18-22 x 9-10 um, at first smooth, finally becoming sculptured with reticulations which are regular in form and shallow, except at the ends of the spores where the ridges project, usually containing 2 large oil-droplets, 1-seriate, usually obliquely arranged in ascus, the ends often overlapping; ascus reaching 175-250 um long and 12-15 um wide, cylindric or nearly so; paraphyses strongly and rather abruptly enlarged at apex, the end often nearly spherical, reaching a diameter or 7-8 um, filled with orange granules, (Seaver), spores 13-24 x 7.5-10 um, (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  means "orange"^ (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
SIMILAR  Caloscypha fulgens is more yellow, typically flushed with green or blue-green on exterior, and grows only in spring whereas Aleuria aurantia fruits in spring and fall, (McKnight). See also SIMILAR section of Pseudaleuria quinaultiana.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Arora(1)*, Trudell(4)*, Phillips(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Lincoff(1)*, Miller(14)*, Seaver(1), Larsen(1), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Courtecuisse(1)*, McKnight(1)*, Ammirati(1)*, Sept(1)*, Perry(2), AroraPocket(1)*, Bacon(1)*, Buczacki(1)*, Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2)*, McBride(1)*, McAdoo(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
5
FAMILY  Stereaceae, Order Russulales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Aleurodiscus grantii  Lloyd^  Mycol. Writ. 6 (Note 62): 927. 1920
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also included in Crusts category. Features include 1) growth on the lower surface of small dead branches on live conifers, 2) disc-shaped or cup-shaped fruitbodies at first 0.1-0.4cm across, sometimes becoming confluent, surface pale orange-pink to pink, with distinct margin ringed with tiny white hairs, the abhymenial surface white, gray, or pale brown and finely hairy or matted, 3) spores large and nearly round to broadly elliptic, with amyloid spines, 4) hymenium of a) basidial elements, b) hyphidia, and c) crystals up to 10 um wide (which also occur in the context), and 5) context monomitic with some septa clamped.^ | Aleurodiscus grantii is more common in the Pacific Northwest than the very similar Aleurodiscus amorphus. RANGE ^Aleurodiscus grantii is found from the Pacific Coast to the eastern foothills of the Rocky Mountains. Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, YT, CA, and MT, (Ginns(16)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  disc-shaped or pezizaeform [shaped like Peziza cup fungus], 0.1-0.4cm across, "scattered to gregarious, sometimes confluent", 0.05-0.1cm thick, surface flat to slightly convex; typically pale orange pink to pink, sometimes faded when old or after storage; finely granulose; margin determinate [distinct], ringed with white, shiny fascicles of hyphal hairs up to 0.02cm long^, (Ginns(16))
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  "white, grey or pale brown, finely hirsute or matted"^, (Ginns(16))
STEM  "attached by a short, central base"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  typically on lower surface of small (1-6cm diameter), dead branches in the lower crown of live conifers, sometimes on trunks of dead saplings or on fallen stems; most often collected on Abies (fir), especially A. grandis (Grand Fir) and A. lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), and less often on other conifers^, (Ginns(16)) 
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 22-32(39) x 18-24(28) um, broadly elliptic to nearly round, with amyloid spines up to 4 um long, wall colorless, acyanophilic, up to 1 um thick, apiculus broad (up to 3 um), blunt^; basidia 4-spored, +/- 230 x 25-28 um, clavate, tapering to a 4 um wide base, with clamp connection, sterigmata up to 21 um long; hyphidia colorless, thin-walled to rather thin-walled, infrequently thick-walled, straight to wavy, unbranched or with up to 4 short branches, cylindric or with the apex irregularly swollen or strangulated, swellings sometimes moniliform, 4-6 um wide; pseudocystidia lacking; crystals: hymenium, subhymenium, and adjacent context "with few to numerous, square to angular crystals up to 10 um wide"; hyphae monomitic, generative hyphae in the context colorless, branched, "thin- to sometimes rather thin-walled, the wall often with a 1.5 um thick gelatinized exterior as viewed in 2% KOH", about 10% of the septa with clamp connections; abhymenial surface "sometimes with hyphae parallel, compact", rather thin-walled to thick-walled, brownish yellow, up to 7 um wide, hyphal "hairs" on the abhymenial surface and the margin 3-5(6) um wide, straight, rarely branched (branching dichotomously), thin-walled to rather thin-walled, simple-septate, (Ginns(16))
NAME ORIGIN  named after Grant, collector of the type
SIMILAR  Aleurodiscus amorphus also has discoid or pezizoid fruitbodies with large, spiny, amyloid spores, but 1) lacks clamp connections (in A. grantii found at about 10% of the septa on the context hyphae, and at the base of nearly all mature basidia), 2) has slightly smaller spores (unusual to find spores over 28 um, whereas A. grantii typically has some spores over 30 um long), and 3) has broad, apically moniliform pseudocystidia (in A. grantii some hyphidia in some specimens have the apical part strangulated to form irregular to moniliform swellings, and these strangulated hyphidia resemble the pseudocystidia of A. amorphus, but they never produce swellings that are as uniformly globose [spherical] or as broad (up to 11 um) as those of A. amorphus), (Ginns(16)).
SOURCES  Ginns(16), Ginns(5)
6
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Anthracobia macrocystis  (Cooke) Boud.^  Hist. Class. Discom. Eur. p.65. 1907
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small reddish orange cup or disc, paler exterior dotted and barred with brown, absent stem, growth on burnt ground, and microscopic characters.^ | Another species, listed for Washington and Alberta by Larsen, is Anthracobia nitida Boud., is probably a synonym of this species. RANGE ^A. macrocystis is found in BC, OR, ID, and CA, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.3cm, cup-shaped to disc-shaped; reddish orange^, (Dennis), 0.1-0.3cm, hemispheric at first then disc-shaped to plate-shaped; orange to reddish orange; the margin dotted with small brownish tufts of hyphae, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  paler than upper surface, dotted and barred with brown towards the margin^, (Dennis), somewhat paler than upper surface and dotted with small brownish tufts of hyphae, (Breitenbach)
STEM  none^ (Dennis, Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on burnt ground, July to October, (Dennis for UK), gregarious to crowded on burned ground (Breitenbach for Switzerland)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-18 x 7-8 um, oblong-elliptic, smooth, with two oil drops^; asci up to 200 x 15 um; paraphyses slender, clavate, enlarged to 7 um wide at tips; at the margin, "surface cells are subglobose with thin brown walls and bear short, broad, thin-walled, 1-2-celled hairs, a few up to 70 x 23 um, the majority only 1-celled and about 25 x 15 um", (Dennis), spores 16-18 x 8-9 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 2 droplets; asci 8-spored, 160 x 15 um; paraphyses cylindric, septate, tips thickened to 7 um wide; hairs (clavate hyphal outgrowths) 25-60 x 10-15 um, 1-celled or 2-celled, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Anthracobia melaloma is a more yellowish ochraceous shade of orange, paraphyses do not stain green in Melzer's reagent, and hairs have several septa (in A. macrocystis they are more rudimentary short hairs with only one septum). Pyronema omphalodes does not have tufts of hair on exterior, is more or less confluent rather than just crowded, is more pink in color, and has a conspicuous white cobwebby subiculum.
SOURCES  Dennis(1), Breitenbach(1)*, Hansen, L.(1), Larsen(1), Buczacki(1)*
7
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Anthracobia melaloma  (Alb. & Schwein. ex Fr.) Boud.^  Hist. Class. Discom. d'Europe: 65. 1907
ENGLISH NAME(S)  burn site ochre cup
NOTES  Features include cup-shaped to disc-shaped, orange, stemless fruitbody, paler exterior that has bunches of brown downy hairs, growth on burned wood and burned ground, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Anthracobia melaloma is found in BC, WA, OR, ID, CA, and CO, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.5cm, cup-shaped, disc concave then flattened; ochraceous orange^, (Dennis), 0.1-0.3cm, hemispheric when young, then disc-shaped to plate-shaped; orange to pale orange; margin appearing somewhat furfuraceous, (Breitenbach), 0.2-1.2cm, yellowish ochraceous, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  slightly paler than upper surface, "dotted brown with the bunches of downy hairs, particularly towards the margin and hence often appearing striate when dried"^, (Dennis), lighter than upper surface and darkly punctate with tufts of appressed hairs, (Breitenbach), pale brownish, with brownish hairs, (Hansen)
STEM  none^ (Dennis, Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on burnt wood and sites of bonfires^, July to January (Dennis for UK), gregarious on burned ground and charred wood (Breitenbach for Switzerland), clustered or crowded, often in broad masses, (Lincoff)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-22 x 7-11 um, oblong-elliptic, smooth, with two oil drops^; asci up to 200 x 15 um; paraphyses slender, clavate at tips and up to 6 um wide; hairs "up to 110 x 10 um, cylindrical, obtuse, septate, with thin, smooth, light brown walls", (Dennis), spores 16-17.5 x 8-9 um, narrowly elliptic, smooth, with 2 droplets; asci 8-spored, 160-190 x 11-12 um, inamyloid; paraphyses slender, cylindric, septate, thickened at tips to 6 um wide; hairs up to 80 x 13 um, smooth, multiseptate, thin-walled, slightly brownish, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Anthracobia macrocystis is a more bright reddish shade of orange, paraphyses stain green in Melzer's reagent, and hairs are more rudimentary and short with only one septum. Pyronema omphalodes does not have tufts of hair on exterior, is more or less confluent rather than just crowded, is more pink in color, and has a conspicuous white cobwebby subiculum.
SOURCES  Dennis(1), Breitenbach(1)*, Hansen, L.(1), Seaver(1) (as Patella melaloma), Lincoff(2)*, Larsen(1), Courtecuisse(1)*
8
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascobolus albidus  P. Crouan & H. Crouan^  Annls. Sci. Nat., Bot., ser. 4 10:1-6. 1858
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, top-shaped to cylindric fruitbody that is whitish with blackish dots on upper surface, base that is yellowish brown without a stem, growth on dung, and microscopic characters, including purplish spores with occasionally anastomosing lines on surface.^ RANGE ^Ascobolus albidus is found at least in WA, AK, WY, (Larsen), Denmark, Norway, Iceland, Sweden, Finland, (Hansen), and ON, CT, MA, ME, WY, Greenland, Belgium, Bulgaria, Czech Republic, France, Germany, Iceland, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Sweden, and the United Kingdom, (Brummelen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.03-0.1(0.15)cm across, fruiting body 0.04-0.08cm high, "at first closed, subcylindrical or barrel-shaped, then obconical, cylindrical with an obconical base or urceolate", white, more or less translucent, finally often entirely yellowish brown, rarely blackish brown or brownish; spore-bearing upper surface flat, white, dotted with protruding tips of asci; margin not differentiated^, (Brummelen), 0.03-0.1cm across, obconic, disc flat; "dingy ochraceous with a few blackish asci protruding", (Dennis), 0.04-0.06mm broad, up to 0.1cm high, turbinate to cylindric; whitish, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white to orange; smooth^, (Dennis)
STEM  sessile [without a stem] on a narrow base, base pale yellowish brown^ (Brummelen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered or gregarious, superficial, on dung of cow, horse, sheep, goat, moose, dog, wolf, rabbit, hare and muskrat^, (Brummelen), "on dung, especially that of cow but also that of horse, sheep and rabbit, throughout the year", (Dennis), on dung of herbivores (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (18)20-36(39) x (9)11-14(16) um, elliptic-oblong, "usually with longitudinal occasionally anastomosing striae, sometimes with short more or less curved striate", "with thick transparent, unilateral, gelatinous cap", spore color at first colorless then pale violet, finally violet, biseriate^; asci 8-spored, (160)300-410 x 26-38 um, cylindric-clavate, gradually narrowing downwards, rounder at top, ascal wall deep blue in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses 1.7-3.2 um thick, 1.0-4.7 um at tip, cylindric, slightly clavate, filiform [thread-like] or forked in upper part, branched, colorless, septate, embedded in a colorless mucus that quickly dissolves in water; hypothecium very thin or not clearly differentiated, of isodiametric cells 5-12 um across; context very thin, up to 100 um thick, of rounded elongated cells 7-19 x 5-8 um, colorless; excipulum in upper part 7-13 um wide, near base 20-39 um wide, "of isodiametric or slightly elongated, rounded or angular cells 14-43 x 8-29 um (mostly textura angularis)", colorless, (Brummelen), spores 20-23 x 11-14 um, elliptic, "violet, ornamented with rather close anastomosing striae; paraphyses slender, up to 5 um thick at the tip", (Dennis), spores 25.5-29.5 x 12-13.5 um, elliptic, with more or less parallel striae that sometimes anastomose, purplish, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "albidus" meaning "whitish"^, (Brummelen)
SIMILAR  Ascobolus sacchariferus has spores 16.5-20.5 x 8.5-10.5 um and a fruiting body that is clearly developed, with fine white granules.
SOURCES  Brummelen(1), Larsen(1), Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1)
9
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascobolus carbonarius  P. Karst.^  Fungi Fenniae no. 463. 1866
ENGLISH NAME(S)  burn site shield cup
NOTES  Features include cup-shaped to saucer-shaped fruitbodies that are yellowish green then brownish to blackish, dotted with protruding asci, the exterior somewhat lighter in color and finely mealy or scaly, margin that is weakly scurfy-notched, absent stem, growth on burned ground or charcoal, and microscopic characters including warted spores that are colorless to purplish.^ RANGE ^Ascobolus carbonarius is found at least in BC, OR, CA, and AB, (Larsen). Collections were examined from OR, MB, PQ, CT, IA, IN, MI, ME, NC, NY, OH, PA, TN, VA, WI, WV, Costa Rica, Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, and Uganda, (Brummelen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.5cm across, up to 0.1cm high, at first nearly spherical, then scutellate, finally flattened, disc concave, then flat, yellowish green, more brownish when old, dotted with black protruding tips of asci, finally almost black; margin crenulate [scalloped], finally almost smooth and blunt^, (Brummelen), 0.2-0.5(0.8)cm across, cup-shaped when young, later flat and saucer-shaped; orange to olive-yellow, quickly becoming dark olive-brown to blackish and rough because of projecting asci; margin weakly scurfy-notched, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  greenish yellow, becoming more brownish when old, finally blackish brown; finely mealy or scaly^, (Brummelen), somewhat lighter in color than spore-bearing upper surface and furfuraceous, (Breitenbach)
STEM  none^ (Brummelen, Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or crowded on charcoal, burnt vegetable debris, and burnt soil, rarely on humid soil without remnants of a fire^, (Brummelen), sometimes single but usually gregarious to crowded, on burned ground, March to August, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17.5-25(27.5) x (11.5)13-14.5 um (including pigment), elliptic, with pointed ends when immature and with truncate ends when mature (with pigment), rarely swollen, at first colorless, then dark violet, finally dark purplish brown, "ornamented with irregular or rounded, isolated warts varying considerably in size", "pigment in a very thick layer, at the sides 1.5-2.7 um thick, at the ends 2.4-3.1 um thick", spores uniseriate in ascus, finally more or less biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 190-270 x 22-26 um, cylindric-clavate, narrowing downwards, rounded at top, only when young the wall pale blue in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses about 2 um thick, cylindric, septate, occasionally branched, not or scarcely thickened in upper part, up to 3.5 um thick at tip, embedded in yellowish green mucus, (Brummelen), 22-23 x 13-14 um (not including warts), broadly elliptic, warty, warts projecting up to 1 um, (thickened warts at poles not seen), violet-brown when mature; asci 8-spored, 150-230 x 13-22 um, amyloid; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], septate, forked, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  "from Latin, carbonarius, pertaining to charcoal"^, (Brummelen)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Brummelen(1), Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Lincoff(2)*, Seaver(1), Larsen(1)
10
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascobolus crenulatus  P. Karst.^  Fungi Fenn. No. 763. 1868
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, top-shaped to cushion-shaped, green-yellow fruitbodies with dark dots on the spore-bearing upper surface, scurfy exterior and scalloped margin both of the same color as the upper surface, no stem, growth on dung and sometimes on rotten plant material, and microscopic characters including relatively small spores that become brown-violet with light-colored longitudinal anastomosing ribs.^ RANGE ^Ascobolus crenulatus is found at least in ID (Larsen), and ON, PQ, CT, FL, GA, MA, NH, NJ, NY, VA, WI, Belgium, Czech Republic, Finland, Netherlands, United Kingdom, and Australia, (Brummelen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.2cm, turbinate [top-shaped] when young, then disc-shaped to cushion-like; green-yellow when young, then olive-yellow and dotted dark brown by projecting asci; margin furfuraceous^, (Breitenbach), fruitbody 0.03-0.18cm across, 0.02-0.09cm high, at first nearly spherical and closed, then opening and expanding to hemispheric; spore-bearing upper surface concave then flat, greenish yellow, dotted with dark purplish tips of asci; prominent crenulate [scalloped] margin, (Brummelen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  the same color as upper surface; scurfy^, (Breitenbach), greenish yellow or pale olive-green, "coarsely or finely furfuraceous or granulated, especially near the margin, rarely almost smooth", (Brummelen)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach), without a stem, or rarely substipitate, (Brummelen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious on dung of various animals, such as deer, dogs, and goats, principally in winter months^, (Breitenbach), gregarious, superficial on "dung of grouse, pheasant, partridge, pigeon, raven, deer, porcupine, fox, dog, and rabbit, but also on paper saturated with dog urine, on rotten leaves of oak and on rotten leaves and stalks of herbs", (Brummelen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-16 x 8-9 um, elliptic, colorless when young, "then brown violet, ornamented with 5-6 light-colored and in part anastomosing longitudinal ribs"^; asci 8-spored, 135-15 x 14-19 um, inamyloid; paraphyses slender, septate, tips with slight clavate thickenings, (Breitenbach), spores (8)9.5-15(16) x (5)6-8 um, elliptic or short-elliptic with rather blunt ends, sometimes swollen, "ornamented with a rather regular pattern of longitudinal, rarely anastomosing striae, sometimes with unilateral mucilaginous substance", first colorless, then pale violet, finally brownish violet, uniseriate, when mature biseriate; asci 8-spored, 125-150 x 13-15 um, cylindric-clavate, narrowing downward into rather long stem, rounded at top, the wall pale blue in Melzer's reagent only when young; paraphyses 2-3.5 um wide, cylindric, 2.0-10.5 um wide at tip, simple or branched, septate, sometimes swollen just under the septa, colorless, the upper part enlarged, narrowed, forked, regular or irregular, embedded in abundant yellowish green mucus; context "of varying thickness, of isodiametric or oblong cells 4.5-20 x 4.5-14 um", colorless; excipulum "15-30(65) um thick, of globular, subangular or oblong rather thick-walled cells 7-30(40) x 7-20 um (textura globulosa or angularis)", the walls pale yellowish; margin consisting of fragments of excipular layer covered with groups of nearly spherical cells 20-37 um across, (Brummelen)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin 'crenulatus', diminutive of 'crenatus', meaning 'notched'; means 'crenulate' (finely scalloped)
SIMILAR  Ascobolus michaudii has different color and larger spores, (Brummelen).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Seaver(1) (as Ascobolus viridulus), Larsen(1), Brummelen(1)
11
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascobolus foliicola  Berk. & Broome^  J. Linn. Soc., Bot. 14: 109. 1873
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include cup-shaped to scutellate fruitbody with spore-bearing upper surface greenish yellow then brownish and dotted with blackish protruding asci, greenish yellow exterior with reddish brown furfuraceous particles, prominent furfuraceous margin, clearly developed stem, growth on rotten vegetable debris, and microscopic characters including spores that become purplish with lighter longitudinal lines.^ RANGE ^Ascobolus foliicola is found at least in OR, CO, and CA, (Larsen). Collections were examined from OR, CA, MA, NY, VA, MB, ON, Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, France, Germany, Portugal, United Kingdom, Yugoslavia, and Sri Lanka, (Brummelen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.5cm across, 0.05-0.1cm high, at first closed and nearly spherical, then opening at top and becoming cup-shaped, finally expanded and scutellate, disc concave when young, later flat or slightly wavy, greenish yellow, then brownish, dotted with almost black protruding tips of asci; margin prominent, sometimes curved back against substrate when old
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  greenish yellow, with reddish brown furfuraceous particles or warts regularly distributed over surface
STEM  short stem attached more or less centrally^, (Brummelen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or gregarious on rotten leaves, stems, wood and bark of plants^, (Brummelen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15.5-22 x 8-11.5 um, elliptic with rounded or obtuse ends, with strong tendency to swell, at first colorless then violet, finally purplish brown, ornamented with lighter longitudinal anastomosing lines, when swollen often with reticulating [networking] lines, spores biseriate in ascus^; asci 8-spored, 170-200 x 18-20 um, cylindric-clavate, narrowing downwards, rounded at top, the wall not, or scarcely blue in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses about 2 um thick, branched, septate, cylindric, clavate or irregularly swollen to 5 um thick at tip, colorless, embedded in greenish-yellow mucus, (Brummelen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'inhabiting leaves'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Brummelen(1), Seaver(1) (as Ascobolus striisporus), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1)
12
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascobolus geophilus  Seaver^  Mycologia 8: 96. 1916
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small fruitbodies with concave to flat spore-bearing upper surface that is greenish yellow becoming dark brown to blackish and roughened by protruding asci; greenish yellow furfuraceous exterior that becomes more brownish; absent stem; growth on humid soil or mud-covered bark; and microscopic characters including spores that become purplish with granular then reticulated pattern.^ RANGE ^Ascobolus geophilus is found at least in OR, ID, CO, (Larsen), and WA (Kanouse). Collections were specimens examined from OR, CO, NE, NY, VA, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, France, Italy, Poland, and the United Kingdom, and reported from India, (Brummelen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.5(1)cm, 0.05-0.08cm high; at first nearly spherical, then expanding and scutellate or discoid, disc slightly concave, then flat, greenish yellow, finally dark brown to almost black, roughened by protruding tips of asci; margin often smooth and eroded
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  greenish yellow, more brownish when old; finely furfuraceous, especially near base^, (Brummelen)
STEM  on a broad base, without a stem^, (Brummelen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered, gregarious or crowded on humid soil, especially when covered with algae, also on bark of a tree covered with mud^, (Brummelen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (17)19-22.5(24) x (9)9.5-13 um, elliptic, often in part swollen, at first colorless, then violet, finally dark purplish brown, "at first smooth or extremely finely granular, then with a pattern of very short, fine fissures in all directions, finally often reticulated or warted, pigment in a rather thick layer, 1.0-1.5(1.7) um thick", uniseriate, finally often more or less biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 160-200 x 17-20 um, cylindric-clavate, narrowing downwards, rounded at top, the wall not, or scarcely blue in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um thick, filiform [thread-like], simple or branched, septate, colorless, scarcely thickened in upper part, embedded in yellowish mucus that becomes brownish when old, (Brummelen), asci 8-spored but often with only 4 spores developed (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'earth-loving'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Brummelen(1), Seaver(1), Larsen(1), Tylutki(2), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6)
13
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascobolus immersus  Pers. ex Pers.^  in Neues Mag. Bot. 1: 115. 1794
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Ascobolus immersus is a common species on herbivore dung. It grows more or less immersed, with a yellow or greenish yellow disc, and is recognized by the very large spores with a thick glutinous envelope surrounding each spore.^ RANGE ^It is found at least in BC, CO, and AZ, (Larsen). Collections were examined from OR, ON, PQ, AZ, CO, CT, HI, IA, MA, ME, NJ, NY, VA, Argentina, Bermuda, Brazil, Puerto Rico, Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, France, Finland, Germany, Iceland, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Poland, Switzerland, United Kingdom, India, Pakistan, Australia, and New Guinea, (Brummelen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  subcylindric or hemispheric, immersed in dung up to the margin, disc up to 0.1cm across, flat or convex, disc "yellow or greenish, with only a few protruding asci"^, (Dennis), 0.05-0.1(0.15)cm across, 0.05-0.07cm high, at first immersed or partially immersed, then erumpent or superficial, spherical or pear-shaped, "at first closed, then irregularly opening near the top", without margin, disc flat or convex; disc yellow or greenish yellow, "with only a few ripe asci protruding far above the surface", these easily visible with a hand lens as black spike-like protuberances; smooth or covered with thin layer of downy colorless hyphae, more rarely somewhat furfuraceous, (Brummelen), not exceeding 0.1-0.2cm across, at first immersed or partly immersed, expanding and becoming subturbinate [somewhat top-shaped], spore-bearing upper surface flat or more often convex, similar in color to exterior, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  outer surface may be covered by a thin layer of appressed hyphae but there are no distinct hairs^, (Dennis), yellowish brown or greenish brown or yellowish, "rarely with a reddish or purplish hue", (Brummelen), greenish yellow, becoming brownish (Seaver)
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in dung of cow and many other animals, especially in fall^, (Dennis), scattered or gregarious on dung of cow, horse, sheep, goat, dog, hare, rabbit, (Brummelen), scattered or thickly gregarious, but not usually crowded, on dung of various kinds, especially after it has weathered for a long time, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores mostly 50-75 x 25-40 um, oblong-elliptic, "smooth or with one or very few longitudinal splits in the epispore, surrounded by a thick, colourless gelatinous envelope", violaceous then brown^; asci 1-40 per fruitbody, up to 8-spored, up to 700 x 130 um; paraphyses slender, up to 3 um wide, colorless, embedded in yellow mucus, (Dennis), spores (35)58-71(81) x (24)28-36(40) um, oblong-elliptic, more rarely cylindric or nearly round, rounded at ends, "smooth or with one or a few lines which occasionally anastomose", sometimes with a coarse or fine network of narrow lines, a thick gelatinous envelope surrounding each spore, spores at first colorless, then purple or violet, finally sometimes purplish brown, spores biseriate or irregularly disposed; asci 8-spored (but often with only a part of the spores developed), 1-40 per fruitbody, 490-720 x 100-130 um, with short stem, rounded at top, walls amyloid; paraphyses filiform, 2-3 um wide, simple or branched, septate, not enlarged at tip, colorless, embedded in abundant greenish yellow mucus, (Brummelen)
NAME ORIGIN  "from Latin, immersus, plunged, below the surface"^, (Brummelen)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Brummelen(1), Seaver(1), Dennis(1), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1)
14
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascobolus lignatilis  Alb. & Schwein. ex Pers.^  Mycol. eur. 1: 342. 1822
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a yellow to greenish yellow fruitbody with a flat disc dotted with blackish protruding tips of asci, exterior with white, irregular, furfuraceous particles, long stem, growth on rotten debris and dung, and microscopic characters including spores that become purplish with lighter longitudinal lines.^ RANGE ^Ascobolus lignatilis is found in OR, (according to Larsen, but not included in the PezWeb preliminary checklist of North American Pezizales which emphasizes western species). Collections were examined from MA, Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Netherlands, Poland, and the United Kingdom, (Brummelen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  (0.2)0.5-1.2cm across, up to 0.5cm high, at first closed and subglobose [nearly spherical] or cylindric, then opening and becoming scutellate or cyathiform, finally flattened, disc flat, finally sometimes slightly convex, dingy yellowish-green to yellowish, dotted with almost black protruding tips of asci; margin prominent, rather thin, finally often slightly curved outward, at first often slightly crenulate [scalloped] or fimbriate [fringed]^, (Brummelen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  dingy yellow to greenish yellow; furfuraceous^, (Brummelen)
STEM  distinct, often broadening at base; furrowed or furfuraceous^, (Brummelen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered or gregarious on rotten wood, branches or leaves, on manure heap, on rotten straw and old paper, on humus in a hothouse, on owl-pellets, on dung of cows and humans, and on all kinds of substrates that have been dirtied or mixed with dung or urine^, (Brummelen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-19.5 x 8.5-10 um, when swollen reaching 22 x 13 um, elliptic to fusiform-elliptic, with blunt ends, at first colorless, then violet, finally sometimes purplish brown, "ornamented with subparallel, usually longitudinal lines, that only occasionally anastomose, more or less reticulated when swollen", biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 160-230 x 16-20 um, clavate, gradually narrowing downward, rounded at top, wall amyloid; paraphyses "simple or branched, septate, cylindrical, 1.5-2.5 um thick, clavate or irregularly swollen to 6 um thick at the tip", embedded in greenish yellow mucus, (Brummelen)
NAME ORIGIN  "from Latin, lignatilis, pertaining to wood"^, (Brummelen)
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Ascobolus stercorarius.
SOURCES  Larsen(1), Brummelen(1), PezWeb(1) (does not include)
15
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascobolus michaudii  Boud.^  Hist. Class. Discom. Eur. 71. 1907
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, yellow fruitbodies that are scurfy on the exterior, short or inconspicuous stem, growth on dung, and microscopic characters including spores that become violet to brownish, ornamented by longitudinal lighter lines.^ RANGE ^Ascobolus michaudii is found at least in BC (Larsen). Collections were examined from ON, Czechoslovakia, France, Netherlands, and Poland, (Brummelen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.07-0.25cm across, 0.08-0.2cm high, at first closed, spherical, barrel-shaped or cylindric, then opening and expanding, finally more or less obconic or with short stem, disc concave or flat, finally slightly convex; yellow or greenish yellow, dotted with the purplish black protruding tips of asci; margin dentate or mealy, finally almost smooth^, (Brummelen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  yellow or lemon-yellow; "covered with very small whitish grains, mealy or scurfy, rarely almost smooth"^, (Brummelen)
STEM  "substipitate or with a short stalk"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or scattered on dung of cow, horse, and rabbit^, (Brummelen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17-22 x 9.5-12 um, elliptic, "ornamented with more or less longitudinal or oblique, rather widely spread, rarely anastomosing lines", with unilateral mucilaginous substance, at first colorless then pale or dark violet, finally sometimes brownish, uniseriate at first, finally biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 180-280 x 22-26 um, clavate-cylindric, gradually narrowing downwards, rounded at top, walls amyloid; paraphyses 2.2-3.5(7) um wide, cylindric or clavate, "enlarged, narrowed or forked above, at the apex 1.5-12 um thick", simple or branched, septate, colorless, embedded in abundant greenish-yellow mucus, (Brummelen)
NAME ORIGIN  "after Monsieur Michaud"^, (Brummelen)
SIMILAR  Ascobolus crenulatus has a yellowish green spore-bearing surface and smaller spores, (Hansen).
SOURCES  Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1), Brummelen(1)
16
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascobolus sacchariferus  Brumm.^  Persoonia Suppl. 1: 122. 1967
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small, saucer-shaped fruitbody with a white spore-bearing upper surface dotted with violet protruding tips of asci, white exterior covered with fine white granules especially at the margin, growth on dung, and microscopic characters including spores that become violet with lighter longitudinal anastomosing striae.^ RANGE ^Ascobolus sacchariferus is found at least in BC, WA, CA, (Larsen), and Denmark, Norway, Sweden, and Finland, (Hansen), and was examined from the Netherlands (Brummelen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.07-0.17cm across, 0.05-0.08cm high, at first closed and spherical, then opening at top and hemispheric, finally high saucer-shape; disc concave then flat, white, dotted with the violet protruding tips of asci; margin narrow, clearly developed, with fine white granules^, (Brummelen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white, finally darkened by the adhering spores; covered regularly with fine white granules especially at margin^, (Brummelen)
STEM  none^ (Brummelen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered on dung of deer^ (Brummelen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-20 x 9-10 um, elliptic, at first colorless then violet, ornamented with lighter "longitudinal, anastomosing striae with strongly swelling (up to 19 x15 um), unilateral, gelatinous cap", at first uniseriate, finally biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 190-226 x 16-24 um, cylindric-clavate, with slightly curved stem, rounded at top, when young wall amyloid; paraphyses 1.5-2.5 um thick, cylindric, simple or branched, septate, forked, swollen or irregular in upper part, 2.5-7 um wide at tip, colorless, embedded in somewhat granular colorless mucus, (Brummelen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'sugar-bearing'
SIMILAR  Ascobolus albidus has spores 25.5-29.5 x 12-13.5 um.
SOURCES  Brummelen(1), Larsen(1) (as Ascobolus sacchariferus van Brumm.), Hansen, L.(1)
17
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascobolus stercorarius  (Bull. ex St.-Amans) J. Schroet.^  in Cohn, Krypt.-Fl. Schlesien (Breslau) 3.2(12): 56 (1893) [1908];  Ascobolus furfuraceus  Pers.  Neues Mag. Bot. 1: 115 (1794)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small cup-shaped to cushion-shaped yellow to green yellow fruitbodies that become dark brown, scurfy exterior and margin that are lighter in color, growth on dung, especially of cow, and microscopic characters including elliptic spores ornamented by 7-9 anastomosing light colored lines.^ | Van Brummelen gives Ascobolus stercorarius (Bull. per St. Amans) Schroet. as a synonym, and the online Species Fungorum, accessed November 3, 2013, gave the latter as the valid name with Ascobolus furfuraceus Pers. as a synonym. On the other hand Dennis says Ascobolus stercorarius (Bull. ex St.-Amans) J. Schroet. emend. Olive may be distinguished from Ascobolus furfuraceus Pers. ex Fr. by the former's shorter spores 17-22 x 9.5-12.5 um on which about 5-7 freely anastomosing striae are visible at one time. RANGE ^Ascobolus stercorarius is found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, CA, and CO, (Larsen for A. furfuraceus Pers. ex Pers.). Collections of A. furfuraceus Pers. per Hook. were examined from OR, ID, AL, CA, CO, CT, DC, FL, GA, IA, MA, ME, MO, MT, NC, NE, NH, NY, OH, OK, PA, SC, TN, WY, Bermuda, Greenland, Argentina, Chile, Venezuela, Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Monaco, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, India, Pakistan, Algeria, Madagascar, and Australia, (Brummelen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.3(0.5)cm, cup-shaped becoming flat and disc-shaped to slightly cushion-like; sulphur-yellow to green-yellow when young, later increasingly violet-brown to black-brown or olive-brown (because of darkening spores); smooth becoming rougher (because of projecting asci); margin slightly projecting, lighter in color than spore-bearing surface and finely scurfy^, (Breitenbach), 0.05-0.5cm across, 0.04-0.08cm high, at first closed and spherical, then opening and hemispheric or cup-shaped, finally saucer-shaped, disc slightly concave or flat; at first yellowish, greenish or yellowish green, dotted with almost black protruding tips of asci, finally often brownish or blackish brown; margin "furfuraceous, denticulated, membranaceous or smooth", (Brummelen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  lighter in color than upper surface; finely scurfy^, (Breitenbach), yellowish green or yellowish, often becoming olive-green, ochraceous, or brownish; "wholly or partially, coarsely or finely, whitish furfuraceous, almost smooth or smooth", (Brummelen)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach, Brummelen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  sometimes single, but usually gregarious to crowded on dung, principally of cow^, (Breitenbach), single or gregarious on dung of cow, horse, deer, goat, bear, pig, fox, rabbit, and hare, on manured soil, on rotten refuse, and on rotten stems of cabbage, (Brummelen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 23-26 x 10-14 um, elliptic, colorless when young and surrounded with a gelatinous sheath, "violet-brown when mature and ornamented with 7-9 anastomosing light-colored longitudinal ribs"^, asci 8-spored, 200-220 x 20-22 um, amyloid; paraphyses "slender, septate, with slight clavate thickenings to 8 um at the tips", (Breitenbach), spores (16)19-28(32) x (9)10-14(16) um, elliptic, "ornamented with more or less longitudinal, occasionally anastomosing striae, rarely swollen and reticulated, with unilateral mucilaginous substance", at first colorless then violet, finally often purplish brown, when mature biseriate or irregularly disposed; asci 8-spored, (120)180-250 x (20)24-30(32) um, clavate, walls amyloid, narrowing downward into rather short stem, rounded at top; paraphyses filiform, 2-4 um thick, "usually scarcely thickened above, only very rarely with ellipsoid, strongly swollen cells up to 21 um thick", simple or branched, septate, embedded in yellowish or yellowish green mucus, (Brummelen), spores 22-28 x 12-13 um, elliptic, ornamented with longitudinal occasionally anastomosing lines, about 8 or 9 of which are visible on each view of the spore, spores violet then brown; paraphyses slender, embedded in yellow mucus, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  "from Latin, furfuraceus, scurfy"
SIMILAR  Ascobolus lignatilis differs by stemmed fruitbodies and smaller spores on the average, (13)16-18(21) x 8-9(10) um, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Brummelen(1) (as Ascobolus furfuraceus), Breitenbach(1)* (as Ascobolus furfuraceus), Dennis(1) (as Ascobolus furfuraceus and Ascobolus stercorarius), Seaver(1), Tylutki(2) (as Ascobolus furfuraceus), Kanouse(6), Larsen(1) (as Ascobolus furfuraceus), Desjardin(6)*
18
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascobolus viridis  Curr.^  in Trans. Linn. Soc. London 24: 154 1(1863)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a disc-shaped to saucer-shaped fruitbody with a furfuraceous margin and yellowish green yellow spore-bearing surface dotted with blackish protruding tips of asci; greenish to brownish, furfuraceous underside; growth on soil from summer to fall; and spores that become purplish with anastomosing lines.^ RANGE ^Ascobolus viridis is found at least in OR (Larsen(1), H. Larsen pers. comm.). Brummelen says it is not known from North America, and Seaver says it was not known from America at the time he wrote. It is found in Denmark, Norway, Sweden, and Finland, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-0.6cm, "disc-shaped with distinct furfuraceous margin"; greenish yellow spore-bearing upper surface^, (Hansen), up to 0.5cm, saucer-shaped, disc concave or flat; dingy yellowish-green with prominent crenulate margin, (Dennis), 0.3-0.6(0.8)cm across, 0.1-0.2cm high, cup-shaped then scutellate, disc slightly concave or flat, yellowish green, finally more olive-brown, dotted with almost black protruding tips of asci; margin not very prominent, but furfuraceous, (Brummelen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  greenish, becoming pale brownish; furfuraceous^, (Hansen), light brown; coarsely mealy, (Dennis), yellowish green, finally more olive-brown, coarsely brownish furfuraceous, (Brummelen)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered or gregarious on humid soil, especially in woods^, (Brummelen), on rich soil, often only one or two fruiting bodies, summer to fall, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 28.5-33 x 10.5-13.5 um, fusoid (spindle-shaped), "purplish with short, narrow ridges and anastomosing striae"^, (Hansen), spores 30-35 x 13-15 um, markedly fusiform, violaceous, "ornamented with repeatedly anastomosing or reticulating striae; paraphyses somewhat clavate, up to 10 um thick at the tip, embedded in yellowish-green mucus", (Dennis), spores (23.5)28.5-37.5 x (10)11-14 (exceptionally up to 52 x 24) um, fusiform or elliptic with strongly pointed ends; at first colorless, then violet, ornamented with long or short longitudinal ridges of pigment, pigment up to 2 um thick, finally biseriate; asci 8-spored, 240-350 x 23-30 um, cylindric-clavate, narrowing downwards, rounded at top, only when young the wall blue in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses 2.5-3.1 um, cylindric, simple or branched, septate, colorless, "swollen to 7 um thick at tip, embedded in yellowish green or pale greenish mucus", (Brummelen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'green'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Larsen(1), Brummelen(1), Dennis(1), Seaver(1), Hansen, L.(1), PezWeb (does not include)
19
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascocoryne cylichnium  (Tul.) Korf^  in Phytologia 21: 202. 1971
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly category. Features include top-shaped to disc-shaped or cup-shaped fruitbody that is purple to pink and gelatinous, stem lacking or short, tightly clustered growth on wood, and microscopic characters including ascospores 18-30 um long that are multiseptate. Breitenbach & Kranzlin say it can be separated from Ascocoryne sarcoides only by the spore size.^ | The same macroscopic description is given for both species, word for word (Breitenbach). It is common in the Pacific Northwest (Phillips). RANGE ^Phillips says in the North American context "Found in the Pacific Northwest and probably other areas." It is also found in Denmark, Norway, Sweden, and Finland, (Hansen), and Switzerland, (Breitenbach).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-1(2)cm across, spherical when young then turbinate [top-shaped] to cup-shaped or disc-shaped, or cushion-like with central depression, usually irregularly undulating, spore-bearing upper surface flesh-pink to violet-pink, smooth to somewhat wrinkled when mature^, (Breitenbach), up to 2cm wide, "lobed or irregularly cup-shaped with a flattened or concave disc; dark reddish brown or purplish brown; moist, slimy, minutely scurfy", (Phillips), 0.6-3cm, disc-shaped to turbinate [top-shaped], purplish, (Hansen)
FLESH  gelatinous^ (Breitenbach)
UNDERSIDE  the same color as upper surface and smooth^, (Breitenbach)
STEM  none or very short^ (Breitenbach, Phillips)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  usually in tight clusters, forming a surface sometimes as large as a hand, rarely single; on rotting branches and trunks of trees on ground, as well as stumps^, (Breitenbach), "clustered on stumps and fallen logs", (Phillips), on old stumps, often among mosses, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-24 x 5.5-6 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with several septa when ripe, often with small secondary spores, with droplets when young^; asci 8-spored, 209-220 x 10-12, biseriate, amyloid; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], tips with clavate thickening up to 4 um, (Breitenbach), spores 18-30 x 4-6 um, fusoid [spindle-shaped], "multiseptate and bud off secondary spores while still in the ascus"; ascus 200-220 x 10-12 um, (Phillips), spores 18-30 x 4-6 um, becoming multiseptate and budding off spherical secondary spores while still in the ascus, (Dennis), spores 18-33 x 4-6 um, narrowly elliptic, multiseptate, often developing small globose conidia already in the ascus, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  from 'kylichne', Greek for 'small cup'
SIMILAR  Ascocoryne sarcoides has smaller spores 10-19 x 3-5 um and according to Dennis often has smaller fruiting bodies. See also SIMILAR sections of A. sarcoides and Ascocoryne striata.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Phillips(1)*, Hansen, L.(1), Dennis(1)
20
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascocoryne sarcoides  (Jacq.) J.W. Groves & D.E. Wilson^  Taxon 16(1): 40. 1967;  Coryne sarcoides  (Jacq.) Tul. & C. Tul.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  purple jelly-drops
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly category. Features include a top-shaped to disc-shaped or cup-shaped fruitbody that is purple to pink and gelatinous, stem that is lacking or short, tightly clustered growth on wood, and microscopic characters including ascospores 10-19 um long that are nonseptate to 1-septate.^ | Breitenbach(1) say it can be separated from Ascocoryne cylichnium only by the spore size, and gives the same macroscopic description for both species, word for word. Breitenbach(1) also say that it is not rarely encountered in its conidial stage which usually differs only insignificantly from the ascus stage, and Dennis says that fruitbodies are almost invariably accompanied by a similarly colored conidial state. RANGE ^Ascocoryne sarcoides occurs in CA (MykoWeb), throughout North America (Lincoff(2)), ME to OR and probably throughout North America, Europe, and the West Indies, (Seaver). The University of British Columbia has collections from BC and the University of Washington has collections from WA and New Zealand.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-1(2)cm across, spherical when young then turbinate [top-shaped] to cup-shaped or disc-shaped, or cushion-like with central depression, usually irregularly undulating, spore-bearing surface flesh-pink to violet-pink, smooth to somewhat wrinkled when mature^, (Breitenbach), up to 1cm across, cup-shaped, disc concave or flattened, often irregular and lobed; reddish purple, (Dennis), "eventually the cup surface becomes irregular with a distinct dark edge", (Trudell)
FLESH  gelatinous^ (Breitenbach)
UNDERSIDE  the same color as upper surface and smooth^, (Breitenbach), usually minutely scurfy, the same color as upper surface, (Dennis)
STEM  stemless or with very short stem^, (Breitenbach), sessile or short-stemmed (Dennis) 
ODOR  none in particular^ (Lincoff(1))
TASTE  none in particular^ (Lincoff(1))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  usually in tight clusters, forming a surface sometimes as large as a hand, rarely single; on rotting branches and trunks of trees on ground, as well as stumps^, (Breitenbach), clustered on stumps and fallen logs, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-16 x 4.5-5 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with single septa when ripe, with two droplets^; asci 8-spored, 114-125 x 8-10, uniseriate to biseriate, amyloid; paraphyses cylindric, forked, with few septa, some rather thickened toward the tips, (Breitenbach), spores 10-19 x 3-5 um, elliptic to inequilateral, often biseriate, "at first non-septate with 2 oil drops, becoming usually 1-septate, occasionally 3-septate, sometimes germinating within the ascus"; asci 8-spored, up to 160 x 10 um, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses "slender, often abruptly swollen to 4 um at the tip", (Dennis), when young may produce only asexual spores (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  from Greek meaning "fleshy"^ (Lincoff(1))
SIMILAR  Ascocoryne cylichnium is very similar but often has larger fruitbodies and is distinguished by larger spores 18-30 x 4-6 um, which become multiseptate and bud off spherical secondary spores while still in the ascus, (Dennis). A. cylichnium "cannot be differentiated in the field" from A. sarcoides. "The only separating characteristic lies in the larger size of the spores." (Breitenbach(1), but note that the microscopic descriptions and illustrations also show several septa in the spores when ripe (a single septum when ripe in A. sarcoides) and paraphyses are unbranched (branched in A. sarcoides))
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Seaver(2) (as Coryne sarcoides), Lincoff(2)*, Lincoff(1)*, Dennis(1), Trudell(4)*, Sept(1)*, MykoWeb(1)*, Desjardin(6)*
21
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascocoryne striata  (Ellis & Everh.) V. Kucera & Lizon^  Mycotaxon 93: 163. 2005;  == Bulgaria striata  Ellis & Everh.;  == Coryne striata  (Ellis & Ever.) Sacc.;  == Didymocoryne striata  (Ellis & Ever.) Sacc. & Trotter
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly category. Ascocoryne striata has a gelatinous purplish brown fruitbody on wood, "characterised by the receptacle's striate margin, the occurrence of ampuliform [sic], sigmoid or irregular cells and the presence of oxalate crystals in the ectal excipulum", (Kucera & Lizon 2005).^ RANGE ^It is rare, and known from OR and Austria. The two specimens in CUP (Cornell University Plant Pathology Herbarium) under the name Ascocoryne striata (Ellis & Everh.) Korf are different taxa of Ascocoryne (Kucera & Lizon).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.4cm across and 0.1cm high, "cup-shaped to flattened, subsessile, irregularly obconical, gelatinous, distinctly striate when dry"; spore-bearing surface circular, concave, purplish brown with a violaceous tint; margin obtuse
FLESH  gelatinous
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  subsessile
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or in small clusters, on decayed wood
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (10)12-14(20) x 3-3.5(6) um, narrowly elliptic to fusiform, straight or slightly curved, colorless, usually 1-septate, with numerous lipid bodies 0.5-1 um in diameter, budding ovoid to irregular blastoconidia, 1.5-2 um^; asci 8-spored, biseriate, 85-150 x 7-10 um, clavate, slender toward base, apical pore turning blue in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses "narrow, slender or only slightly swollen at the tip, unbranched", terminal cell 12-15 x 1-2 um; medullary excipulum of textura intricata, up to 650 um thick, cells 18-45 x 2.5-5 um, colorless, immersed in a gelatinous matrix; ectal excipulum up to 120 um thick, of irregularly branched cells and hyphae, individual cells 8-12 x 4-8 um, ampulliform, fusiform, irregularly curved, somewhat sigmoid, horn-shaped, often slightly swollen, ectal excipulum containing oxalate crystals; anamorph unknown
NAME ORIGIN  means 'striate'
SIMILAR  Ascocoryne cylichnium also has oxalate crystals but the excipular cells are +/- regular rather than ampulliform, sigmoid, or irregular, (Kucera).
SOURCES  Kucera(1)
22
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ascophanus brunneus  Kanouse^  Mycologia 39: 638. 1947
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small fruitbody with an upraised margin, a dark brown upper surface, a cinnamon brown exterior that becomes blackish brown downward, broad attachment, growth on dung, and microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Kanouse(6). RANGE ^Ascophanus brunneus was described from WA but not included in the Larsen(1) checklist or the PezWeb preliminary checklist of North American Pezizales (which emphasizes western species).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-1cm across; spore-bearing upper surface "dark brown to blackish brown (when dry), lighter at margin", margin upraised, drying somewhat scalloped
FLESH  soft
UNDERSIDE  cinnamon brown near margin when fresh, becoming blackish brown downward
STEM  broadly attached
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on dung
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-24 x 9-11 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 225-250 x 16 um, cylindric, the ascus tips becoming deep blue in iodine; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], "not enlarged upwards, 3 um or less in width at the apices, colorless, clumps of paraphyses fusing and becoming indistinguishable" in mature fruitbodies; hypothecium prosenchymatic
NAME ORIGIN  means 'brown'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(6), Larsen(1) (does not include), PezWeb(1) (does not include)
23
FAMILY  Godroniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Atropellis pinicola  Zeller & Goodd.^  Phytopathology 20: 563. 1930;  == Godronia zelleri  Seaver  Mycologia 37: 354. 1945
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, blackish, cup-shaped to disc-shaped fruiting bodies that are pruinose on the inner and outer surface, growth on pine bark, and microscopic characters.^ | This is not the same as Godronia pinicola (Reb.) Karst.; Groves(3) in his monograph on Godronia gives Atropellis pinicola Zeller & Goodd. as the correct name for Godronia zelleri Seaver. RANGE ^Atropellis pinicola is found from OR to CA, MT and BC, (Seaver). Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, ID, (Reid, J.).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.4cm wide, at first closed, opening by star-shaped or irregular clefts, leaving rather fimbriate [fringed] margins, expanding to disc-shaped, "usually rolling up from two sides when drying"; black; pruinose
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  external surface black to fuscous black; pruinose
STEM  without stem, or on very short central stem
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or gregarious, erupting from outer layers of bark on living branches of Pinus lambertiana, Pinus monticola, Pinus strobus, and Pinus contorta
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 36-63 x 1.5-3.5 um, filiform [thread-like] to acicular-clavate [needle - club-shape], colorless, continuous, guttulate^; asci 8-spored, 74-178 x 8-13 um, clavate, colorless, staining brown with iodine; paraphyses exceeding the length of the asci by 32-38 um, hair-like, flexuous [wavy], "tips slender, agglutinated, forming a dense epithecium with rosy and purplish tints in section", (Seaver(2)), spores 32-63 x 1.5-3.5, filiform to acicular-clavate, colorless, 1-6-celled; asci 74-178 x 8-13 um, (Reid, J.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'inhabiting pine'
SIMILAR  Atropellis pinicola is easily distinguished from other Atropellis species on pine because of its long narrow spores: Atropellis piniphila has spores (14)16-28(32) x 4-7(8) um, "elliptic-fusoid, with acute ends, straight or sigmoid, (0) to 1-septate (rarely becoming 3-septate)", and asci (85)90-160 um, (Reid, J.).
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Godronia zelleri), Reid, J.(2), Groves(3)
24
FAMILY  Godroniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Atropellis piniphila  (Weir) M.L. Lohman & E.K. Cash^  Journal of the Washington Academy of Science 30(6): 260. 1940;  Atropellis arizonica  M.L. Lohman & E.K. Cash;  Cenangium piniphilum  Weir
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Atropellis piniphila is most easily differentiated from Atropellis pinicola by its spores. Features include growth on cankers of Ponderosa and lodgepole pine, the fruitbody first closed and rounded to ellipsoid, then expanding, 0.2-0.3cm across, brown to black, with leathery-membranaceous texture and a stem-like base, and microscopic characters, (Weir 1921).^ | It attacks Pinus ponderosa and Pinus contorta between the ages of 5 and 25 years, the infection occurring usually at the nodes, less frequently on the internodes (but may spread throughout the length of the stem), and causes cankers on the surface. After further examination of Atropellis piniphila (Weir) M.L. Lohman & E.K. Cash and the type of Atropellis arizonica M.L. Lohman & E.K. Cash, the only feature that appeared to differ was the septation of the spores (0-1-septate for the former and 0-3-septate for the latter, not considered enough to define a new species in view of the small number of 3-septate spores examined), (Reid, J.). RANGE ^Collections of A. piniphila were examined from WA, ID, AB, MT, NM, and (the only collection corresponding to A. arizonica) AZ, (Reid, J.(2)). It causes considerable damage to Pinus contorta (lodgepole pine) in several areas of AB, BC, and the western United States (Hopkins(1)). Zeller(19) recorded it from Pinus albicaulis in OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  rupturing the epidermis of host, at first rounded or ellipsoid, closed, then cone-shaped, tapering to a stem-like base, "expanding and becoming almost plane with the margin, irregularly incurved, but not wholly closed when dry", coriaceous [leathery], membranaceous, 0.2-0.5cm across, carbonous; disc brownish to black, surface velvety or wrinkled^, (Weir)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  tapering to stem-like base^ (Weir)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine) and Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine)^ (Weir)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (14)16-28(32) x 4-7(8) um, "elliptic-fusoid, with acute ends, straight or sigmoid, (0) to 1-septate (rarely becoming 3-septate)"^; asci (85)90-160 um, (Reid, J.), spores averaging 18.9 x 6.4 um, oblong to elliptic or fusiform, ends acute, colorless, continuous, usually with a single central oil droplet (occasionally with two oil droplets), irregularly biseriate, sometimes uniseriate; asci 8-spored, averaging 135.8 x 14.1 um, clavate, rounded at top, long-stemmed; paraphyses filamentous, branched, longer than the asci, colorless, (Weir)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'liking pine'
SIMILAR  Atropellis pinicola has spores 32-63 x 1.5-3.5, filiform to acicular-clavate, colorless, 1-6-celled, and asci 74-178 x 8-13 um, (Reid, J.).
SOURCES  Weir(1), Reid, J.(2), Hopkins(1), Zeller(19)
25
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Belonidium cenangioides  (Ellis) Raitv.^  Akad. Nauk Estonskoi S.S.R., Inst. Zool. Bot., Tartu: 47. 1970;  Lachnella cenangioides  Ellis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features are tiny cup-shaped fruiting bodies that are narrow-mouthed at first, the concave disc whitish, the marginal fringe white or pale brown, the exterior clothed with short dark brown hairs, stem absent, growth on dead or decaying herbaceous stems, and microscopic characters.^ | Belonidium has been synonymized with Lachnum (as is Lachnella Boud.) but this species was not combined in Lachnum in the online Species Fungorum, accessed March 24, 2014. The description is derived from Dennis(3) except where noted. RANGE ^The type is from UT, and another collection (described here) is from WA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody urceolate, then cup-shaped, about 0.033-0.05cm across, disc concave, whitish, marginal fringe white or pale brown, (Dennis), the Latin description of the type in Saccardo, P.A. Sylloge Fungorum VIII: 396 (1889) gives the diameter as "730 mm.", presumably 0.073cm
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  clothed with short dark brown hairs
STEM  sessile on a broad base
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  superficial, on dead herbaceous stems, at 6000 feet (1800 m), June, in UT; on decaying stems of Mertensia paniculata, at 6000-7000 feet (1800-2100 m), September, in WA
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-19 x 3 um (Ellis 15-18 um long), fusoid, irregularly uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, cylindric-clavate, the small pore blued by Melzer's reagent, 70-80 x 6 um in the type (immature), up to 108 x 8 um in WA collection; paraphyses 3-4 um wide, cylindric with pointed tips, slightly longer than the asci; hairs 3-4 um wide, 40 um long in the type and up to 110 um long in the WA collection, septate, cylindric, hair walls "thin, brown, rather coarsely granulate", the short apical cell slightly enlarged and colorless [apical cells are shorter than previous segments in 2 of the 3 illustrated hairs]; "excipular cells cuboid with thin brown walls", 7-8 um in diameter
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dennis(3)
26
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Belonidium sulphureum  (Pers.) Raitv.^  Akad. Nauk Estonskoi S.S.R., Inst. Zool. Bot., Tartu: 45. 1970;  Trichopeziza sulphurea  (Pers.) Fuckel;  Dasyscyphus sulphureus  (Pers.) Massee;  Lachnum sulfureum  (Fr.) P. Karst.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute cup-shaped to disc-shaped fruitbodies, upper surface that is grayish white, margin and exterior thickly set with sulfur yellow hairs, growth on Urtica (nettle) and other herbs, and microscopic characters including long cylindric spores.^ | Kanouse said that in Washington it was "found commonly and on a wide variety of substrata". Haines(1) says that this is the only Dasyscyphus species "commonly occurring on herbaceous substrates in western Washington which has long, multiseptate spores". RANGE ^Belonidium sulphureum was reported from WA (Kanouse), NY to IA, Europe, (Seaver), Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden, (Hansen), and Switzerland (Breitenbach).
