There are collections from BC as Dasyscyphus sulphureus under Belonidium sulphureum at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.2cm across, cup-shaped when young expanding to plate-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface gray-whitish, smooth; margin thickly set with sulfur-yellow hairs^, (Breitenbach), 0.05-0.2cm across, spore-bearing upper surface grayish white, hairs sulfur yellow, (Hansen), reaching 0.1-0.15cm across, at first closed, expanding to flat with slightly raised margin; upper surface concave or flat, whitish or creamy white, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  thickly set with sulfur-yellow hairs^ (Breitenbach), densely clothed with sulfur-yellow hairs, (Seaver)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach), without a stem but "narrowed below approaching substipitate", (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to densely cespitose on "dead stems of Urtica (nettle), as well as other herbs, especially Umbelliferae (carrot family)", April to October^, (Breitenbach), especially on Urtica but also found on Anthriscus (chervil), (Hansen), on herbaceous stems, on Sambucus sp., on Rubus stems, (Kanouse), scattered on dead herbaceous stems, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 26-29 x 1.9-2 um in one collection and 30-35 x 2.5-3 um in another, cylindric, "often slightly curved, with indistinct septa when mature", smooth, colorless, biseriate [illustrated as one bundle of 4 above another bundle of 4]^; asci 8-spored, up to 100 x 10 um, positive reaction in iodine; paraphyses projecting beyond the asci, narrowly lanceolate to filiform [thread-like]; hairs "yellowish, +/- thin-walled, septate, sparsely encrusted with isolated granules, ending in a +/- blunt tip", no hair coloration in the two specimens examined, (Breitenbach), spores 25-35 x 2-3 um, narrowly fusoid, 0-3-septate; asci 80-100 x 6-8 um; paraphyses exceeding asci by 5-20 um, 4-5 um wide, lanceolate; hairs 150-225 x 3-4.5 um, yellowish, (Hansen), spores 8-10 x 1.5-2 um or rarely 15-16 um long, slender-elliptic, straight or slightly curved, or fusoid, 2-seriate; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 50-75 um and a width of 5 um, clavate; paraphyses about as thick as the ascus, lanceolate; hairs cylindric, straight or slightly curved, pale yellowish or occasionally yellowish brown, septate, either blunt or gradually tapering with semiacute tip, minutely roughened, (Seaver), spores 20-35 x 2 um, narrowly fusiform, 1-4-septate, flexuous, "often filled with large droplets as wide as the cell, biseriate to multiseriate in the ascus", (Haines)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'sulfur-yellow'
SIMILAR  "Other fungi have been described which are identical except for smaller, non-septate spores but I have not seen any of this material." (Haines(1)), Discocistella grevillei was examined one from Urtica lyalli (stinging nettle) and once from Heracleum lanatum (cow parsnip) in Washington, by Haines(1) (as Dasyscyphus grevillei). He says that the sessile cups (up to 0.05cm across) are cream-white when fresh with short, light yellow hairs, the disc cream-colored. He says that spores are 6-9 x 1.5-2.0 um; paraphyses narrowly lanceolate or almost filiform, 2-2.5 um wide, exceeding the asci by up to 5 um, and colorless; and hairs 3-5 um wide, up to 40 um long, irregularly cylindric, "sometimes slightly enlarged at the tips", colorless, thin-walled, continuous or with 1 or 2 septa, "finely roughened except at the base, without apical crystals", (Haines(1))
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1) (as Dasyscyphus sulfureus (Pers. ex Fr.) Massee), Hansen, L.(1) (as Trichopeziza sulphurea), Kanouse(6) (as Lachnum sulfureum), Seaver(2) (as Lachnella sulfurea), Haines(1) (as Dasyscyphus sulfureus)
27
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Belonioscypha miniata  Kanouse^  Mycologia 39: 640. 1947
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute fruitbody that is flat (with the margin slightly inrolled), creamy yellow in color, and delicately roughened by granules of an amorphous deposit lining the cup, short stem, growth on old sedge stems, and microscopic characters.^ | Dictionary of the Fungi Ninth Edition synonymizes this genus with Cyathicula De Not., and Jan Vesterholt (in Hansen, L.(1)) synonymizes both with Crocicreas Fr. RANGE ^Belonioscypha miniata was found in OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.02-0.04cm, flat when moist with margin slightly inrolled; creamy yellow when fresh, drying pale yellow; "delicately roughened by granules of an amorphous deposit outlining the cup"^, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  0.005cm long^ (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on old stems of Carex, the infected area of the leaf blade was outlined by an irregular darkened band that did not touch the fungus^, (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-12 x 2-3 um, cylindric, with pointed ends, straight to slightly curved, nearly colorless, 3-septate, usually biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 50-70 x 6-9 um, cylindric-clavate, ascus pore becoming blue in iodine; paraphyses projecting slightly beyond the asci, filiform, colorless, not enlarged at tips, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6)
28
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Bisporella sulfurina  (Quel.) S.E. Carp.^  in Korf & Carpenter, Mycotaxon 1(1): 59. 1974;  Helotium sulfurinum Quel.;  Calycina claroflava  (Grev.) Kuntze  [as 'clariflava'], Revis. gen. pl. (Leipzig) 3(3): 448 (1898) (proposed current name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  lemon-drops
NOTES  Bisporella sulfurina is a minute, yellow, shallow cup with almost no stem, that grows on hardwood logs in association with pyrenomycetes which are often small, round, crust-like, and black. It can be minutely downy on the exterior but is otherwise bald. It tends to be tightly clustered, unlike Bisporella citrina which is not particularly associated with pyrenomycetes. But some authors regard the two species as synonyms.^ | The online Species Fungorum, accessed September 12, 2022, listed the current name as Calycina claroflava (Grev.) Kuntze, but MycoBank, accessed on the same date, listed the current name as Bisporella sulfurina (Quel.) S.E. Carp. |The original basionym was spelled 'sulphurina'. RANGE ^There are collections from BC at the University of British Columbia, identified by O. Ceska. It is included for CA by Desjardin(6) and Siegel(2).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.01-0.10cm across, saucer-shaped to shallowly cup-shaped; bright lemon yellow; smooth; "margin even, lacking hairs"^, (Desjardin), 0.1-0.3cm across, shallow cup-shaped to disc-shaped, typically flattening out when old, upper surface "bright yellow to sulfur-yellow"; smooth; margin brighter or paler, (Siegel), 0.05-0.15cm across, irregularly cup-shaped to saucer-shaped, "margin slightly projecting"; hymenium sulfur-yellow, smooth, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  thin, soft; pale yellow^, (Desjardin), very thin and fragile, (Siegel)
UNDERSIDE  outer surface yellow; bald or minutely downy^, (Desjardin), pale yellow; powdery, "very finely downy to smooth", (Siegel), outer surface and margin somewhat paler than upper surface, "and with fine down", (Breitenbach)
STEM  sessile^ (Desjardin), absent or very short (Siegel), barely stalked, (Breitenbach)
ODOR  indistinct^ (Siegel)
TASTE  indistinct^ (Siegel)
EDIBILITY  unknown (Desjardin)
HABITAT  gregarious or in small clusters "on hardwood logs, usually associated with old, black, crustose fruitbodies of a pyrenomycete", fall through early spring, (Desjardin), often "in small masses of many fruitbodies or in scattered troops on decaying logs, branches or woody debris, almost always with small, round, black fruitbodies of a Pyrenomycete present", generally "found on oak and Tanoak, but will occur on many different hardwoods", (Siegel), occasionally single, "but usually compactly clustered and fused at the base", growing on dead branches of hardwood trees, "usually on old fruiting bodies of Sphaeriales", fall-spring, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-11 x 2-2.5 um, narrowly elliptic to fusoid, "sometimes curved, smooth, 1-septate"^; asci "inoperculate, tips inamyloid"; paraphyses filiform, with yellow granules, (Desjardin), spores 8-11 x 1.5-2.5 um, cylindric, "smooth, often with oil droplets", (Siegel), spores 8-10(12) x 2 um, elliptic-fusiform, "sometimes rather curved", smooth, colorless, "with 1 septum", usually with 4 droplets; asci 8-spored, 60-90 x 4-4.5 um, iodine negative; paraphyses "filiform, filled with many yellow droplets", (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to sulfur' because of its color
SIMILAR  Bisporella citrina "has larger fruiting bodies not growing in clusters and does not occur on Sphaeriales"; spores are 8-12 x 3-3.6 um, although Dennis 1978 said 9-14 x 3-5 um, (Breitenbach(1)). B. citrina forms slightly larger fruitbodies (0.1-0.3cm) "that grow gregarious but not clustered, is not associated with pyrenomycete crusts, and has slightly broader spores" 3-3.5 um wide, (Desjardin(6)). B. citrina is differentiated by its larger spores (9-14 x 3-5um) and growth on wood without a nearby Pyrenomycete, (Siegel).|Yellow species of Hymenoscyphus are distinctly stalked (Breitenbach(1)). There are many other yellow disc fungi that are difficult to identify.
SOURCES  Desjardin(6)*, Breitenbach(1)*, Siegel(2)*
29
FAMILY  Bulgariaceae, Order Leotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Bulgaria inquinans  Pers.^  Syst. mycol. (Lundae) 2: 166. 1822;  Bulgaria polymorpha  (Oeder) Wettst.;  Phaeobulgaria inquinans  (Pers.) Nannf.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  black jelly-drops, poor man's licorice, black bulgar, bachelor-buttons
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly fungi category. Features include gelatinous to rubbery, top-shaped to shallow cup-shaped fruitbody that is black and smooth (shiny when wet) on the upper surface and dark brown and roughened on the exterior, growth on hardwood, and microscopic characters including 4 dark spores and 4 lighter ones in each ascus. The hymenium of the mature fruitbody colors the finger black when stroked (Breitenbach & Kranzlin).^ RANGE ^Bulgaria inquinans is found from NY to AL, west to the Pacific Northwest (Lincoff(2)), OR (Zeller), and CA (Arora).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-4cm broad and/or high, 'at first rounded to somewhat cylindrical to shallow cup-shaped or top-shaped, then broadening into a flattened or broadly convex, flabby "cap"'; fertile upper surface "blackish and often shiny when wet"^, (Arora), turbinate [top-shaped] when young, then expanded and saucer-shaped; black to brown-black; "shiny when wet and dull when dry, smooth", (Breitenbach), up to 4cm across, turbinate, slightly concave, black, (Dennis), rounded to turban-shaped, becoming flat-topped, (Lincoff(2))
FLESH  "gelatinous or at least very rubbery, pliant and tough, not brittle"^, (Arora), gelatinous, ocher-brownish, (Breitenbach), gelatinous, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  "brown to blackish and roughened"^, (Arora), dark brown to black-brown and +/- furfuraceous-scurfy, (Breitenbach), sooty brown and scurfy, (Dennis)
STEM  "absent or present as narrowed base, continuous with and colored like the exterior or underside"^, (Arora), sometimes narrowed into stem-like base, but usually stemless, (Breitenbach)
ODOR  mild^ (Miller)
TASTE  unknown^ (Miller)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, scattered, in rows, or densely gregarious or clustered on dead hardwood logs and branches, especially on oak^, (Arora), often clustered but not becoming confluent, (Dennis), several to numerous, often in cespitose clusters, "on the bark of recently fallen hardwood trees especially oak, beech, and birch"; fall, (Miller), fall and winter (Bacon)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores "11-14 x 6-7 um, more or less kidney-shaped, smooth, not septate", brown to black in mass, but only the upper four in ascus brown, the other 4 colorless^, apex of ascus blue in iodine, (Arora), spores 9-17 x 6-7.5 um, broadly elliptic to lemon-shaped or kidney-shaped; asci 8-spored, usually only upper four well developed, 95-124 x 8.5-9 um, irregularly uniseriate; paraphyses thin and thread-like, forked toward base, tips sinuous, (Breitenbach), spores of two kinds in asci, "the upper four somewhat kidney-shaped, 11-14 x 6-7 um, very dark brown and opaque", the lower four similarly shaped but colorless, and smaller, containing several small oil drops; asci up to 200 x 9 um; paraphyses very slender, with slightly swollen brown tips, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin meaning "dirtying", because touching the mature fruiting body stains one's fingers blackish^, (Lincoff(1))
SIMILAR  Exidia glandulosa has minute pimples on its surface. If a fruitbody leaves a sooty zone around it when left overnight on paper, it cannot be Exidia glandulosa, which has colorless spores, (Dennis). Urnula padeniana and Pseudosarcosoma latahense are larger, somewhat different in shape, and different microscopically.
SOURCES  Arora(1)*, Breitenbach(1)*, Miller(14)*, Dennis(1), Seaver(2) (as Phaeobulgaria inquinans), Lincoff(2)*, Lincoff(1)*, Zeller(2), Bacon(1)*, Buczacki(1)*, Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2)*
30
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Byssonectria cartilaginea  (Kanouse et A.H. Sm.) Pfister^  Mycologia 85(6): 956. 1993 [as 'cartilagineum'];  == Pseudocollema cartilagineum  Kanouse & A.H. Sm.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Individual fruitbodies are very small. Byssonectria cartilaginea is characterized by orange fruiting bodies densely gregarious on a thick, tightly interwoven, white to tan subiculum that forms over rodent dung and associated debris, which it binds into a firm mass. Fruiting occurs in spring.^ | Spores are in the range 20-24 x 8-9.6 um, (Pfister 1993). In the type, the stromatic mass on which the bright orange fruitbodies were closely gregarious was 9-15cm long by 6-10cm wide and 10cm high. RANGE ^It is found in the western mountains of the US and Canada: WA, and also AB, CA, UT, and WY, (Pfister).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1cm wide, 0.1cm high, at first spherical, becoming subturbinate [somewhat top-shaped], soft, fleshy; bright orange throughout, fading when dry to brownish^, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  without stem, "produced upon a thick cartilaginous stroma-like base formed over a dung heap"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  directly associated with rodent dung, in the western mountains of the US and Canada, generally early in the season as the snow is melting^, (Pfister)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 19-21 x 9-10 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, 1-seriate, parallel or diagonally arranged^; asci 8-spored, 230-250 x 15-17 um, inamyloid; paraphyses slender, slightly enlarged in upper part; hypothecium pseudoparenchymatous, (Kanouse), spores 20-24 x 8-9.6 um, (Pfister)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  See SIMILAR section of Byssonectria terrestris. Byssonectria aggregata (here a synonym of B. terrestris) is only occasionally and incidentally associated with dung, has a circumboreal distribution, and has been shown to be associated with Nannfeldtia aggregata.
SOURCES  Kanouse(7), Pfister(3)
31
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Byssonectria terrestris  (Alb. & Schw.) Pfister^  Mycologia 85(6): 953. 1993;  == Thelebolus terrestris  Alb. & Schwein.;  = Byssonectria aggregata  (Berk. & Broome) Rogerson & Korf;  = Humaria aggregata  (Berk. & Broome) Sacc.;  Humarina aggregata  (Berk. & Broome) Seaver;  = Inermisia aggregata  (Berk. & Broome) Svrcek;  = Octospora aggregata  (Berk. & Broome) Eckblad
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include turbinate to somewhat cylindric fruiting body with orange spore-bearing upper surface that has a fringe-like border, seated on conspicuous mycelial growth, whitish or pale orange underside, growth in early spring, and microscopic characters including spores in the range 18.4-25.6 x 8-9.6 um.^ | The description is derived from Seaver for Humarina aggregata (Berk. & Broome) Seaver except where noted. This is the most commonly collected species in the genus. The online Species Fungorum, accessed December 14, 2013, gives the current name Thelebolus terrestris Alb. & Schwein. with Byssonectria terrestris (Alb. & Schwein.) Pfister as a synonym, and gives the "aggregata" names as synonyms of Byssonectria fusispora (Berk.) Rogerson & Korf. Here we follow Pfister(3) who includes the "aggregata" names and Thelebolus terrestris Alb. & Schwein. as synonyms of Byssonectria terrestris (Alb. & Schw.: Fr.) Pfister - see SIMILAR. Byssonectria aggregata (a synonym here) is thought to associate with Nannfeldtia aggregata. RANGE ^Byssonectria terrestris is found in WA, and also AB, MB, NB, ON, PQ, AK, ME, MI, NH, NY, TN, WI, and WY, (Pfister), and Europe including Denmark (Perry). Oluna Ceska identified and vouchered it (as Byssonectria fusispora) from BC.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.3cm, somewhat cylindric or turbinate [top-shaped], spore-bearing upper surface concave or nearly flat, surrounded by a delicate fringe-like border; bright orange
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  whitish or pale orange
STEM  seated on a conspicuous mycelial growth
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or more often crowded together into confluent masses, on the ground, (Seaver), "covering and binding leaves, mosses, pine needles, and twigs and on soil in areas where animals have urinated", "dung sometimes present"; found in early spring, (Pfister)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 22-25 x 8-9 um, (Pfister gives a range of 18.4-25.6 x 8-9.6 um), fusoid [spindle-shaped], colorless, containing 2 oil droplets, uniseriate, often with ends strongly overlapping or irregularly crowded and partially biseriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 200-225 um and a width of 10-12 um, cylindric to clavate, narrowing rather abruptly in lower part; paraphyses rather strongly enlarged in upper part, (Seaver), subiculum less than 0.2cm thick (Pfister)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'aggregated'
SIMILAR  Pfister(3) recognizes 4 species of Byssonectria: B. terrestris, B. cartilagineum [sic], B. fusispora (examined from Nunavut, IN, FL, United Kingdom), and B. seaveri (examined from NJ, SC), and gives a key. B. terrestris has fruitbodies gregarious on extensive mycelial mats, subiculum less than 2 mm thick, arachnoid, "covering and binding leaves, mosses, pine needles, and twigs and on soil in areas where animals have urinated", "dung sometimes present", spores 18.4-25.6 x 8-9.6(10.4) um. B. cartilagineum [sic] has fruitbodies gregarious on extensive mycelial mats, subiculum 0.2-0.5cm thick, covering and binding rodent dung under or associated with melting snow, spores 20-24 x 8-9.6 um. B. fusispora has fruitbodies formed on mycelial tufts, subiculum scanty or lacking, associated with burned areas, spores 24-28.8 x 7.2-11 um (23-28 um long in another part of the article), paraphyses straight or curved, not interwoven. B. seaveri has fruitbodies formed on mycelial tufts, subiculum scanty or lacking, on sandy soil often associated with burned plant debris, spores 29-36 x 8-10 um, paraphyses sometimes interwoven to form a thin epithecium, (Pfister). Oluna and Adolf Ceska reported B. fusispora from Vancouver Island in British Columbia, with spore size (20)23-25 x 8-9(10) um. According to Pfister(3), "Rifai (1968) largely discounted the use of ascospore size differences to distinguish species. He examined primarily type collections and proposed a broad species concept recognizing a single species Inermisia fusispora (Berk.) Rifai with a wide ascospore size range." . See also SIMILAR section of Byssonectria cartilaginea.
SOURCES  Pfister(3), Seaver(1), Perry(2)
32
FAMILY  Marasmiaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Calathella ellisii  Agerer^  Mtt. Bot. Staatssamml. Muenchen 19: 198. 1983;  Flagelloscypha coloradensis  W.B. Cooke;  Lachnella oregonensis  W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Calathella ellisii is a small brownish basidiomycete cup with whitish hairs on the exterior, absent or short stem, growth on willow branches, and microscopic characters.^ | Agerer proposed this name to replace Peziza campanula Ellis, which is a later homonym of Peziza campanula Nees (now Calyptella campanula), and in doing so included as synonyms Cooke's species Flagelloscypha coloradensis and Lachnella oregonensis described below, (Ginns). RANGE ^It is found in OR, CO, and UT, (Ginns).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.3cm across, cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface light brown when dry; margin wavy and with hairs, (Cooke for Flagelloscypha coloradensis), 0.1-1cm across, cup-shaped, spore-bearing surface brown, (Cooke for Lachnella oregonensis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white when dry, covered with surface hairs, those at cup edges shorter than those below, (Cooke for Flagelloscypha coloradensis), white from the hairs, (Cooke for Lachnella oregonensis)
STEM  stem absent, (Cooke for Flagelloscypha coloradensis), stem up to 0.1cm long, dark-colored, (Cooke for Lachnella oregonensis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on branches of Salix sp. (willow), (Cooke for Flagelloscypha coloradensis), single to gregarious on branches of Salix sp., (Cooke for Lachnella oregonensis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8.5-10.5 x 1.5-2.5 um, cylindric to allantoid [curved sausage-shaped], smooth, colorless, apiculate^; basidia 4-spored, 14-22 x 3-5 um, densely compacted, sterigmata 2 um long, basidia clamped at base; clamp connections in subhymenial region; hairs 150-300 x 3-4 um but reaching 500 um long, colorless, "incrusted with acicular granules, unbranched, not septate", "brittle, tortuous, appearing interwoven but straight and parallel at the cup margin", (Cooke for Flagelloscypha coloradensis), spores 8-9 x 3-3.5 um, allantoid, smooth, colorless, apiculate; basidia 4-spored, 16.5-20 x 3.5-5 um, hairs 275-325 x 4-5 um, flexuous [wavy], white, hyaline, clothed with minute granules the whole length, (Cooke for Lachnella oregonensis)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Cooke(2), Ginns(5)
33
FAMILY  Marasmiaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Calathella eruciformis  (P. Micheli ex Batsch) D.A. Reid^  Persoonia 3(1): 123. 1964;  Lachnella eruciformis  (P. Micheli ex Batsch) W.B. Cooke;  Flagelloscypha eruciformis  (P. Micheli ex Batsch) Singer;  Cyphella albissima  Pat. & Doass.;  Cyphella albocarnea  Quel.;  Lachnella campanula  (Ellis) Sacc.;  Cyphella eumorpha  P. Karst.;  Stromatocyphella lataensis  W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, gray-white cup-shaped fruiting bodies appearing yellow in mass, the cup exterior looking minutely hairy under hand-lens, with an indistinct stem-like base, growth usually on dead wood and herbage of Populus species, and microscopic characters including basidia.^ | The Cooke description here is of Lachnella eruciformis (Fr.) Cooke, found in BC and ID, which is assumed to be the same as or similar to Calathella erucaeformis (Fr.) Reid mentioned by Redhead for BC and ID and having the same spore size and habitat. RANGE ^Collections were examined from ID, MB, MI, UT, Denmark, Finland, Sweden, also known from Turkey, (Reid), and BC, ID, AB, MB, ON, CA, MI, and UT, (Ginns).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.2cm across and 0.2cm high, varying from almost tubular or narrowly funnel-shaped when young, to campanulate [bell-shaped] or turbinate [top-shaped] when mature, may be pendulous [hanging] in certain situations; when old the margin often conspicuously lobed and this may give the impression of a small colony; spore-bearing surface ?pinkish^, (Reid), 0.02-0.1cm, more or less cup-shaped, spore-bearing upper surface gray-white; margin inrolled when dry, (Cooke)
FLESH  firm^ (Reid)
UNDERSIDE  white at first, becoming dark gray or blackish from below; appearing minutely hirsute [hairy] under a hand-lens^, (Reid), gray-white, surface hairs white, appearing yellow in mass, (Cooke)
STEM  fruitbodies narrow downwards to a broad, indistinct, stem-like base up to 0.015cm high and wide^, (Reid), subsessile to sessile (Cooke) 
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  often widely scattered, but sometimes occurring in groups of 2 or 3, occasionally appearing aggregated into small dense colonies, (Reid), on bark, dead wood, fallen branches, twigs, barkless logs, herbage, on Populus and Salix, (Ginns)^, single to gregarious, on dead wood and herbage, usually on Populus species, but also on other hardwoods and Juncus, (Cooke)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-8(10.2) x (1.75)2-2.5(2.75) um, (slightly broader in Scandinavian collections, 1.75-3.75 um), varying from subcylindric to very slightly allantoid (curved), sometimes tapered toward apex^; basidia 4-spored, 20-26 x 5-6 um, clavate, 'often with a rather distinct "tail" that curves round parallel to the sides of the hymenial cavity'; cystidia and gloeocystidia absent; hairs up to 250 um long and 2.5-3.5 um wide in aniline blue in lactic acid but up to 5 um wide in 10% KOH, cylindric with obtuse tip and a long drawn-out base ending in a clamped septum, some hairs may taper gradually to acute tip, colorless, but in older specimens becoming brown toward base, thick-walled with rather narrow lumen, except toward apex where walls may thin out, toward the base the hairs becoming strongly agglutinated or even gelatinized and forming a distinct outer layer to fruitbody of very variable width; subhymenium hyphae 2-2.5 um wide, much branched, colorless, clamped; context hyphae up to 3 um wide, parallel, thin-walled, colorless, branched, with clamp connections, (Reid), spores 5-9 x 2.5-4 um, ovate to cylindric to suballantoid (somewhat curved and sausage-shaped), apiculate, smooth, colorless; surface hairs finely to coarsely granule incrusted their whole length, thick-walled, 90-325 x 5-10 um, hairs at margin of cup with a broad base; context of clamped hyphae 3-4 um in diameter; subhymenial hyphae 2.5 um in diameter, clamped; basidia 17-23.5 x 4-7 um, 4-spored, clamped at base, (Cooke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'shaped like a caterpillar'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Stromatocyphella conglobata.
SOURCES  Reid(4), Cooke(2) (as Lachnella), Redhead(21) (as Calathella erucaeformis), Ginns(5) (as Calathella eruciformis var. eruciformis)
34
FAMILY  Calloriaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Calloria atrosanguinea  Rehm^  Annls mycol. 5(6): 518. 1907;  Belonium atrosanguineum  (Rehm) Seaver  The North American Cup-fungi (Inoperculates) p.172. 1951
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, punctiform, blackish red fruitbodies, growing on mycelium of a Stereum on conifer logs, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Belonium atrosanguineum was described from WA and known according to Seaver only from the type specimen.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.015cm wide, punctiform, when moist blackish red, when dry black
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious, parasitic on the mycelium of a Stereum on conifer logs
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-12 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic to clavate, becoming 1-septate, finally 3-septate^; asci 8-spored, reaching 40-50 um long and 10 um wide; paraphyses filiform, 1 um wide, globose at apices, 4 um wide
NAME ORIGIN  from "ater" meaning "black" and "sanguineus" meaning "of blood, bloody"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Belonium atrosanguineeum)
35
FAMILY  Calloriaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Calloria oregonensis  Kanouse^  Papers Mich. Acad. Sci. 24: 26. 1939
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute, flat, purple fruitbody with a purplish exterior, soft somewhat gelatinous flesh, absent stem, and microscopic characters including paraphyses abruptly enlarged at tips.^ RANGE ^It is found in found OR (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1cm across, spore-bearing upper surface flat, purple
FLESH  soft and subgelatinous [somewhat gelatinous]^ (Seaver)
UNDERSIDE  purplish^ (Seaver)
STEM  without stem^ (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on coniferous wood^ (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-12 x 5-6 um, elliptic, becoming 1-septate and constricted at septum^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 120-150 um and a width of 7-8 um, cylindric; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], stiff, abruptly enlarged at their tips, the capitate apex reaching a width of 4 um, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Oregon'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2)
36
FAMILY  Caloscyphaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Caloscypha fulgens  (Pers.) Boud.^  Hist. Class. Discom. Eur. pt. 22, pl. XII A. 1909
ENGLISH NAME(S)  snowbank orange-peel fungus, blue-staining cup, dazzling cup, snowbank orange-peel
NOTES  Features include a bright orange to yellow orange cup that stains blue-green especially where handled, growth under conifers just after snow melt, and microscopic characters including round spores.^ | An albino form with bluish stains was found in Idaho (Arora). Caloscypha fulgens is a parasite of conifer seeds (Trudell). RANGE ^It is found in BC, WA, OR, ID, and also AB, CA, CO, MT, UT, and WY, (Larsen), MB, NB, ON, PQ, (Ginns), and Europe and temperate Asia (Trudell).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  to 4cm wide, cup-shaped with mouth constricted, sometimes split like Otidea; bright orange-yellow with mottling of blue-green, especially where bruised; smooth^, (Ginns), 2-4cm, spherical when young, then irregularly cup-shaped to saucer-shaped; bright yellow, more orange on drying; smooth to tuberculate [bumpy]; margin "even to sinuous, in part split and notched", (Breitenbach)
FLESH  to 0.1cm thick, very brittle; pale yellow^, (Ginns)
UNDERSIDE  "pale yellow or brownish with a distinct green tinge, finely pruinose, smooth"^, (Ginns), ocher-brownish, turning a greenish color when touched; farinose [mealy], (Breitenbach)
STEM  sometimes short-stemmed^, (Breitenbach), essentially sessile (Ginns), "absent or present only as a short, narrowed whitish base", (Arora)
ODOR  none^ (Miller)
TASTE  mild^ (Miller)
EDIBILITY  poisonous at least to some individuals, (Ammirati)
HABITAT  "on soil among mosses or sometimes attached to buried rotten wood, apparently only under conifers", generally in May in Canada, but as early as mid-April in BC^, (Ginns), fruiting shortly after snow melts (Arora), single to gregarious on mossy ground or needle and leaf litter, in hardwood and coniferous forests, March to May, may be mycorrhizal with Abies, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), in boggy places and in mountainous coniferous areas (Lincoff), single, scattered or in clusters, (Ammirati)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (5.5)6-6.5(7) um in diameter, round or nearly round, smooth, colorless, pale yellow in Melzer's, wall slightly thickened (to 0.5 um), at first 2-seriate but when mature 1-seriate^; asci 8-spored, 110-135 x 8-9 um, inamyloid; paraphyses cylindric to wavy, some tapering in the apical 20 um, 2.5-3.5 um wide, generally septate and branched 40-60 um below tips, contents homogeneous, (yellow granules noted in paraphyses by Seaver), (Ginns), spores 5-6 um in diameter, round, smooth, colorless, without droplets; asci 8-spored, 100 x 10 um, inamyloid; paraphyses cylindric, septate, forked toward base, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'shining'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Aleuria aurantia.
SOURCES  Ginns(11)*, Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Arora(1)*, Trudell(4)*, Phillips(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Miller(14)*, Seaver(1) (as Pseudoplectania fulgens), Larsen(1), McKnight(1)*, Ammirati(1)*, Desjardin(6)*, Marrone(1)*, McAdoo(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
37
FAMILY  Pezizellaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Calycina citrina  (Hedw.) Gray^  Nat. Arr. Brit. Pl. (London) 1: 670. 1821;  Bisporella citrina  (Batsch ex Fr.) Korf & S.E. Carp.  Mycotaxon 1(1): 58. 1974;  Calycella citrina  (Hedw.) Boud.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  yellow fairy cups, minute lemon cup
NOTES  Features include tiny shallow yellow cups growing in large numbers on dead hardwoods, stemless or with short stem, and microscopic characters.^ | Calycina citrina is commonly identified in the Pacific Northwest, often as Bisporella citrina. RANGE ^Under the name Bisporella citrina it is found throughout North America, July to November, (Lincoff(2)). The University of British Columbia has collections from BC and MN and the University of Washington has collections from WA, OR, AK, and New Zealand. Cornell (CUP) has collections from ON, MD, Denmark, Finland, France, Greenland, and Hungary.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.3cm across, saucer-shaped to plate-shaped or expanded with a convex disc, "lemon-yellow to yolk-yellow, margin often somewhat darker"^, (Breitenbach), up to 0.3cm across, shallow cup-shaped, slightly concave; deep yellow drying orange-yellow, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  lemon-yellow to yolk-yellow; smooth^, (Breitenbach), paler than upper surface; smooth, (Dennis)
STEM  stemless or with very short stem^ (Breitenbach), narrowed to a small base (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious and cespitose on dead branches of hardwoods, usually covering entire branches^, (Breitenbach), gregarious, on wood or erumpent from bark, (Dennis), in large numbers on dead wood of hardwoods (Phillips), spring to fall (Lincoff(1)), in large numbers on hardwood branches that have lost their bark (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-12 x 3-3.6 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 2 drops, with single septum when mature, irregularly uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 100-125 x 7-8 um, amyloid; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], tips with slight clavate thickenings, (Breitenbach), spores 9-14 x 3-5 um, elliptic, with oil drops at each end, biseriate, often becoming 1-septate; asci 8-spored, up to 135 x 10 um, cylindric-clavate, pore not distinctly blue with iodine; paraphyses slender, slightly widened upward and containing large yellow oil drops, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin meaning "lemon-like" from color^, (Lincoff(1))
SIMILAR  Bisporella sulfurina, illustrated by Desjardin(6) for California (as B. sulphurina), forms smaller cups (0.05-0.15cm across), gregariously or in small clusters on wood, growing "on or near old, black crustose fruitbodies of a pyrenomycete" - it has narrower spores 8-11 x 2-2.5 um. O. Ceska has identified B. sulfurina from BC.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Bisporella), Dennis(1) (as Bisporella), Phillips(1)* (as Bisporella), Lincoff(2)* (as Bisporella), Lincoff(1)* (as Bisporella), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)* (as Bisporella), Trudell(4)* (as Bisporella), Desjardin(6) (as Bisporella), Baral(2), Mitchell(1)*, MacKinnon(1)* (as Bisporella)
38
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Calyptella capula  (Holmsk. ex Pers.) Quel.^  Flore Mycol. France 25. 1878;  == Cyphella capula  (Holmsk. ex Pers.) Fr.;  == Chaetocypha capula  (Holmsk. ex Pers.) Kuntze
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, pitcher-shaped, pendant or erect, white to cream fruiting bodies +/- stem, growth on dead plant remains and dead wood, and microscopic characters including basidia.^ | According to R. Singer, C. capula (Holmsk. ex Fr.) Quel. sensu Donk has spores 5-6 um wide: similar species with narrower spores are often determined as Calyptella capula sensu Bourdot & Galzin, Reid. RANGE ^Calyptella capula is found at least in BC, WA, ID, and also AB, MB, NF, ON, FL, IL, LA, MA, MD, NC, NJ, NY, OH, SC, and VA, (Ginns).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.4(0.5)cm wide x 0.1-0.3cm deep, cup-shaped, dorsally stipitate, pendant, extremely fragile, discoid when young becoming conic to bell-shaped, spore-bearing upper surface smooth to radially furrowed or folded, whitish to pale gray or yellowish gray; margin incurved at first, flaring when old and becoming slightly eroded^, (Redhead(35)), 0.2-0.5cm in diameter, 0.1-0.3cm long, pitcher-shaped (with large body and small mouth), becoming discoid to funnel-shaped when old, pendant; spore-bearing surface whitish to gray; in some specimens cups rimmed with perpendicular hairs up to 25 um long, (Cooke), 0.2-0.5cm x 0.2-0.7cm, small erect or pendant cup, goblet-shaped to funnel-shaped, spore-bearing surface white to cream, smooth; margin wavy, smooth to slightly crenate [scalloped], (Breitenbach)
FLESH  very thin^ (Cooke), delicate, soft consistency, (Breitenbach)
UNDERSIDE  whitish to pale mouse gray, when old becoming blackish; bald or appearing frosted when magnified slightly^, (Redhead(35)), white to avellaneous, to gray and yellowish gray; smooth to almost floccose, (Cooke), white to cream, smooth, (Breitenbach)
STEM  0.02-0.2cm long, usually eccentric, solid; colored as receptacle or darker; often frosted or pubescent^, (Redhead(35)), 0.05-0.2cm long if present (Cooke), +/- stemmed, up to 0.2cm x 0.05cm, merging gradually to abruptly with cup, (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on senescent stems of Medicago sativa, Lathyrus sp., Lactuca serriola var. integrata, Cirsium arvense, Symphytum officinale, leaves of Carex sp.; in fields, swamps and wet depressions back of coastal dunes, near the ground level^, (Redhead(35)), gregarious, without subiculum, on dead wood and herbaceous litter (Cooke), dead wood, dead stems, herbs and grass litter, Carex sp., Cirsium arvense, Eupatorium sp., Foeniculum sp., Lactuca serriola, Lathyrus sp., Medicago sativa, Pelargonium zonale, Pteretis pensylvanica, Symphytum officinale, (Ginns), single to gregarious on dead plant remains and dead wood in damp places, (Breitenbach), summer to fall (Buczacki)
SPORE DEPOSIT  white^ (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  spores (6.4)8-9(10) x 4.0-5.6(6.2) um, elliptic to oboval, inequilateral, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled, colorless, with a prominent apiculus^; basidia 4-spored, 20-24 x 5-7 um, clamped, cylindric when young, becoming clavate, subhymenium: hyphae densely interwoven, noninflated, thin-walled, clamped; receptacle pellis: hyphae repent, radiating, noninflated, 2-5 um in diameter, becoming diverticulate and developing coralloid branches or ends especially at the rim, less diverticulate and becoming more elongated near the pseudostem, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled near pseudostem, trama: hyphae parallel, inflated, clamped, 3.2-16 um in diameter, walls hyaline to pale gray, inamyloid, (Redhead(35)), spores 6-11 x 3-4.5 um, ovate, flattened on one side smooth, colorless, apiculate; hairs up to 25 um long that are sometimes dichotomously branched and acanthophysoid; hymenium formed by tight palisade of basidia 21-25 um thick, basidia 16-23 x 3.5-8 um, 4-spored; context of clamped hyphae 2-3 um in diameter reaching 8 um in diameter in outer tissues of some specimens, (Cooke), spores 6-9 x 3.5-4.5 um, elliptic, somewhat flattened on one side, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; basidia 4-spored, 20-25 x 6-8 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; cystidia not seen; hyphal system monomitic, hyphae in subhymenium 2-4 um wide, septa with clamp connections, hyphae in stem and trama up to 15 um wide, "hyphal ends in the marginal part of the cup sinuous-gnarled with outgrowths", (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Calyptella campanula (reported from Ontario) varies in color from sulphur yellow to yellowish white in young stages to pale yellow to ochreous in older stages, and microscopically lacks the grayish walls of the tramal hyphae that characterize C. capula. Its diverticulate hyphae are less well developed. (Redhead(35)). Calyptella griseopallida (reported from Manitoba) is grayish to ochreous and is characterized by a repent covering of mycelial hairs that are generally smooth but occasionally become coralloid at their apices especially near the rim of the receptacle, (Redhead(35)).
SOURCES  Redhead(35), Cooke(2), Breitenbach(2)*, Redhead(21), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
39
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Capitotricha bicolor  (Bull.) Baral^  Beih. Z. Mykol. 6: 60. 1985;  Lachnum bicolor  (Bull.) P. Karst.;  Dasyscypha bicolor  Fuckel  Symb. Myc. 305. 1869;  Lachnella bicolor  (Bull.) W. Phillips
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small cup-shaped to saucer-shaped fruitbody with an egg-yellow to orange-yellow upper surface, the margin and exterior with a dense covering of white hairs, absent or very short stem, growth on hardwood branches and twigs and (var. rubi) thimbleberry and other Rubus canes (see SIMILAR), and microscopic characters including narrow spores and lanceolate paraphyses.^ | It is very common in the Pacific Northwest (Trudell(4)). RANGE ^It is found from NY to WA and AK to Mexico, and also in Europe, (Seaver), Switzerland (Breitenbach), United Kingdom (Dennis), and Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen). There are collections from BC at the University of British Columbia (some as Lachnella bicolor). Desjardin(6) illustrated it from CA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.2cm across, cup-shaped to saucer-shaped, when old plate-shaped; upper surface egg-yellow to orange-yellow, smooth; margin thickly set with long white hairs, strongly inrolled when dried^, (Breitenbach), reaching 0.1-0.2cm across, at first closed, becoming expanded; spore-bearing upper surface nearly flat, orange-yellow, (Seaver), disc concealed by the incurved hairs when dry, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  thickly set with long white hairs^ (Breitenbach), with dense covering of white hairs (Seaver)
STEM  more or less stemless^, (Breitenbach), without stem, or with short stem, (Seaver), tiny, densely covered with white hairs, (Phillips)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  not edible (Phillips)
HABITAT  found most frequently on old canes of salmonberry and other Rubus species, but also common on branches of hardwoods such as Alnus (alder)^, (Trudell), gregarious to cespitose on fallen twigs and branches of hardwoods, (Breitenbach), closely gregarious, or scattered, on small twigs of various trees and shrubs, (Seaver), on small twigs, July to September, (Phillips), on deciduous twigs (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 1.5-2 um, fusiform [spindle-shaped] to fusiform-clavate, smooth, colorless, biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 50 x 4.5 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses projecting beyond the asci, lanceolate; hairs colorless, thin-walled, septate, with fine granular encrustation and sometimes a tuft of crystals at tip, (Breitenbach), spores 6-12 x 1.5-2 um, fusiform, straight or slightly curved; asci reaching a length of 40-50 um and width of 5-6 um, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses lanceolate, very sharply pointed; hairs reaching a length of 200 um and width of 4 um, colorless, "cylindric, septate, externally roughened with granules", often with crystalline caps, (Seaver), paraphyses considerably longer than the asci, 5 um wide, lanceolate, (Dennis), spores 6-11 x 1-2 um; paraphyses lance-shaped, projecting beyond the asci, hairs "encrusted with granular material that sometimes forms discrete crystals", (Trudell), paraphyses exceeding asci by 10-15 um (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'two-colored'
SIMILAR  Capitotricha rubi (Bres.) Baral is regarded by some as a variety of Capitotricha bicolor. There are collections by F. Rhoades 1980 and D. Stuntz 1966 and 1968 from WA at the University of Washington. Haines(1) describes collections from western Washington, differentiating it by longer spores 8-11 um (as opposed to 7-9 um for Lachnum bicolor), shorter hairs (up to 250 um, as opposed to up to 350 um for Lachnum bicolor) and habitat on Rubus, especially last year's stems of R. parviflorus - thimbleberry, (as opposed to hardwoods, especially Alnus, for Lachnum bicolor). Lachnum pygmaeum has a definite stem.
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Lachnella), Breitenbach(1)* (as Dasyscyphus bicolor), Dennis(1) (as Dasyscyphus bicolor), Trudell(4)* (as Dasyscyphus bicolor), Phillips(1)* (as Dasyscyphus bicolor), Hansen, L.(1) (as Lachnum bicolor), Desjardin(6)* (as Dasyscyphus bicolor), Haines(1)
40
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cenangium acuum  Cooke & Peck, Cooke & Ellis^  Grevillea 7: 40. 1878;  Mollisia pinastri  Sacc.;  Cenangium acicola  Fuckel ex Rehm
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute cups that erupt as spheres from pine and juniper needles, then open into reddish brown cups with irregular margins, the cup exterior darker reddish brown and pruinose, absent stem, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Cenangium acuum is found in NY and NJ to BC, and also Europe, (Seaver), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.1cm across, "erumpent through the epidermis of the host, at first closed, soon opening with an irregular aperture leaving the margin irregularly toothed"; spore-bearing upper surface concave or nearly flat, lighter reddish brown than outside of fruitbody^, (Seaver), 0.1-0.2cm across, erumpent, spherical and closed, then cup-shaped, with tear-shaped openings, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  reddish brown (Seaver), dark brown; pruinose, (Hansen)
STEM  none^ (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on needles of Pinus strobus and other pine species^, (Seaver), on needles of Pinus (pine) and Juniperus (juniper), early summer to early fall, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-14 x 3-4 um, fusoid^; asci 8-spored, reaching length of 80-100 um and a width of 8-10 um, narrowing downwards into an abrupt stem-like base; paraphyses filiform, enlarged in upper part, reaching a diameter of 2-3 um, (Seaver), spores 10-16 x 4-6 um, narrowly elliptic to cylindric, non-septate, guttulate; asci inamyloid; paraphyses colorless, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Cenangium ferruginosum grows only on Pinus. It has larger fruitbodies (0.2-0.3cm across) and the spores are broadly elliptic to fusoid (12-14 x 5-6 um). (Hansen). R. Bandoni deposited collections at University of British Columbia of Cenangium alniellum, Cenangium griseum, and Cenangium vaccinii.
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Hansen, L.(1)
41
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cenangium ferruginosum  Fr.^  Vet. Akad. Handl.  1818. 361. 1818;  Cenangium abietis  (Pers.) Rehm;  Cenangium abietis  (Pers.) Duby
ENGLISH NAME(S)  pine die-back
NOTES  Features include minute, yellowish brown cup-shaped fruitbodies with a dark reddish brown powdery coating on the exterior, almost no stem, growth on branches of pine and other conifers, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Cenangium ferruginosum is found in northeastern North America to OR, CA and AL, (Seaver), and WA (Kanouse). It is also found in Europe including United Kingdom (Dennis), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen). There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.3cm wide, at first spherical and closed then turbinate [top-shaped] and then "opening by an irregularly torn aperture", deeply concave; spore-bearing upper surface ochraceous, hidden by inrolled margin when dry^, (Dennis), 0.1-0.15cm wide, at first nearly spherical, later opening irregularly, expanding and becoming somewhat top-shaped, often irregular by pressure from neighboring cups, margin turned in when dry; yellowish to olive-brown, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  exterior dark brown and pruinose or mealy^, (Dennis), coated with a reddish brown powder, (Seaver)
STEM  subsessile [almost no stem]^, (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  singly or in small clusters on dead twigs and small branches of Pinus^, (Dennis), "gregarious, usually occurring in cespitose clusters", "on branches of various species of Pinus, Abies, Picea and probably other conifers", (Seaver), on twigs and small branches of Pinus, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-14 x 5-6 um, elliptic-fusiform, colorless, non-septate, sometimes 2-seriate in upper part of ascus^; asci up to 80 x 15 um, cylindric-clavate, broadly rounded in upper part, pore not blue with iodine; paraphyses about 2 um thick, slender, colorless, "septate, swollen to 4-5 um at the clavate tips when are embedded in a layer of firm mucilage, contents yellowish, oily", (Dennis), spores 10-14 x 5-7 um, elliptic, 1-seriate or partly 2-seriate; asci 8-spored, reaching length 100-120 um and width 12-18 um, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses about 2 um wide, simple, stout, slightly enlarged in upper part, pale yellowish, (Seaver), spores 12-14 x 5-6 um, broadly elliptic to fusoid, non-septate, guttulate; asci inamyloid; paraphyses colorless, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means "ferruginous", presumably referring to reddish-brown powder that coats exterior
SIMILAR  Cenangium acuum grows on Juniperus as well as Pinus. It has smaller fruitbodies (0.1-0.2cm) and the spores are narrowly elliptic to cylindric, (10-16 x 4-6 um). (Hansen). R. Bandoni deposited collections at University of British Columbia of Cenangium alniellum, Cenangium griseum, and Cenangium vacinii.
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Cenangium abietis), Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6)
42
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Chaetothiersia vernalis  B.A. Perry & Pfister^  Fungal Diversity 28: 69. 2008
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a pale gray cup that has a narrow base at first but expands to disc-shaped or convoluted, 2) cup exterior and margin with dark to pale brown hairs, more or less appressed and sometimes projecting, 3) growth on decaying conifer wood and bark, and 4) microscopic characters including smooth, elliptic spores without droplets, hairs on the exterior and margin that are brown, non-rooting, and stiff, a dense medullary excipulum of textura intricata, and a very thin ectal excipulum of globose to angular-globose cells.^ | The description is derived from Perry(5). RANGE ^The holotype is from CA, where it was found in the Northern High Sierra mountains. It has been identified in OR as well (see iNat 79378143).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-3.0cm across, deeply cup-shaped fruitbody with a narrow base at first, "expanding to discoid" and tending to become +/- convoluted, "larger forms often appressed to the substrate"; inner spore-bearing surface pale gray to nearly white, smooth
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  exterior of cup +/- colored as the inner spore-bearing surface, "densely to sparsely covered with dark to pale brown", stiff, +/- appressed and occasionally projecting hairs with blunt tips
STEM  with a narrow base at first
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to cespitose (tufted) on decaying wood and bark of conifers and on woody debris in soil; fruiting April to June, associated with moisture produced by spring snowmelt
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16.8-18.4(19.2) x 10-11.2(12) um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, "not refractive in media containing lactic acid, with granular cytoplasmic contents", without droplets, often collapsing in media other than water^; asci 8-spored, 304-380 x 8-16 um, cylindric, operculate, iodine negative, "arising from a pleurorhynchous base", paraphyses 1.6-2.4 um wide, exceeding asci by up to 10.4 um, "equal to barely expanding apically, straight, multiseptate, unbranched", colorless; |hymenium 300-400 um thick; medullary excipulum up to 840 um in sections 1-2 mm inward from margin, composed of densely compacted textura intricata, cells 1.6-6.4 um wide; ectal excipulum only a few cells thick, up to 40 um, "extending beyond hymenium to form distinct margin, composed of angular-globose to broadly clavate cells" 4.8-16 um in diameter, (also referred to as "globose to angular-globose"), "tending to form small irregular pustules"; |excipular hairs 60-720 x 4-14.4 um, brown to nearly colorless, multiseptate, thick-walled (up to 2.4 um), "apically rounded, arising from angular-globose cells of the ectal excipulum, those near the margin typically straight and projecting, those of the receptacle often flexuous and quite narrowed apically" (about 2 um wide), "interspersed with shorter, broader forms"
NAME ORIGIN  "vernalis" means "pertaining to spring" (Perry(5))
SIMILAR  Humaria hemisphaerica has ornamented spores with droplets (Perry(5)). |Trichophaea spores have a droplet or droplets (Perry(5)). |Paratrichophaea species have hairs that are a) typically rooting, b) acuminate, c) often bifurcating basally, and d) arising from the medullary excipulum, whereas the hairs in C. vernalis are superficial, arising from the ectal excipulum, and are rounded at the tip (Perry(5)). | Trichophaeopsis species are smaller and have "ectal cells arranged in distinct vertical rows, and often forked excipular hairs which tend to have a long branch pointing upwards, relative to the orientation of the apothecium, and a shorter branch pointing down", (Perry(5)).
SOURCES  Perry(5)*
43
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cheilymenia fimicola  (Bagl.) Dennis^  British Ascomycetes, Rev. Edn: 45. 1978;  = Cheilymenia coprinaria  (Cooke) Boud.;  = Patella coprinaria  (Cooke) Seaver;  = Scutellinia coprinaria  (Cooke) Kuntze;  = Lachnea coprinaria  (Cooke) Sacc.;  = Patella michiganensis  Povah;  = Scutellinia michiganensis  (Povah) Povah
ENGLISH NAME(S)  eyelash dung cup
NOTES  Features include a saucer-shaped to disc-shaped fruiting body with orange spore-bearing upper surface that becomes yellowish or brownish when old, cup exterior with abundant dark brown hairs, lack of a stem, growth on dung, and microscopic characters.^ | Cheilymenia coprinaria (Cooke) Boud. was given as a synonym of Cheilymenia fimicola (Bagl.) Dennis in the online Species Fungorum accessed February 4, 2017, but MycoBank, accessed on the same date, listed them separately. RANGE ^Cheilymenia fimicola is found in BC, WA, OR, and ID, and also CA, CO, and UT, (Larsen), and OR, MI, NE, OH, NC, NY, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, and Great Britain, (Denison).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-0.5(0.7)cm, saucer-shaped to disc-shaped, orange, becoming yellowish or brownish when old^, (Denison), (0.1)0.3-0.7(1)cm, "at first closed but soon opening to become shallowly cup-shaped" to disc-like or somewhat cushion-shaped; orange to pale orange becoming yellow or brownish when old; smooth; "margin fringed with minute dark brown hairs, often wavy", (Arora), up to 1cm wide, at first closed, expanding and becoming scutellate to discoid; spore-bearing upper surface flat or concave, bright yellow to pale orange; margin slightly wavy, pale yellow, sparingly clothed with hairs, (Seaver), reddish orange, fading to yellowish orange when old, (Trudell)
FLESH  thin^ (Arora)
UNDERSIDE  abundant dark brown hairs^ (Denison), paler than upper surface, clothed with dark hairs, (Arora)
STEM  none^ (Arora)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to gregarious, on dung^, (Denison), single to densely gregarious "on dung and manure or compost, etc., fruiting in wet weather", (Arora), gregarious or scattered on dung (Seaver), on cow patties as well as the droppings of wild animals, (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (13)14-17(20) x (6)7-9(11) um, elliptic to nearly cylindric, smooth, without oil droplets^; asci 140-165 um long, cylindric, not blueing in iodine; paraphyses narrowly clavate, 5-7 um broad at apices, simple, the upper third nonseptate, [presumably when fresh there are granules or droplets of yellow to red pigmented material]; hairs 175-700 um long, and 20-30 um wide near base, heavy-walled, 3-8 septate, unbranched but conspicuously forked and rooting at base, narrowing in upper part to sharp point, (Denison), spores (14)17-22(25) x 8-12 um, elliptic, smooth, without oil droplets, (Arora)
NAME ORIGIN  from 'copros', Greek for 'dung'
SIMILAR  Cheilymenia stercorea is smaller, with hairs that differ microscopically (Denison). C. stercorea differs in having stellate 3-5-armed hairs on the lower part of the cup, (Dennis). Cheilymenia theleboloides has scattered inconspicuous hairs that differ microscopically (Denison). C. theleboloides has more yellow cups with whitish hairs, and "occurs on rotting plant remains, or horse manure and straw", (Trudell). Scutellinia crucipila is smaller and has hairs that differ microscopically, (Denison). S. crucipila "grows among mosses or on bare ground under grasses or other herbaceous plants" and "has branched brownish hairs near the base of the cup", (Trudell).
SOURCES  Denison(1) (as Cheilymenia coprinaria), Arora(1)* (as Cheilymenia coprinaria), Larsen(1) (as Cheilymenia coprinaria), Seaver(1) (as Patella coprinaria), Trudell(4)*, Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Desjardin(6)*
44
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cheilymenia stercorea  (Pers.) Boud.^  Icon. Mycol. (Paris) 2: pl. 384. 1907;  == Scutellinia stercorea  (Pers. ex Fr.) Kuntze;  == Patella stercorea  (Pers. ex Fr.) Seaver;  == Lachnea stercorea  (Pers. ex Fr.) Gillet 
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a saucer-shaped to shallow cup-shaped fruiting body with a red orange spore-bearing upper surface that becomes yellowish or brownish when old, the cup exterior with hairs of two types (far-projecting ones particularly at the margin and shorter, stellate ones toward the base of the cup), lack of a stem, growth on dung, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Cheilymenia stercorea is found in BC, WA, OR, ID, and also CA, CO, and NV, (Larsen), and BC, CA, CO, MT, NY, and OH, (Denison).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.3cm, saucer-shaped to shallow cup-shaped, red orange, becoming yellowish or brownish when old^, (Denison), 0.1-0.3cm, conic with flat disc, spore-bearing upper surface orange; margin "ciliated with far-projecting light brown hairs", (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  hairs of two types: bristle-like rooting hairs at margin, mingled in lower part with stellate hairs^, (Denison), paler than spore-bearing surface, "loosely set with long, pointed, upright, bristly, brownish hairs, somewhat felty toward the base with mostly short hairs", (Breitenbach)
STEM  none^ (Denison)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to gregarious on dung^, (Denison), single or gregarious on cow and deer manure, perhaps on dung of other animals, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (12)14-18(19) x (6)8-10(11) um, elliptic, smooth, without oil droplets^; asci 175-220 x 9-12 um, cylindric, not blueing in iodine; paraphyses slender, narrowly clavate in upper part, 3-5 um broad at top, simple or sparingly branched in lower part, with a few widely spaced septa, [presumably when fresh there are granules or droplets of yellow to red pigmented material]; rooting hairs 100-300 um long, 12-24 um wide near base, medium brown, "heavy-walled, 5-12 septate, unbranched, with a number of bulbous rootlike processes at base"; stellate hairs "pale yellow to medium brown, consisting of a swollen basal cell from which project several (2-5) pointed, septate, stiff arms, the arms highly variable in length", (Denison), spores 17.5-19 x 8-9 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, without droplets, uniseriate; asci 8-spored, 225-230 x 12-13 um, inamyloid; paraphyses slender, septate, forked; hairs on the margin and upper part of the fruitbody to 700 x 10-20 um, "straight, ending in a point, multiply septate, base with multiply forked to lobed roots, brownish"; hairs toward the base of fruitbody "stellate, multiply forked and septate, also brownish", (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  from 'stercus' Latin for 'dung'
SIMILAR  Cheilymenia fimicola is larger, with hairs that differ microscopically, (Denison). Cheilymenia theleboloides has scattered inconspicuous hairs that differ microscopically, (Denison). Scutellinia crucipila has similar basal hairs but is larger, grows on soil, is not ciliated with bristles, and has punctate spores under oil immersion, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Denison(1), Breitenbach(1)*, Larsen(1) 
45
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cheilymenia theleboloides  (Alb. & Schwein. ex Fr.) Boud.^  Histoire et Classification des Discomycetes d'Europe (Paris): 62. 1907;  == Scutellinia theleboloides  (Alb. & Schwein. ex Fr.) Kuntze;  = Lachnea ascoboloides  (Bertero ex Mont.) Massee;  = Neottiella ascoboloides  (Bertero ex Mont.) Sacc.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small saucer-shaped to disc-shaped fruiting bodies with golden yellow spore-bearing upper surface; inconspicuous hairs on the exterior and margin; lack of stem; growth on dung, soil, decaying vegetable matter, or other substrates; and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Cheilymenia theleboloides is found in WA, OR, ID, and also AB, CA, CO, and WY, (Larsen), and WA, NC, NY, Bermuda, Chile, Costa Rica, Germany, and the United Kingdom, ("cosmopolitan and common"), (Denison), Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Norway (Perry).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.5(1)cm, saucer-shaped to disc-shaped, golden yellow, becoming reddish brown in drying^, (Denison), up to 0.6cm wide, saucer-shaped, disc flat; egg-yellow, (Dennis), 0.5-1cm, cup-shaped to saucer-shaped, spore-bearing upper surface orange to olive-yellow; margin "somewhat darker and turned outward when mature", with sparse and indistinct colorless hairs, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  comparatively few hairs, yellow-brown to almost transparent, the longest ones at the margin^, (Denison), paler than spore-bearing surface, clothed with inconspicuous, scattered, colorless to yellowish-brown pointed hairs, (Dennis), colored the same as spore-bearing surface, orange to olive-yellow; with sparse and indistinct colorless hairs, (Breitenbach)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to crowded on dung, rich soil, or decaying plant debris^, (Denison), cow dung or occasionally rich soil, rubbish, paper, cloth, etc., (Seaver), "on spent hops, less often on leaf-mould or lime waste," (Dennis), gregarious on rotting remains of plants and decomposed paper, as well as horse manure mixed with straw, (Breitenbach), "on rotting plant remains, or horse manure and straw", (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (15)17-20(22) x (7)8-10(11) um, elliptic, smooth, without oil droplets^; asci 180-220 x 10-15 um, cylindric, not turning blue in iodine; paraphyses slender, infrequently septate, subclavate at apices, 3-4 um in lower part, 5-7 um at apices; the longest hairs at margin 170-800 um long, 8-10 um wide just above base, the base often swollen to 15-25 um wide, yellow brown to nearly transparent, 1-4(6)-septate, straight, unbranched, narrowing slightly, usually with blunt tip, originating from superficial cells of ectal excipulum, (Denison), spores 12-18 x 7-10 um, smooth, without droplets; asci up to 250 x 14 um; paraphyses slender, slightly clavate, yellowish at tip; hairs up to 220 x 20 um, the wall 1 um thick, 1-3-septate, (Dennis), spores 15-20 x 9-10.5 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, without drops; asci 8-spored, 250 x 13.5 um, inamyloid; paraphyses slender, cylindric, septate, tips with slight clavate thickening to 6 um; hairs to 200 x 16.5 um, colorless, thin-walled, 1-3(4)-septate, ending in a point, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like Thelebolus'
SIMILAR  Cheilymenia fimicola and Cheilymenia stercorea have numerous dark brown hairs that differ microscopically (Denison). Scutellinia crucipila has numerous hairs that differ microscopically. Seaver placed Lachnea diplotricha Rehm (=Humaria diplotricha (Rehm) Kanouse) in synonymy with Patella theleboloides, but Kanouse points out that the spore size from her WA collection (14-16 x 8-9 um) is closer to Rehm's measurements (14-15 x 7-7.5) than to those of C. theleboloides, and that the WA specimens were growing on bare soil and were some shade of orange rather than yellow, (Kanouse).
SOURCES  Denison(1), Dennis(1), Seaver(1), Larsen(1), Breitenbach(1)*, Kanouse(6), Trudell(4), Perry(2)
46
FAMILY  Hemiphacidiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Chlorencoelia versiformis  (Pers.) J.R. Dixon^  Mycotaxon 1(3): 224. 1975;  == Helotium versiforme  (Pers.) Fr.;  Chlorosplenium versiforme  (Pers.) de Not;  == Coryne versiformis  (Pers.) Schroet.;  == Chlorociboria versiformis  (Pers.) Seaver ex C.S. Ramamurthi, Korf & L.R. Batra;  Midotis versiformis  (Pers.) Seaver;  = Craterellus caespitosus  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small fruitbody that is shallow cup-shaped to funnel-shaped or ear-shaped, colored olive-yellow to olive green, with the underside and stem dark olive-green to brownish olive, and microscopic characters.^ | Ramamurthi(1) comment in 1957 that about half of the collections they examined in North America that were determined as Chlorociboria versiformis proved to be Chlorociboria rugipes (Peck) C.S. Ramamurthi & Korf, which Dixon(1) later considered a synonym of Chlorencoelia torta. The description of Chlorencoelia versiformis here is derived from Dixon(1). RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, ON, PQ, MI, MN, NC, NH, NY, OH, PA, WV, Argentina, Denmark, Russia, Sweden, Yugoslavia, and Japan, (Dixon).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody up to 0.9(1.7)cm in diameter, mostly 0.7-0.9cm in diameter, shallow cup-shaped to funnel-shaped, "becoming convex-expanded to repand in mature specimens, occasionally revolute", may be spatulate [spatula-shaped] or otideoid [ear-shaped, like Otidea]; olive-yellow to olive-green when fresh becoming chestnut brown to black upon drying
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  dark olive-green to brownish olive when fresh, drying dark brown or greenish black, with a pruinose greenish yellow cast when dry; furrowed to rugose [wrinkled]
STEM  up to 0.7cm x 0.05-0.1cm, colored as the exterior; bald, rugose [wrinkled] especially on drying
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  superficial, single to gregarious, occasionally in cespitose clusters from a common stem, on decayed wood of conifers and hardwood trees, collected on Betula (birch), Nothofagus (southern beech), Quercus (oak), Tsuga (hemlock), and unidentified wood; fruiting in summer and fall, most frequently in fall
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (10)11-15(16) x 2.5-3.5 um, cylindric-oblong to allantoid, smooth, colorless, unicellular to 1-septate, having 0 to 2, 3, 4 droplets, occasionally also with several smaller droplets, irregularly biseriate in the ascus^; asci 8-spored, (79)95-130(150) x (4)5-8 um, cylindric-clavate with long tapering stems, strongly iodine positive, apex rounded to subconic [somewhat conic], wall at apex 1.5-3 um thick, 0.5-1.0 um thick along the sides, arising from repeated croziers; paraphyses 2-3 um wide, scarcely longer than the asci, filiform [thread-like], occasionally subclavate at the tip, "unbranched or branching near the base with the point of branching being so low in some specimens as to appear unbranched", colorless or filled with numerous guttules [droplets] and/or green granules; hymenium (80)95-130(145) um thick, colorless with occasional brown parts "due to abundance of pigmented paraphyses"; subhymenium 20-35 um thick, of colorless and/or light brown - walled textura intricata, with colorless or brown contents, hyphae 2.4-4.0 um wide; medullary excipulum of colorless to light brown, loose to tightly compacted textura intricata, parts often with collapsed hyphae, hyphae 3-5 um wide, "smooth or more often roughened with dark brown granulations, sympodially branched"; ectal excipulum 25-100 um thick, of colorless to dark-walled textura intricata to textura angularis that gives rise to filamentous to slightly clavate tomentum hyphae oriented nearly perpendicularly to the flanks of the fruitbody, "hyphae at the base of the tomentum hyphae often highly septate, forming cuboid cells of various sizes", tomentum hyphae 5-7 um wide, with colorless walls 0.25(1.5) um wide, "in occasional specimens tomentum hyphae containing green pigment and/or granules"
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "verso", meaning "to turn up, to turn hither and thither", plus "formo", meaning "to shape or form", "referring to the fact that the shape of the apothecium may be spathuloid or otideoid and sometimes convoluted", (Dixon)
SIMILAR  Chlorencoelia torta (Schwein.) J.R. Dixon differs in having somewhat smaller fruitbodies (usually less than 0.7cm in diameter), irregularly elliptic spores (5.6)9-11(12) x 2-4 um, medullary excipulum of dark-walled hyphae, and ectal excipulum of stemmed, nearly spherical to definitely clavate tomentum hyphae, whereas C. versiformis fruitbodies are 0.7-0.9(1.7)cm in diameter, spores are cylindric to allantoid, (10)11-15(16) x 2.5-3.5, medullary excipulum is of colorless to light brown - walled hyphae, and ectal excipulum produces filamentous to slightly clavate tomentum hyphae. Collections of C. torta were examined from ON, PQ, AL, CT, GA, IN, IA, KY, MA, ME, MI, NC, NJ, NY, OH, PA, VA, WI, Puerto Rico, Russia, Japan, Australia and New Zealand. (Dixon).
SOURCES  Dixon(1), Ramamurthi(1)
47
FAMILY  Chlorociboriaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Chlorociboria aeruginascens  (Nyl.) Kanouse ex C.S. Ramamurthi, Korf & L.R. Batra^  Mycologia 49: 858 (1958) [1957];  Chlorosplenium aeruginascens  (Nyl.) P. Karst.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  green stain, green cups, green wood-cups
NOTES  Features include a blue-green fruitbody on wood with off-center (infrequently central) stem and microscopic characters including smooth tomentum hyphae. (Its close relative C. aeruginosa has central to slightly off-center stem, larger spores and granularly roughened tomentum hyphae.) Blue-green staining of wood is more commonly seen than the fruitbodies.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, ID, and also ON, PQ, AK, CA, CO, GA, IA, ME, MA, MI, MN, NC, NH, NJ, NY, OH, TN, VT, WI, Cuba, Greenland, Venezuela, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, Netherlands, Sweden, Ukraine, United Kingdom, Armenia, China, Georgia, India, Japan, Philippines, and Russia, (Dixon). B. Callan has determined collections from BC of both Chlorociboria aeruginosa and C. aeruginascens deposited at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  less than 0.7cm across, cup-shaped to spathulate when young, becoming expanded - funnel-shaped when fully mature; color varying from light orange-yellow to colored as exterior (underside) to whitish-pale-green, on drying becoming slightly darker^, (Dixon), up to 0.7cm across, "turquoise to greenish or olivaceous", (Trudell)
FLESH  thin^ (Lincoff), on breaking, stem showing cortex and interior both colored as exterior, (Dixon), same color as exterior (underside) (Trudell)
UNDERSIDE  bluish-aeruginous; bald or finely tomentose, lower part furrowed and rugose especially on drying^, (Dixon)
STEM  less than 0.6cm long and 0.1-0.15cm thick, off-center to infrequently central; colored as exterior; frequently with several fruitbodies arising from a darkly pigmented and irregularly shaped fundament or "stromatic mass"^, (Dixon), fruitbodies often arising from a common base (Trudell)
ODOR  none^ (Miller)
TASTE  unknown^ (Miller)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious on barkless and decayed wood; spring, summer, and fall^, (Dixon), on rotting logs and barkless wood, especially oak, (Lincoff)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-7(10) x 1.0-1.5(2.4) um (average 6 x 1.5 um), fusiform to elliptic-fusiform, smooth, colorless or with light green contents with bipolar droplets, unicellular, irregularly biseriate^; asci 8-spored, (40)50-65(75) x 3-4(5) um; paraphyses scarcely extending beyond asci, (1)1.5(2) um wide, filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, blunt at tip, branching near base; ectal excipulum gives rise "to few to numerous, coiled or sometimes straight, smooth-walled tomentum hyphae", tomentum hyphae 1.0-1.5(2) um wide, (Dixon), spores 5-8 x 1-2 um (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  "from Latin, aeruginosus, deep-green with a mixture of blue, + -ascens, becoming, perhaps referring to the fact that the wood becomes aeruginous"^, (Dixon)
SIMILAR  Chlorociboria aeruginascens has a stem that is usually off-center (infrequently central), whereas the stem of Chlorociboria aeruginosa is usually central (rarely off-center); C. aeruginascens often has several fruitbodies arising from each darkly pigmented irregularly shaped fundament or "stromatic mass", whereas C. aeruginosa arises singly from a scarcely differentiated stromatic mass; spores of C. aeruginosa are (8)9-14(15) x 2-4 um, asci are (57)68-80(95) x (4)5-7(7.5) um and ectal excipulum gives rise "to few to numerous, straight or coiled, strongly granularly roughened tomentum hyphae", (Dixon, who also describes interior stem flesh as orange yellow in C. aeruginosa and bluish aeruginous in C. aeruginascens). C. aeruginosa has smaller fruitbodies (less than 0.5cm across as opposed to up to 0.7cm) that usually arise singly as opposed to several arising from a common base, yellow-orange flesh instead of the same color as the exterior, and larger spores, (Trudell).
SOURCES  Dixon(1), Trudell(4)*, Dennis(1) (as Chlorosplenium aeruginascens), Seaver(2) (as Chlorociboria aeruginosa (Oed.) Seaver, for which he gives as synonyms the names used above), Phillips(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Miller(14)* (as Chlorosplenium aeruginascens), Arora(1), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6), Courtecuisse(1)*, Sept(1)*, Bacon(1)*, Buczacki(1)*, Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2)*, MacKinnon(1)*
48
FAMILY  Chlorociboriaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Chlorociboria aeruginosa  (Pers. per Pers.) Seaver ex Ramamurthi, Korf & L.R. Batra^  Mycologia 49(6): 859 (1958) [1957]
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a blue green fruitbody on wood with a central to slightly off-center stem and microscopic characters including granularly roughened tomentum hyphae. (The close relative C. aeruginascens has off-center stem, smaller spores and smooth tomentum hyphae). Blue-green staining of wood is more commonly seen than the fruitbodies.^ | The description is derived from Dixon except where specified. RANGE ^Collections were examined from WA, OR, ID, and also PQ, CA, IN, MI, MN, NH, NY, OH, PA, WY, Costa Rica, Jamaica, Mexico, Panama, Argentina, Brazil, Venezuela, Ukraine, United Kingdom, China, India, Japan, Philippines, and Russia, (Dixon). B. Callan has determined collections from BC of both Chlorociboria aeruginosa and C. aeruginascens deposited at the Pacific Forestry Centre. 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  less than 0.5cm across, cup-shaped to rarely convex-flat, "the edges of the disc enrolling to the point of often touching"; color varying even in the same collection from orange-yellow to almost concolorous with the exterior (underside) to light pea-green when fresh, becoming slightly darker to greenish black on drying^, (Dixon), less than 0.5cm, "turquoise to greenish or olivaceous", (Trudell), yellowish to pale green (Hansen, L.)
FLESH  the stem on breaking shows an aeruginous cortex with orange-yellow interior^ (Dixon), yellow-orange (Trudell), orange-yellow (Arora), orange flesh not observed in at least some Washington collections, (M. Beug, pers. comm.)
UNDERSIDE  aeruginous when fresh, becoming bluish-aeruginous on drying; bald or finely tomentose, pustulate, often vertically ribbed or rugose, especially on drying
STEM  less than 0.3cm x 0.05-0.1cm, central to slightly off-center; colored as exterior; pustulate (often more so than exterior)^, (Dixon), usually arising singly (Trudell)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious on decayed and barkless wood; spring, summer, and fall
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (8)9-14(15) x 2-4 um (average 13 x 3 um), fusiform-elliptic, colorless or with light green contents, unicellular to submedian 1-septate, with 2 prominent droplets and/or with several smaller droplets, irregularly biseriate^, spores often germinating in the ascus by unipolar or bipolar germ tubes, with occasional round to nearly round microconidia 1.0-2.5 um in diameter "being produced at the ends of the germ tube and floating free in the mounting media"; asci 8-spored, (57)68-80(95) x (4)5-7(7.5) um; paraphyses scarcely extending beyond asci, (1)1.5(2) um wide, filiform, blunt at tip, colorless, septate, branching near base; ectal excipulum gives rise "to few to numerous, straight or coiled, strongly granularly roughened tomentum hyphae" (if tomentum seems absent, check the margin of the fruitbody), (Dixon), spores 9-14 x 2-4 um (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  "from Latin, aeruginosus, deep-green, with a mixture of blue, referring to color of fruitbody"^, (Dixon)
SIMILAR  Chlorociboria aeruginascens has a stem that is usually off-center (infrequently central), whereas the stem of Chlorociboria aeruginosa is usually central (rarely off-center). C. aeruginascens often has several fruitbodies arising from each darkly pigmented irregularly shaped fundament or "stromatic mass", whereas C. aeruginosa arises singly from scarcely differentiated stromatic mass. Spores of C. aeruginascens are 5-7(10) x 1.0-1.5(2.4) um, asci are (40)50-65(75) x 3-4(5) um and the ectal excipulum gives rise "to few to numerous, coiled or sometimes straight, smooth-walled tomentum hyphae". (Dixon, who also describes interior stem flesh as orange yellow in C. aeruginosa and bluish aeruginous in C. aeruginascens). C. aeruginascens has larger fruitbodies up to 0.7cm (as opposed to less than 0.5cm), several often arising from a common base instead of arising singly, flesh that is the same color as the exterior instead of yellow-orange, and small spores 5-8 x 1-2 um, (Trudell).
SOURCES  Dixon(1), Arora(1), Hansen, L.(1), Trudell(4), Desjardin(6)*
49
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Chloroscypha alutipes  (W. Phillips) Dennis^  Persoonia 3(1): 34. 1964;  Kriegeria alutipes  (W. Phillips) Seaver  The North American Cup Fungi (Inoperculates) p.103. 1951;  Phialea alutipes  Sacc.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute yellowish to pale brown fruitbody that is yellowish green with transmitted light, with or without a stem, growth on dead foliage of Libocedrus decurrens, and microscopic characters.^ | The genus Kriegeria Rab. used by Seaver has been absorbed into Rutstroemia P. Karst. RANGE ^Chloroscypha alutipes is found in OR and CA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.2cm across, spore-bearing upper surface similar in color to underside (yellowish to pale brown, darker, almost black in dried specimens)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  yellowish to pale brown, darker, almost black in dried specimens, yellowish green with transmitted light^, (Seaver)
STEM  with stem short or up to 0.1-0.2cm long, or subsessile [almost without stem], stem gradually widening into the upper part of the fruitbody^, (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on dead foliage of Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-Cedar)^, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT
