MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-20 x 5-8 um, fusoid, multinucleate^; asci reaching a length of 90 um and a width of 10-12 um; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], rather abruptly widened in upper part, the ends agglutinated together and surrounded with a yellowish substance, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'leather-stem'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Kriegeria), Desjardin(6)*
50
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Chloroscypha flavida  (Kanouse & A.H. Sm.) Baral^  in Baral, Galan, Platas & Tena, Mycosystema 32(3): 421. 2013;  Gelatinodiscus flavidus  Kanouse & A.H. Sm.  Mycologia 32: 756. 1940
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly Category. Chloroscypha flavida forms concave to convex, stemmed, yellow, gelatinous fruitbodies growing on the dead foliage, twigs, and cones of Yellow-cedar, near or under melting snowbanks.^ RANGE ^It has been found at least in WA and OR, (Castellano), and BC (collections at the University of British Columbia).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.5cm across, up to 0.4cm tall, the spore-bearing upper surface at first concave becoming flat then convex when mature, bright yellow, opaque, even; margin bald, not extending beyond spore-bearing surface^, (Castellano), reaching 0.5cm across, opening cup-shaped, becoming convex; "yellow ochre" throughout, drying "dark olive" (Ridgway colors), shrinking greatly with drying, (Kanouse(7))
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  bright yellow, colored as spore-bearing surface, appearing translucent or gelatinous; bald except for short yellow fuzz at base^, (Castellano)
STEM  0.2-0.5cm long and about 0.1cm wide^, (Castellano), 0.2-0.5cm x 0.1cm, broadly attached to substrate, (Kanouse(7))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to gregarious on cones, twigs, and foliage of Cupressus nootkatensis (Yellow-cedar), consistently near or under melting snowbanks, April through August^, (Castellano), on Cupressus nootkatensis lying in seepage from a snowbank, (Kanouse(7))
SPORE DEPOSIT  brown^ (Castellano)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 26-34 x 9-11 um, nearly elliptic to oblong-elliptic but with one end broader than the other, smooth, colorless to yellow at first, with 2 droplets^; asci 8-spored, opening by a broad pore, amyloid in part of the apical region, maturing simultaneously; paraphyses colorless, branched, curved at apices, (Castellano), spores 26-34 x 9-11 um, oblong-elliptic, smooth, greenish-yellow, with 2 large oil droplets, biseriate; asci 8-spored, 150-160 x 15-17 um, cylindric, thin-walled, operculate, apices turn blue with iodine; paraphyses slender, colorless, branched irregularly, curved and slightly enlarged at tips, 1.5 um thick, (Kanouse(7))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'yellow'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(7) (as Gelatinodiscus flavidus), Kanouse(6) (as Gelatinodiscus flavidus), Castellano(1)* (as Gelatinodiscus flavidus)
51
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ciboria amentacea  (Balb.) Fuckel^  Symb. Myc. 311. 1870;  Rutstroemia amentacea  P. Karst.;  Hymenoscypha amentacea  W. Phillips
ENGLISH NAME(S)  catkin cup
NOTES  Ciboria amentacea forms light brown to yellow brown cups with stems, growing on fallen catkins of alder and willow.^ | Hansen, L.(1) give this species as synonym of Ciboria caucus (Rebent.: Fr.) Fuckel, and Seaver says they are close. RANGE ^It is found from NY to OR, and in Europe, (Seaver). There are collections from BC at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 1cm wide or rarely larger, shallow cup-shaped then expanded; yellowish brown^, (Seaver), 0.5-1.2cm wide, at first shallowly cup-shaped, expanding to flat when old; light brown to yellow brown; smooth, (Arora), up to 1cm wide, cup-shaped; light brown, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  smooth and similar in color to interior^ (Arora), smooth (Dennis)
STEM  stem often reaching 2-4cm long, arising from sclerotium formed in mummified catkins on host^, (Seaver), 1-5cm x 0.1-0.2cm, equal, often curved, not arising from a sclerotium; light brown to yellow-brown; smooth, (Arora), long and slender (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on mummified catkins of Alnus incana and Salix discolor^ (Seaver), "solitary or in small groups on old, fallen alder and willow catkins", usually fruiting in the spring, (Arora), on fallen male catkins of Alnus and Salix, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-13 x 4-5 um, elliptic or somewhat elliptic^; asci 8-spored, uniseriate, reaching 110-120 x 7-10 um, cylindric or somewhat cylindric; paraphyses 1-2 um wide, thread-like, slightly enlarged in upper part, (Seaver), spores 7.5-13 x 4-6 um (Arora), spores 7.5-10.5 x 4.5-6 um, elliptic or slightly inequilateral, uniseriate; asci 8-spored, reaching 135 x 9 um, pore blued by iodine; paraphyses up to 5 um thick at top, cylindric, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Ciboria caucus is an "almost indistinguishable species on fallen catkins of Populus", (Dennis).
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Arora(1), Hansen, L.(1), Dennis(1)
52
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ciboria caucus  (Rebent.) Fuckel^  Symb. Myc. 311. 1870;  Phialea caucus  Gillet;  Hymenoscypha caucus  W. Phillips
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Ciboria caucus forms brown cups with stems, growing on fallen catkins of Populus.^ | Hansen, L.(1) give C. amentacea (Balb.) Fuckel as a synonym of this species. RANGE ^It is from found NY to OR and MB, as well as in Europe, (Seaver), and according to Kanouse from WA. There is collection from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.8cm wide, cup-shaped with incurved margin, expanding to saucer-shaped or somewhat disc-like; brown, (Seaver), 0.4-1.5cm wide, pale to medium brown, (Hansen) 
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  0.2-0.8cm long and 0.5cm wide, (Seaver), 0.5-3.5cm x 0.03-0.17cm (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  arising from mummified sclerotium in fallen catkins of Populus tremuloides and Salix, (Seaver), on catkins of Populus, Salix, and Alnus, exceptionally Corylus, fruiting in spring and early summer, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-10 x 5-6 um, elliptic or somewhat elliptic, colorless^; asci 8-spored, reaching 130 x 9 um, cylindric-clavate, (Seaver), spores 7.5-10(11.5) x 4.5-6 um (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Ciboria amentacea is similar if not a synonym, but grows on alder and willow.
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6)
53
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ciboria gordonii  A. Funk^  Trans. Br. mycol. Soc. 86(1): 186. 1986
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Ciboria gordonii is a microscopic species, included here to compare with other species of Ciboria: it was the smallest species of Ciboria described to that point. Features include a cup with a stem, pruinose surface, the stem and exterior of the cup medium brown to mottled with black, and growth on hemlock needles.^ RANGE ^It was described from BC.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.024-0.06cm across, fruitbody up to 0.09cm high, cup-shaped with stem, fruitbody said to be pruinose but it is not clear which surfaces are indicated; color of hymenium not specifically indicated but presumably brown based on microscopic description
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  medium brown to mottled with black
STEM  0.015-0.07cm x 0.015-0.03cm, straight; medium brown to mottled with black; base immersed in needle tissue
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on dead retained needles of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-14 x 3-6 um, oval to elliptic or rarely subreniform, smooth, colorless, with 2 droplets, non-septate but becoming 1-septate at germination, uniseriate or biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 75-80 x 6-8 um, "produced from croziers, cylindric to broadly clavate, sometimes slightly expanded at the base, apex thickened, contents of ascus pore staining blue in Melzer's reagent"; paraphyses 50-90 x 3 um, simple but occasionally branched near base, slightly broadened in upper third, colorless, septate, "sometimes longer than the asci but not forming an epithecium"; subhymenium about 10 um thick, of densely interwoven, light brown hyphae 1.5 um wide; medullary excipulum up to 60 um thick, of light brown, septate hyphae 2-3 um wide, parallel to each other and to surface of disc; ectal excipulum up to 24 um thick, of 2-4 layers of thin-walled, light brown to colorless, spherical cells 4-8 um in diameter, a thin outer layer of brown covering hyphae appears granular in cross-section; margin formed from continuation of both ectal and medullary excipula; stem composed of a layer of globose cells to the outside, with a core of parallel hyphae running parallel with the stem, similar to structure of excipular tissues
NAME ORIGIN  named after C.C. Gordon (1928-1981), forest mycologist, University of Montana, (Funk(8))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Funk(8)
54
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ciboria rufofusca  (O. Weberb.) Sacc.^  Syll. Fung. 8: 203. 1889
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Ciboria rufofusca is an orange to chestnut brown or brown cup with a stem, growing on fallen true fir cones in spring. The same or a similar species grows on Douglas-fir in the Pacific Northwest.^ | Beug(3) shows what looks like this species growing on a Douglas-fir cone. RANGE ^It is found in WA (Kanouse). There are collections from BC at the University of British Columbia, from WA at the University of Washington, and from OR at Oregon State University. Desjardin(6) illustrated it from CA. It also occurs in Europe including Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen), and Switzerland (Breitenbach). Douglas-fir cones have been photographed in WA and BC bearing this kind of fungus.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-1(1.5)cm, bladder-like when young, then goblet-shaped to saucer-shaped and expanded and flat; orange to chestnut-brown; smooth; margin "sometimes rather sinuous and split, as well as finely dusted with white"^, (Breitenbach), 0.3-1.5cm, dark to medium to pale brown, (Hansen), up to 1.5cm, "Prout's brown" (Ridgway color) when fresh, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  the same color as upper surface, orange to chestnut brown, frosted with white^, (Breitenbach), "Prout's brown" when fresh, (Kanouse)
STEM  0.3-0.7cm long; brownish, darker toward base^, (Breitenbach), 0.2-0.7cm x 0.07-0.15cm, (Hansen), up to 1.5cm long (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to a few per scale, on damp scales of Abies (fir) cones lying on ground, April to May^, (Breitenbach), on stromatized cone scales of Abies, spring and early summer, (Hansen), on scales of Abies cones, May and June, (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-7 x 3-3.5 um, oval, smooth, colorless, sometimes with 2 small droplets, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 75-80 x 5-5.5 um, amyloid; paraphyses slender, barely thickened toward tips, without septa, (Breitenbach), spores 5.5-7.5 x 3-3.5 um; asci 65-90 x 5.5-6.5, (Hansen), spores 4-6 x 2-3 um; asci 45-55 x 4-5 um; paraphyses filiform, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'rufous-fuscous' referring to color of fruitbody
SIMILAR  Similar cups grow on Douglas-fir - it is not clear how these cups relate to Ciboria rufofusca (a long-stemmed brown cup was photographed by Daniel Winkler in Washington and the cups illustrated for C. rufofusca in Beug(3) appear to be on a Douglas-fir cone).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Trudell(4)*, Kanouse(6), Hansen, L.(1), Desjardin(6)*, Beug(3)*, McAdoo(1)*
55
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ciboria seminicola  (Kienholz & E.K. Cash) Hechler^  in Hechler & Steindl, Berichte des Botanischen Vereins zu Hamburg 12: 19 (1992) [1991];  Helotium seminicola  (Keinholz & E.K. Cash) Seaver;  Phialea seminicola  Kienholz & E.K. Cash
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Ciboria seminicola produces small smooth cups growing singly on alder seeds or 2-3 together, with a fawn spore-bearing upper surface and a slender stem that is sometimes hairy toward base.^ RANGE ^It was described from OR (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.6cm across, at first cup-shaped, expanding and often flat; interior spore-bearing surface flat or concave and fawn in color
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  smooth
STEM  reaching length of 1cm and usually 0.05-0.08cm wide, sometimes hairy toward the base when young
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or two or three arising from a seed, on seeds of Alnus rubra (Red Alder)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-20 x 3.5-5 um, fusoid-elliptic, with ends attenuated, with several small oil droplets^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 75-130 um and width of 7-12 um, clavate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], simple or branched in lower part, slightly enlarged in upper part, reaching a width of 4 um
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living on seed'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Helotium)
56
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ciborinia whetzelii  (Seaver) Seaver^  North American Cup-fungi (Inoperculates) p.70. 1951
ENGLISH NAME(S)  aspen ink spot
NOTES  Ciborinia whetzelii produces brown cup-shaped stemmed fruitbodies arising in the spring from overwintering black sclerotia that develop on browned aspen leaves giving an "inkspot" appearance and later fall to the duff leaving "shotholes" in the leaves.^ | It is common throughout BC (Allen). RANGE ^It is found in BC (Allen), and throughout Canada and the northern United States, but the sexual state has not yet been documented in BC, (Callan). It occurs specifically in PQ and NY, (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-1cm, at first cup-shaped, expanding and becoming subdiscoid [nearly disc-shaped]; brownish; sclerotia form on living leaves, circular or irregularly subcircular in form, persistent or dehiscent, (Seaver), sclerotia form dark "inkspots" on living leaves that drop out in late summer leaving shotholes, (Allen), browning of foliage is followed in about one month by circular to elliptic black sclerotia on infected leaf blades; sclerotia are 0.2-0.8cm across, black, circular to oval or with rounded irregular outlines; sclerotia begin to fall from infected leaves as early as mid-July, and leaves may remain attached to the tree, bearing characteristic "shot-holes"; overwintered sclerotia germinate on the surface of deep moist duff under aspen and give rise to fruitbodies by the hundreds; fruitbodies are 0.2-1cm across, cup-shaped, pale brown, (Callan)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  brownish^ (Seaver)
STEM  0.5-2.5cm long^ (Seaver, Callan)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  fruitbodies on sclerotia lying on ground that have dehisced from the leaves of Populus tremuloides, (Seaver), sclerotia on aspen and cottonwood leaves, (Allen), on aspen, rarely on balsam poplar, (Callan)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11-16 x 4-7 um, elliptic, uniseriate^; asci reaching a length or 150-200 um and width of 9-12 um, (Seaver), spores 7-10 x 3-4 um, oval, single-celled, colorless; asci 8-spored, 160-180 x 11-12 um, club-shaped, with a small apical plug that stains blue in Melzer's reagent; sclerotia have a distinctive palisade layer of cells just under the outer surface, (Callan), paraphyses numerous (Funk)
NAME ORIGIN  after H.H. Whetzel
SIMILAR  Ciborinia seaveri Groves and Bowerman, common in Alberta and eastern Canada but not reported in BC, produces similar symptoms in leaves, but the sclerotia are smaller, averaging 0.3-0.5cm across, and occur mainly on veins and petioles rather than leaf blades, (Callan).
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Allen(1), Callan(1), Funk(1)
57
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cistella dentata  (Fr.) Quel.^  Ench. Fung. p.319. 1886;  Cyathicula dentata  (Pers.) Sacc.;  Niptera dentata  Fuckel;  Mollisia dentata  Gillet;  Calloria dentata  (Pers.) W. Phillips
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Cistella dentata has a minute pale watery gray fruitbody with a dentate margin, growing scattered on sticks of maple, and is characterized by its microscopic features.^ RANGE ^It was reported from WA by Kanouse. According to Seaver who lists it among doubtful and excluded species, it was reported from WA and MI.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  minute, frequently not over 0.03cm across, pale watery gray^, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale watery gray^ (Kanouse)
STEM  none^ (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered on sticks of maple^, (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-6 x 2.5 um, straight, colorless, one-celled, biseriate^; asci 30-40 x 6 um, short-cylindric, ascus pore blue with iodine; paraphyses filiform [thread-like]; "excipular cells near the margin differentiated into hyphal extensions that are grouped together in fascicles making the margin appear dentate", (Kanouse who notes that in the genus Cistella hairs are "thin-walled, septate, and arise from the excipular cells without being differentiated from the basal cell. The tips of the hairs are more or less club-shaped, often there are minute roughenings; marginal hairs are often arranged in broad teeth.")
NAME ORIGIN  means "dentate", referring to toothed margin
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(6), Seaver(2)
58
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cistella geelmuydenii  Nannf.^  Studien uber die Morphologie und Systematik der nicht-Lichenisierten Inoperculaten Discomyceten. p. 270. 1932
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Cistella geelmuydenii has an extremely small gray-white translucent fruitbody, frequently with a toothed margin.^ RANGE ^It was reported from WA by Kanouse and occurs in Europe including Denmark and Sweden (Hansen, L.).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.01-0.03cm, white, (Hansen), fruitbody 0.01cm across, gray-white, translucent, delicately fringed at margin, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white (Hansen), gray-white (Kanouse)
STEM  none^ (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on hardwood, noted from Fagus (beech), (Hansen), on wood debris (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4-6 x 2-2.5 um, elliptic^, asci 25-30 x 4-6 um, paraphyses cylindric to narrowly lanceolate; hairs to 30 x 4 um, (Hansen), spores 5-6 x 1.5-2 um, asci 35-40 x 6-7 um; marginal hairs frequently arranged in tooth-like fascicles, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(6), Hansen, L.(1)
59
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cistella xylita  (P. Karst.)  Nannf.^  Studien uber die Morphologie und Systematik der nicht-Lichenisierten Inoperculaten Discomyceten. p. 270. 1932
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute substipitate cup on wood, which is cream color but reddening, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Cistella xylita was reported from WA (Kanouse).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.04-0.12cm across, cream color, reddening, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  minutely downy in this genus (Hansen)
STEM  substipitate (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on wood of conifers (Hansen), Nannfeldt said to limit this species to Populus, Kanouse collection appears to be on Alnus rubra (Red Alder), (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-10 x 1.5-2.5 um, narrowly elliptic^; asci 8-spored, 37-45 x 4-5.5 um; paraphyses slightly exceeding the asci, cylindric; hairs up to 30 x 3.5 um, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  from xylon, Greek for wood
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(6), Hansen, L.(1)
60
FAMILY  Tympanidaceae, Order Phacidiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Claussenomyces olivaceus  (Fuckel) Sherwood^  in Hawksworth & Sherwood, Can. J. Bot. 59(3): 367. 1981
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny dark olivaceous to black fruitbodies, the disc slightly concave with a wavy margin, consistency that is fleshy when moist and leathery when dry, the narrowed base of the disc arising from a dark brown subiculum, growth superficial and scattered on resinous exudates of conifers, and microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Hawksworth(1). RANGE ^Collections were examined from Austria and United Kingdom and it is reported from CO, (Hawksworth(1)). It has also been found in BC (Funk(5)), and there are several collections from BC determined by A. Funk at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.05-0.1cm across, dark olivaceous to black, disc slightly and persistently concave; margin "thin, often crisped and undulating, incurved"
FLESH  consistency fleshy when moist, leathery when dry
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  sessile [without a stem] on a narrowed base, "arising from a subiculum of dark brown hyphae"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  superficial, scattered, on resinous exudates of conifers
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11-28 x 3.5-7 um, "ellipsoid to fusiform, variable, simple or up to seven-septate, and sometimes becoming muriform, with a single incomplete longitudinal septum"^; asci (120)150-190 x 16-19 um, "cylindric-clavate, thin walled, not reacting in iodine, without an obvious differentiated apical pore", initially 8-spored; ascal conidia 2.0-2.5 um in diameter, round, colorless, unicellular; paraphyses numerous, filiform [thread-like], septate, usually branched near the tip and swollen to 2.0-2.5 um wide, the tips embedded in brown gelatinous material and forming an epithecium; "subhymenium thick, gelatinous, composed of textura intricata, nearly colourless"; excipulum up to 60 um thick, of radially arranged hyphae with a cell lumen about 1 um in diameter "and thick gelatinizing walls, externally dark"; conidia abundantly produced, 1.5-3 um in diameter, nearly round but often angular by mutual compression, colorless, slightly thick-walled, aseptate, "in compact slimy masses, not catenate"; conidiogenous cells "enteroblastic, phialidic, not proliferating", "cylindrical, not or slightly tapering toward apex", colorless, smooth-walled, "with small collarette but a distinct, sometimes elongate channel", mainly 7-15 x 1.5-3 um; conidiophores up to 20 x 1.5-3 um, lining the cavity of the pycnidium, cylindric, colorless, "simple or irregularly dichotomously branched", bearing conidiogenous cells sympodially and 1 to 3 apically
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Sarea difformis is a lichen that produces dark brown to black fruitbodies on the resinous exudates of conifers, but macroscopically Claussenomyces olivaceous "can be recognized by the persistently concave disc and thin, often crisped and undulating, incurved margin", and microscopically, "the asci are quite different in structure in lacking any apical thickening, and not reacting at all with iodine" - furthermore ascospores are muriform when first formed and then produce minute, round spores directly from the original ascospores, (Hawksworth).
SOURCES  Hawksworth(1), Funk(5)
61
FAMILY  Tympanidaceae, Order Phacidiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Claussenomyces pini  A. Funk^  Mycotaxon 27: 283. 1986
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, black, shiny, circular or undulate fruitbodies in a stem of pine; stem lacking or rudimentary; the release of a dark pigment when mounted in KOH; and microscopic characters including 1-3-septate, fusoid-elliptic spores.^ RANGE ^Claussenomyces pini was described from BC with a voucher at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^ionomidotic [releasing a dark pigment into aqueous KOH solution]
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.02-0.08cm wide, up to 0.04cm high, marginate, circular or undulate; black; shiny
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  black
STEM  sessile [without a stem] to substipitate [with a rudimentary stem]
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or subcespitose in a stem of Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), collection made in mid-winter
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-18 x 3 um, fusoid-elliptic, straight or slightly curved, colorless, 1-3-septate^; asci 8-spored, 85-105 x 8-10 um, clavate, long-stemmed, apex thickened, pore not staining in iodine; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], branching, slightly swollen at tips and forming a dark epithecium; excipulum composed of radiating hyphae, hyphae 2-4 um wide, dark green, gelatinized, irregular; ascoconidia rarely produced in the ascus, but abundantly on agar, 4 x 2 um, ovoid, continuous, colorless
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Pinus', referring to habitat
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Funk(5)
62
FAMILY  Thelebolaceae, Order Thelebolales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Coprotus glaucellus  (Rehm) Kimbr.^  Am. J. Bot. 54: 22. 1967;  == Ascophanus glaucellus  Rehm
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a disc-shaped to lens-shaped, translucent to white fruiting body up to 0.12cm across, and growth on dung of deer, goat, moose, porcupine and rabbit.^ | The description is derived from Kimbrough(1) who says it is one of the most common of the discomycetes living on dung. RANGE ^Coprotus glaucellus is found in ON, FL, MI, NJ, NY, CO, Europe, and Mexico, (Kimbrough), and BC and CO, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.01-0.12cm, discoid to lenticular, broadly attached; translucent to white, becoming slightly yellowish on drying
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  absent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to gregarious on dung of deer, goat, moose, porcupine, and rabbit
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7.5-9 x 4.5-5.5 um, elliptic, 1-seriate to 2-seriate, each with 1 de Bary bubble^; asci 8-spored, 40-55 x 8-12 um, cylindric, rounded in upper part, narrowed in lower part, ending on a short stem; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, strongly uncinate [hooked] at apices, 1.5 um in lower part, slightly wider in upper part, without oil droplets
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Coprotus lacteus (eastern North America, Europe) has white fruiting bodies 0.02-0.05cm across, but asci are 65-84 um long, and paraphyses are slightly inflated in the upper part and only somewhat hooked.
SOURCES  Kimbrough(1), Larsen(1)
63
FAMILY  Thelebolaceae, Order Thelebolales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Coprotus granuliformis  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan) Kimbr.^  in Kimbrough & Korf, Am. J. Bot. 54: 22. 1976;  == Ascobolus granuliformis  P. Crouan & H. Crouan;  == Ascophanus granuliformis  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan) Boud.;  = Ascobolus argenteus  Curr.;  = Ascophanus rosellus  Starback
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Coprotus granuliformis is a white to pale yellow cup or disc 0.02-0.06cm across, growing mostly on cow dung but also on deer and sheep dung. It is easily distinguished from other Coprotus species by its short, very broadly clavate asci and by paraphyses that are greatly inflated at their apices.^ RANGE ^It is found in OR, and also ON, SK, CO, NY, WY, Austria, and Sweden, (Kimbrough).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.02-0.06cm, cup-shaped to disc-shaped; white to pale yellow, margins darker^, (Kimbrough), up to 0.025cm wide, subpyriform (somewhat pear-shaped); white, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  absent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mostly on cow dung, but also on deer and sheep dung^, (Kimbrough)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9.0-15.0 x 6.5-9.5 um, broadly elliptic, mostly 2-seriate, each with one large de Bary bubble^; asci 8-spores, 40-55 x 15-30 um, broadly clavate, almost truncate in upper part, sharply tapering to short stem in lower part; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], septate in lower part, inflated at apices to 5.0-8.0 um, colorless to slightly pigmented, often with minute oil droplets, (Kimbrough), spores 10-12 x 6-7 um, elliptic; asci 40-50 x 20 um; paraphyses clavate, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kimbrough(1), Dennis(1)
64
FAMILY  Thelebolaceae, Order Thelebolales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Coprotus luteus  Kimbr., Luck-Allen & Cain^  Can. J. Bot.  50: 966. 1972
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include the minute, disc-shaped to cup-shaped, orange to yellow fruiting body, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Coprotus luteus is found at least in BC, and also AB, ON, MT, NY, SD, WY, and Mexico (Kimbrough).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.02-0.08cm, disc-shaped to cup-shaped; yellow to orange, margins more pigmented
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered on dung of various animals (moose, cow, deer, goat, horse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8.0-10.5 x 5-6.5 um, elliptic, thin-walled, colorless, mostly 1-seriate, each with 1 de Bary bubble^; asci 8-spored, 60-85 x 10-15 um, cylindric, rounded in upper part, ending in a short stem; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], septate, simple or sparingly branched, slightly uncinate [hooked] in upper apart, enlarged to 3.5 um, filled with numerous small yellow droplets
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Coprotus aurora (AB, ON, WY, DE, IL), is even more brightly colored and is distinguished by its larger more elliptic spores and more uncinate and highly pigmented paraphyses. Coprotus breviascus (WY, Austria), also with a yellowish to orange fruiting body, has short asci 45-55 x 15-18 um and spores 10-13 x 6.5-8.5 um. Coprotus ochraceus, with a pale yellow to orange fruiting body, has spores 15-18 x 9-10.5 um. (all three from Kimbrough).
SOURCES  Kimbrough(1)
65
FAMILY  Thelebolaceae, Order Thelebolales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Coprotus ochraceus  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan) Kar. Larsen^  Dan. Bot. Tidsskr. 66: 1-32. 1971;  == Ascobolus ochraceus  P. Crouan & H. Crouan;  == Ascophanus ochraceus  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan) Boud.;  = Ascophanus subgranuliformis  Rehm;  = Ascophanus violascens var. falcatus  Velen.;  = Ascophanus bilobus  Velen.;  = Ascophanus  velenovskyi  Svrcek.;  = Ascophanus hyalino-niveus  Svrcek
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include pale yellow to orange, cup-shaped to disc-shaped fruiting body, growth on dung of cows and other animals, and microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Kimbrough. RANGE ^It is found in ID, OR, CA, IA, NS, PQ, Bermuda, Puerto Rico, Czechoslovakia, France, Brazil, and Pakistan, (Kimbrough), and WA (Kanouse).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.15cm, at first cup-shaped becoming disc-shaped; pale yellow to orange
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  absent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on dung of various animals (most often cow, in Pakistan on camel)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14.0-18.0 x 9.0-11.0 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless to slightly yellowish, each with 1 de Bary bubble, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 110-150 x 12-18 um, cylindric, rounded in upper part, narrowing in lower part; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], septate, containing numerous yellowish oil droplets, 1.5 um in diameter in lower part, inflated at apices to 4-5 um and slightly uncinate [hooked]; excipulum [tissue containing the hymenium] "of a textura angularis to globulosa, medullary area of thin-walled cells 25-30 um in diameter, marginal cells elongated, 12-14 x 6.0-8.0 um, walls somewhat thickened, slightly yellowish"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ochraceous'
SIMILAR  Cheilymenia granulata has frequently been confused, but has longitudinous cyanophilic striations in the walls of the spores, and cells of the excipulum are larger and cyanophilic as well, (Kimbrough). Coprotus sexdecimsporus (CO, NY, WY, ON, Mexico, France, Great Britain) has 16 spores 11-16 x 8-10 um in wider ascus 85-140 x 20-30 um (Coprotus duplus of ON, PQ also has 16 spores but 7.5-10 x 4.0-6.5 um in ascus 70-90 x 10-18 um), (Kimbrough). Coprotus luteus has spores less than 10 um long, Coprotus aurora has spores 12-14 x 6.0-8.5 um in asci 65-90 x 10-15 um, and Coprotus breviascus has spores 10-13 x 6.5-8.5 um in asci 45-55 x 15-18 um, (all three from Kimbrough).
SOURCES  Kimbrough(1), Kanouse(6) (as Ascophanus ochraceus)
66
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Corticium minnsiae  (H.S. Jacks.) Boidin & Lanq.^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 99: 275.  1983;  == Aleurodiscus minnsiae  H.S. Jacks.;  == Laeticorticium minnsiae  (H.S. Jacks.) Donk
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Crust Category. It grows flat on wood but a cup-like structure develops. Features include 1) (the most distinctive feature) a flaring cup-shaped structure about 0.5cm across, on the upper side of twigs and small branches, in which develops a bright salmon egg-like sclerotium 0.2-0.3cm across, that when mature is loosely attached at the base and easily removed (it is thought that this sclerotium is disseminated by raindrops to other wood where the fruitbody grows), 2) the resupinate fruitbody that grows widely spread out or in irregular patches, and is soft-membranous in consistency, separable, pink in color, with an irregular margin that is abrupt or thinning out, 3) spores that are ovoid with a conspicuous apiculus, smooth, inamyloid, and colorless, 4) basidia arising from deep in the subiculum, 5) abundant paraphyses with irregular peg-like branches, and 6) hyphae with clamp connections.^ | The description is derived from Jackson(5). RANGE ^Corticium minnsiae is found in BC, OR, also ON, PQ, CA, ME, MI, NC, NH, NY, PA, TN, VT, (Ginns), and WA (I. Gibson, pers. comm.).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  when mature widely spread out or in irregular patches, 0.013 to 0.02cm thick, soft membranous, separable; "bright pinkish buff to shell pink or pale flesh color when fresh, fading to cream buff or white"; surface at first continuous, becoming rimose [cracked] when old exposing the subiculum; margin "irregular, abrupt or thinning out"; basidial fruitbody preceded or accompanied by a characteristic sclerotial disseminating phase, a small flaring cup-shaped structure on the upper side of twigs and small branches, in which develops a bright salmon egg-like sclerotium that when mature is loosely attached at the base and easily removed, (Jackson)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  a cup-shaped structure on the upper side of twigs and small branches contains sclerotium in August and early September, but is shriveled and dried later in the fall after the sclerotium has been disseminated (perhaps by a similar splashing mechanism from raindrops to the one operating in bird's nest fungi), the resupinate fruitbodies develop in the fall but are generally sterile at first, fruiting in late May or June of the following year; found on Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock), Pinus contorta (Lodgepole Pine), Pinus ponderosus (Ponderosa Pine), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), (Jackson), also Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), (Ginns)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-16 x 8.5-11 um, ovoid, slightly flattened on one side, with conspicuous apiculus, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled^; basidia 4-spored, arising from deep in the subiculum, 80-100 x 8-10 um, long cylindric or subclavate, more or less flexuous [wavy], sterigmata subulate, arcuate, 7-8.5 um long; paraphyses abundant, 1.5-2 um wide, nodulose, with irregular peg-like branches; subiculum made up of hyphae 3-4 um wide, thick-walled, arranged more or less horizontally in lower part, interwoven in subhymenium, with regular clamp connections, (Jackson)
NAME ORIGIN  after Miss S. Minns
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Jackson(5), Ginns(5)
67
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cudoniella clavus  (Alb. & Schwein. ex Fr.) Dennis^  in Persoonia 3: 73. 1964;  Cudoniella aquatica  (Lib.) Sacc.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Clubs category. Features include a small, concave, stemmed fruiting body that becomes convex with a reflexed margin, the color whitish to grayish to buff or reddish, often with violaceous tints; surface smooth, stem darker at base; growth on rotting twigs and leaves, especially those covered by water; and microscopic characters.^ |There may be a question about whether the relatively common, gelatinous species going under this name in Helotiaceae is truly a Cudoniella; true Cudoniella may be non-gelatinous, not preferring wet habits, and residing in Tricladiaceae, (D. Miller, pers. comm., August 21, 2022). RANGE ^It is found in the Pacific Northwest (Phillips), Europe including Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Finland, (Hansen), the United Kingdom (Dennis), and Switzerland (Breitenbach). It is probably the same as Ombrophila clavus (A. & S.) Cooke, reported from New England to WA, (Seaver), and CA (MykoWeb). There are collections from BC at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 1cm across, concave becoming strongly convex with reflexed margin; "whitish to grayish or ochraceous-buff, usually flushed with violaceous tints"^, (Phillips), up to 1cm (var. grandis up to 2cm), at first concave, then strongly convex with reflexed margin; whitish or grayish, usually flushed with violaceous tints, (Dennis), 0.4-1.2cm, turbinate [top-shaped] when young, then with cushion-like cap; gray-whitish to ocher-whitish, sometimes with violet cast; smooth, (Breitenbach), 0.4-1.2cm, gray to reddish (Hansen), 0.3-0.6(1)cm across, at first obtuse-conic to turbinate [top-shaped], when old convex to nearly flat, margin flat to downcurved when mature; cream to dull brown, slightly darker at center; moist, bald, margin lacking hairs, (MykoWeb)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  colored as upper surface; smooth^ (Breitenbach), bald in this genus (Hansen), colored as upper surface; bald, (MykoWeb)
STEM  "short; white, but often brown or black at base; smooth"^, (Phillips), more or less stemmed, long enough to lift the disc clear of the water, white, but often brown or black at base; smooth, (Dennis), distinct, often to 2cm long when substrate under water; brown-black toward the base, (Breitenbach), brown at base (Hansen), 1-2cm long and 0.1cm wide, widened toward apex; watery white, becoming dark brown to blackish toward base; slightly tomentose (use hand lens), (MykoWeb)
ODOR  not distinctive^ (MykoWeb)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (MykoWeb)
EDIBILITY  no (Phillips), unknown (MykoWeb)
HABITAT  on wet, rotting twigs and leaves, in ditches and swamps, also on dead stems; August to October^, (Phillips), gregarious or single, best developed "on rotting twigs and leaves covered with water, as in ditches and swamps, but also on dead stems of Chamaenerion and the like, May and June, sometimes in July", (Dennis), single to gregarious, on dead twigs of trees and shrubs, as well as woody remains of herbs, always in very wet places such as wheel ruts and drainage ditches, spring to summer, (Breitenbach), on submerged leaves and barkless twigs, spring to early summer, (Hansen), single to gregarious on rotting stems of grasses and herbs in boggy mountain meadows, in spring shortly after snow melt, (MykoWeb)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-17 x 3-5 um, oblong-fusiform, often narrower at one end^; asci 8-spored, up to 115 x 10 um, varying greatly in length, cylindric-clavate, (Phillips), spores 10-17 x 3-5 um, oblong-fusiform, often narrower at one end, nonseptate, uniseriate or irregularly biseriate; asci 8-spored, up to 115 x 10 um, varying greatly in length, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses slender, cylindric, (Dennis), spores (8)9.5-15 x (3.5)4-5 um, elliptic-fusiform, smooth, colorless, without droplets; asci 8-spored, (90)100-115 x 9-10 um; inamyloid; paraphyses filiform, septate, sometimes forked, (Breitenbach), spores 10-17 x 3-5 um, non-septate, (Hansen), 9.5-17.5 x 3.5-4.5 um, oblong-cylindric to subfusiform, smooth, (MykoWeb)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Peziza oliviae.
SOURCES  Dennis(1), Phillips(1)*, Breitenbach(1)*, Hansen, L.(1), Seaver(1), MykoWeb(1) (accessed October 23, 2004)
68
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cyathicula alpina  Ellis. & Everh.^  Proc. Phil. Acad. Nat. Sci. p.349. 1894
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Cyathicula alpina is a minute translucent cup with an obscurely dentate margin and with a stem, growing on dead stems of plants, characterized by microscopic features.^ RANGE ^It was reported by Kanouse from WA. Seaver describes from CO, but notes under Cyathicula that it is "doubtful if this species belongs here".
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  translucent shining cups (Kanouse), about 0.05cm across, less than 0.01cm high; pallid; margin "fibrous, the extremities of the fibers prolonged and subfasciculate so as to make the margin obscurely dentate", (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  with a stem^ (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on Equisetum sp.; on stems; on stems (?of Delphinium), (Kanouse), on dead stems of Pedicularis and culms of Elymus condensatus, altitude 9500 feet, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-9(10) x 1.5-2 um^; asci 8-spored; tooth-like fascicles of hairs at the margin measure 60-80 broad and 40 um long; paraphyses filiform, (Kanouse), spores 8-10 x 1.5-2 um, subcylindric; asci 8-spored, clavate-cylindric; paraphyses filiform, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'alpine'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(6), Seaver(2)
69
FAMILY  Niaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cyphellopsis confusa  (Bres.) D.A. Reid^  Persoonia 3(1): 110. 1964;  == Solenia confusa  Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute yellowish gray fruitbodies in colonies on wood, the exterior with hairs, and microscopic characters including basidia.^ | Dictionary of the Fungi Ninth Edition synonymizes Cyphellopsis with Merismodes. According to the online Species Fungorum, accessed December 15, 2013, this taxon is a synonym of Merismodes fasciculata (Schwein.) Donk. RANGE ^Cyphellopsis confusa (Bres.) D.A. Reid is found at least in BC according to Redhead(21), who however says, "The specimens assigned to this species are somewhat at variance with those that Reid examined and may represent a distinct taxon.". There are collections from BC at University of British Columbia. C. confusa is found in MI and Europe, (Reid).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.03cm across and up to 0.04cm high (when examined in KOH), turbinate [top-shaped], the fruitbody appears yellowish-gray, and distinctly villose-tomentose under a lens, when dried the margin rolls in to cover the spore-bearing area^, (Reid)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  when young appears grayish white due to covering of granule-encrusted hairs, old fruitbodies "have a browner appearance and fully mature fruitbodies become snuffbrown in colour"^, (Reid)
STEM  narrows in lower part into stem-like base up to 0.02cm long and 0.01cm wide^, (Reid)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  densely crowded in cushion-shaped colonies 0.15-0.35cm across, "the colonies often consisting of well over 50 fruiting bodies"^, (Reid), in colonies like those of Merismodes anomala, having areas up to 2cm x 5cm; on barkless wood, Populus in one collection and hardwood in the other, (Redhead for BC)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (5.5)7-8.2 x 2-2.2 um, narrowly elliptic or subcylindric to slightly allantoid, colorless, thin-walled^; basidia 4-spored, up to 27 um wide and 5.5 um wide, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; cystidia and gloeocystidia absent; the hyphae of the stem-like base are 2(3) um wide and densely compacted, and diverge to form the tissue of the cup; subiculum 200 um thick, consisting of erect hyphae 2.5 um wide: these hyphae, "which are identical with the surface hairs of the fruitbody, have thickened brown walls, but retain a narrow lumen with occasional indistinct secondary septa", they are long, up to 200 um, and also have long, colorless, often flexuous [wavy] tips; the hairs, which are also elongated, arise from vegetative hyphae to which they are joined by a clamp connection, they have thickened brown walls, and long, thin-walled, colorless, granule-encrusted tips, and are secondarily septate, the encrustation very fine, amorphous, and soluble in KOH, tips of hairs mostly bluntly rounded but sometimes variously inflated (capitate or clavate, in the latter case the clavate part sometimes constricted by a septum), the inflated part being thin-walled and colorless or occasionally thick-walled and brown, (Reid), spores ranging up to 7-10 x 2-3.5 um, (Redhead)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'mixed together, vague, obscure' (Latin)
SIMILAR  Merismodes fasciculata is similar especially if the spiral coiling of hairs in Merismodes fasciculata is poorly developed, but then it is most readily distinguished by the manner in which the spore-bearing surface of Merismodes fasciculata lines a deep cavity extending almost to the base of the fruitbody, (Reid). Merismodes anomala has spores 8-9.5 x 3.7-4.5(5) um according to Breitenbach(2).
SOURCES  Reid(4), Redhead(21), Breitenbach(2) (discussing Merismodes anomala)
70
FAMILY  Niaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cyphellopsis subglobispora  D.A. Reid^  Kew Bull. 15: 265. 1961
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute rounded to top-shaped fruitbody with pale cream or whitish spore-bearing upper surface, the exterior thickly covered with brown hairs that overarch to cover the spore-bearing upper surface, either without a stem or narrowed in lower part into a short thick stem-like base; growth densely gregarious on wood; and microscopic characters including basidia.^ | The Ninth Edition and Tenth Edition of Dictionary of the Fungi synonymize Cyphellopsis with Merismodes [which is in Niaceae]. MycoBank places this species in Marasmiaceae but MycoBank places it in Niaceae (both accessed June 7, 2014). RANGE ^It is found at least in BC, (Redhead), and Venezuela (Reid). There is a S. Redhead collection from BC at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.013-0.015cm across, 0.015-0.02cm high, subglobular [nearly spherical] or turbinate [top-shaped], "densely gregarious on a common subiculum forming scattered colonies", spore-bearing upper surface pale cream or whitish^, (Reid)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  brown: the exterior thickly covered with brown hairs that overarch and completely cover the spore-bearing surface^, (Reid)
STEM  without a stem or narrowed in lower part into a short thick stem-like base 0.004-0.005cm long and 0.004cm wide^, (Reid)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on hardwood (Redhead), on twigs (Reid)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-8.75 x 5-6.5 um including apiculus, broadly elliptic to nearly round, colorless^; basidia 4-spored, up to 28.6 x 10 um, "broadly clavate, tapering to a very narrow base"; hyphal system monomitic, of generative hyphae 2-2.5 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, branched, appearing to have clamp connections on some of the septa, these hyphae vertical in the stem-like base and diverging to form fleshy base of cup, toward outside of cup hyphae develop slightly thicker, brownish walls and become more highly branched, and from these arise numerous granule encrusted hairs, 2-3 um wide, with "slightly thickened brown walls and strongly enrolled, crozier-like apices, the tips of which often become swollen and irregularly clavate or capitate"; clamp connections in this species tend to be abortive and often mere peg-like outgrowths near the septa, (Reid) 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with nearly round spores'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Reid(5), Redhead(21), Ginns(5)
71
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cytidia lanata  W.B. Cooke^  Mycologia 43: 205. 1951
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Crusts category. Features include 1) growth on birch bark, 2) cup-shaped fruitbodies 1-3cm across, attached at and near a central point, free over the rest of the upper surface and covered with tan to brownish woolly tomentum, the spore-bearing surface dull purple and smooth to somewhat wrinkled, 3) spores ovate to oblong-elliptic, smooth, and colorless, 4) multiple hymenial layers, 5) lack of sterile elements, and 6) gelatinous hyphae without clamp connections at the infrequent septa.^ RANGE ^The type was found in ID (Ginns).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  receptacles 1-3cm across, attached at and near a central point, free over remainder of upper surface; hymenium dull purple, smooth to somewhat wrinkled^, (Cooke)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  free surface covered with tan to brownish woolly tomentum, more or less zonate^, (Cooke)
STEM  attached at and near a central point^ (Cooke)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type scattered on bark of branch of Betula (birch)^, (Cooke)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-7 x 2-3 um, ovate to oblong-elliptic, flattened on one side, smooth, colorless, with apiculus^; basidia 4-spored, 23-28 x 4-6 um, with small clamp connections at bases; no sterile elements seen in context or hymenium; hymenium 50-60 um in section, brownish, in 2 to 3 layers, "the lower layers of which appear as brown palisades of collapsed cells through which hyphae penetrate to form a context from which an additional hymenial layer arises"; receptacle 600-800 um thick in section, free surface made up of colorless hyphae that are united into bundles that are more compactly arranged toward the outside, the bundles merging and anastomosing and connected by individual hyphae, hyphae 5-8 um wide, bundles 25-50 um wide, hyphae of tomentum originate from context through a zone of darkened tissue, hyphae of context densely interwoven, more or less parallel, without clamp connections at the infrequent septa, "with gelatinous walls, becoming perpendicular to the receptacle in the subhymenial region of each annual increment", (Cooke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'woolly'
SIMILAR  Cytidia salicina has receptacles with a surface that is pruinose rather than woolly (Cooke).
SOURCES  Cooke(3), Ginns(5)
72
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cytidia patelliformis  (Burt) Weiden^  Mycologia 50: 304. 1958;  == Stereum patelliforme  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Crusts category. Features include 1) resupinate to open cup-shaped fruitbodies with spore-bearing surface pink to dark reddish brown, and abhymenial surface with coarse hairs and yellow-buff to dark reddish brown in color, 2) growth on fallen hardwood branches, 3) spores that are slightly curved, smooth, and colorless, 4) thin branched elements among the basidia, 5) projecting cystidia that are cylindric or tapering slightly, and 6) hyphae that are strongly gelatinized and having prominent clamp connections.^ RANGE ^Cytidia patelliformis is found in WA, CA, and NM, (Ginns).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  resupinate to open cup-shaped, 0.5-2cm long, 0.3-0.9cm wide, some fruitbodies with confluent margins; "hymenial surface pink to dark reddish-brown, pulverulent to setulose under the lens"^, (Welden), 0.3cm x 0.2cm, up to 2.5cm x 0.3cm, the margin free all around and rolled up 0.1-0.2cm, "coriaceous-fleshy, resupinate, the margin becoming free or narrowly reflexed", the margin entire; hymenium waxy, even, cracking in drying, drying cinnamon to bone-brown, (Burt)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  "superior surface from yellow-buff to dark reddish-brown, strigose with matted white hairs in well-developed receptacles"^, (Welden), hoary with a few short hairs, drying cinnamon to bone-brown, (Burt)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on fallen branches; hosts include Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), Corylus cornuta (Beaked Hazel), C. californica (California Hazel), Crataegus douglasii (Black Hawthorn), Fraxinus latifolia (Oregon Ash), Purshia tridentata (Antelope Bitterbrush), Quercus sp. (oak), Rhus diversiloba (poison-oak), Rosa nutkana (Nootka rose), (Ginns), on fallen branches of Acer, Quercus, and other hardwoods, August to April, (Burt)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-15 x 4-5 um, slightly curved, with apiculus, smooth, colorless^; basidia 4-spored, 56-80(108) x 6-8 um, often projecting 10-11 um above hymenial surface, sterigmata fleshy, arcuate, 6-8 um long; dendrophyses intermingled with basidia, 2-3 um wide; cystidia projecting up to 60 um beyond hymenial surface, 7-8 um wide, cylindric or tapering slightly, a few with swollen apices, non-septate, thin-walled, unincrusted; receptacle 525-700 um thick in free-hand section, cuticle absent to poorly developed, context and hymenium forming the two zones generally present, "context interwoven with the hyphae turning outward to form the superior surface of the receptacle and the hymenium, in resupinate forms only the hyphae next to the substrate densely interwoven, then radiating outward forming the hymenium at their tips", hyphae with walls somewhat thickened and strongly gelatinized, with numerous and prominent clamp-connections, branching, 4-6 um wide, subhymenial hyphae similar but with thinner walls, 3-4 um wide, (Welden)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'in the form of a small pan, dish'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Welden(1), Burt(2) (as Stereum patelliforme), Ginns(5)
73
FAMILY  Corticiaceae, Order Corticiales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Cytidia salicina  (Fr.) Burt^  Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 11: 10. 1924;  == Thelephora salicina  Fr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  scarlet-splash
NOTES  Also listed in Crusts and Jelly categories. Features include growth on attached dead or damaged willow branches, at first growing flat, but loosening along the margin to resemble shallow orange to wine-red cups, which then become confluent. Microscopic characters include cylindric spores that are smooth, iodine negative, and colorless; large basidia that protrude from a dense layer of dendrohyphidia; and monomitic hyphal system with hyphae that turn blue in sulfovanilline, have clamp connections, and are strongly agglutinated by gelatinous interhyphal substance.^ RANGE ^Cytidia salicina is found in BC, WA, OR, ID, and also MB, NB, NF, NS, ON, PQ, YT, AK, AL, CO, CT, IN, LA, MA, ME, MI, MN, MT, NC, ND, NH, NM, NY, OH, PA, VA, VT, WI, WV, and WY, (Ginns), Europe including Switzerland, and Asia, (Breitenbach), France, Sweden, central and eastern Europe, and north Asia, (Eriksson), and Algeria, Austria, Czechoslovakia, Finland, Germany, Italy, Latvia, Norway, and Sweden, (Cooke).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  when young disc-shaped to slightly plate-shaped to cup-shaped, irregularly rounded to oblong, 0.5-1cm in size, "with a pointlike attachment on underside, later coalescing in rows to form bands often several decimeters long", up to 0.05-0.08cm thick, elastic, gelatinous, tough, when dry shriveled and crustose, corneous [horny] and hard; bright orange to wine-red, drying dull wine-red; "when moist smooth, pruinose and dull, slightly verrucose-tuberculate", drying dull, with inrolled margin^, (Breitenbach), growing flat on wood, loosening along the margin and becoming cup-shaped, almost umbilicate, and looking like a discomycete, about 1cm wide, but sometimes confluent to larger irregular structures, when wet coriaceous [leathery] to somewhat gelatinous, soft, pliable, when dry corneous [horny], hard and brittle; "orange red when young, then dark red to violaceous red", "smooth, even or when wet somewhat tuberculate", at first bald, when fertile pruinose from spores and projecting basidia; margin "more or less revolute, esp. in the dry state", (Eriksson)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  upper side "covered by crystals and therefore whitish, farinose or finely floccose"^, (Eriksson)
STEM  resupinate [growing flat], loosening along margin to become cup-shaped, (Eriksson), with a point-like attachment, later coalescing, (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on "attached dead or damaged branches with bark, as well as standing trunks", of various Salix (willow) species, throughout the year but mature only in late fall, (Breitenbach), on various Salix species, Alnus spp., Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch), Populus spp., Prunus serotina (Black Cherry); on limbs, (Ginns), on dry, still attached twigs and branches of Salix, mostly seen in shadowed thickets on branches 1-2 meters above the ground, (Eriksson)
SPORE DEPOSIT  white^ (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12.5-17.5 x 4-5 um, cylindric, slightly allantoid [curved], smooth, iodine negative, colorless, with many small droplets^; basidia 4-spored, 80-100 x 7-9 um, narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; cystidia none; dendrohyphidia in hymenium 2.5-3 um wide, "very densely interwoven and imbedded in a gelatinous substance, gnarled, strongly branched, brownish", +/- thick-walled, stain bluish in sulfovanillin; hyphal system monomitic, hyphae 2-4 um wide, thin-walled to thick-walled, septa with clamp connections, stain bluish in sulfovanillin, (Breitenbach), spores 12-18 x 4-5 um, allantoid [curved sausage-shaped], smooth, inamyloid, acyanophilic; basidia 4-spored, very large, 75-100 x 8-11 um (according to Bourdot 60-225 x 7-9 um), young basidia "develop within the dendrohyphidial layer and protrude at maturity"; cystidia none, dendrohyphidia numerous, richly branched, forming a dense layer, light yellowish brown, best seen on young fruiting bodies as they seem to disintegrate to some degree as basidia develop, (best studied in KOH heated close to boiling over a flame, when the other hyphae will swell and the dendrohyphidia will not), stain strongly in sulfovanillin; hyphal system monomitic, hyphae about 2-3 um wide, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled, mostly straight, sparsely septate and with clamp connections at all septa, strongly agglutinated by gelatinous interhyphal substances, all hyphae blue or violaceous blue in sulfovanillin, (Eriksson)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to Salix [willow]'
SIMILAR  Cytidia lanata has receptacles with a woolly surface (Cooke).
SOURCES  Eriksson(3), Breitenbach(2)*, Ginns(5), Courtecuisse(1)*, Cooke(3), Buczacki(1)*
74
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Daleomyces petersii  (Berk.) Van Vooren^  Ascomycete.org 12(4): 185. 2020;  Peziza petersii  Berk. & M.A. Curtis  Grevillea 3: 150. 1875;  Galactinia sarrazinii  Boud.;  Peziza proteana  var. proteana  (Boud.) Seaver  Mycologia 9(1): 1. 1917
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a cup-shaped fruitbody with a grayish brown upper surface and a scurfy exterior that is gray in lower part becoming brownish toward the margin, 2) growth on burned ground or burned wood, and 3) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Peziza petersii (here Daleomyces petersii) from OR was included in the Vizzini(1) study, confirming the presence of its synonym Peziza proteana forma proteana. The typical form of Peziza proteana is otherwise not well documented from the Pacific Northwest, partly because the form is often not specified (e.g. Larsen(1) lists Washington Oregon, and California for Peziza proteana; the University of Washington online has two Washington collections not specifying the form; Oregon State University online has two Oregon collections not specifying the form [one is Daleomyces phillipsii]). Even if the herbarium collections were examined and found to be simple cups, it would not be straightforward to confirm the diagnosis. Seaver lists Peziza proteana from New York, Texas, and France, (Seaver(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 5cm, cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface brown with grayish tints^, (Dennis), 2-5cm across, deeply cup-shaped, upper surface grayish brown with blue tinge, (Hansen), reaching 3-5cm across, at first closed and spherical, gradually expanding, regular or much contorted; upper surface pale brown to dark brown; margin usually crenate [scalloped], (Seaver)
FLESH  thin; gray^, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  lead-gray in lower part, becoming brownish toward margin; scurfy^, (Dennis), "outer surface above glabrous, bluish", (Hansen), whitish, becoming dingy when old; densely pustulate, the pustules giving rise to bran-like particles as the fruitbody matures, (Seaver)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  often clustered, on "burnt ground in woods and on charred stumps", June to October^, (Dennis), on burnt ground in hardwood forests with rich soil, fall, (Hansen), gregarious, scattered or cespitose on charcoal and burned areas, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-12 x 5.5-6 um, finely warted, with 2 oil droplets^; asci about 200 x 10 um; paraphyses somewhat clavate, up to 7 um wide at tip, "which contains brown globules and is often curved", (Dennis), spores 11-12 x 6-6.5 um, narrowly elliptic, with elongate delicate warts (illustration indicates warts in the form of short ridges), with 2 small droplets, (Hansen), spores 15-17 x 8-10 um, elliptic, becoming minutely warted, colorless to faintly yellowish, uniseriate; asci reaching a length of 275 um and width of 12-14 um; paraphyses strongly widened in upper part and reaching width of 7-8 um at tip, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Daleomyces phillipsii (Massee) Seaver was reported by Zeller(19) from Oregon. See also SIMILAR section of Peziza domiciliana.
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as Peziza pustulata (Hedw.) Pers.), Hansen, L.(1) (as Peziza petersii), Dennis(1) (as Peziza petersii), Larsen(1) (as Peziza petersii), Van Vooren(2), Zeller(19) (re Daleomyces phillipsii). Vizzini(1)
75
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Daleomyces phillipsii  (Massee) Seaver^  North American Cup-fungi, (Operculates). Supplemented edition: 337. 1942;  Peziza campbellii  (Sacc.) Vizzini, Medardi & Forin  in Vizzini, Medardi, Tamm, Forin, Voyron & Ercole, Mycol. Progr. 19(5): 515. 2020;  Underwoodia campbellii  (Sacc.);  Peziza proteana  forma sparassoides  (Boud.) Korf  Mycologia 48(5): 714. 1956;  Peziza proteana  var. sparassoides  (Boud.) Seaver;  Aleuria proteana var. sparassoides  Boud.;  Underwoodia sparassoides  (Boud.) Banhegyi;  Durandiomyces phillipsii  (Massee) Seaver;  Daleomyces gardneri  Setch.  Mycologia 16(5): 241. 1924
ENGLISH NAME(S)  false Sparassis, bonfire cauliflower, cabbage-head fungus
NOTES  Features include 1) large cabbage-like clumps of cups, the clumps becoming almost spherical or elongated and up to 25cm high, or up to 120cm wide, extensively convoluted like a Gyromitra and the cups distorted by mutual pressure, 2) a spore-bearing surface whitish flushed with pink, lilac, or pale ochraceous, 3) brittle flesh, 4) absent to short, thick stem, 5) growth on the ground or on stumps, often in burnt places, and 6) microscopic characters. This species has been known as Peziza proteana var. sparassoides.^ |Seaver described it fungus as Daleomyces phillipsii (Massee) Seaver. He also described Peziza proteana (Boud.) Seaver forma proteana. The two are similar microscopically but Peziza proteana forma proteana lacks the very convoluted form, taking the form of a similarly colored cup or disc 2-6cm across. According to Korf(8) and Dennis(1) these two agree in microscopic characters and those authors as well as others regarded Daleomyces phillipsii (Massee) Seaver as a variety sparassoides or a form sparassoides of Peziza proteana. Korf(8) pointed out that three different authors reported seeing the two forms growing together. |But in 2020, Vizzini(11) concluded from DNA sequencing that Peziza proteana var. proteana was a synonym of Peziza petersii, and Peziza proteana forma sparassoides is a different species which should be called Peziza campbellii. [It may be that that single cups accompanying the sparassoid forms are related to those forms rather than to Peziza petersii (=P. proteana).] | Also in 2020, Van Vooren(2) provided a rationale for the breakup of Peziza into several genera. This process, discussed in more detail under Peziza praetervisa, results in resurrection of Daleomyces phillipsii as the current name of Peziza campbellii. |Both Vizzini(11) and Van Vooren(2) regard Peziza proteana forma proteana (here Daleomyces petersii) as a separate species from Peziza proteana forma sparassoides (here Daleomyces phillipsii). Peziza petersii (here Daleomyces petersii) from Oregon was included in the Vizzini(1) study, confirming the presence of its synonym Peziza proteana forma proteana. The typical form of Peziza proteana is otherwise not well documented from the Pacific Northwest, partly because the form is often not specified (e.g. Larsen(1) lists Washington Oregon, and California for Peziza proteana; the University of Washington online has two Washington collections not specifying the form; Oregon State University online has two Oregon collections not specifying the form [one is Peziza campbellii (here Daleomyces phillipsii), see below]). Even if the herbarium collections were examined and found to be simple cups, it would not be straightforward to confirm the diagnosis. Seaver lists Peziza proteana from New York, Texas, and France, (Seaver(1)). |Seaver describes the sparassoid form as Durandiomyces phillipsii initially and then in the supplement as Daleomyces phillipsii, listing New York, Washington, Oregon, and Europe as the distribution. RANGE ^The attached photos by Laurel Saville and Fred Rhoades are from the same WA collection. Daleomyces phillipsii has been found from NY to WA and OR and Europe, (Seaver(1)). A collection from OR by W.C. Denison was deposited at Oregon State University and was designated Peziza campbellii (here Daleomyces phillipsii) in the molecular study of Vizzini(11).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  forming large cabbage-like clumps 10-30cm or more across, the cups much distorted by mutual pressure; spore-bearing inner surfaces whitish to tan, often with a pinkish or lilac tinge, smooth or wrinkled; margin(s) often wavy^, (Arora), very large, becoming almost spherical or elongated and up to 25cm high, extensively convoluted like a Gyromitra but without stem; spore-bearing surface whitish flushed with pink, lilaceous or pale ochraceous tints, (Dennis, forma sparassoides), reaching a height of 20-25cm and diameter of 15-20cm (Seaver), a collection 100cm wide reported (Seaver), the white to pinkish fruitbodies in many ways resemble a head of cabbage, not uncommonly 30cm in diameter and reported at least as large as 120cm in diameter, (Korf)
FLESH  thin, brittle^, (Arora)
UNDERSIDE  same color as inner (upper) surface, "or slightly paler or darker, or often lilac-tinged at or toward the base; often slightly scurfy"^, (Arora)
STEM  "scarcely attenuated at the base"^ (Seaver), absent or rudimentary (Arora), "In some specimens there is an undifferentiated, sterile base which has been termed by some authors a stipe", (Korf), illustration showing a short stout stem [about a third the height and a quarter the width of the fruitbody], (Setchell) 
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  "Several herbarium labels and notes refer to its excellent esculent qualities." (Korf(8))
HABITAT  on ground in woods, especially of Fagus, often after fires, September to October^, (Dennis), "on the ground in burnt places (Seaver), usually occurs on burned-over areas, not uncommonly on burned stumps and/or soil in beech or predominantly beech forests", (Korf)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-13 x 4.5-7 um, elliptic, minutely roughened, usually with 2 small oil droplets^, (Arora), spores 10-13 x 6-7 um, minutely warted, with 2 oil drops; asci up to 300 x 11 um; paraphyses straight, slightly clavate, slender, colorless or containing yellowish drops, (Dennis), spores 11-12 x 7 um, elliptic, becoming minutely ornamented with minute warts or papillae, usually containing 2 oil droplets; asci reaching a length of 250-300 um and a width of 10-11 um, cylindric or subcylindric, scarcely narrowed at base; paraphyses widened upward, reaching 5-7 um at tip, (Seaver for forma sparassoides as Durandiomyces phillipsii)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as Durandiomyces phillipsii)*, Arora(1) (as Peziza proteana forma sparassoides), Dennis(1) (as Peziza proteana forma sparassoides) Larsen(1) (discussing Peziza proteana), Korf(8) (as Peziza proteana forma sparassoides), Durand(1) (as Peziza proteana var. sparassoides)*, Setchell(1)* (as Daleomyces gardneri)*, Vizzini(11) (as Peziza campbellii)
76
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dasyscyphella nivea (R. Hedw.) Raitv.^  Akad. Nauk Estonskoi S.S.R., Inst. Zool. Bot., Tartu: 72. 1970;  Lachnum niveum  (Hedw.) P. Karst.,
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Dasyscyphella nivea forms tiny white stalked cups on hardwood, often oak, the margins and underside thickly covered with white hairs. Microscopically spores are fusiform to fusiform-clavate, paraphyses are filiform, and hairs are colorless, encrusted, and septate, the tips slightly clavate and smooth, sometimes with the remains of an exudate.^ RANGE ^There are three collections of Dasyscyphella nivea from BC at the University of British Columbia, deposited by O. Ceska, F24438 Jun 11,2010, F24900, Jan 12, 2011, and F25936 May 10, 2013, all from the Observatory Hill survey on Vancouver Island. The first was reidentified on Mushroom Observer by O. Ceska as Dasyscyphella montana Raitv. Jun 3, 2013 but the last is still listed as Dasyscyphella nivea.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.2cm across, "cup-shaped when young, then expanded and plate-shaped"; white to cream; smooth; "margin white and thickly covered with white hairs", in damp places the margin often with colorless droplets^, (Breitenbach), cup-shaped to shallow cup-shaped, disc 0.05-0.10cm across, "concave, whitish when fresh, whitish to pale yellowish when dry", (Raitviir)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white and thickly covered with white hairs^, (Breitenbach), pure white; "densely covered with straight hairs shorter at the flanks and longer at the margin that are white when fresh, yellowish and covered with orange to brownish orange granules when dry", (Raitviir)
STEM  long^ (Breitenbach), 0.05-0.12cm long, cylindric, (Raitviir)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to densely cespitose (tufted), on damp rotten wood of Quercus (oak) lying on the ground, rarely on Fagus (beech), "commonly on cavities and on buried pieces of wood", fruiting throughout the year, (Breitenbach), on fallen sticks and decaying wood of Quercus robur (English Oak), more rarely on Carpinus spp., Betula spp., Fagus spp., Populus spp., Salix spp., Pyrus communis, (Raitviir for Eurasia), O. Ceska's collections from BC were fruiting in January, May, and June and growing on Quercus garryana or unidentified hardwood
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7.5-8(10) x 2 um; fusiform to fusiform-clavate, smooth", colorless, without droplets, not septate^; asci 8-spored, 45-60 x 4-5 um, iodine positive, spores irregularly seriate in ascus; paraphyses 1-1.5 um thick, "filiform, septate", "projecting a little beyond the asci"; hairs colorless, "thin-walled, encrusted, septate, tips slightly clavate and smooth, sometimes with remains of an exudate" (Breitenbach), spores (5.0)6.0-7.5(9.0) x 1.7-2.3 um, elliptic-fusoid (sometimes slightly clavate), colorless, aseptate, without inclusions, uniseriate; asci 8-spored, 40-53 x 3-5 um, cylindric to cylindric-clavate, arising from croziers, apical pore blue in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses exceeding the asci by up to 12 um, 1.5-3 um wide, cylindric to narrowly lanceolate, aseptate; hairs 60-110 x 2-4 um, "coarsely granulate with one or two smooth apical cells", 4-5 septate, "bearing sparse to numerous crystals and spherical crystal balls of calcium oxalate, heavily encrusted with deep orange amorphous matter dissolving in KOH", apical cell "only slightly longer than the other cells", up to 20 x 4 um, "subclavate with rounded tip"; ectal excipulum composed of textura prismatica, cells colorless, thin-walled, 12-18 x 5-8 um, (Raitviir).
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Lachnum virgineum is similar or the same species as Dasyscyphella nivea: Seaver gives Lachnum niveum Karst. as a synonym of Lachnella virginea (Batsch) Phill. saying that none of the characters used to differentiate the two species appear to have any particular value (Phillips in British Discomycetes uses lanceolate paraphyses in L. virgineum, Rehm says they both have lanceolate paraphyses and uses other criteria, Gillet uses the form of the cup or length of hairs). However, the differentiation is maintained by such modern authors as Hansen, L.(1), Dennis(1), and Breitenbach(1) as follows. Lachnum virgineum has hairs that are granulose at the apex, whereas Dasyscyphella nivea has the apical 1-3 cells(s) of hairs smooth, also paraphyses of Lachnum virgineum are lanceolate, whereas those of Dasyscyphella nivea are cylindric to narrowly lanceolate, (Hansen). Lachnum virgineum has lanceolate paraphyses considerably longer than the asci, whereas Dasyscyphella nivea has filiform paraphyses, scarcely longer than the asci, as well as a different type of hairs on exterior, (Dennis). Lachnum virgineum has lanceolate paraphyses, hairs with blunt to slightly clavate tips, and grows on dead branches and twigs, Rubus canes, beechnut shells, cones, etc. but Dasyscyphella nivea has filiform paraphyses, hairs with slightly clavate and smooth tips, sometimes with the remains of an exudate, and grows primarily on wood, mostly oak, (Breitenbach). Kanouse records both species from WA without making clear what criteria she used to separate them: her collection of Lachnum niveum on Rubus species has lanceolate paraphyses, (Kanouse), characters that fit the modern concept of Lachnum virgineum better than Dasyscyphella nivea: the presence of Dasyscyphella nivea in the Pacific Northwest remains a subject of inquiry. Dasyscyphus montana Raitv. was collected from BC by O. Ceska, originally identified as D. nivea, but re-identified by her as D. montana. However, spores were measured at 8-11 x 2.5-3 um, narrower than the measurements given in Raitviir(2): (5.0)7.17.8(9.0)  1.82.2 um.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Dasyscyphus niveus), Raitviir(2), Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1)
77
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dasyscyphus pini  (Brunch.) G.G. Hahn & Ayers^  Mycologia 26(6): 487. 1934 [as 'Dasyscypha'];  Lachnella pini  Brunch.;  Lachnellula pini  (Brunch.) Dennis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny bright orange cup-shaped to disc-shaped fruitbodies with cinnamon hairs on the margin and exterior, distinct stem, gregarious occurrence on resinous cankers of 5-needled pines, and microscopic characters.^ | Most Dasyscyphus species in the Pacific Northwest have current names in Lachnum or Lachnellula, but the current name for this one remains Dasyscyphus pini (the online Species Fungorum, and MycoBank, both accessed June 14, 2016). RANGE ^Collections examined from BC, WA, ID, MT, and MI, and reported from Norway and Sweden, (Hahn).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.4cm across, occasionally 0.5cm, at first spherical, urn-shaped, expanding as a flat disc with a bright orange upper surface which becomes yellow ocher when old; disc surrounded by marginal hairs; when dry the exterior "folds against itself over the center in an elongate fashion concealing the disc" and in large fruitbodies, "the folding may occur from three places on the margin"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale cinnamon hairs cover the exterior, when old the hairs may darken to cinnamon-brown
STEM  distinct stem even at an early age
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  fruitbodies "separate or aggregate, occurring abundantly on resinous cankers" of 5-needled pines (parasitic on them): Western White Pine (Pinus monticola), Eastern White Pine (Pinus strobus), Whitebark Pine (Pinus albicaulis), and in Europe on the 2-needled Scots Pine (Pinus sylvestris); in the Pacific Northwest it grows at upper elevations
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13.0-22.0 x 4.4-7.0 um, commonly 15-20 x 5-6 um, elongate elliptic, straight, occasionally pyriform [pear-shaped], with one apex obtuse, the other tapering to a subacute or acute end, uniseriate, "unicellular, commonly becoming bicellular on germination, two or three septa, however, may be laid down"^; asci 8-spored, (70)88.4-123.4 x 7.2-11.8 um; paraphyses 1.5-2 um wide, of equal diameter without swelling at tip, filamentous, protruding beyond asci, with yellowish oil droplets, septate, branched at base; hairs "simple, elongate, septate with short cells, moderately scabrous with minute roughenings, microscopically pale olive-buff, concolorous, longest hairs filiform, tapering, attenuate with exceedingly slender acuminate apices, 1-2 um broad, extremities of shorter cylindrical hairs, subacute or obtusely rounded, 3-4 um wide [using mu symbol for um]"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of pine'
SIMILAR  Lachnellula fuscosanguinea (Rehm) Dennis (=Dasyscyphus fuscosanguineus Rehm) is similar, and D. pini was recombined by Dennis as Lachnellula pini. There is debate about whether the two are one species and whether L. fuscosanguinea occurs in North America. Desjardin(6) reported the latter from California but it is not known whether they distinguish Dasyscyphus pini. They were maintained separately in the online Species Fungorum, accessed June 14, 2016. Hahn(1) regard Dasyscyphus fuscosanguineus as a saprophytic fungus occurring on pine in highlands of central Europe and say that whether it occurs in North America is problematic. According to W.W. Diehl, D. pini differs from D. fuscosanguineus in having definitely branched paraphyses, not thickened at the apex, spores that are often biseptate, and larger asci and spores. (Hahn(1)). Lachnellula arida (W. Phillips) Dennis has smaller spores and asci, and paraphyses with swollen tips, (W.W. Diehl in Hahn(1)).
SOURCES  Hahn(1) (as Dasyscypha pini), Desjardin(6) (regarding Lachnellula fuscosanguinea) 
78
FAMILY  Ploettnerulaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dennisiodiscus crossotus  (Ellis) Svrcek^  Ceska Mykol. 30(1): 9. 1976;  Trichodiscus crossotus  (Ellis) Dennis;  Trichopeziza crossota  (Ellis) Sacc.;  Teichospora crossota  Ellis & Everh.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute cup-shaped fruiting body, greenish concave disc, exterior clothed with blackish hairs, absent stem, growth on wood, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^The type from UT was in poor condition but a better specimen from WA was used for the description here (Dennis(3)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  about 0.5cm across, cup-shaped; disc concave, brownish when examined dried but apparently greenish when fresh 'a dull bottle glass green throughout, disk and all'
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  clothed with blackish hairs
STEM  "sessile on a broad base"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered, superficial; on weather-beaten wood, at 6000 feet (1800 m) in May in UT, on dead branches of Arctostaphylos nevadensis (pinemat manzanita), at 6000-7000 feet (1800-2100 m) in WA 
SPORE DEPOSIT
