MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-9 x 2.5 um, "elliptic-cylindric, straight or slightly curved", biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 50-60 x 6-7 um, cylindric-clavate, pore blued by Melzer's reagent; paraphyses 2-3 um wide, cylindric, equal or longer than the asci, obtuse; hairs up to 130 x 5 um, cylindric, obtuse, septate, walls thin and dark olive-brown, smooth; excipular cells 5-7 um in diameter, quadrate, in vertical rows
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  The well-developed obtuse paraphyses rule out Dasyscyphus, the iodine-positive asci rule out Perrotia, and the characters of the hairs rule out Lachnellula, (Dennis(3)).
SOURCES  Dennis(3) (as Trichodiscus crossotus)
79
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dermea balsamea  (Peck) Seaver^  in Dodge, Mycologia 24: 427. 1932
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, circular or wavy, yellowish to brownish then black fruitbodies that are furfuraceous at first, the spore-bearing surface concave to slightly convex and often umbilicate, colored light brown to olivaceous brown or black, the margin at first raised, yellowish, and furfuraceous, the consistency leathery to horny (fleshy-leathery when moist), erumpent growth on fir and hemlock, and microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Groves(2). RANGE ^Collections were examined from NS, ON, PQ, NH, ME, PA, and VA, (Groves). There are numerous collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre determined by A. Funk.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.1-0.25cm across, 0.04-0.08cm high, circular or undulate, "at first yellowish to brownish, furfuraceous", finally black and bald; spore-bearing surface at first concave then flat or slightly convex, often umbilicate, light brown to olivaceous brown or black (more greenish when moist), "roughened and sometimes cracked"; margin "at first raised, yellowish, furfuraceous", later black and bald, finally disappearing; conidial fruitbodies 0.05-0.1cm across, 0.02-0.05cm high, "rounded to cylindric or subconic", "yellowish or olivaceous to black", furfuraceous to bald, "tearing open irregularly and widely at the top, brittle, waxy in consistency, more fleshy when moist, usually containing a single, simple or more or less lobed cavity, occasionally with more than one"
FLESH  consistency "hard, leathery to horny", "becoming more fleshy-leathery when moist"
UNDERSIDE  "at first yellowish to brownish, furfuraceous", finally black and bald
STEM  sessile [without a stem], slightly narrowed in lower part
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  apothecia "erumpent, gregarious, mostly separate, sometimes cespitose with 2-4 in a cluster", on Abies balsamea (Balsam Fir) and Tsuga canadensis (Eastern Hemlock); conidial fruitbodies "erumpent to subimmersed, gregarious to scattered", (Groves), BC specimens mostly on Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir) and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), also on Abies amabilis (Pacific Silver Fir), Pinus monticola (Western White Pine), and Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (18)20-30(35) x (5)6-8(10) um, elliptic-fusiform, straight or slightly curved, colorless or slightly yellowish, 1-4-celled, irregularly biseriate or almost uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, (90)100-130(150) x (12)14-16 um, cylindric-clavate, tapering to a more or less elongated stem; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um in diameter, filiform [thread-like], colorless, "septate, usually much branched", "the tips glued together forming a yellowish epithecium, and only very slightly or not at all swollen"; conidia (50)60-75(90) x 4-5 um, elongate-filiform, usually curved, sickle-shaped to sigmoid, (sometimes almost straight), pointed at ends, colorless to pale greenish yellow, 1-4-celled; conidiophores 15-25 x 2.0-2.5 um, colorless, "septate, sometimes branched, tapering to a slender tip"; microconidia 11-22 x 1.0-1.5 um, filiform, straight or curved, colorless, 1-celled
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to balsam'
SIMILAR  Dermea pseudotsugae also has relatively large (for Dermea) yellow to black apothecia and conidia with sharply pointed ends, exceeding 35 um long, and both grow on conifers, but the fruiting structures of Dermea balsamea are larger: apothecia reach 0.25cm whereas those of D. pseudotsugae rarely exceed 0.15cm, the maximum length of the spores in D. balsamea is 7 um more than in D. pseudotsugae, and the maximum length of the macroconidia in D. balsamea is twice the length in D. pseudotsugae, (Funk(2)). Dermea cerasi and Dermea molliuscula have different habit, habitat, and microscopic characters (Dermea balsamea occurring on Abies and Tsuga and apothecia usually occurring singly or in clusters of 2 or 3, having asci somewhat broader and ascospores slightly larger than the other two, conidia mostly longer than those of D. cerasi and broader than those of D. molliuscula, and conidial fruitbodies usually with only a single cavity and smaller and more pycnidium-like than those of either of the other two species), (Groves). Dermea grovesii has reddish brown apothecia, (Funk(2)).
SOURCES  Groves(2), Funk(2)
80
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dermea cerasi  (Pers.) Fr.^  Syst. Orb. Veg. 115. 1825;  Cenangium cerasi  Fr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, blackish, cup-shaped to cushion-shaped fruitbodies, brown-black exterior that projects as a margin, clustered growth from under bark on dead Prunus branches, conidial stage also emerging, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Dermea cerasi is found from ME to WA and SC, is probably widely distributed through North America, and is also found in Europe, (Seaver). It is found in Switzerland (Breitenbach). Collections were examined from BC, NS, ON, PQ, MD, ME, MI, NH, NJ, NY, PA, Austria, Belgium, Hungary, Sweden, and the United Kingdom, (Groves).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.2-0.5cm, turbinate [top-shaped] when young, then convex to cushion-like^; spore bearing surface black to brown-black, rough, and surrounded by a projecting brown margin, (Breitenbach), apothecia 0.1-0.3cm wide and 0.15cm high, narrowed in lower part, "at first brownish, finally black, leathery to horny; hymenium at first concave, becoming plane, or convex, often slightly umbilicate, black, or slightly olivaceous"; conidial stage emerging, "irregular in form, circular, or elongate to conical, usually with several flask-shaped bodies which open irregularly", reaching a height of 0.1cm, soft-waxy, whitish to yellowish, (Seaver), 0.1-0.3cm across, up to 0.15cm high, circular to undulate; spore-bearing surface at first concave, becoming flat or convex, roughened, sometimes cracked, occasionally slightly umbilicate, black, olivaceous to greenish when moist; margin at first thick, raised, furfuraceous, finally bald and disappearing, openings of the pycnidial cavities often appearing as yellowish wrinkles around the margin; conidial fruitbodies erumpent, gregarious, 0.05-0.2(0.3)cm in length, 0.02-0.1cm high, very irregular in shape, circular or elongated, rounded irregularly to conic, whitish to yellowish, pruinose to farinaceous, surface wrinkled, soft, waxy, brittle, becoming more fleshy when moist, usually containing several flask-shaped, more or less lobed cavities that open irregularly and sometimes widely, tissue similar to the basal stroma of the apothecia, (Groves)
FLESH  yellow to yellow-green^, (Breitenbach), consistency leathery to horny, becoming more fleshy-leathery when moist, (Groves)
UNDERSIDE  brown-black^ (Breitenbach), at first brownish to yellowish brown, furfuraceous, finally black and bald, (Groves)
STEM  arising in clusters from a stroma lying under the bark^, (Breitenbach), sessile, fruitbody narrowed in lower part, (Groves)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  emerging from bark on dead branches of Prunus cerasus (sour cherry) or Prunus avium (wild cherry) in compact groups, in spring, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), simple, or more often cespitose [in tufts], "on branches of various species of Prunus", (Seaver), erumpent, "gregarious, separate or sometimes cespitose, with few in a cluster", on Prunus species
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-25 x 4-5 um, fusiform-elliptic, straight or slightly curved on one side, smooth, colorless, with 1 to several droplets, with 1 septum when mature, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 100-125 x 10 um, amyloid; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], sometimes forked toward tip, septate, (Breitenbach), spores 15-25 x 5-7 um, elliptic-fusoid, colorless to yellowish, straight or slightly curved, simple becoming 3-septate; asci 8-spored, reaching 100-150 um long and 10-15 um wide, cylindric-clavate, tapering in lower part to a stem-like base; paraphyses simple or branched, the tips swollen and forming a yellowish epithecium; conidia 35-65 x 2.5-4.5 um, sickle-shaped or almost straight, fusiform [spindle-shaped], colorless to faintly yellowish, simple or 1-septate; conidiophores 10-25 x 2-2.5 um, simple or branched, tapering to a slender tip; microconidia 12-23 x 1-1.5 um, filiform [thread-like], straight or curved, simple, colorless, (Seaver), 
NAME ORIGIN  means "of cherry"
SIMILAR  Dermea padi (Alb. & Schwein.) Fr. (examined from NY, Austria) and Dermea prunastri (Pers.) Fr. are also found on Prunus: ascospore and ascus characters are similar and the characters that most clearly separate them are the size and shape of the conidia. In D. cerasi 1) the sexual fruitbodies, usually occurring in clusters, are relatively large, usually exceeding 0.1cm and often more than 0.15cm in diameter, 2) the conidial fruitbodies consist of fleshy stromata usually containing several cavities, and 3) the conidia are mostly 40-60 x 2.5-4.5 um and sharply pointed at the ends. In Dermea padi, 1) the sexual fruitbodies are smaller, mostly about 0.1cm in diameter and mostly occurring singly, 2) the conidial fruitbodies consist of hard, horny, rostrate stromata, usually containing a single cavity, and 3) the conidia are similar in shape to those of D. cerasi but much smaller, 20-30 x 2.5-4.0 um. In Dermea prunastri, 1) the sexual fruitbodies are usually in clusters, more brownish than those of the other 2 species, and usually less than 0.1cm in diameter, 2) the conidial fruitbodies are usually cespitose, long-rostrate, very hard and horny in consistency, and contain a single cavity, and 3) the conidia are 20-30 x 4-7 um, about the same length as those of D. padi but thicker and not as sharply pointed at the ends. (Groves). See also SIMILAR section of Dermea balsamea.
SOURCES  Groves(2), Seaver(2), Dennis(1), Breitenbach(1)*
81
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dermea grovesii  J. Reid & Piroz.^  Can. J. Bot. 44: 648/ 1966
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, circular, dark reddish brown to black, slightly furfuraceous fruitbodies with the spore-bearing surface black and flat to convex, the margin at first raised; consistency leathery to horny (fleshy-leathery when moist); erumpent growth on spruce; and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Dermea grovesii was described from ON. There are 2 collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre determined by A. Funk.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.03-0.1cm across, 0.04-0.12cm high, "circular to slightly undulate"; spore-bearing upper surface black, flat to becoming convex; "at first with a thick, raised margin which later disappears"; conidial fruitbodies 0.02-0.045cm in diameter at their base, 0.1-0.2cm high, "cylindric to cylindric-conic or subulate to frequently slightly swollen at their tips", brown to black, bald, consistency "hard, horny, brittle, becoming more fleshy-leathery when moist"
FLESH  consistency hard, leathery to horny, becoming more fleshy-leathery when moist
UNDERSIDE  dark reddish brown to black; slightly furfuraceous
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "erumpent, scattered to gregarious, separate or sometimes two to four in a cluster" on Picea glauca (White Spruce); conidial fruitbodies "erumpent, scattered, single, or clustered in groups of two to five and then united at their base", arising from a spherical to irregularly shaped basal stroma, (Reid, J.), BC specimens were also on Picea glauca
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16.5-21.5 x 6-8 um, elliptic, straight to somewhat curved, colorless, but containing a yellowish-brown pigment in the droplets, 0-2-septate but mainly with one median septum, not constricted^; asci 8-spored, 65-120 x 13-15 um, cylindric-clavate, tapering in lower part into a short stem; paraphyses filiform, colorless, "septate, simple or branched, slightly swollen and glued together at their tips through gelatinization"; conidia 60-95 x 6.5-8 um, "straight to usually curved, falcate", at first colorless and continuous [aseptate], becoming yellowish brown and 6-septate to 10-septate; phialides 33-55 x 2.5-4 um, "with a minute collar, simple, cylindric, with 1 or 2 septa", colorless to nearly colorless at their base; microconidia not seen
NAME ORIGIN  "in honor of Dr. J. W. Groves whose studies on the genus Dermea have clarified this difficult genus", (Reid, J., genus name italicized)
SIMILAR  Dermea piceina Groves, described from Ontario on spruce, has slightly longer asci and slightly shorter spores, but the most significant difference is that the conidial fruitbodies of D. piceina are almost spherical and 0.01-0.03cm in diameter and the conidiophores lining the cavity are simple to branched and produce 1-celled to 4-spored conidia only 22-40 x 3-5 um, (Reid, J.). See also SIMILAR section of Dermea balsamea and Dermea pseudotsugae.
SOURCES  Reid, J.(1)
82
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dermea libocedri  J.W. Groves^  Mycologia 38: 382. 1946
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, circular, dark brown to black fruitbodies, the spore-bearing surface concave to flat, black, and rough, the margin at first raised, brownish, and thick; the consistency leathery to horny (fleshy-leathery when moist); erumpent growth on Incense-cedar; and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Dermea libocedri was described from one collection in Del Norte County in northwestern CA: it should be looked for in the Oregon range of Libocedrus decurrens.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.03-0.05cm across, 0.02-0.03cm high, circular to slightly undulate, dark brownish black to black; spore-bearing surface concave to flat, black, rough; margin, thick, raised, brownish, later disappearing; conidial fruitbodies 0.02-0.03cm across and about the same high, "rounded to subcylindric, opening at the tip, similar in consistency to the apothecia", black, bald, "containing a single oval or slightly lobed cavity lined with conidiophores"
FLESH  consistency leathery to horny, more fleshy-leathery when moist
UNDERSIDE  dark brownish black to black
STEM  sessile (without a stem), fruitbody slightly narrowed in lower part
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  apothecia "erumpent, gregarious", separate or in small clusters of 2 to 4, on Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar); conidial fruitbodies erumpent, separate
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-20 x 6-8 um, elliptic-fusiform, straight or slightly curved, colorless, 1-4-celled, biseriate in upper part of ascus and uniseriate in lower part^; asci 8-spored, 75-100 x (12)14-17 um, cylindric-clavate, with short stem; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um wide, filiform [thread-like], colorless, simple or branched, the tips swollen to 3-4 um and forming an epithecium; conidia 42-65 x 4-6 um, elongate-filiform, sickle-shaped or sigmoid, pointed at ends, colorless, 1-4-celled; conidiophores 20-30 x 2.5-3.5 um, cylindric, pointed at tip, simple or branched near base, colorless, aseptate, occasionally septate; microconidia 10-18 x 1.0-1.5 um, filiform, straight or curved, ends not pointed, colorless, 1-celled
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Libocedrus', referring to habitat
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Groves(2)
83
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dermea molliuscula  (Schwein.) E.K. Cash^  Mycologia 29: 304. 1937
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) tiny, circular or wavy or distorted, yellowish brown then blackish fruitbodies, the spore-bearing surface concave then convex, colored dark olivaceous brown to black, the margin at first thick, raised, and yellowish brown, 2) consistency leathery to horny (fleshy-leathery when moist), 3) erumpent growth on birch, and 4) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from NS, ON, PQ, NH, NY, and PA, (Groves). A collection from BC is at the Pacific Forestry Centre determined by A. Funk.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.1-0.3cm across, 0.1-0.2cm high, circular, sinuate [wavy], or distorted by crowding and sometimes more or less laterally fused, "ochraceous tawny" or "tawny" (colors from Ridgway(1)) to almost black, usually slightly furfuraceous to bald; spore-bearing surface "at first concave, becoming strongly convex", dark olivaceous brown to black, greenish when moist, sometimes cracked; margin at first thick, raised, yellowish brown, later disappearing; conidial stromata 0.1-0.4cm across and 0.05-0.1cm high, "transversely elongated or almost circular", 'slightly furfuraceous, "ochraceous tawny" to blackish, waxy-fleshy in consistency, usually containing several more or less lobed, flask-shaped cavities which tear open irregularly and sometimes very widely'
FLESH  consistency hard, leathery to horny, more fleshy-leathery when moist
UNDERSIDE  "ochraceous tawny" or "tawny" (colors from Ridgway(1)) to almost black, usually slightly furfuraceous to bald
STEM  sessile [without a stem] to substipitate [with a rudimentary stem]
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  apothecia "strongly erumpent, scattered, separate or in clusters of about 2-6", on Betula spp. (birch); conidial stromata erumpent, gregarious
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (13)15-20(22) x 4-7 um, narrowly elliptic to subfusiform, straight or slightly curved, colorless becoming yellowish, 1-4-celled, irregularly biseriate to uniseriate in ascus^; asci 8-spored, (85)100-120(150) x 12-15 um, "cylindric-clavate, tapering toward the base"; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um wide, filiform, colorless, "septate, simple or branched", "the tips slightly swollen, embedded in a yellowish matrix and forming a dark epithecium"; conidia 50-75 x 2.5-3.5 um, subfiliform, "sickle-shaped or sigmoid to almost straight", ends pointed, colorless or pale yellowish, 1-4-celled; conidiophores 15-30 x 1.5-2.0 um, cylindric, colorless, septate, simple or branched; microconidia 7-12 x 1.0-1.5 um, "bacilliform, straight or slightly curved", colorless, 1-celled
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Dermea balsamea.
SOURCES  Groves(2)
84
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dermea prunastri  (Pers.) Fr.^  Summa Veg. Scand. 362. 1849;  Cenangium  prunastri  Fr.;  Dermatella prunastri  Dowson;  Tympanis prunastri  Wallr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) minute, smooth, dark brown to black fruiting bodies with concave to slightly convex black spore-bearing surface, the margin at first thick, raised, sometimes incurved, the consistency hard, leathery to horny, lacking a stem or with small ill-defined stem, 2) erumpent growth from cracks on bark on dead twigs of Prunus spp., and 3) microscopic characters.^ | The conidial stage of Dermea prunastri is found quite often on small, dead twigs of Prunus, but the sexual fruitbodies less often. |The modern name for the species described here is unclear. Groves lists Tympanis prunastri Wallr. as a synonym. The online Species Fungorum, accessed September 15, 2022, renames the Groves(2) description on Mycologia 38: 406 1946, which Groves had called Dermea prunastri (Pers.) Fr., calling it instead Dermea prunastri (Pers.) Groves. But they give the latter as a synonym of Eutypella prunastri (Pers.) Sacc., and treat Tympanis prunastri as a separate current name. MycoBank, accessed on the same date, does not have an entry for Dermea prunastri. RANGE ^It is found from NH to WA and SC, (Seaver). Collections were examined from WA, ID, NS, ON, PQ, NH, NY, SC, and Germany, (Groves). There is a collection from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre labeled as this species. It is also found in Europe including the United Kingdom (Dennis).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.05-0.1(0.12)cm across, 0.02-0.1cm high, dark brown to black; spore-bearing upper surface concave to flat or slightly convex, black, roughened; margin "at first thick, raised, sometimes incurved, brownish, later almost disappearing"; conidial fruitbodies 0.02-0.04cm across at the base, 0.01-0.02cm high, "cylindric to cylindric-conic or subulate", "black to greenish or olivaceous when moist", bald, consistency "hard, horny, brittle, becoming more fleshy-leathery when moist", "arising from a more or less circular to transversely elongated basal stroma", "containing a single, ovoid cavity which is frequently in the tip of the beak only but may extend down into the basal stroma"^, (Groves), fruitbody cup-shaped, leathery, dark brown to black throughout, smooth; disc flat, about 0.1cm across; conidial state often associated with the fruitbodies, consists of a cylindric or conic, smooth, black pycnidium, up to 0.2cm tall, (Dennis), fruitbody circular or undulated, 0.05-0.1cm across, 0.02-0.1cm high, leathery to horny, fleshy when moist, dark brown to black; spore-bearing surface concave to flat or slightly convex, black; conidial bodies 0.02-0.04cm across at base, 0.1-0.2cm high, cylindric or cylindric-conic to subulate [awl-shaped], hard, horny, brittle, softer when moist, black to greenish, or olivaceous when moist, "with a single, ovoid cavity which is frequently in the tip of the beak only but may extend into the basal stroma also", (Seaver)
FLESH  consistency "hard, leathery to horny", "becoming more fleshy-leathery when moist"^, (Groves)
UNDERSIDE  dark brown to black^ (Groves)
STEM  sessile [without a stem], fruitbody narrowed in lower part^, (Groves), small, ill-defined, (Dennis), sessile, narrowed in lower part; conidial bodies "arising from a more or less circular, or transversely elongated basal stroma", (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "erumpent, scattered, cespitose, occasionally single", on Prunus spp.; conidial fruitbodies "erumpent, cespitose, occasionally single"^, (Groves), erumpent in small groups from cracks in bark, on dead twigs of Prunus, (Dennis), single or cespitose [clustered], erumpent, on various species of Prunus, conidial bodies also erumpent, occasionally single, more often cespitose, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (12)15-20(25) x 5.0-7.5 um, elliptic-fusiform, straight or slightly curved, colorless becoming yellowish, 1-4-celled, irregularly biseriate in ascus^; asci 8-spored, (80)90-115(125) x (10)12-14(15) um, cylindric-clavate, short-stemmed; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um wide, filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, simple or branched, the tips slightly swollen to 2.5-3 um "and glued together forming a yellowish epithecium"; conidia (15)20-30(35) x (4.0)5.0-7.0 um, elongate-fusiform, "almost straight to slightly sickle-shaped, occasionally sigmoid, ends pointed", colorless to slightly greenish yellow, 1-celled; conidiophores 20-35 x 2.5-3.0 um, "cylindric, tapering to a slender point", colorless, septate, simple [unbranched]; microconidia 7-10 x 1.5 um, "filiform, straight or slightly curved", colorless to yellowish, 1-celled, ends rounded, (Groves), spores 15-20 x 5-7.5 um, narrowly elliptic, straight or slightly curved, irregularly biseriate; asci 8-spored, up to 120 x 15 um, cylindric-clavate, the pore sometimes turning feebly blue in iodine; paraphyses usually branched near apex, tips closely septate, enlarged to 3 um wide and adhering together; the conidia 20-30 x 4-7 um, narrowly fusiform, more or less sickle-shaped, colorless, non-septate, (Dennis), spores 15-25 x 5-7.5 um, elliptic-fusiform, straight or slightly curved, colorless becoming yellowish, simple or 1-3-septate, irregularly biseriate; asci 8-spored, reaching a length or 90-125 um and a width of 12-15 um, cylindric-clavate, short-stemmed; paraphyses 1.5-2 um wide, filiform, colorless, simple or branched, the tips swollen to 2.5-3 um and glued together to form a yellowish epithecium; conidia 20-35 x 5-7 um, elongate-fusiform, almost straight or slightly sickle-shaped, simple, transparent, slightly greenish, the ends acute, microconidia 7-10 x 1.5 um, filiform, straight or slightly curved, colorless to yellowish, simple, ends rounded, conidiophores 20-35 x 2.5-3 um, cylindric, colorless, simple, tapering to a slender point, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Dermea padi (Alb. & Schwein.) Fr. (examined from NY, Austria) and Dermea cerasi (Pers.) Fr. are also found on Prunus: ascospore and ascus characters are similar and the characters that most clearly separate them are the size and shape of the conidia. In D. cerasi 1) the sexual fruitbodies, usually occurring in clusters, are relatively large, usually exceeding 0.1cm and often more than 0.15cm in diameter, 2) the conidial fruitbodies consist of fleshy stromata usually containing several cavities, and 3) the conidia are mostly 40-60 x 2.5-4.5 um and sharply pointed at the ends. In Dermea padi, 1) the sexual fruitbodies are smaller, mostly about 0.1cm in diameter and mostly occurring singly, 2) the conidial fruitbodies consist of hard, horny, rostrate stromata, usually containing a single cavity, and 3) the conidia are similar in shape to those of D. cerasi but much smaller, 20-30 x 2.5-4.0 um. In Dermea prunastri, 1) the sexual fruitbodies are usually in clusters, more brownish than those of the other 2 species, and usually less than 0.1cm in diameter, 2) the conidial fruitbodies are usually cespitose, long-rostrate, very hard and horny in consistency, and contain a single cavity, and 3) the conidia are 20-30 x 4-7 um, about the same length as those of D. padi but thicker and not as sharply pointed at the ends. (Groves).
SOURCES  Groves(2) (as Dermea prunastri (Pers. ex Fr) Fr.), Seaver(2), Dennis(1) (as Dermea prunastri (Pers.) Fr.)
85
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dermea pseudotsugae  A. Funk^  Can. J. Bot. 45: 1803. 1967
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) tiny, circular, black or yellow fruitbodies with the spore-bearing surface flat or concave and the margin slightly raised, 2) consistency hard (fleshy when moist), 3) absent stem, 4) erumpent growth on Douglas-fir branches and stems, 5) the production of a yellowish brown color when specimens are mounted in KOH, and 6) microscopic characters.^ | This species is a causal agent of phloem necrosis in Douglas-fir. RANGE ^Dermea pseudotsugae was described from specimens from the interior of BC. It occurs on BC coast but usually only in the conidial state. It has caused serious damage to Douglas-fir plantations in northern CA, (Funk(4)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^apothecia mounted in dilute KOH produce a yellow brown discoloration in the liquid (Funk(2))
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.1-0.16cm across, 0.02-0.04cm high, circular or slightly undulate, black or yellow; spore-bearing surface flat or concave, black or yellow; margin slightly raised; conidial fruitbodies 0.03-0.1cm across, 0.02-0.05cm high, "immersed or partially erumpent, circular or somewhat flattened", "yellow to black, tearing open widely at the top, usually with a single, simple cavity", (Funk(2)), conidial fruitbodies yellow (Funk(4))
FLESH  consistency hard, fleshy when moist, (Funk(2))
UNDERSIDE  black or yellow (Funk(2))
STEM  sessile [without a stem] (Funk(2))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "erumpent, separate, gregarious", on branches and stems of Pseudotsuga menziesii [Douglas-fir], late August and September, conidia produced somewhat earlier in the year, many of the apothecia overwintered "and in the spring were found to contain ascospores which did not appear to be viable", (Funk(2))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-28 x 4-7 um, elliptic, straight or slightly bent, colorless, continuous to 3-septate^; asci 8-spored, 80-150 x 9-14 um, cylindric to clavate, short-stemmed, pore stains blue in iodine; paraphyses "longer than the asci and agglutinated to form an epithecium", filiform [thread-like], colorless, "septate, simple or branched, slightly swollen at the tips"; macroconidia 42-56 x 3-4 um, sickle-shaped, colorless to pale yellow, 0-3-septate, microconidia 8-14 x 1-2 um, filiform, curved or bent, colorless; conidiophores 18-30 um long, colorless, simple or branched (Funk(2))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Pseudotsuga'
SIMILAR  Dermea balsamea also has relatively large (for Dermea), yellow to black apothecia and conidia with sharply pointed ends, exceeding 35 um long, and both grow on conifers, but the fruiting structures of Dermea balsamea are larger: apothecia reach 0.25cm whereas those of D. pseudotsugae rarely exceed 0.15cm, the maximum length of the spores in D. balsamea is 7 um more than in D. pseudotsugae, and the maximum length of the macroconidia in D. balsamea is twice the length in D. pseudotsugae, (Funk(2)). Dermea grovesii has reddish brown apothecia, (Funk(2)).
SOURCES  Funk(2), Funk(4)
86
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dermea rhytidiformans  A. Funk & Kuijt^  Can. J. Bot. 48: 1481. 1970
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a tiny dark brown fruitbody on cork ridges of Subalpine Fir trees with cork bark disease, a brownish color change in the liquid when mounted in dilute KOH, and microscopic characters. Dermea rhytidiformans causes cork-bark disease of Subalpine Fir.^ RANGE ^It was described from BC.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^apothecia "mounted in dilute KOH produce a brownish discoloration in the liquid"
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.08-0.1cm across, up to 0.1cm high, "round or slightly undulate", dark brown; spore-bearing surface flat, marginate, dark brown; conidial fruitbodies 0.02-0.06cm across, 0.05-0.07cm high, "columnar to conicotruncate" to nearly spherical, "involuted on the top", dark brown, furfuraceous
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  dark brown; furfuraceous
STEM  present
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  superficial on the cork ridges of cork bark of Abies lasiocarpa (Subalpine Fir), fruiting perennially from the sides of the ridges: the fruitbodies are "at first slightly erumpent through the outer cork cells, but then appearing superficial, though sometimes slightly hidden in small cracks"; apothecia aggregated or single, superficial, "appear to be prime in late summer and autumn and occur intermixed with the conidial state"; conidial fruitbodies "single or aggregated, superficial on cork ridges or erumpent through smooth bark in early infections", "usually very abundant and present throughout the year"
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-28 x 8-11 um, elliptic to oval or irregular, light brown, aseptate^; asci 8-spored, 130-155 x 14-17 um, cylindric-clavate, short-stemmed, pore not staining blue in iodine; paraphyses "slightly longer than asci, forming an epithecium strongly encrusted with brown granules", filiform [thread-like], branching; macroconidia 25-65 x 3.5-5.5 um, "sickle-shaped to almost fusoid", colorless to light brown, 0-3-septate, "frequently with one or two swollen cells"; microconidia 10-22 x 1.5 um, "filiform, strongly curved at one end", colorless, 1-celled
NAME ORIGIN  means 'forming ridges or folds'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Funk(3)
87
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Dermea tetrasperma  A. Funk^  Can. J. Bot. 54: 2853. 1976
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, elliptic or circular, black fruitbodies with the spore-bearing surface flat, leathery consistency, absent stem, erumpent growth on Douglas-fir stem, and microscopic characters including 4-spored asci.^ RANGE ^It is found in BC (Funk).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.05-0.15cm in diameter, ellipsoid to suborbicular [nearly circular], black, spore-bearing surface flat, without margin, black; conidial fruitbody erumpent, black, 0.03-0.1cm in diameter, irregular, becoming shallow cup-shaped or disc-shaped
FLESH  consistency coriaceous [leathery]
UNDERSIDE  black
STEM  sessile [without a stem]
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  erumpent, single, gregarious, on stem of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), the conidial state first described from a blister rust canker of Pinus monticola (Western White Pine); "associated with die-back in semimature trees and also with small cankers in young trees", one collection "found on callus growth around a graft"
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-17 x 4-6 um, elliptic, colorless, continuous [aseptate], with 2 droplets^; asci 4-spored, 78-95 x 8-10 um, clavate; paraphyses "longer than the asci and agglutinated at the tips to form an epithecium", filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, branched; conidia 15-22 x 5-6 um, falcate [sickle-shaped], continuous, colorless; conidiophores 10-30 x 2-3 um, "simple, cylindric, phialidic"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with 4 spored', referring to the 4-spored asci
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Funk(4)
88
FAMILY  Chorioactidaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Desmazierella acicola  Lib.^  Ann. Sci. Nat. 17: 83. 1829
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a saucer shaped fruitbody with a flat or slightly convex disc, a whitish spore surface with dark brown dots conspicuous under a hand lens, thick white flesh, sparse dark brown bristles on the exterior, growth on old conifer needles, and microscopic characters including unusual paraphyses.^ | In the United Kingdom the fruitbody is rare but the conidial state (Verticicladium trifidum) is common on fallen pine needles (Dennis). RANGE ^It is found at least in OR (Larsen), WA (Kanouse), the United Kingdom (Dennis), and Norway (Perry).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.5cm across, saucer-shaped with flat or slightly convex disc, spore-bearing upper surface whitish or slightly glaucous, with bristles conspicuous under a hand-lens^, (Dennis), 0.1-0.3cm, disc-shaped to turbinate [top-shaped], spore-bearing surface whitish but with numerous dark brownish dots, (Hansen)
FLESH  thick, white^, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  light brown; rather sparsely set with stiff, very dark brown, bristle-like hairs^, (Dennis)
STEM  none^ (Dennis, Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on old needles of Pinus (pine) in spring, (Hansen), on needles of hemlock (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-17 x 8-10 um, elliptic, smooth, containing 2 oil droplets, with rounded colorless apiculus about 1.5 um thick at each end^; asci about 400 x 15 um; paraphyses "slender, much branched near the tip to form small fascicles of brown, septate, finger-like bodies, 3-5 um thick, with minute granules on their walls, some protruding as bristles above the general level of the hymenium", also slender simple paraphyses, "hyaline below but produced above into brown, rough-walled, septate bristles which protrude above the general level of the disc, and are conspicuous under a hand-lens"; hairs on outer surface up to 1000 um long x 20 um wide at base, narrowing to about 5 um wide at tip; flesh of loosely woven hyphae 5-6 um wide, (Dennis), spores 20 x 12 um, elliptic, smooth, with 2 droplets; protruding, branched setae-like paraphyses (illustrated), dark in upper part, in spore-bearing surface; upper part of exterior with brown, stiff, pointed hairs up to 1000 um long, lower part of exterior with slender, flexuose, brown hyphae, (Hansen), spores 15-18 x 10 um; asci 8-spored; unusual paraphyses branched above the middle, with the terminal parts pointed and dark brown; exterior sparsely covered with stellate hairs that are 250-300 um long, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living on needles'
SIMILAR  Desmazierella piceicola occurs in Europe on spruce needles in fall, with spores 48-52 x 11-12 um, (Hansen).
SOURCES  Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6), Larsen(1), Perry(2)
89
FAMILY  Drepanopezizaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Diplocarpon rosae  F.A. Wolf^  Bot. Gaz. 54: 231. 1912;  Fabraea rosae  (F.A. Wolf) Seaver  The North American Cup-fungi (Inoperculates) p.190. 1951  
ENGLISH NAME(S)  black spot
NOTES  Diplocarpon rosae forms black spots on rose leaves, and rarely minute fruiting bodies. The conidial stage, black spot of rose, is widely distributed wherever the rose is cultivated.^ RANGE ^Distribution includes BC, WA, OR, and ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.025cm wide, spherical to discoid, at first closed, opening with a star-shaped aperture; conidial stage forming large dark brown or blackish spots, sometimes confluent and involving the entire leaf
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on rose leaves
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-25 x 5-6 um, elliptic, colorless, unequally 2-celled, constricted at the septum^; asci 8-spored, reaching length of 70-80 um and width of 15 um, subclavate [more or less club-shaped]; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], enlarged at tips; conidia 18-25 x 5-6 um, "formed on erumpent acervuli, 1-septate and constricted at the septum"
NAME ORIGIN  means "of rose"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Fabraea rosae)
90
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Discinella schimperi  (Navashin) Redhead & K.W. Spicer^  Mycologia 73:  906. 1981;  == Helotium schimperi  Navashin;  == Hymenoscyphus schimperi  (Navashin) Eckblad
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, white to nearly colorless, obconic fruitbodies occurring on Sphagnum squarrosum Crome. Its mycelium penetrates and parasitizes mucilaginous cells on that species. Randomly collected samples of Sphagnum squarrosum are usually infected with D. schimperi, but fruitbodies are less common.^ RANGE ^Collections of Sphagnum squarrosum infected with D. schimperi were examined from BC, OR, AB, MB, NB, NF, NS, NT, ON, PE, PQ, SK, YT, AK, CO, ME, MT, PA, WI, Greenland, Finland, Sweden, Japan, Russia, and Ukraine (Redhead).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 0.02-0.08cm across, obconic; white to nearly colorless; bald; spore-bearing surface flat to slightly convex
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  without stem, but attached by a web of mycelium to host's phyllids
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  grows on the sphagnum moss Sphagnum squarrosum and commonly infects the mucilaginous cells in the axils of its phyllids
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-20 x 4.5-5.2 um, cylindric to vaguely elliptic, sometimes inequilateral, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled, often with two droplets^; asci 8-spored, 81-85 x 9-11 um, cylindric to narrowly elliptic, slightly tapered or rounded at top, inoperculate, apex thickened and refractive, and faintly amyloid with a more prominently amyloid, truncated funnel-like central pore when fresh, with a short narrowed pedicel and crozier; paraphyses 1-2 um wide, filiform or scarcely enlarged in upper part, sparsely or not branched; when the mucilaginous cells are infected, a single hypha "makes contact with the apical papilla on the host's cell", "and produces an appressed appressorium of much branched, closely packed ends which eventually form a dome over the upper quarter or third of the cell": at the same time, "the cell is penetrated through the apical papilla and a much branched haustorium-like structure is formed just inside the host cell's wall", growing along it, and eventually reaching the base of the mucilaginous cell, the haustorial hyphae "are closely packed, highly branched in a rivulose manner, thick-walled and slightly gelatinized", and are easily observed in a cotton blue in lactic acid solution
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Redhead(45)
91
FAMILY  Morchellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Disciotis venosa  (Pers. ex Fr.) Boud.  group^  Icones mycologicae II, Livraison 10 (October 1906)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  veined cup, cup morel, bleach cup
NOTES  Features include reddish brown to yellowish brown or light or dark brown color; cup-shape that later becomes flatter; radial wrinkles, veins or ribs; light colored margin and underside; stem short and stout and embedded in the ground if present; chlorine odor; growth under trees; and microscopic characters including spores that lack large droplets and sometimes have small droplets on both ends outside the spore walls.^ | There are several unnamed species of Disciotis in America that are similar to Disciotis venosa of Europe (Beug(3), M. Beug pers. comm., September 12, 2022). RANGE ^Disciotis venosa group is found at least in OR, ID, and also in CA, CO, NM, and UT, (Larsen). It has been reported from WA by Andrew Parker, pers. comm.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  (3)5-20cm wide, cup-shaped, usually flattening; reddish brown to brown, dark brown, or ocher brown; smooth usually becoming at least at the center radially wrinkled or veined or reticulate [with a network], or corrugated, or pebbled; margin often wavy and/or split^, (Arora), 5-15(25)cm wide, deep dish-shaped to flat plate-shaped; light to dark brown; "strongly radially wrinkled, veined, or ribbed toward the center", margin "light-colored, strongly sinuous", (Breitenbach), up to 15cm when fully expanded, dark brown, in large specimens always more or less deformed by ribs and furrows radiating from the center, (Dennis)
FLESH  fairly thick and brittle^ (Arora), 0.3-1cm thick, fragile, (Breitenbach), brittle so that large expanded specimens often split extensively and hard to collect intact, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  "whitish to buff or tinged brown"; scurfy, rough, or minutely warty, often fluted or wrinkled at the base^, (Arora), whitish to ocher; "smooth, but wrinkled to ribbed toward the base", finely furfuraceous, (Breitenbach), whitish or cream, minutely scurfy, (Dennis)
STEM  when present short, thick, and usually buried^, (Arora), short stem embedded in ground, base generally fused with the ground, (Breitenbach), 0.5-1cm long and thick, often buried in soil, (Lincoff(2))
ODOR  conspicuously like chlorine bleach (Breitenbach for Switzerland), slight odor of chlorine (Lincoff(1))^, strong smell of bleach (at least when rubbed), (Courtecuisse for Europe)
TASTE  mild^ (Breitenbach)
EDIBILITY  edible when cooked but not recommended (Arora), poisonous if eaten raw (Lincoff(2))
HABITAT  "single, scattered or in small groups in damp soil or humus under or near trees or occasionally in the open", mainly in spring^, (Arora), single to grouped in "forest on floodplains, clearcuts, hedges, among herbs on damp or mossy ground", (Breitenbach for Switzerland), typically on ground under hardwoods, but in Pacific Northwest reported under conifers; March to May (Lincoff(2))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 19-25(30) x 12-15(17) um, elliptic, smooth, without large oil droplets^, (Arora), spores 19-23(25) x 12-13(15) um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, sometimes with small droplets on both ends outside the spore wall; asci 8-spored, 300-350 x 17-23 um, inamyloid; paraphyses "septate, some of them forked toward the base, with clavate thickenings at the ends to 8-10 um and with brownish contents", (Breitenbach), "paraphyses septate, with brown sap, slightly clavate and up to 12 um broad at the tip", (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin meaning "veined", from appearance^, (Lincoff(1))
SIMILAR  Peziza species have thinner flesh and the ascus layer turns blue if a drop of iodine solution is placed on it, (McKnight). Gyromitra ancilis is less cup-like, less veined, with a mild odor, and has warted spores that have three oil drops.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Arora(1), Dennis(1), Lincoff(2)*, Lincoff(1)*, Larsen(1), Courtecuisse(1)*, McKnight(1)*, Buczacki(1)*, Beug(3), Marrone(1)*
92
FAMILY  Rhytismataceae, Order Rhytismatales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Discocainia treleasei  (Sacc.) J. Reid & A. Funk^  Mycologia 58: 432. 1966;  Scleroderris treleasei  Sacc.;  Atropellis treleasei  (Sacc.) Zeller & Goodd.;  Godronia treleasei  (Sacc.) Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) small, very dark brown to black fruitbodies with a narrow point of attachment, opening at maturity by tearing of the tissue overlying the concave, light yellow to brown spore-bearing surface, 2) consistency that is cartilaginous to leathery when moist, 3) erumpent, scattered or clustered growth on hemlock and spruce, and 4) microscopic characters including filiform-clavate spores.^ | The family position is uncertain, and some authors consider this taxon to be in the family Helotiaceae. RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, and AK, (Reid, J.).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] up to 0.4cm across and 0.15cm high, circular to oval, "very dark brown to black at maturity"; opening at maturity by irregular or crenate tearing of the excipulum overlying the spore-bearing surface; spore-bearing surface concave, light yellow to brown
FLESH  consistency of fruitbody cartilaginous to leathery when moist
UNDERSIDE  "very dark brown to black at maturity"
STEM  narrowed in lower part to a narrow point of attachment, appearing to arise from a black stromatic tissue seated in the host periderm
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  erumpent, scattered or clustered, on Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock) and Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 35-56(60) x 1.5-2.5 um, filiform-clavate, broadest near upper end, tapering gradually in lower part to a point, nearly straight to slightly curved, 1-celled, "lying parallel or occasionally spirally coiled along the long axis of the ascus"^; asci 8-spored, 100-142 x 5.5-10 um, "clavate, broadest near apex", conspicuously narrowed in upper part, "then acutely rounded at the apex", pore not turning blue in iodine; paraphyses 1.5-2.5 um wide, "filamentous, curled, coiled, or recurved", colorless, simple or branched at tips, projecting beyond the asci to form an epithecium
NAME ORIGIN  after William Trelease, taxonomist and the Missouri Botanical Garden's first director
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Reid, J.(1)
93
FAMILY  Dacrymycetaceae, Order Dacrymycetales, Class Dacrymycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ditiola peziziformis  (Lev.) D.A. Reid^  Trans. Br. mycol. Soc. 62(3): 474. 1974;  Femsjonia pezizaeformis  (Lev.) P. Karst.;  Femsjonia luteoalba  Fr.;  Femsjonia radiculata  (Sowerby) G.W. Martin;  Guepinia luteoalba  (Fr.) Lloyd;  Ditiola conformis  P. Karst.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly category. Ditiola peziziformis has top-shaped to cup-shaped, gelatinous, yellow fruit bodies with a whitish margin and a downy, whitish outer surface, and they usually grow on hardwoods.^ RANGE ^Distribution includes BC, and also NS, ON, PQ, GA, ME, MI, NH, NY, OH, SC, and VT, (Ginns), Europe (Breitenbach), Japan (Martin), and the British Isles, Czechoslovakia, Finland, Germany, Sweden, USSR, and Japan, (McNabb).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-1cm wide and the same tall, cylindric, turbinate [top-shaped] to cup-shaped, disc usually flat to concave but sometimes slightly convex, margin even or slightly wavy, fruiting bodies compressed when clustered, margin white; smooth to somewhat wrinkled^, (Breitenbach), 0.3-1.4cm in diameter, 0.5-1.5cm high, at first pustulate, becoming turbinate or pezizoid, often collapsing on substrate when old; interior of cup dingy yellow, yellow, or orange yellow when fresh, darkening when old, drying dull red-brown, (McNabb)
FLESH  gelatinous, soft, translucent with whitish core; light yolk-yellow^, (Breitenbach), consistency of fruiting body firm-gelatinous, (McNabb)
UNDERSIDE  whitish, finely pubescent, "sometimes drawn out toward the base like a stipe"^, (Breitenbach), white, drying dingy white to cream; tomentose, (McNabb)
STEM  without stem or with short stem, tomentose, occasionally surrounded by a dingy cream mycelial weft^, (McNabb)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on hardwoods (Alnus, Betula, Fagus, Liriodendron), rarely conifers (Abies, Tsuga), on limbs with bark, wood with bark, branches^, (Ginns), breaking through the bark gregariously to clustered, on dead wood of Abies as well as various hardwoods, usually on upper side of fallen branches still with bark, summer to fall, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 22-25 x 8-9 um, cylindric to elliptic, some slightly curved, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with granular contents, when fully mature with 3 to multiple septa, up to 32 um long, and forming secondary spores^; basidia 60-100 x 5-6 um, tuning-fork-shaped; cystidia not seen, hyphae 2-8 um wide, sometimes inflated, most septa without clamp connections, (Breitenbach), spores (19)22-27.5(30) x 7.5-11 um, "broadly curved-cylindrical, narrowing basally, thin-walled with thin indistinct septa, tinted, apiculate", becoming tardily 3-many-septate at maturity, germination by colorless spherical to nearly spherical conidia; probasidia (65)75-110(125) x 5-7.5 um, cylindric to cylindric-subclavate, with basal clamp connections, becoming bifurcate; hymenium "superior, confined to interior of cup, composed of basidia and occasionally simple cylindrical dikaryophyses"; internal hyphae "thick-walled, smooth or roughened, clamp connections present"; cortex and stem "covered with long cylindrical, thick-walled hairs, simple or sparingly branched, with conspicuous clamp connections at all septa", (McNabb)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'in the form of a Peziza'
SIMILAR  The appearance of Ditiola peziziformis suggests an ascomycete, but the microscopic differences are obvious. Heterotextus alpinus is dull and smooth to pimply or ribbed on undersurface rather than velvety, (McKnight(1)).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)* (as Femsjonia pezizaeformis), McNabb(6) (as Femsjonia peziziformis), Ginns(5) (as Femsjonia peziziformis), Martin, G.W.(1) (as Femsjonia pezizaeformis), Courtecuisse(1)* (as Ditiola pezizaeformis), McKnight(1) (discussing Guepiniopsis alpina)
94
FAMILY  Dacrymycetaceae, Order Dacrymycetales, Class Dacrymycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ditiola radicata  (Alb. & Schwein.) Fr.^  Syst. mycol. (Lundae) 2(1): 170. 1822;  == Helotium radicatum  Alb. & Schwein.;  Dacrymyces radicatus  ([Alb. & Schwein.] Fr.) Donk
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly category. Ditiola radicata is characterized by rooting fruiting bodies with a different microscopic structure in the cap and the stout stem, and tardily 1(2)-septate spores. Young fruiting bodies are often covered by a white "veil" before the spore-bearing surface develop.^ | This description is for var. radicata. Var. gyrocephala is distinguished by more prominent stem, normally darker color, and 3-septate spores. (McNabb 1966). RANGE ^Var. radicata is found in BC, AB, NS, ON, AZ, CA, GA, IA, MA, MD, NC, NH, NY, OH, and VT, (Ginns), and the British Isles, Finland, France, Germany, Norway, Sweden, and Switzerland, (McNabb). Var. gyrocephala is found in NS, ON, LA, MA, ME, MN, MS, NJ, NY, and SC, (Ginns). D. radicata is also found in Estonia and Russia, (Raitviir), and the United Kingdom (Reid, who notes that Lowy collections are suspect because they are said to have clamp connections).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.7cm high, at first cylindric, turbinate [top-shaped], or piston-shaped, becoming stoutly stemmed and capped, occasionally with two or more caps on common stem, cap 0.2-0.5cm in diameter, shallow cup-shaped or inflated and gyrose; orange when fresh, drying dark orange brown^, (McNabb), up to 0.3(0.4-0.5)cm, at first small hemispheric pustules, but soon relatively thick and disc-shaped with shallow central depression, or barrel-shaped, cup-shaped, or cylindric, with an apical depression, but finally turbinate [top-shaped] with a flattened, smooth or wrinkled disc up to 0.25cm across; "orange when fresh becoming orange-brown when dry, but when young appearing almost hoary due to a covering of a minute scurfy-pruinose tomentum", (Reid)
FLESH  consistency of fruiting body tough-gelatinous^, (McNabb)
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  cylindric, even, stout, 0.2-0.4cm x 0.1-0.2cm, prolonged basally into a simple or forked root; stem dingy white or cream, drying pallid tan, somewhat tomentose^, (McNabb), 0.25-0.4cm x 0.1-0.2cm, covered with a whitish cream felt-like tomentum, expanding in upper part into disc and strongly rooting in lower part, in some case fruitbodies may branch from a common base, (Reid) 
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  conifer wood and hardwood, fallen limbs with bark, usually barkless wood, associated with a brown rot, Abies balsamea, Betula spp., Pinus sp., Pinus contorta, Quercus sp. Quercus coccinea, cedar, (Ginns), gregarious on conifer wood, (McNabb), all year (Buczacki)
SPORE DEPOSIT  yellow^ (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  spores (8.5)10-13(14.5) x 3.5-4.5(5) um, cylindric to slightly curved-cylindric, thin-walled with thin septa, tinted, apiculate, tardily 1(2)-septate at maturity, germination by germ tubes, occasionally by conidia^; probasidia 33-50 x 3.5-5 um, cylindric-subclavate, with basal septa, becoming bifurcate; hymenium "amphigenous, composed of basidia and occasionally simple, cylindric dikaryophyses"; structure of cap and stem are different: cap "composed of thin-walled, septate, branched hyphae of smaller diameter" [than those in stem] "loosely arranged", stem "composed of thick-walled, sparingly septate and typically unbranched hyphae lying more or less parallel and projecting into the pileus"; clamp connections absent from all hyphae; hairs on stem thick-walled, roughened, septate, with terminal cells often slightly inflated, (McNabb), spores 8.0-9.75 x 3.75-4.0 um, elliptic, none seen with septa, (Reid)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with a root'
SIMILAR  D. radicata may be confused with stemmed species of Dacrymyces, but it is readily distinguished microscopically by the difference in the structure of the cap and stem, (McNabb). Dacrymyces capitatus is very similar when immature, because the heterogeneous internal structure of Ditiola radicata does not become evident until late in development: the only sure way of distinguishing these two is to ensure that one has mature fruiting bodies while checking the internal structure, and the septation of the spores: those of Ditiola radicata are tardily 1-(2-)septate, and those of Dacrymyces capitatus are 3-septate with the septa often thickened, (Reid).
SOURCES  McNabb(7), Reid(1), Raitviir(1), Lowy(2), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)*
95
FAMILY  Sarcosomataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Donadinia nigrella  (Seaver) M. Carbone, Agnello & P. Alvarado^  Ascomycete.org 5(1): 6 (2013) [2012];  Plectania nannfeldtii  Korf  Mycologia 49: 109. 1957;  Helvella nigrella  (Seaver) F.L. Tai;  Macropodia nigrella  (Seaver) Teng;  Macroscyphus nigrellus  (Seaver) Z.S. Bi;  Paxina nigrella  Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  black snowbank cup fungus
NOTES  Donadinia nannfeldtii is a small black cup with a long slender stem, growing on wood and debris under conifers, usually near melting snowbanks.^ | This species should not be confused with Pseudoplectania nigrella (Pers. ex Fr.) Fuckel which is based on a different type collection. RANGE ^Donadinia nannfeldtii is found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, CO, and AB, (Larsen), CA and CO, (Seaver), and OR, ID, AB, and MT, (Miller).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.8-3cm across, shallow cup-shaped, usually circular in outline from above to somewhat wavy, margin straight or slightly inrolled; spore-bearing inner surface deep brownish black, smooth^, (Miller), reaching 2-3cm across, 1cm or less deep, shallow cup-shaped; inner surface black; margin more or less wavy, (Seaver)
FLESH  fibrous, tough^, (Miller)
UNDERSIDE  black; clothed with minute black hairs, wrinkled when dry^, (Miller), brownish black, clothed with inconspicuous hairs, (Seaver)
STEM  1.5-3.5(4.5) x 0.1-0.3cm, "nearly equal widening somewhat toward the base", oval to flattened in cross-section; smooth or fluted, clothed with minute black hairs, black mycelium surrounding the base^, (Miller), reaching 3-4cm long and 0.2-0.3cm wide, nearly equal, roundish or angular in cross-section, clothed like exterior with brown hairs and attached at base with a dense mass of coarse black mycelium, (Seaver), 2-6cm x 0.2-0.4cm (Arora)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora)
HABITAT  single or in a cluster of 2 to several on conifer sticks, usually in or near melting snow, at 3000-8000 feet elevation, late May to early August^, (Miller), scattered on rotten wood in coniferous woods, (Seaver), single to gregarious "in duff and debris or on buried or rotten wood under conifers (particularly fir and spruce)", in spring shortly after snow melts or even developing under snow, (Arora)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 22-32(37) x 10-15 um, elliptic, colorless with yellow granular contents in Melzer's reagent and in KOH, walls 1.0-1.8 um thick, (in 3% KOH the wall may rupture and may appear sculptured), usually with 2 droplets, one at each end, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 280-400 x 16-18 um, narrowly clavate tapering gradually toward base, operculate, colorless in KOH and in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses abundant, 380-420 x 3.5-4.5(12) um, light brown in KOH, light reddish brown in Melzer's reagent, "septate with a hypha-like end cell culminating a series of irregular swollen cells or occasionally entirely hypha-like throughout", (Miller), spores 30-35 x 15 um, elliptic, colorless or faintly yellowish, usually containing 2 small oil droplets and numerous granules, uniseriate, parallel with ascus; ascus reaching a length of 500 um and a width of 20 um, cylindric in upper part, gradually narrowing in lower part; paraphyses "numerous slightly enlarged at their apices, dark brown, reaching a diameter of 4-5 um"; hairs reaching 10 um wide, "pale brown, septate, thin-walled, flexuous", (Seaver), spores 21-35 x 10-15 um, elliptic, smooth to finely roughened, lacking large oil droplets, (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Helvella corium is larger, not as tough, and often shows ribs on the stem, (Arora). Plectania milleri differs in having at most a short stem, "cups with a toothed edge and hairier exterior", and slightly smaller spores (21-26 x 9-11 um), (Trudell). Plectania melastoma has at most a short stem, a hairy exterior with reddish orange granules, and spores 20-25 x 8-12 um that are warty, (Trudell). Pseudoplectania melaena has a short or long stem, is slightly larger, and has a yellow-brown cup when young (but blackens when old), (Arora). P. melaena has a shorter stem, an olivaceous brown cup when young, and round spores with an oil drop, (Trudell). Pseudoplectania nigrella lacks a distinct stem and has round spores (Trudell).
SOURCES  Carbone(1)*, Miller(11) (as Plectania nannfeldtii), Seaver(1) (as Paxina nigrella), Arora(1)* (as Plectania nannfeldtii), Trudell(4)* (as Plectania nannfeldtii), Larsen(1) (as Plectania nannfeldtii), Desjardin(6)*, Marrone(1)*
96
FAMILY  Drepanopezizaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Drepanopeziza ribis  (Kleb.) Hoehn.^  Annls mycol. 15: 332. 1917;  Pseudopeziza ribis  Rehm  Kleb. Cent. Bakt. II. 15: 336. 1905;  Gloeosporium ribis  Kleb.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  These are minute, conic, dark brown fruitbodies emerging from the surface of fallen Ribes leaves.^ RANGE ^Drepanopeziza ribis is found in OR, ON, and Europe, (Seaver), including the United Kingdom (Dennis).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  obconic with flat disc and small base; dark brown, smooth, disc about 0.03cm across^, (Dennis), 0.025cm across, becoming nearly flat, (Seaver); 2 collections from British Columbia at University of British Columbia identified as this species
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  small base^ (Dennis), short, stout, stem-like base, (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  erumpent [emerging] from surface of fallen Ribes leaves^, (Dennis), erumpent on leaves of species of Ribes (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-14 x 5-6 um, elliptic, with an oil droplet near each end, non-septate, biseriate^; asci 8-spored, up to 70 x 15 um, cylindric-clavate, the pore turning blue in iodine; paraphyses slender, slightly swollen up to 3.5 um wide at tip, (Dennis), spores 12-17 x 7-8 um, oval; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 80-100 um and a width of 18-20 um, clavate; paraphyses filiform, branched, scarcely widening in upper part, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means "of Ribes"
SIMILAR  Drepanopeziza punctiformis Gremmen is the teleomorph of Marssonina brunnea, Drepanopeziza populi-albae Kleb. is the teleomorph of Marssonina castagnei (Desmaz. & Mont.) Magnus, and Drepanopeziza populorum (Desmaz.) Hoehn. is the teleomorph of Marssonina populi (Lib.) Magnus: these asexual forms grow on Populus leaves (and occasionally stems) in British Columbia and elsewhere, but the Drepanopeziza fruitbodies are not well documented in British Columbia, (Callan(1)).
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Pseudopeziza ribis), Dennis(1), Callan(1)
97
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Encoelia furfuracea  (Roth ex Pers.) P. Karst.^  in Not. Sallsk. Fauna Flora Fennica 11: 253. 1870;  Cenangium furfuraceum  (Roth) Sacc. 
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include cup-shaped, cinnamon to dark brown fruitbodies covered with whitish to rust-colored meal that can be wiped off, growth on alder in spring, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Encoelia furfuracea is found from NF to ID, CA, south to IA, and PA, and also Europe, (Seaver), including the United Kingdom (Dennis). There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre and the University of British Columbia, and a collection from WA at the latter.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 1.5cm wide, cup-shaped, cinnamon-colored, drying black^, (Dennis), 0.5-1.5cm, closed and bladder-like when young, then splitting open apically more or less in the form of a star and becoming irregularly cup-shaped to saucer-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface cinnamon-brown to dark brown, smooth, (Breitenbach), reaching 1cm or more wide, closed at first but "finally opening rather irregularly and expanded but with the margin usually incurved", color of spore-bearing surface not given, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  covered with rust-colored meal^, (Dennis), lighter in color than spore-bearing surface; "strongly furfuraceous-scurfy with flakes that can be wiped off", (Breitenbach), externally whitish-furfuraceous (Seaver)
STEM  none^ (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  singly or in small clusters on living branches of Alnus and Corylus, December to May, (Dennis for U.K.), emerging in small dense groups from bark of "still-standing dead trunks and branches of Corylus (hazel) and Alnus (alder)", often covering entire branches, December to March, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), in cespitose [in tufts] clusters of five or six, or more rarely singly, on branches of species of Alnus, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-11 x 2-2.5 um, cylindric with rounded ends, slightly curved, 2-seriate^; asci 8-spored, up to 120 x 7 um, clavate with slender stem, the pore blue in iodine; paraphyses slender, swollen to 5 or 6 um wide at tip; meal consisting of globose cells 10-15 um wide, (Dennis), spores 9-11 x 2 um, allantoid [curved sausage-shaped], smooth, colorless, with 1 small droplet at each end, biseriate; asci 8-spored, 90-100 x 6 um, amyloid; paraphyses "slender, with gradual clavate thickenings toward the tips to 5 um"; detached excipulum cells 10-15 um wide, rounded, brown, (Breitenbach), spores 8-10 x 2-4 um, narrow-elliptic or allantoid [curved sausage-shaped], often with two small oil drops; asci 8-spored, reaching 80 um long and 6-7 um wide, narrowly clavate; paraphyses filiform but slightly enlarged in upper part, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means "furfuraceous"
SIMILAR  In addition to Encoelia pruinosa, Encoelia fascicularis has been recorded at least from BC (collection at Pacific Forestry Centre in Victoria): both occur on Populus.
SOURCES  Dennis(1), Breitenbach(1)*, Seaver(2) (as Cenangium furfuraceum)
98
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Encoelia pruinosa  (Ellis & Everh.) Tork. & Eckblad^  Norwegian J. Bot. 24(2): 139. 1977;  Dermatea pruinosa  Ellis and Everh.;  Cenangium singulare  (Rehm) R.W. Davidson & E.K. Cash
ENGLISH NAME(S)  sooty bark canker
NOTES  The short-stemmed fruitbodies erupt by the thousands in blackened areas of standing and fallen dead aspen where bark has sloughed off, (Callan 1998).^ RANGE ^Encoelia pruinosa is the most damaging primary canker pathogen of aspen in northern and central BC, and in the Rocky Mountain region of the United States: in CO more than half the tree mortality in commercially managed aspen stands is attributed to sooty bark cankers, (Callan). Collections were examined from ID, and also ON, CO, MI, NH, NY, (Davidson).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.3cm across, saucer-shaped; spore bearing upper surface brown; when weather dry, outer margins curl inward and the fruitbodies roll into grayish brown, rough-surfaced, longitudinally split tubes^, (Callan), reaching 0.3-0.4cm across, cup-shaped with mouth at first constricted, when dry becoming boat-shaped or angular; brown to brownish black, the margin slightly crenate [scalloped], (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  grayish brown; rough^, (Callan), brown to brownish black; covered with a white granular coat, (Seaver)
STEM  short^ (Callan)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in BC known only from Populus tremuloides (Trembling Aspen), but reported to occur occasionally on P. trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood) and P. balsamifera (Balsam Poplar) in other areas^, (Callan), on trunks of Populus, gregarious, occurring in large numbers under outer aspen bark, which rolls back exposing large blackened areas on which fruitbodies are seated, (Seaver), aspen is associated with a number of canker diseases: this one is common in most areas of the central Rocky Mountains, rather uniformly distributed through older or mature stands, seldom found in young stands up to 60 years, the bark over the cankered area usually remaining intact and tightly attached even after the tree dies, the cankers not being conspicuous but sometimes taking on "a slightly target-like appearance where part of the outer white surface has flaked away in a somewhat zoned pattern exposing part of the blackened inner bark", except for the thin white outer layer the bark becomes a uniform sooty black, fruitbodies usually develop abundantly on the old diseased black bark or under the loosened white surface layer, the fruitbodies being present in all seasons, (Davidson)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-11 x 2-3 um, sausage-shaped, colorless; asci 8-spored, 40-55 x 4-5 um on average^, (Callan), spores 8-10 x 2 um, allantoid [curved sausage-shaped]; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 55 um and a width of 4-5 um, narrow-clavate; paraphyses filiform, very slender, enlarged in upper part, with dark brown tips, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pruinose'
SIMILAR  in addition to Encoelia furfuracea, Encoelia fascicularis has been recorded at least from BC (collection at Pacific Forestry Centre in Victoria): Seaver(2), who reports E. fascicularis as Cenangium populneum on Populus or more rarely Fraxinus from CO, IA, KS, MA, and Europe, differentiates it by cespitose (as opposed to scattered), non-pruinose fruiting bodies.
SOURCES  Callan(1)*, Seaver(2) (as Cenangium pruinosum), Davidson, R.W.(2) (as Cenangium singulare)
99
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Encoeliopsis rhododendri  (Ces. ex Rabenh.) Nannf.^  Nova Acta R. Soc. Scient. upsal., Ser. 4 8(1.2): 306. 1932;  Cenangella rhododendri  (Ces.) Rehm;  Niptera rhododendri  (Ces.) De Not.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Description not available apart from the habitat. Encoeliopsis rhododendri was collected in OR by C.R. Stillinger and L.N. Goodding, on Still Creek, Clackamas County, "So far as the writer is aware, this is the first report of this species from America. The Oregon material answer's Rehm's description of the European type very closely, except that the spores in ours are mostly 19-22 x 7 um, while the descriptions give 15-20 x 4-6 um. A few pycnidia of Diplodina eurhododendri Voss were found associated, as in Europe. These pycnidia are 150-300 um in diameter with pycnidiospores 11-14 x 2.5-3.5 um.", (Zeller 1934).^ | Nannfeldt reduced Cenangella to a synonym of Dermatea (Nova Acta R. Soc. Scient. upsal. ser. 4 8(2), 1932), according to Dictionary of the Fungi, Ninth Edition, who further reduce Dermatea to a synonym of Dermea. RANGE ^included OR, Europe
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on seed capsules and stems of the inflorescence of Rhododendron californicum, June^, (Zeller)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores mostly 19-22 x 7 um^
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Zeller(14) (as Cenangella)
100
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Eustilbum aureum  (Pers.) Seifert & S.E. Carp.^  Can. J. Bot. 65(6): 1263. 1987;  Bisporella resinicola  (Baranyay & A. Funk) S.E. Carp. & Seifert  in Seifert & Carpenter, Can. J. Bot. 65(6): 1263 (1987);  Helotium resinicola  Baranyay & A. Funk [as 'resinicolum']  Can. J. Bot. 47: 1011. 1969
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) tiny fruitbodies occurring in aggregates (up to 10 but usually 2-4) on a usually short branched stem, 2) each pale orange fruitbody flat or convex, at first with a thick, raised infolded margin which may disappear, 3) an orange spore-bearing surface, 4) a whitish-yellow stem, sometimes appearing powdery, on a white subiculum that grows on resin flowing from a conifer, 5) a conidial state occasionally found together with the fruitbodies, even on the same subiculum, and 6) microscopic characters.^ |The description is derived from Baranyay(1). |Eustilbum aurea (current name in MycoBank, accessed September 18, 2022) was formerly known as Bisporella resinicola (current name, same date, online Species Fungorum). E. aureum fruitbodies occur "only on or near resin flows or exudates of conifers". "The resin exudate usually arises from cankers or wounds on the host stem." An anamorph state is also found and both states may share the same subiculum. Sarea resinae and other fungi can occur on the same resin deposit. (Baranyay(1)). RANGE ^Eustilbum aureum was described originally from Vancouver Island in BC; collections also examined from 10 other locations in BC and likely occurring more widely, (Baranyay(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  0.02-0.06(0.2)cm across, "up to 8-10 in a cluster (usually 2-4)", fruitbody flat or convex, "at first with a thick, raised, infolded margin which may later disappear"; fruitbody pale orange, hymenium orange
FLESH  fleshy when moist, hard when dry
UNDERSIDE  pale orange
STEM  0.05-0.07cm long, (short), branched, in lower part narrowing slightly; whitish-yellow, "somewhat pulverulent"; "usually on a white cottony subiculum"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "gregarious or solitary, caespitose, with up to 8-10 in a cluster (usually 2-4), rarely single"; on resin exudate of conifers; "observations over several years indicate that the apothecial state usually develops most abundantly during the winter season in the south coastal region of British Columbia", but in the interior of BC, well-developed fruitbodies "have been found in mid-summer"
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  ascospores 5.0-8.5 x 1.5-2.5 um, elliptic or oval, colorless, "contents granular or guttulate", "obliquely uniseriate to irregularly biseriate in upper part of ascus"^; ascus 8-spored, 45-67 x 4.5-7.5 um, "cylindric clavate", "pore not blue in iodine"; paraphyses 1.5-2.5 um in diameter, filiform, colorless, "septate, simple or once branched"; "tissue of the apothecium plectenchymatous, the hyphae forming a dense ectal excipulum"; "subhymenial hyphae more compact"; conidia where they occur are 2.0-2.5 um in diameter, round to nearly round, "with a small denticle at the point of attachment", colorless, but "orange in mass"
NAME ORIGIN  refers to its occurrence on resin exudate
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Baranyay(1)
101
FAMILY  Niaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Flagelloscypha libertiana  (M.C. Cooke) Agerer^  Persoonia 10: 339. 1979;  == Lachnella libertiana  (M.C. Cooke) W.B. Cooke;  == Cyphella libertiana  M.C. Cooke;  Lachnella rosae  W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute cream-colored receptacles on dead rose canes and other material, the exterior covered with opaque or yellowish surface hairs, and microscopic characters including basidia and granule incrusted hairs.^ RANGE ^Flagelloscypha libertiana has been reported from WA and ID, (Ginns), and also Belgium and Holland, (Cooke).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  receptacle 0.04cm across, 0.04cm high, cream-colored, (Cooke for Lachnella libertiana), 0.02-0.05cm, white, (Cooke for Lachnella rosae)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  cream-colored, covered with opaque or yellowish surface hairs, (Cooke for Lachnella libertiana), white, with colorless surface hairs, (Cooke for Lachnella rosae)
STEM  subsessile to sessile (Cooke for Lachnella rosae)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on dead canes of Rosa spauldingii, (Lachnella rosae), on barkless branches of Cornus mas (Lachnella libertiana), (Cooke)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-14 x 4.5-5.5 um, cylindric, flattened on one side, smooth, colorless, apiculate^; basidia 4-spored, 21.5-24 x 7-9 um, with clamp connection at base; hymenium of basidia only; subhymenial hyphae 2.5 um wide, with clamp connections; context hyphae 2.5-3.5 um wide, compact; hairs 80-100 x 3.5 um, granule-incrusted, opaque or yellowish, (Cooke for Lachnella libertiana), spores 10-11 x (4)5-7 um, ovate, smooth, apiculate, colorless; surface hairs colorless, of two types, one without staining contents, simple, granule-incrusted with large non-acicular granules that adhere to the wall, round pointed, (75)100-125 x 4-5 um, the other with contents staining red in phloxine, simple or branched, with pointed tips, (85)100-160 x 1-2 um; subhymenial hyphae 1-2 um in diameter, clamped; basidia 4-spored, 36 x 7 um, (Cooke for Lachnella rosae)
NAME ORIGIN  after M.A. Libert who collected the type
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Cooke(2) (as Lachnella libertiana and Lachnella rosae), Ginns(5)
102
FAMILY  Niaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Flagelloscypha minutissima  (Burt) Donk^  Lilloa 22: 312. 1951;  == Cyphella minutissima  Burt;  Flagelloscypha citrispora  (Pilat) D.A. Reid;  Flagelloscypha faginea  sensu W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute white cups with thin hairs on the outer surface, no stem, growth on wood and herbaceous debris, and microscopic characters including hairs that are incrusted with large rod-like to needle-like crystals of calcium oxalate.^ RANGE ^Flagelloscypha minutissima has been found in MB, SK, IA, IL, LA, ME, MI, NH, NJ, and VT, (Ginns), BC, MI, British Isles, France, Germany, and USSR, (Redhead(21)), and MI, Czech Republic, France, United Kingdom, and Azerbaijan, (Reid).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody reaching 0.05cm across, and 0.05cm high, deeply cup-shaped, very thin and delicate, on drying becoming spherical; white throughout, on drying spore-bearing upper surface may become cream-colored^, (Reid), 0.03-0.1cm, irregularly and shallowly cup-like or saucer-like; spore-bearing surface lining cup gray to ochraceous, smooth, (Buczacki)
FLESH  soft, fragile; whitish^, (Buczacki)
UNDERSIDE  "densely hairy, margin white, fringed hairy, almost completely inrolled when dry"^, (Buczacki)
STEM  sessile (no stem), in some collections associated with a fine arachnoid [webby] mycelium^, (Reid), none (Buczacki)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious, forming small scattered colonies, on very rotten fallen trunks, on woody and herbaceous debris^, (Reid), on twigs of Picea sp., ? Pseudotsuga menziesii, ? dead Alnus sapling, Populus bark, fallen Pteridium aquilinum (bracken fern), dead Vicia ?gigantea, (Redhead(21)), also Poria sp. (Ginns), in densely +/- tufted groups; on dead wood and other woody debris of hardwoods, occasionally on other plant debris, summer to fall, (Buczacki)
SPORE DEPOSIT  white^ (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  spores (6.2)8-12.2 x (3)4-5(5.75) um, varying considerably in shape according to degree of maturity, fully mature spores as seen in a spore print measure (7.5)8.75-12.2 x 4-5 um, and vary in side view from amygdaliform [almond-shaped] with a rather pronounced snout-like apex, to elliptic, but in face view appear more or less navicular [boat-shaped]^; basidia 4-spored, 18 x 5.5 um, clavate with a basal clamp connection; walls of fruitbody rarely exceed 40 um in thickness and context only a few hyphae wide and 5-10 um thick, the hyphae 2.5-4 um wide, thin-walled, colorless, branched and clamped with each hypha slightly swollen at septa; from a clamped septum on the outermost hyphae arise hairs 2.5-3(3.5) um wide, up to 210 um long, which narrow gradually to a whip-like apex and also to a lesser extent toward the base of the hair, the walls slightly thickened but thinning toward apex and sometimes base of hair, the hairs covered except at ends by conspicuous detersile, rod-like or needle-like crystals that dissolve rapidly in 10% KOH, (Reid), spores colorless, inamyloid; hairs thin, colorless, thick-walled, inamyloid, incrusted with crystals of calcium oxalate (large acicular crystals as opposed to small granular ones on Lachnella species hairs), (Cooke), spores 7-10 x 3.5-4.5 um, pip-shaped to boat-shaped, smooth, inamyloid; basidia 2-spored; cystidia absent; hyphal system monomitic; marginal hairs "white, thick-walled, encrusted to halfway, tip smooth, tapering, very slender", (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'very small'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Reid(4) (as F. citrispora), Redhead(21) (as F. citrispora), Redhead(5), Ginns(5), Cooke(2), Buczacki(1)*
103
FAMILY  Niaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Flagelloscypha orthospora  (Bourdot & Galzin) Bertault & Malencon^  Acta Phytotax. Barc. 19: 30. 1976;  == Cyphella villosa var. orthospora  Bourdot & Galzin;  Lachnella ciliata  (Saut.) W.B. Cooke sensu W.B. Cooke 
ENGLISH NAME(S)
