NOTES  Features include a minute, whitish, substipitate cup with a wrinkled margin, the cup covered externally with hairs, growth on dead twigs and herbage, and microscopic characters including crystal incrusted hairs.^ RANGE ^Flagelloscypha orthospora has been found in OR, and also ON, ME, and VA, (Ginns, assigning Cooke's records of L. ciliata (Saut.) W.B. Cooke to this species on the basis that Cooke listed Cyphella villosa var. orthospora as a synonym).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  receptacle 0.01-0.05cm across, 0.01-0.05cm high, whitish with wrinkled margin^, (Cooke), 0.1cm across (?dried), cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface white, (Bourdot)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  covered with erect, bristle-like hairs^, (Cooke), pure white, with woolly hairs, (Bourdot)
STEM  substipitate^ (Cooke), sessile (Bourdot)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on dead twigs and herbage of various plants^, (Cooke), on leaves and stems of herbaceous plants, foxglove, mullein, etc., on an apple branch, (Bourdot), in British Isles mainly on gorse (Buczacki)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-8 x 2.5-4 um, ovate to teardrop-shaped, smooth, colorless, apiculate^; basidia 4-spored, 14.5-16 x 5-7 um; subhymenial hyphae 2-3 um wide, no clamp connections seen; context thin, of colorless hyphae 3-4 um wide; hairs 50-80 um long, sometimes 175-250 x 5.5-6.5 um, narrowing gradually to a point from a base 5.5 um wide, or even and rounded at top, finely incrusted with crystalline granules, (Cooke), spores 7-10 x 4-5 um, oblong or subelliptic; basidia 18-25 x 4.5-6 um; hairs 150-200 x 3-6 um, thin-walled, subulate or abruptly narrowed to a point that is more or less long, rough (rugueux), asperulate or granulose, (Bourdot)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with cilia ' or short hairs
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Cooke(2) (as Lachnella ciliata), Bourdot(1) (in French, as Cyphella orthospora), Ginns(5), Buczacki(1)
104
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Geopora arenosa  (Fuckel) S. Ahmad^  Monogr. Biol. Soc. Pakistan &: 176. 1978;  Sepultaria arenosa  (Fuckel) Boud.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small cup partially buried in sandy soil with whitish spore-bearing interior surface and brown hairs externally extending into the soil, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^It is found in OR and CO, (Larsen), and NY to CO, and Europe, (Seaver). There is a BC collection deposited by Paul Kroeger at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 1cm across, cup-shaped (or occasionally subscutellate), partially buried, finally becoming subsuperficial [nearly superficial]; spore-bearing surface inside white or whitish; the margin entire or splitting^, (Seaver), 1-2cm across, at first spherical and only slightly embedded in the ground, later cup-shaped to saucer-shaped; spore-bearing interior surface light gray to ocher, smooth; margin notched to split, brown and with short sinuous brown hair-like hyphae and adhering sand grains, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  relatively thick and fragile; whitish^, (Breitenbach)
UNDERSIDE  externally clothed with hairs that are often tufted^, (Seaver), brown and with short sinuous brown hair-like hyphae and adhering sand grains, (Breitenbach)
STEM  without stem^ (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered on sandy soil^, (Seaver), single to gregarious on damp sandy ground, also around burned places, spring and fall, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 23-25 x 13-18 um, elliptic, the ends slightly narrowed, usually containing 2 oil droplets, uniseriate or partially biseriate^; asci 200-225 um and width of 15-18 um, nearly cylindric in upper part; paraphyses gradually enlarged in upper part where they reach a width of 7-9 um; hairs reaching a length of 200 um and a width of 9 um, flexuous [wavy] or crooked, more rarely straight and nearly rigid on exposed parts, often swollen at base, the hairs on the lower part of the cup giving rise to rhizoid-like hyphae that extend into surrounding soil, (Seaver), spores 19.5-21 x 10.5-12 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 1-2 droplets; asci 8-spored, 240 x 20 um, inamyloid; paraphyses slender, with gradual clavate thickening toward tips to 6 um wide, with few septa; hairs 80-200 x 6-10 um, "sinuous, brownish, smooth, thick-walled with thin septa, singly to multiply branched", (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'sandy'
SIMILAR  Sepultaria arenicola, [known from at least CO in western North America according to Larsen(1)], cannot be differentiated macroscopically but has larger spores, 23-28 x 14-16 um, (Breitenbach). See also SIMILAR section of Geopora cercocarpi.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Seaver(1) (as Sepultaria arenosa), Larsen(1) (as Sepultaria arenosa), Dennis(1)
105
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Geopora cercocarpi  D. Southw. & J.L. Frank^  Mycologia 103: 1196. 2011
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Truffles etc. category. Features include pale tan cups with rusty external hairs, white interior, underground habitat in association with Cercocarpus ledifolius, and microscopic characters including relatively large spores.^ | The description is derived from Southworth(1). G. cercocarpi is considered to be an ectomycorrhizal mutualist with C. ledifolius. RANGE ^G. cercocarpi is found in OR and UT (Southworth).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-5.5cm across, 0.4-2.3cm high, cup-shaped or disk-shaped, distinct margin inrolled; spore-bearing surface white
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  outer surface pale tan with rusty hairs that are more dense in immature fruitbodies and more dense near the base in mature fruitbodies
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to scattered, "buried under leaf litter or deeper in soil", under the canopy of Cercocarpus ledifolius (curl-leaf mountain mahogany), collections recorded May to July
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (20)23-32 x 13-18 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, containing one central droplet^; asci 8-spored, 200 x 18-21 um, colorless, inamyloid, thin-walled, uniseriate; paraphyses exceeding asci by up to 30 um, 5.0 um wide, thread-like, straight, unbranched, septate, rounded at tip; hairs up to 1500 x 13-14 um, branched, rusty brown to colorless, cell wall surface rough, wall 1.5 um thick, septa 0.7 um centrally but thicker at margin, tips rounded; ectal excipulum about 50 um thick, "cells generally rounded, non-interlocking", 26-30 x 20-22 um, colorless, medullary excipulum thicker, up to 600 um, of dense textura intricata, cells 9-18 um in diameter, colorless 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Cercocarpus'
SIMILAR  Geopora arenosa has smaller fruitbodies and narrower spores, (Southworth).
SOURCES  Southworth(1)
106
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Geopyxis carbonaria  (Alb. & Schwein. ex Pers.) Sacc.^  Syll. fung. 8: 71. 1889
ENGLISH NAME(S)  pyxie cup, earth box, dwarf acorn cup, stalked bonfire cup
NOTES  Features include a small cup up to 2.5cm across, with yellow brown to orange brown to red-brown interior, its margin white-scalloped or white-toothed, the exterior colored more or less as the interior, sometimes lighter toward margin and dusted with white, a stem up to 1.4cm long when present, and growth on burnt ground or burnt wood.^ | In the Pacific Northwest, Geopyxis collections may be determined with confidence as Geopyxis carbonaria if long-stemmed and on burned areas. PNW collections may be determined with confidence as Geopyxis deceptiva group if without a stem and off burned areas, or even (as is more common) on burned areas if stem is absent and spores mostly average about 16.7 um long. Placement of the genus in Pyronemataceae is not certain. RANGE ^Collections were examined from OR, AK, CA, CO, QC, Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, Norway, Poland, Sweden, India, and Japan, (Wang, X.-H.). It has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, and also AB, CA, CO, MT, and UT, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-2.5cm across, 0.2-1.8cm high, urn-shaped, funnel-shaped, nearly spherical with margin incurved, cup-shaped, "sometimes later opening with margin cracking downward into the cup in several places", shallowly cup-shaped, "regular, sometimes becoming slightly irregular due to mutual compression"; spore-bearing surface ochraceous, brown, brownish orange, rarely pale orange, darker when drying; margin "distinct, crenulate, cream-colored to whitish"^, (Wang, X.-H.), 0.5-1.5(2)cm, goblet-shaped to urceolate [with large body and small mouth]; red-brown; smooth, margin with white teeth, (Breitenbach), up to 1.5cm wide, cup-shaped; light red; margin minutely crenate [scalloped], (Dennis), 0.5-2cm, cup-shaped, ocher brown or pink-tinged, margin toothed and whitish, (Lincoff), reddish tan (Trudell)
FLESH  fleshy, pale yellow^ (Wang, X.-H.), 
UNDERSIDE  the same color as the upper surface, slightly darker or lighter than the upper surface, smooth^, (Wang, X.-H.), same color as upper surface, "somewhat lighter towards margin and dusted with white", (Breitenbach), "whitish to flesh color, minutely scurfy", (Dennis), orange-brown or pink-tinged, with minute scales, (Lincoff), yellowish tan (Trudell)
STEM  most fruitbodies clearly stipitate (stemmed), stem up to 1.4cm x 0.4cm, cylindric, expanding gradually or abruptly into cup, "solid, sometimes totally buried in the substrate", the same color as or paler than the exterior of the cup^, (Wang, X.-H.), slender, embedded in substrate, (Breitenbach), slender, whitish, (Dennis), when present 0.5-2cm x 0.1-0.15cm, slender, orange-brown to off-white, (Lincoff)
ODOR  none or fetid^ (Wang, X.-H.), sometimes smells a little like sulphur (M. Beug, pers. comm.)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to densely gregarious; on burned ground^, (Wang, X.-H.), on burnt ground or attached to charred wood, (Dennis), single to gregarious and in troops on burned ground, May to September, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12.0-13.5-16.5-18.0 x 6.5-7.4-9.6-11.0 um (the middle two values being the lowest and highest mean value for the measured collections), "subfusiform to fusiform", rarely elliptic with round ends, "smooth, rarely finely warted (seen on surface using x1000 bright field and DIC), with aggregated granules, slightly to moderately refractive"^; asci 190-230(250) x 9-13 um, presumably 8-spored; paraphyses 1.5-3 um wide at the basal and middle parts, 2.5-5(6) um wide at apices, "of equal width or slightly enlarged toward apices, some subclavate", "straight, rarely slightly bending, rarely with a small knob near the apex, with small guttules and granules in the whole length or middle-upper portion, mostly strongly refractive, rarely slightly refractive with sparse contents, when fresh with scattered yellowish brown granules and droplets", dissolving or becoming colorless to pale yellow in Melzer's reagent, (Wang, X.-H.), spores (11)12-15(17) x 6.5-8(9) um, elliptic to slightly fusiform, smooth, colorless, without droplets; asci 8-spored, 180-210(250) x 10-11 um; inamyloid; paraphyses slender, cylindric, "septate, forked toward the base, tips with slight clavate thickenings, sometimes rather lobed with gnarled outgrowths", (Breitenbach who illustrates the paraphyses forking upwards from near the base), spores 13-16 x 6-8 um, narrowly elliptic, rather pointed at each end, smooth, without oil droplets; asci up to 200 x 10 um; paraphyses slender, slightly clavate, (Dennis), spores 11-18 x 6-9 um, do not contain prominent oil droplets, (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin, meaning "growing on charcoal"^, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
SIMILAR  Geopyxis deceptiva has a stem that is 0.05-0.3 long if present, spore length is mostly > 15 um, and habitat is non-burned or burned ground, whereas fruitbodies of Geopyxis carbonaria are most often clearly stemmed (stem 0.1-1.4cm long), habitat is burned ground, and spore size is 12.0-13.5-16.5-18.0 x 6.5-7.4-9.6-11.0 um, (Wang, X.-H(1)). G. deceptiva group (as the misapplied name G. vulcanalis) is more yellowish tan, is found mostly in unburned areas, and has larger spores (14-21 x 8-11 um), (Trudell). (G. deceptiva group can grow in burned areas as well). Tarzetta species have spores with two oil drops, (Lincoff).
SOURCES  Wang, X.-H.(1)*, Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Seaver(1) (as Humarina araneosa), Lincoff(2)*, Trudell(4)*, Miller(14)*, Larsen(1), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Courtecuisse(1)*, McKnight(1)*, Buczacki(1)*, Desjardin(6)*, McAdoo(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
107
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Geopyxis deceptiva  X.H. Wang & K. Hansen  group^  Mycologia 108(6): 1189-1215
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a cup-shaped to urn-shaped, orange to brownish yellow fruitbody up to 1.1cm across, with a whitish margin that is often cracked, 2) an exterior that is smooth and colored like the inner surface or somewhat paler, with or without a short stem up to 0.3cm long that is often buried in the substrate, a mild to sulphur-like odor, and habitat most often but not exclusively on burned ground, especially in the mountains.^ |The Geopyxis deceptiva group includes Geopyxis deceptiva, Geopyxis rehmii, and the extralimital Geopyxis alpina. The members are not readily distinguishable except by DNA and all used to be known under the name Geopyxis alpina or the name Geopyxis vulcanalis, but the isotype of G. vulcanalis has been determined to be a synonym of Geopyxis carbonaria. According to Wang, X.-H.(1), Geopyxis vulcanalis sensu Seaver likely refers to G. deceptiva or G. rehmii. The description here is for Geopyxis deceptiva by Wang, X.-H.(1). In the Pacific Northwest, Geopyxis collections may be determined with confidence as Geopyxis carbonaria if long-stemmed and on burned areas. PNW collections may be determined with confidence as Geopyxis deceptiva group if without a stem and off burned areas, or even (as is more common) on burned areas if stem is absent and spores mostly average about 16.7 um long. Placement of the genus in Pyronemataceae is not certain. RANGE ^Collections of Geopyxis deceptiva were examined from OR, CO (including type), and CA (Wang, X.-H.(1)). Collections of Geopyxis rehmii were examined from WA, OR, ID, Poland (type), and Kyrgyzstan. Collections of Geopyxis alpina sensu stricto were examined from Austria, Czech Republic, Cyprus, France, Italy, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, and China, (Wang, X.-H.(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-1.1cm across, 0.2-0.9cm high, deeply cup-shaped, cup-shaped to urn-shaped, "sometimes expanding to strongly flattened, discoid, narrowly attached to the substrate, partly deformed by mutual pressure", margin distinctly raised; pale orange, orange to brownish yellow, grayish to brownish orange, ochraceous yellow to brownish yellow, drying orange to brownish orange; margin "often cracked, paler, cream to white, crenulate"
FLESH  thin
UNDERSIDE  colored as upper surface or paler; smooth
STEM  0.05-0.3 x 0.05-0.1cm (when present, bald or covered with white tomentum), without a stem or with a short stem, stem often buried in substrate, rarely clearly having a stem, sometimes base tapering downwards, forming a tapering stem
ODOR  "indistinctive, rarely unpleasant", (Wang, X.-H.(1)), may have a distinct sulphur odor (M. Beug, pers. comm.)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered or gregarious, often on burned ground, rarely from unburned ground, collections June, July, September, (Wang, X.-H.(1) for G. deceptiva), Geopyxis rehmii was described as a species from burned ground. In comparison with G. carbonaria it was also recognized "to have a lower tolerance to burn conditions", and fruitbodies "developed later (in second year) and toward the edge of the burns, until pH values had lowered in the center (in third year)". "Our data from broad sampling show that this species occurs on both burned and unburned places." In Poland it is restricted to mountain areas, "which may also be the case in North America (based on the localities in the material examined by us).", collections June, July, September, (Wang, X.-H.(1) for G. rehmii)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13.5-16.3-17.1-18.5 x 7.5-8.4-10.0-11.0 um (the middle two values being the lowest and highest mean value for the measured collections), elliptic to subfusiform, rarely typically fusiform, smooth, colorless, without droplets, "moderately to strongly refractive with small granules and amorphous content", 1-seriate^; asci 8-spored, cylindric, 230-270(300) x 10-15(17) um, colorless, base with croziers; paraphyses "mostly straight, of equal width, some slightly enlarged toward apices, rarely with deformed or forking apices", 1.5-3 um wide at the basal and middle parts, 2-4 um wide at the apices, colorless, "with sparse slightly refractive granules and amorphous content in the middle-upper portions", when fresh with small, colorless vacuoles, (Wang, X.-H.), With reference to G. rehmii, "It has a wide range of spore sizes", "and although it was described as a species with roughened spores", "most of the collections studied by us have smooth spores." (Wang, X.-H. whose figure shows spore sizes for 8 collections averaging 15..3-17.2 x 8.5-9.5 um)
NAME ORIGIN  "For being deceptive in comparison with G. alpina and G. rehmii, and because mycologists were deceived to believe it represented G. vulcanalis" (Wang, X.-H.(1), Latin names italicized)
SIMILAR  Fruitbodies of Geopyxis carbonaria are most often clearly stemmed (stem 0.1-1.4cm long), habitat is burned ground, and spore size is 12.0-13.5-16.5-18.0 x 6.5-7.4-9.6-11.0 um, whereas in G. deceptiva stem is 0.05-0.3 long if present, and spore length is mostly > 15 um, (Wang, X.-H(1)) [The criterion actually given in the key for G. carbonaria and G. delectans together is "Apothecia almost exclusively on burned ground, clearly stipitate, often with long stipes, or sessile, broadly attached to the substrate; spore length mostly <15 um (mean length <= 14.6 um)", (Wang, X.-H(1) with conventional symbols for mu and <=). This would seem to imply that the mean length <=14.6 um applies also to G. carbonaria which seems doubtful with the spore dimensions given - perhaps it is a matter of punctuation.] Geopyxis delectans, which occurs as close as Colorado, is sessile but broadly instead of narrowly attached to the substrate, it has spore length mostly < 15 um (11.0-12.2-13.9-15.0 x 6.0-7.3-8.3-9.5 um), and habitat is burned ground (Wang, X.-H(1)). G. carbonaria is darker, reddish tan to pale ocher-brown (as opposed to pale orangish buff), and is common [in Sierra Nevada and coastal California] in burnt areas in forests and campfire pits, (MykoWeb, who give habitat of G. deceptiva as bare soil, moss, or duff)
SOURCES  Wang, X.-H.(1)*, MykoWeb(1)*
108
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Geoscypha tenacella  (Sacc.) Van Vooren^  Ascomycete.org 12(4): 187. 2020;  Peziza praetervisa  Bres.  Malpighia 11: 266. 1897 sensu Pfister, Dennis;  Peziza violacea  sensu Seaver;  Peziza subviolacea  Svrcek
ENGLISH NAME(S)  violet cup
NOTES  This species is part of our Geoscypha violacea group, differing from G. violacea chiefly in its spores. Features include a saucer-shaped to expanded fruitbody with violet upper surface and pale violaceous scurfy lower surface, absent stem, growth on burned places and occasionally elsewhere on the ground, and finely warted mature spores.^ |There have been difficulties interpreting P. violacea Pers. and P. praetervisa Bres.: according to Pfister(5), "Peziza praetervisa has lightly ornamented spores as described by Seaver for P. violacea. The spores of P. violacea are completely smooth. Though P. violacea exists in North America, it is infrequently collected. Most collections under that name are P. praetervisa." The name Peziza praetervisa Bres. in the sense of Dennis has been used for Geoscypha tenacella with finely ornamented spores, as the sense of Bresadola may correspond to Peziza petersii Berk. & Curt. (now Daleomyces petersii). Because of these difficulties the name Peziza subviolacea Svrcek was proposed for P. praetervisa Bres. sensu Dennis. In effect, one view (that of Dennis(1), Pfister(5), Breitenbach(1)) uses the name P. praetervisa Bres. for the commoner species in North America that has finely warted mature spores and P. violacea Pers. for the one with smooth mature spores, and the other uses the name Peziza violacea Pers.: Fr. or Peziza subviolacea Svrcek for the commoner species in North America with finely warted spores and Peziza sublilacina Svrcek for the one with smooth spores. We follow Michael Beug in avoiding the name Peziza violacea which is ambiguous. |The current name of Peziza sublilacina in Species Fungorum was Peziza moseri when accessed on February 14, 2022. |A further development (Van Vooren(2)) is the designation of a 2010 neotype for Peziza violacea Pers., using the current name Geoscypha violacea (Pers.) Lambotte. It is hard to know what this may represent in North America, but DNA will probably solve that question. So far, according to D. Miller, pers. comm. January 8, 2022, collections matching the Geoscypha violacea neotype have been found in Alaska (1) and Oregon(2). Microscopic confirmation of smooth or roughened spores is not available for these collections. |The rationale for the use of the genus Geoscypha is that the group of species containing Peziza violacea Pers. (synonyms including P. lobulata (Velen.) Svrcek and P. pseudoviolacea Donadini) is not closely related to the core group of Peziza (containing Peziza vesiculosa, P. varia, P. oliviae, P. echinospora, and P. arvernensis, etc.). As a result, along with some morphological factors, this violacea-ampelina clade needs a resurrected genus. Besides P. violacea with its neotype, Van Vooren(2) combines Peziza queletii Medardi, Lantieri & Cacialli as Geoscypha ampelina, and Peziza tenacella W. Phillips ex Sacc. (nom. illeg.) as Geoscypha tenacella. In Table 2 on page 182, Van Vooren(2) lists Peziza praetervisa sensu Dennis and Peziza subviolacea Svrcek as older names corresponding to the current name Peziza tenacella W. Phillips (1886), nom. illeg. Later in the paper, he appears to list the last name as a synonym of Geoscypha tenacella, but lists the name as Peziza tenacella W. Phillips, in Cooke, Grevillea, 15: 100 (1887), nom. illeg. with a different date. In the actual Grevillea issue, the date associated with the entry is 1887, but the Grevillea issue is dated 1886-1887, so the date discrepancy can presumably be ignored. |The Peziza core group could still have been defined as including the /violacea-ampelina, /howsei, and /petersii lineages as well as the genera Elderia and Mattirolomyces. But if we accept the Van Vooren(2) use of new and resurrected genera for Peziza, this means that we have a different name for Peziza praetervisa sensu Dennis (and Peziza subviolacea), namely Geoscypha tenacella. (The synonymy was not explicitly made in the paper however.) It also means that Peziza proteana f. proteana is Daleomyces petersii rather than Peziza petersii in the schema of Vizzini(11) and that Peziza proteana f. sparassoides is Daleomyces phillipsii rather than Peziza campbellii in the schema of Vizzini(11). |At present we use the name Geoscypha tenacella for the species with finely warted spores and Geoscypha violacea (or Peziza moseri) for the one with smooth spores. |According to Beug(3), P. praetervisa has lightly ornamented spores with two oil drops and Peziza sublilacina has smooth spores with no oil drops. RANGE ^Peziza praetervisa has been found at least in OR, ID, also AB, CO, (according to Larsen(1) who also list P. violacea for British Columbia, Washington, Oregon, and Idaho). There are collections under the name Peziza praetervisa Bres. for BC at Pacific Forestry Centre and University of British Columbia. It has been reported from WA by Andrew Parker, pers. comm.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-6cm, "rather circular and saucer-shaped when young, then expanded and irregularly deformed"; spore-bearing upper surface light to dark violet, also brown-violet, smooth^, (Breitenbach), up to 3cm, cup-shaped then expanded; upper surface violet, sometimes with brownish tints, (Dennis)
FLESH  thin, fragile^, (Breitenbach), thin; mauve, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  lighter in color than upper surface; finely furfuraceous^, (Breitenbach), pale violaceous; minutely scurfy, (Dennis)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or gregarious, "often several individuals fused together to form a cluster", on burned places, principally in the first 12 months after fire, "also occurring in masses on sandy forest paths without any relationship to charred wood"^, (Breitenbach), often clustered, on burned ground in woods and heaths, occasionally on sawdust; October to May, (Dennis), fruiting 10-150 weeks after the firs (Hansen, L.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-14(15) x 6-8 um, elliptic, with fine warts when mature, colorless, with 2 drops^; asci 8-spored, 170-250 x 9-12 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses weakly clavate, 1.5-2.5 um, slightly curved, tips with brown-violet contents, (Breitenbach), spores 11-13(15) x 6-8 um, finely warted, with 2 oil droplets; asci about 250 x 10 um; paraphyses "slightly clavate, mostly slightly curved at the tip, which is filled with purplish granules", (Dennis), spores 11-15 x 6-8 um, ornamented with low warts, containing two oil droplets, (Trudell), spores 11-15 x 6-8 um, finely warted with two droplets, paraphyses slightly clavate, up to 7 um at tips, tips slightly bent, filled with violet to violet-brown granules, (Beug(3)).
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Geoscypha violacea (=Peziza lobulata (Velenovsky) Svrcek, =Peziza violacea Persoon sensu Dennis, =Plicaria adusta Velen.) is closely related to G. tenacella (as Peziza praetervisa) - it has spores 13-15.5 x 7-8.5 um and curved paraphyses (Beug(3)). While Beug(3) says that P. lobulata is not associated with burn sites, Svrcek(1) examined Velenovsky's material of the synonym Plicaria adusta from burnt soil, giving spore size 13-14 x 7-8 um. Hansen, L.(1) says the fruitbodies of P. lobulata are disc-shaped to cup-shaped and 0.5-3cm across, the hymenium violet, the exterior bluish gray and bald, the habitat newly burnt ground, the spores 13-15.5 x 7-8.5 um, smooth without guttules, and the paraphyses curved, with violaceous brown contents. |Malvipezia howsei is a purple cup that has large spores (17-22 x 8-11 um) and is not associated with burn sites (Beug(3)). It is sometimes considered a purple variation of Malvipezia emileia, for which there is some evidence of presence in the Pacific Northwest. |See also SIMILAR section of Peziza domiciliana and Peziza moseri.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as P. praetervisa Bres. sensu Dennis), Dennis(1) (as Peziza praetervisa sensu Dennis), Trudell(4) (as Peziza praetervisa), Seaver(1) (as Peziza violacea), Larsen(1) (Peziza praetervisa and Peziza violacea), Pfister(5) (as Peziza praetervisa sensu Pfister), Siegel(2)* (as Peziza praetervisa), Beug(3)* (as Peziza praetervisa), Hansen, L.(1) (as Peziza violacea ss. auct. but referencing P. subviolacea Svrcek, also re Peziza lobulata), Svrcek(1) (type study), Hansen, K.(5), Van Vooren(2), Cooke, M.C.(1) (re Peziza tenacella)
109
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Geoscypha violacea (Pers.) Lambotte  group^  Mem. Soc. roy. Sci. Liege, Serie 2 14(7): 320 [prepr.] (1887) [1888];  Peziza lobulata (Velen.) Svrcek, Ceska Mykol. 30(3-4): 130 (1976)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  We use this group to include purple cups that often grow on burned soil, whether with finely warted spores or smooth spores. There is little or no stem. The group includes ||1) Geoscypha violacea |(smooth spores, neotype designated by Van Vooren) |= Peziza violacea sensu Pfister, Dennis |= Peziza lobulata |= Peziza pseudoviolacea Donadini |= Plicaria adusta Velen. ||2) Geoscypha tenacella (Sacc.) Van Vooren, Ascomycete.org 12(4): 187. 2020 |(finely warted mature spores) |= Peziza tenacella W. Phillips 1886 |= Peziza praetervisa sensu Dennis 1978, Pfister 1982 |= Galactinia praetervisa sensu Boudier 1905-1910 |= Peziza subviolacea Svrcek 1976 |= Peziza violacea "f. typica" Donadini 1978, ||3) Peziza moseri Aviz.-Hersh. & Nemlich, Israel J. Bot. 23(3): 157 (1974) |(smooth spores)|= Peziza violacea sensu Breitenbach & Kranzlin 1981 |= Peziza sublilacina Svrcek 1976 |= Aleuria lilacina Boud. 1907 ||Van Vooren(2) designated Geoscypha violacea to fix a smooth-spored type, as Peziza violacea had been variously interpreted. See separate account for Geoscypha tenacella regarding interpretations of Peziza violacea and Peziza praetervisa, as well as the rationale for separating Geoscypha from Peziza. |The relationship between Peziza moseri and Geoscypha violacea is not clear and they are both smooth-spored - see separate account for Peziza moseri. |There is a third Geoscypha species, Geoscypha ampelina with the divergent character "an amyloid ascus reaction of WT type instead of WTR", but this was not mentioned for North America. |The description below is that of Dennis(1) for Peziza violacea except where noted. Note the difference in spore length: spore measurements are difficult to use in identification (see all the different measurements in Van Vooren). RANGE ^Peziza violacea is found at least in British Columbia, Washington, Oregon, and Idaho, according to Larsen(1) who also lists Peziza praetervisa. Although Larsen(1) list P. praetervisa also for Oregon and Idaho, it is possible that some of the collections of P. violacea that they list for the Pacific Northwest as noted above correspond to our concept of Geoscypha tenacella. |Desjardin(6) recorded smooth spored "Peziza violacea" for CA. A collection of Peziza lobulata from WA was used in the molecular study Hansen, K.(5). There is a Tennessee collection on burnt soil at the University of Illinois "99% match with LSU to Peziza lobulata in GenBank! 98% match with ITS to Peziza lobulata in GenBank!" but the material was in such poor collection that it was difficult to see ascomata. All other MyCoPortal entries are from Europe. |So far, according to D. Miller, pers. comm. January 8, 2022, collections with sequences matching Geoscypha violacea have been found in AK (1) and OR (2). Microscopic confirmation of smooth spores is not available for these collections. 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  "seldom more than 3cm across, cup-shaped then soon fully expanded"; upper surface dark violet or purplish brown, (Dennis)
FLESH  rather thin; pale purple, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  grayish to light brown; pruinose, (Dennis)
STEM  none^ (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on burned ground, often amongst Funaria, spring and fall, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-15 x 7-9 um, elliptic, smooth^; asci up to 300 x 15 um; paraphyses "slender, distinctly clavate and often somewhat curved at the tip, which contains purplish-brown sap"; flesh composed of large spherical cells interspersed with hyphae and with a narrow hyphal stratum near the outer surface, (Dennis), spores 16-17 x 8-10 um, smooth, elliptic, lacking large oil droplets, (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'violaceous'
SIMILAR  Although Beug(3) gave Peziza violacea sensu Dennis and Peziza lobulata as synonyms, they said that Peziza lobulata is not associated with burn sites. Other authors (e.g. Hansen, L.(1)) do not agree with the habitat difference. |Peziza tenacella (as Peziza praetervisa) has lightly ornamented spores with 2 droplets, while Peziza sublilacina [like Geoscypha violacea] has smooth spores without oil droplets (Beug(3)).
SOURCES  Van Vooren(2), Trudell(4)* (as P. violacea and P. praetervisa), Arora(1) (as P. violacea), Larsen(1) (as P. violacea and P. praetervisa), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)* (as P. violacea), Dennis(1) (as P. violacea and P. praetervisa), Pfister(5) (as P. violacea and P. praetervisa), Hansen, L.(1) (as P. lobulata and P. violacea), Desjardin(6)* (as P. violacea and P. praetervisa), Hansen, K. (as Peziza lobulata)

FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gloeotinia granigena  (Quel.) T. Schumach.^  Mycotaxon 8(1): 125. 1979;  Gloeotinia temulenta  (Prill. & Delacr.) M. Wilson, Noble, & E.G. Gray;  Sclerotinia temulenta  (Prill. & Delacr.) Rehm;  Phialea temulenta  Prill. & Delacr.;  Stromatinia temulenta  Prill. & Delacr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Gloeotinia temulenta forms 1-3 small brown cups with slender stems on infected grass seeds.^ | Hansen gives this species as a synonym of Gloeotinia granigena (Quel) T. Schumach. but Alderman(2) attempts to refute the synonymy. RANGE ^It is found at least in OR, Denmark, France, Ireland, Netherlands, Sweden, United Kingdom, Australia, and New Zealand, (Alderman).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.7cm wide, disc at first closed, opens to cup-shaped and when old becomes saucer-shaped and then flat; light pinkish brown to deep brown, orange brown, or pale pinkish cinnamon, darkening to cinnamon when old; margin smooth and entire^, (Alderman(1)), up to 3.5cm wide, becoming flat; cinnamon, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  margin radially wrinkled around top of stem^, (Alderman(1))
STEM  0.1-1cm x 0.02-0.05cm, narrowing downward; white or gray, internally pinkish brown; longitudinally furrowed, smooth but velvety under magnification^, (Alderman(1)), up to 0.8cm long, slender, smooth, (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  causes blind seed diseases of grasses (described from rye, but subsequent occurrence on this species is rare, and the disease is primarily a problem of forage and turf grasses grown for seed); one to seven (usually one to three) fruitbodies emerge from each infected seed, infected caryopses appear shriveled, rough on the surface, and rusty brown or pinkish in color, conidia "accumulate on seed surface in a spore secretion (slime), which may be waxy and clear or pale pink in color"^, (Alderman(1)), fruitbodies arising on caryopses of grasses, macroconidial state produced in a copious pink slime on surface in summer, microconidial state produced in pink pulvinate [cushion-shaped] sporodochia on surface, (Hansen), on fruits of Secale cereale (rye) "to which is gives poisonous properties", (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-14 x 2.5-4.5 um, elliptic, fusoid to broadly fusoid, smooth, colorless, usually with 2 droplets^; asci 8-spored, uniseriate, 66-120 x 3-8 um, cylindric and clavate, with spores in upper two thirds of ascus, ascus base tapers to about 2-5 um, apical cap 1-3 um thick, apical plug does not stain blue with iodine; paraphyses as long or slightly longer than asci, 1.5-4 um wide, fusiform, colorless, nonseptate or sparsely septate, reported both to be swollen at apex and not swollen; macroconidia 11-21 x 2.5-6 um, cylindric to slightly crescent-shaped with rounded ends, smooth, unicellular, uninucleate, colorless, usually with two droplets, budded from apex of macroconidiophores 5-15 x 2-3 um, barrel-shaped, up to 30 macroconidia per macroconidiophore, in clusters perpendicular to the hypha; microconidia 2.3-6 x 1.8-3.0 um, ovoid, colorless, unicellular, uninucleate, with one or two droplets, first formed by constriction below apex of microconidiophore which is 5-9 x 2-5 um, branched 2 or 3 times, colorless, septate, guttulate, (Alderman(1)), spores 7.5-12 x 3-6 um, elliptic with pointed ends; uniseriate, with 2 droplets; asci 8-spored, pore not blued by iodine; paraphyses cylindric, slender, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Alderman(1) accessed Sep 24, 2002 at www.ars.usda.gov/is/np/blindseed/contents.htm, Dennis(1), Seaver(2) (as Sclerotinia), Hansen, L.(1) (as Gloeotinia granigena), Alderman(2)
