FAMILY  Godroniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Godronia cassandrae  Peck^  N.Y. St. Mus. Ann. Rep. 39: 50. 1887
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, nearly spherical fruitbodies that open to become urceolate, the exterior tawny to reddish brown to dark olivaceous brown, slightly furfuraceous, and striate, the spore-bearing surface whitish to gray or greenish gray, the margin even or slightly fringed, somewhat lobed, stem absent, inconspicuous conidial state, growth on Vaccinium and other plants, and microscopic characters including 8 thread-like spores per ascus.^ | Godronia cassandrae is one of the best known of the Godronia species because it is the cause of a disease of considerable economic importance in Vaccinium. Various forms distinguished by different hosts are of dubious taxonomic status according to Groves. RANGE ^Collections were examined of forma vaccinii (habitat on Vaccinium spp.) BC, OR, NS, ON, and PQ, of forma cassandrae (habitat on Chamaedaphne calyculata) ON, PQ, MI, and NY, of forma ribicola (habitat on Ribes spp.) ON, CO, NH, and UT, of forma spiraeicola (habitat on Spiraea spp. and Sorbaria sp.) Austria, Finland, Germany, Latvia, and Russia, of forma callunae (on Callunae vulgaris) the United Kingdom, and of forma betulicola (on Betula alba) Germany, (Groves).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.05-0.1(0.12)cm across, 0.03-0.08(0.1)cm high, at first nearly spherical, opening circularly and becoming urceolate [goblet-shaped]; spore-bearing surface concave to flat, whitish to gray or greenish gray, more fleshy than the exterior; margin even to slightly fimbriate [fringed], somewhat lobed; conidial fruitbodies 0.015-0.03cm across and about the same in height, nearly spherical, black, bald, fleshy-leathery in consistency, tearing open at the top; conidial fruitbodies 0.15-0.3cm across and about the same in height, immersed to erumpent, mostly separate to subcespitose [somewhat cespitose], nearly spherical, tearing open at the top, black, bald, fleshy-leathery, conidial state when found usually small, nearly spherical to ovoid stromata, not beaked
FLESH  fruitbody consistency hard, brittle, coriaceous-waxy [leathery-waxy], becoming more coriaceous-fleshy when moist
UNDERSIDE  exterior tawny to reddish brown to dark olivaceous brown; slightly furfuraceous, more or less longitudinally striate
STEM  fruitbody sessile, narrowed in lower part
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "erumpent, separate to cespitose in small clusters or sometimes up to 10 in a cluster", see NOTES for hosts
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (40)50-70(85) x (1.5)2.0-3.0(3.5) um, filiform, straight or curved, pointed at the ends, colorless, 3-7-(9-)septate, "fasciculate or more or less intertwined in the ascus"^; asci 8-spored, (70)95-115(130) x (7.0)7.5-9.0(10.5) um, cylindric to cylindric-clavate, narrowed in lower part, pore turning blue with iodine; paraphyses 1.5-2 um in diameter, filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, simple or branched, "the tips not or very slightly swollen, not forming an epithecium"; conidia (7.0)9.0-14.0(18.0) x 1.5-2.5(3.5) um, colorless, narrow-fusiform, mostly straight, mostly 2-celled, sometimes 1-celled, ends pointed, conidiophores variable in length, about 6-25 x 1.5-2 um, cylindric to cylindric-subulate, colorless, "continuous or septate, simple or branched"
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Five other species occur on Ribes besides Godronia cassandrae (forma ribicola): 1) Godronia uberiformis with a conspicuous conidial state, 2) Godronia davidsonii with shorter spores, 3) Godronia grossulariae (rare and known to Groves only from the type collection, fruitbodies similar microscopically but are larger, more blackish, more strongly erumpent, and open more widely), 4) Godronia lobata (margin splits to form overlapping lobes, known from California), and 5) Godronia ribis (common in Europe but not established for North America), (Groves).
SOURCES  Groves(3)
112
FAMILY  Godroniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Godronia confertus  (D.S. Hone) J.W. Groves^  Can. J. Bot. 43: 1217. 1965;  == Godronia urceolus var. confertus  Hone
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, nearly spherical fruitbodies that open to become urceolate to turbinate, the exterior dark olive-brown or reddish brown to black, and striate to wrinkled, the spore-bearing area whitish to grayish or pale greenish, the stem short, clustered growth in spring on cankered areas near the base of Prunus saplings, conspicuous conidial state, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, ON, PQ, MN, NH, and NJ, (Groves).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.03-0.12cm across, 0.08-0.2cm high, at first nearly spherical, opening circularly and becoming urceolate [goblet-shaped] to turbinate; spore-bearing surface concave, whitish to grayish or pale greenish, more fleshy than the exterior; margin even or slightly fimbriate [fringed], inrolled when dry; conidial fruitbodies 0.02-0.06cm across, 0.05-0.08cm high, "erumpent, gregarious, cespitose or occasionally single", nearly spherical to ovoid, flask-shaped or cylindric, bald, olivaceous brown to black, consistency similar to that of the apothecia [sexual fruitbodies]
FLESH  consistency of fruitbody hard, brittle, coriaceous-waxy [leathery-waxy], more coriaceous-fleshy when moist
UNDERSIDE  fruitbody exterior dark olive-brown or reddish brown to black; "more or less striate to wrinkled or rugose"
STEM  narrowed in lower part, with short stem
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "erumpent, densely gregarious and cespitose with up to 40 or more in a cluster but usually much less and occasionally single", "usually found in the spring or early summer on cankered areas near the base of Prunus saplings" (genus name italicized)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (40)45-60(70) x 1.5-3.0 um, filiform [thread-like], straight or slightly curved, pointed at the ends, 3-septate to mostly 5-septate, more or less fasciculate in the ascus^; asci 8-spored, (85)90-115(130) x (5.0)6.0-8.0(10.0) um, cylindric to cylindric-clavate, tapering to a slender stem, pore turns blue with iodine; paraphyses 1.5-2 um wide, filiform, colorless, septate, simple or branched, "tips not or very slightly swollen, not forming an epithecium"; conidia (10)12-18(25) x (1.5)2.0-3.0(3.5) um, cylindric-fusoid, straight or slightly curved, colorless to yellowish green, 1-celled to 4-celled, pointed at the ends, conidiophores variable in length, 6-25 x 2.0-3.0 um, cylindric-subulate, colorless, septate, simple or branched
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pressed together, crowded'
SIMILAR  Godronia urceolus has collections listed through MyCoPortal from BC, OR, NS, ON, AK, CA, CO, GA, MA, ND, NH, NJ, NY, and VT, but it is unknown whether those identifying Pacific Northwest collections had access to descriptions of the full range of Godronia spp. 
SOURCES  Groves(3)
113
FAMILY  Godroniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Godronia davidsonii  E.K. Cash^  Mycologia 26: 269. 1934 [as davidsoni]
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, olive-brown to ochraceous brown, urceolate cups, with gray spore-bearing surface, the margin becoming fringed, hard consistency, little or no stem, growth on Ribes canes, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from OR, NF, AK, and CO, (Groves). It was also reported in Washington (by Kanouse, but on Rubus cane).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.05-0.1cm across and about the same in height, at first almost spherical, becoming urceolate [goblet-shaped] "and opening with a pore-like mouth"; spore-bearing surface concave, pale yellowish gray, more fleshy than the exterior; margin becoming fimbriate [fringed]; conidial fruitbodies about 0.02-0.05cm across, erumpent, separate, nearly spherical, opening at the top, black, bald^, (Groves), up to 0.1cm across, up to 0.1cm high, depressed globose or urceolate [mouth narrower than cup], opening with a circular opening; spore-bearing upper surface concave, smoky gray; margin fimbriate [fringed], (Seaver)
FLESH  consistency of fruitbody hard, brittle, membranaceous-waxy to coriaceous-waxy [leathery-waxy], becoming more coriaceous-fleshy when moist^, (Groves)
UNDERSIDE  exterior of fruitbody olive-brown to ochraceous brown, "slightly furfuraceous and striate"^, (Groves), dark-colored, greenish olive, (Seaver)
STEM  sessile [without a stem], narrowed in lower part to substipitate [with rudimentary stem]^, (Groves), without a stem or substipitate, (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "erumpent, scattered to gregarious, separate", on Ribes spp.^, (Groves), single on stems of Ribes wolfii, and on R. bracteosum X R. nigrum, (Seaver), on dead canes of Rubus sp. (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 34-54 x 2.0-3.5(5.0) um, filiform [thread-like], pointed at the ends, straight to slightly curved, colorless, 3-septate to 5-septate, "more or less fasciculate to interwoven in the ascus"^; asci 8-spored, 100-125(150) x 6.0-8.0 um, cylindric to cylindric-clavate, narrow, tapering in lower part to a slender stem, pore turning blue with iodine; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um wide, filiform, colorless, septate, simple or branched, "scarcely enlarged at the tip and not forming an epithecium"; conidia (8)10-18 x 1.5-2.5(3.0) um, "elongate-fusiform, straight or slightly curved, pointed at ends", colorless, 1-celled or 2-celled; conidiophores variable in length up to 25 um or more, 1.5-2.0 um wide, cylindric-subulate, colorless, septate, branched, (Groves), spores 33-45 x 2.5-3 um, acicular-fusoid, parallel, or slightly twisted in the ascus, becoming 3-septate; asci 8-spored, reaching a length or 90-120 um and a width of 5-7 um, cylindric, gradually narrowed toward base and upper part; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], simple, colorless, gradually enlarged in upper part, reaching width of 2-2.5 um, often curved at tips, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Five other species of Godronia grow on Ribes: 1) Godronia uberiformis (densely cespitose habit, long spores, and cylindric to flask-shaped conidial fruitbodies with conidia mostly 15-20 x 2.5-4 um), 2) Godronia cassandrae forma ribicola (longer spores), 3) Godronia grossulariae (longer spores, rare and known by Groves only from the type collections), 4) Godronia lobata (margin splits and forms overlapping lobes, known from California), and 5) Godronia ribis (common in Europe but not known to occur in North America), (Groves).
SOURCES  Groves(3), Seaver(2), Kanouse(6)
114
FAMILY  Godroniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Godronia fuliginosa  (Fr.) Seaver^  Mycologia 37: 344. 1945;  == Cenangium fuliginosum;  == Tympanis fuliginosa  (Fr.) Wallr.  var. pezizaeformis  Wallr.;  == Scleroderris fuliginosa  (Fr.) Karst.;  = Cenangium difforme;  = Godronia striata  (Ell. & Ev.) Seaver;  = Godronia betheli;  = Phacidium carbonaceum  Fr.;  = Pilidium carbonaceum  (Fr.) Lib.;  Sphaeria proboscidea  Fr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, reddish brown to blackish, urceolate cups, with grayish to whitish spore-bearing surface, the margin becoming fringed, hard consistency, little or no stem, growth on willow, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^There are several collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Center, one determined by J. Groves in 1964. Collections were examined from ON, SK, CO, NY, Finland, Germany, and Sweden, (Groves(3)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.05-0.12cm across and about the same high, at first nearly spherical, opening circularly and becoming urceolate [goblet-shaped]; spore-bearing surface concave, more fleshy than the exterior, grayish to whitish; margin fimbriate [fringed]; conidial fruitbodies "erumpent, densely gregarious, separate to subcespitose", about 0.01-0.05cm across, more or less spherical to ovoid, black, bald, similar in consistency to the apothecia
FLESH  consistency of fruitbody hard, coriaceous-waxy [leathery-waxy], more coriaceous-flesh when moist
UNDERSIDE  dark reddish brown to blackish; "more or less fibrillose-striate to slightly ridged, somewhat furfuraceous"
STEM  sessile [without a stem] or narrowed in lower part to substipitate [with rudimentary stem]
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "erumpent, densely gregarious to cespitose in effused patches, sometimes more scattered or singly among the conidial fruiting bodies in cankered areas", on Salix (willow)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (40)55-80(90) x (1.5)2.0-3.5(4.0) um, filiform [thread-like], "more or less curved to nearly straight, pointed at ends", colorless, mostly 5-septate to 7-(9-)septate, fasciculate to somewhat interwoven in the ascus^; asci 8-spored, (90)105-135(150) x (8)9-12(14) um, cylindric to cylindric-clavate, tapering in lower part to a slender stem, pore blue with iodine; paraphyses 1.5-2.5 um wide, filiform, colorless, septate, simple or branched, "the tips not or very slightly swollen, not forming an epithecium"; conidia (18)20-30(36) x (2.0)2.5-3.5 um, "elongate-fusiform, straight or curved", colorless, mostly 3-septate; conidiophores about 6-25 x 2-2.5 um or longer, "cylindric-subulate, septate, simple or branched"; microconidia 3.0-4.0(5.0) x 2.0-3.0 um, elliptic, colorless, 1-celled
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fuliginous' in color
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Groves(3)
115
FAMILY  Godroniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Godronia grossulariae  J.W. Groves^  Can. J. Bot. 43: 1226. 1965
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, blackish, striate, urceolate cups on Ribes, with spore-bearing surface pale gray, and margin more or less fringed; tough consistency; absent stem; and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Godronia grossulariae is rare: Groves knew it only from the type described from OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.05-0.15cm across, 0.05-0.12cm high, at first nearly spherical, becoming urceolate [goblet-shaped], "circular or slightly elongated, infolded when dry", spore-bearing surface concave, pale gray with a tinge of greenish, more fleshy than the exterior; margin more or less fimbriate [fringed]; conidial fruitbodies 0.02-0.03cm across, erumpent, separate, nearly spherical, black, bald, "containing a single cavity, tearing open at the top and spreading open widely"
FLESH  consistency of fruitbody hard, rather tough, coriaceous [leathery] to coriaceous-waxy becoming more coriaceous-fleshy when moist
UNDERSIDE  exterior black or very dark brownish, bald to slightly furfuraceous, more or less longitudinally striate to ridged
STEM  sessile [without stem], narrowed in lower part
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "erumpent, separate to subcespitose or more or less in rows", type on Ribes watsonianum (spring gooseberry)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (48)50-65(73) x 2.0-3.0 um, filiform [thread-like], "straight or slightly curved, pointed at the ends", colorless, 3-septate to 7-septate, "fasciculate to interwoven in the ascus"^; asci 8-spored, (80)100-125 x 8.0-10.0 um, cylindric, tapering in lower part to a slender stem, pore turning blue with iodine; paraphyses 2.0-2.5 um wide, filiform, colorless, septate, simple or branched, "the tips slightly swollen but not forming an epithecium"; conidia 9.0-14.0 x 2.0-2.5 um, "narrow-fusiform to subcylindric, straight or slightly curved", pointed at ends, colorless, 1-celled or mostly 2-celled; conidiophores variable in length up to 45 um, 2.0-3.0 um wide, cylindric to cylindric-subulate, colorless, septate, simple or branched
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Five other species occur on Ribes: 1) Godronia cassandrae (forma ribicola) (fruitbodies of G. grossulariae similar microscopically but are larger, more blackish, more strongly erumpent, and open more widely), 2) Godronia uberiformis with a conspicuous conidial state, 3) Godronia davidsonii with shorter spores, 4) Godronia lobata (margin splits to form overlapping lobes, known from California), and 5) Godronia ribis (common in Europe but not established for North America).
SOURCES  Groves(3)
116
FAMILY  Godroniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Godronia multispora  J.W. Groves^  Can. J. Bot. 43. p. 1231. 1965
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, nearly spherical fruitbodies that open to become urceolate to expanded, the exterior reddish brown or ochraceous brown to black, slightly furfuraceous, and more or less longitudinally striate, the spore-bearing area pale grayish, stem absent, growth on birch, and microscopic characters including asci that begin with 8 thread-like spores but these spores break into many smaller spores.^ RANGE ^There are four collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Center determined by A. Funk. Collections were examined from ON, Germany, and Latvia, (Groves).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.05-0.1(0.12)cm across and 0.04-0.15cm high, at first nearly spherical, opening circularly and becoming urceolate [goblet-shaped] to expanded; spore-bearing area concave, pale grayish, more fleshy than the exterior; margin more or less fimbriate [fringed]; conidial fruitbodies "erumpent, separate or cespitose", 0.02-0.06cm across, nearly spherical to ovoid, tearing open widely at the top, brown to black, bald, similar in consistency to the apothecia or more membranous
FLESH  consistency hard, brittle, coriaceous-waxy [leathery-waxy], more coriaceous-fleshy when moist
UNDERSIDE  "reddish brown or ochraceous brown to black"; "slightly furfuraceous, more or less longitudinally striate"
STEM  sessile [stem lacking], narrowed in lower part
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "erumpent, separate to cespitose in small clusters", on Betula papyrifera (Paper Birch) and B. pendula (European White Birch)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 54-75 x 2.0-3.0 um, soon fragmenting into short cells about 5-9 x 2-3 um, cylindric to elliptic, colorless, these budding off minute spores about 2.0-3.0 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, colorless^; asci (80)90-120(130) x (6.0)7.0-8.0(9.0) um, at first 8-spored but becoming multispored by fragmentation and budding, cylindric to cylindric-clavate, tapering in lower part to a slender stem, pore blue with iodine; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um, filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, simple or branched, "the tips not or very slightly swollen, not forming an epithecium"; conidia (8)10-20(25) x (1.5)2.0-3.5 um, "elongate-fusiform to subfiliform, pointed at ends, straight or slightly curved, sometimes slightly sigmoid", colorless, mostly 2-celled, occasionally 4-celled; conidiophores 10-35 x 2.0-3.0 um or longer, cylindric-subulate, colorless, septate, simple or branched; microconidia 2-3 x 1-2 um, elliptic, colorless, 1-celled
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with many spores'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Groves(3)
117
FAMILY  Godroniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Godronia spiraeae  (Rehm) Seaver^  Mycologia 37: 342. 1945
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, nearly spherical fruitbodies that open to become urceolate, the exterior dark olivaceous brown to blackish and slightly striate, the spore-bearing area grayish, the margin fringed and sometimes paler than the exterior, the stem rudimentary, growth on Spiraea, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, ON, PQ, NH, NY, and PA, (Groves).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.05-0.13cm across, 0.05-0.1cm high, at first spherical to nearly spherical, opening circularly and becoming urceolate [goblet-shaped]; spore-bearing surface concave to flat, grayish, softer and more fleshy than the exterior; the margin sometimes paler than the exterior to yellowish olive, more or less fimbriate [fringed], infolded when dry; conidial fruitbodies "erumpent or semi-immersed, separate", 0.02-0.05cm across and about the same high, nearly spherical to ovoid, black, bald, "tearing open widely at the top", containing a nearly spherical to slightly chambered cavity
FLESH  consistency hard, coriaceous-waxy [leathery-waxy], more coriaceous-fleshy when moist
UNDERSIDE  dark olivaceous brown to blackish; slightly striate
STEM  fruitbody narrowed in lower part, substipitate [with a rudimentary stem]
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "erumpent, separate or cespitose in small clusters", on Spiraea spp.
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-35(45) x 2.5-3.5(4.0) um, "elongate-fusiform to subfiliform, occasionally slightly subclavate, straight or slightly curved", pointed at ends, colorless, 3-septate, more or less fasciculate in the ascus^; ascus 8-spored, (75)90-110(125) x (5.0)7.0-9.0(10.0) um, cylindric to cylindric-clavate, tapering in lower part to a slender stem, pore blue with iodine; paraphyses about 1.5-2.0 um wide, filiform, colorless, septate, simple or branched, "the tips not or very slightly swollen, not forming an epithecium"; conidia 15-25 x 2.0-3.0(4.0) um, "elongate-fusiform to subfiliform, straight or slightly curved, sometimes sigmoid, pointed at ends", colorless, 1-celled to 4-celled; conidiophores 10-25 x 1.5-2.0 um, sometimes larger, cylindric-subulate, colorless, septate, branched, "bearing conidia at the tip"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Spiraea'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Groves(3)
118
FAMILY  Godroniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Godronia uberiformis  J.W. Groves^  Can. J. Bot. 43: 1245. 1965
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, dark olivaceous brown to black, more or less striate fruitbodies that are spherical at first and open to become urceolate, the spore bearing surface inside light gray and the fringed margin yellowish to whitish, hard consistency, rudimentary stem, growth on Ribes canes, conspicuous conidial state, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from ID, ON, CO, Finland, Sweden, and United Kingdom, (Groves).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia [sexual fruitbodies] 0.05-0.15cm across, 0.05-0.2cm high, at first spherical or nearly spherical, opening circularly and becoming urceolate [goblet-shaped]; spore-bearing surface concave to flat, light gray, more fleshy than the exterior; margin paler than exterior, yellowish to whitish, more or less fimbriate [fringed], infolded when dry; conidial fruitbodies 0.04-0.06cm across, 0.05-0.1cm high, "erumpent, separate or cespitose, cylindric to flask-shaped", dark olivaceous brown to black, bald, tough, coriaceous-waxy [leathery-waxy] in consistency, becoming more coriaceous-fleshy when moist, "containing a more or less ovoid to elongated cavity which tears open at the top"
FLESH  consistency of fruitbody hard, tough, coriaceous-waxy [leathery-waxy] in consistency, becoming more coriaceous-fleshy when moist
UNDERSIDE  exterior of fruitbody dark olivaceous brown to black, somewhat furfuraceous to bald, more or less striate
STEM  fruitbody narrowed in lower part, substipitate
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "erumpent, densely gregarious, cespitose, occasionally single", on Ribes spp.
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (50)60-75(85) x (1.5)2.0-3.0(3.5) um, filiform, straight or slightly curved, up to 7-septate, colorless, "more or less parallel to intertwined in the ascus"^; asci 8-spored, (90)110-155(200) x (7.5)8.0-11.0(12.0) um, cylindric to cylindric-clavate, tapered in lower part to a stem, pore turning blue with iodine; paraphyses 2.0-2.5 um wide, filiform, colorless, septate, simple or branched, "slightly swollen at the tip but not forming an epithecium"; conidia (14)15-20(30) x 2.5-4.0(5.0) um, elongate-fusiform, straight or slightly curved, pointed at the ends, colorless, 1-celled to 4-celled, conidiophores very variable in length, about 10-80 x 1.5-2.5 um, cylindric-subulate, colorless, septate, simple or branched, bearing conidia at tip
NAME ORIGIN  'uber' means 'breast, teat, udder' but also as an adjective 'fruitful, full, copious', '-formis' means 'in form or shape', the name being chosen by Groves to emphasize the connection to Topospora uberiformis, the conidial state, and because it suggested copious fruiting, which is applicable to the sexual fruitbody as well as the conidial state
SIMILAR  Five other species occur on Ribes: 1) Godronia cassandrae (forma ribicola) - lacks the conspicuous conidial states with ovoid to conic or slightly beaked stromata, 2) Godronia grossulariae (rare and known to Groves only from the type collection, also lacks the conspicuous conidial state with ovoid to conic or slightly beaked stromata), 3) Godronia davidsonii (smaller spores), 4) Godronia lobata (margin splits to form overlapping lobes, known from California), and 5) Godronia ribis (common in Europe but not established for North America), (Groves).
SOURCES  Groves(3)
119
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Grovesiella abieticola  (Zeller & Goodd.) M. Morelet & Gremmen^  Annales de la Societe des Sciences Naturelles et d'Archeologie de Toulon et du Var 185: 8. 1969;  Godronia abieticola  (Zeller & Goodd.) Seaver  The North American Cup-fungi (Inoperculates) p.332. 1951;  Scleroderris abieticola  Zeller & Goodd.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, blackish, shiny cups on cankers on living branches and twigs of true fir, smooth to flaky external surface, and microscopic characters.^ |This is not the same as Godronia abietina (Ellis & Ev.) Seaver or Godronia abietis (Naumov) Seaver. RANGE ^Grovesiella abieticola was found in OR (Seaver). There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.12cm wide, at first closed, spherical or ellipsoid, opening by star-shaped or irregular cleft, then cup-shaped to expanded; shiny-slate to shiny-black
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  external surface grayish black to shiny black; smooth to flaky
STEM  short stem or almost no stem
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or gregarious, on cankers on living branches and twigs of Abies grandis and Abies amabilis
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 40-67 x 3.5-4.5 um, filiform [thread-like], with many oil droplets, finally distinctly 5-8-septate^; asci 8-spored, or rarely 4-spored, reaching 118-135 um long and 9-14 um wide; paraphyses filiform, slightly enlarged in upper part, "somewhat agglutinated but not forming an epithecium"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living on Abies [true fir]'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Godronia abieticola)
120
FAMILY  Dacrymycetaceae, Order Dacrymycetales, Class Dacrymycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Guepiniopsis buccina  (Pers.) L.L. Kenn.^  Mycologia 50: 888. 1959
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly category. Guepiniopsis buccina produces small yellow to orange gelatinous cups with conspicuous longitudinal striations on exterior surface, and microscopically with septate cortical hairs with inflated cells, and absent clamp connections, growing usually on hardwood.^ RANGE ^It has been found in BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, ON, CA, CO, IA, MA, MI, MN, NC, NY, OH, SC, and VT, (Ginns), and Jamaica, Ecuador, Argentina, British Isles, Czechoslovakia, Eire, France, Germany, Italy, China, Japan, Australia, and New Zealand, (McNabb). It has been reported from Estonia, Poland, and Russia, (Reid). Lowy's cited collections may be dubious because of the report of clamp connections.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 1cm high, with cap and stem, both caps and stems often partly fusing, cap 0.3-0.9cm in diameter, cup-shaped or obliquely cup-shaped; yellow to orange-yellow when fresh, drying bright orange, orange-red or rusty orange^, (McNabb), up to 0.8cm high, consisting of stem that expands in upper part into saucer-shaped to cup-shaped, yellow or orange disc, up to 0.6cm across, sometimes obliquely inclined, (Reid)
FLESH  consistency of fruiting body firm gelatinous^, (McNabb), firm-gelatinous (Reid)
UNDERSIDE  externally ribbed^, (McNabb), prominently ribbed, (Reid)
STEM  central, expanded apically, longitudinally ribbed^, (McNabb), stout or slender rooting stem, up to 0.5cm high and 0.05-0.08cm wide, (Reid)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  closely gregarious or cespitose [in tufts] on hardwood and perhaps occasionally conifer wood^, (McNabb), Abies, Acer, Artemisia tridentata, Pinus, Pseudotsuga, Quercus, Salix, (Ginns)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (11)12-14.5(16) x 4-6 um, cylindric to curved-cylindric, thin-walled with thin septa, tinted, apiculate, becoming 3-septate at maturity^, germination by colorless, spherical to nearly spherical conidia or by germ tubes, probasidia 35-56 x 4.5-5.5 um, cylindric-subclavate, with basal septa, becoming bifurcate; hymenium confined to inside of cup, consisting of basidia; internal hyphae "compactly arranged, thin-walled, roughened, septate, often with bulbous septa, clamp connections absent"; cortex and stem "covered by a palisade of thin- or thick-walled, septate hairs, individual cells typically inflated and hairs appearing catenate", "hairs thin-walled and smooth near hymenium, thick-walled and roughened on stipe and base of pileus", (McNabb), spore bearing surface is limited to inside of cup (Reid)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'shepherd's horn
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  McNabb(4), Reid(1), Ginns(5), Lowy(2)
121
FAMILY  Discinaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gyromitra ancilis (Pers.) Kreisel^  Boletus, SchrReihe 1: 29 (1984);  == Discina ancilis  (Pers.) Sacc.;  = Discina perlata  (Fr.) Fr.;  = Gyromitra perlata  (Fr.) Harmaja;  = Gyromitra macrospora  (Bubak) Harmaja;  = Discina macrospora  Bubak;  = Gyromitra fluctuans  (Nyl.) Harmaja;  = Gyromitra warnei  (Peck) Harmaja
ENGLISH NAME(S)  pig's ears, thick cup
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include a fruitbody that is cup-shaped to saucer-shaped or with a down-turned margin, usually wrinkled or veined or convoluted; the upper surface some shade of brown; the underside paler or whitish and sometimes ribbed in lower part; the stem usually present as a short thick gathered base with ribs or pits; brittle flesh; growth in spring on wood or sometimes on the ground; and microscopic characters including spores with a pointed projection from each end.^ |The online Species Fungorum, accessed March 9, 2022, gives the current name as Discina ancilis (Pers.) Sacc., Syll. fung. (Abellini) 8: 103 (1889). RANGE ^It is found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, and also AB, MB, SK, AK, WY, eastern North America, and Europe including Czechoslovakia, (Abbott). Distribution includes also CA, CO, MT, and UT, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  (2)3-10(20)cm across, at first cup-shaped becoming saucer-like, then wavy or flattened to broadly convex (with down-turned margin) or umbonate or umbilicate, outline round to irregular or somewhat angular when old; spore-bearing upper surface "some shade of brown: tan to yellow-brown or brown, cinnamon-brown, or dark brown (usually paler or yellower when growing in or near snow)"; "usually wrinkled, veined, or convoluted, especially toward the center, but sometimes smooth"^, (Arora), 0.8-7cm across, 0.3-2cm high, up to 12cm x 4cm when fresh, shallowly cup-shaped, disc-shaped, or reflexed, margin inrolled at first; spore-bearing upper surface red-brown to medium or dark brown when fresh, nearly smooth or typically undulate-rugose [wavy-wrinkled], (Abbott), 3-15cm across, cup-shaped when young, then flat and plate-like, "strongly deformed, irregular, veined-wrinkled, with sinuous margin"; red-brown to chestnut-brown, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  "rather thick but brittle"^ (Arora), whitish (Breitenbach)
UNDERSIDE  paler than spore-bearing surface or whitish or somewhat translucent when moist; more or less smooth^, (Arora), white to cream or pale gray-brown; nearly bald to pubescent [finely downy], smooth or somewhat ribbed near stem, ribs rarely extending onto three quarters of exterior, (Abbott), whitish to ocher, also brownish pink, (Breitenbach)
STEM  "sometimes absent but more often present as a short (up to 1cm long), thick (1-3cm), narrowed base", usually appearing "gathered", with broad ribs and/or pits; white or tinged tan to brown^, (Arora), "virtually lacking or with a thickened base to distinct", up to 4.5cm x 2.5cm (up to 3cm wide when fresh), flaring and merging with cup; white to cream or pale red brown; nearly bald to pubescent, "typically fluted with broadly rounded ribs, solid or with few chambers", (Abbott), 1-3cm long, "stiffly cartilaginous, wrinkled", (Breitenbach)
ODOR  none^ (Breitenbach)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  not recommended: some eat it but care must be taken to cook it thoroughly and identify it correctly, (Arora)
HABITAT  single to gregarious or clustered, "on ground or around old stumps or occasionally on rotten wood in forests", mainly in spring or early summer under conifers, a characteristic snowbank fungus^, (Arora), single, gregarious or subcespitose and numerous, scattered on soil, litter, or woody debris, less often on rotted wood or burnt debris, under conifers or rarely under hardwoods or in mixed woods, March to July, (Abbott), single to gregarious, on rotting wood, especially conifer stumps, buried remains of wood, etc., (Breitenbach), "on wet soil or rotting wood in the mountains in spring", often as a snowbank fungus, (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 25-35 x (8)11-16 um, "spindle-shaped with an apiculus (knob or short projection) at each end, smooth or becoming minutely roughened at maturity, with one large central oil droplet and two or more smaller ones at the ends"^, (Arora), spores 27.6-45.6 x 11.6-16.1 um, subfusoid to fusoid, nearly smooth to distinctly roughened when mature, apiculi well developed, pointed, and 1.7-5.4 um long, some spores rarely non-apiculate, spores with one to three droplets, large central droplet round to broadly elliptic, with one or two small round polar droplets; asci 350-375 x 17.0-25.0 um; paraphyses 5.1-10.7 um wide at tip, terminal cell 64-103 um long, "clavate, gradually enlarged to abruptly swollen, brown individually, dark brown in mass, contents coarsely granular", (Abbott), spores 24-30 x 13-14 um without appendages, finely warty, when mature finely reticulate and with 3 oil droplets and a pointed colorless appendage of 3-6 um on each end; asci 8-spored, 300-350 x 17 um, negative reaction to iodine; paraphyses cylindric, slightly clavate, tips 7-10 um wide, with brownish contents, septate, (Breitenbach), spores 25-45 x 8-16 um (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Disciotis venosa is more cup-like and more veined, sometimes has a chlorine odor, and has smooth spores without large oil droplets (but sometimes small droplets at ends outside the spore wall). Discina leucoxantha is yellowish, has somewhat different spores, and is found under both hardwoods and conifers, (Arora). D. leucoxantha has a bright yellow brown to orange brown fresh upper surface and the spore apiculi are depressed (concave-truncate, each appearing as if there are two points instead of one), (Abbott). Gyromitra melaleucoides has a somewhat waxy-looking underside when moist, a sometimes slightly longer narrower stem, and much shorter non-apiculate spores, (Arora). Gyromitra olympiana is smaller, with different spores (strongly three-sided, in one view narrow and in another almost diamond-shaped), whereas spores of G. ancilis are narrowly fusoid and have prominent apiculi, (Kanouse(6) discussing Discina olympiana and Discina perlata). Some spores of Gyromitra olympiana have a broad blunt thickening at both ends. Spores of Gyromitra ancilis, Gyromitra olympiana, Gyromitra leucoxantha, and Gyromitra melaleucoides should be mature spores from a spore deposit when comparison is made (Michael Beug, pers. comm.)
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Breitenbach(1)* (as Discina perlata), Trudell(4)* (as Discina perlata), Arora(1)* (as Discina perlata), Miller(14)* (as Discina perlata), Larsen(1) (as Discina perlata), Ginns(7) (as Discina macrospora), Phillips(1)* (as Discina perlata), Lincoff(2)* (as Discina perlata), McKnight(1)* (as Discina perlata), Dennis(1) (as Discina perlata), Ammirati(1) (as Discina perlata), Kanouse(6) (discussing Discina olympiana), Desjardin(6)* (as Discina perlata), Marrone(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
122
FAMILY  Discinaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gyromitra leucoxantha  (Bres.) Harmaja^  Karstenia 9: 11. 1969;  Discina leucoxantha  Bres.;  = Discina larryi  McKnight;  = Gyromitra larryi  (McKnight) Harmaja;  = Discina convoluta  Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include irregularly cup-shaped to wavy-flattened-wrinkled fruitbody that is yellow-ocher or yellow to orange-brown to yellow; underside that is whitish and downy; distinct fluted stem usually buried in ground; growth under conifers; and microscopic characters including rough spores with a projection at each end that is two-pointed at maturity.^ RANGE ^Gyromitra leucoxantha is found at least in BC, AB, and UT, (Abbott), and OR and ID, (Larsen). It has been reported from WA by Andrew Parker, pers. comm., as well as from ON and PQ, (Ginns), and from eastern North America and Europe (including United Kingdom and Italy,) (Abbott).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-3.5cm across, 0.5-1.5cm high (up to 6.5cm x 2cm fresh), irregularly cup-shaped to reflexed; orange brown to bright orange brown, when dry bright red-brown; undulate-wrinkled^, (Abbott), 2-5(8)cm, disc-shaped to plate-shaped when young, "then expanded and flat and lying close to ground with a slightly turned-up margin" that is irregularly sinuous and wavy; upper spore-bearing surface ocher-yellow to yolk-yellow, irregularly wrinkled and undulating, (Breitenbach), 4-7cm across, nearly spherical at first, expanding and finally flat; when fresh yellow-ochraceous or bright ochraceous brown, drying pale brown; smooth to irregularly rugulose [wrinkled], (Ginns), up to about 10cm across (Trudell)
FLESH  two-layered in section^, (Breitenbach)
UNDERSIDE  white to pallid brown; pubescent [finely downy], smooth or with a few ribs at base^, (Abbott), whitish to cream, (Breitenbach), pale yellow brown or pale yellow; smooth to wrinkled, often in a pattern of concentric ridges, (Ginns)
STEM  0.5-1.5cm x 0.5-1cm (up to 2.5cm x 1.5cm fresh), usually distinct but often buried, equal, flaring and merging with cup; white to pallid brown; pubescent, fluted, ribs broadly rounded, solid^, (Abbott), thick, distinct, embedded deeply in ground, (Breitenbach), about 1cm long, fluted, solid or apparently hollow, (Ginns)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious on soil, litter, or woody debris in coniferous woods, May 10 to June 8 in BC^, (Abbott), single to gregarious under larch and spruce, shortly after snowmelt, (Breitenbach), on soil in woods of mixed hardwood and coniferous species, in May and early June, (Ginns)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 25.9-31.1 x 11.1-13.9 um, subfusoid to fusoid [somewhat spindle-shaped to spindle-shaped], distinctly roughened to reticulate, colorless, apiculus prominent 1.5-2.8 um long "with depressed (concave) apiculi at maturity, submature spores with slight apical thickenings, truncate knobs, or small depressed apiculi", with 1 to 3 droplets, one large central round to elliptic one and 0-2 smaller ones at the ends^; asci 19.2-22.3 um wide; paraphyses 6.4-9.0 um wide at tip, club-shaped, gradually enlarged to abruptly swollen at tip, "brown, contents coarsely granular", (Abbott), spores 28-32 x 14-16 (not including appendages), elliptic, finely punctate and weakly reticulate, colorless, with 1 droplet, usually with appendage on each end, each with 2 projections; asci 8-spored, 280 x 17 um, inamyloid; paraphyses "cylindric, tips slightly clavate with granular contents", (Breitenbach), spores 30-36 x 12-15 um, (Dennis), spores 26-31 x 10-13 um in water (excluding appendages), elliptic, smooth to coarsely wrinkled, colorless, IKI-, appendages one at each end, broad, truncated, usually centrally depressed, 1.8-3.6 um long, (Ginns), spores 30-40 x 12-18 um with two-humped tips (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'white-yellow'
SIMILAR  Gyromitra ancilis has its fresh upper surface colored orange-brown to red-brown or dark brown, and spore apiculi are pointed rather than depressed (concave-truncate appearing as if there are two points instead of one), (Abbott). Gyromitra olympiana spores may develop a broad blunt thickening at both ends. Gyromitra melaleucoides spores are smaller and lack apiculi. Spores of Gyromitra ancilis, Gyromitra olympiana, Gyromitra leucoxantha, and Gyromitra melaleucoides should be mature spores from a spore deposit when a comparison is made (Michael Beug, pers. comm.).
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Larsen(1) (as Discina leucoxantha), Breitenbach(1)* (as Discina leucoxantha), Ginns(10) (as Discina leucoxantha), Dennis(1) (as Discina leucoxantha), Trudell(4) (as Discina leucoxantha)
123
FAMILY  Discinaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gyromitra melaleucoides  (Seaver) Pfister^  Mycologia 72: 615. 1980;  == Peziza melaleucoides  Seaver;  = Paxina recurvum  Snyder;  = Gyromitra recurva  (Snyder) Harmaja;  = Paxina recurva  Snyder
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include irregularly disc-shaped, cup-shaped, or lobed fruitbody with margin typically reflexed [turned down] but free from stem, the upper surface brown-gray to gray-brown or dark brown and the lower surface whitish and quickly turning white as it starts to dry out, relatively short infolded fluted stem that is cream to pale yellow-brown, but may be indistinct or absent, growth on wood or on ground, in spring, and elliptic finely warted non-apiculate spores.^ | Harmaja comments on the shape of the apothecium being apparently unique in the genus (for the synonymized Gyromitra recurva), in that the stem is distinct, slender, and +/- smooth, and meets the cup abruptly, and the cup is +/- convex already when young, lacks distinct folds, and has a recurved margin which is loose and far from the stem, (Harmaja(5)). Reports of Gyromitra melaleuca (Bresadola) Donadini from CO and WA are unconfirmed and may represent G. melaleucoides. RANGE ^G. melaleucoides is found at least in BC, WA, ID, also AB, AK, CO, (Abbott), and also OR, MT, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.9-6.8cm across (up to 11cm across fresh), 0.9-5cm high, irregularly disc-shaped, cup-shaped, or lobed, margin typically reflexed [turned back] but free from stem; spore-bearing upper surface "dark gray brown, brown or dark red brown when dried", smooth to undulate-rugose [wavy-wrinkled]^, (Abbott), broadly and shallowly bowl-shaped to repand or slightly undulate but not truly strongly lobed; "brown-gray to gray-brown, varying to nearly black when old or partially dried"; surface even when young but often becoming undulate or irregular when old, (Castellano), interior surface of cup light to dark brown (Trudell), interior surface of cup pale gray-brown to dark brown or dark brown, (Beug)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  cream to pale yellow-brown; bald to finely pubescent [downy]^, (Abbott), more or less ivory to off-white; bald, without prominent ribs, (Castellano), exterior light brown to whitish (Trudell), underside quickly turns white as it starts to dry out, whereas Gyromitra ancilis, Gyromitra leucoxantha, and Gyromitra olympiana tend to retain more color on the underside as they start to dry out, (Beug)
STEM  1.5-5cm x 0.3-2.6cm, distinctly flaring at top, in lower part equal or widened at base, infolded/fluted, internally with hollow chambers; cream to pale yellow-brown; bald to finely pubescent^, (Abbott), sometimes absent to reduced (when old), varying to short-stemmed or indistinctly stemmed, (Castellano)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, gregarious, subcespitose, or scattered "on soil, litter, or rotted wood in coniferous or mixed forests", April 11 in BC to July 22 in ID^, (Abbott), on or adjacent to well-decayed (brown cubical-rotted) wood in moist coniferous forests, spring, (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11.6-14.4 x 8.0-9.4 um, elliptic to broadly elliptic, especially when immature, rough, warted, colorless, non-apiculate, with 2 droplets or infrequently with 1 droplet^, "de Bary bubbles present in a small proportion of mature spores"; asci 205-235 x 11.0-14.6 um; paraphyses 5.4-9.0 um wide at tip, terminal cell 53-105 um long, clavate, enlarged gradually to tip, pale yellow-brown to brown individually, brown in mass, (Abbott), spores 12-14 x 7-10 um, finely warted; asci J-, (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'like [Gyromitra] melaleuca'
SIMILAR  Discina species [here treated as Gyromitra ancilis, G. leucoxantha, G. olympiana] have dingy yellow to red-brown fruitbodies with the underside colored the same or paler, whereas G. melaleucoides has gray-tan to brown-gray or dark brown fruitbody with bald, "more or less ivory to off-white underside that lacks prominent ribs (but may have broad folds)", (Castellano), Discina species [here treated as Gyromitra] have at most a rudimentary stem and spores are different, (Trudell), spores of Gyromitra ancilis, G. olympiana, and G. leucoxantha are larger and may have apiculi at both ends; spores of Gyromitra ancilis, Gyromitra olympiana, Gyromitra leucoxantha, and Gyromitra melaleucoides should be mature spores from a spore deposit when comparison is made (Michael Beug, pers. comm.)
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Castellano(2)*, Trudell(4)*, Larsen(1), Harmaja(5) (as Gyromitra recurva), Beug(3)*, Marrone(1)*
124
FAMILY  Discinaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Gyromitra olympiana  (Kanouse) Harmaja^  Karstenia 13: 56, 1973;  Discina olympiana  Kanouse  Mycologia 39: 648. 1947;  = Discina apiculata  McKnight;  = Gyromitra apiculata  (McKnight) Harmaja;  Paradiscina olympiana  (Kanouse) Benedix
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Gyromitra olympiana is similar in shape to Gyromitra ancilis. Features include a fruitbody that is shallowly cup-shaped to disc-shaped or reflexed; upper surface that is yellow-brown to brown or red-brown when old, sometimes with olive tints; cream to pallid underside; stem lacking to rudimentary; growth on soil or duff in spring, often near melting snowbanks; and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, AB, UT, and WY, and reported from eastern North America, (Abbott). It has been recorded from WA, ID, CA, UT, and WY, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.9-5cm across, 1-1.5cm high, (up to 5.4cm x 2.5cm fresh), deeply to shallowly cup-shaped to disc-shaped or reflexed, margin inrolled at first and rarely splitting when old; spore-bearing upper surface "(fresh) pale to dark yellow brown to brown or red brown in age, sometimes with olivaceous tints, dark brown when dried"; smooth to undulate-rugose [wavy-wrinkled]^, (Abbot), 1.5-3cm across, flat with edge rolled under; "tawny olive" when fresh, drying blackish brown, (Kanouse)
FLESH  leathery^ (Abbot), thick, soft, (Kanouse)
UNDERSIDE  cream to pallid brown; bald to pubescent [finely downy]^, (Abbot)
STEM  lacking to rudimentary, up to 0.4cm x 0.4cm (2cm x 2cm fresh), solid, flaring and merging with cup; cream to whitish brown; "smooth or slightly fluted, finely pubescent"^, (Abbot), 0.2-0.3cm long, 0.2-0.3cm wide, wrinkled when dry, gradually expanded into the cup; cream to flesh-colored, (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, gregarious or scattered on soil or duff in coniferous forests or mixed woods, in spring, frequently near melting snow^, (Abbot)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (24.4)27.2-39.8(40.7) x (10.7)12.0-17.6(19.5) um, elliptic to subfusoid or fusoid [nearly spindle-shaped or spindle-shaped], finely roughened, colorless, apiculi virtually absent or broadly rounded thickenings, sometimes distinct broad truncate knobs, with 1 droplet or less often 3 droplets, (with large round central droplet and 0-3 smaller round polar droplets)^; asci 16.7-26.6 um wide; paraphyses 5.6-13.1 um wide at tip, terminal cell 84-218 um long, clavate to irregularly lobed, gradually enlarged or abruptly swollen at tip, sometimes bent or branched at tip, when present branches bifurcate at tip or paraphyses with knob-like branch bud below primary tip, yellow brown, brown in mass, contents coarsely granular, (Abbott), spores 30-32(36) x 12-14(16) um, "subtrihedrate (like beech nuts), in one view truly ellipsoid, in another broadly fusoid to diamond-shaped", smooth, thick-walled, sometimes thickened at ends to form small flat apiculi, containing one large highly refractive oil-droplet, often also 2 smaller oil droplets, uniseriate; asci 8-spored, 275-300 x 20-22 um in the spore-bearing part, cylindric, narrowing in lower part into long slender stem that readily collapses; paraphyses 7-9 um at tips, stout, bunched together in fascicles, brown; hypothecium pseudoprosenchymatic, (Kanouse), spores 28-36 x 13-16 um, with inconspicuously ornamented tips, (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  after Olympic National Park, where the type collection was found (Kanouse)
SIMILAR  Gyromitra ancilis is larger and has different spores that are narrowly fusoid and with prominent apiculi, whereas those of G. olympiana strongly three-sided (in one view narrow and in another almost diamond-shaped), (Kanouse, discussing Discina perlata and Discina olympiana). Some spores of Gyromitra ancilis have prominent pointed apiculi at both ends. Some spores of Gyromitra leucoxantha have concave apiculi at maturity. Spores of Gyromitra melaleucoides are smaller and lack apiculi. Spores of Gyromitra ancilis, Gyromitra olympiana, Gyromitra leucoxantha, and Gyromitra melaleucoides should be mature spores from a spore deposit when comparison is made (Michael Beug, pers. comm.).
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Larsen(1) (as Discina olympia), Kanouse(6) (as Discina olympia), Trudell(4) (as Discina olympia)
125
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hamatocanthoscypha laricionis  (Velen.) Svrcek.^  Ceska Mykol. 31: 11. 1977
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute cup on conifer cones, needles, twigs and bark chips, white hairy exterior, stem usually present, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from WA, YT, Austria, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, and Japan, (Huhtinen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.055cm across when fresh, cup-shaped throughout development, rarely undulate-crenate [wavy-scalloped] when (relatively) large; disc shallow to flat when fresh, bordered by thin but dense zone of marginal hairs that rise only slightly above spore-bearing surface, margin "fleshy and incurved when dry, often obscuring part of the hymenium"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pure white when fresh, dry fruitbodies ranging from pure white to straw color, apricot, or orange-brownish, rarely with a reddish tinge; hair cover "dense, minute, snow-white"
STEM  usually with stem, up to 0.013cm x 0.005cm, more rarely without stem on a gradually narrowing base
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious, mostly in fall, mostly on conifers (cones, fallen needles, twigs, and bark chips), more rarely on Lycopodium, once on Rhododendron leaves
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4.8-7.0(7.5) x 1-2(2.3) um, cuneiform-subfusiform, rarely oblong-elliptic, colorless, aseptate, minute droplets^; asci 8-spored, 23-36(41) x 4.0-5.1(6.3) um, cylindric to cylindric-clavate with slightly conic apex, arising from croziers, apical pore blue in iodine; paraphyses cylindric to slightly widened at tip, typically colorless, sometimes with inconspicuous yellowish pigment, first dichotomous branches occurring below the level of the asci, end cells 18-31 x 1.2-2.0 um, the widened apices 1.8-2.3 um wide; outer excipulum of texture prismatica, cells on middle flanks prismatic but typically inflated and/or elongated, 9.4-24(31) x 3.7-8.2(8.9) um, becoming smaller toward margin, inner excipulum of narrower textura prismatica, cells about 9-14 x 2-4 um; hairs 10-28(46) x 2.0-3.6 um, varying from almost cylindric to narrowly conic, uncinate [hooked], "in a few populations only hairs with apically undulating to straight hairs predominate, these always mixed with uncinate hairs, aseptate to basally two-septate", typically colorless, occasionally yellowish, apex blunt, ranging from scarcely to strongly tapering, walls thin, smooth to minutely and loosely roughened (fresh in water)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to Larix (larch), one of its hosts
SIMILAR  Hamatocanthoscypha uncinata var. phaeotricha is brownish and has somewhat larger spores and a different type of excipulum, (Huhtinen).
SOURCES  Huhtinen(2)
126
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hamatocanthoscypha uncinata  (W. Phillips) Huhtinen^  Karstenia 29: 197. 1989 (1990)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute cup on conifer needles, brownish hairy exterior, stem usually present, and microscopic characters.^ | This description is for variety phaeotricha which was recorded from Washington, var. uncinata differs mainly in its hairs, which have a unique one-sided thickening and are relatively long. Also, fruitbodies of var. uncinata are always deeply pigmented and lack the variation found in var. phaeotricha, and the excipular cells of var. uncinata are somewhat more isodiametric and darker than in var. phaeotricha. RANGE ^Material of var. phaeotricha was studied from WA, Norway, and Sweden. Material of var. uncinata was studied from was studied from CA, Norway, and Sweden. (Huhtinen(2)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.005-0.022 across when dry, cup-shaped throughout development, rarely undulate-crenulate [wavy-scalloped] when (relatively) large; disc shallow to flat when dry, often lighter in color than exterior, disc bordered by copious margin, which is clearly incurved when dry
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  blackish to grayish brown to brownish to grayish to cream, (the darker colors modified by a whitish hair cover), densely covered with hairs that vary from blackish brown to white between populations
STEM  0.002-0.008cm x 0.003-0.005cm, more rarely sessile on a somewhat tapering base; often darker in color than the flanks of the cup
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to gregarious; on needles of Abies (Washington), in Europe on Juniperus; spring to the end of the growing season
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5.4-11.7(13.6) x 1.2-2.6(2.8) um, cuneiform-subfusiform, rarely oblong-elliptic, aseptate (less than 1% septate), droplets lacking to inconspicuous^; asci 26-41 x 4.2-5.0(5.7) um, arising from croziers, apical pore blue in iodine; paraphyses cylindric to slightly widened at the tip, colorless, "first dichotomous branches typically occurring below the level of the ascal bases", end cells 19-35 x 1.5-2.3 um, the widened tips 1.8-2.8 um wide, mean septal intervals 7.2 um; ectal excipulum of texture prismatica, cells on middle flanks varying from isodiametric to regularly prismatic, more rarely clearly elongated, 4.3-13.5(21) x 3.6-7.0(8.2) um, walls in outer parts 0.4-1.0 um thick, deep brown to colorless, pigment distributed evenly in walls, hyphae of inner excipulum lighter to colorless, pigment often encrusted; hairs varying from 15-25 x 2.2-5.8 um, cylindric-tapering to lageniform, uncinate, aseptate to basally one-septate, tip tapering to 1.8-2 um in narrow-haired populations to 2.2-3 um in others, wall thin, brown to colorless, smooth or sparsely warted when pigment occurs in encrustations
NAME ORIGIN  means 'hooked', referring to the hairs
SIMILAR  Hamatocanthoscypha laricionis is light-colored and has somewhat smaller spores and a different type of excipulum, (Huhtinen).
SOURCES  Huhtinen(2)
127
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helotium albuminum  (Cooke & Peck)  Sacc.^  Syll. Fung. 8: 214. 1889;  Calycina albumina  Kuntze
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute whitish cup-shaped fruiting bodies, a stem that is slender and often nearly lacking, growth on wood of quince or maple, and microscopic characters.^ | Note that the genus Helotium has been abandoned in favor of Hymenoscyphus and Cudoniella. The epithet is spelled albumineum in Saccardo, but Seaver uses Peziza albumina Cooke & Peck, Calycina albumina Kuntze, and Helotium albuminum (Cooke & Peck) Sacc., and the online Species Fungorum, accessed December 16, 2015, gave this spelling as well. RANGE ^It is found from NY to ON and OR, (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  less than 0.1cm in diameter, "rather deeply concave, even, or slightly irregular", expanding and becoming nearly flat in dried specimens; whitish or yellowish^, (Seaver), fruitbody pale yellow when dry and more or less concolorous throughout; disc opening by a pore, expanding to nearly flat, reaching 0.04-0.06(0.09)cm (dimensions as dried?), colored as exterior when dried, or yellowish, often varying toward citron; margin turned inward in dried material partially obscuring disc, circular or lobed, (White)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  whitish, pale yellow when dry^, (Seaver), when dry cream-colored to buff or pale ochraceous, (White)
STEM  slender, often nearly lacking^, (Seaver), papilla-like or slender, cylindric, and distinct; even when nearly absent, cup is free from substrate, (White)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, more often gregarious, sometimes crowded and tending to become confluent, on wood and bark, reported on quince and maple^, (Seaver), single or more often gregarious, sometimes crowded and showing a slight tendency to become confluent; on dead wood and bark of hardwoods, (quince?, maple, and undetermined), one collection on a pyrenomycete, (White)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 1.2-1.8 um, allantoid [curved sausage-shaped]^; asci 8-spored, reaching 42-55 um long and 5 um wide, cylindric in upper part and slightly narrowed in lower part; paraphyses "simple, scarcely enlarged at their apices, about 2 um in diameter", (Seaver), spores 7-9 x 1.2-1.8 um, allantoid, 1-celled, biseriate; asci 42-55 x 5 um, cylindric in upper part, subtruncate, slightly narrowed in lower part to a broad basal part; paraphyses simple, scarcely or not at all enlarged at tip, about 2 um wide, (White)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2), White, W.L.(1)

FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helotium caraborum  Velen.^  Mono. Discom. Bohem. Pars. 1. p208. 1934
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, milky gray fruitbody with a short stem, growth on moss, and microscopic characters.^ | Note that the genus Helotium has been abandoned in favor of Hymenoscyphus and Cudoniella. RANGE ^Helotium caraborum is found at least in WA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  less than 0.1cm across, milky gray with a brownish margin [not clear from description whether milky gray color refers to upper (inner) surface or underside (exterior)]
FLESH  soft-waxy
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  short-stemmed
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on moss
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10(12) x 4-5 um, ovate-elliptic, colorless, one-celled, containing several oil droplets, obliquely uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 60-90 x 6-8 um, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses filiform, slightly enlarged and brownish at the tips
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(6)
129
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helvella acetabulum  (L.) Quel.  group^  Enchiridion Fungorum p.275. 1886;  == Paxina acetabulum  (L.) Kuntze;  Acetabula vulgaris  Fuckel
ENGLISH NAME(S)  vinegar cup, brown-ribbed elfin-cup, ribbed-stalked cup
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include deep brown cups with a white to yellow-brown stem about half as tall as the cup, sharp ribs on the stem continuing at least a third of the way onto the cup and sometimes to the margin, fruiting in spring, and microscopic characters.^ |It is possible that the Californian variation is a different species from the northern variation, and this is the reason for the group designation. |'acetabulum' does not agree in its ending with 'Helvella' because it is a noun rather than an adjective. RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, ID, and also AB, MB, ON, WY, Great Britain, Netherlands, France, and Scandinavia, and it has been reported from Asia, (Abbott). It has also been recorded from AZ, CO, and UT, (Larsen), CA (Arora).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-8cm across, 0.5-2cm high, deeply cup-shaped, margin expanding to slightly reflexed when old; "medium to dark brown (fresh and dried)"; smooth^, (Abbott), 2-6cm across, fruitbody 2-7(10)cm high, shell-shaped to cup-shaped or goblet-shaped, irregularly undulating and expanded when old; spore-bearing upper surface gray-brown, chestnut-brown, or red-brown, "here and there with lilac tinges", smooth, (Breitenbach), 2-8cm across, up to 4cm deep, cup-shaped or bowl-shaped, margin even or irregularly split when old; spore-bearing surface "light to dark brown (or in one form tinged violet), smooth", (Arora), light yellowish brown to dark brown, sometimes with a tinge of violet, (McKnight)
FLESH  thin, rather brittle^, (Arora), white (Phillips), wax-like, quite elastic in stem, (Lincoff(1))
UNDERSIDE  "brown near margin, yellow brown to white at base", "pubescent to densely pubescent, prominently ribbed, with sharp, branching and anastomosing ribs extending to marginal region"^, (Abbott), colored as upper surface but becoming pale towards the stem; finely furfuraceous, ribs from the stem continue onto the cup often up to the margin, and branch to form veins, (Breitenbach), brown in upper part, paler (white or creamy) at base; smooth or minutely hairy; conspicuously ribbed with blunt or sharp-edged ribs that are branching, usually cream-colored, typically extending at least half way up cup and often nearly to margin, (Arora)
STEM  0.3-4.5cm x 0.2-3cm, equal or narrowing toward base; white to light yellow-brown; "pubescent, highly ribbed", rarely lacunose [with holes], "ribs sharp or rarely blunt, branched and anastomosed, internally chambered"^, (Abbott), stem usually about half as tall as the cup, chambered internally and hollow, with raised, sharp-edged, white to ocher longitudinal ribs that continue onto the cup; smooth to slightly downy, (Breitenbach), sometimes absent but usually 1-5(9)cm x 0.5-3cm, stout, equal or widening in lower part, deeply ribbed, convoluted or chambered in cross-section; white or cream (or sometimes brown if very short), (Arora)
ODOR  none in particular^ (Lincoff(1))
TASTE  none in particular^ (Lincoff(1))
EDIBILITY  poisonous (Phillips), sometimes reported as edible with caution, (McKnight), fair when cooked, especially after being boiled, poisonous raw, (Lincoff(1))
HABITAT  single to gregarious on soil or litter in coniferous, mixed or hardwood woods, March to July^, (Abbott), single to gregarious in hardwood and coniferous forests, in pastures, commonly on pathsides and roadsides, on sandy chalky soil, April to June, (Breitenbach), single to gregarious on ground in woods and at their edges, spring and summer, but in CA may fruit in winter and early spring, (Arora), May to June (December to April in southwest), (Phillips)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-20 x 11-13.7 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 1 droplet^; asci 260-330 x 16-18 um, pleurorhynchous; paraphyses 4-6 um wide at tip, clavate to nearly equal, enlarged gradually to tip, "pale brown, contents finely granular", (Abbott), spores 17.5-19(20.5) x 11.5-13.5 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 1 droplet; asci 8-spored, 270-320 x 15-20 um, not turning blue in iodine; paraphyses cylindric, septate and branched at base, tips with slight clavate thickenings to 6-8 um, (Breitenbach), 16-20 x 11-14 um, elliptic, smooth, with central oil droplet, (Arora)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'a vinegar cup, any cup-shaped vessel'
SIMILAR  Helvella costifera has been differentiated on the basis of color (H. costifera is grayer and the underside is not yellow brown), ribbing (H. costifera ribs are blunt and often more widely spaced, but rarely ribs on H. acetabulum are blunt), and fruiting time (H. costifera fruits later, but overlaps with later collections of H. acetabulum), (Abbott). Harmaja describes other similar species from Fennoscandia including two with small fruiting bodies and spores averaging larger that fruit from late July to August, (Harmaja(9)). See also SIMILAR section of Helvella leucomelaena.
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Breitenbach(1)* (as Paxina acetabulum), Arora(1)*, Phillips(1)* (as Paxina acetabulum), Lincoff(1)* (as Paxina acetabulum), Lincoff(2)*, McKnight(1)*, Larsen(1), Buczacki(1)*, Harmaja(9), Desjardin(6)*, Marrone(1)*
130
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helvella corium  (O. Weberb.) Massee^  British Fungus Flora 4: 463. 1895;  = Helvella arctica  Nannf.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include black, cup-shaped fruitbodies, densely fine-hairy exterior, and stem and that is cylindric to shallowly fluted.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, ID, and also AB, MB, NT, NF, ON, PQ, SK, YT, AK, WI, Svalbard, Sweden, and Poland, and it has been reported from eastern North America and Asia, (Abbott). It has been recorded also from OR (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-2.5cm across and 0.2-1cm high (up to 4cm across and 1.2cm high when fresh), deeply to shallowly cup-shaped; black and drying black; smooth; margin inrolled at first, expanding at maturity^, (Abbott)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  black or blackish brown; "often with white to grayish white marginal pubescence, densely pubescent to villose near margin, smooth or rarely with ribs extending onto basal quarter"^, (Abbott)
STEM  0.2-2.9 x 0.05-0.8cm (up to 4cm long when fresh), equal or widened at base, solid, round in cross-section or slightly sulcate [grooved] or often slightly fluted especially at base, rarely strongly ribbed; black or very dark brown, often white or pale gray at base; pubescent^, (Abbott)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or typically gregarious to numerous and scattered, often on bare soil, typically with willows in deciduous or mixed woods or tundra, typically June to August, but from May to September^, (Abbott)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16.1-20.6 x 9.4-13(15) um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with one droplet^; asci 225-250 x 12.2-17 um; paraphyses 4.1-8 um wide at tip, clavate, enlarged gradually to abruptly at tip, brown, contents finely granular, (Abbott)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Other black species of Helvella (H. atra, H. pezizoides, and H. vespertina (as H. lacunosa)) have an irregular lobed head or cap, (Abbott). See also SIMILAR section of Plectania nannfeldtii.
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Larsen(1), Marrone(1)*
131
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helvella costifera  Nannf.^  Fungi Exsiccati Suecici Praesidium Upsaliensis Fasciculata 41-42: 37. No. 2061;  = Helvella griseoalba  N.S. Weber
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include deeply cup-shaped fruitbodies with a gray-brown upper surface; medium to pale gray-brown, downy underside; white to cream, downy stem with blunt ribs extending up onto the underside; growth in summer; and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from WA, ID, and also AB, YT, AK, MI, Norway, and Sweden, and it has been reported from eastern North America, and Asia, (Abbott). It has been recorded from AK and CA (Larsen but occurrence not confirmed by either Larsen or Denison).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1.6-4.2cm across, 1-2cm high, deeply cup-shaped, margin slightly inrolled at first, expanding when mature, sometimes laterally compressed at first; spore-bearing upper surface medium to dark gray-brown (fresh and dried), smooth to slightly undulate-rugose [wavy-wrinkled]^, (Abbott), fruitbody 2-6cm across, 2-6cm high, shell-shaped to cup-shaped, undulating [wavy] when old and split at the margin; spore-bearing surface ocher, gray-ocher, smooth, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  "medium to pale gray-brown, often white near base"; finely to densely pubescent [downy]; "ribs white to cream, branching and anastomosing, blunt and rounded, extending to marginal region"^, (Abbott), the same color as upper surface but somewhat lighter; finely downy, (Breitenbach)
STEM  0.8-2cm x 0.8-1cm, narrowing to base or nearly equal; white to cream; finely pubescent [downy], strongly ribbed, sometimes sparingly lacunose [with holes], "ribs blunt, branched and anastomosed, internally chambered"^, (Abbott), conic cup tapering into the pointed stem, which "shows blunt rounded longitudinal ribs which gradually run out into the cup", ribs often with low cross-veins, (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious on soil in coniferous or mixed woods, June to August^, (Abbott), gregarious in coniferous and hardwood forests on humusy, lime-rich soils, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14.4-19.7 x 9.6-12.4 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with one droplet^; asci 313-381 x 13.3-17.1 um, pleurorhynchous; paraphyses 3.6-6.2 um wide at tip, end cell 13.3 um long, clavate, widening gradually to tip, "pale brown, brown in mass, contents finely granular", (Abbott), spores 18-21.5 x 11.5-12.5 um (according to Dissing 15-19 x 10-13 um), broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with one droplet, sometimes with additional smaller droplets on the ends; asci 8-spored, 250-300 x 12-14 um, not turning blue in iodine; paraphyses cylindric, tips with slight clavate thickening to 3-5 um; hyphal outgrowths present on excipulum, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing ribs'
SIMILAR  Helvella acetabulum has been differentiated on the basis of color (H. costifera is grayer and the underside is not yellow brown), ribbing (H. costifera ribs are blunt and often more widely spaced, but rarely ribs on H. acetabulum are blunt), and fruiting time (H. costifera fruits later, but overlaps with later collections of H. acetabulum), (Abbott). Helvella solitaria is similar in color but has less prominent ribbing on stem and underside of cap, and a relatively narrower stem, (Abbott).
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Breitenbach(1)* (as Paxina costifera), Larsen(1)
132
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helvella crassitunicata  N.S. Weber^  Beihefte Nova Hedwigia 51: 27. 1975
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include a cup-shaped fruitbody with medium to dark brown upper surface; medium to dark brown external surface that is densely downy; medium brown to pallid densely downy stem with rounded ribs that extend onto the basal half of the underside of the cap; and microscopic characters including large spores and thick-walled paraphyses with a long terminal cell in addition to the normal thin-walled ones for the genus. RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, and AK, but it is rare and endemic, (Abbott). It is found in WA and OR, (Castellano).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.4-5cm across, 0.3-3.3cm high (up to 10cm x 6cm fresh), deeply cup-shaped, margin inrolled at first, expanding to shallowly cup-shaped or somewhat reflexed when mature; spore-bearing upper surface "medium to dark brown fresh, when dried dark brown to blackish brown", smooth to slightly undulate-rugose [wavy-wrinkled]^, (Abbott), fruitbody up to 4cm across at maturity, up to 2-3cm tall, bowl-shaped when young, spreading when old, regular from above to slightly compressed; some shade of brown to gray-brown, (Castellano)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  "medium to dark brown, sometimes paler at basal region, pubescent to densely pubescent, ribs extending onto basal half of excipular surface (rarely extending only slightly onto excipulum)"^, (Abbott), colored as upper surface near margin, paler toward base; lacking extensive ridges, ridges not extending to margin, (Castellano)
STEM  0.2-2cm x 0.2-1.3cm (up to 5cm x 4cm fresh), internally solid, sulcate, flaring and merging with underside of cap; "medium brown to pallid (especially at base)"; "finely pubescent to pubescent, ribs indistinct to prominent, rounded, widely separated, may be bifurcate branched, but with no anastomosis between ribs"^, (Abbott), subsessile to short-stemmed, up to 2cm long, "consisting of rounded ribs, resembling soft folds"; "ivory to off-white", (Castellano)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, gregarious, or subcespitose [somewhat tufted] on soil under conifers, May to October^, (Abbott), scattered to gregarious on soil, especially along trails, in montane regions with Abies spp. (fir), August to October, (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 22.7-27.6 x 12.6-14.6 um, broadly elliptic or elliptic to subcylindric, smooth, colorless, with one droplet^; asci 350-400 x 17-20 um, aporhynchous; paraphyses 5.4-8.8 um wide at tip, of two forms, "most thin-walled, terminal cell in some becoming elongated and thick-walled, clavate, expanding gradually to apex, often slightly irregular, terminal of thin-walled paraphyses 67-94 um long, terminal cell of thick-walled paraphyses 235-300 um long, pale brown to brown, contents finely granular, walls of thick-walled paraphyses pigmented", (Abbott), spores 23-28(30) x 13-15 um, elliptic, smooth; asci 8-spored, inamyloid, with single basal scar; paraphyses "straight, narrowly clavate, by maturity at least some with distinctly thickened walls", (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'thick-skinned'
SIMILAR  Helvella leucomelaena has a different color, weaker pubescence of the underside and stem, and less pronounced ribbing of the stem and underside, (Abbott). H. leucomelaena fruits from winter to early summer and differs microscopically, (Arora).
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Castellano(1)*, Arora(1)
133
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helvella cupuliformis  Dissing & Nannf.^  Svensk Botanisk Tidskrift 60: 326. 1966;  Cyathipodia cupuliformis  (Dissing & Nannf.)  J. Breitenb. & F. Kranzl.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include an ocher-brown shallow cup, the underside and margin somewhat lighter in color and felty-furfuraceous, a solid white to cream stem that is cylindric and finely furfuraceous near the top, growth on the ground in forest, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from OR (rare), and also TX, SC, Sweden, and Switzerland, and it is reported from eastern North America and Asia, (Abbott).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.9-3.5cm across, 0.4-1.6cm high, deeply cup-shaped at first, expanding to shallowly cup-shaped when mature, margin inrolled at first, sometimes splitting when old; dark brown to gray-brown when dried; smooth^, (Abbott), 1.5-3cm across, irregularly dish-shaped to slightly saddle-shaped, soon becoming flat and plate-like; ocher-brown; smooth, dull; margin smooth, border finely felty-furfuraceous and somewhat lighter, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  gray-brown, paler than upper surface; densely pubescent to villose^, (Abbott), somewhat lighter than upper surface; felty-furfuraceous, (Breitenbach)
STEM  0.2-1cm x 0.2-0.8cm, indistinct to prominent, solid, round in cross-section or slightly fluted, white to cream or light gray brown near top; densely pubescent to villose (especially at top)^, (Abbott), 1.5-2.5cm x 0.4-0.6(0.8)cm, solid, cylindric, more rarely somewhat longitudinally furrowed; white to cream; smooth, finely furfuraceous toward the tip, (Breitenbach) 
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on clay soil under Arbutus menziesii and Arctostaphylos sp., March in OR^, (Abbott), single to gregarious on path embankments on loamy-sandy soil in hardwood and coniferous forests, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18.4-21.0 x 11.4-12.2 um, broadly elliptic to elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 1 droplet^; asci 250-300 x 15-17 um; paraphyses 4.3-6.6 um wide at tip, clavate, enlarged gradually to tip, pale brown to brown in mass, contents finely granular, (Abbott), spores 18-20(21) x 12-13.5 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 1 large droplet; asci 8-spored, 300-350 x 17-20 um, not turning blue in iodine; paraphyses cylindric, tips with slight clavate thickening to 7 um; hyphal outgrowths on the excipulum "with rather squared-off cells", (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'cup-shaped'
SIMILAR  Helvella fibrosa has a gray to gray-brown head and spores are somewhat narrower, (Breitenbach, discussing its synonym Cyathipodia villosa). H. fibrosa has a longer, less robust stem, and dried fruitbodies have gray-brown rather than yellow head, (Abbott discussing its synonym H. chinensis). Helvella solitaria is highly ribbed on the stem (rarely sparsely ribbed), and may have a gray-brown stem, (Abbott). See also SIMILAR section of Helvella macropus.
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Breitenbach(1)* (as Cyathipodia cupuliformis)
134
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helvella fibrosa  (Wallr.) Korf^  Mycotaxon 103: 311 2008;  == Macropodia fibrosa  (Wallr.) Sacc.;  == Helvella villosa  (Hedw. ex Kuntze) Dissing & Nannf.;  == Octospora villosa  Hedw.;  == Cyathipodia villosa  (Hedw.) Boud.;  == Helvella dissingii  Korf;  = Helvella chinensis  (Velen.) Nannf. & L. Holm;  = Macropodia chinensis  Velen.;  = Helvella pallidula  N.S. Weber
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include relatively small size, laterally compressed cup-shaped fruitbody with dark gray to gray-brown upper surface, lighter gray-brown finely hairy margin and underside, whitish to gray-brown cylindric finely hairy stem, and microscopic characters.^ | H. pallidula is regarded by Abbott as a pale variant of H. chinensis, which is regarded here as a synonym of Helvella fibrosa. RANGE ^Collections of Helvella fibrosa were examined from WA, ID, AB, AK, IA, MI, MO, PA, Norway, and Sweden, and it has been reported from Asia and Australia, (Abbott, as Helvella chinensis). 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across (up to 3cm across fresh), 0.5-1cm high, shallowly cup-shaped to flat, sometimes laterally compressed at first, rarely reflexed-convex when old; spore-bearing upper surface gray to gray-brown when dried, smooth^, (Abbott), 1.5-3cm, irregularly dish-shaped to slightly saddle-shaped, somewhat compressed from side to side; dark gray to gray-brown, smooth, dull; margin sinuous, bent inward, slightly notched, sometimes rather split, somewhat lighter gray-brown, finely felty-furfuraceous, (Breitenbach)
FLESH
