UNDERSIDE  gray-brown; villose to densely pubescent [finely hairy]^, (Abbott), somewhat lighter gray-brown than spore-bearing surface, finely felty-furfuraceous, (Breitenbach)
STEM  1.1-3.0 x 0.1-0.5cm (up to 4cm long fresh), equal or apex narrowing slightly, round in cross-section, solid; gray brown; densely pubescent^, (Abbott), 1.5-2.5cm x 0.4-0.6(0.8)cm, solid, cylindric, more rarely somewhat longitudinally furrowed; white to cream; smooth but finely furfuraceous toward the tip, (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious or scattered and numerous on litter in hardwood, mixed, or coniferous woods, April to October^, (Abbott), single to gregarious on pathsides and roadsides on sandy bare soil in spruce forest, according to literature also under hardwoods and on humusy and loamy ground, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16.5-20 x 10-12 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with one droplet^; asci 240-260 x 17-29 um; paraphyses 5-7.5 um wide at tip, clavate, enlarged gradually to tip, colorless to pale brown, (Abbott), spores (16)17-20 x 10.5-12 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with one large droplet; asci 8-spored, 230-280 x 15 um, not turning blue in iodine; paraphyses cylindric, tips with slight clavate thickening to 7 um wide; hyphal outgrowths on excipulum with oblong cells, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Helvella cupuliformis has a short robust stem and dried fruitbodies are yellow, (Abbott). H. cupuliformis is ocher-brown, with somewhat broader spores, (Breitenbach). Helvella macropus is very similar macroscopically but has different spores, (Abbott). H. macropus has a hymenium that is lighter in color, (Korf). Helvella solitaria grows larger, has prominent ribbing of the stem, and has slightly broader spores, (Abbott).
SOURCES  Abbott(1) (as Helvella chinensis), Breitenbach(1)* (as Cyathipodia villosa), Phillips(1)* (as Helvella villosa), Korf(6)
135
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helvella leucomelaena  (Pers.) Nannf.^  in Lundell & Nannfeldt. Fungi Exsiccati Suecici Praesidium Upsaliensis Fasciculata 19-20: 21. no. 952. 1941;  = Helvella confusa  Harmaja;  = Helvella pedunculata  Harmaja
ENGLISH NAME(S)  white-footed elfin-cup, sooty cup
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include a dark brown to gray-brown upper surface, finely downy underside, white stem with well separated blunt ribs that do not extend beyond the lower quarter of the underside, fruiting from spring to early summer, and microscopic characters including relatively large spores and aporhynchous asci.^ | It is quite common in the Rocky Mountains in late spring (Weber). RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, ID, and also AB, NF, ON, PQ, AK, WY, Argentina, Sweden, Finland, Denmark, Netherlands, Italy, Australia, reported from north Africa, Middle East, and Asia, (Abbott). Collections were examined from OR, ID, CA, CO, UT, WY, (Weber). It also occurs in Switzerland (Breitenbach).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.4-6cm across, 0.3-3.4cm high (up to 7cm across fresh), deeply cup-shaped, at first almost spherical and nearly closed, margin expanding when mature to shallowly cup-shaped, "often becoming split and somewhat reflexed, occasionally laterally compressed when immature, cups rarely irregular and repand when growing in clusters"; spore-bearing upper surface "dark brown to gray-brown when fresh, rarely with paler areas, when dry dark brown to blackish brown", smooth to slightly undulate-rugose [wavy-wrinkled]^, (Abbott), fruitbody 1-4cm wide, 1-3(4)cm tall, cup-shaped, "expanded and flat and split at the margin only in age"; spore-bearing upper surface dark gray-brown to black-brown, smooth, (Breitenbach), fruitbody (12)2-5(7)cm across and high, cup-shaped or bowl-shaped, interior of cup dark gray to dark brown, dark grayish brown, or blackish; smooth; the margin often finely scalloped, lobed, or split, especially when old, (Arora)
FLESH  thin, rather brittle^, (Arora)
UNDERSIDE  brown to dark brown at margin, pallid brown in lower part, white near base; "pubescent, ribs absent or extending onto basal quarter only"^, (Abbott), dark gray-brown to black-brown, the same color as upper surface, fading in embedded individuals to whitish toward the stem; ribs from stem scarcely continuing onto the cup or doing so only for a short distance, (Breitenbach), in upper part colored like upper surface, shading to white or cream in lower part; minutely roughened, not ribbed or only ribbed basally, (Arora)
STEM  0.1-2cm x 0.1-1.5cm, "internally sulcate and solid or chambered", widening in upper part and merging with cup, in lower part equal or base rarely slightly enlarged; white; "finely pubescent, sparingly ribbed, ribs broad and rounded"^, (Abbott), short and stout, embedded in ground, longitudinally folded into ribs, lighter gray-brown than upper surface on the above-ground parts; finely downy, (Breitenbach), 0.5-2(4)cm x 0.5-1.5(3)cm at top, often buried till maturity, "with distinct, broad, low, rounded, whitish ribs" ending at base of cup, short and stout to practically absent (in the latter case the base of the bowl appears gathered); usually white but at times dingy grayish; channeled in cross-section, (Arora)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, gregarious, subcespitose [somewhat tufted], or scattered and numerous on bare soil, moss, or litter in coniferous woods, April to September^, (Abbott), gregarious in forests and meadows, commonly on pathsides and roadsides, in stony, sandy, humus-poor places, April to June, (Breitenbach), scattered to densely gregarious or clustered, occasionally single, on ground, usually near or under pine or other conifers, favoring bare, grassy or hard-packed soil along roads and paths; in spring and early summer, or in California in winter and early spring, (Arora)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-24.2 x 10.9-15 um, broadly elliptic to elliptic, smooth, colorless, one droplet^; asci 225-330 x 14.6-20 um, aporhynchous; paraphyses 4.9-9 um wide at tip, end cell 144-145 um long, clavate, enlarged gradually to abruptly at tip, "pale brown to brown, contents finely granular", (Abbott), spores 18-23 x 10-14 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with one droplet, sometimes with additional small droplets in the ends; asci 8-spored, 250-300 x 13-16 um, not turning blue in iodine; paraphyses cylindric, thickened toward tips to 8 um, septate towards base, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'white-black'
SIMILAR  Helvella crassitunicata has a different color, stronger pubescence of the underside and stem, and more pronounced ribbing of stem and underside, (Abbott). H. crassitunicata usually fruits in late summer and fall and differs microscopically, (Arora). H. crassitunicata fruits in the fall, has larger spores, and has peculiarly thickened paraphyses that almost resemble setae, (Weber). Helvella solitaria has pleurorhynchous asci and smaller spores, (Abbott). H. solitaria has a more distinct stem, usually develops above the ground, and differs microscopically, (Arora). Helvella acetabulum has "usually larger and paler tan cups with more pronounced ribs extending upward to near the cup margin" (Trudell).
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Breitenbach(1)* (as Paxina leucomelas), Arora(1)*, Larsen(1), Buczacki(1)*, Marrone(1)*
136
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helvella macropus  (Pers.) P. Karst.^  Notiser ur Sallskapets pro Flora et Fauna Fennica Forhandlingar 11: 224. 1870;  == Cyathipodia macropus  (Pers.) Dennis;  = Paxina subclavipes  (W. Phillips & Ellis) Seaver;  = Macropodia subclavipes  (W. Phillips & Ellis) Rehm;  = Helvella macropus var. brevis  Peck;  = Helvella brevis  (Peck) Harmaja;  Macroscyphus macropus  Pers. ex Gray
ENGLISH NAME(S)  long-stalked gray cup, scurfy elfin-cup, felt saddle
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include a cup-shaped fruiting body with a dark brown to gray upper surface; a light to medium brown or gray-brown, densely downy undersurface, sometimes with olivaceous tints; a light to medium gray-brown densely downy stem that is round in cross-section or fluted over its lower half; and microscopic characters including spindle-shaped spores each with three droplets. RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, ID, and also AB, MB, ON, PQ, AK, MA, MI, NJ, NY, WI, and Japan, and it has been reported from southern North America, Central America, Caribbean, Europe, and Asia, (Abbott). It is also recorded from AZ and CO, (Larsen), and CA (Arora).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-3.5cm across, 0.4-1.2cm high, deeply cup-shaped, expanding to shallowly cup-shaped or disc-shaped when old, often laterally compressed at first, margin inrolled at first; spore-bearing upper surface dark brown (fresh and dried), smooth^, (Abbott), 1.5-3cm across, saucer-shaped, rarely becoming somewhat saddle-shaped when old; gray to gray-brown; smooth; margin felty-hairy, (Breitenbach), 0.8-3(6)cm across, sometimes closed when young, but soon opening to shallow cup-shaped, rarely becoming flat when old, margin at first incurved; upper surface usually gray to grayish brown, varying to grayish tan or grayish olive or grayish buff, smooth, (Arora), brownish gray (Phillips)
FLESH  thin^ (Arora)
UNDERSIDE  light to medium brown or gray-brown, sometimes with olivaceous tints; densely pubescent [densely downy] to villose^, (Abbott), same color as upper surface or lighter; "distinctly felty-hairy (felt consisting of tiny tufts of hair)", (Breitenbach), colored like upper surface or slightly paler or grayer; hairy or minutely fibrillose-scaly or dandruffy, (Arora), appearing pale gray due to dense covering of tufted downy hairs (Phillips)
STEM  0.4-6cm x 0.1-0.9cm when fresh, equal or widened at base, tip typically tapered, "terete or fluted over basal half, terete to slightly sulcate and internally solid"; light to medium gray-brown; densely pubescent to villose^, (Abbott), 2-5cm long, cylindric, thickened somewhat toward base, solid; the same color as underside of cap; felty-hairy, (Breitenbach), 1-5(7)cm x 0.2-0.5cm, equal or often widened at base, round or flattened but not chambered in cross-section, "not ribbed but sometimes with wrinkles or pits at the base"; "colored like the exterior of cup above and hairy or scaly-dandruffy, usually paler or whitish at the base", (Arora), gray, paler in lower part, (Phillips)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  no (Phillips)
HABITAT  single to gregarious on litter or soil, infrequently on rotted wood, in hardwood, mixed, or coniferous woods, July to October^, (Abbott), often single, sometimes in coniferous forests but primarily in hardwood forests, on bare ground or moss-covered places, July to October, (Breitenbach), single, scattered, or gregarious "on ground or rotten wood under both hardwoods and conifers", summer, winter, and spring, (Arora), June to November, (December to January on the west coast), (Phillips)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-25.1 x 10.3-12.2 um, subfusoid, smooth to verruculose, colorless, with 3 droplets or infrequently with 1 droplet^; asci 175-250 x 14-18 um; paraphyses 5-9.6 um at tip, clavate, enlarged gradually to abruptly at tip, "pale brown to brown in mass, contents finely granular", (Abbott), spores (19.5)20-27(31) x (9.5)10-12 um, fusiform-elliptic, colorless, usually finely punctate, more rarely smooth, sometimes with coarse round warts when young, spores with one large and usually 1-2 smaller drops in each end; asci 8-spored, 220-350 x 15-20 um, not turning blue in iodine; paraphyses cylindric and thickened on tips "to 9-12(7) um" [sic]; with chains of oval cells projecting from exterior as hairs, (Breitenbach), spores (18)20-25 x 10-12.5 um, "more or less spindle-shaped, finely roughened or smooth, with one large oil droplet and a smaller one at each end", (Arora), spores 20-30 x 10-12 um (Phillips)
NAME ORIGIN  from Greek meaning "large-footed" (Lincoff(1)), or "with a long leg" (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
SIMILAR  Helvella fibrosa (as H. chinensis) and Helvella cupuliformis have different color and spores (Abbott). H. fibrosa has a darker hymenium, (Korf(6)).
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Breitenbach(1)* (as Macroscyphus macropus), Arora(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Larsen(1), Phillips(1)*, Lincoff(1)* (as Macroscyphus macropus), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Korf(6) (discussing Helvella fibrosa), Buczacki(1)*
137
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helvella pezizoides  Afzel.^  K. svenska Vetensk-Akad. Handl., ser. 2 4: 308. 1783
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include a lobed to cup-shaped or disc-shaped cap that is black when dry; finely hairy underside that is dark brown to dark gray-brown; solid, finely hairy stem that is round to fluted and when dry is dark brown to dark gray-brown; growth on the ground or wood; and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from AB, Northwest Territories, PQ, AK, MI, Jamaica, Norway, and France, and it has been reported from eastern North America, southern North America, Europe, and Asia, (Abbott). It has been recorded from OR, CA, CO, and NM, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.25-0.8cm across, 0.2-0.7cm high, 2-lobed or irregularly lobed to irregularly cup-shaped or disc-shaped, occasionally laterally compressed at first, margin strongly inrolled at first, remaining incurved at maturity; when dry black in color; smooth or rarely slightly undulate-rugose [wavy-wrinkled]^, (Abbott)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  dark brown to dark gray-brown [this may be the color when dry]; pubescent to villose [finely hairy]^, (Abbott)
STEM  0.3-2.5cm x 0.05-0.3cm, solid, round in cross-section or fluted at base, widening slightly to base, tapered at top; when dry dark brown to dark gray-brown or blackish brown; pubescent to villose^, (Abbott)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious on soil, humus, or rotted wood in woodland, bog or tundra habitats^, (Abbott)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16.9-20.8 x 10.7-13.3 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with one droplet^; asci 100-315 x 14.1-18.6 um; paraphyses 4-8.6 um wide at tip, end cell 40-60 um long, clavate, enlarged gradually to abruptly at tip, brown to dark brown in mass, contents finely granular, (Abbott)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Helvella atra (see Morels etc. category) is close but H. pezizoides differs in its strongly inrolled cap margin, occasional irregular cup or disc shape, densely pubescent to villose cap underside, and strong brown pigmentation of cap underside and stem: Helvella atra has a slightly incurved cap margin at the submature stage and a reflexed margin at maturity, finely pubescent cap underside, and cap underside and stem are not as dark in color, (Abbott). See also SIMILAR section of Helvella corium.
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Larsen(1)
138
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Helvella solitaria  P. Karst.^  Bidrag Kannedom af Finlands Natur och Folk 19: 37. 1871;  = Helvella queletii  Bres.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include a cup-shaped to bilobed fruitbody with gray-brown to dark brown upper surface; gray-brown, downy undersurface without ribs; whitish to gray-brown, downy stem that is highly ribbed; fruiting from April to October; and microscopic characters.^ | The description below derived from Arora is for Helvella queletii (which he says has a longer stem than H. solitaria). Helvella queletii included as a synonym by Abbott. RANGE ^Collections of H. solitaria were examined from BC, WA, OR, ID, and also the Northwest Territories, AB, MB, SK, AK, NY, WY, Norway, Finland, and Romania, and it has been reported from eastern North America and Europe, (Abbott). It has also been recorded from CA and CO, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1.3-6cm across, 0.4-4.4cm high (up to 12.0 x 5cm fresh), cup-shaped, often laterally compressed at first, often becoming bilobate, shallowly cup-shaped, or somewhat reflexed when old, margin slightly inrolled at first; spore-bearing upper surface gray-brown to dark brown when fresh, when dry dark gray-brown to blackish brown, smooth to slightly undulate-rugose [wavy-wrinkled]^, (Abbott), 2-8(12)cm across, usually concave with opposite margins at first rolled up and in, becoming shallowly cup-shaped or saucer-shaped to flat or even with down-curved margin when old; upper surface blackish to grayish brown to brown or in one form pale brown to buffy-brown; smooth; margin often splitting when old, (Arora)
FLESH  ^thin, rather brittle, (Arora)
UNDERSIDE  medium to dark gray-brown at margin, base typically paler gray-brown to white; pubescent [downy] to densely pubescent, ribs absent or extending very slightly onto base of underside^, (Abbott), same color as upper surface or more often paler or grayer; minutely roughened (granulose) to nearly smooth, without ribs, (Arora)
STEM  0.7-10.5cm x 0.2-5cm (up to 12cm x 5cm when fresh), equal or widened at base, top flaring slightly, sulcate and internally solid or with a few chambers; "white to pale or grey brown", occasionally dark gray-brown at top; finely pubescent to pubescent, highly ribbed or rarely with sparse ribbing, ribs simple or branching and anastomosed^, (Abbott), (1)2.5-7(12)cm x 0.5-2(5)cm, equal or wider in lower part, deeply longitudinally ribbed, the ribs extending only to the base of the cup; white or sometimes tinged buff, tan, or ocher, (Arora)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or often gregarious to numerous and scattered on ground in soil or litter in coniferous, mixed, or occasionally hardwood woods, April to October^, (Abbott), single, scattered or in small groups in forest humus or occasionally on rotting wood, usually under hardwoods, late spring and summer, but in California may fruit in winter and early spring, (Arora)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17-21 x 11-13.5 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with one droplet^; asci 240-300 x 14-18 um, pleurorhynchous; paraphyses 7-8 um wide at tip, end cell 89-144 um long, "clavate, brown, contents finely granular", (Abbott), spores (17)19-22 x 11-14 um, elliptic to oblong, smooth, with large central oil droplet, (Arora)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'alone'
SIMILAR  Helvella costifera is similar in color but has more prominent ribbing on the stem and the underside of the cap and a relatively broader stem, (Abbott). Helvella leucomelaena has aporhynchous asci and larger spores, (Abbott). H. leucomelaena has a less distinct stem that is often buried until maturity and the species differs microscopically, (Arora). Helvella cupuliformis never attains a large size, has an unpigmented stem, and lacks prominent ribbing on the stem with the ribs always absent from the base of the excipulum, (Abbott). Helvella fibrosa (as H. chinensis) never achieves large size, lacks prominent ribbing on stem and has slightly narrower spores, (Abbott).
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Arora(1) (as Helvella queletii), Larsen(1)
139
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Henningsomyces candidus  (Pers.) Kuntze^  Rev. Generum Plantarum 3(2): 483. 1898;  == Solenia candida  Pers.;  Solenia polyporoidea  (Peck) Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute whitish fruiting bodies like tall tubular cups growing in colonies on rotting coniferous and hardwood wood and bark, with fleeting subiculum, and microscopic characters including basidia.^ RANGE ^Henningsomyces candidus is found in BC, WA, OR, ID, and also NS, ON, PQ, AZ, CA, CO, CT, DE, FL, GA, IA, KY, LA, MA, ME, MI, MO, NC, NH, NJ, NM, NY, OH, PA, SC, TN, TX, VA, VT, and WA, (Ginns), and Bermuda, Jamaica, Panama, Trinidad, Brazil, Ecuador, Chile, Austria, Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Latvia, Macedonia, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Sweden, United Kingdom, Sri Lanka, Japan, Turkey, Algeria, Morocco, Sierra Leone, Tunisia, Australia, New Zealand, Philippines, and Tristan da Cunha, (Cooke).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.02-0.05cm in diameter, 0.02-0.08(0.3)cm tall, like a tall tubular cup, margin inrolled when dry, free to confluent, when confluent not separating without damage^, (Cooke), fruitbodies "developing as individual tubes, gregarious, closely packed but easily separated"; white; 0.06-0.072cm long and 0.018-0.024cm wide, (Gilbertson), 0.05-0.1cm long and 0.02-0.04cm wide, tubular; spore-bearing surface lining the tubes white and smooth, (Buczacki)
FLESH  thin^ (Cooke), soft, fragile; white-cream, (Buczacki)
UNDERSIDE  white at first, then cream color in some specimens when dry^, (Cooke), exterior farinaceous to finely tomentose under at 30x lens, (Gilbertson), "outer surface smooth to slightly roughened" (Buczacki)
STEM  appearing sessile at first (with no stem), with a stem-like base that may be half as long as the 'cup' at maturity; with a fleeting subiculum (underlying mass of hyphae) which may not be present in some specimens^, (Cooke)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on rotting coniferous and hardwood wood and bark^ (Cooke), on hardwood and conifer wood: bark and wood, barkless and decaying wood, rotten wood, twigs, dead branches, rotten logs, old plank; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), single "or in densely tufted or trooping groups" on rotting wood of hardwoods, all year, (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter
SPORE DEPOSIT  white^ (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 3.5-6.0 x 3.0-5.0 or 3-6 x 3-6 um, round to nearly round, or oval, smooth, apiculate, hyaline^; basidia 14.5-21 x (4-5)-7-8 um, 2-4-spored; 'cup' covered with a fine network of clamped hyphae 1-2 um in diameter, finely branched, forming a dichophysoid (repeatedly dichotomously branched) pellicle dichophysoid hyphae 10-25(50) x 0.5-1.0(1.5) um; a palisade of dichophyses around margin of 'cup', colorless, dichotomously branched, 1-2 um in diameter, with slender tips, (Cooke), spores 5-7 x 4-5 um, nearly round to broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, inamyloid; basidia 2-4 spored, 13.5-20 x 5.5-7 um, clavate; cystidioles 18-25 x 4-6 um, fusiform; hyphal system dimitic, generative hyphae 2-3.5 um wide, thin-walled, with obscure clamp connections, skeletal hyphae 1-2 um wide, making up outer tomentum, slender, nonseptate, with frequent branching, often dendritic, (Gilbertson), spores 4.5-6 x 4-5 um, nearly round, smooth, inamyloid; basidia 4-spored, 15-20 um, clavate; cystidia absent; hyphal system monomitic; marginal hairs "white, smooth, very finely branched", (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'white'
SIMILAR  Henningsomyces puber has dichophytic hairs except at the extreme margin, whereas H. candidus is almost bald with dichophytic hairs only in the region near the extreme margin, (Reid(4)).
SOURCES  Cooke(2) (as Solenia candida), Gilbertson(4), Ginns(5), Redhead(5), Reid(4), Buczacki(1)*, Desjardin(6)*
140
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Henningsomyces puber  (Romell ex W.B. Cooke) D.A. Reid^  Persoonia 3: 119. 1964;  Solenia pubera  Romell ex W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, hanging, tall tubular whitish cups, stem absent except as a narrowing to bring fruitbodies on oblique surfaces to a vertical position, growth on dead wood, scattered in small groups or densely crowded in large colonies, and microscopic characters including external dichophytic hairs except at extreme margin, and basidia.^ | Reid's description is for var. americana which he says differs from the type variety only in having clamp connections (while Cooke says basidia of the type are 4-spored, Reid found only 2-spored basidia in the type: if this is true throughout the collection, it may be a consequence of a haploid state and then the absence of clamp connections would be of questionable taxonomic significance), (Reid). RANGE ^Henningsomyces puber is found in BC, ON, CT, and MI, (Ginns), and Sweden, (Cooke).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbodies nearly spherical at first, becoming tubular up to 0.08cm long pointing downwards; white when fresh, cream or buff when dried^, (Reid), 0.025-0.05cm in diameter, 0.1-0.2cm tall, like a tall tubular cup, pendant, (Cooke)
FLESH  thin^ (Cooke)
UNDERSIDE  white when fresh, cream or buff when dried; more or less bald to the eye but minutely scurfy-pruinose under hand-lens^, (Reid)
STEM  normally without stem, but some fruitbodies that are obliquely situated may narrow near base into a stem-like base that curves downward so that the fruitbody is brought into position pointing downward; without any obvious trace of a subiculum^ (Reid)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered in small groups or densely crowded in large colonies, on dead wood^, (Reid), type on rotten wood of Betula, (Cooke)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4.5-5.75 x 4-4.75 um, broadly elliptic to nearly round, with short lateral or oblique apiculus, smooth, colorless, thin-walled^; basidia either 2-spored or 4-spored, up to 30 um long and 8 um wide, clavate, with elongated narrow bases ending at a clamped septum; cystidia and gloeocystidia absent; hyphae of context up to 2 um wide, thin-walled, colorless, bearing clamp connections although these are difficult to demonstrate, in one collection there are crystalline masses in context but there is very little development of oleaginous droplets (unlike. H. candida); toward outer surface some of the hyphae curve away and end as irregularly dichotomously branched hairs, occurring anywhere on exterior except extreme margin, the hairs tapering from unbranched base to ultimate branchlets often less than 1 um wide, branching often limited to one or two dichotomies near the hair tip except at base of fruitbody, forking often unequal and only one of the branches having a second dichotomy, bases of hairs up to 3.5 um wide with very slightly thickened walls, occasional secondary septa in basal region of hairs, in basal part of fruitbody, hairs more freely branched and have slightly thicker walls, (Reid), spores 5.8-8.7 x 5.8-8.7 um, round or nearly round (but note that Reid measured the spores of the type as 4.75-6.2 x 3.75-5 um, round to very broadly elliptic), apiculate, strongly granular, appearing roughened under lower magnifications but smooth under oil; basidia 4-spored, 24 x 7.5 um (but Reid found them to be up to 40 x 8 um in type and 2-spored in the ones he observed in type), 'cup' covered with large dichophyses (dichotomously branched terminal hyphae) 5.8-8.7 um in diameter at base (but Reid measured the bases in type to be 3.5(5) um wide), reaching 60-75 um long, finely branched at tips, context hyphae more or less pseudoparenchymatous (questioned by Reid), 3.5-5 um in diameter, no clamp connections seen; subhymenial hyphae 2.5-3 um in diameter, (Cooke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'downy'
SIMILAR  Henningsomyces candidus is almost bald with dichophytic hairs only in the region near the extreme margin, whereas H. puber has dichophytic hairs except at the extreme margin, (Reid(4)).
SOURCES  Reid(4), Cooke(2), Redhead(5), Ginns(5)
141
FAMILY  Dacrymycetaceae, Order Dacrymycetales, Class Dacrymycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Heterotextus alpinus  (Tracy & Earle) G.W. Martin^  Mycologia 24: 217. 1932;  Guepiniopsis alpina  (Tracy & Earle) Brasf.;  Ditiola shopei  Coker;  Heterotextus monticolus  (Tracy & Earle) Lloyd
ENGLISH NAME(S)  golden jelly cone, jelly cup
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly category. Heterotextus alpinus has gelatinous, orange to yellow, top-shaped to cup-shaped fruitbodies that are common on conifer wood in spring. It is characterized within the genus by tardily 3-septate spores and long-cylindric conidia.^ | The online Species Fungorum, accessed December 9, 2013, gave the current name as Guepiniopsis alpina (Tracy & Earle) Brasf. It is not edible (Phillips). It is abundant during spring snow-melt, (Lincoff). RANGE ^Heterotextus alpinus is found in BC, WA, OR, ID, ON, AR, AZ, CA, CO, MT, NM, UT, and WY, (Ginns), Argentina and Chile, (Lowy), and the United Kingdom (Reid), and is reported from Argentina and Japan, (McNabb).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-1cm in width and about the same in depth, cup-shaped, becoming expanded; "bright orange to pallid amber when moist, deep orange red when dry"; upper spore-bearing surface smooth or nearly so, more or less grooved-ribbed^, (Martin), up to 1cm high, with stem and cap, cap cup-shaped, 0.6-1cm in diameter; bright orange to pallid amber when fresh, drying dark orange-red, (McNabb), 0.3-2.5cm, top-shaped to cone-shaped or cup-shaped; yellow to orange; smooth, (Arora)
FLESH  consistency of fruiting body gelatinous^ (McNabb), consistency flabby to gelatinous, (Arora)
UNDERSIDE  more or less grooved-ribbed, the exterior of the expanded portion more or less tuberculate (with bumps)^, (Martin), grooved-ribbed, roughened, and somewhat tuberculate [with bumps], (McNabb)
STEM  central and short^ (McNabb), small, narrowed point of attachment, (Arora)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on coniferous wood^ (McNabb), scattered to gregarious "on conifer logs, stumps, branches, twigs, etc.; fruiting in the spring (usually as or just after the snow melts)", rarely in summer or fall, (Arora)
SPORE DEPOSIT  yellowish
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-17.5 x 5-6 um, allantoid (curved sausage-shaped), at first simple, becoming 3-4-septate^; conidia elongate, up to 4.5 x 1.5 um; basidia 40-50 um long before branching and 4-5 um wide; "cortex composed of a palisade layer of vesicular hairs, mostly 40-70 um in length and 15-20 um thick, varying from broadly pyriform to nearly cylindrical, with a narrow lumen and thick, gelatinized walls, rough exteriorly, often elongated at the apex into an obtuse beak; interior of the basidiocarp composed of loosely interwoven, extremely gelatinous hyphae, with numerous well-defined clamp-connections", (Martin), spores 14.5-16.5(18) x 4.5-5.5 um, "cylindrical to slightly curved-cylindrical, thin-walled with thin septa, tinted, apiculate", becoming tardily 3-septate at maturity, germination by colorless cylindric conidia, to 4.5 x 1.5 um; probasidia 35-53(65) x 4-5.5 um, cylindric-subclavate with basal clamp connections, becoming bifurcate; hymenium confined to interior of cup, consisting of basidia; internal hyphae "thin-walled, smooth or roughened, clamp connections present"; cortex and stem "covered by a palisade of vesicular cells with thick, gelatinous walls and reduced lumina, varying in shape from broadly obpyriform to almost cylindrical, externally roughened basally, typically elongated apically into a smooth, obtuse beak, 35-75-(95) x 12-25 um", (McNabb), spore deposit yellowish (Phillips), spores borne on concave surface of cone, (Arora)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'alpine'
SIMILAR  Heterotextus luteus is smaller and has 5-7(9)-septate spores, (McNabb). Dacrymyces and Tremella have a different shape. Dacrymyces chrysocomus has a yellow cup-shaped fruitbody, larger spores, and a preference for hardwoods, (Arora). Ditiola peziziformis is velvety on the undersurface (McKnight). Cup fungi are not gelatinous, (Arora). Cup fungi are brittle, and very different microscopically, (Lincoff). 
SOURCES  Martin, G.W.(1) (as Guepiniopsis alpina), McNabb(5), Arora(1) (as Guepiniopsis alpina), Phillips(1)* (as Guepiniopsis alpina), Lincoff(2)* (as Guepiniopsis alpina), McKnight(1)* (as Guepiniopsis alpina), Lowy(2) (as Guepiniopsis alpina), Reid(1) (as Guepiniopsis alpina), Ginns(5), Marrone(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
142
FAMILY  Dacrymycetaceae, Order Dacrymycetales, Class Dacrymycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Heterotextus luteus  (Bres.) McNabb^  New Zealand Journal of Botany 3: 221. 1965;  Heterotextus occidentalis  (Lloyd) Lloyd
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly category. Heterotextus luteus has yellow gelatinous fruitbodies with a short stout stem and a shallow cup or disc roughened on the underside, growing on conifer wood. It is characterized within the genus by smooth-walled cortical cells and large allantoid typically 7-septate spores.^ RANGE ^It is found in BC, WA, AK, and New Zealand, (McNabb).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.8cm high, with cap and stem, cap 0.4-1cm in diameter, shallow cup-shaped or flattened disc-shaped, often collapses on substrate when old; yellow to pallid yellow or lemon when fresh, drying pallid yellow or orange-yellow
FLESH  consistency of fruiting body gelatinous
UNDERSIDE  externally roughened
STEM  short and stout
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on conifer wood
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (16)17.5-22(24) x 4.5-5.5(6) um, "strongly curved-cylindrical to allantoid, thin-walled with thin septa, tinted, apiculate", becoming 5-7(9)-septate at maturity^, germination by colorless, elliptic to short-cylindric conidia or by germ tubes; probasidia 42-60(70) x 3.5-4.5 um, cylindric-subclavate, with basal clamp connections, becoming bifurcate; hymenium "confined to interior of cup or superior surface of disc, composed of basidia and occasionally simple, cylindrical dikaryophyses"; internal hyphae "thin-walled, smooth or roughened, clamp connections present"; cortex and stem "covered by a palisade of vesicular cells with thick, gelatinous walls and reduced lumina, varying in shape from ovate to obpyriform, often elongated apically into a smooth, obtuse beak, basally smooth, to 60 x 20 um"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'yellow'
SIMILAR  Heterotextus alpinus is larger, more common, and has 3-septate spores, (McNabb). 
SOURCES  McNabb(5)
143
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Humaria hemisphaerica  (F.H. Wigg. ex Fr.) Fuckel^  Jahrb. Nass. Vereins Naturkunde 23-24: 322. 1870
ENGLISH NAME(S)  hairy fairy cup, brown-haired white cup, glazed cup
NOTES  Features include a whitish, stemless cup with a brown exterior and stiff pointed dark brown hairs covering the exterior and margin, growth on humus or rotten wood, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^It is found in BC, WA, ID, and also AB, AK, CA, (Larsen). It is widely distributed throughout many parts of North America (Phillips), and also in Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach), and the United Kingdom (Dennis).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-3cm broad, at first nearly spherical, opening to cup-shape; white or whitish to grayish; smooth, margin fringed with brown hairs^, (Arora), 1-3cm wide, saucer-shaped (illustrated as low-brimmed cup with incurved margin), gray-whitish, sometimes with bluish glint, margin brown, covered with pointed dark brown hairs, (Breitenbach), up to 3cm wide, permanently cup-shaped; white or whitish, (Dennis), 1-3cm wide, 0.5-1.5cm high; off white to grayish, (Lincoff(2))
FLESH  thin^, (Arora), thin, wax-like, (Lincoff(1)), whitish to grayish (Trudell)
UNDERSIDE  densely covered with stiff brown hairs^, (Arora), brown and covered with pointed dark brown hairs, (Breitenbach), covered with stiff dark brown hairs (Dennis)
STEM  none or only as abruptly narrowed base^, (Arora), none, (Breitenbach, Dennis)
ODOR  none^ (Lincoff(1))
TASTE  none^ (Lincoff(1))
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, scattered, or in groups on ground or occasionally rotten wood, under both hardwoods and conifers, summer and fall^, (Arora), usually gregariously, sometimes singly, on damp ground and very rotten wet wood, July to October, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), "on soil in woods or, occasionally, on very rotten wood in wet places, July to October," (Dennis for UK)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 22.5-27 x 10-13 um, broadly elliptic, with coarse warts, colorless, with 2 drops^; asci 8-spored, 230-270 x 19-23 um, inamyloid, uniseriate; paraphyses with clavate thickenings 7-8 um wide on the tips; hairs 200-525 x 14-21 um, (on margin up to 1000 um long), tapering evenly to point, thick-walled, multiseptate, dark brown, smooth, (Breitenbach), spores 20-24 x 10-12 um, broadly elliptic, coarsely warted, with two conspicuous oil droplets; asci 350 x 20 um; paraphyses clavate, 7-8 um wide at tips; hairs 500 um long and 20 um thick at base, tapering evenly to point, marginal hairs may be 1 mm long, (Dennis), spores with two or sometimes three droplets, (Arora), spores 20-27 x 10-15 um, elliptic, "covered with small irregular warts", with 2 large oil droplets; hairs pointed, thick-walled, and partitioned by cross-walls, (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'hemispheric'
SIMILAR  Trichophaea species usually have smooth spores with one to several droplets (Breitenbach). Trichophaea species are usually smaller (Trudell). Chaetothiersia vernalis has smooth spores without droplets.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Arora(1)*, Phillips(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Lincoff(1)*, Trudell(4)*, Seaver(1) (as Patella albida), Larsen(1), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Courtecuisse(1)*, Buczacki(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
144
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hyalopeziza ciliata  Fuckel^  Jb. nassau. Ver. Naturk. 23-24: 298 (1870) [1869]
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute whitish cup that is hairy on exterior, growth on leaves, and microscopic characters including long strigose hairs with thick walls and thin septa.^ RANGE ^It was reported from WA by Kanouse. It is also found in Europe, including Denmark and Finland, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 0.01-0.025cmm cup-shaped, white^, (Hansen), fruitbody up to 0.06cm across, "pinkish buff" (probably Ridgway color), (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white; hairy^, (Hansen)
STEM  sessile to substipitate^, (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on leaves^ (Hansen), on Delphinium sp. (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 3.5-5.5 x 1-2 um, elliptic^; asci 8-spored, 23-40 x 3.5-5 um; paraphyses 1-2 um wide, not exceeding asci; hairs 125-170 x 2-5 um, cylindric to narrowly conic with acute tip, walls thick and glassy, unchanged in 5% KOH, (Hansen), hairs long, strigose, with thick walls and thin septa, (Kanouse), spores 3.5-5 x 1-1.5 um; asci 8-spored, 23-38 x 3.5-5 um, (Raschle)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6), Raschle(1) (in German)
145
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hyaloscypha diabolica  Huhtinen^  Karstenia 29(2): 124. 1989 (1990)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) minute, cylindric to cup-shaped fruitbodies that are straw-colored to orange-brown when dry, modified by white hair cover, 2) margin with dense hairs, 3) short stem, 4) gregarious to confluent growth on coniferous wood, and 5) microscopic characters including hooked hairs that often have a solid tip or in Melzer's reagent a clear globule, lack septa, and may have deforming warts.^ RANGE ^Hyaloscypha diabolica is known only from two areas in OR (Huhtinen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.02cm across when dry, cylindric to cup-shaped when young, cup-shaped when mature; margin fleshy and incurved when dry, obscuring most of the spore-bearing upper surface, hair cover dense at margin
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  straw-color to orange-brown when dry, modified by hair cover; hair cover dense to sparse, snow-white
STEM  0.005-0.008cm x 0.003-0.005cm, more rarely without a stem on a gradually tapering base
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to confluent, on bulky coniferous wood (in one case spruce), March and August
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5.3-7.2 x 1.8-2.3(2.7) um, "elliptic to oblong-elliptic to subfusoid, aseptate", wall colorless and not seen to become brownish when old, droplets prominent^; asci 8-spored, 29-48 x 4.3-5.5 um, cylindric to cylindric-clavate, arising from simple septa, with slightly conic apex, apical pore blue in iodine; paraphyses cylindric, unpigmented, first dichotomous branches occurring at the level of the lowermost third, terminal cells 13-37 x 1.2-1.6 um; ectal excipulum of textura prismatica, cells of middle flanks prismatic to rounded or somewhat elongated, 12-24 x 4-10 um, becoming smaller toward margin; hairs 29-50 x 2.8-5.0 um, narrowly conic to slightly lageniform, uncinate to bent, rarely straight, aseptate, tip tapering to 1-2 um, fairly often tip solidified, tip often showing apical globule in Melzer's reagent, wall thin, not locally thick except at tip, colorless, smooth, more rarely prominently warted
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Huhtinen(2)
146
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hyaloscypha fuckelii  Nannf. var. alniseda  (Velen.) Huhtinen^  Karstenia 29: 134. 1989 (1990);  Hyaloscypha alniseda  Velen.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, pale watery gray cups growing on hardwood, absent stem, and microscopic characters including asci that arise from simple septa.^ | Var. fuckelii differs mainly in that the asci of that variety arise from a basal crozier. Collections were examined by Huhtinen from Yukon Territory and eastern North America and Eurasia but not the Pacific Northwest. RANGE ^Collections of H. fuckelii var. alniseda were examined from ID, WA, and also PQ, NT, NY, VT, Czech Republic, Finland, France, Germany, Norway, Slovakia, Sweden, United Kingdom, and Kirghizstan, (Huhtinen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.01-0.03cm across, cup-shaped, margin fringed^, (Kanouse), fruitbody "ranging from watery grey to K71 to Cream to K75 and K77 when dry within the same population, rarely clearly reddish brown (L25, P15)", (Huhtinen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale watery-gray^ (Kanouse)
STEM  without a stem^ (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on hardwood, rarely on coniferous wood, sometimes on pyrenomycete, once on sacking, once on dead grass^, (Huhtinen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-7 x 2 um, straight to slightly bent, colorless, one-celled^; asci 30-40 x 5 um; paraphyses filiform [thread-like]; "margin fringed with a single row of one-celled hairs which are bulbous at the origins", (Kanouse), spores 6.1-10.0(12.0) x 2.0-2.9(3.2) um fresh in water, elliptic to oblong-elliptic, very rarely one-septate; asci 8-spored, 26-54(61) x 5.1-7.7(7.8) um fresh in water, arising from simple septa; ectal excipulum "of textura prismatica, cells on middle flanks regularly prismatic, ranging between populations from 8-12 x 3.8-5.0 um to 13-17 x 3.8-7.0 um"; hairs 30-60(90) x 2-6(8), rarely 20-30 x 2-4 um, narrowly conic to conic to lageniform, "aseptate to occasionally basally or centrally one-septate", about 8% of populations with fairly many multiseptate hairs in a fruitbody, septum thin, wall thin, rarely prominently thickened at the constriction, tip tapering to 0.8-1.2 um, typically with minutely thickened apical wall, (Huhtinen)
NAME ORIGIN  probably after K.W.G.L. Fuckel, 1821-76
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Hyaloscypha vitreola.
SOURCES  Huhtinen(2), Kanouse(6) (as Hyaloscypha alniseda), Hansen, L.(1) 
147
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hyaloscypha vitreola  (P. Karst.) Boud.^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 1: 118. 1885
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, cup-shaped fruitbodies that are white, brownish, yellowish or grayish, with sparse hairs concentrated at the margin, stem usually absent but rarely short, gregarious to confluent growth on rotten hardwood, and microscopic characters including relatively large spores, large asci showing croziers, and smooth narrow hairs.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from WA, NY, Czech Republic, Finland, Germany, Lithuania, Norway, Russia, Sweden, Ukraine, and the United Kingdom, (Huhtinen). There is a BC collection by O. Ceska at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.06cm across when fresh, typically 0.02-0.03(0.05)cm across when dry, cyathiform when young, cup-shaped when mature; disc shallow to flat-convex when fresh, bordered by thin zone of marginal hairs that rise only slightly above the spore-bearing upper surface, margin fleshy and incurved when dry, obscuring much of spore-bearing surface
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pure white, brownish, yellowish or grayish when fresh, very old fruitbodies yellowish brown, dry fruitbodies light yellowish or straw-colored to more orange brown, rarely reddish brown; hair cover sparse (concentrated in margin), white
STEM  narrowly to broadly sessile [without stem] or with a gradually tapering base, rarely with a 0.002-0.003cm long stout stem; prominent anchoring hyphae usually lacking
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to confluent, on hardwood, especially very soft water-soaked inner wood already degraded by other organisms, March to November, peaking in summer
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8.5-15.0(20) x 2.9-3.7(4.2) um fresh in water, oblong-elliptic to bean-shaped, "with rounded to slightly tapered apex, frequently one-septate after being discharged, more rarely while still inside the asci", septum thin, central, wall colorless but in old discharged spores brownish, droplets large and light when fresh in water, separate to coalescent in dry material^; asci 8-spored, 40-75(84) x 7.3-10.5(12.8) um when fresh in water, cylindric-clavate with slightly conic apex, arising from croziers, apical pore blue in iodine; paraphyses cylindric or slightly widened at tip, "unpigmented, first dichotomous branches occurring at the level of lowermost 1/3", terminal cells 17-58 x (1.3)1.5-2.5(2.8) um; ectal excipulum of textura prismatica, cells on middle flanks regularly prismatic, ranging between populations from 8-13 x 3-6 to 14-20 x 5-9 um, becoming narrower toward margin; hairs 30-60(85) x 2-3(6) um, narrowly conic to almost filiform, "straight to bent, of uneven width and mostly aseptate", apex tapering to 0.8 um or rarely swollen, very rarely partly solidified, without apical globule in Melzer's reagent, wall thin, or up to 0.4 um thick in upper half, seldom locally thickened and even then without massive thickenings, colorless, smooth, very rarely bearing a few tiny colorless apical warts
NAME ORIGIN  means 'glassy'
SIMILAR  Hyaloscypha fuckelii var. alniseda does not have croziers, and hairs often have thickened tips.
SOURCES  Huhtinen(2)
148
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hymenoscyphus epiphyllus  (Pers..) Rehm^  apud Kauffman in Papers Michigan Acad. Science, Arts, Letters 9: 77. 1929;  Helotium epiphyllum  Fr.;  Phaeohelotium epiphyllum (Pers.) Hengstm., Mycotaxon 107: 272. 2009 
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, cup-shaped to disc-shaped fruitbody that is bright yellow to orange throughout, short stem when present, growth on fallen leaves or needles, and microscopic characters.^ | Hengstmengel(1) made a case that this species should be called Phaeohelotium epiphyllum. The online Species Fungorum and MycoBank, both accessed September 12, 2022, listed the current name as Hymenoscyphus epiphyllus. RANGE ^Hymenoscyphus epiphyllus was found in WA, (Kanouse), and probably occurs throughout the United States and Canada, as well as in Europe, (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.4cm, spore-bearing surface concave to flat or sometimes repand [edge turned back], becoming yellow to orange or occasionally dull red^, (Seaver), up to 0.2cm, fruitbody bright yellow to orange throughout, cup-shaped, (Dennis), "amber yellow" when fresh (probably Ridgway color), (Kanouse), 0.1-0.4cm, cup-shaped to disc-shaped, (Hansen)
FLESH  fruitbody fleshy to waxy^ (Seaver) 
UNDERSIDE  bright yellow or dull orange when fresh, the color not changing much on drying^, (Seaver), bright yellow to orange (Dennis), bright yellow to orange (Hansen)
STEM  exceedingly short when present^, (Seaver), "subsessile, on a cylindrical smooth base", (Dennis), no stroma present (Kanouse), subsessile (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered, or in groups of 2 to 4 on leaves of various hardwood or more rarely coniferous trees, also on forest debris^, (Seaver), scattered on fallen leaves (Dennis), on leaves of Alnus (alder), arising in most cases from the veins of the leaves, (Kanouse), on fallen leaves or needles (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-20 x 4-5 um, fusoid, "more or less unsymmetrical or slightly curved, simple", granular, often with 2 or 3 definite oil droplets, uniseriate in upper part, biseriate in lower part^; asci 9-spored, reaching a length of 90-130 um long and a width of 9-12 um, clavate; paraphyses straight, scarcely thickened in upper part, reaching a width of 2-3 um, (Seaver), spores 15-18 x 3.5-5 um, oblong-fusoid [oblong - spindle-shaped], often pointed in lower part, sometimes appearing one-septate, often becoming biseriate; asci 8-spored, up to 120 x 12 um, cylindric-clavate, pore becomes blue in iodine; paraphyses cylindric, 2-3 um wide, sometimes branched, (Dennis), spores 12-18 x 3.5-5 um, fusoid, 0-1-septate; asci 90-120 x 8-12 um, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'on leaf'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(6) (as Helotium epiphyllum), Dennis(1), Seaver(2) (as Helotium epiphyllum), Hansen, L.(1), Hengstmengel(1)
149
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hymenoscyphus fastidiosus  (Peck) Arendh.^  Morphologisch-taxonomische Untersuchungen an blattbewohnenden Ascomyceten aus der Ordnung der Helotiales (Hamburg): 88. 1979;  Helotium fastidiosum  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute, yellowish cup with a flat or slightly concave spore-bearing surface; a smooth pale yellow exterior; a slender stem about equal in length to the diameter of the fruit-body, and brownish or yellow with a brownish base; growth on fallen alder leaves in wet places; and microscopic characters including long somewhat club-shaped spores.^ RANGE ^Hymenoscyphus fastidiosus is found from NY to PQ and OR (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching about 0.1cm across, rarely larger; spore-bearing surface flat or slightly concave, yellow^, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale yellow, smooth^ (Seaver)
STEM  about equal in length to the diameter of the fruitbody, slender; brownish, or yellow with a brownish base^, (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on petioles and midribs of fallen leaves of Alnus (alder) in wet places, also reported on catkins^, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores about 32 x 4-4.5 um, elongate, subclavate, with multiple droplets, crowded, or biseriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 80-100 um and a width of 9-12 um, narrow-clavate; paraphyses slender, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Helotium fastidiosum)
150
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hymenoscyphus rufescens  (Kanouse) T. Schumach.^  Mycotaxon 38: 234. 1990;  Ciboriella rufescens  (Kanouse) Seaver;  Ciboria rufescens  Kanouse
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small orange fruitbody that dries rich red, a short stem, and growth on decaying leaves of hardwoods. The bright red coloring matter is soluble in water (exuded when fruitbody is crushed in water). Kanouse said it is a common species in the western woods on old leaves of hardwoods.^ RANGE ^Hymenoscyphus rufescens is found in WA and OR (Kanouse).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 0.2-0.5cm across, 0.1-0.2cm high; "apricot orange" when fresh, "dragon's blood red" when dry, exuding a red juice when crushed in water^, (Kanouse), apricot orange to brick red, (Schumacher re-examination of type)
FLESH  firm-fleshy^, (Kanouse), cartilaginous, (Schumacher re-examination of type)
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  short, slender, smooth, colored as the upper surface^, (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on decaying leaves; including Alnus, Acer^, (Kanouse), arising from leaf laminas of withered Alnus leaves, (Schumacher re-examination of type)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-8 x 3.5 um, fusoid, colorless, 1-celled, biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 35-60 x 7-8 um, clavate, ascus pore J+; paraphyses filiform; excipulum pseudoparenchymatic, cells thick-walled, hypothecium pseudoprosenchymatic, (Kanouse), outermost excipulum "a short-celled textura prismatica, approaching a textura angularis toward the flanks of the receptacle", "no gelatinous matrix present in ectal excipulum", fruitbodies arising from non-stromatized areas of leaves, leaves apparently attacked by another stromatic fungus, (Schumacher re-examination of type)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'turning red'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(1) (as Ciboria rufescens), Seaver(2) (as Ciboriella rufescens), Schumacher(1)
151
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hymenoscyphus salicellus  (Fr.) Dennis^  Persoonia 3(1): 73. 1964;  Helotium salicellum  Fr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute brownish yellow, smooth cup with a yellowish interior, a short stem, scattered growth on bark of fallen willow branches, and microscopic characters.^ | Fuckel regards this species as a variety of Helotium virgultorum (here considered as Hymenoscyphus virgultorum). RANGE ^Hymenoscyphus salicellus is found in OR as well as Europe, (Seaver). There are two collections from BC at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.2cm across, at first spherical, then expanding and becoming shallow cup-shaped; spore-bearing surface slightly concave or nearly flat, yellowish^, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  brownish yellow; smooth^, (Seaver)
STEM  short, scarcely exceeding 0.1cm long and 0.03cm wide^, (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered, emerging through bark of fallen branches of Salix (willow)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 25-30 x 5-7 um, "fusoid, with the ends acute, straight or curved, usually containing one or two oil-drops, becoming spuriously 1-3-septate"^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 75-100 um and a width of 12-25 um, clavate; paraphyses filiform, reaching a width of 2 um, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to its host Salix (willow)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Helotium salicellum)
152
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hymenoscyphus scutula  W. Phillips^  Brit. Discom. (London): 137. 1887 [as scutulus];  Helotium scutula  (Pers.) P. Karst.;  Ciboria ciliatospora  Fuckel;  Calycella scutula  Quel.;  Helotium ciliatosporum  Boud.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute, pale yellow to white, smooth cup, a slender stem, growth on herbaceous stems, and microscopic characters that may include a bristle on each end of the spore.^ RANGE ^Hymenoscyphus scutula is found from NY to OR, and MO, and probably throughout North America (as well as in Europe), (Seaver). It has also been found in WA (Kanouse, var. grossulariae, forma rubi, and var. caudatum which may correspond to a similar species Hymenoscyphus caudatum). There is a collection from BC determined by R. Bandoni at the University of British Columbia (as Helotium), and 2 other collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.1-0.2cm across, shallow cup-shaped, becoming nearly flat; spore-bearing upper surface slightly concave, pale yellow, similar in color to exterior of cup^, (Seaver), 0.1-0.4cm, saucer-shaped to funnel-shaped, also plate-shaped; spore-bearing surface yellow-ocher to cream, smooth; margin with a sharp edge and often rather whitish, (Breitenbach), up to 0.4cm, "disc flat with thin low margin, cream to yellowish, drying ochraceous", (Dennis), fruitbody white when fresh, (Kanouse for var. caudatum), fruitbody avellaneous when fresh (Kanouse for var. grossulariae)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale yellow^ (Seaver), somewhat lighter in color than spore-bearing surface; sometimes with faint longitudinal fibers, (Breitenbach), whitish, appearing fibrous under hand-lens and often longitudinally streaked with darker bands, (Dennis), white, but turns pale yellow when dried except for the rolled edge of cup which becomes dark tan, (Kanouse for var. caudatum), avellaneous, (Kanouse for var. grossulariae)
STEM  with stem variable in length, often reaching 0.5cm, usually about 0.03cm wide, or occasionally almost sessile [without stem]; often springing from a dark-colored subiculum^, (Seaver), 0.1-0.7cm long, slender, cylindric; cream, (Breitenbach), slender, cylindric, (Dennis), rather stout and firm and thickened in the middle, (Kanouse for var. caudatum)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  thickly gregarious, on herbaceous stems of various kinds^, (Seaver), occasionally single but usually gregarious and covering entire stems; on rotting stems of various herbs, especially Compositae, in damp places under the plants, (Breitenbach), scattered on dead herbaceous stems, (Dennis), on leaves of Salix (willow), (Kanouse for var. caudatum), on herbaceous stems (Kanouse for var. grossulariae), on Rubus stems (Kanouse for forma rubi)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-28 x 3-4 um, "fusoid, or clavate, slightly curved, often spuriously 1-3-septate", irregularly biseriate, occasionally with a cilium at one or both ends^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 90-100 um and a width of 8-10 um, clavate; paraphyses filiform, reaching a diameter of 7 um, (Seaver), 19-20 x 3.2-4 um, fusiform, smooth, colorless, with 2 or several droplets, normally with colorless bristle on each end, sometimes one-septate, spores biseriate in asci; asci 8-spored, 90-95 x 8 um, amyloid; paraphyses "slender, gradually thickened slightly toward the tips to 3 um wide, septate", (Breitenbach), spores 18-27 x 3.5-5 um, somewhat cylindric, pointed in lower part and asymmetrically rounded or slightly beaked in upper part, with a fine colorless bristle at lower end and usually a shorter one at upper end, containing 2 oil droplets, biseriate, sometimes becoming septate; asci 8-spored, 110 x 11 um, cylindric-clavate, somewhat conic at tip with pore made blue by iodine; paraphyses slender, widened upwards to about 3 um, (Dennis), spores 18-20 x 4-6 um, one-celled in contrast to type variety which is two-celled, ascus turns weakly blue in iodine, (Kanouse for var. caudatum), spores 14-18 x 3.5-4 um, smaller than in typical material, (Kanouse for var. grossulariae), spores (12)14-18 x 3-4 um, slightly curved and almost pointed at one end, one-celled, (Kanouse for forma rubi)
NAME ORIGIN  from 'scutula' Latin for 'small plate or dish'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Helotium scutula), Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Kanouse(6) (as Helotium scutula)
153
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Hymenoscyphus virgultorum  (Vahl) W. Phillips^  Man. Brit. Discom. (London): 134. 1887 [as Hymenoscypha];  Phialea virgultorum  Sacc.;  Helotium virgultorum  (Vahl) Fr.;  Hymenoscyphus calyculus (Sowerby) W. Phillips (proposed name used for this taxon by some authors)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, cup-shaped to convex fruitbodies that are whitish to pale yellowish, with a bright yellow interior, a stem that is two to three times as long as the cup is wide, gregarious growth on partly buried sticks and roots, and microscopic characters.^ | Some authors including Dennis(1) give Hymenoscyphus calyculus (Sowerby ex Fr.) W. Phillips as the current name for this species. He says that Helotium virgultorum is an ill-defined name often used for the species. Hansen, L.(1) gives H. calyculus (Sowerby: Fr.) W. Phillips ss. auct. as a synonym for Hymenoscyphus virgultorum (Weber) W. Phillips. The online Species Fungorum, accessed March 1, 2018 and September 12, 2022, listed the current name as Hymenoscyphus calyculus, but MycoBank, accessed on the same dates, listed the current name as Hymenoscyphus virgultorum. RANGE ^Hymenoscyphus virgultorum is found from ON to CO, WA, CA, and Europe, (Seaver), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen). There are two collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre (as Hymenoscyphus calyculus but determined as Hymenoscyphus virgultorum by J. Groves). There are three collections from BC and one from OR at the University of British Columbia, all determined by O. Ceska.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.1-0.3cm across, "at first closed, expanding and becoming shallow cup-shaped to patellate, or occasionally even convex"; spore-bearing upper surface usually concave, bright yellow^, (Seaver), 0.05-0.5cm across, cup-shaped, spore-bearing surface golden-yellow, (Hansen), about 0.2cm across, cup-shaped with concave disc, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  whitish to pale yellowish^, (Seaver), paler than spore-bearing surface (Hansen)
STEM  two to three times as long as the diameter of the cup, cylindric; whitish or yellowish, (Seaver), 0.05-0.5cm long, pubescent toward base, (Hansen)^, cylindric, may be downy toward base, (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on partially buried sticks and roots, (Seaver), on hardwood (Hansen), scattered or in small clusters on dead wood and fallen twigs, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-20 x 4-5 um, fusoid or subclavate [spindle-shaped or nearly club-shaped], partially biseriate, usually containing two oil droplets with several smaller ones, occasionally spuriously septate^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 100-120 um and a width of 9-10 um, clavate; paraphyses filiform, slightly enlarged in upper part, (Seaver), spores 13-19 x 4-5 um, elliptic to inequilateral, aseptate; asci 120-140 x 8-11 um, (Hansen), spores 15-22 x 3-4.5 um, cylindric, rounded in upper part and tapering in lower part, irregularly biseriate, sometimes appearing one-septate; asci 8-spored, up to 125 x 10 um, cylindric-clavate, pore turns blue in iodine; paraphyses cylindric, up to 3 um thick, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Helotium virgultorum (Vahl) Fr.), Hansen, L.(1) (as Hymenoscyphus virgultorum (Weber) W. Phillips), Dennis(1) (as Hymenoscyphus calyculus (Sowerby ex Fr.) Phillips)
154
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Iodophanus carneus  (Pers.) Korf^  Am. J. Bot. 54: 19. 1967;  == Ascobolus carneus  Pers.;  == Ascophanus carneus  (Pers. per Pers.) Boud.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, pinkish to salmon, lens-shaped fruitbodies growing stemless on dung, decaying vegetable matter, or soil, a delicate fringe on the margin, a blue reaction of the whole spore-bearing upper surface in iodine, and microscopic characters including very finely punctate spores that are 1-2-seriate and asci with walls that turn blue in iodine.^ RANGE ^Iodophanus carneus is found at least in WA, ID, CA, and CO, (Larsen), CO, FL, ND, NY, Bermuda, Puerto Rico, and Europe, (Seaver), the United Kingdom (Dennis), and Switzerland (Breitenbach). There is a collection from BC by R. Bandoni at the University of British Columbia (as Ascophanus).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.15cm across, knob-like when young, then turbinate [top-shaped], spore-bearing surface convex to cushion-like, pale pink to salmon-colored, brownish when old, rough; margin uneven^, (Breitenbach), fruitbody up to 0.15cm across, lens-shaped, pink, salmon, or flesh-color; disc convex, papillate with protruding ascus tips, (Dennis), usually not exceeding 0.1cm across, or rarely as large as 0.2cm; spore-bearing surface at first concave, becoming convex, similar in color to underside but a little brighter, roughened by protruding asci; margin with delicate fringe-like border, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  the same color as upper surface^ (Breitenbach), flesh-colored, the color becoming brighter when dried, (Seaver)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on animal dung, according to literature also on rotting plant debris and cloth, etc.; throughout the year^, (Breitenbach), on dung, rotting vegetable matter, including textiles and rope, and on soil, throughout the year, (Dennis), gregarious or occasionally crowded in clusters of variable size, on dung of various kinds, (Seaver), in burn areas or on dung, wet rags, etc. (Beug)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18.5-20 x 11-12 um, elliptic, dotted with fine warts (oil immersion needed to see with certainty), colorless, without droplets, biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 190-210 x 25-28 um, turning blue in iodine: when treated with iodine, the whole spore-bearing surface turns blue within 10-30 minutes; paraphyses "slender, septate, tips thickened to 10 um", (Breitenbach), spores 18-22(30) x 10-12(18) um, elliptic, very finely punctate, 1-2-seriate; asci 8-spored, up to 225 x 30 um, broadly clavate; paraphyses "stout, simple or forked, septate, up to 8 um thick at the tip", (Dennis), spores 17-20 x 11-12 um, or rarely 24-26 x 14-16 um, elliptic, at first smooth, becoming very minutely warty, colorless, 2-seriate in upper part or becoming irregularly crowded; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 200-300 um and a width of 25-40 um, rather broad-clavate, narrowing in lower part into stem-like base; paraphyses septate, stout, enlarged at tips, where they reach width of 7-8 um, densely filled with orange granules; excipulum gives rise in upper part "to a palisade of mycelium the loose ends of which form a very delicate fringe-like border, the ends of the peridial mycelium reaching a diameter of 12-15 um", (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of flesh, flesh-colored'
SIMILAR  Iodophanus testaceus (Moug. in Fr.) Korf is very similar if not identical, and has been found at least WA, OR, (Larsen), CT, IA, IN, LA, MA, ND, NJ, Europe, (Seaver), Hansen includes this species in Iodophanus carneus (Pers.: Fr.) Korf, Dennis says Ascophanus testaceus (Moug. ex Fr.) Phillips is probably a synonym of I. carneus (Pers.) Korf, and Seaver says further study is needed to say whether they are distinct. . See also SIMILAR section of Pyronema domesticum and Pyronema omphalodes.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Seaver(1) (as Ascophanus carneus), Larsen(1), Beug(3)
155
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ionomidotis irregularis  (Schwein.) E.J. Durand^  Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts & Sci. 59: 9. 1923;  Midotis irregularis  Cooke, Sacc.;  Cordierites irregularis  Cooke;  Otidea doratophora  Sacc.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a dark brown cup that opens and becomes elongated on one side and irregularly lobed or lacerated, the exterior dark chestnut-brown and scurfy, growth in cespitose clusters from a common stem-like base on wood, and microscopic characters.^ | Placement of this genus is uncertain. Dictionary of the Fungi 10th Edition gives it as ?= Wynnella (Helvell.), even though it is apparently inoperculate, and gives the genus Ionomidotis as ?= Ameghiniella fide Zhuang 1988 and Gamundi 1991. The description is from Seaver(2) except where otherwise specified. RANGE ^Ionomidotis irregularis is found from NH to OR, PA, and OH, (Seaver), OR, ON, CT, MI, NY, OH, and Austria, Poland, USSR, (Zhuang)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching width and height of 3cm, often in clusters reaching a diameter of 5-7cm, "at first closed then opening and becoming elongated on one side and irregularly lobed or lacerated"; dark brown, almost black
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  dark chestnut-brown, lighter than spore-bearing surface; scurfy
STEM  fruitbodies occur "singly, or more often in cespitose clusters from a common stemlike base up to 2cm. in length which penetrates the substratum"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  singly, or more often in cespitose clusters from a common stem-like base, on rotten wood and branches lying on the ground
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10 x 3-4 um, colorless or nearly colorless, smooth, containing 2 or 3 oil-drops, 1-seriate, or partially 2-seriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching 50-70 x 4-5 um, cylindric-clavate, the apex truncate-rounded; "paraphyses with a violet tint, each terminated by a lanceolate, 1-3-septate head 3-4 x 18-30 um which project beyond the hymenium and is easily detached"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'irregular'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Zhuang(1)
156
FAMILY  Niaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnella alboviolascens  (Alb. & Schwein.) Fr.^  Summa veg. Scand. (Stockholm) 2: 365. 1849;  Cyphella alboviolascens  (Alb. & Schwein.) P. Karst;  Cyphella pezizoides  Zopf
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) minute basidiomycete fruiting bodies that are grayish on spore-bearing surface, with whitish marginal hairs and exterior, 2) absent stem, 3) growth on woody herbaceous stems, and on bark and branches of trees and shrubs, and 4) microscopic characters including basidia.^ | In the Cooke and Donk description below, the color of fresh specimens is not clearly separated from the color of dried ones. RANGE ^Lachnella alboviolascens is found at least in BC, WA, ID, and also ON, AZ, CA, DE, MA, MD, ME, MO, OH, PA, SC, VA, and WI, (Ginns), and the British Isles, Denmark, France, Germany, South Africa, and New Zealand, (Redhead).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.15cm across, "irregularly and shallowly saucer-like"; spore-bearing surface lining cup gray-white, "smooth, often bearing secondary fruit bodies", "margin white, fringed hairy, inrolled"^, (Buczacki), 0.01-0.015cm x 0.004-0.01cm, margin inrolled, spore-bearing upper surface yellowish or bluish gray to pale violet, (Cooke), "It would seem that the colour of the disk is variable. In most cases it becomes dark at least when drying and in the herbarium the disk is seen as a dark ring shining through the hairy covering in flattened and pressed fruit-bodies. However, more or less luxurious and proliferous fruit-bodies may lack any indication of the purplish colour and the disk may remain pallid, yellowish", (Donk)
FLESH  waxy, soft, fragile; whitish^, (Buczacki)
UNDERSIDE  densely hairy^ (Buczacki), white to gray, pale bluish or lilaceous gray; with surface hairs, (Cooke)
STEM  absent^ (Buczacki)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  bark and branches of trees and shrubs, woody herbaceous stems, litter and duff; associated with a white rot^, (Ginns), in densely tufted groups; on dead wood, twigs and branches of hardwood trees and shrubs, "herbaceous stems and other plant debris, often on gorse and broom"; spring to fall, (Buczacki for British Isles), densely gregarious to scattered on woody herbaceous stems of plants and on the bark and branches of trees and shrubs, (Cooke)
SPORE DEPOSIT  white^ (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12.5-15 x 10-11 um, broadly and irregularly elliptic, sometimes flattened on one side, smooth, inamyloid^; cystidia absent; hyphal system monomitic; outer hairs "white above, brownish toward base, thick walled, narrowly cylindrical, encrusted, dextrinoid", (Buczacki), spores (10)13.5-15(17) x (6.5)9-11 um, elliptic, nearly round, or tear-shaped, usually flattened on one side, sometimes pointed at distal end, smooth, colorless; basidia 33-70 x 10-15 um, 4-spored, sterigmata up to 10 um long; surface hairs 100-300 x 3-10 um, densely and finely granule encrusted, tapered, thick-walled, with a very narrow lumen, (Cooke), spores 13.5-15.25 x 9-12 um, broad-obovoid, adaxially somewhat flattened, with distinct, blunt, eccentric apiculus, contents granular; basidia 2-4-spored, 60-75 x 12-16 um; hairs about 200 x 5-6 um, (Donk)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to white and violet colors
SIMILAR  Donk writes of Lachnella villosa, "The fruit-body is on an average much smaller and more tender than in Lachnella alboviolascens, and closes less perfectly to a globular body. The latter species has a more fleshy disc which almost invariably (at least in not too proliferous fruit-bodies) turns dark. The presence of numerous 'basidioles' [in L. villosa] may be another important difference. Finally, L. villosa prefers herbaceous or only slightly woody substrata, while L. alboviolascens grows almost invariably on woody substrata (though these may be very thin branches).", (Donk(1), with Latin names in italics), L. villosa usually occurs on herbaceous stems and has a whiter spore-bearing surface, slightly smaller spores, and spear-shaped cystidia, (Buczacki), L. villosa has thinner hymenium.
SOURCES  Redhead(21), Buczacki(1)*, Cooke(2), Donk(1), Ginns(5)
157
FAMILY  Niaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnella tiliae  (Peck) Donk^  Lilloa 22: 245. 1951;  Trichopeziza tiliae  (Peck) Sacc.;  Cyphella tiliae  (Peck) M.C. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) minute basidiomycete fruitbody that is white and cup-shaped with hairs on exterior and shorter ones at margin, 2) stem-like base, 3) growth on bark of twigs, branches, and trunks of basswood, and 4) microscopic characters including basidia.^ RANGE ^Lachnella tiliae is found at least in OR, and also MB, ON, PQ, OH, UT, VT, and WI, (Ginns), and MI and NY (Reid).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.1cm across, cup-shaped, with shallow concave disc fully exposed (unlike L. alboviolascens and L. villosa), disc white but when dry creamy yellow, margin with inconspicuous marginal fringe of hairs shorter than those covering the external surface^, (Reid), receptacle 0.02-0.3cm across, 0.02-0.1cm high; spore-bearing upper surface whitish to yellowish, (Cooke)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white; appear minutely villose-tomentose especially under hand-lens^, (Reid), with white surface hairs (Cooke)
STEM  broad tubercular stem-like base^, (Reid), short, arising from a black sclerotic base, (Cooke)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious in colonies that may be small or extend over many square feet, sometimes covering entire trunks, almost confined to branches and trunks of Tilia (basswood), but has been reported on Juglans regia (English Walnut), Acer spp. (maple, but some of these misidentified), Populus tremuloides and Ulmus (elm)^, (Reid), scattered to gregarious on bark of twigs and branches of Tilia spp. and Tilia americana (American Basswood), also reported on Juglans regia, Acer spp., and Populus tremuloides, (Cooke), Tilia spp., Ulmus sp., (Ginns)
SPORE DEPOSIT  white^ (Reid)
MICROSCOPIC  spores from spore print 13-19 x 6.2-7.2 um, "appearing subfalcate in side view and amygdaliform when viewed from above", colorless, thin-walled, apiculus very prominent^; basidia 2-spored or 4-spored, up to 80 um long and 10 um wide, clavate with a basal clamp connection, prominent horn-shaped sterigmata may exceed 10 um long; basidioles present among the basidia, often exceeding the basidia in abundance, variable in size and shape, 25-70 um long (possible more) and 2.5-6.2 um wide, either cylindric, somewhat clavate or more commonly lanceolate, thin-walled to slightly thick-walled; hairs up to 260 um long and 4-5.5 um wide, cylindric, with slightly thickened walls covered by a fine granular encrustation that is soluble in KOH, tip broadly rounded, hair may narrow slightly near the very tip, rarely with transverse septa in apical part, often prolonged at base into a tail that arises from a hypha at a clamped septum; context hyphae monomitic, with clamp connections, 2.5-3 um wide in base, up to 3.5 um wide in sides of cup, (Reid), spores 10-20 x 4-10 um, cylindric, ovate-allantoid to tear-shaped, flattened on one end, smooth, apiculate, colorless; surface hairs white, straight, densely and finely granule-incrusted, 100-200 x 4-8 um; basidia 4-spored, 33-60 x 10-15 um, (Cooke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Tilia' referring to host
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Reid(4), Cooke(2), Ginns(5)
158
FAMILY  Niaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnella villosa  (Pers. ex Schwein. in Fr.) Gillet^  Champignons de France, Discom.: 80. 1881
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) minute basidiomycete fruitbodies that are cup-shaped and white to bluish gray with white surface hairs, the spore-bearing upper surface white to cream color, 2) absent stem, 3) growth on herbaceous litter and twigs of woody plants and hardwoods, and 4) microscopic characters including basidia.^ RANGE ^Lachnella villosa collections were examined from BC (Redhead), OR, CA, SC, VA, Argentina, Chile, Ecuador, Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Portugal, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, China, Sri Lanka, Tunisia, Australia, and the Philippines, (Cooke).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.01-0.1cm wide and high, margin inrolled when dry; spore-bearing upper surface white to cream color^, (Cooke)
FLESH  thin
UNDERSIDE  white to bluish-gray; with white surface hairs^, (Cooke)
STEM  sessile to subsessile^ (Cooke)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to separate on herbaceous litter and twigs of woody plants and hardwoods^ (Cooke)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-12 x 5-9 um, ovate to cylindric, flattened on one side, apiculate, smooth, colorless^; surface hairs colorless, 100-275(500) x 3-8 um, densely, finely granule-incrusted, occasionally ending in a whip-lash, tapering to a point; context hyphae 3-4 um in diameter, clamped; subhymenial hyphae 2-3 um in diameter; basidia 26-50 x 6-10 um, 4-spored, clamped at the base, (Cooke), spores 10-15 x 7-10 um, broad obconic, adaxially faintly flattened, with distinct, blunt, eccentric apiculus; basidia 2-4-spored, 40-60 x 9-11 um; 'basidioles' numerous, "originally subcylindrical with tapering top, then becoming inflated at middle and spindle-shaped, finally like the basidia but with apical nipple"; hairs in KOH about 150-200 x 4.75-6 um, colorless, "with asperulated surface, the full-grown ones with very thick walls and capillary lumen (lumen somewhat widening in the tip), many with deformed portions which are much swollen and very transparent (asperulation has disappeared) and have a thread-like or vanished lumen", (Donk)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'villose' or finely hairy
SIMILAR  Lachnella alboviolascens has larger spores, (Cooke). See Lachnella alboviolascens SIMILAR for macroscopic differences.
SOURCES  Cooke(2), Redhead(21), Donk(1)
159
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnellula agassizii  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Dennis^  Persoonia 2(2): 183. 1962;  Lachnella agassizii  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Seaver;  Dasyscyphus agassizii  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Sacc. [as Dasyscypha]
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small cup with white flexuous [wavy] hairs on the exterior and the margin, a bright orange-yellow upper surface, a short stem, gregarious growth on bark and wood of conifers, and microscopic characters including relatively small spores.^ | This is the most common Lachnellula in the Pacific Northwest (Trudell(4)). Bingham(2) have provided means of separating this species from Lachnellula calyciformis (see SIMILAR), but Seaver(2) says this, "The differences are so slight that it seems to the writer a question whether or not they should be separated." RANGE ^It is found in WA (Kanouse), NF, CO, MT, and PA, (Seaver). There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre and at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
