UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.4cm across but often much smaller, at first nearly spherical, becoming expanded and shallow cup-shaped, or nearly flat; spore bearing surface bright orange-yellow; margin fringed with white hairs^, (Seaver), creamy yellow (Trudell), 0.05-0.55cm across (Bingham(2))
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  with white flexuose hairs^ (Seaver), white or pale yellow (Trudell), "light yellow, but appearing white due to a covering of white hairs which may become detached as the fungus ages", (Haines)
STEM  short-stemmed^ (Seaver), up to 0.25cm long (Bingham(2))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on bark and wood of conifers^ (Seaver), on branches of Abies (fir), Pinus (pine), and Tsuga (hemlock), (Trudell), it is most commonly found on Abies species but also occurs on Pinus and Tsuga, "It has never been known to be associated with cankers of living trees, although it may appear on quite recently killed trees.", (Haines)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 x 2.5-3 um^ (Trudell), spores 6-10 x 3-4 um, narrow-elliptic, colorless, uniseriate or biseriate; asci reaching a length of 60-95 um and a width of 3-4 um, cylindric or subcylindric; paraphyses clavate, reaching a width of 2-5 um at tip; hairs reaching a length of 100 um and a width of 2-3 um, colorless, blunt or attenuated, externally covered with coarse granules, (Seaver), spores 5.0-9.5 x 2.0-4.0 um, elliptic to oval, indistinctly biguttulate; paraphysis 47.5-94.5 x 1.0-3.5 um, tips usually swollen, (Bingham(2)), spores 6-8 x 2.5-3.0 um, various numbers of refractive droplets, commonly 2, uniseriate; asci 55-70 x 4.5-5 um, cylindric with slightly narrowed stalk; paraphyses "filiform or sometimes slightly swollen near the apex", median diameter 2-2.5 um, often branched near base, usually colorless but containing yellow droplets, thin-walled, usually non-septate; hairs 4-5 um wide, up to 150 um long, cylindric with obtuse apices, "conspicuously roughened, moderately thin-walled, multiseptate", septa forming 15-30 um cells, (Haines)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Lachnellula calyciformis has spores 4.0-7.5 x 1.5-3.5 um, and paraphyses with tips that are usually unswollen. Fruitbodies are 0.05-0.20cm across, stems are short, external hairs persistent (lost with age in L. agassizii), and there are 1 or a few fruitbodies from a common base (1-12 fruitbodies from a common base in L. agassizii), (Bingham(2)). According to Desjardin(6), its spores are 5-7 x 2.5-3 um and it grows on the bark of dead conifers including true fir. According to Hansen, L.(1) it grows mostly on Abies but also on Picea and Pinus, spores are 4.5-6.5 x 2.5-3 um and have 2 droplets, asci are inamyloid and paraphyses are filiform and 1.5 um wide. Lachnellula occidentalis and Lachnellula willkommii have larger spores. Lachnellula suecica has round spores. Lachnellula subtilissima has also been identified by O. Ceska from British Columbia. According to Hansen, L.(1), it grows on conifer branches, spores are 6-9 x 2-2.5 um without droplets, asci have an amyloid pore, and paraphyses are filiform. Lachnellula gallica (P. Karst. & Hariot) Dennis has also been identified from BC by O. Ceska. According to Hansen, L.(1), it grows on branches of Abies (true fir), spores are 8-10 x 5-6.5 um, and paraphyses are filiform. 
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Lachnella agassizii), Kanouse(6) (as Dasyscypha agassizii), Trudell(4)* (as Lachnellula agassizii (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Seaver), Desjardin(6) (re Lachnellula calyciformis), Hansen, L.(1), Bingham(1), Bingham(2), Haines(1)
160
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnellula arida  (W. Phillips) Dennis^  Persoonia 2(2): 183. 1962;  Dasyscyphus arida  (W. Phillips) Sacc. [as 'Dasyscypha'];  Lachnella arida  (W. Phillips) Seaver;  Trichoscyphella arida  (W. Phillips) E. Mull. & S. Ahmad
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Lachnellula arida is distinguished by its brown exterior and brown hairs, relatively broad spores, and growth on the wood of Abies (true fir) spp. (Trudell & Ammirati, 2009). Other features include small size, cup-shaped to plate-shaped fruitbody with pale to gold-yellow upper surface, and short stem.^ RANGE ^Lachnellula arida was described originally from CA. The distribution is from at least NF to AB and south to CO and CA, as well as Europe (Seaver). It is included for the Pacific Northwest in Trudell(4), and is found in WA and NM (S. Trudell, pers. comm.). Haines(1) reported it for WA in his Masters of Science thesis.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-0.5(0.7)cm, cup-shaped to plate-shaped, also slightly cushion-like when old; pale to gold-yellow; smooth^, (Breitenbach), reaching 0.4-0.8cm across, at first spherical, then expanded but often irregularly angular, or subhysteriform, especially when dry; spore-bearing surface concave, yellowish [also referred to as "bright yellow"], (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  "outer surface and margin thickly set with brown hairs"^, (Breitenbach), densely covered with brown hairs (Seaver), densely covered with moderately long (up to 0.02cm), dark brown hairs, (Desjardin(6)), almost naked at maturity due to loss of most of the hairs (Haines)
STEM  attached to substrate with short stem^, (Breitenbach), very short-stemmed, or apparently without a stem, (Seaver), up to 0.1cm long and up to 0.05cm wide (Haines)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on fallen dead branches of Larix (larch) still with bark, according to literature also on other conifers^, (Breitenbach), on wood of Abies (fir) species (Trudell), scattered, on bark of conifers (Abies, Larix, Picea), or more rarely on the needles (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-8.5 x 3.5-4.5 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, sometimes with one droplet^; asci 8-spored, 55-60 x 7.5-8 um, uniseriate, iodine negative; paraphyses cylindric, "tips with slight clavate thickenings, sometimes with small outgrowths"; hairs up to 190 x 6-8 um, dark brown, +/- thick-walled, "coarsely encrusted, with distinct septa, tips rounded"; excipulum of textura angularis/globulosa, (Breitenbach), spores 6-8 x 2.5-3.5 um (Trudell), spores 7 x 4 um, partly 2-seriate; asci reaching a length of 50 um and a width of 5 um, paraphyses filiform, hairs reaching a length of 200-300 um (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  'arida' means 'dry'
SIMILAR  Lachnellula flavovirens was collected from BC and WA and deposited by O. Ceska at the University of British Columbia. This species and Lachnellula arida are shown on the same page in Breitenbach(1) who give the spore measurements as 10-13 x 3.5-5.5 um for L. flavovirens and say the margin is "thickly set with cinnamon-brown hairs". Lachnellula fuscosanguinea (Rehm) Dennis is illustrated by Desjardin(6) for California. Habitat is bark of dead conifer branches including pine, external hairs are yellowish brown to rusty brown as opposed to dark brown for L. arida, and spores are larger, measuring 13-15 x 4-5 um. (Desjardin(6)). See also Dasyscyphus pini which might be the same species as L. fuscosanguinea. D. pini has larger spores and asci, and paraphyses lack swollen tips, (W.W. Diehl in Hahn(1)). Several Lachnum species also have brown hairs but are generally smaller, often with lanceolate paraphyses. See descriptions for Lachnum cerinum, Lachnum clandestinum, and Lachnum flavofuligineum. According to Haines(1), Brunnipila calyculiformis (=Lachnum calyculiforme, =Dasyscyphus calyculiformis) was reported from WA by Kanouse but Seaver stated that there was some doubt about the determination. There is a D. Stuntz collection from WA at the University of Washington. Haines(1) reported two collections from WA with the reservation that the hairs were longer (up to 200 um) than Dennis's description and there was no color reaction with the hairs in KOH. Haines(1) reported from WA one collection of yet another brown-haired species, Lachnum fuscescens, "easily recognized by its thick-walled hairs, tipped with crystal masses". Haines(1) further reports from WA, a collection of Brunnipila palearum (=Lachnum palearum, =Dasyscyphus palearum) "striking in its appearance" due to the presence on the tips of the brown hairs of yellowish crystal masses which contrast with the brown exterior of the cup and give the cup a frosty appearance. Haines(1) examined a collection of Lachnum barbatum (as Dasyscyphus barbatus, also known as Trichopezizella barbata) from before 1942 by J.W. Hotson on Oplopanax horridus (devil's club). It has large, smooth, dark brown hairs 4-5 um wide, up to 250 um long, some with swollen tips, others with tapering tips. See also Lasiobelonium spp.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Trudell(4)*, Seaver(2) (as Lachnella arida), Desjardin(6)*, Haines(1), Hahn(1) (re Dasyscyphus pini)
161
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnellula calyciformis  (Battarra) Dharne^  Phytopath. Z. 53: 124. 1965;  Dasyscyphus calyciformis  (Battarra) Rehm [as 'Dasyscypha'];  Trichoscypha calyciformis  (Battarra) Grelet
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small cup with white hairs on the exterior and the margin, a bright orange-yellow upper surface, a short stem, gregarious growth on bark and wood of conifers, and microscopic characters including paraphyses that are usually unswollen at the tip.^ | Bingham(2) have provided means of separating this species from Lachnellula agassizii (see SIMILAR), but Seaver(2) says this, "The differences are so slight that it seems to the writer a question whether or not they should be separated." This species should not be confused with Lachnellula calycina or Lachnum calyculiforme (the latter a synonym of Brunnipila calyculiforme with brown hairs), or with Lachnum calycioides (also known as Brunnipila calycioides). RANGE ^Lachnellula calyciformis is found in CA (Desjardin(6)). O. Ceska has identified it from BC and deposited collections at the University of British Columbia. J. Lindgren has deposited collections from WA at the University of Washington.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.15-0.3cm across, saucer-shaped to shallowly cup-shaped, "margin inrolled in dry weather"; "yellowish orange to orange"; smooth except for the white marginal hairs^, (Desjardin), 0.1-0.5cm across, orange to orange yellow, (Hansen, L.), 0.15-0.3cm, "cup-shaped to flat and saucer-shaped"; yellow to orange-yellow; smooth, margin thickly set with white hairs, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  "covered with coarse, relatively long, white hairs"^ (Desjardin), thickly set with white hairs (Breitenbach)
STEM  "absent or tiny", 0.05-0.10cm x 0.02cm, cylindric, (Desjardin), attached to bark by short stem (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Desjardin)
HABITAT  gregarious "on the bark of dead conifers (fir)"; in California fruiting "from spring through summer"^, (Desjardin), mostly on branches of Abies (true fir), but also on Picea (spruce) and Pinus (pine), (Hansen, L.), single or gregarious to cespitose, on dead branches of Abies and Picea, spring and fall, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-7 x 2.5-3 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless^; ascus apical pore inamyloid; "paraphyses filiform, septate"; external hairs colorless, "thin-walled to slightly thick-walled, septate, granular-incrusted" (Desjardin), spores 4.5-6.5 x 2.5-3 um, elliptic, "with 2 oil-drops"; asci 45-63 x 4-5.5 um, inamyloid; paraphyses filiform, 1.5 um broad, "exceeding the asci"; hairs 3-4 um wide, cylindric, colorless, (Hansen, L.(1)), spores 4.5-7 x 2.5-3 um, oval, smooth, colorless; asci 8-spored, uniseriate, 45-55 x 4.5-5 um, iodine negative; paraphyses "filiform, septate, sometimes slightly lanceolate"; hairs colorless, "multiply septate, thin-walled and finely encrusted", (Breitenbach), spores 4.0-7.5 x 1.5-3.5 um, elliptic to oval, indistinctly biguttulate, paraphyses 45.0-77.0 x 1.0-3.0 um, tips usually unswollen, (Bingham(2))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'cup-shaped'
SIMILAR  Lachnellula agassizii has spores 5.0-9.5 x 2.0-4.0 um and paraphyses with tips that are usually swollen. Fruitbodies are 0.05-0.55cm across, stems are up to 0.25cm long, external hairs are lost with age (persistent in L. calyciformis), and there may be up to 12 fruitbodies from a common base (1 to a few for L. calyciformis), (Bingham(2)). Lachnellula subtilissima has also been identified by O. Ceska from British Columbia. According to Hansen, L.(1), it grows on conifer branches, spores are 6-9 x 2-2.5 um without droplets, asci have an amyloid pore, and paraphyses are filiform. Lachnellula gallica (P. Karst. & Hariot) Dennis has also been identified from BC by O. Ceska. It grows on branches of Abies (true fir), spores are 8-10 x 5-6.5 um, and paraphyses are filiform. Lachnellula occidentalis and Lachnellula willkommii have larger spores. Lachnellula suecica has round spores. The name Lachnellula calyciformis should not be confused with Lachnum calyculiforme which is a different species with brown hairs, or with Lachnellula calycina which has round spores 2-2.5 um in diameter.
SOURCES  Desjardin(6)*, Hansen, L.(1), Breitenbach(1)*, Bingham(1), Bingham(2), Seaver(2)
162
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnellula ciliata  (G.G. Hahn) Dennis^  Persoonia 2(2): 183 (1962);  Dasyscypha ciliata  G.G. Hahn  Mycologia 32: 141. 1940;  Lachnella ciliata  (G.G. Hahn) Seaver  North American Cup-fungi (Inoperculates) p.247. 1951
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a tiny cup with an yellow to orange disc surrounded by whitish hairs, 2) a short, stout stem, 3) growth on dead branches and twigs of Douglas-fir, 4) relatively large spores, and 5) thread-like paraphyses about the same length as the asci.^ | Dasyscyphus ciliatus is not the same as Lachnella ciliata (Sauter) Cooke, which is a basidiomycete and a synonym of Flagelloscypha orthospora. (Most ascomycete Lachnella species are considered to belong in Lachnum or Lachnellula.) It is not the same as Lachnum ciliatum (Fuckel) Rehm which is an ascomycete but is a synonym of Hyalopeziza ciliata Fuckel. RANGE ^The type is from OR, and other collections were examined from BC and OR (Hahn). S. Trudell identified a collection from Washington (deposited at the University of Washington), commenting in the notes "Spores rather broad, but otherwise material seems to fit this species."
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.2cm across (commonly), "at first globular, closed, opening as a flat disc under moist conditions, laterally compressed and closed when dry"; disc orange^, (Hahn), 0.1-0.2cm across, at first spherical, expanding and becoming disc-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface concave or flat, orange; with a fringe-like margin from hairs, (Seaver), up to 0.15cm across, "disc shallowly cup-shaped or almost flat when moist, almost completely covered by the infolding of the margin when dry"; disc "cream-yellow to orange"; "slightly waxy in appearance", (Haines)
FLESH  waxy-fleshy (Seaver)
UNDERSIDE  whitish, with conspicuous elongate hairs that readily break away to reveal bald tissue beneath, hairs around the rim persistent, fringe-like^, (Hahn), whitish (Seaver), densely covered when young "with long, stiff whitish hairs", becoming almost bare when old, exposing the yellow to orange exterior, (Haines)
STEM  "very shortly but definitely stipitate"^ (Hahn), short (Seaver), stout, up to 0.04cm x 0.04cm, (Haines)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "so far as we know D. ciliata is restricted in its growth to the small, shaded-out, dead branches and twigs of Douglas fir"^, (Hahn, Latin name italicized), usually scattered, occasionally grouped, on dead branches of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Seaver), cups single, "erumpent throughout the bark of the recently killed host", known only from Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Haines)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8.0-12.4 x 4.0-6.6 um, ovate or elliptic with obtuse ends, smooth, colorless, uniseriate and arranged "in a regular oblique manner"^; asci 8-spored, 63.0-92.8 x 6.0-12.0 um, "clavate, apex obtusely rounded"; hairs cylindric, minutely roughened, colorless, thin-walled; conidial state not observed, (Hahn), ascospores 8-12 x 4-6 um, oval to elliptic, obliquely 1-seriate; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 70-80 um and a width of 7-10 um, clavate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], slightly swollen at tips; hairs 3 um wide, cylindric with acute ends, minutely roughened, giving rise to the fringed margin of fruitbody, (Seaver), spores 8-10.5 x 5-5.5 um, ovate to short elliptic, colorless, "comparatively thick-walled, at first with a single large droplet which breaks down to fill the spore with many small droplets at maturity"; asci 8-spored, 70-80 x 8-10 um, "cylindric-clavate, relatively thick-walled", tip hemispherical, "base narrowed to a short stalk"; paraphyses 2-2.5 um wide, thread-like, "about the same length as the asci, filled with yellow droplets"; hairs up to 140 um long, 2.5-4.5 um wide, cylindric with blunt tips, colorless, "distinctly roughened externally, multiseptate", septa forming cells 15-30 um long, (Haines)
NAME ORIGIN  probably referring to the long hairs (ciliate)
SIMILAR  Lachnellula agassizii differs in spore characters (smaller) "and in the size of its fruit cups"; an imperfect stage "which is present in the life-history of D. Agassizii is apparently lacking in the life-history of this new Douglas fir species"; Lachnellula agassizii grows not only on small branches, but also on large trunks, (Hahn, Latin name italicized). Lachnellula pseudotsugae has smaller spores and a conspicuous imperfect stage: it grows on cankers and roughened bark occurring on the living trunks and branches of Douglas-fir (saplings and trees of pole-size that are suppressed or growing on poor sites), (Hahn).
SOURCES  Hahn(2) (as Dasyscypha ciliata), Haines(1) (as Dasyscypha ciliata), Seaver(2) (as Lachnella ciliata)
163
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnellula occidentalis  (G.G. Hahn & Ayers) Dharne^  Phytopath. Z. 53: 129. 1965;  Dasyscypha occidentalis  G.G. Hahn & Ayers;  Lachnella occidentalis  (G.G. Hahn & Ayers) Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) small cups thickly set with white hairs on the outside and margin, the upper surface yolk-yellow to orange, 2) short stem, 3) growth on larch or sometimes other conifers, and 4) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Lachnellula occidentalis is found in BC, PA, and VT, (Seaver), Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Denmark, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen). There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.3(0.5)cm across, goblet-shaped when young, then cup-shaped to saucer-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface yolk-yellow to orange, smooth; margin thickly set with white hairs, strongly inrolled when dry^, (Breitenbach), reaching 0.1-0.3cm across, at first spherical and closed, "opening in a roundish form, the margin incurved, later expanding and becoming saucer-shaped under moist conditions, laterally compressed and closed when dry"; spore-bearing surface salmon-orange, (Seaver), spore-bearing surface ochraceous to orange (Hansen)
FLESH  fleshy^ (Seaver)
UNDERSIDE  thickly set with white hairs^ (Breitenbach), densely clothed with white hairs (Seaver)
STEM  short^ (Breitenbach, Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on dead branches of Larix (larch) still with bark, (sometimes also on old cankers), Picea (spruce), according to literature also on other conifers; March to December^, (Breitenbach), abundant, scattered, or grouped, on species of larch (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-17 x 3.5-6 um, fusiform-elliptic [spindle-shaped - elliptic], smooth, colorless, uniseriate to biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 110 x 9-10 um, not turning blue in iodine; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], septate, forked, submoniliform toward tips [with constrictions at septa to give the effect of swollen cells like a string of long beads]; hairs colorless, thin-walled, septate, finely encrusted, tips blunt, (Breitenbach), spores 10-18 x 4-7 um, elliptic, obliquely uniseriate, becoming one-septate on germination; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 130 um and a width of 12 um, clavate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], swollen at tips, 1-2 um wide; hairs long, 3-4 um wide, flexuous, roughened on outside; microconidia 2-5 x 1-1.5 um, elliptic, or allantoid, simple, conidial stage "consisting or a fleshy stroma with irregular labyrinthiform cavities in which the microconidia are abstricted from the tips of slender, pointed, verticillately branched sporophores", (Seaver), spores 18-20 x 7-9 um, elongate-elliptic; asci 120-150 x 10-12 um, paraphyses exceeding the asci, monilioid, 1.5-2.5 um wide with tip 4-5 um wide; hairs cylindric, 2.5-4 um wide, colorless, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Lachnellula willkommii has larger spores and does not have submoniliform paraphyses, (Breitenbach). Lachnellula suecica has round spores, (Breitenbach). Lachnellula agassizii has smaller spores. See also SIMILAR section of Lachnellula calyciformis.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Seaver(2) (as Lachnella), Hansen, L.(1)
164
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnellula populina  (Seaver) Partel & Baral^  in Baral & Quijada, Index Fungorum 454: 2. 2020;  Perrotia populina  (Seaver) Dennis  Kew Bull. 17(2): 358. 1963;  Lachnella populina  Seaver  The North American Cup-fungi (Inoperculates) p.270. 1951
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute ascomycete fruitbodies that are thickly coated with brown hairs, yellowish brown spore-bearing upper surface when dry, growth on wood of quaking aspen, and microscopic characters including asci.^ | The description is form Seaver(2). RANGE ^Lachnellula populina is found from CO and MT to OR, (Seaver). 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  at first spherical, becoming expanded but with incurved margin, when dry either rounded or hysteriform, reaching a diameter of 0.1-0.15cm, spore-bearing upper surface yellowish brown in dried specimens (fresh color not indicated)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  thickly clothed with brown hairs
STEM  sessile or subsessile [without a stem or almost without a stem]
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  thickly gregarious on bark and barkless wood of Populus tremuloides (Quaking Aspen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-15 x 4 um, or occasionally as long as 18 um, "straight, or slightly curved, irregularly fusoid", obliquely uniseriate or becoming biseriate to irregularly disposed^; asci reaching a length of 65-80 um and a width of 9-10 um, rather short and stubby, cylindric, scarcely narrowed at base; paraphyses clavate, rather strongly widened in upper part where they reach a width of 4 um; hairs reaching a length of 150 um and a width of 5-6 um, cylindric, flexuous [wavy], roughened with minute granules
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Populus' referring to its host
SIMILAR  Dasyscyphus populicola (Seaver) McKnight (described from CO) looks the same macroscopically and also occurs on Populus tremuloides but has smaller spores (8-9 x 2 um) and lanceolate paraphyses, (Seaver as Lachnella populicola). Two collections of Dasyscyphus populicola were reported by Haines(1) from WA in his Master's thesis with spores 6-10 x 1.5-2 um.
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Lachnella populina, discussing also Dasyscyphus populicola as Lachnella populicola), Haines(1) (regarding Dasyscyphus populicola as D. populicolus)
165
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnellula pseudotsugae  (G.G. Hahn) Dennis^  Persoonia 2(2): 184. 1962;  Lachnella pseudotsugae  (G.G. Hahn) Seaver  The North American Cup-fungi (Inoperculates) p.246. 1951;  Dasyscyphus pseudotsugae  G.G. Hahn [as Dasyscypha]
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small ascomycete cups with external hairs and orange-yellow to orange spore-bearing upper surface, growth on living branches of Douglas-fir, and microscopic characters including relatively small ascospores.^ | The description is derived from Seaver(2) except where noted. RANGE ^Lachnellula pseudotsugae was described as Dasyscypha pseudotsugae and examined from BC, OR, and CA (Hahn(2)). There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.35cm across, at first spherical and closed, "opening in a roundish form, the margin incurved, urn-shaped, becoming widely expanded and discoid under moist conditions, laterally compressed when dry"; spore-bearing upper surface light orange-yellow to orange
FLESH  waxy-fleshy
UNDERSIDE  whitish (Hahn(2))
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered, or closely grouped, forming cankers on living branches of Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)^, (Seaver), on living branches and trunks of Pseudotsuga menziesii, (Hahn(2))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  ascospores 4-7 x 2-4 um, elliptic to fusoid, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 50-60 um and a width of 4-5.4 um, clavate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], slightly swollen in upper part; hairs 3-3.5 um wide, cylindric with obtuse ends, hyaline-white, minutely roughened; conidia 2.4-4 x 1.8-3 um, elliptic, colorless, produced on the ends of simple, or branched conidiophores; conidial stage "consisting of waxy-fleshy, light-buff stromata with labyrinthiform cavities in which the conidia are borne and from which they exude in a droplet or tendril", (Seaver), paraphyses "outranking asci, filiform, of even diameter, septate, not swollen or only slightly so toward the tip with obtuse extremities, minutely guttulate"; exterior hairs 3-3.5 um wide, "persistent, minutely roughened, hyaline, thin-walled, cylindrical with obtusely rounded extremities, septate, cells short", (Hahn(2))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Pseudotsuga' referring to its host
SIMILAR  Lachnellula ciliata (G.G. Hahn) Dennis, has larger spores and is said by Haines(1) to be the most common Lachnellula on Douglas-fir. In his Master's thesis that included Lachnellula spp. of western Washington, he does not mention L. pseudotsugae by name though he adds that a similar species has been described which is the cause of cankers of Pseudotsuga "but no material was seen for comparison". Dasyscyphus ellisianus (Rehm) Sacc. is an eastern North American species found to be associated with cankers on Douglas-fir among other species by Hahn(4), but at that time (1934) it was not found west of Texas.
SOURCES  Hahn(2) (as Dasyscypha pseudotsugae), Seaver(2) (as Lachnella pseudotsugae), Hahn(4) (regarding Dasyscyphus ellisianus - as Dasyscypha ellisiana), Haines(1)
166
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnellula suecica  (de Bary ex Fuckel) Nannf.^  in Lundell & Nannfeldt, Fungi Exsicc. 41-42: 48. 1953;  Lachnellula chrysophthalma  (Pers.) P. Karst.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small cup with a dense covering of white hairs on outside and margin, yolk-yellow to orange upper surface, short stem, growth on bark of conifers (especially Ponderosa pine in the Pacific Northwest), and microscopic characters including small round spores.^ RANGE ^Lachnellula suecica is found from ON to ID, MT and CO, (Seaver), Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen). There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre and (as Lachnellula chrysophthalma) at the University of British Columbia. Haines(1) included it (as Lachnellula chrysomphalma) after examining material from Goose Lake ID (note the discrepancy in hair length from Seaver), and says "it is believed to occur abundantly on the ponderosa pines of the eastern slopes of the Cascade Mountains".
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.4cm across, "cup-shaped when young, then irregularly distorted, saucer-shaped to flat and plate-shaped"; spore-bearing upper surface yolk-yellow, smooth; margin white hairy-felty, "often split or notched and strongly inrolled when dry"^, (Breitenbach), reaching 0.5-0.6cm, at first nearly spherical, expanding and becoming shallow cup-shaped; spore-bearing surface concave or nearly flat, orange-red, (Seaver), 0.1-0.6cm across, with orange spore-bearing surface, (Hansen), up to about 1cm across (Trudell), up to 0.7cm across, disc yellow to orange, fruitbody margins folding in on drying, "often forming into a cocked-hat shape, seldom concealing the entire disc", (Haines)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white hairy-felty^ (Breitenbach), with dense covering of white hairs (Seaver), white to cream where exposed, but "covered externally with a dense, tangle mat of white hairs which persists even at maturity", (Haines)
STEM  short^ (Breitenbach), short-stemmed, appearing as if no stem, (Seaver), short, up to 0.1cm x 0.05cm, (Haines)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious on dead branches of Pinus (pine), according to literature also on Larix (larch), July to September^, (Breitenbach), emerging through outer bark of conifers, frequently in Rocky Mountains on Abies (fir) and Picea (spruce) and occasionally on Pinus (pine), (Seaver), saprophytic on branches of Larix, Picea, Pinus, and Juniperus, (Hansen), in the Pacific Northwest mostly east of the Cascade crest on branches of Pinus ponderosa (Ponderosa Pine), (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4.5-5 um in diameter, round, smooth, colorless, sometimes with droplets, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 70 x 7-8 um, weak reaction in iodine; paraphyses barely projecting beyond the asci, filiform [thread-like], sometimes forked toward the tips; hairs colorless, thin-walled, multiply septate, finely encrusted, tips rounded, (Breitenbach), spores reaching a diameter of 5-6 um, round, uniseriate; asci reaching a length of 80 um and width of 5-6 um, cylindric, tapering in lower part into "a rather slender, stem-like base which is often forked"; paraphyses filiform, slightly widened in upper part, reaching a width of 2-2.5 um, filled with oil droplets; hairs reaching a length of 50-60 um and a width of 4 um, cylindric, densely covered with minute granules, colorless, (Seaver), spores 4-6.5 x 4-6.5 um; asci 50-80 x 5-8.5 um, with amyloid pore; paraphyses exceeding the asci, filiform, 2-2.5 um wide; hairs 2.5-4 um wide, cylindric, colorless, (Hansen), spores 4.5-5.0 um in diameter, round, relatively thick-walled, usually with a single large, round, refractive inclusion and several small ones; asci 8-spored, 60-70 x 5-6 um, with a narrowed stalk, wall slightly thickened; paraphyses thread-like, up to 2 um wide at widest point, up to 8 um longer than asci, thin-walled, often with septum in lower part, "often with numerous, small, refractive, yellow inclusions", otherwise colorless; hairs up to 150 um long and 2.5-3.0 um wide, cylindric with obtuse apex, conspicuously roughened by small adherent granules measuring up to 1 um, colorless, thin-walled, multiseptate, septa forming cells up to 25 um long, (Haines)
NAME ORIGIN  suecica means 'Swedish'
SIMILAR  Lachnellula agassizii, Lachnellula occidentalis, and Lachnellula willkommii do not have round spores. See also SIMILAR section of Lachnellula calyciformis.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Seaver(2) (as Lachnellula chrysophthalma), Hansen, L.(1), Trudell(4)*, Haines(1) (as Lachnellula chrysophthalma)
167
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnellula willkommii  (Hartig) Dennis^  Persoonia 2(2): 184. 1962;  Lachnella willkommii  Hartig;  Trichoscypha willkommii  Boud.;  Trichoscyphella willkommii  Nannf.;  Dasyscypha willkommii  (Hartig) Rehm
ENGLISH NAME(S)  larch canker
NOTES  Features include a cup-shaped fruitbody with yolk-yellow to orange upper surface, the margin and exterior with dense white hairs, absent or short stem, parasitic growth on larch, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Lachnellula willkommii is found from MA to ID, (Seaver), Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Denmark, Finland, Iceland, and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.3(0.5)cm across, goblet-shaped when young, then cup-shaped to saucer-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface yolk-yellow to orange; margin thickly set with white hairs, strongly inrolled when dry^, (Breitenbach), reaching 0.1-0.3cm across, at first closed and rounded, becoming expanded and finally scutellate; spore-bearing (upper) surface becoming nearly flat, yellow to orange, (Seaver), 0.2-0.3cm across, spore-bearing surface orange to apricot, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  thickly set with white hairs^ (Breitenbach), white and clothed with dense covering of white hairs (Seaver)
STEM  short^ (Breitenbach), without a stem or with short stem (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on attached branches of Larix (larch) or in the immediate vicinity of cankers, March to December; it is a wound parasite that causes larch canker^, (Breitenbach), "scattered, or gregarious in small groups and occasionally several closely crowded together", on branches of Larix europaea, (Seaver), parasitic on Larix, causing cankers and sinuose growth of the trunk, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-20 x 7-8 um, elliptic-fusiform, smooth, colorless, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 120 x 10-11 um, colorless, weakly dextrinoid in iodine; paraphyses projecting beyond the asci, filiform [thread-like], septate; hairs colorless, "thin-walled, multiply septate, finely encrusted, tips blunt", (Breitenbach), spores 15-20 x 6-8 um, or rarely as long as 25 um, elliptic, often with ends narrowed, colorless, granular within; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 100-120 um and a width of 8-10 um, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses slender, clavate, reaching a width of about 3 um; hairs flexuous [wavy], of nearly uniform thickness throughout length, minutely roughened; microconidia 2-8 um x 1-2 um, elliptic or allantoid, simple, colorless, conidial stage that precedes apothecial stage "consists of waxy, whitish stromata with irregular labyrinthiform cavities in which the microconidia are abstricted from the tips of slender, subulate, simple or verticillately-branched sporophores", (Seaver), spores 20-24 x 7-10 um; asci 135-165 x 11-13 um, inamyloid; paraphyses exceeding asci, filiform, 1.5-2.5 um wide, with widened tip 3-3.5 um wide; hairs cylindric, 3-4 um wide, colorless, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Lachnellula occidentalis has smaller spores and submoniliform paraphyses, (Breitenbach). Lachnellula suecica has round spores (Breitenbach). Lachnellula agassizii has smaller spores. See also SIMILAR section of Lachnellula calyciformis.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Seaver(2) (as Lachnella), Hansen, L.(1)
168
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnum capitatum  (Peck) Svrcek^  Ceska Mykol. 39(4): 214 1985;  Dasyscyphus capitatus  (Peck) Kanouse [as Dasyscypha];  Lachnella capitata  (Peck) Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a very minute cup with the external surface clothed with a dense coat of white hairs and the spore-bearing upper surface white or yellowish, 2) absent stem, 3) growth on old leaves, and 4) microscopic characters including hairs that are often terminated with a crystalline cap.^ RANGE ^Lachnum capitatum was reported from WA (Kanouse). Distribution is NY to MO, OH, and PA, (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  very minute, at first spherical and closed, finally expanding; spore-bearing upper surface white, or yellowish^, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  clothed with a dense coat of white hairs^ (Seaver)
STEM  without stem^ (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on leaves of Quercus (oak)^, (Seaver), on old leaves (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-7 um long, cylindric, slender^; asci reaching a length of 30 um, cylindric or subcylindric; paraphyses longer than asci, thick, lanceolate; hairs colorless with transmitted light, often terminated with a crystalline cap, (Seaver), spores 7.5-9 x 2 um, hairs capped with large conspicuous stellate crystals, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with a head', probably referring to crystalline cap on hairs
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(6) (as Dasyscypha capitata), Seaver(2) (as Lachnella capitata)
169
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnum cerinum  (Pers.) Nannf.^  Nova Acta Regiae Soc. Sci. Upsal., ser. 4, 8, p.262. 1932;  Dasyscyphus cerinus  (Pers.) Fuckel;  Lachnella cerina  (Pers.) W. Phillips
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute, cup-shaped fruitbody clothed with brown hairs, with spore bearing upper surface described as various colors; a distinct short dark stem present or not; growth on wood of hardwoods; and microscopic characters including short spores.^ | Another name, Neodasyscypha cerina (Pers.: Fr.) Spooner, is considered to be in an genus that has an invalid name, according to Dictionary of the Fungi 9th Edition, following Eriksson & Hawksworth. Haines(1) in his Master's thesis considered this "one of our most common colored species of Dasyscyphus which occurs on hardwood remains (commonly Populus)" (referring to western Washington, with Latin names underlined). RANGE ^Lachnum cerinum is found in WA, and also NF, TN, WV, and Europe, (Seaver), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen). There is an R. Bandoni collection from BC deposited at the University of British Columbia (as Lachnella cerina).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^golden yellow hairs turn olive-brown when mounted in 3% KOH (the golden yellow granules almost completely dissolve in KOH) (Haines)
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.1cm across, at first closed and nearly spherical, expanding to shallow cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface becoming nearly flat, yellow^, (Seaver), 0.05-0.1cm across, cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface reddish brown to dark brown, (Hansen), up to 0.15cm across, shallow to deeply cup-shaped; disc white to cream-colored, (Haines)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  clothed with brown hairs^ (Seaver), with dark brown hairs (Hansen), black, "densely covered with short, yellow to rust-brown hairs", (Haines)
STEM  short, dark^, (Seaver), +/- stemmed (Hansen), subsessile or shortly stipitate (Haines)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on wood of hardwoods^, (Seaver), saprophytic on hardwood, found on Quercus (oak), (Hansen), on hardwood remains (commonly Populus) (Haines)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-6 x 2.5-3 um, elliptic, uniseriate or biseriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 40-50 um and a width of 4-5 um, cylindric or subcylindric; paraphyses extending far beyond the asci, reaching a width of 2 um, filiform [thread-like]; hairs reaching a length of 120 um and a width of 4-5 um, "brown, septate, roughened on the outside", (Seaver), spores 4.5-7.5 x 2-3 um, elliptic to fusoid, colorless, non-septate; asci 8-spored, 40-48 x 3.5-5 um, cylindric to clavate, with amyloid pore; paraphyses exceeding the asci by 5-10 um, 2-2.5 um wide, narrowly lanceolate; hairs 70-140 x 3-4 um, cylindric, brown, paler toward tip, +/- thick-walled, multiseptate, densely covered with attached granules, (Hansen), spores 4-6 x 2-2.5 um, short-elliptic, uniseriate, usually without conspicuous inclusions; asci 8-spored, cylindric with rather thick stalk; paraphyses 1.5-2 um wide at the widest point, filiform [thread-like] "or narrowly lanceolate", "with obtuse apices, barely exceeding the asci", "usually filled with numerous yellow droplets, non-septate"; hairs up to 10 um long and 4-5 um wide, cylindric with obtuse tip but tapering slightly at both ends, "golden yellow but turning olive-brown when mounted in 3% KOH, densely covered with coarse, golden yellow granules which almost completely dissolve in KOH", "multiseptate, moderately thick-walled, often filled with storage material", the upper third often colorless; outer excipulum "of one or two layers of subglobose, thick-walled, cells" 5-10 um in diameter "which are similar to the hairs in color and KOH reaction", "inner excipulum of closely packed, short-celled, parallel, hyaline hyphae", (Haines, the length of the hairs may be an error here and the ascal dimensions are clearly wrong, being identical to the spore dimensions)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'waxy' or 'wax-colored'
SIMILAR  Other small brown-haired Lachnum species include Lachnum clandestinum and Lachnum flavofuligineum. See also SIMILAR section of Lachnellula arida which discusses brown-haired species.
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Lachnella), Hansen, L.(1) (as Neodasyscypha), Haines(1) (as Dasyscyphus cerinus)
170
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnum clandestinum  (Fr.) P. Karst.^  Bidr. Kann. Finl. Nat. Folk 19: 178. 1871
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a light brown cup covered with brown farinose hairs (tipped with a mass of calcium oxalate), the disc cream to ocher and smooth, a short stem when present, growth on dead raspberry canes and other herb stems, and microscopic characters including lanceolate paraphyses.^ RANGE ^Lachnum clandestinum is found in WA (Kanouse), Switzerland (Breitenbach), United Kingdom (Dennis), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.1cm, goblet-shaped when young, then cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface cream to ocher, smooth^; margin thickly set with light brown hairs that are farinose at tips (crystals of calcium oxalate), margin inrolled when dry, (Breitenbach), cup-shaped, disc drying yellow, up to 0.1cm across, (Dennis), spore-bearing surface ochraceous (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  thickly set with light brown hairs^ (Breitenbach), light brown, covered with yellowish brown hairs, each tipped with a mass of calcium oxalate, (Dennis)
STEM  +/- stemmed^ (Breitenbach), short-stemmed (Dennis), shortly but definitely stipitate (Haines)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to cespitose, on Rubus idaeus (raspberry) canes lying on the ground, and according to literature other herbs, May to August, (Breitenbach), on twigs of willow (?), on Acer circinatum, on woody stems of nettle, on Rubus canes, (Kanouse)^, scattered, on dead herb stems, especially Rubus idaeus, April to August but especially in spring, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 x 1.5-1.8 um, fusiform [spindle-shaped], smooth, colorless, biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 40-45 x 5 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses projecting strongly beyond the asci, lanceolate; hairs yellow-brownish, thin-walled, septate, finely encrusted and set with oxalate crystals at the tips, (Breitenbach), spores 7-9 x 1-1.5 um; long rough brown hairs with conspicuous crystal formation at the tips, (Kanouse), spores 5-6 x 1.5 um, fusiform, non-septate, biseriate; asci 8-spored, up to 50 x 5 um, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses much longer than asci, 3-4 um wide, lanceolate, (Dennis), paraphyses exceeding asci by up to 30 um; hairs 80-100 x 3-5 um, cylindric, thick-walled, with apical crystals, (Hansen), spores 6-10 x 2.0-2.5 um, narrowly fusiform, colorless, "clear or with very tiny refractive bodies"; colorless, lanceolate paraphyses exceeding asci but up to 25 um in hymenium; hairs 3.5-4.5 um wide, up to 150 um long, "dark brown, not exuding color in 3% KOH, finely granulate", apical cell not greatly enlarged but colorless, "thinner-walled than the rest of the hair, and usually crowned by a mass of crystaline matter, multiseptate, cylindrical, slightly thickened walls, usually curved upwards from the excipulum", (Haines)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'secret, hidden'
SIMILAR  Other small brown-haired Lachnum species include Lachnum cerinum and Lachnum flavofuligineum. See also SIMILAR section of Lachnellula arida.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Dasyscyphus clandestinus (Bull. ex Merat) Fuckel), Dennis(1) (as Dasyscyphus clandestinus (Bull. ex Merat) Fuckel), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6), Seaver(2) (as Dasyscypha clandestina (Bull.) Fuckel), Haines(1) (as Dasyscyphus clandestina)
171
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnum flavofuligineum  (Alb. & Schwein) Rehm^  Beih. bot. Zbl. 38. 1921;  Dasyscyphus flavofuligineus  (Alb. & Schwein.) Fuckel
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Lachnum flavofuligineum forms cups (presumably very small) with numerous, very long, brown hairs on the exterior, and spores 9-10 x 2.5-3 um.^ RANGE ^Lachnum flavofuligineum was reported by Kanouse from WA (on sticks at Lake Crescent, June 3, 1939, and on Sambucus sp., Lower Elwha River, July 3, 1939).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  "The brown hairs are very long and numerous on the outside of the cups"^ (Kanouse)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on sticks; on Sambucus sp.^, (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-10 x 2.5-3 um^; the hairs bear no crystals, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'yellow-fuliginous', fuliginous meaning 'sooty brown or dark-smoke colored'
SIMILAR  Other small brown-haired Lachnum species include Lachnum clandestinum and Lachnum cerinum. See also SIMILAR section of Lachnellula arida.
SOURCES  Kanouse(6)
172
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnum gaultheriae  (Ellis & Everh.) Zeller^  Mycologia 26: 292. 1934;  Lachnella gaultheriae  (Ellis & Everh.) Seaver;  Dasyscyphus gaultheriae  Ellis & Everh. [as Dasyscypha]
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute, pale orange cup clothed with dense short white hairs, pale orange spore-bearing surface, growth on salal leaves on large, semicircular spots that are pinkish gray to grayish white on the upper surface and rusty brown on the lower surface, with a dark purple border, and microscopic characters.^ | According to Zeller, this species is closely related to Trichopeziza echinulata Rehm. Dennis(3) regarded the status of this taxon as dubious based on the differentiation from Dasyscyphus albocitrinus using the short spores 4-5 x 1.25 um and his observation of specimens determined as L. gaultheriae with spores up to 8 x 1.5 um. (The hairs of D. albocitrinus are also slender, tapering, thin-walled, and hyaline, but he gives the spores of D. albocitrinus as 10-11 x 1-1.5 um in another part of the paper.) L. gaultheriae is common according to Zeller(14) writing about the Pacific Northwest. RANGE ^Lachnum gaultheriae was described from WA and found there also by Kanouse. It is found from WA to OR and CA (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.1cm across, nearly closed at first, then opening and becoming cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface pale orange^, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale orange, closed densely with short white hairs^, (Seaver)
STEM  "stem short, rather less than the diameter of the apothecium", seated on large, semicircular, grayish to brownish spots with a dark purple border^, (Seaver), associated leaf-spot is large and circular, 2-4cm across, pinkish gray to grayish white on upper surface, rusty brown on lower surface, with a purplish black, smooth border, (Zeller)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on Gaultheria shallon (salal)^, (Seaver), on the underside of a large leaf spot of Gaultheria shallon, February to July, (Zeller)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4-5 x 1.25 um, elliptic or clavate-elliptic, 2-seriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 40 um and a width of 3-4 um, clavate-cylindric, (Seaver), hairs slender, tapering, thin-walled, hyaline, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Gaultheria (salal)', referring to its host
SIMILAR  Lachnum echinulatum Rehm is similar if not identical, but it is a "promiscuous, folicose saprophyte" [folicose presumably meaning leaf-like], (Zeller)
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Lachnella), Zeller(14), Kanouse(6), Dennis(3)
173
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnum miniatum (Kanouse)  M.P. Sharma^  Achievements and Prospects in Mycology and Plant Pathology (Dehra Dun): 35. 1997;  Lachnaster miniatus  Kanouse  Mycologia 39: 662. 1947;  Albotricha miniata  (Kanouse) Raitv.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include very minute, white fruiting bodies having a margin edged with long hairs arranged in teeth, and lance-like paraphyses.^ | The description is derived from Kanouse. Lachnaster (characterized by the marginal hairs being arranged in teeth and by lance-like paraphyses) is synonymized in Dictionary of the Fungi 10th Edition with Lachnum. RANGE ^Lachnum miniatum was originally described from WA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.01cm broad, with very short stem to substipitate; white; "margin edged with long whip-lash hairs arranged in teeth"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on Pterydium aquilinum (bracken fern)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 x 1-1.5 um, straight, colorless, arranged obliquely in ascus^; asci 30-35 x 5-6 um, 8-spored, pore blue with iodine; paraphyses 50 x 6-7 um, lance-like, colorless, wider and longer than the asci; "hairs 75-90 x 6-8 um, septate, rough, pale yellow, the lower half broader, abruptly narrowing to the sharp pointed upper portion"
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Several other small cups develop on ferns.
SOURCES  Kanouse(6) (as Lachnaster miniatus), Seaver(2) (as Lachnaster miniatus)
174
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnum nardi  Rehm^  in Rab. Krypt.-Fl. 1(3): 883. 1893;  Dasyscyphus nardi  (Rehm) Sacc.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute, white fruitbody with long hairs that on the margin are in fascicles, stem present, growth on sedge (type on Nardus grass), and microscopic characters.^ | It was reported from WA by Kanouse, and the description below is derived from this report. Seaver says, "Lachnum Nardi Rehm in Rob. Krypt.-Fl. 1(3): 883. 1893. This species originally reported on Nardus has been recorded by Dr. B. Kanouse on some sedge from Washington. No material seen." RANGE ^includes WA (Kanouse)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  minute; white; margin with long hairs in fascicles^, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white when fresh, with long hairs^, (Kanouse)
STEM  with stem^ (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on sedge^ (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-7 x 1 um^; paraphyses extending 30 um beyond the asci, broadly lanceolate; hairs turn violet in iodine solution, long, rough, septate, at the margin of the apothecium clustered in fascicles, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  originally reported on Nardus (mat-grass or nard)
SIMILAR  L. nardis is distinguished from other species on sedges by its small spores (Kanouse). Lachnum carneolum (Sacc.) Rehm is reported on grass: Rehm gives the spore size as similar to L. nardi but the original description gives the spores as considerably larger in both length and width, (Kanouse).
SOURCES  Kanouse(6), Seaver(2)
175
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnum pallideroseum  (Saut.) Rehm^  in Rab. Krypt.-Fl. 1(3) 885. 1893
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a delicate, stemmed cup with "vinaceous buff" spore-bearing upper surface, becoming rose red when dry, the external surface white from short rough hairs, growth on grass stems, and microscopic characters including large paraphyses.^ | It was reported from WA by Kanouse, and this description is based on that report. Seaver says "Reported on grasses from Washington. No material seen." RANGE ^includes WA (Kanouse)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  "This is a delicate, stipitate plant with the hymenium "vinaceous buff" when fresh. On drying in becomes rose red. The outside of the cup is white from the short rough hairs" ["vinaceous buff " is probably Ridgway color]
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white from the short, rough hairs^, (Kanouse)
STEM  stem present^ (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on grass stems (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-10 x 1.5 um^; "paraphyses are very large, prominent, and exceed the asci", (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pallid - rose-colored'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(6), Seaver(2)
176
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnum pulverulentus  (Lib.) P. Karst.^  Bidr. Kann. Finl. Nat. Folk 19: 175. 1871;  Dasyscyphus pulverulentus  (Lib.) Sacc. [as Dasyscypha];  Lachnella pulverulenta  (Lib.) Quel.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a bright yellow cup covered with short yellowish hairs, often with lumps of red resin at their tips, stem absent or very short, and growth on fallen conifer needles.^ |Dennis(1) is eloquent about the typical variety, "As viewed fresh, under a hand-lens, well developed specimens have a barbaric beauty reminiscent of the enamelled bronzes of the late Celtic period." RANGE ^Var. purpurascens was reported from WA (Kanouse as in description below). Lachnum pulverulentus is also found in NJ and MI, (Seaver, typical variety), Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen, typical variety), and the United Kingdom (Dennis, typical variety).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody small, bright canary yellow^, (Kanouse), 0.02-0.1cm across, at first spherical, opening and becoming cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface concave, whitish to yellow, (Seaver), 0.05-0.1cm across, bright yellow, (Hansen), disc yellow, up to 0.1cm across, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  with patches of bright red extraneous material that cling to the hairs, the hairs somewhat drawn together into bundles by the material adhering to them, the red material (which may be resinous in nature) becoming tinged violet on drying^, (Kanouse), lemon-yellow, clothed with hairs, (Seaver), bright yellow, covered with short yellow hairs, often each tipped by a lump of red resin, (Dennis)
STEM  without stem or with very short stem^, (Seaver), subsessile (Hansen, Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on fir needles, (Kanouse for Washington), scattered on fallen pine needles (Seaver)^, on fallen needles of Pinus (Hansen for Scandinavia), on fallen pine needles, in spring and fall, (Dennis for United Kingdom)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  "The spores of this variety are slightly smaller than those reported for typical material. They measure 4-6 x 1.5 um as compared with 5-8 x 1.5-2 um in the typical variety."^, (Kanouse), spores 5-8 x 1.5-2 um, fusoid; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 30-50 um and a width of 3-4 um, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], 2 um wide; hairs reaching a length of 30-90 um and a width of 4-5 um, rough, yellow, often with yellowish-brown masses at tips, (Seaver), spores 4-5 x 1 um, cylindric to clavate, aseptate; asci 30-40 x 3-4 um; paraphyses exceeding asci by 5-10 um, narrowly lanceolate, 2 um wide; hairs 50-70 x 3-4 um, cylindric, fairly thick-walled, colorless, without apical crystals but often with lumps of resin, (Hansen), spores 4-5 x 1 um, somewhat clavate, biseriate; asci 8-spored, 40 x 4 um, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses usually longer than asci, very slender, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pulverulent' (powdery)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(6) (as Dasyscypha pulverulenta), Dennis(1) (as Dasyscyphus pulverulentus), Seaver(2) (as Lachnella pulverulenta), Hansen, L.(1)
177
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnum pygmaeum  (Fr.) Bres.^  Fungi Polonici Ann. Mycol. 1903 p.120;  Dasyscyphus pygmaeus  (Fr.) Sacc. [as Dasyscypha];  Lachnella pygmaea  (Fr.) W. Phillips
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a yellow to whitish or dull orange cup with white downy hairs on the exterior and margin, disc that is yellow to orange, slender stem, and clustered growth just at or below ground level on plant debris and wood.^ | Haines(1) says it is a fairly common fungus in western Washington. It is one of the larger members of the genus in North America. RANGE ^It is "found throughout northern US and southern Canada", and also in Europe, (Seaver). It was reported by Oluna Ceska near Nanaimo BC (determined by J. Ginns from British Cup Fungi and their Allies by Dennis). Haines(1) reported it from WA in his Master's thesis.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 0.2-0.4cm across, 0.2-0.7cm high, at first funnel-shaped, then spreading and flat; spore-bearing upper surface pale yellow to deep yellow, often varying toward orange or apricot, retaining the color when dried or becoming more ochraceous; margin rather blunt, when dried becoming somewhat elevated above the spore-bearing surface, finely and obscurely puberulent [downy]^, (Seaver), cup-shaped becoming expanded to expose a yellow disc up to 0.4cm across, (Dennis), fruitbody 0.2-0.4cm wide, white to yellowish, drying yellow, (Hansen), fruitbody 0.10-0.15cm across, disc flat or shallowly cup-shaped; light yellow, (Haines)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale yellow to flesh-color, or dull orange, more or less whitish-puberulent, often appearing smooth when dried^, (Seaver), clothed with fine downy hairs (Dennis), white, drying yellow; "scantily covered with short, white appearing hairs that tend to fall off at maturity", (Haines)
STEM  slender, flexuous [wavy], usually somewhat thickened just below the disc^, (Seaver), usually long and slender (Dennis), 0.3-0.7cm long, (Hansen), long-stemmed (Haines)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "gregarious or cespitose, typically occurring in a few cespitose clusters of five to ten each, surrounded by a few growing singly", "arising at ground level on partly buried plant debris of all sorts, especially on roots and rhizomes of grasses and other herbaceous plants" and on limbs of both hardwood and coniferous trees^, (Seaver), clustered or gregarious "on dead wood or branches just covered by soil or on dead roots and grass rhizomes, often on Ulex", in spring and fall, (Dennis), on buried dead branches, roots and rhizomes, (Hansen), "usually found on roots or other partially buried wood" (Haines)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-11 x 1.9-2.4 um, "narrow, broadest just above the middle, slightly tapering toward a point, at the lower end, round, or only slightly pointed above, straight", 1-celled, biseriate^; asci 60-75 x 4.5-6 um, cylindric; paraphyses protruding above the asci, 3-4.5 um wide, more or less lance-pointed, septate; hairs 20-50 um long, 4-6 um wide, clavate, rough, hyaline-white, 1-2-septate, (Seaver), spores 7-12 x 1.5-2.5 um, narrowly fusiform, non-septate, biseriate; asci 8-spored, up to 70 x 6 um, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses much longer than asci, 5 um wide, lanceolate; hairs up to 40 x 5 um, (Dennis), spores 7-12 x 1.5-2.5 um, cylindric to fusoid, aseptate; asci 60-75 x 4.5-6 um; paraphyses exceeding the asci by 15-25 um, 4-5 um wide; hairs 20-45 x 3-4 um, cylindric, thin-walled, colorless, without apical crystals, (Hansen), spores (6)7-9(10) x 2 um, "clavate, pointed at one end, sometimes very slightly curved", colorless, "non-septate, usually without conspicuous inclusions, obliquely oriented in the ascus"; asci 6-8-spored, 50-55 x 4-5 um, cylindric with a long, tapering, thick stalk; lanceolate paraphyses 2.5-3.5 um at widest part, exceeding the asci by up to 25 um, "usually without conspicuous, granular contents, septa, when present, only in the lower portion"; hairs 2.5-3.0 um wide, up to 50 um long, "with a slightly bulbous tip" up to 6 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, "septate, finely but distinctly granulate on the surface, no crystal masses were observed at the tips", (Haines)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'dwarf'
SIMILAR  Capitotricha bicolor is more or less stemless. Lachnum virgineum has similar hairs but L. pygmaeum is much larger and almost bald at maturity, and has long-stalked asci, (Haines(1)).
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Lachnella pygmaea (Fr.) Phill.), Dennis(1) (as Dasyscyphus pygmaeus (Fr.) Sacc.), Hansen, L.(1), Haines(1) (as Dasyscyphus pygmaeus)
178
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lachnum virgineum  (Batsch) P. Karst.^  Bidr. Kann. Finl. Nat. Folk 19: 169. 1871;  Dasyscyphus virgineus  (Batsch) Gray [as Dasyscypha];  Lachnella virginea  (Batsch) W. Phillips
ENGLISH NAME(S)  stalked hairy fairy cup
NOTES  Features include a minute white cup thickly set on exterior and margin with white hairs, white hairy stem, growth on dead branches, twigs, canes, wood, cones, nutshells and plant stems, and microscopic characters including conspicuous lanceolate paraphyses.^ | Haines(1) described a provisional variety exiguus in his Master's thesis which occurs on Pteridium aquilinum sensu lato (bracken fern) in Washington and is distinctly smaller in all its features including hairs (up to 50 um), asci (30-35 um), spores (5-8 x 1-1.5 um), and paraphyses (4-5 um wide, up to 15 um longer than asci). The cup is up to 0.05cm across, stem up to 0.1cm long. Haines says that Dennis mentions 2 smaller collections [of Lachnum virgineum] on Pteridium aquilinum. Lachnum virgineum is very common in the Pacific Northwest (Trudell(4)). RANGE ^It is widely distributed in North America and is also found in Europe. It is reported specifically for WA by Kanouse and there are collections (as Dasyscyphus virgineus) from WA at the University of Washington. There are several collections at Cornell Plant Pathology Herbarium for OR. There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre and (as Dasyscyphus virgineus) at University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.1cm across, goblet-shaped when young, remaining cup-shaped for a long time, finally plate-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface white to cream, smooth; margin white and thickly set with white hairs^, (Breitenbach), cup-shaped, disc up to 0.1cm across, cream, (Dennis), 0.05-0.2cm across, (Hansen), up to 0.1cm across (Haines)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white and thickly set with white hairs^, (Breitenbach), white and covered with white hairs, (Dennis), white, drying white or pale ochraceous, (Hansen)
STEM  0.05-0.1cm long, distinct^, (Breitenbach), long stem (Dennis), with stem (Hansen), 0.15-0.3cm long, densely covered with long white hairs, (Phillips), up to 0.1cm long (Haines)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  no (Phillips)
HABITAT  gregarious to densely cespitose on dead branches and twigs, canes of Rubus (blackberry), beechnut shells, cones, etc.; throughout the year but especially in spring^, (Breitenbach), on "many kinds of substrates such as wood, woody stems, cupules, cones and leaves", (Hansen), "scattered or in large groups on dead wood, twigs, and plant stems", April to June, September to October, (Phillips), primarily on hardwood debris (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-8 x 1.5-2 um, fusiform to fusiform-clavate, smooth, colorless, without drops, uniseriate, not septate^; asci 8-spored, 45 x 3.5-4 um; paraphyses projecting beyond asci, 55 x 2.5-3 um, lanceolate; hairs colorless, "thin-walled, encrusted, septate, tips blunt to slightly clavate", according to Dennis less than 120 um long, (Breitenbach), spores 6-10 x 1.5-2.5 um, fusiform or clavate, non-septate; asci 8-spored, up to 55 x 5 um, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses considerably longer than asci, lanceolate, up to 5 um wide, (Dennis), spores 6-11 x 1.5-2.5 um, fusoid, aseptate; asci 45-55 x 4-5 um; paraphyses exceeding asci by 10-25 um, 4-5 um wide, lanceolate; hairs 80-120 x 3-4.5 um, "cylindric or with clavate to capitate apex, thin-walled", colorless, without apical crystals, (Hansen), spores 6-10 x 2 um; asci 40-50 x 3.5-4 um; paraphyses 3.5-4 um wide, up to 15 um longer than the asci; hairs up to 100 x 3.5-4 um, (Haines)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Lachnum pygmaeum has similar hairs but is much larger and almost bald at maturity, and has long-stalked asci, (Haines(1)). |Dasyscyphella nivea (R. Hedw.) Raitv. is similar or the same species as L. virgineum: Seaver gives Lachnum niveum Karst. as a synonym of Lachnella virginea (Batsch) Phill. saying that none of the characters used to differentiate the two species appear to have any particular value (Phillips in British Discomycetes uses lanceolate paraphyses in L. virgineum, Rehm says they both have lanceolate paraphyses and uses other criteria, Gillet uses the form of the cup or length of hairs). However, the differentiation is maintained by such modern authors as Hansen, L.(1), Dennis(1), and Breitenbach(1) as follows. Lachnum virgineum has hairs that are granulose at apex, whereas Dasyscyphella nivea has the apical 1-3 cells(s) of hairs smooth, also paraphyses of Lachnum virgineum are lanceolate, whereas those of Dasyscyphella nivea are cylindric to narrowly lanceolate, (Hansen). Lachnum virgineum has lanceolate paraphyses considerably longer than the asci, whereas Dasyscyphella nivea has filiform paraphyses, scarcely longer than the asci, as well as a different type of hairs on exterior, (Dennis). Lachnum virgineum has lanceolate paraphyses, hairs with blunt to slightly clavate tips, and grows on dead branches and twigs, Rubus canes, beechnut shells, cones, etc. but Dasyscyphella nivea has filiform paraphyses, hairs with slightly clavate and smooth tips, sometimes with the remains of an exudate, and grows primarily on wood, mostly oak, (Breitenbach). Kanouse records both species from WA without making clear what criteria she used to separate them: her collection of Lachnum niveum on Rubus species has lanceolate paraphyses, (Kanouse), characters that fit the modern concept of Lachnum virgineum better than Dasyscyphella nivea: the presence of Dasyscyphella nivea in the Pacific Northwest remains uncertain. |Lachnum brevipilosum has been identified by O. Ceska and deposited at the University of British Columbia. Haines(1) also examined L. brevipilosum from western Washington. He says it is related to L. virgineum, but differs in its shorter hairs measuring 40-50(70) um long, smaller spores measuring 5 x 3.5-4 um (clavate), and yellower hymenium (drying to light yellow), and does not have the ragged appearance of L. virgineum. |Haines(1) examined 2 collections from Washington State of Dasyscyphus pudicellus (current name Lachnum tenuissimum (Quel.) Korf & W.Y. Zhuang) on grasses. He said the short-stemmed cups were up to 0.5cm across, entirely cream-white "densely covered with short, white glassy-appearing hairs", the spores 7-10 x 1.5-2.0 um, fusiform to naviculate, the broadly lanceolate paraphyses 4-5 um at widest point, exceeding asci by up to 25 um, hairs 35-65 x 2.5-3.0 um, conspicuously swollen at tip to 4.5-5.0 um, finely granulate for their full length. |Haines(1) also reported a collection of Lachnum roridum (as Dasyscyphus roridus), on thimbleberry stems, "made distinctive by large crystal formations on the tips of its hairs, and by the large size of its paraphyses". He says the short-stemmed cups are up to 0.07cm across, cream-colored on disc and exterior, the exterior densely covered by white-appearing hairs, the spores 6-8(1) x 1.5-2.0 um, narrowly fusiform, the broadly lanceolate paraphyses 4-6 um wide at widest point, 70-100 um long, exceeding asci by up to 50 um, and colorless, the hairs 50-70 x 4.5-5.0 um, usually capped by crystal masses up to 7 um across, cylindric, "sometimes with very slightly enlarged tips", colorless, "thin-walled, finely but conspicuously roughened", 1 or 2 septate. |See also Psilachnum inquilinum on Equisetum under Roseodiscus subcarneus. 
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Dasyscyphus virgineus S.F. Gray), Hansen, L.(1), Dennis(1) (as Dasyscyphus virgineus S.F. Gray), Seaver(2) (as Lachnella virginea), Phillips(1)* (as Dasyscyphus virgineus), Lincoff(2)* (as Dasyscyphus virgineus), Kanouse(6), Trudell(4) (as Dasyscyphus virgineus), Haines(1) (as Dasyscyphus virgineus)
179
FAMILY  Rutstroemiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lambertella pruni  Whetzel & Zeller^  Lloydia 6: 40. 1943
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a brown fruitbody with a flat or concave spore-bearing upper surface; a fringed brown margin; a furfuraceous exterior; a stem that if present is short, constricted at the attachment, and black at the base; and growth on a thin black crust on mummified fruit and seedlings of sweet cherry.^ RANGE ^It was described from Salem OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.15cm wide when mature, with flat or convex spore-bearing upper surface; pale brown, darker when old; margin fringed with short hyphal tips and brown in color
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  furfuraceous
STEM  short-stemmed or without a stem, stem when present "sharply constricted at point of attachment and black at the base", arising from stroma that consists of "a thin, wrinkled, black crust surrounding the host"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious, as many as a hundred springing from a single fruit, on mummified fruits and seedlings of Prunus avium (sweet cherry)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-15 x 7-8 um, lunate, with broad blunt ends, smooth, golden brown, becoming dark olivaceous brown at maturity, containing 2 oil droplets^, uniseriate; paraphyses branched, septate, slightly enlarged in upper part
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Prunus', referring to host
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2)
180
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lamprospora crechqueraultii  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan) Boud.^  Hist. Class. Discom. Eur. (Paris): 69. 1907;  Ramsbottomia crechqueraultii  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan)  Benkert & T. Schumach.  Agarica 6(12): 33. 1985;  Sphaerospora perplexa  Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small saucer-shaped to flat, pale orange fruitbody that is minutely downy on the outer surface; absent stem; growth on clay soil; and microscopic characters including spiny round spores.^ RANGE ^Lamprospora crechqueraultii is found in OR, ID, and CO, (Larsen), WA (Kanouse), NY to DE, WV and CO, Europe, and Australia, (Seaver), Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen), and the United Kingdom (Dennis). 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.2-0.5cm, becoming disc-shaped to scutellate, margin indistinct; spore-bearing upper surface becoming flat or more often convex, pale orange fading to dirty yellow when dried^, (Seaver), up to 0.5cm across, saucer-shaped; disc convex, light orange; margin scarcely toothed, (Dennis), fruitbody 0.1-0.3cm across, yellow, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  very pale orange; smooth^, (Seaver), pale orange, colored as upper surface; minutely downy, (Dennis)
STEM  without stem^ (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on clayey soil^, (Seaver), on wet clay soils, June to October, (Dennis), on bare soil, in wheel tracks, etc., fall, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-25 um in diameter including ornamentation of very sharp spines, at first smooth before becoming spiny, the spines broad at the base, reaching 2-3 um long, "in dried specimens often bent or adpressed but regaining their normal form when wet", spores colorless, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, often protruding above the surface of the hymenium, reaching a length of 300-325 um and a width of 27 um, cylindric or subcylindric in upper part; paraphyses rather stout, reaching 3-4 um wide in lower part, widened in upper part and often reaching 10 um wide at tips; excipulum of large roundish cells on lower part and giving rise to a palisade of mycelium in upper part, "the loose ends of which are club-shaped, reaching a diameter of 17-18 um", (Seaver), spores 16-19 um in diameter, round, with spines 1-2 um long, containing several oil droplets; asci up to 300 x 26 um; paraphyses straight, slightly widened upwards to about 5-6 um at tip; hairs "up to 60-15 um long" [sic], 2-3 celled, thin-walled, obtuse [blunt], (Dennis), spores 18-20 x 18-20 um, with spines 1-2 um long and wide (illustrated), (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Lamprospora miniata has reticulated spores. Seaver(1) lists 20 Lamprospora species for North America, Hansen, L.(1) lists 19 for Scandinavia, and Dennis(1) lists 6 for United Kingdom: these sources and the references in Hansen, L.(1) should be consulted for small orange to red discs growing on moss, with dentate margin, bald exterior, and round spores with warty, spiny, or reticulate ornamentation that dissolves in KOH. Lamprospora polytrichina (Rehm) Seaver and Lamprospora spinulosa Seaver are two described in Seaver(1) that have been reported for the Pacific Northwest (see Larsen(1), but neither author confirmed its presence, and they are not listed in the PezWeb preliminary checklist of North American Pezizales which emphasizes western species).
SOURCES  Seaver(1), Dennis(1), Kanouse(6), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1) (as Ramsbottomia crechqueraultii)
181
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lamprospora miniata  De Not.^  Comm. Soc. crittog. Ital. 1(fasc. 5): 388 (1863) [1864];  Lamprospora crouanii  (Cooke) Seaver  Mycologia 6: 8. 1914
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  This species remains needs confirmation for the Pacific Northwest; nevertheless, a number of Lamprospora species probably do occur (see SIMILAR). Features of this species include a small bright orange disc with a whitish fringe-like margin and pale orange exterior, absent stem, growth on damp soil usually among mosses, and microscopic characters including round spores with a mesh pattern and stout paraphyses.^ RANGE ^Lamprospora miniata is found in WA and CO, (Larsen, but occurrence not confirmed by either author). It was not included in the PezWeb preliminary checklist of North American Pezizales (which emphasizes western species). It is found from NY to CO and Bermuda, Europe, and Australia, (Seaver), Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen), and the United Kingdom (Dennis). 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.3-0.5cm across, but often not exceeding 0.1cm, at first spherical, expanding and becoming disc-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface becoming flat or a little concave, bright reddish orange; with a whitish fringe-like border^, (Seaver), up to 0.5cm across, saucer-shaped; disc convex, orange; margin dentate, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale orange^, (Seaver), light orange; pruinose, (Dennis)
STEM  without stem^ (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or crowded on damp soil, usually among mosses^, (Seaver), "among Tortula ruraliformis, T. intermedia etc., on sandy soils and old walls", November to April, (Dennis for United Kingdom), growing with/on various mosses, e.g. Barbula, Tortula, and Encalypta, (Hansen for Scandinavia)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores reaching a 18-22 um in diameter including sculpturing, at first smooth, colorless, containing 1 oil droplet that nearly fills the spore, finally becoming sculptured with reticulations, the meshes of the reticulations ranging from 2-4 or rarely 5-6 um across, "3-6-sided, often giving rise to almost perfect hexagonal figures, the ridges of the reticulations less than 1 um thick and shallow as indicated by the projections about the periphery of the spore", uniseriate^; asci reaching a length of 350 um and a width of 20-26 um, cylindric or subcylindric in upper part, tapering in lower part into a stem 7-8 um wide; paraphyses stout, about 5 or 6 um wide in lower part, widened in upper part and reaching a width of 9 um at tip, filled with minute orange granules; "excipulum composed of a palisade of parallel or rather loosely interwoven, closely septate, and strongly swollen mycelium, the loose ends of which project above, giving rise to the whitish border", the palisade mycelial threads clavate, reaching a width of 10-12 um, often delicately roughened, (Seaver), spores 17-19 um in diameter, round, containing one large oil droplet, "ornamented with a coarse-meshed reticulum, the meshes 3-6 um across", uniseriate; asci up to 260 x 25 um; paraphyses straight, slightly widened upward to 5 um at tip, (Dennis), spores more or less round, 14-16 um in diameter, with 5-8 meshes across, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means "red lead colored"
SIMILAR  Lamprospora crechqueraultii has spiny spores. Seaver(1) lists 20 Lamprospora species for North America, Hansen, L.(1) lists 19 for Scandinavia, and Dennis(1) lists 6 for United Kingdom: these sources and the references in Hansen, L.(1) should be consulted for small orange to red discs growing on moss, with dentate margin, bald exterior, and round spores with warty, spiny, or reticulate ornamentation that dissolves in KOH. Lamprospora polytrichina (Rehm) Seaver and Lamprospora spinulosa Seaver are two described in Seaver(1) that have been reported for the Pacific Northwest (see Larsen(1), but neither author confirmed its presence, and they are not listed in the PezWeb preliminary checklist of North American Pezizales which emphasizes western species).
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as Lamprospora crouanii), Dennis(1) (as Lamprospora crouanii), Larsen(1) (as Lamprospora crouanii), Hansen, L.(1), PezWeb(1) (does not include)
182
FAMILY  Rutstroemiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lanzia luteovirescens  (Roberge ex Desm.) Dumont & Korf^  Mycotaxon 7(2): 185. 1978;  Rutstroemia luteovirescens  (Roberge ex Desm.) W.L. White;  Hymenoscyphus luteovirescens  (Roberge ex Desm.) W. Phillips;  Ciboria luteovirescens  (Roberge ex Desm.) Sacc.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small fruitbody that is olivaceous yellow-buff throughout, with a cup-shaped or flat upper surface, relatively long stem, growth from blackened patches on the petioles of leaves, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Lanzia luteovirescens is found in WA, (Phillips), Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen), Switzerland (Breitenbach), and the United Kingdom (Dennis). There are collections from BC by Oluna Ceska at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.4cm across, disc concave then flattened, olivaceous yellow-buff^, (Phillips), 0.1-0.3cm, cup-shaped to flat; pale greenish yellow, (Hansen), 0.2-0.3cm, flat saucer-shaped to plate-shaped; yellow-olive; smooth, (Breitenbach), pallid greenish yellow (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  olivaceous yellow-buff, similar to upper surface, smooth and slightly striate^, (Phillips), brownish (Hansen), yellow-olive, same color as upper surface, (Breitenbach)
STEM  up to 1.2cm long, slightly striate^, (Phillips), 0.5-1.5 x 0.05-0.1cm, (Hansen), up to about 1cm long, cylindric and slightly bent; the same color as the underside, (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  no (Phillips)
HABITAT  growing from blackened patches on stems of fallen sycamore leaves, September to October^, (Phillips), "arising from stromatized patches of host tissues without a clear stromatal rind", singly on petioles of fallen leaves of Acer (maple), Tilia (linden), Fagus (beech), and Quercus (oak), summer and fall, (Hansen), single or gregarious from blackened places in substrate, on rotting petioles of Acer, September to October, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT
