MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-15 x 5-7 um, elliptic, slightly pointed at each end, often containing 2 oil drops^; asci 150 x 12 um, (Phillips), spores 12-16 x 5-7 um, colorless, with 2 droplets, non-septate to 2-septate; asci 120-150 x 10-12 um; outer excipulum "of thin-walled prismatic cells (textura prismatica), without a gelatinous matrix", (Hansen), spores 12-13 x 6-7 um, irregularly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 2 droplets, uniseriate, not septate; asci 8-spored, 150 x 10-12 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses filiform, with slight clavate thickenings toward tip up to 3 um, (Breitenbach), pore of ascus turning blue in iodine; paraphyses cylindric, 4 um thick toward tip, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'yellow becoming green' or 'yellow-greenish'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Phillips(1)* (as Rutstroemia luteovirescens), Hansen, L.(1), Breitenbach(1)* (as Rutstroemia luteovirescens), Dennis(1) (as Rutstroemia luteovirescens)
183
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lasiobelonium corticale  (Pers.) Raitv.^  Scripta Mycologica, Tartu 9: 106. 1980;  Dasyscyphus corticalis  (Pers.)  Massee;  Lachnella corticalis  (Pers.) Fr.;  Helotium corticale  (Pers.) P. Karst.;  Lachnum corticale  (Pers.) Nannf.;  Belonidium corticale  (Fr.) Raitv.;  Lachnella canescens  (Cooke) W. Phillips;  Dasyscyphus canescens  Massee [as Dasyscypha];  Dasyscyphus borealis  Sacc. [as Dasyscypha]
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute cup thickly set on the outside and the margin with light-colored hairs that may have a crystalline appearance, the upper spore-bearing surface pale yellow to pinkish ocher; absent or very short stem; growth on hardwood; and microscopic characters, including large spores, large asci, and narrow paraphyses.^ RANGE ^Lasiobelonium corticale is found from NY to MB, WA and CO, and also in Europe, (Seaver), Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen), Bulgaria (Dimitrova), and Switzerland (Breitenbach).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 0.05-0.1cm, cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface flesh-colored to pale pink-ocher, smooth; margin thickly set with light hairs^, (Breitenbach), reaching 0.1cm across, at first closed and nearly spherical, expanding to shallow cup-shaped with mouth constricted; spore-bearing upper surface concave, cream or yellowish, (Seaver), hemispheric; disc 0.02-0.08cm across, pale-yellow, (Dimitrova), fruitbody 0.05-0.15cm across, spore-bearing upper surface pale, (Hansen), up to 0.15cm across, "saucer-shaped when fresh, closing to cup-shaped when dry"; disc gray-brown, (Haines)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  thickly set with light hairs^, (Breitenbach), densely clothed with grayish hairs that may change to yellowish, or brownish when old, the hairs often with a crystalline appearance, (Seaver), covered with pale-beige to brown hairs, (Dimitrova), hairs brown (Hansen), gray-brown, "covered with whitish to light brown hairs", (Haines)
STEM  without stem or stem very short^, (Breitenbach, Hansen), without stem or stem short (Seaver), sessile or subsessile, (Dimitrova), sessile or with a very short stem (Haines)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregariously in groups on dead hardwood, "bare or still with bark, and on rootstocks, usually growing in cracks and on undersurfaces"^, (Breitenbach), thickly gregarious on bark of various hardwoods, (Seaver), single or in groups on rotten hardwood, (Dimitrova), on hardwood (Hansen), apparently a spring species that occurs on hardwood bark, especially of Acer macrophyllum (Bigleaf Maple), (Haines)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores variable in size, 14-20 x 4-4.5 um, fusiform [spindle-shaped], smooth, colorless, with 1 septum and several droplets, biseriate^; asci 8-spored, variable in size, 80-100 x 6-10 um, positive reaction in iodine; paraphyses projecting beyond asci, filiform [thread-like], septate; hairs slightly brownish, colorless toward tip, thin-walled, multiply septate and sparsely encrusted with +/- sharp tip, (Breitenbach), spores about 15-20 x 4 um, or rarely as long as 30 um, fusoid, slightly curved, obliquely biseriate, often with a row of oil droplets, giving the spore a pseudoseptate appearance, or often 1-septate; asci reaching a length of 100 um and a width of 10 um, clavate, tapering in lower part; paraphyses projecting far beyond the asci, cylindric in lower part, semiacute at tips, 2-3 um wide; hairs reaching a length of 100-150 um and a width of 3-4 um at base, gradually narrowing, semiacute, septate, pale yellow in lower part, colorless toward tip, "the hairs often tipped with masses of minute, rod-like bodies" that give them a crystalline appearance, (Seaver), spores 8-12.5 x 2-2.5(3) um, elliptic-fusiform, colorless, unicellular, with 1 septum when mature, obliquely uniseriate in the ascus; asci 8-spored, 62.5-95 x 5-8 um, cylindric-clavate, with rounded tips and a small iodine-blue pore; paraphyses slightly longer than the asci, acuminate at the tips, 1.5-2 um wide; hairs 120-185 x 3.5-4 um, cylindric, septate, tapering towards the tip, apically colorless, covered with fine baculate grains, (Dimitrova), spores 18-24 x 3.5-4 um, clavate, slightly curved, tardily 1-septate; asci 83-102 x 7.5-9 um; paraphyses exceeding asci by up to 17 um, 1.5-3 um wide, cylindric to narrowly lanceolate; hairs 115-165 x 3-4 um, slightly tapering, brownish, tip colorless, (Hansen), spores 12-18 x 2.5-4 um, short-fusiform or elliptic, 0-1 septate, often with 1 or 2 large droplets, "which sometimes grow to fill the entire cell", "irregularly biseriate in the ascus"; asci 8-spored, 7-10 um wide, up to 50-90 um long, stalk very short; paraphyses 2-3 um wide, exceeding the asci by up to 10 um, filiform or narrowly lanceolate, "usually nonseptate, hyaline, and without conspicuous inclusions"; hairs 2.5-3.5 um wide, up to 140 um long, "golden brown, color located in the cell walls, thin-walled but stiff, sparsely roughened by large, adhering granules, or smooth, cylindrical, but tapering slightly toward the tip", tip rounded, no crystal masses observed, multiseptate, septa forming cells 8-14 um long, (Haines)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to bark
SIMILAR  Lasiobelonium nidulum (J.C. Schmidt & Kunze) Spooner (one collection) was examined from western Washington on Rubus sp. (Haines(1) as Dasyscyphus nidulus). He says the sessile cups were up to 0.2cm across, the exterior with long, stiff, red-brown hairs, the disc white but drying to cream, spores 10-14 x 1.5-2 um, paraphyses 4.5-5.5 um wide, exceeding asci by up to 20 um, broadly lanceolate, hairs up to 200 um long, tapering slightly toward blunt tip, sparsely covered with orange-red granules up to 1 um in diam that dissolve in water, hairs moderately to very thick-walled, most of the golden brown to dark brown color in the cell interior.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Dasyscyphus corticalis), Seaver(2) (as Lachnella corticalis), Hansen, L.(1), Dimitrova(1) (as Dasyscyphus corticalis), Haines(1) (as Dasyscyphus corticalis)
184
FAMILY  Ascodesmidaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lasiobolus cuniculi  Velen.^  Monogr. Discom. Bohem. 1: 363. 1934;  = Lasiobolus leporinus  Velen.;  = Lasiobolus brachytrichus  Velen.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute (less than 0.1cm) yellowish fruiting body that is obconic to cup-shaped, with stiff setae arising from the lower and median parts of receptacle, growth on dung, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Lasiobolus cuniculi was found in ID and OR (atypical specimens in each case), and also ON, CA, CO, CT, FL, NY, WY, Bermuda, Mexico, Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Switzerland, and the Ukraine (Bezerra). There are collections by O. Ceska from BC at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.02-0.07cm wide, 0.025-0.04cm high, obconic to cup-shaped, disc flat, yellowish
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  colored as disc, stiff setae arising from lower and median parts of fruitbody
STEM  absent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on dung of rabbit, hare, sheep, goat, raccoon, cow, horse, and other animals
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (16)18-24(26) x (9)12-14(16) um, elliptic, rounded at both ends, more or less colorless, smooth-walled, each with a conspicuous deBary bubble, biseriate or obliquely uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 100-215 x 19-36 um, broadly clavate, rounded in upper part, abruptly constricted in lower part, short pedicellate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, simple or branched, slightly inflated to 3.0-4.5 um at apices, shown in diagram as straight or curved at top; setae 100-450 um long and 10-24 um wide at widest part
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Lasiobolus ciliatus has asci that are cylindric or clavate-cylindric, and setae that are ventricose and up to 42 um wide at base, whereas L. cuniculi has asci that are broadly clavate, and setae that are subventricose and up to 24 um wide at the base, (Bezerra). Lasiobolus papillatus has wider asci and narrower setae (Bezerra). Lasiobolus lasioboloides and Lasiobolus intermedius have smaller spores (Bezerra). Lasiobolus macrotrichus and Lasiobolus ruber have longer setae (Bezerra).
SOURCES  Bezerra(1)
185
FAMILY  Ascodesmidaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lasiobolus intermedius  J.L. Bezerra & Kimbr.^  Can. J. Bot. 53: 1218. 1975
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute yellow fruitbody with stiff setae arising from the lower and median region of the exterior, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Lasiobolus intermedius is found in WA, ID, and also ON, PQ, CO, WY, Sweden, Switzerland, and New Zealand, (Bezerra).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.021-0.047cm, disc flat, yellow, rough, without margins, receptacle obconic to turbinate [top-shaped]
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  colored as disc, stiff setae arising from lower and median region
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to crowded, on dung of moose, horse, deer, elk, opossum, sheep, muskox, and porcupine
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13.0-18.0 x 7.5-11.5 um, elliptic, rounded at both ends, often collapsed at one side, smooth-walled, colorless, each with prominent deBary bubble, uniseriate to biseriate in upper part^; asci 8-spored, (90)120-160(180) x 14-20 um, clavate cylindric, rounded or truncate at top, narrowed in lower part, with stem; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, simple or branched, slightly inflated to 2-3 um at apices; setae 200-522 um long and 12-30 um wide at widest part, non-septate, pointed, slightly ventricose at bases
NAME ORIGIN  refers to intermediate size of spores between large-spored species such as L. papillatus and L. diversisporus and small-spored species like L. microsporus and L. trichoboloides
SIMILAR  Lasiobolus papillatus has larger fruiting bodies, spores and asci. Lasiobolus lasioboloides has cylindric setae. Lasiobolus macrotrichus, Lasiobolus ruber, Lasiobolus cuniculi, and Lasiobolus papillatus have longer spores.
SOURCES  Bezerra(1)
186
FAMILY  Ascodesmidaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lasiobolus lasioboloides  Marchal^  Mem. Soc. Bot. Belgique. 24: 68-69. 1885
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute whitish to yellow fruiting body, with stiff setae arising from lower and median areas of its exterior, growth on dung, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Lasiobolus lasioboloides found in OR, and also AB, CO, and WY, (Bezerra).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  (0.021)0.03-0.075cm, disc convex or flat, whitish to yellow, without margins, receptacle spherical at first, then cushion-shaped
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  colored as disc, stiff setae arising superficially from lower and median areas
STEM  absent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to gregarious on dung of moose, deer, rat, elk, sheep, and goat
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-18 x 9-13.5 um, broadly elliptic, rounded at both ends, smooth-walled, colorless, each with a deBary bubble, biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 75-115 x 18-30 um, clavate cylindric, rounded in upper part, narrowed in lower part, short-pedicellate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, sometimes branched, slightly inflated to 1.5-2.0 um at apices; setae (25)65-192 um long by 5-9 um wide at widest part, needle-like, sharp, straight, not ventricose, non-septate
NAME ORIGIN  means "appearing like a Lasiobolus"
SIMILAR  other Lasiobolus species have larger or smaller spores or have setae that are somewhat ventricose at base. See also SIMILAR section of Lasiobolus cuniculi, Lasiobolus intermedius, Lasiobolus macrotrichus, Lasiobolus papillatus, and Lasiobolus ruber.
SOURCES  Bezerra(1)
187
FAMILY  Ascodesmidaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lasiobolus macrotrichus  Rea^  Trans. Brit. Mycol. Soc. 16: 440. 1917;  = Lasiobolus longisetosus  Povah
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute (< 0.1cm) pale orange to tan fruiting body, long bristles on the exterior to 0.1cm or more long, growth on dung, and microscopic details.^ | The description is derived from Bezerra(1). RANGE ^Lasiobolus macrotrichus is found in OR (Larsen), ON, MI, MT, NY, PA, WY, Czechoslovakia, Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland, and New Zealand, (Bezerra).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  (0.03)0.042-0.08(0.1)cm, disc flat, without distinct margins, pale orange to tan, receptacle obconic to funnel-shaped
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  colored as disc, bristle-like setae arising superficially from lower and median areas of receptacle exterior
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to crowded on dung of various animals
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (15)17-22(24) x (5.5)9.0-12.0(13.5) um, elliptic, rounded at both ends, smooth, colorless, each with a conspicuous deBary bubble, obliquely uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 110-240 x 15-27 um, cylindric, rounded or truncate in upper part, narrowing in lower part, usually long pedicellate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, branched, slightly inflated to 2-3 um wide at apices; setae 300-1000(1380) um long and 20-48 um wide at widest part, straight, pointed, ventricose, non-septate, walls smooth and 3.0-7.5 um thick
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the long setae
SIMILAR  Lasiobolus ruber has larger somewhat spindle-shaped spores. Lasiobolus lasioboloides, Lasiobolus intermedius, Lasiobolus cuniculi, and Lasiobolus ciliatus have shorter setae. See also SIMILAR section of Lasiobolus papillatus.
SOURCES  Bezerra(1), Larsen(1)
188
FAMILY  Ascodesmidaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lasiobolus papillatus  (Pers.) Sacc.^  Bot. Centralbl. 18: 220. 1884;  = Lasiobolus ciliatus  (J.C. Schmidt ex Pers.) Boud.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute (less than 0.1cm), light yellowish to orange fruiting body with roughened spore-bearing upper surface and setose outer surface, growth on dung, and microscopic characters.^ | PezWeb preliminary checklist of North American Pezizales (which emphasizes western species) includes this species. Bezerra(1) give Lasiobolus papillatus (Pers. ex Fr.) Sacc. among the synonyms for Lasiobolus ciliatus (Schmidt ex Pers.) Boud., but the online Species Fungorum, accessed February 3, 2017, listed Lasiobolus ciliatus (J.C. Schmidt) Boud. as a synonym of Lasiobolus papillatus (Pers.) Sacc. and MycoBank, accessed on the same date, listed Lasiobolus ciliatus (J.C. Schmidt) Boud. as an illegitimate name. The description here is derived from Bezerra(1) for Lasiobolus papillatus (Pers. ex Fr.) Sacc. RANGE ^Lasiobolus papillatus is found in OR, ID, and also AB, NU, NS, ON, PQ, YT, AL, CA, FL, GA, IN, IA, KS, MA, MT, ND, NJ, NY, OH, WY, Argentina, Bermuda, Brazil, Mexico, Venezuela, Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Germany, Great Britain, Italy, Sweden, and Switzerland (Bezerra(1)). Larsen also mentions AK, CO, and UT for Lasiobolus ciliatus. Adolf and Oluna Ceska reported it from BC on deer dung.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.03-0.075(0.09)cm, disc flat or convex, from light yellowish to orange, rough, receptacle at first spherical then turbinate [top-shaped], and finally cup-shaped or shallow funnel-shaped
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  of the same color as or paler than the disc, stiff setae arising from lower and median part of the receptacle
STEM  absent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on various kinds of dung, including human feces
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (17)19-25 x (9)12-14(15) um, elliptic, rounded at both ends, colorless, each with a prominent deBary bubble, smooth walled, uniseriate or biseriate^; asci 8-spored, (112)180-270 x 15-30 um, clavate-cylindric, rounded or truncate at top, narrowed in lower part to stem; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, branched, 2-2.5 um wide in lower part, slightly inflated to 2.5-3.5 um at top; setae 200-600 um long and (12)20-42 um wide at widest part, non-septate, pointed, distinctly ventricose at base 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'papillate'
SIMILAR  Lasiobolus cuniculi has broader asci and narrower setae. Lasiobolus diversisporus (Fuckel) Sacc. (found in WY, ON, South America, Europe) has larger spores (21.0)24.0-34.5 x 12.0-17.0(19.5) um that tend to be colored (unlike other Lasiobolus species). Lasiobolus intermedius has smaller fruiting bodies, spores and asci. Lasiobolus ruber and Lasiobolus macrotrichus have longer setae. Lasiobolus lasioboloides has smaller spores.
SOURCES  Bezerra(1), Larsen(1), PezWeb(1)
189
FAMILY  Ascodesmidaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Lasiobolus ruber  (Quel.) Sacc.^  Syll. Fung. 8: 537. 1889;  == Ascophanus ruber  Quel.;  = Lasiobolus capreoli  Velen.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute (<0.1cm) orange or reddish fruiting body with bristles on the exterior, growth on dung, and microscopic characters including somewhat spindle-shaped spores.^ | The description is derived from Bezerra(1). RANGE ^Lasiobolus ruber is found in WA, MI, and Czechoslovakia, (Bezerra). It was found in OR and CO (Larsen, but occurrence not confirmed by either author).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.03-0.09cm, disc flat, orange or reddish, without margins, rough, receptacle at first nearly spherical, becoming obconic or cup-shaped
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  colored as disc, bristly setae arising from the basal and median parts of the receptacle
STEM  absent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on dung of cow, deer, wapiti, goat, and wolf
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 22.5-30.0 x 9.0-13.5 um, elliptic to almost fusiform [spindle-shaped], narrowed at both ends, smooth, colorless, each with an obvious deBary bubble, uniseriate or biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 156-255 x 18-27 um, clavate cylindric, rounded or truncate in upper part, narrowed in lower part, pedicellate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], colorless, simple or branched, septate, 1.5-2 um wide in lower part and 4-5 um wide at inflated apices; setae 350-825 um long and 30-48 um wide at widest part, ventricose at the base, acute, non-septate, wall smooth and 3.0-7.5 um thick
NAME ORIGIN  means 'red'
SIMILAR  Lasiobolus lasioboloides has cylindric setae and smaller spores. Lasiobolus intermedius has smaller spores. Lasiobolus macrotrichus has shorter spores. Lasiobolus cuniculi and Lasiobolus papillatus have shorter setae.
SOURCES  Bezerra(1), Larsen(1)
190
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Legaliana badia  (Pers.) Van Vooren^  Ascomycete.org 12(4): 188. 2020;  Peziza badia  Pers. ex Merat  Nouv. Fl. Paris 2e ed. 1: 24. 1821
ENGLISH NAME(S)  red-brown cup, pig's ears, bay cup
NOTES  Long known as Peziza badia, its features include saucer-shaped, undulating cup with the upper surface olive-brown, thin fragile reddish brown flesh, reddish brown underside that is furfuraceous especially toward the margin, absent stem, growth on ground (rarely on wood), and microscopic characters including spores with a reticulum of longitudinal ridges.^ | The name Peziza badia has been used in the past for Phylloscypha phyllogena (see SIMILAR). RANGE ^Legaliana badia is found at least in BC, OR, ID, and also AB, MB, NF, NS, ON, PE, PQ, AK, CA, CO, CT, FL, IA, MA, ME, MI, MT, NJ, NY, TN, VA, VT, and WI, (Elliott, M.E.(2)), and BC, WA, OR, ID, AB, AK, CA, CO, and NM, (Larsen). It is widely distributed in northern North America as well as AL and CA, (Phillips).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  3-7(10)cm, saucer-shaped, irregularly undulating; spore-bearing upper surface dark olive-brown^, (Breitenbach), up to 8cm across, more or less cup-shaped but irregularly undulating when old; spore-bearing upper surface olive-brown, drying darker, (Dennis)
FLESH  thin, fragile; reddish brown^, (Breitenbach), thin, pale reddish brown with watery juice, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  reddish brown; furfuraceous, especially toward margin^, (Breitenbach), reddish brown, scurfy, especially toward margin, (Dennis)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach, Dennis)
ODOR  none in particular^ (Breitenbach)
TASTE  none in particular^ (Breitenbach)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on path embankments, in forests, on bare sandy ground, commonly on freshly broken sandy-loamy soils, June to October^, (Breitenbach), on ground in hardwood, coniferous or mixed woods, in two collections only from rotten or buried wood, (Elliott, M.E.(2)), on ground in woods, especially on sandy soil, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (15)17.5-18.5 x (8)10-11 um, elliptic, with irregular reticulate ornamentation, colorless, usually with 2 droplets^; asci 8-spored, 300-330 x (12)15 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses cylindric, septate, weakly clavate at tips, (Breitenbach), spores (14.0)15.3-20.0(21.5) x 7.6-9.6(11.0) um (average 17.5 x 9.0 um), "ornamented with short predominantly longitudinal ridges which unite to form an incomplete and irregular reticulum, ridges about 0.5 um in height, apiculus not seen", pale yellow-brown in IKI and the outer wall with a blue tinge, colorless to nearly colorless, in apical (110)125-140(180) um of ascus, uniseriate, (one-)two-guttulate; asci 8-spored, (250)270-335(365) x (13.5)15.0 um, cylindric, tapering slightly in lower part, forming a foot at the base, rounded to truncate at top, tip J+ in IKI and faint blue extending down ascus wall to third or fourth spore; paraphyses "not numerous, slightly longer than asci, septate, branched near base, slightly wider at tip, about 5.0 um, often slightly roughened at tip", (Elliott, M.E.(2)), spores 17-20 x 9-12 um, elliptic, ornamented with short ridges that tend to unite to form an irregular reticulum, mostly with 2 oil droplets but one often larger than the other; asci up to 330 x 15 um; paraphyses straight, slightly clavate, (Dennis) 
NAME ORIGIN  means "reddish-brown", from Latin, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
SIMILAR  Phylloscypha phyllogena (as P. badio-confusa Korf) was distinguished from L. badia in 1954 by Korf: speaking of P. badio-confusa Korf, he said, "This species is almost invariably determined in America as Peziza badia [name in italics], and certainly is that figured by Seaver... under this name. It is perhaps our commonest large cup-fungus, and it seems to me that it must have been described before 1897 by some European or American author, but I have seen no types which match it. The true P. badia [name in italics] has reticulate spore-markings, as shown by Le Gal". (Korf(5)). |Elliott & Kaufert in 1974 redescribed both of these species microscopically, refining the distinction between the two species: Phylloscypha phyllogena [as Peziza phyllogena] had spores with "walls finely roughened, with warts about 0.5 um in height, frequently smooth at ends of mature spores as primary wall remains attached (apiculus)" (with the letter mu used for um), whereas P. badia had spores "ornamented with short predominantly longitudinal ridges which unite to form an incomplete and irregular reticulum, ridges about 0.5 um in height, apiculus not seen"; if the fruitbody was found on downed wood rather than on the ground it was much more likely to be P. phyllogena although occasional collections of P. badia are found on wood, P. phyllogena was collected from May 18 to July 26 in Canada and from March 28 to June 25 in the US (excluding AK), [although Ginns examined a September 12 collection from ON and cites a September collection from AK], whereas P. badia was collected from July 18 to October 25 in Canada and from June 21 to October 5 in the US; P. phyllogena was examined from BC, ON, PQ, AK, MA, NY, MD, and PA. (Elliott, M.E.(2)). P. phyllogena was reported from BC, WA, OR, ID, CA, UT, (Larsen as P. badioconfusa). |See also SIMILAR section of Legaliana limnaea.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Peziza), Korf(5) (as Peziza), Elliott, M.E.(2) (as Peziza), Larsen(1) (as Peziza), Phillips(1)* (as Peziza), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)* (as Peziza), Miller(14)* (as Peziza), Courtecuisse(1)* (as Peziza), Dennis(1) (as Peziza), Pfister(5) (note 32) (as Peziza), Ginns(9) (discussing P. phyllogena as P. badioconfusa), Buczacki(1)* (as Peziza), Harmaja(4) (as Peziza), Van Vooren(2)
191
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Legaliana limnaea  (Maas Geest.) Van Vooren^  Ascomycete.org 12(4): 188. 2020;  Peziza limnaea  Maas Geest.  Persoonia 4(4): 422. 1967;  Peziza limosa  (Grelet) Nannf.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include an olive brown to olive yellow cup-shaped to expanded fruitbody that is bald to delicately scurfy on the exterior in its upper part and downy in its lower part. Microscopic characters include spores with warts some of which have adjoining short ridges.^ RANGE ^Legaliana limnaea is found at least in WA, OR, AK, (Larsen), Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-7cm broad, deeply cup-shaped to expanded, spore-bearing upper surface olivaceous^, (Hansen), 0.5-3cm, flat cup-shaped then disc-shaped and undulating and expanded; "hymenium smooth, outer surface darkly punctate when young, later likewise smooth, dark olive-brown to almost black in dry habitats, in damp shady ones olive-brown to bright olive-yellow" [unclear which surface the color is describing here], (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  in upper part reddish brown, in lower part whitish; in upper part bald to delicately scurfy, in lower part pubescent [downy], (Hansen)
STEM  without stem or with very short stem^ (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  often under Alnus (alder); on moist rich soil, fall, (Hansen), single to gregarious on sandy, muddy path edge, sandy-loamy building rubble, bare ground on streetsides, under Urtica (nettle) and Petasites (butterbur), in summer, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17-20 x 8-10 um, elliptic, with low comma-like warts (illustrated), with 2 droplets^, (Hansen), spores 15-18 x 9-10 um, narrowly elliptic, warty, some of the warts connected by ridges, but not reticulate, colorless, with 1-2 indistinctly visible droplets when young, Maas Geesteranus gives spores (15)17.9-22.4 x (8)9-10.7 um; asci 8-spored, 250-340 um x 11-12 um, weakly positive reaction with iodine; paraphyses "cylindric, irregularly swollen to 3-8 um toward the tips, septate"; medulla of rounded cells 50-60 um across and loosely woven hyphae 10-20 um wide, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  from 'limne', Greek for 'marsh' or 'pool'
SIMILAR  Legaliana badia has incompletely reticulate spores (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Peziza), Larsen(1) (as Peziza limosa), Hansen, L.(1) (as Peziza), Van Vooren(2)
192
FAMILY  Leptopeltidaceae, Order Uncertain, Class Dothideomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Leptopeltis aquilina  (Fr.) Petr.^  Sydowia 1(4-6): 237. 1947;  Leptopeltis pteridis (Mouton) Hoehn.  Ber. dt. bot. Ges. 35: 422. 1917;  Cyathicula aquilina  (Rehm) Sacc.;  Coronellaria aquilina  Rehm
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Leptopeltis pteridis produces a stemless cup growing on fern debris and salal, characterized by microscopic characters including much-branched paraphyses.^ | According to Seaver, Rehm makes Cyathicula aquilina a synonym of Mollisia pteridina Karst. RANGE ^Leptopeltis pteridis was reported from WA by Kanouse. 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  translucent when fresh, changing to "chamois" when dry^, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  sessile
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on fern debris, on salal^, (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10 x 4 um; paraphyses much branched^; marginal hairs in tooth-like fascicles [bundles], measuring up to 500 um long, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of the eagle'
SIMILAR  Several other small cups develop on ferns.
SOURCES  Kanouse(6) (as Cyathicula aquilina), Seaver(2) (as Cyathicula aquilina)

FAMILY  Drepanopezizaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Leptotrochila repanda  (Fr.) P. Karst.^  Bidr. Kann. Finl. Nat. Folk 19: 246. 1871;  Pseudopeziza repanda  (Fr.) P. Karst.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute fruitbody with the upper surface dingy brown and the exterior greenish black, growth on living Galium leaves (and occasionally other herbaceous plants), and microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Seaver(2). RANGE ^Leptotrochila repanda is found OR and Europe (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.03cm across, at first lightly submerged, soon becoming superficial but deep seated in the tissues of the host, opening with a laciniate margin; spore-bearing upper surface dingy brown
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  greenish black
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on living leaves of Galium (bedstraw) and occasionally on other herbaceous plants
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores "3-4 x 16-12 um" [sic], fusoid, biseriate or partially so^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 50-60 um and a width of 6-7 um, clavate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like]
NAME ORIGIN  means "wavy", "folded" in Latin, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Pseudopeziza repanda), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1) (discussing etymology of Peziza repanda)

FAMILY  Niaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Maireina marginata  (McAlpine) W.B. Cooke^  Beih. Sydowia 4: 89. 1961;  == Cyphella marginata  McAlpine
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a minute yellowish basidiomycete cup with brown exterior hairs and a darker margin, the spore-bearing upper surface cream to yellowish, 2) growth from bark of dead twigs on living fruit trees, and 3) microscopic characters including basidia.^ | Donk treated Maireina as a section of Cyphellopsis (Ginns), and Cyphellopsis is considered to be part of Merismodes by Dictionary of the Fungi 10th Edition, but according to Ginns, this species awaits transfer. The online Species Fungorum, accessed December 16, 2015, listed the current name as Cyphella marginata McAlpine. RANGE ^A collection was examined from OR (Cooke).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.03-0.1cm across, cup-shaped, sometimes nearly repand, margin inrolled, spore-bearing upper surface cream to yellowish^, (Cooke)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  yellowish with a darker margin; surface hairs brown^, (Cooke)
STEM  "mostly sessile to occasionally substipitate"^, (Cooke)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to somewhat gregarious, emerging from outer bark, on dead twigs of fruit trees including those of Pyrus malus (cult apple), Prunus persica (peach) and P. amygdalus, and on twigs of Cytisus scoparius (Scottish broom), the dead twigs usually on living trees^, (Cooke)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-16.8 x 6-10 um, ovate to cuneate, tear-shaped, cylindric or allantoid, flattened on one side^; basidia 4-spored, 50-65 x 10-15 um, clavate; hairs 125-375 x 6-10 um, brown, "incrusted on outer fourth to one half of length", tips colorless, pointed, (Cooke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'marginate', with darker border
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Cooke(2), Ginns(5)
195
FAMILY  Niaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Maireina thujae  W.B. Cooke^  Beih. Sydowia 4: 95. 1961
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a minute buff-colored basidiomycete cup covered with brown hairs, 2) growth on wood and bark of Western Red-cedar, and 3) microscopic characters.^ | Donk treated Maireina as a section of Cyphellopsis (Ginns), and Cyphellopsis is considered to be part of Merismodes by Dictionary of the Fungi 10th Edition, but according to Ginns, this species awaits transfer. RANGE ^The type collection was found in ID.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.1cm across, 0.05-0.1cm high, cup-shaped^, (Cooke)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  buff-colored when fresh, covered with brown hairs^, (Cooke)
STEM  sessile^ (Cooke)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on wood and bark of Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)^, (Cooke)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12.5-16 x 7-9 um, elliptic, flattened on one side, smooth, colorless, with granular contents, apiculate^; basidia 4-spored, 40-45 x 7-9 um, densely granular when young, sterigmata up to 7 um long; occasional paraphysoid hyphae also in hymenium, 35-40 x 2-4 um, colorless; subhymenial hyphae brown, with occasional clamp connections; hairs 60-100 x 3-4 um, straight to tortuous or geniculate, not at all or rarely septate, brown, granule incrusted, with dilute to colorless tips, (Cooke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Thuja', referring to its host Thuja plicata (Western Red-cedar)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Cooke(2), Ginns(5)
196
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Malvipezia emileia  (Cooke) Van Vooren^  Ascomycete.org 12(4): 188 (2020);  Peziza emileia  Cooke 1879
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a cup-shaped or expanded fruitbody with the upper surface varying from ochraceous brown to pale brown, a whitish scurfy underside, absent stem, growth on the ground in woods or on lawns, and microscopic characters including finely warted spores.^ | There is variation in the color of the upper surface. Dennis(1) wrote that the name Peziza howsei Boud. refers to a violaceous form of Peziza emileia, but Hansen, L.(1) maintained them as two species. The online Species Fungorum, accessed October 13, 2021 gave the current name as Malvipezia emileia (Cooke) Van Vooren. In 2014, the online Species Fungorum had listed Peziza emileia Cooke as a synonym of Peziza howsei (now Malvipezia howsei). RANGE ^Malvipezia emileia (as P. emileia) is found at least in OR, CA, CO, UT, (Larsen), WI, France, (Seaver), United Kingdom (Dennis), and Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen). There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre determined (as P. emileia) by J. Groves and by J. Ginns. It is possible that some records refer to Malvipezia howsei as Dennis(1) regarded Peziza howsei as a distinctly violaceous form of Peziza emileia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 8-10cm across, at first cup-shaped, becoming expanded and then often irregularly repand, regular in form or contorted; spore bearing upper surface concave, flat, or occasionally convex, even or undulating, ochraceous brown; margin even or more or less lobed, (Seaver), up to 7cm across, spore-bearing surface ochraceous to pale brown, (Hansen), cup-shaped or finally expanded with wavy margin; spore bearing upper surface varying from violaceous with yellowish tints to fawn, (Dennis) 
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white or whitish-farinose ^, (Seaver), whitish, often yellowish toward margin; scurfy, (Dennis)
STEM  without stem^ (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or scattered on damp soil in woods [but in key says "on wood"]^, (Seaver), in hardwood forests (Hansen), gregarious on lawns and in woods, June to October, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-18 x 8 um, elliptic, becoming sculptured with very minute warts or papillae, colorless, uniseriate^; asci reaching a length of 200 um and a width of 12-15 um, cylindric or subcylindric; paraphyses slender, strongly enlarged in upper part, septate, (Seaver), spores (17)18-21(22) x 8-10(11) um, finely verrucose [finely warted] with 2 droplets; paraphyses simple, colorless, (Hansen), spores 17-22 x 8-11 um, elliptic, finely warted, with 2 droplets; asci about 250 x 12 um; paraphyses slender, straight, slightly clavate, colorless or containing violaceous granules, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as Peziza emileia), Larsen(1) (as Peziza emileia), Hansen, L.(1) (as Peziza emileia), Dennis(1) (as Peziza emileia), Van Vooren(2)
197
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Marcelleina persoonii  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan) Brumm.^  Persoonia, Suppl. 1: 233. 1967;  Pulparia persoonii  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan) Korf, Pfister & J.K. Rogers;  Barlaea persoonii  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan) Sacc.;  Ascobolus persoonii  P. Crouan & H. Crouan 
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small, flat, stemless, violet disc, 2) relatively thick, soft flesh, 3) margin with a dark sharp-edged line, 4) underside paler than upper surface, 5) growth on soil, humus, or roots, in summer to fall, and 6) round spores with ridges forming an almost complete reticulum (network of ridges).^ RANGE ^The fruitbodies in the accompanying photograph were found by Paul Kroeger in an indoor plant pot in BC. It occurs also in Europe, including the United Kingdom (Dennis), Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Denmark, Norway, Sweden, and Finland, (Hansen, L.).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.4-1.0cm across, with a regular rounded disk, the margin "with a dark sharp-edged line"; spore-bearing upper surface violet, smooth^, (Breitenbach), about 1cm across, "with flat violet disc", (Dennis)
FLESH  "relatively thick and soft"^ (Breitenbach), thick, soft, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  the same color as the upper surface but somewhat lighter^ (Breitenbach), paler than upper surface (Dennis)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach, Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or gregarious on bare ground, also among mosses, under Petasites (butterbur), and on roots, in damp places, (Breitenbach), on humus and roots in swamps, under Glyceria, Juncus (rush), and Filipendula (meadowsweet), also on bare soil under Tussilago (coltsfoot), July to October, (Dennis), on calcareous soil and burnt ground, summer to fall, (Hansen, L.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10(11) x 8-10(11) um, round, colorless, "with coarse ribbonlike elongated warts and occasional anastomoses", spore usually with 1 droplet^; asci 8-spored, 200 x 18-20 um, iodine-negative; paraphyses "slender, septate, and branched at the base", tips with clavate thickening up to 8 um and strongly bent, 'and covered with brownish material', (Breitenbach), spores 10-13 x 10-13 um, round, coarsely warted, colorless, containing one large oil droplet; asci about 200 x 15 um; paraphyses "slender, septate, scarcely enlarged upwards", about 5 um thick at the tip, "strongly curved above and united by a slight purplish epithecial crust of amorphous matter", (Dennis), spores 10-12 x 10-12 um, round, colorless, with a +/- complete reticulum, (Hansen, L.)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1)
198
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Melastiza chateri  (W.G. Sm.) Boud.^  Icones Mycologicae (Paris) 2: pl. 386. 1907
ENGLISH NAME(S)  red saucer, false eyelash cup
NOTES  Features include bright orange to vermilion, cup-shaped, stemless fruitbody with short downy brown hairs on the margin, growth on the ground, and microscopic characters including spores with a coarse network of ornamentation and some with a thorny outgrowth at each end.^ RANGE ^Melastiza chateri is found in BC, WA, OR, ID, and also AB and CO, (Larsen); eastern North America, west to CO, ID, and AK, (Beug).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 1.5cm wide, exceptionally larger, cup-shaped then expanding; bright orange to vermilion^, (Dennis), 0.5-1.5cm, hemispheric then conic to saucer-shaped, irregularly wavy when mature; bright red-orange to vermilion, margin colored brownish by small tufts of brown hyphae, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  paler than upper surface, dotted toward the margin by minute bunches of downy, brown hairs^, (Dennis), colored as upper surface, (Breitenbach)
STEM  none^ (Dennis, Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Phillips)
HABITAT  on bare or mossy soil^, (McKnight), on damp sandy soils, October to March, (Dennis for UK), growing "singly, gregariously to clumped together", "along the edges of paths and roads, in forests and on grassy herb-covered spots, on bare sandy or loamy ground, May to September", (Breitenbach for Switzerland)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17-19 x 9-11 um, elliptic but with a coarse raised reticulum that often has a spine-like projection at each end of the spore^; asci up to 300 x 15 um; paraphyses clavate, up to 10 um wide at tip, which is filled with orange granules, (Dennis), spores 17-19.5 x 9-10 um (not including ornamentation), ornaments projecting up to 4 um, elliptic, "with coarse network of ridges, some also with apical thorny outgrowths, sometimes with small droplets on the spore ends"; asci 8-spored, to 300 x 15 um, inamyloid; paraphyses "cylindrical, tips with clavate thickenings to 7 um"; hairs to 200 x 14-16.5 um, brownish, smooth, with 2-5 septa, more or less cylindric, ending in blunt tip, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  named after J.J. Chater, the finder, in 1872, a gardener in Cambridge^, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
SIMILAR  Scutellinia species are generally smaller, have longer hairs with a different structure, and have different spores. Under a hand lens, the hairs of Scutellinia scutellata are stiff, brown, and bristle-like, whereas the hairs of M. chateri can be seen as soft, shorter, brown, and matted together, giving a streaky rather than spiny appearance, (McKnight).
SOURCES  Dennis(1), Breitenbach(1)*, Seaver(2) (as M. charteri), Kanouse(6) (as M. charteri), Larsen(1), Phillips(1)*, Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Courtecuisse(1)*, McKnight(1)*, Beug(3)*
199
FAMILY  Niaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Merismodes anomala  (Pers.) Singer^  Agaricales in Modern Taxonomy, Edn 3 (Vaduz): 665. 1975 [as 'anomalus'];  Cyphellopsis anomala  (Pers.) Donk;  Solenia anomala  (Pers.) Fuckel
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute basidiomycete fruitbody that is cup-shaped or urn-shaped to saucer-shaped, with cream to ocherish upper surface, cream margin that is floccose-fringed from hairs, exterior that is tomentose from light brown hairs, stemless growth in groups on a light brown subiculum on wood, and microscopic characters.^ | Reid notes that W.B. Cooke has a wide concept of this species that includes species with narrowly cylindric spores, broadly elliptic spores, and ovate or subglobose spores, whereas European authors recognize more than one species. The online Species Fungorum, accessed January 19, 2005 and December 17, 2013, gave the current name as Cyphellopsis anomala (Pers.) Donk, but Dictionary of the Fungi, Tenth Edition synonymizes Cyphellopsis with Merismodes. RANGE ^Merismodes anomala is found in BC, WA, OR, ID, and also AB, MB, NF, NS, ON, PQ, AK, AL, AZ, CA, CO, CT, DE, GA, IA, IL, IN, KS, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MO, MT, NC, ND, NE, NH, NJ, NM, NY, OH, PA, SC, TN, VA, VT, WI, and WV, (Ginns).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.02-0.05cm across and 0.01-0.03cm high, cup-shaped, urn-shaped, to saucer-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface cream to ocherish, smooth; margin cream, "floccose-fringed from exserted tips of the hairs"^, (Breitenbach), 0.05-0.3cm across, shallowly cup-like or saucer-like on a well-developed subiculum, margin paler than exterior, fringed hairy, (Buczacki)
FLESH  soft when fresh, corneous and hard when dry^, (Breitenbach), "soft, fragile, hard when dry"; pale ochraceous, (Buczacki)
UNDERSIDE  "tomentose from light brown, appressed, closely spaced hairs"^, (Breitenbach), densely hairy (Buczacki)
STEM  stemless on light brown subiculum^, (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "in groups or densely cespitose, sometimes covering areas decimeters in size", on dead wood of hardwoods, shrubs, and more rarely of Picea (spruce), with and without bark; throughout the year^, (Breitenbach), on a variety of hardwoods, wood, dead bark, twigs and branches, slash, logs; associated with a white rot, (Ginns), on rotting and fallen hardwood, especially Fagus (beech), and often on the cut surfaces of felled timber, in large densely tufted groups, all year, (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter
SPORE DEPOSIT  white^ (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-9.5 x 3.7-4.5(5) um, elliptic to slightly allantoid, smooth, colorless, some with droplets^; basidia 4-spored, 30-40 x 5-6.5 um, slenderly clavate, with basal clamp connection; cystidia not seen; hyphal system monomitic, hyphae 1-2 um wide, thin-walled, with clamp connections; hairs 2-4 um wide, up to 150 um long, "brown, thick-walled, upper half incrusted", tip clavate and widened up to 6 um, lighter-colored than lower part, (Breitenbach), spores 8-10 x 4-5 um, elliptic to +/- sausage-shaped, smooth, inamyloid; cystidia absent; hyphal system monomitic; outer hairs "brown, thick walled, encrusted from halfway, tip club-shaped, paler", (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'abnormal, unusual'
SIMILAR  Merismodes fasciculata is practically identical macroscopically except that it is not cespitose but grows clustered in small groups, mainly on Alnus, and microscopically, spores measure 6.5-8.5 x (2)2.5-3.3 um, and hairs are sinuous toward the end, with the tip obtuse not clavate, (Breitenbach). M. fasciculata has spores 6-8 x 2-2.5 um, (Buczacki). Cyphellopsis confusa has spores (5.5)7-8.2 x 2-2.2 um (Reid). See also SIMILAR section of Merismodes ochracea.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)* (as Merismodes anomalus), Reid(4) (as Cyphellopsis anomala), Ginns(5) (as Cyphellopsis anomala), Buczacki(1)*
200
FAMILY  Niaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Merismodes fasciculata  (Schwein.) Donk^  in Singer Lilloa 22: 345 (1951) [1949];  Cantharellus fasciculatus  Schwein.;  Cyphella fasciculata  (Schwein.) Berk. & M.A. Curtis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small brown basidiomycete fruitbody that is deeply tubular to cup-shaped with a cream inner spore-bearing surface, external hairs that usually exhibit spiral coiling, growth on hardwood often in clusters, and microscopic characters.^ | Var. occidentalis differs in having spores 9-11 x 3.5-4.5 um. Var. oreganus differs in having spores 9-13 x 5-7.5 um. RANGE ^Var. fasciculata is found in BC, OR, and also MB, NF, NS, ON, PQ, YT, AL, CO, DE, GA, IN, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MO, NC, NH, NJ, NY, PA, RI, SC, VA, VT, WI, and WY, var. occidentalis is found in WA, OR, ID, CA, and CO, and var. oreganus is found in WA and OR, (Ginns).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.5cm, shallow cup-shaped, margin straight to more or less undulate [wavy], in robust specimens becoming split to somewhat fimbriate [fringed], when the stem is extended the cups are hanging; cream colored; smooth to weakly wrinkled in some older or larger specimens^, (Cooke), up to 0.1cm in height and width as measured dried, produced in a pustule that breaks out from beneath the bark, deeply tubular-campanulate or horn-shaped; when dried with a pale yellowish or cream colored spore-bearing upper surface, similarly colored when fresh, (Reid)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  covered with hairs, zoned in older specimens^, (Cooke), when dried snuff brown, when fresh similar in color, old weathered fruitbodies appear grayish; appearing minutely villose under a hand lens, old weathered fruitbodies may be somewhat lobed and grooved, (Reid)
STEM  with a stem, but stem sometimes remaining within the lenticel^, (Cooke), with a stem or without, fruitbodies toward the outside of a crowded colony become pushed to one side and frequently develop very distinct stems; "fruitbodies are separated from each other by the development of erect, brown subicular hyphae resembling the surface hairs" that clothe the fruitbody, (Reid)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  fasciculate, rarely single, in clusters of 3-10 or more from lenticels or from cracks in bark, clusters reaching 1cm across^, (Cooke), "single, in small groups of twos and threes or in densely crowded colonies of 20 or more fruitbodies", on small twigs and branches of hardwoods, especially Alnus spp. (alder), (Reid)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores typically 7-9(10-11) x (1.5)2-3(3.5) um, cylindric to allantoid [curved sausage-shaped]^, clamp connections common especially in subhymenial tissue and at base of basidia; hairs 275 x 3-4 um, brown, thick-walled, smooth in lower part, "closely and finely granule incrusted on outer half to three-quarters of length, granules easily removed in mounting", with pointed, colorless, incrusted tips, straight to flexuous [wavy], curled, hooked or spiraled, (Cooke), spores 6.2-10.5 x 2-2.5 um, narrowly subcylindric to slightly allantoid, colorless or pale brown, thin-walled; basidia 4-spored, up to 20.8 x 5.5 um, clavate; cystidia absent; hairs up to 450 um long and 3.5(4) um wide, with distinctly thickened brown walls except for the tip part that is often thin-walled and colorless, toward the obtuse uninflated apex some hairs become wavy or coiled in a loose spiral, but this may be difficult to demonstrate, hairs usually narrow toward base and end in a clamped septum, they may develop occasional secondary septa; pustular base formed of hyphae up to 5 um wide, irregularly kinked and branched, colorless, clamped; walls of similar hyphae 2.5-3 um wide, more regularly arranged and parallel, (Reid)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fasciculate' (bundled)
SIMILAR  Merismodes anomala is practically identical macroscopically except that it may grow densely cespitose, it grows on a variety of hardwoods, and microscopically, the spores are 8-9.5 x 3.7-4.5(5) um, and the hairs are not sinuous and have the tip clavate and lighter in color that the rest of the hair, (Breitenbach). Cyphellopsis confusa is similar especially if the spiral coiling of hairs in Merismodes fasciculata is poorly developed, but then it is most readily distinguished by the manner in which the spore-bearing surface of Merismodes fasciculata lines a deep cavity extending almost to the base of the fruitbody, (Reid).
SOURCES  Cooke(2), Reid(4), Burt(4), Breitenbach(2), Ginns(5)
201
FAMILY  Niaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Merismodes ochracea  (Hoffm.) D.A. Reid^  Persoonia 3: 116. 1964;  Solenia ochracea  Hoffm.;  Phaeocyphellopsis ochracea  (Hoffm.) W.B. Cooke;  Cyphella mellea  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute, honey-yellow to brown basidiomycete fruitbody that is broadly tubular to narrowly cup-shaped with a cream to yellowish inner spore-bearing surface, external hairs incrusted by granules, and microscopic characters.^ | The synonymy of Cyphella mellea Burt according to W.B. Cooke is disputed by Reid on the basis that it has very broadly ellipsoid-ovate spores 4.5-7 x 3.5-5.25 um. RANGE ^The distribution is BC, WA, and also MB, NS, ON, AL, CA, CO, DE, FL, IA, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MA, MD, MI, MO, NE, NC, NJ, NY, OH, PA, TN, and WV, (Ginns), and Cuba, Argentina, Brazil, Venezuela, Austria, Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Latvia, Poland, Russia, Sweden, United Kingdom, Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Algeria, and Australia, (Cooke, but note that Reid states all of the Kew Herbarium collections determined by Cooke as this species in fact belonged to the taxa that Cooke places under Cyphellopsis anomala).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.3cm high, 0.02-0.06cm across, broadly tubular to narrowly cup-shaped, inner surface cream to yellowish^, (Cooke)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  honey-yellow to brown, with hairs incrusted with granules on outer half^, (Cooke)
STEM  no stem or short stem^ (Cooke)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to closely gregarious on rotting wood and litter of many genera of hardwood trees and shrubs, (Cooke), on rotten wood, decayed stump, rotting litter, on Acer macrophyllum, Fagus grandifolia, Populus trichocarpa, Salix nigra, Salix scouleriana, (Ginns)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4.75-7.5 x 3.2-4.2 um, colorless, with a few brown spores present 7.2-7.5 x 4-4.2 um, elliptic (not ovate), and in another collection 6.2-7.2 x (3)3.75-4.2 um, elliptic, all colorless^; hairs bluntly rounded at apex, (Reid), spores (5)6-8(10.5) x 3-5.5 um, ovate, smooth, contents granular, giving the appearance of a rough wall at lower magnifications, at first colorless, some becoming brown after spore discharge, in some collections more than half the spores brown; basidia 4-spored, 13.5-24 x 5-7 um; surface hairs 50-150 x 3-6 um, straight, brown, appressed, smooth in lower part, granule-incrusted on outer half to two-thirds of length, tapered to a point, (Cooke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ochraceous', a yellowish brown color
SIMILAR  Merismodes anomala has different spores, and usually darker colored fruitbodies with somewhat different-shaped hairs, (Cooke, but note Reid's claim that Cooke has misidentified Cyphellopsis anomala = Merismodes anomala collections as this species).
SOURCES  Cooke(2) (as Phaeocyphellopsis ochracea), Reid(4), Ginns(5)
202
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Micropodia pteridina  (Nyl.) Boud.^  Icon. Mycogr. 3. pl. 527. 1905-1910;  Hyaloscypha pteridina  Velen.;  Mollisia pteridina  (Nyl.) P. Karst.;  Pezizella pteridina  (Nyl.) Rehm
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Micropodia pteridina is a microscopic cup with a short stem growing on Pteridium fern, with microscopic characters that include small spores and asci, and a particular appearance of the cells on the outside of the cup.^ | It is based on Peziza pteridina Nyl., not Peziza pteridina Pers. ex Fr. which is a sessile fungus. RANGE ^Micropodia pteridina was reported from WA by Kanouse.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.02cm across, 0.01cm high^, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  0.004-0.005cm long, 0.004cm wide^, (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on Pteridium aquilinum (bracken fern)^ (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4-6 x 1-1.5 um, straight, colorless, one-celled^; asci 25-30 x 4-5 um, paraphyses filiform; "excipular cells on lower one-half of the cup arranged in scale-like triangular patches overlapping like shingles on a roof, color of the lower part of each scale light sordid brownish shading to nearly hyaline at the tips; margin bordered by similar cell groups, from twenty to twenty-five at the edge of each cup", (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to its host, the fern Pteridium
SIMILAR  Several other small cups develop on ferns.
SOURCES  Kanouse(6)
203
FAMILY  Sarcoscyphaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Microstoma protractum  (Fr.) Kanouse^  Mycologia 40: 486. 1948 [as protracta]
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a bright red cup on a slender stem arising from a hard black "root" attached to buried wood, the cup margin often turned outward and lobed, and the exterior covered with soft white hairs.^ | Microstoma protractum was photographed by Drew Parker in WA. RANGE ^It is found at least in CO and AB, (Larsen), and also Canada, Austria, Finland, Germany, Hungary, Norway, "Russia", Sweden, Switzerland, UK, and Japan, (Kanouse).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 2cm wide, cup-shaped then flattened and torn to lobed at margin; vivid rose-red^, (Dennis), up to 1cm wide, at first funnel-shaped, expanding to shallow cup-shaped, the margin lobed and often reflexed outward; bright red, almost scarlet, (Seaver), cup 1-2cm wide, 1-2cm high, at first nearly spherical to pear-shaped, expanding to deep vase-shaped, often with flat collar, finally laciniate [as if cut into delicate bands], opening by a small pore surrounded by a row of stiff, short, colorless hairs; vivid rose red, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  orange (Dennis), clothed with soft, white hairs that are flexuous [wavy], forming a delicate but abundant tomentum, (Seaver); bright orange-red; lower part of cup covered with colorless hairs, upper part smooth, (Kanouse)
STEM  arising from a buried hard elongate pseudorhiza, aerial part "long, slender, often branched, lower half dark colored, upper half whitish, downy with hyaline hairs"^, (Dennis), slender, reaching a length of 3-4cm and a width of 0.1-0.2cm, gradually expanding into the cup, (Seaver), arising from buried, hard, elongate pseudorhiza attached to buried wood or roots of trees, the above-ground stems branched usually several times, giving rise to as many as eleven fruitbodies, the above-ground stem 2-6cm long, (depending on the depth to which the pseudorhiza is buried), slender, lower one half dark colored, upper one half light colored, covered with colorless hairs, (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  the hard black pseudorhiza is usually attached to buried wood, (Dennis), on buried sticks and roots (Kanouse), "fruits right after snowmelt, sometimes on frozen ground", (Beug)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 24-45 x 10-14 um, elliptic-fusoid, containing several oil droplets, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, up to 275 x 23 um, operculum somewhat laterally placed; paraphyses "slender, dichotomously branched, only slightly enlarged at the tips, with red contents which turn green with iodine", (Dennis), spores 25-50 x 13-16 um, elliptic, narrowed toward either end, smooth, usually containing one large oil droplet and one or two smaller ones, 1-seriate; asci reaching a length of 200-250 um and a width of 20-22 um; paraphyses slender, slightly enlarged toward tip; hairs reaching a diameter of 6-7 um, of about the same diameter throughout their length, blunt, colorless, (Seaver), spores 24-45 x 10-14 um, elliptic to fusoid, colorless to slightly yellowish, lying obliquely in asci, sometimes slightly overlapped, usually containing conspicuous droplets which vary in size and number; asci 8-spored, 200-275 x 20-23 um, cylindric, operculum lateral, base contracted into long slender hyphae; paraphyses sometimes extending beyond the asci, not flexuous [wavy], dichotomously branched several times, "when fresh filled with red coloring matter (said to be stained green in iodine solution when fresh)", "hypothecium consisting of a subhymenial layer of densely matted hyphae, a middle layer of gelatinous hyphae and excipular layer the outermost tissue of which gives rise to the excipular hairs", (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(3), Dennis(1), Seaver(1) (as Plectania hiemalis), Larsen(1), Beug(3)*
204
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Miladina lecithina  (Cooke) Svrcek^  Ceska Mykologie 26: 214. 1972 [as 'lechithina'];  == Humaria lecithina  (Cooke) Sacc.;  == Helotium lecithinum  (Cooke) Massee;  == Pustularia lecithina  (Cooke) Rea
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a convex-cushion-shaped yellow to orange fruiting body up to 0.5cm across; growth on barkless wood in water; and microscopic characters.^ | Psilopezia aquatica (DC.) Rehm is a nomen ambiguum used by Seaver for collections referable to this species, according to Pfister. RANGE ^Miladina lecithina is found in OR, ID, and UT, (Larsen), MI, NY, UT, Czechoslovakia, and Russia, (Pfister), NJ and NY to MN and UT, and Europe, (Seaver), and Denmark and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.5cm, convex-pulvinate [convex-cushion-shaped]; luteous to orange, deep orange when dried; margin sometimes undulate (wavy)^, (Pfister), discoid; yellow; margin even, (Dennis), 0.3-0.5cm, becoming disc-shaped and closely adhering to substrate, spore-bearing upper surface flat or slight convex; bright orange or becoming dingy when old, blackish when dry; surrounded about the margin by a white radiating mycelium, (Seaver), 0.5-1.5cm, disc-shaped to pulvinate [cushion-shaped]; deep yellow to orange or ochraceous, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  exterior deep yellow to orange or ochraceous like upper surface; bald^, (Hansen)
STEM  broadly attached, appearing to have a white subiculum when dried^, (Pfister), without stem, on broad base, disc surrounded by whitish anchoring hyphae, (Dennis), sessile on broad base (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or scattered, on decorticated wood (in many cases Betula), in or under moving water^, (Pfister), single or in small clusters, on water-soaked wood, (Dennis), gregarious on stones and water-soaked logs, (Seaver), on water-soaked or immersed wood, summer to fall, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-24 x 8-14 um, elliptic, sometimes asymmetric, small sometimes anastomosing cyanophilic warts, colorless, thin-walled, 1-seriate, multiguttulate to spumose, 1-nucleate, de Bary bubbles sometimes present especially in dried material, when young with 1, 2, or 3 droplets and thick-walled^; asci 8-spored, 200-275 x 13-20 um, with a terminal operculum, J-, cylindric, tapering slightly to croziers at the base; paraphyses extending beyond the asci, expanded at tip to 5-8 um, neither branching nor anastomosing, in fresh material containing orange-yellow granules that become green in Melzer's, (Pfister), spores 18-25 x 11-12 um, elliptic, with finely warted walls, colorless, usually with numerous small oil droplets, uniseriate; asci 8-spored, up to 250 x 19 um; "paraphyses slender, straight, enlarged up to 8 um wide at the tip, containing orange pigment", (Dennis), spores 20-24 x 12-13 um, elliptic, smooth or becoming minutely sculptured, the ornamentation when present consisting of very minute granules, 1-seriate, colorless or faintly yellowish, usually containing 2 oil droplets or occasionally with numerous smaller ones; asci reaching length of 275 um and width of 16-20 um, becoming strongly spirally twisted, cylindric in upper part, gradually narrowing in lower part; paraphyses rather strongly enlarged in upper part, reaching diameter of 7-8 um, (Seaver), spores 20-22.5 x 12-15 um, broadly elliptic, verruculose, colorless, with numerous droplets; excipulum of spherical to angular cells, clavate toward margin, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Pfister(2), Dennis(1), Seaver(1) (as Psilopezia aquatica), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1)
205
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Moellerodiscus tenuistipes  (J. Schroet.) Dumont^  Mycologia 68(2): 260. 1976;  Ciboria tenuistipes  J. Schroet.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute cup on alder leaf blades or veins, with dull brown spore-bearing upper surface and mouse-gray exterior; long stem in relation to cup size; and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Moellerodiscus tenuistipes is found at least in WA (Kanouse).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2cm, cup remaining expanded after drying; dull brown; "margin slightly scalloped, the free ends of the excipular cells forming a pubescence" [unclear whether this refers to margin or exterior or both]^, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  mouse-gray^ (Kanouse)
STEM  0.3-1.0 long, widening upwards into cup^, (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious, arising from Alnus leaf blades or veins without stroma^, (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 3-4 um, one-celled, colorless, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, ascus pore not blue with iodine; paraphyses filiform, colorless, (Kanouse)

SOURCES  Kanouse(6) (as Ciboria tenuistipes)
