FAMILY  Mollisiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Mollisia amenticola  (Sacc.) Rehm^  in Rab. Krypt.-Fl.1: 540. 1891
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute, saucer to disc-shaped, yellow-ocher fruitbody, growth on damp female alder cones, and microscopic characters including spherical to hexagonal cells in the external surface.^ RANGE ^Mollisia amenticola was reported from WA (Kanouse), and from Switzerland (Breitenbach).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.03-0.1cm across, irregularly saucer-shaped to disc-shaped, spore-bearing upper surface yellow-ocher, smooth^, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  yellow-ocher, brownish toward base^, (Breitenbach)
STEM  without stem, resting on the individual cone-scale^ (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, gregarious or clustered, "on damp female cones of Alnus (alder), lying on the ground", November to February^, (Breitenbach), on cones of Alnus (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-5.5 x 1.5-2 um, elliptic, sometimes rather curved, smooth, colorless, with 2 small droplets, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 40-45 x 4 um, with positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses cylindric, septate; excipulum of a textura globulosa (with spherical cells), (Breitenbach), spores 6-9 x 1.5-2.5 um; "excipular cells below are hexagonal, small and dark-colored"; marginal hairs are palisade-like and pale, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Seaver(2) lists 39 Mollisia species for North America, plus another 11 doubtful species: it is likely that some others of these occur in the Pacific Northwest. They are generally up to 1mm in size, usually blackish to grayish or brownish or whitish, and identifiable only with a microscope and with knowledge of the host. According to Dictionary of the Fungi 9th Edition, Mollisia is poorly defined and probably polyphyletic.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Kanouse(6), Seaver(2)
207
FAMILY  Mollisiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Mollisia caespiticia  P. Karst.^  Myc. Fenn. 1: 188. 1871;  Pyrenopeziza caespiticia  (P. Karst.) Gremmen
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a gray to brownish fruitbody that eventually opens to reveal a gray spore-bearing upper surface; growth in cespitose clusters on hardwood; and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Mollisia caespiticia was reported from WA by Kanouse, and is listed for MI and Europe by Seaver.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.02-0.15cm across, at first spherical and closed, finally opening and becoming cup-shaped, at length nearly flat; spore-bearing upper surface grayish white^, (Seaver), up to 0.15cm across, cup-shaped; disc slightly concave, often deformed from mutual pressure, dark gray, (Dennis)
FLESH  waxy^ (Seaver)
UNDERSIDE  brownish^ (Seaver), gray, darker toward base; smooth, (Dennis)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  for the most part in cespitose clusters, on old wood, Salix (willow), Ulmus (elm), etc.^, (Seaver), emerging from bark in small clusters, "often seated over some member of the Sphaeriales", on "dead branches as of Betula, Ribes, Salix and Sambucus, September to October", (Dennis), on sticks; on Alnus (alder); on crab-apple, (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4-6 x 1-1.5 um, elongated and somewhat fusoid [spindle-shaped], straight or curved, biseriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 30-45 um and a width of 3-4 um, clavate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], 3 um wide, (Seaver), spores 4-7 x 1 um, narrowly clavate, non-septate, biseriate; asci 8-spored, up to 40 x 5 um, the pore not turning blue with iodine; paraphyses few, slender, cylindric; "A collection has also been seen on Crataegus, in spring, in which apothecia with normal ascospores occur together with others in which the asci are filled with innumerable small rod-shaped spores like those of a Tympanis.", (Dennis), spores 4-6 x 1-1.5 um, (Breitenbach(1))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Seaver(2) lists 39 Mollisia species for North America, plus another 11 doubtful species: it is likely that some others of these occur in the Pacific Northwest. They are generally up to 1mm in size, usually blackish to grayish or brownish or whitish, and identifiable only with a microscope and with knowledge of the host. According to Dictionary of the Fungi 9th Edition, Mollisia is poorly defined and probably polyphyletic. See also SIMILAR section of Pyrenopeziza benesuada.
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Dennis(1), Kanouse(6), Breitenbach(1) (discussing Pyrenopeziza benesuada as Mollisia benesuada)
208
FAMILY  Mollisiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Mollisia cinerea  (Batsch) P. Karst.^  Mycologia Fennica 1: 189. 1871;  Tapesia fusca  (Pers.) Fuckel
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a minute, cup-shaped to distorted, gray-brown fruitbody with a gray spore-bearing upper surface and whitish margin, 2) absent stem but sometimes anchoring hyphae, 3) gregarious growth on damp rotting hardwood, and 4) microscopic characters.^ | Many if not most mycologists consider Tapesia fusca to be the same species as Mollisia cinerea, in which case Mollisia cinerea is the correct name, Mollisia being conserved against Tapesia. RANGE ^Mollisia cinerea is found throughout North America as well as in Europe, (Seaver). It has been specifically reported for WA (Kanouse), MI (Kanouse in Seaver), Switzerland (Breitenbach), Denmark, Finland, Iceland, and Norway, Sweden, (Hansen), and the United Kingdom (Dennis). A sequenced OR collection labeled Mollisia cinerea was used in Tanney(2). Mollisia cinerea is the type species of the genus Mollisia. But according to Tanney(2) the precise identification of the species is unclear and the holotype is lost: epitypification is needed.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.2cm, urceolate [with small mouth] to cup-shaped when young, "then expanded and irregularly undulating and distorted"^; spore-bearing upper surface gray to gray-ocher; margin often whitish in young stages, (Breitenbach), at first nearly spherical, then expanding to nearly flat or occasionally repand; spore-bearing upper surface undulating, cinereous to yellowish, often becoming nearly black; margin whitish, (Seaver), saucer-shaped becoming flattened, outline often irregular or undulating; disc up to about 0.2cm across, if larger then usually irregular, light gray, sometimes drying yellowish; margin whitish, (Dennis), 0.1-0.3cm, disc-shaped, often irregular in outline; spore-bearing upper surface grayish or yellowish gray; margin paler to nearly whitish, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  grayish brownish, with fine down, margin often whitish in young stages^, (Breitenbach), cinereous, with a whitish margin, (Seaver), gray-brown, with whitish margin (Dennis), brownish; furfuraceous, (Hansen)
STEM  resting stemless on substrate, sometimes surrounded at base with colorless anchor hyphae^, (Breitenbach), with short anchoring hyphae (Dennis), without stem, with anchoring hyphae at base that sometimes form a brownish mat (subiculum), (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to cespitose and crowded, on "damp rotting wood, especially of Quercus (oak) and Fagus (beech)"^, (Breitenbach), gregarious or scattered, on decaying wood of many kinds, (Seaver), gregarious and superficial on dead wood and branches, throughout the year, (Dennis), gregariously crowded, on decaying wood of hardwoods, throughout the season, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 2-2.5 um, elliptic, sometimes slightly curved, smooth, colorless, often with droplets^; asci 8-spored, 50-70 x 5-6 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses cylindric, with blunt ends, (Breitenbach), spores 6-10 x 2-3 um, elliptic to fusoid, straight or curved, biseriate; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 45-60 um and a width of 5-7 um; paraphyses filiform, widened in upper part to 3-5 um wide, (Seaver), spores 7-10 x 2-2.5 um, narrowly elliptic-oblong, straight or only very slightly curved, non-septate, biseriate; asci 8-spored, up to 70 x 6 um, cylindric-clavate, the pore turning blue with iodine; paraphyses cylindric, obtuse, (Dennis), spores 7-10 x 2-2.5 um, cylindric, straight, sometimes slightly curved, colorless, non-septate; asci with amyloid pore, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'ash-colored'
SIMILAR  Mollisia oblonga (C.J.K. Wang & B. Sutton) I. Wagner, Prell & Baral, was originally described as the hyphomycete Paradidymobotryon oblongum and later combined as Phialocephala oblonga before being renamed in Mollisia in 2020. The renaming is controversial and a case can be made for retaining the name Phialocephala oblonga (Tanney(2)). At issue is how narrowly the genus Mollisia should be defined, given that it is polyphyletic as currently used. A collection of fruitbodies from Washington may be seen as iNat observation 32114116. |Seaver(2) lists 39 Mollisia species for North America, plus another 11 doubtful species: it is likely that some others of these occur in the Pacific Northwest plus others not mentioned by Seaver. There are over 700 names in the online Species Fungorum, accessed September 15, 2022, of taxa that have been named in Mollisia. They are generally up to 1mm in size, usually blackish to grayish or brownish or whitish, and identifiable only with a microscope, with knowledge of the ecology, and sometimes with mating or DNA studies.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Seaver(2), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6), Tanney(2)
209
FAMILY  Mollisiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Mollisia complicatula  Rehm^  in Rab. Krypt.-Fl. 1(3): 520. 1891;  Cenangium complicatulum (Rehm) Rehm  Ber. bayer. bot. Ges. 13: 186. 1912  (proposed current name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a minute, brownish black fruitbody with an inrolled margin, 2) erumpent growth on wood of honeysuckle, 3) spores 9-12 x 2-2.5 um, and 4) asci 50-60 x 6-7 um.^ The current name of this species is listed as Cenangium complicatulum (Rehm) Rehm in the online Index Fungorum, accessed September 14, 2022, but in MycoBank, accessed on the same date, the current name Mollisia complicatula Rehm is listed. RANGE ^Mollisia complicatula was reported by Kanouse from WA and MI, (Seaver, who did not examine any material).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.03-0.1cm across, (Seaver), fruitbody inrolled, brownish black, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  brownish black (Seaver)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  erumpent on wood of Lonicera (honeysuckle) and Populus, (Seaver), on Lonicera in Washington and in original description from the Tyrol, (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-12 x 2.5 um, (Seaver), spores 9-12 x 2-2.5 um; asci 50-60 x 6-7 um, (Kanouse)^
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Seaver(2) lists 39 Mollisia species for North America, plus another 11 doubtful species: it is likely that some others of these occur in the Pacific Northwest. They are generally up to 1mm in size, usually blackish to grayish or brownish or whitish, and identifiable only with a microscope and with knowledge of the host. According to Dictionary of the Fungi 9th Edition, Mollisia is poorly defined and probably polyphyletic.
SOURCES  Kanouse(6), Seaver(2)
210
FAMILY  Mollisiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Mollisia gaultheriae  Ellis & Everh.^  Proc. Acad. Sci. Phila. 1894: 349. 1894.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute, dark liver-colored fruitbody with a slightly dentate margin, growth on dirty brown spots on living salal leaves (more numerous on the underside), and microscopic characters.^ |The description is derived from Seaver(2). RANGE ^The holotype of Mollisia gaultheriae was found on leaves of Gaultheria shallon (salal).in WA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 0.05cm across, dark liver-colored, nearly black when dry; spore-bearing upper surface concave; margin slightly dentate^, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  dark liver-colored, nearly black when dry^, (Seaver)
STEM  occurring on large (1-2cm wide) circular dirty-brown spots which are sometimes irregular in shape and occupying the greater part of the leaf^, (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on living leaves of Gaultheria shallon (salal), on both sides but more numerous on underside^, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-12 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic, biseriate^; asci reaching a length of 45-55 um and a width of 10-12 um, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses filiform, branched, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means "of Gaultheria", referring to host Gaultheria shallon (salal)
SIMILAR  Seaver(2) lists 39 Mollisia species for North America, plus another 11 doubtful species: it is likely that some others of these occur in the Pacific Northwest. They are generally up to 1mm in size, usually blackish to grayish or brownish or whitish, and identifiable only with a microscope and with knowledge of the host. According to Dictionary of the Fungi 9th Edition, Mollisia is poorly defined and probably polyphyletic.
SOURCES  Seaver(2)
211
FAMILY  Mollisiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Mollisia plantaginis  (Fuckel) W. Phillips^  Man. Brit. Discomyc. (London): 183. 1887;  Pyrenopeziza plantaginis  Fuckel
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Mollisia plantaginis produces minute black apothecia with a white fimbriate margin, associated with necrotic spots on the leaves of Plantago lanceolata (English plantain, narrow-leaved plantain).^ |The description is derived from Stone(1). RANGE ^It occurs at least in OR (Stone), and in the United Kingdom.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.01-0.03cm across, "black with narrow, white fimbriate margin"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  erumpent, partly embedded in host tissue
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  leaf necrosis of Plantago lanceolata associated with Mollisia plantaginis develops in late fall and early winter in Europe, primarily December to March, and is considered common there; collected in Oregon March to May
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-15 x 2.5-3.3 um, fusiform, colorless, with two droplets^; asci 8-spored, 45-50 x 7-8 um, biseriate, "with minute apical pore, faintly I+ without KOH pretreatment"; paraphyses 35-44 x 1.5-2.5 um, "filiform, straight"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Plantago' referring to its host
SIMILAR  Seaver(2) lists 39 Mollisia species for North America, plus another 11 doubtful species: it is likely that some others of these occur in the Pacific Northwest. They are generally up to 1mm in size, usually blackish to grayish or brownish or whitish, and identifiable only with a microscope and with knowledge of the host. According to Dictionary of the Fungi 9th Edition, Mollisia is poorly defined and probably polyphyletic.
SOURCES  Stone(1)* (as Pyrenopeziza plantaginis), Seaver(2) (about Mollisia in general)
212
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Monilinia demissa  (B.F. Dana) Honey^  Am. J. Bot. 23: 105. 1936;  Sclerotinia demissa  B.F. Dana
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Monilinia demissa produces sclerotia in mummified overwintered fruits. Fruiting bodies are cup-shaped, later flat, and the stem is long. Conidia (Monilia) are produced on living leaves, twigs and fruits of the common choke cherry. The conidia are in unbranched chains, ovoid to spherical, colorless, cream colored in mass, simple, and 7-14 x 3-9 um.^ RANGE ^Monilinia demissa was originally described from WA (Seaver). There is a collection from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  at first cup-shaped, later flat
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  1-3.5cm, "long-stipitate"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  mostly single, sometimes two from overwintered mummy of Prunus virginiana var. demissa
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-15 x 5-6 um, elliptic, one end narrower than the other, uniseriate, colorless^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 150-160 um and diameter of 7 um; paraphyses slender
NAME ORIGIN  refers to host, Prunus virginiana var. demissa, 'demissa' means 'drooping'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2)
213
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Monilinia fructicola  (G. Winter) Honey^  Mycologia 20: 153. 1928;  Ciboria fructicola  G. Winter;  Ciboria fructicola  Winter;  Sclerotinia fructicola  (G. Winter) Rehm;  Sclerotinia americana  Norton & Ezek.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  cherry cup
NOTES  Monilinia fructicola produces a pale brown cup with a stem, growing from a thin black rind on mummified overwintered fruit of Prunus.^ RANGE ^It is found in BC, and was examined by Elliott, M.E.(1) from ON, PQ, who gives a distribution in Canada also including BC and SK. There are also reports from AB, MB, NB, NS, and PE, (Elliott, M.E.(1)). Seaver says it occurs in eastern North America and in Europe, (Seaver). The type is from Europe.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  (0.2)0.4-1.4cm wide, deep cup-shaped to cup-shaped; Sienna to Ochreous to Fulvous (colors from Rayner); colonies of conidial state buff-colored^, (Elliott, M.E.), reaching width of 1-1.5cm, shallow cup-shaped, or nearly flat when mature; pale brown; conidial state ash-gray or dark olivaceous, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  slightly darker than upper surface (Elliott, M.E.), lighter than upper surface (Seaver)
STEM  1.5-4cm long and about 0.1cm wide at top; close to Bay (color from Rayner), stroma "well-developed, a thin, black rind on both outer and inside surfaces of the flesh of the fruit, appears as a hollow spheroid, often enclosing the mummified fruit"^, (Elliott, M.E.), of variable length but often reaching 2-3cm, (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  arising from mummified overwintered fruit on Prunus, conidia on fruit, peduncles, twigs, leaves, or blossoms^, (Elliott, M.E.), fruitbodies in considerable numbers from a mummified fruit, on overwintering orchard fruits, the cause of brown-rot of fruits throughout eastern North America, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8.3-11.6 x 4.5-7.0 um, elliptic to oval; obliquely uniseriate, one-celled, binucleate (generating ascospores with 4 nuclei)^; asci 8-spored, 125-159 um x 8-10 um, cylindric, tapering in lower part to form indistinct stem, slightly expanded at base, rounded or flattened at tip, spores generally in upper half of ascus, inoperculate, pore stained blue in IKI; paraphyses only slightly longer than asci, about 2.5 um wide at somewhat enlarged tip, colorless, thread-like, septate, rarely branched near base; conidia 13-27 x (6)8-17 um, elliptic, elongate-elliptic to lemon-shaped, rarely spherical, developed acrogenously in chains, nearly colorless to pale olivaceous-buff; microconidia 2.5-3 um, in chains and phialides, colorless, spherical, often freed with collarette attached, associated with conidia and rarely fruitbodies, (Elliott, M.E.), spores 6-7 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic, containing one or more oil droplets, colorless or slightly colored; asci 8-spored, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses simple or branched near their bases; conidia elliptic, elongate-elliptic, or rarely spherical, developed in simple or branched chains, colorless or light colored; microconidia small, spherical, colorless on short-clavate conidiophores, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin, meaning "living on fruit"^, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Elliott, M.E.(1), Seaver(2), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Rayner(2)
214
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Monilinia gregaria  (B.F. Dana) Honey^  Am. Jour. Bot. 23: 105. 1939;  Sclerotinia gregaria  B.F. Dana
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Monilinia gregaria produces a gray cup or disc up to 0.5cm wide, with a stem, on Amelanchier cusickii with the conidial stage a Monilia.^ |Seaver comments somewhat obscurely, "While this species has been recorded, Honey expresses some doubt, suspecting that the wrong fungus may have been reported as the perfect stage of the Monilia." RANGE ^The type is from WA. 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^

FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  0.1-0.3cm long
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  conidial stage on living leaves and fruits of Amelanchier cusickii (serviceberry), gregarious ascus-bearing stage on mummified fruits of same host

FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Monilinia laxa  (Ehrenb.) Honey^  Am. Jour. Bot. 23: 105. 1936;  Monilia oregonensis  Barss & Posey
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Monilinia laxa produces a grayish brown cup or disc with a stem, growing gregariously on mummified plums, but the fruitbody is rare in nature. The conidial stage is more common, forming soft grayish pustules on flowers, branchlets and young plums.^ |The Hansen, L.(1) description is for M. laxa (Aderh. & Ruhl) Honey. RANGE ^Monilinia laxa is found in WI and on the Pacific Coast, and is also reported from Europe (including Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Finland), and Japan. There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.4-0.9cm broad, at first club-shaped, expanding and becoming cup-shaped, finally nearly flat with umbilicate center; gray or almost white^, (Seaver), 0.3-0.8cm broad; grayish brown; conidial stage of soft grayish pustules, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  with a stem 1-3cm x 0.1-0.2cm^, (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  usually several from the same stroma from mummified plums (Prunus); conidial stage consists of a Monilia of the cinerea type^, (Seaver), macroconidial anamorph (Monilia cinerea Bonord.) on flowers and branchlets and later on young fruits in spring and summer; ascus-bearing fruitbodies gregarious on mummified fruits but rare in nature, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores about 12 x 6 um in diameter, elliptic, uniseriate, or becoming partly biseriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching length of about 175-180 um and a diameter of 8-9 um, cylindric, narrowed in lower part; conidia 12-23 x 9-15 um; paraphyses 2-2.5 um wide, slender, slightly enlarged in upper part, (Seaver), spores 7-19 x 4.5-8.5 um, elliptic, with rounded ends; asci 120-190 x 7.5-12 um; conidia 8-23 x 7-16 um, oval to lemon-shaped, macroconidia "not separated by disjunctors", (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'loose'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Hansen, L.(1)
216
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Monilinia oxycocci  (Woronin) Honey^  Am. Jour. Bot. 23: 105. 1936;  Sclerotinia oxycocci  Woronin
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Monilinia oxycocci produces a reddish brown cup, disc, or reflexed cup, with a long thin stem, on overwintered mummified cranberries (Vaccinium macrocarpon).^ | Ascospores infect cranberry shoots and about 3-4 weeks later conidia start to form on the shoots. The conidia disperse, grow to penetrate the ovaries of the flowers, and thereby infect the berries. Young infected cranberry shoots show "tip blight" symptoms: "shriveled shoot tips resemble a shepherd's crook and a tan discoloration spreads from the tip of the shoot down the stem and into leaves"; "To distinguish cottonball tip blight from other shoot diebacks, check the leaves for tan V-shaped or U-shaped lesions centered on the leaf midvein"; "Another indicator is the presence of masses of white, powdery spores (conidia) that appear on diseased shoots just before and during bloom"; "Cottonball tip blight is often inconspicuous and can easily be overlooked"; "Immature diseased berries show no external symptoms, but are filled with the white, cotton-like fungus"; "Healthy berries turn red as they mature; diseased berries may acquire a red blush but are generally yellowish with tan stripes or blotches". (McManus). The distribution is "where the cranberry is cultivated" (Seaver). McManus(1) writes that cottonball, a disease caused by this fungus, fills berries with a cotton-like fungus that makes them unmarketable. It is an economically important disease on many cranberry marshes in Wisconsin. Typically, 2 to 10% of the fruit in diseased beds is infected; if left unchecked the amount can exceed 40%. Cottonball also occurs in the Pacific Northwest and southeastern Canada but losses in those areas have generally been minor. RANGE ^The online Pacific Northwest Plant Disease Management Handbook, accessed December 22, 2013, says that this disease was a problem in WA during the 1920s and 1930s but is rarely found now, except in BC where it is still considered an economic problem. Monilinia oxycocci also occurs in Europe including Denmark, Norway, Sweden, and Finland (Hansen), as well as WI as mentioned above (McManus).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  about 0.5cm wide and often as deep, cup at first rather deep, becoming shallow cup-shaped or often reflexed (curved backwards), so that spore bearing surface concave, flat, or convex; reddish brown^, (Seaver), 0.3-0.9cm wide, cup-shaped; dark reddish brown, (Hansen), tan or brown (McManus)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  similar in color to upper surface^ (Seaver)
STEM  with a stem, the stem often 4-5cm long and about 0.1cm wide, gradually expanding at top into cup^, (Seaver), 1-7cm x 0.05-0.15cm, (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  fruiting body arising from sclerotia (usually one from each sclerotium), in fallen mummified fruits of Vaccinium oxycoccos (cranberry)^, (Seaver), 1 to 6 fruiting bodies in early spring from hollow black pseudosclerotium (mummified berry), macroconidial state on wilting shoot of the host in summer, (Hansen), mummies are roughly spherical and about 1.2cm in diameter (McManus)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-14 x 6 um, elliptic^; asci reaching 150 x 5-6 um, 8-spored, clavate, (Seaver), 4 large spores 9.5-14.5 x 5.5-8.5 um, abortive spores 6-10 x 4-5 um; conidia 14.5-25 x 9.5-15 um, oval, "in chains with 3-6 um long disjunctors", (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of cranberry'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Hansen, L.(1), McManus(1), http://pnwhandbooks.org/plantdisease/cranberry-vaccinium-macrocarpon-cottonball%20
217
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Monilinia urnula  (Weinm.) Whetzel^  Mycologia 37(6): 673. 1945;  Sclerotinia urnula  (Weinm.) Rehm
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Monilinia urnula produces shallowly cup-shaped to flat, dark brown fruiting bodies on fallen mummified Vaccinium berries in spring and early summer. It causes mummyberry disease of blueberries (along with Monilinia vaccinii-corymbosi) which became serious in the Puget Sound area of Washington in the early 1960s and was soon present up and down the coast wherever blueberries were grown. The fungus causes a blossom blast [destruction of blossom buds] in addition to blight of young twigs and leaves, the fruit becoming a mummy that falls to the ground and creates new infections the following spring.^ |Note the difference in the width of the fruitbody given by Dennis(1) and by Hansen, L.(1). RANGE ^Monilinia urnula is found in WA, and Europe including Denmark, Sweden, and Finland, (Hansen, L.), and the United Kingdom (Dennis).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.1cm wide, shallow cup-shaped, dark brown, smooth, (Dennis), 0.2-2cm, shallowly cup-shaped to flat; dark chestnut brown, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  1-4.8cm x 0.05-0.2cm (Hansen), long-stemmed (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  1-3 on fallen mummified berries of Vaccinium species, spring and early summer, (Hansen), buff macroconidial state on wilting shoots of host [in summer], mainly on the axis of the dead shoot, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-18 x 7.5-9 um, equal in size, elliptic, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 190-200 x 12.5-13.5 um; paraphyses cylindric; conidia 25-30 x 15-17 um, in short chains, top-shaped, (Dennis), spores 10-17.5 x 6-8.5 um; asci 150-200 x 10-14 um; conidia 22-42 x 13.5-25 um, lemon-shaped, with chains with 3-8 um long prominent disjunctors, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'small urn'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dennis(1); Hansen, L.(1); http://plantpath.wsu.edu/aboutplantpath/hwwrec2.htm, (as Sclerotinia); Farr, D.F., Rossman, A.Y., Palm, M.E., and McCray, E.B. (n.d.) Fungal Databases, Systematic Botany and Mycology Laboratory, ARS, USDA. Retrieved January 24, 2003 from http: //nt.ars-grin.gov/fungaldatabases/
218
FAMILY  Repetobasidiaceae, Order Hymenochaetales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Muscinupta laevis  (Fr.) Redhead, Luecking & Lawrey^  Mycol. Res. 113(10): 1167. 2009;  == Cyphellostereum laeve  (Fr.) D.A. Reid;  == Cantharellus laevis  Fr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Gilled, Veined, and Other categories. Features include small white fruitbodies on Polytrichum and similar mosses, with concave hymenial surface facing downward or sideways, and short indistinct stem.^ RANGE ^It is found in BC, WA, OR, ID, and also ON, CT, MT, MN, NY, and VT, (Ginns), United Kingdom (Watling), and Scandinavia (Eriksson). Collections were examined from ID, CT, Venezuela, Czech Republic, Finland, Sweden, and the United Kingdom, (Reid).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  about 0.5-1cm wide, rounded or spathulate, upper (non-hymenial surface) flat or somewhat convex upwards; white^, (Eriksson), 0.2-2cm wide, kidney-shaped, spathulate or sometimes almost funnel-shaped or ear-shaped, soft; white, only slightly discoloring when old; appressed silky tomentose becoming radially and concentrically grooved on drying, with fringed margin, (Watling), 0.2-0.6cm, spathulate, dorsally or laterally attached, without stem or with short stem, pendant or erect; white; silky to minutely tomentulose becoming bald; spore-bearing surface smooth to rugulose (finely wrinkled), white, drying pale pink-tan, (Castellano), 0-1(1.5)cm, spatula to mussel-shaped or funnel-like; white, (Moser), fruitbody seldom exceeding 1.5cm high, discrete, dimidiate, reniform, spathulate or rarely infundibuliform, coriaceous-membranous [leathery-membranous], soft, white, at length fuscescent, minutely and adpressedly silky-tomentose, sometimes radiato-scrobiculate, becoming radiately and concentrically sulcate on drying; margin sometimes fimbriate [fringed], (Reid)
FLESH  very thin^ (Watling), thin; soft, (Trudell)
UNDERSIDE  hymenial surface facing sideways or downwards concave; white or cream; smooth or almost smooth, continuous; margin somewhat inflexed^, (Eriksson), reduced to slight rugulosities (fine wrinklings) or with smooth spore-bearing surface; white drying ochraceous, (Watling), hymenophore smooth or lightly wrinkled, (Moser), spore-bearing surface white (drying ochraceous), smooth or slightly rugose [wrinkled], (Reid)
STEM  fruitbody tapers to short indistinct stem^, (Eriksson), 0.5-1cm, reduced to lateral strap-like extension of cap, or as a distinct attachment round in cross-section; colored similarly to cap; bald, (Watling), stem when present 0.1-0.5cm x 0.05cm, lateral, white, bald, (Castellano), 0.5-1cm, white, lateral, more rarely more or less central, (Moser), narrowed into a reduced strap-like or distinct terete stem, 0.5-1cm long, usually lateral (rarely central but often obsolete), white, bald, (Reid)
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Castellano)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Castellano)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered with various mosses (Polytrichum, Dicranella) in forests^, (Castellano), growing on living mosses (Eriksson), on or amongst mosses and liverworts, especially of the genus Polytrichum, (Watling), growing on or amongst mosses, especially of the genus Polytrichum, (Reid), late summer and fall (Trudell), summer to winter (Buczacki)
SPORE DEPOSIT  white^ (Watling)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4-4.5 x 2-2.5 um, nearly round or somewhat elliptic, tapering toward apiculus, illustrated smooth, somewhat cyanophilic, thin-walled, with one oil droplet^, basidia 4-spored, 15-18 x 4.5-6 um, clavate, with small droplets in protoplasm, without basal clamp connection; cystidia numerous, projecting, 35-55 x 6-7 um, "narrowly fusiform, widest near base, apically rounded to a insignificantly rounded head", thin-walled, not incrusted; hyphal system monomitic: hyphae 2-3 um wide, even, sparsely branched, colorless, slightly cyanophilous, without clamp connections, "distinct subhymenium formed by densely interwoven hyphae", (Eriksson), spores 3-4 x 2-2.5 um, broadly elliptic with prominent apiculus, smooth, inamyloid, thin-walled; basidia 4-spored, 18-21 x 3-4 um, clavate, often with very long sterigmata up to 3 um long; cystidia abundant, 35-50 x 4-4.5 um with long narrow neck 1.5-2 um wide, apex often obtuse or somewhat enlarged, thin-walled, colorless; cap cuticle of more or less erect groups of smooth cylindric hyphae, "adhering in groups but collapsing in age to give a strand-like appearance"; clamp connections absent, (Watling), spores 3-4 x 2-2.5 um, inamyloid, cystidia hair-like with base swollen, to 20 um, (Moser), spores 3-4 x 2-2.5 um, broadly cylindric, colorless, rather scanty in the collections examined, often with one droplet, (Reid), spores 4-5 x 2.5-3 um (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'smooth'
SIMILAR  Arrhenia retiruga differs in being paler gray to gray brown when fresh, with larger spores (6-9 x 3.2-5 um) and no cystidia, (Castellano).
SOURCES  Eriksson(3) (as Cyphellostereum laeve), Watling(2) (as Cyphellostereum laeve), Reid(6) (as Cyphellostereum laeve), Castellano(2)* (as Cyphellostereum laeve), Moser(1) (as Cyphellostereum laeve), Redhead(6) (as Cyphellostereum laeve), Ginns(5) (as Cyphellostereum laeve), Trudell(4)* (as Cyphellostereum laeve), Buczacki(1)* (as Cyphellostereum laeve)
219
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Myriosclerotinia caricis-ampullaceae  (Nyberg) N.F. Buchw.^  Friesia 3(4): 301. 1947;  Sclerotinia caricis-ampullaceae  Nyberg
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include brownish cups arising in groups of 2-16 fruitbodies from a long sclerotium that develops between leaf sheaths of young sedge shoots, often in wet areas associated with Sphagnum.^ RANGE ^B. Kanouse determined a collection of A.H. Smith from Mt. Rainier National Park in WA as this species (University of Illinois). A Scot Loring collection from WA had a matching DNA sequence with a collection determined to be this species although there are some differences in the Loring collection, including highly branched apices of the paraphyses. There is a BC collection labeled Sclerotinia caricis-ampullaceae at the University of British Columbia. Schumacher(2) examined collections from AB, MB, WY, Finland, and Sweden. The abstract of Holec(2) indicates that it occurs in central Europe (Czech Republic and Austria).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1.0-3.0cm across, cup-shaped (when mature almost applanate), tapering into stem; cinnamon to umber brown^, (Schumacher), 1-3cm across the disc, cup-shaped, arising 2-16 from a sclerotium, (Hansen, L.) 
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  cinnamon to umber brown, finely tomentose^ (Schumacher)
STEM  3-10cm x 0.1-0.2cm, cinnamon to umber brown; finely tomentose; sclerotium 3-17cm x 0.6-1.5cm, "slenderly ventricose, with an attenuated base and a slender, elongated, pointed tip above"; "with black striate outer rind and white inner context"; microconidial anamorph in locules in host tissue, forming dark, elongate spots 0.2-0.4cm long, 0.1-0.2cm wide, "regularly distributed along the culm below the inflorescences, usually arranged lengthwise along two sides of the culm, at maturity becoming swollen, rupturing the host epidermis as microconidia are liberated"^, (Schumacher), 3-10cm x 0.15-0.25cm, arising from a sclerotium that is 3.0-20.0 x 0.4-1.2cm, "long and slender, curved, with pointed ends, developing apically between leaf sheaths of young shoots" of Carex, (Hansen, L.(1))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  sclerotium developing apically between leaf sheaths of young shoots of Carex; at least in north Europe cups develop on stems of Carex rostrata and C. aquatilis in spring and early summer^, (Hansen, L.), further ecological details are discussed in Holec(2) including that it prefers areas with rather deep Sphagnum peat and a high amount of water
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11-16.5 x 7-10.2 um, broadly elliptic to oval, colorless, without droplets, 1-seriate^; asci 8-spored 180-235 x 9.0-13.5 um, cylindric, pore channel walls faintly iodine + without pretreatment with 2% KOH, after pretreatment strongly iodine positive; paraphyses 1-2 um wide, thread-like, slightly enlarged at tips to 3 um wide, colorless, "septate, simple or branched from below"; microconidia 2.5-3.5 um in diameter, round to oboval, containing one large oil droplet, "with two small pieces of wall material at the often truncate base", walls colorless to light brown, (Schumacher)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Carex ampullacea', a synonym of Carex rostrata
SIMILAR  Myriosclerotinia duriaeana and Myriosclerotinia sulcatula T. Schumach. & L.M. Kohn (= Sclerotinia sulcata Whetzel) have sclerotia less than 3cm long (Hansen, L.). The cups are smaller when mature and the stems shorter. See also SIMILAR section of Myriosclerotinia duriaeana.
SOURCES  Schumacher(2), Hansen, L.(1), Holec(2)
220
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Myriosclerotinia curreyana  (Berk. ex Curr.) N.F. Buchw.^  Friesia 3: 291. 1947;  Sclerotinia curreyana  (Berk.) P. Karst.;  Rutstroemia curreyana  (Berk.) P. Karst.;  Hymenoscyphus curreyana  (Berk.) W. Phillips;  Ciboria juncigena  Ellis & Everh.;  Sclerotinia juncigena  (Ellis & Everh.) Whetzel
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, light cinnamon to umber, cup-shaped to flat, sometimes umbilicate fruitbodies growing through a slit in the culm of Juncus spp., the cup with a stem attached to a sclerotium within the culm and microscopic characters including allantoid uninucleate spores arranged in predominantly biseriate fashion within the ascus.^ |The description is derived from Schumacher(2). RANGE ^Collections were examined from WA (as Ciboria juncigena), Denmark, Germany, Norway, and the United Kingdom, (Schumacher(2)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-1.2cm across, cup-shaped to flat, "often umbilicate when fully expanded"; light cinnamon to umber
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  tapering to form a stem 0.3-1.6cm long and 0.05-0.15cm wide; sclerotium 0.3-4.0cm x 0.05-0.25cm, cylindric to fusiform "with black striate outer rind and white to rose inner context, formed within culms or basal parts of leaves of host, sometimes breaking forth through a slit in the culm wall"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "one to several from a sclerotium through a slit in the culm" of Juncus spp.
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7.2-15.0 x 1.1-2.3 um, narrowly allantoid with obtuse ends, colorless, without droplets, uninucleate, 1-seriate to predominantly 2-seriate^; asci 8-spored, 58-95 x 4.0-5.5 um, cylindric to clavate, pore channel walls distinctly J+ without pretreatment in 2% KOH; paraphyses "filiform, simple or branched from below, septate", colorless, 1.0-2.1 um wide, apices inflated to 3.5 um wide, slightly bent
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Schumacher(2)
221
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Myriosclerotinia duriaeana  (Tul. & C. Tul.) N.F. Buchw.^  Friesia 3: 299. 1947;  Sclerotinia duriaeana  (Tul. and C. Tul.) Rehm.;  Hymenoscypha duriaeana  W. Phillips
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Myriosclerotinia duriaeana produces a fawn-brown cup with a short stem, growing one to several from a black spindle-shaped sclerotium that arises on Carex culms.^ | It should not be confused with Mycocalia duriaeana (Tul. & C. Tul.) J.T. Palmer which is a basidiomycete in Nidulariaceae. Myriosclerotinia duriaeana was recorded in Oregon and New York, (Seaver, who, however says that spores are often inequilateral, making the differentiation from Myriosclerotinia sulculata uncertain - see SIMILAR section). RANGE ^Myriosclerotinia duriaeana is recorded as distinct from M. sulculata in Denmark, Norway, Sweden, and Finland, (Hansen), and MB, Northwest Territories, Greenland, France, and the United Kingdom, (Schumacher).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-0.7cm, cup-shaped, light brown to medium brown, (Hansen), reaching 0.2-1cm, "deep cupshaped when young, expanding when mature"; fawn-colored, (Seaver), 0.3-0.6(1.0)cm across, cup-shaped, at maturity with a wavy margin; light cinnamon to umber brown, (Schumacher)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  0.2-2.5cm x 0.05-0.15cm, arising from sclerotium that is 0.5-1.8cm x 0.1-0.3cm, cylindric, (Hansen), stem 0.5-2cm long, black sclerotium resembling sclerotium of Claviceps, 1-3 in each culm, fusiform (spindle-shaped), often inequilateral, or slightly curved in large specimens, reaching 2-2.5cm x 0.3-0.4cm but often smaller, (Seaver), tapering to form a stem 0.2-2.0cm x 0.05-0.12cm; sclerotium 0.5-1.5cm x 0.1-0.25cm, "slenderly lanceolate to fusiform, straight or slightly curved, subeven to striate, with black outer rind and white to rose inner context", (Schumacher)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  1-3 fruitbodies arising from sclerotium, on Carex, "Sporodochial locules in groups of 3-6 distributed at regular intervals along the host culm, each group dull black, elongate, 1-3mm long", (Hansen), on Carex, sclerotia "one to three in each culm, when mature exposed by the rupture of the epidermis along one or two faces of the culm which thus weakened soon breaks over widening the slit and allowing the sclerotia to fall", (Seaver), one to several from sclerotium in culm of Carex and Eriophorum spp. (Schumacher)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10.5-14 x 5.5-7 um, navicular, flattened to incurved on one side^; asci 130-165 x 7-10 um, (Hansen with illustration of spores), spores 8-18 x 5-9 um, long-ovoid, often inequilateral; asci 8-spored, uniseriate, reaching 150-180 x 7-11 um, slightly narrowed in lower part; paraphyses slender, slightly swollen at top, (Seaver), spores 10.4-18.6 x 5.4-7.2 um (mean 12.3 x 6.4 um), broadly elliptic, flattened to incurved on one side (cymbiform), colorless, without droplets, binucleate or tetranucleate, 1-seriate; asci cylindric, 8-spored, 130-175 x 7-11 um, pore channel wall moderately J+ without pretreatment in 2% KOH; paraphyses filiform, colorless, 2.0-2.5 um wide, "simple, septate", tips slightly inflated to 3.5 um wide
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Myriosclerotinia sulcatula T. Schumach. & L.M. Kohn (= Sclerotinia sulcata Whetzel) has been documented from NY (holotype) and Europe. Ascospores in M. sulcatula, though similar in size measuring 11.1-17.1 x 5.3-7.5 um, are regularly elliptic to slightly inequilateral, whereas in M. duriaeana they are strongly inequilateral to cymbiform [boat-shaped]. The asci of M. sulcatula are consistently longer (150-210 um) than those of M. duriaeana (130-175 um). The locules of the microconidial anamorph are irregularly scattered on the culm in M. sulcatula, but they are uniformly in pairs at more or less regular intervals along the culm in M. duriaeana. The dimensions of the sclerotium are similar measuring 0.3-2.5cm x 0.15-0.4cm, (Schumacher). Myriosclerotinia caricis-ampullaceae, which also grows on Carex, has sclerotia measuring 3-17 x 0.6-1.5cm. The cups are up to 3cm across and the stems are longer.
SOURCES  Hansen, L.(1), Seaver(2) (as Sclerotinia), Schumacher(2)
222
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Neofabraea populi  G.E. Thomps.^  Mycologia 31: 458. 1939;  Pezicula populi  (Thompson) Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Key diagnostic features are the brownish to amber colored, cushion-shaped fruitbodies, erumpent whitish conidial stage, large granular conidia, and growth on Populus.^ | It may cause serious canker formation in native and exotic poplars, especially hybrids and young nursery stock. Cankered areas "first appear slightly more sunken than surrounding tissue, and bark may be discolored orange", acervuli then develop "in concentric waves around the points of inoculation, usually around a lenticel", (Callan). Some authorities regard this as a Pezicula species: Seaver transferred it to Pezicula, and according to Dictionary of the Fungi 10th Edition, molecular data do not support separation of Neofabraea from Pezicula. RANGE ^At the time of Seaver's description, it was known only from the type locality in ON (Seaver), but it is now known more widely, including BC, Europe, and Japan (Callan).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  apothecia (fruitbody) 0.05-0.2cm across, disc-shaped to cushion-shaped, fleshy; pale brown to amber; acervuli 0.05-0.15cm across and up to 0.005cm thick, "they first appear as pimple-like protrusions before they rupture the epidermis to expose their whitish to yellowish surface"^, (Callan), scarcely exceeding 0.05cm across, erumpent [emerging from the bark] but scarcely rising above the surface, surrounded with the upturned edges of the ruptured outer bark; dark brownish black; spore-bearing surface concave or nearly flat, reddish brown with a slightly elevated darker center that gives the spore-bearing surface an umbilicate appearance, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  without stem^ (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  thickly gregarious, usually occurring singly, or rarely two or three crowded together, (Seaver), mature fruitbodies are produced in June, usually erumpent [emerging] first near the center of the cankered area on P. tremuloides, P. trichocarpa, and its hybrids, (Callan for BC, but notes that it occurs on other Populus species elsewhere)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-22 x 5-6 um, oblong-elliptic, straight or slightly curved, or unilaterally flattened, up to 3-septate, colorless^; asci 8-spored, 80-112 x 9-12 um, cylindric to clavate, short-stemmed; conidia 25-45 x 4-5 um, cylindric to spindle-shaped, nonseptate, colorless, often with granular cytoplasm; acervuli are covered by colorless, septate, simple or branched conidiophores measuring 25-35 x 4 um, (Callan), spores 18-20 x 5-6 um, elliptic, becoming indistinctly 3-septate, usually with 2 oil droplets, 2-seriate in upper part; asci apparently normally 8-spored but with only 5 or 6 of the 8 developed, reaching a length of 80 um and a width of 12 um, clavate; paraphyses enlarged in upper part, colorless, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Populus' referring to its host
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Callan(1), Seaver(2) (as Pezicula populi)
223
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Neottiella hetieri  Boud.^  in Bull. Soc. mycol. France 12: 12. 1896;  Leucoscypha hetieri  (Boud.) Rifai
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, platter-shaped, bright orange-red discs that may be slightly concave, delicate white hairs that fringe the margin and inconspicuously clothe the pale orange underside, absent stem, growth with moss on burned soil, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Neottiella hetieri is found in BC (Larsen), NY, CT, Europe, (Seaver), Switzerland (Breitenbach), United Kingdom (Dennis), and Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen). There is a collection from WA at the University of Washington.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.2cm, at first almost spherical, expanding to scutellate [platter-shaped] or subdiscoid [almost disc-shaped]; bright orange-red^, (Seaver), 0.1-0.3cm, saucer-shaped to disc-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface flat, orange, smooth; margin "turned upward, scurfy-notched, sparsely set with indistinct white hairs", (Breitenbach), up to 0.2cm wide, cup-shaped, disc flat; bright orange, margin fringed with delicate white hairs, (Dennis), 0.05-0.2cm wide, turbinate to disc-shaped; orange, margin dentate, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale orange and clothed with delicate white hairs, the hairs fairly abundant but not conspicuous to the naked eye^, (Seaver), orange; scurfy-furfuraceous, (Breitenbach), white, clothed with delicate white hairs (which also form marginal fringe), (Dennis)
STEM  none^ (Dennis, Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on "old burnt place which has been overrun with mosses, or occasionally where there is no trace of fire"^, (Seaver), single or gregarious, on burned ground among mosses (Funaria), in spring, (Breitenbach), amongst Funaria on burnt soil and charcoal, spring and fall, (Dennis for UK), on burnt places, 1-2 years after the burn, among Funaria hygrometrica, (Hansen for north Europe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores about 18 x 12 um, elliptic or more often oval, colorless, containing one large oil droplet or very rarely two, 1-seriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 200-225 um and width of 16-20 um; paraphyses reaching a width of 8 um at tips, stout, rather freely branched, septate, often swollen near the septa, filled with orange granules; hairs reaching a length of 150-200 um and a width of 4-6 um, rigid, blunt when young, sharp pointed when mature, colorless, septate, (Seaver), spores 16-17 x 8-9 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with one droplet; asci 8-spored, 180-200 x 18-20 um, negative reaction with iodine; paraphyses cylindric, septate, sometimes forked, tips with slight clavate widening; hairs 160-200 x 7.5-10 um, colorless, "smooth, thick-walled, usually with 2-3 septa, ending in a +/- blunt tip", (Breitenbach), spores 13-17 x 8-9 um, elliptic, smooth, containing one large oil droplet; asci up to 200 x 17 um; paraphyses up to 7 um wide at tip, slightly clavate, with orange contents; hairs up to 200 x 15 um, fusiform in lower part, tapering to a point, "wall smooth, 1-1.5 um thick, lumen 0-3-septate", (Dennis), spores 16-18.5 x 10-11 um, smooth, with one large eccentric droplet, hairs 200-400 x 4-8 um, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Octospora species have no hairs under the microscope, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as Patella hetieri), Larsen(1) (as Leucoscypha hetieri), Dennis(1), Breitenbach(1)*, Hansen, L.(1)
224
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Neottiella rutilans  (Fr.) Dennis^  British Cup Fungi. p.28. 1960;  Leucoscypha rutilans  (Fr.) Dennis & Rifai
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small, cup-shaped fruitbody with the spore-bearing upper surface reddish orange; the margin scalloped and fringed; the external surface whitish or pale orange with undulating, entangled, downy hairs; absent or short stem; growth among mosses especially Polytrichum; and microscopic characters including broadly elliptic spores ornamented with a more or less continuous colorless reticulum.^ RANGE ^Neottiella rutilans is found in WA, CA, and CO, (Larsen), NH and NY to IA, (Seaver), Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen), and the United Kingdom (Dennis). There is a collection from BC deposited by Paul Kroeger at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 1.5cm, disc concave, outer surface cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface reddish orange^, (Dennis), up to 1cm wide, at first closed and about the same diameter as the stem, gradually expanding to turbinate [top-shaped], the margin crenate [scalloped] and fringed with a few delicate hairs, (Seaver), 0.6-1.8cm wide, turbinate or disc-shaped, (Hansen) 
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  whitish, clothed with undulating entangled downy hairs^, (Dennis), whitish or pale orange (Seaver)
STEM  without a stem, or with a short stem often buried in the soil^, (Dennis), reaching 0.5cm, rather slender and short, gradually expanding it its upper part into the apothecium, (Seaver), substipitate, often with stem buried in sand, (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to scattered or gregarious on soil among mosses (especially Polytrichum), apparently growing on dead remnants and often hidden by the living mosses^, (Seaver), on sandy soils among Polytrichum, October to January, (Dennis for UK)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 22-25 x 13-15 um, broadly elliptic, ornamented with a more or less continuous colorless reticulum, containing one or two large oil drops^; asci up to 300 x 20 um; paraphyses slightly clavate, with orange contents that turn green in iodine; hairs thin-walled, septate, colorless, tapering to a rounded tip, (Dennis), spores 20-25 x 12-14 um, elliptic, at first smooth, becoming sculptured with reticulations that are often interrupted or broken, 1-seriate, obliquely arranged in the ascus, often with the ends overlapping; asci reaching a length of 300-350 um and width of 20 um; paraphyses enlarged at tips, where they reach 6 um wide, filled with orange granules; hairs reaching a length of 300 um and width of 10-12 um, colorless, septate, (Seaver), spores 22-27 x 13-15 um with an incomplete reticulum (illustrated), with one or two droplets; hairs 200-500 x 6-10 um, septate, pointed, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'reddening'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Sowerbyella rhenana.
SOURCES  Dennis(1), Seaver(1) (as Aleuria rutilans), Larsen(1) (as Leucoscypha rutilans), Hansen, L.(1)
225
FAMILY  Chorioactidaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Neournula pouchetii  (Berthet & Riousset) Paden^  Mycologia 64(2): 457. 1972;  Urnula pouchetii  Berthet & Riousset;  Neournula nordmanensis  Paden & Tylutki  Mycologia 60: 1161. 1968
ENGLISH NAME(S)  rose goblet
NOTES  Features include a deep cup with a pinkish to gray interior, a margin that is often toothed and may split and spread when old, a whitish exterior that darkens to grayish when old and discolors dark with handling, a whitish stem typically immersed in soil, litter, or duff, growth in spring under conifers, and microscopic characters.^ | It is possible that North American material is distinct from the European species, in which case the American lineage could be accommodated under the name Neournula nordmanensis Paden & Tylutki (Carbone(1)). RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, WA, ID, (Paden). It has been found at least in BC, WA, OR, and ID, (Larsen), and reported in eastern Canada, (Lincoff), as well as France and North Africa (Trudell).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  2-3cm across, fruitbody up to 4cm tall, when very young club-shaped, hollow in upper part, expanding and spreading to urn-shaped or margin splitting and spreading when old, regular in outline from above; spore-bearing upper (inner) surface "varying from pale pink-gray, gray touched with purple, or dingy pink before exposure to gray at maturity"; even to slightly irregular^, (Castellano), fruitbody 1.3-3.5 across, 2-4.5cm high, tough, leathery, urceolate to goblet-shaped, spore-bearing area on upper surface pale pink when young, about 'Rose Ebony' (color term according to Maerz(1)) when mature; color of spore-bearing surface also given as "pallidum vel purpureum" [pallid to purple]; marginal teeth usually rounded (crenate) but may be sharp-pointed (stellate) when young, (Paden), cup 1.5-3.5cm wide, 2-4.5cm high, deep, with pale pink to rose inner surface; toothed rim, (Lincoff), pinkish brown (Trudell)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  "at first nearly white to very pale gray", darkening to brown-gray to gray when old, "discoloring on handling to brown or brown-black, when fresh with a pale gray felted layer, paler to nearly white at the base"^, (Castellano), pale brown to purplish brown (Paden), whitish to tan to violet-brown (Trudell)
STEM  "expanding smoothly or more or less distinct, rounded in cross-section", paler than exterior (underside); typically immersed in soil, litter or duff, with basal rhizomorphs^, (Castellano), stem and usually part of the cup immersed in substrate; whitish, (Paden), 2-4cm x 0.5-1cm, usually buried; whitish, (Lincoff)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in conifer stands ranging from about 35 to over 200 years old, March through July^, (Castellano), gregarious to scattered, in conifer litter, April through July, (Paden), in conifer litter, under western cedar and hemlock, (Lincoff)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 23-32 x 8-10.5 um, "subcylindric to obscurely fusoid, the majority narrowly elliptic", "ornamented with low random ridges and warts"^; asci "operculate, inamyloid, relatively thick-walled, base narrow and curving", (Castellano), spores 23-31.5 x 8-10.4 um, elliptic to oblong with rounded ends, smooth, becoming covered with warts, (Lincoff), spores 23-31.5 x 8-10.4 um, elliptic to oblong with rounded ends, "smooth when young, at maturity ornamented with low warts that stain in heated cotton blue" and dissolve in dilute KOH, without droplets or containing a few small oil droplets; asci 8-spored, 290-390 x 12-15 um, cylindric, suboperculate, bases blunt, usually twisted, occasionally lobed, connected to the underlying tissue by a relatively narrow hypha, occasionally a lobed base cut off as a separate cell, tips often bent, not maturing simultaneously, suboperculate, opercula eccentric; paraphyses 3-3.5 um wide, "narrow, septate, freely branched and anastomosing", "tips embedded in a pale brown, amorphous material"; medullary excipulum about 500 um thick, of textura intricata (intricately interwoven), the hyphae 2-5 um wide, ectal excipulum of textura angularis (of subrectangular to polyhedral cells), inner cells colorless, outer cells with pale brown walls, giving rise to scattered nearly colorless to pale brown hairs 4-5 um wide, up to 70 um long, (Paden)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Paden(2) (as Neournula nordmanensis), Castellano(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Trudell(4)*, Larsen(1), Maerz(1), Carbone(1)
226
FAMILY  Mollisiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Nipterella parksii  (E.K. Cash) Dennis^  Persoonia 2(2): 189. 1962;  Belonium parksii  (Cash) Seaver [as parksi];  Belonidium parksii  Cash [as parksi]
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include green, stemless cups with fuscous, furfuraceous exterior, gregarious growth on stems of certain plants, and microscopic characters.^ The RANGE ^The type was found in Humboldt County, northwestern CA. There are collections identified as this species from BC 1948-1960 at the Pacific Forestry Centre in Victoria (see also HABITAT)..
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  cup-shaped, glaucous-green, drying chromium green; margin "inrolled, hysteroid, triangular, or irregularly folded"^, (Seaver from Cash) 
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  exterior fuscous, furfuraceous^, (Seaver from Cash)
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  Nipterella parksii "is evidently common on dead attached branches" of Alnus rubra (Red Alder) on Vancouver Island, (Tanney(2)), gregarious on "decorticated stems of Vaccinium parvifolium, Rhamnus purshiana, Garrya elliptica, Physocarpus capitatus and Castanopsis chrysophylla"^, (Seaver from Cash)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores about 13 x 3 um, fusoid, straight or slightly curved, becoming 1-3-septate, obliquely 1-seriate in lower part, 2-seriate in upper part^; asci 8-spored, reaching 65-80 um long and 6-8 um wide, clavate-cylindric, narrowed in upper part, gradually tapered into short stem; paraphyses "filiform, slightly enlarged above, 1.5-2 um thick", (Seaver), spores 11-17 x 2-4 um, usually about 13 x 3 um, fusoid, straight, or slightly curved, obliquely uniseriate in lower part to biseriate in upper part, with 4 droplets, becoming 1-3-septate, acute at both ends; paraphyses filamentous, septate, unbranched, tips granular and slightly enlarged to 1.5-2 um wide; excipulum dark-pseudoparenchymatous, cells 7-12 um in diameter, elongated toward margin, readily breaking up and giving the exterior its furfuraceous appearance, (Cash)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Belonium parksi), Cash(1) (as Belonidium parksi), Tanney(2)*
227
FAMILY  Mollisiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Nipterella tsugae  A. Funk^  Can. J. Bot. 56: 1578. 1978
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny discs that are dark brown and pruinose with a yellow spore-bearing upper surface, occasionally with smaller fruitbodies arising from within the primary one; rudimentary stem; growth on branches of Western Hemlock, and microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Funk(6). RANGE ^The type is from BC.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.15cm across, at first nearly spherical, expanding to broad disc, "regular or sometimes broadly undulate and proliferating smaller apothecia within" (the large undulating discs are formed as though closely situated fruitbodies had fused into one); spore-bearing surface yellow; margin broadly inrolled
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  dark brown; pruinose
STEM  subsessile [with rudimentary stem]
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  superficial, single, gregarious, in branches of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), appears to be a colonizer of the understory branches that are dying due to shading out
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-10 x 2-3 um, elliptic to cuneate, colorless, not septate^; asci 8-spored, 45-55 x 6-8 um, cylindric, "a rectangular plug at the apex staining blue in iodine"; paraphyses broadly filiform or cylindric, colorless, simple, not forming an epithecium; medullary excipulum of colorless plectenchyma, "ectal excipulum of dark brown, moniliform cells arranged perpendicular to surface"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Tsuga'
SIMILAR  Sageria tsugae may be similar superficially and may be found close on the same habitat.
SOURCES  Funk(6)
228
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Octospora leucoloma  Hedw. ex Gray^  Natural Arrangement of British Plants 1: 667. 1821
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include saucer shape, orange color, finely toothed margin, paler exterior, growth on the ground among mosses, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Octospora leucoloma is found in OR, ID, AK, CA, and CO, (Larsen), NY to DE and CO, (Seaver), Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen), and the United Kingdom (Dennis). There is a Robert Bandoni collection from BC at the University of British Columbia (as Humarina).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.3cm, saucer-shaped; orange; margin denticulate [finely toothed]^, (Dennis), reaching width of 0.2-0.5cm, at first spherical and closed, expanding and becoming platter-shaped or nearly disc-shaped; bright orange, (Seaver), fruitbody 0.1-0.3cm across, disc-shaped, yellowish orange, with distinct dentate margin, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  "exterior pale ochraceous with denticulate margin and downy with white anchoring hyphae below"^, (Dennis), pale orange (Seaver)
STEM  none^ (Dennis, Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or scattered on ground among mosses^ (Seaver), typically in cushions of Bryum argenteum in winter and spring, (Dennis for UK), together with Bryum argenteum, spring to fall, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-23.5 x 10.5-12.5 um, broadly elliptic-fusoid, smooth, usually with one large oil droplet and several small ones or occasionally with two almost of equal size, uniseriate or sometimes irregularly biseriate in the upper part^; asci 8-spored, up to 250 x 20 um; paraphyses straight or slightly curved in upper part, enlarged to 5 or 6 um at tip, (Dennis), spores 18-24 x 12-15 um, a few often larger, elliptic or with one or both ends slightly narrowed, smooth, usually with 1 large oil droplet surrounded by several smaller ones, 1-seriate or occasionally crowded, usually diagonally disposed; asci 8-spored, reaching length of 200-250 um and width of 20 um; paraphyses 3-4 um wide in lower part, widening in upper part and reaching a width of 8-9 um, branched, often curved and filled with numerous granules, (Seaver), spores 18-23.5 x 10.5-12.5 um, with one eccentric droplet, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with white border'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as Humarina leucoloma), Dennis(1), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1)
229
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Octospora rubens  (Boud.) M.M. Moser^  Kleine Kryptogamenflora (Stuttgart) 2a: 111. 1963
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small size, disc shape, orange to bright red color, pale orange exterior, growth on soil among mosses, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Octospora rubens is found in WA and CO, (Larsen, but occurrence not confirmed by either author), NY and CO, (Seaver), and Denmark, Finland, and Norway, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.1-0.3cm, at first nearly spherical, expanding to disc-shaped or almost disc-shaped, the spore-bearing upper surface becoming flat or occasionally a little convex; orange to bright red^, (Seaver) 
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale orange^ (Seaver)
STEM  Octospora species have little or no stem
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on damp soil among mosses^, (Seaver), same habitat as O. rustica which is found on burnt ground and sandy soil with Ceratodon purpureus (Hansen for northern Europe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-18 x 10-12 um, elliptic or oval, smooth, colorless, containing 1 large oil droplet, 1-seriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching length of 200 um and width of 16 um; paraphyses "rather stout, simple or branched, often swollen near the joints", reaching a width of 8-9 um at the tip, (Seaver), spores 15-18 x 10-12 um, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'reddening'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as Humarina rubens), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1)
230
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia angiosubvinosa  Baral, R. Tena & E. Weber^  in Baral, Weber & Marson, Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 620. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) a flat, sessile fruitbody that is light to deep orange, with a smooth to crenulate margin, 3) growth on rotting hardwood branches often near water bodies, and 4) microscopic characters including spores that are narrowly fusoid to fusoid-clavate and contain a spore body that is vermiform and may have basal inflation. Glassy processes are also seen microscopically.^ |"Based on the associated dwayaangam-like anamorph [Dwayaangam is a genus in Orbiliaceae] and the deep orange apothecia, the angiosperm-inhabiting Orbilia angiosubvinosa is undoubtedly closely related to the conifericolous O. subvinosa. Our preliminary molecular data indicate a close but distant relationship to that species. Morphologically, O. angiosubvinosa differs in slightly narrower conidia;" (Baral(3) with Latin italicized). |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^A collection from WA (14 km S of Acme) was used in the Baral(3) monograph. The holotype and other collection are from Spain.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody rehydrated (0.02)0.04-0.08cm across, 0.016cm high, +/- round, "disc flat, margin distinct, thin or thick", protruding 8 um, "smooth to distinctly crenulate"; "light to deep orange, rarely rose-orange, hardly to medium translucent", when dry "bright to deep orange-red, with thick protruding margin" 
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  "broadly sessile, superficial"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "very scattered to gregarious in small groups"; collected 1-1.5 m above the ground, "on partially to sometimes entirely decorticated", 0.7-4.0cm thick branches of Corylus, Rosa, and Salix, up to 0.1cm deep, "medium to strongly decayed wood", slightly to strongly grayed, +/- covered by green algae; collected repeatedly at water bodies such as ponds or streams; altitude: 83-1548 m; possibly fruiting throughout the year
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (live) (11.5)14-17(19) x (1.8)2-2.4(3) um, "narrowly fusoid (to fusoid-clavate), apex rounded to obtuse", base +/- attenuated, "sometimes tail-like, straight to very slightly, exceptionally strongly curved near base", spore bodies (live) (2.7)3.5- 5.5(7) x 0.6-1(1.3) um, vermiform or with a +/- ellipsoid basal inflation, "apically not narrowed", +/- broadly attached, straight, with some small lipid bodies^; |asci 8-spored, (live) (50)55-70(79) x (5)6-7(7.5) um, (dead) 40-65 x 4.6-5.5 um, spores (live) 3-4-seriate, 2-4 lower spores inverted, pars sporifera (live) 25-38 um long, apex (dead) hemispheric, dome (dead) 0.8-1.4 to 0.7-1 um thick, "with small apical chamber", "base with short to very long, thick or thin, flexuous stalk", T-shaped to L-shaped; |paraphyses "apically uninflated to very slightly clavate or lageniform", terminal cells (live) 9.5-16 x 1.8-2.8(3.2) um, lower cells (live) 8-11.5 x 1.5-2.6 um; "unbranched at upper septum", "hymenium light orange"; |medullary excipulum "pale rose to orange", 45 um thick, "of dense textura intricata with many inflated cells, medium sharply delimited"; |ectal excipulum "subhyaline at base, light orange towards margin", of (dead) not or slightly gelatinized, vertically oriented textura globulosa-angularis-prismatica from base to mid flanks, 30-35 um thick near base, cells (live) 8-16 x 5-10(13) um; 35 um thick near margin, of textura porrecta oriented at a 10-50 degree angle to the surface, marginal cortical cells (live) 6-15 x 2.5-3.5 um, glassy processes 0-1 or 5-28 x 2.5-3.5(3.8) um, +/- high-refractive, "stratified, coherent to form indistinct to distinct teeth"; |anchoring hyphae "medium abundant", (dead) 1.5-2.7 um wide, walls 0.2-0.3 um thick; KOH-sensitive bodies "in paraphyses and ectal excipulum (at margin) globose", 1-2.5 um in diameter, also crystalloid, in excipulum 2-4.5 x 1-1.5 um, colorless to pale orange; |lipid bodies "in lower part of paraphyses and in ectal excipular cells at mid flanks and margin" minute, +/- scattered, "light yellowish-orange"; |exudate "over paraphyses, margin and flanks" 1-2.5 um thick, cloddy, colorless to pale yellow, loosely attached; |anamorph dwayaangam-like, conidiophores "very short, unbranched", conidia "resembling clothes-pegs", total size (live) (26)35-52 x 10-11 um, 12-21 um wide when arms diverging; stem (live) 11-15 x 2.7-3.3(-3.7) um, "2-septate, usually shorter than basal arms", "twice dichotomously branched: two arms pointing upwards, two downwards, arms straight, not or slightly to medium tapered near the ends", (live) (11)13.5-26 x 3-3.5(3.8) um, 2-3-septate, containing many minute lipid bodies "near septa or close to wall", sometimes also with some large lipid bodies
NAME ORIGIN  "referring to the growth on angiosperms and the similarity with O. subvinosa" (Baral(3) with Latin italicized).
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
231
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia brettii  O. Ceska, Baral, G. Marson & E. Weber^  in Baral, Weber & Marson, Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 1323. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  Brett's Orbilia
NOTES  Features of Orbilia brettii include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) a pink to pinkish orange, cup-shaped fruitbody, with a rough to crenulate, crown-like margin due to glassy processes, 3) a stemless obconic base, 4) elliptic to fusoid or clavate spores containing a minute ampulliform spore body, usually in the upper wider end of the spore, 5) paraphyses that partly tend to be spathulate, and 6) growth on an attached, dry, rotten, hardwood branch.^ |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^Orbilia brettii is known only from the holotype in a valley of the Coast Mountains 1 km from Pemberton, BC.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  (rehydrated) 0.03-0.06cm across and ~0.2-0.25cm thick, round, disc +/- deeply concave, margin raised, protruding ~50-100 um; "light rose (-orange), slightly translucent", "dry bright rose orange"; "finely rough to distinctly crenulate" [probably referring to margin]
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  sessile on obconic base
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  holotype collection scattered to subgregarious, 1.5m above the ground, on a dry, 1.4cm thick, decorticated, medium rotten, attached branch of Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores live (5)6-7.3(8) x (2.5)2.8-3.5(4) um, dead (3)4-5 x 0.8-1.2 um, "ellipsoid, also fusoid or clavate, apex rounded to obtuse, base not or slightly to sometimes strongly attenuated, straight to slightly curved", uniseriate in ascus; spore bodies (living state) 1-1.3 x 0.5-0.8 um, "ampulliform (keyhole-shaped), attached to spore apex by a small point, usually in upper, wider end of spore (if heteropolar), also in narrower end or rarely at both ends"^ |asci 8-spored, live 50-70 x 5-6.5 um, dead 45-65 x (4)4.5-5(5.7) um, ~4-8 lower spores inverted (sometimes strongly mixed); pars sporifera live ~35-40 um, apex (dead) "medium to strongly truncate (not indented, laterally not inflated)", base "with short to long, thin or thick stalk, T- to Y- or h-shaped"; |paraphyses "apically medium to strongly clavate-capitate or sometimes spathulate", apex dead 2.5-3(4.5) um wide; |medullary excipulum ~40-80 um thick, "of dense textura intricata with many small inflated cells, medium sharply delimited"; |ectal excipulum "of thin-walled, indistinctly oriented" textura globulosa-angularis "from base to margin", 50-150 um thick near base, cells (living) ~1025 um in diameter, (dead) 8-16 x 5-12 um; ~20-50 um thick at margin, indistinctly oriented at a ~ 40-90 degree angle to the surface, marginal cortical cells dead ~ 5-8 x 4-5 um; glassy processes ~20-35 x (1.5)2-2.5(3) um, "medium refractive, rough, not distinctly zonate, agglutinated but not forming distinct teeth, curved outwards"; |anchoring hyphae "medium abundant at base", dead 1.5- 3(4) um wide, walls 0.2 um thick, forming a 10-15 um thick, "dense layer of interwoven hyphae at flanks"; |exudate "over paraphyses and glassy processes" ~0.2-0.5 um thick, colorless, "granular, firmly attached" |anamorph unknown
NAME ORIGIN  in honour of Bob Brett M.Sc., "forest ecologist and environmental consultant in British Columbia" [Bob Brett has also organized annual Whistler bioblitzes]
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
232
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia canadensis  Baral & G. Marson^  in Baral, Weber & Marson, Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 1251. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) a slightly concave to flat, sessile fruitbody that is orange-rose with a smooth margin, 3) growth on dry, rotting hardwood twigs and branches, and 4) microscopic characters including 16-spored asci and broadly elliptic spores containing a globose spore body.^ |Orbilia canadensis is easily recognized by its subglobose to broadly ellipsoid ascospores and 16-spored asci, (Baral(3)). |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^Orbilia canadensis was listed from BC, AB (including holotype), Norway, and Greenland. The BC collection was from about 400 km northeast of Vancouver. (Baral(3)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody rehydrated 0.03-0.08cm across, 0.013-0.016cm high, round, "disc slightly concave to flat, margin thin or thick", protruding 0-20 um, smooth; "light to bright pure orange-rose"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  broadly sessile, superficial or +/- erumpent between wood fibres
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to +/- gregarious in small groups; collected 0-2.5 m above the ground, partially to sometimes entirely decorticated, 0.3-1.0cm thick, dry hardwood twigs/branches of the families Betulaceae and Salicaceae, on 0.02-0.03cm deep medium to strongly decayed wood, also on bark, +/- greyed, with some green algae; altitude 200 m (subpolar tundra), 500-1165 m (boreal forests); fruiting June to August "but probably throughout the year", long-lived
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (live) (3.4)3.6-4.5(5.3) x (2.3)2.5-3.2(3.4) um, (dead) 3.6-4.2 x 2.4-2.7 um, "subglobose to ovoid or (broadly) ellipsoid, both ends rounded to obtuse", spore bodies (live) 1.1-1.3(1.5) x 0.8-1.3 um, "globose, sometimes with a very short filum or attachment invisible, also closely attached"^; |asci 16-spored, (live) (51)55-69 x 5.4-6.4 um, (dead) 50-68 x 4.5-5.7 um, spores (live) (sub)biseriate, towards base uniseriate, dead also apically partly uniseriate, "lower spores inversely oriented (strongly mixed, some laterally oriented)", pars sporifera (live) 35-50 um long, apex (dead) "slightly to strongly truncate (not indented, laterally not widened), thin-walled, sometimes with apical thickening" up to 0.5 um "(with very slight apical chamber)", base with short to medium long, thick, +/- flexuous stalk, T-shaped, L-shaped or h-shaped; |paraphyses "apically (uninflated to) slightly to medium (rarely strongly) clavate-capitate to spathulate, rarely lageniform or moniliform", terminal cells (live) 5.5-19.5 x (2.5)3-5(5.7) um, lower cells (live) 7-16 x 1.6-2.7(4) um; sometimes branched near apex; |medullary excipulum colorless "to pale rose-orange", 40-50 um thick, "of medium dense textura intricata with many inflated cells, sharply delimited" |ectal excipulum "(very) pale rose-orange", of (dead) slightly to medium gelatinized (common walls 0.5-2 um thick), vertically oriented textura angularis(-prismatica) "from base to mid flanks", 25-50 um thick near base, cells (live) 8-22 x 6-14.5 um; 15-35 um thick near margin, of textura prismatica oriented at a 20-45 degree angle to the surface, marginal cortical cells (live) 8-18 x 2.8-3 or 4-6.5 um, (live) slightly or (dead) strongly thick-walled (inner wall low-refractive), glassy processes absent; |anchoring hyphae sparse or often abundant, live/dead 2.5-3.5(4) um wide, walls (live) 0.2-0.7 um [(dead) 0.3-0.8(1) um] thick, forming a dense, medium gelatinized textura intricata up to 20-30 um thick. |KOH-sensitive bodies globose, in paraphyses (1)1.8-3.5 um in diameter, in excipular cells 1.5-3.5 um; |exudate over paraphyses 0.5-3 um thick, "continuous to cloddy, smooth to rough, very pale yellowish",  loosely attached, "over margin and flanks rough-cloddy". |anamorph unknown
NAME ORIGIN  "from the geographical origin of the holotype, Canada", (Baral(3))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
233
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia coniferarum  Baral & E. Weber^  in Baral, Weber & Marson, Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 1163. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) a flat, sessile fruitbody that is orange or orange-rose, with a finely rough margin, 3) growth on dry, rotten, conifer branches, and 4) microscopic characters including elliptic to fusoid-clavate spores with a threadlike, flexuous spore body.^ |Orbilia coniferarum "is characterized by rather long, filiform, basally uninflated, flexuous spore bodies and medium-sized ascospores of somewhat variable, ellipsoid- to fusoid-clavate shape (often basally attenuated and curved), also by the occurrence on coniferous substrate." (Baral(3)). |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^Collections from ID, UT (including holotype), TX, Croatia, and France were used in Baral(3).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody rehydrated 0.02-0.05(0.07)cm across, 0.011-0.019cm high, round, "light to bright orange(-rose), not or slightly translucent", disc flat, margin indistinct to distinct, slightly thickened, 0-5 um protruding, finely rough; when dry, bright orange-red
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  +/- broadly sessile, "slightly erumpent or immersed"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY
