HABITAT  "scattered to subgregarious"; collected 0.5-3 m above the ground, decorticated, 0.8-8.0cm thick branches of Abies concolor, Juniperus, Picea sitchensis, Pinus halepensis, P. sylvestris, and Pseudotsuga menziesii, on 0.01-0.04cm "deep medium to strongly decayed wood" or bark, slightly to strongly grayed, "green algae sparse to medium abundant", altitude 1-2778 m, inhabits slightly to strongly rotten wood or bark of dry branches of different coniferous trees and shrubs; fully viable for at least 17 months
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (live) (6.5)8-10(13) x (2.3)2.5-3(3.2) um, (dead) (7)8-10(11) x 2.4-3(3.2) um, ellipsoid-clavate to fusoid-clavate, "apex rounded to obtuse, base mostly medium to strongly attenuated, straight or slightly to medium curved near base", spore bodies (live) (3)4-7.5(10) x (0.2)0.3-0.5(0.8) um in situ (~ 4-10 um actual length), "filiform to vermiform, partly subulate, not or sometimes very indistinctly swollen at base, slightly to strongly flexuous or helicoid, sometimes uncinate", lipid bodies sparse, small^; |asci 8-spored, (live) (38)50-65(70) x (5.3)6-7(7.3) um, (dead) (41)50-60(65) x 4.8-5.7(6.3) um, spores (live) 3(4)-seriate, (2)3-5 lower spores inverted (often mixed), pars sporifera (live) 24-27 um long, apex (dead) "medium to strongly truncate (partly very slightly indented, laterally distinctly inflated or not)", base with short to medium long, +/- thick, flexuous stalk, L-shaped, T-shaped, Y-shaped or h-shaped; |paraphyses "apically slightly to strongly clavate-capitate, sometimes slightly spathulate", terminal cells (live) (6)10-19 x (2)2.7-4.5(5.3) um, (dead) 2.5-4 um wide, lower cells (live) 10.5-14(17.5) x 1.3-2.2 um, (dead) 1-1.5 um wide; "rarely or sometimes branched at upper septum"; |medullary excipulum subhyaline, 40-60 um thick, "of dense textura intricata with slightly inflated cells, indistinctly to very sharply delimited from ectal excipulum" by an inconspicuous textura porrecta; |ectal excipulum "subhyaline to pale orange, of thin-walled, (irregularly) vertically oriented" textura angularis(-prismatica) "from base to mid flanks", 30-70 um thick near base, cells (live) 8-16 x 5-10(16.5) um, 30 um thick at flanks, 20-25 um near margin, of textura prismatica-porrecta oriented at an 80-90 degree angle to the surface, marginal cortical cells (live/dead) 8-15 x 2-5.5 um, thick-walled (dead 0.3-1 um), "somewhat free and agglutinated as indistinct minute teeth"; |anchoring hyphae "medium sparse to abundant", (live/dead) 2.2-3.5(4.2) um wide, walls (0.2)0.3-0.6 um thick, "forming a thin covering layer at flanks"; |KOH-sensitive bodies in paraphyses globose, 1-1.5 um in diameter, "in excipulum not observed"; |exudate over paraphyses 0.2-0.7 um thick, "granular-cloddy, firmly attached", "over margin and flanks thin, granular"; |anamorph tridentaria-like [Tridentaria is an ascomycete genus.], conidiophores not seen, conidia with (3)4-5(6) arms, (live) 29-40 x 11.5-17 um, stem (live) 10-13.5 x 4-5.5 um, (dead) 11 x 3.2 um, 1(2)-septate, arms (live) 14-28.5 x 4.5-5.5 um, (dead) 24-25 x 4 um, (2)4-5-septate, cylindric, "apically mostly slightly to strongly tapering"
NAME ORIGIN  "named after the occurrence on coniferous hosts" (Baral(3))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
234
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia delphinus  Baral & G. Marson^  in Baral, Weber & Marson, Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 1105. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) a slightly concave to slightly convex, sessile fruitbody that is light rose-orange to orange, with a smooth to crenulate margin, 3) growth on dry, rotting twigs and branches of hardwood or occasionally conifer wood, in mountainous areas, and 4) microscopic characters including 16-spored asci, and spores that are narrow fusiform and contain a spore body that is clavate and sometimes flexuous.^ |Orbilia delphinus is characterized by 16-spored asci and narrowly fusiform-clavate ascospores with subulate, +/- flexuous spore bodies, also by the general absence of crystalloid KOH-sensitive bodies, and a montane distribution, (Baral(3)). |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^Collections were included in Baral(3) for AZ, CO (including holotype), ID, UT, France, Spain, and Mongolia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody rehydrated (0.012)0.025- 0.045(0.06)cm across, 0.012-0.02cm high, round, "disc slightly concave to flat, finally slightly to medium convex", margin +/- distinct, protruding 0-20 um, "smooth or often finely rough to crenulate"; "(pale) light (bright) rose-orange to orange(-ochraceous)", +/- translucent, when dry light to deep orange
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  "sessile, superficial or slightly to completely immersed among fibres or biofilm"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  very scattered to +/- gregarious; recorded from rotten wood, more rarely bark, of dry twigs and branches of hardwood or more rarely coniferous trees and shrubs, collected 0.1-3 m above the ground, corticated or more often +/- decorticated, 0.4-2.5(8.0)cm thick twigs and branches of Abies concolor, Amelanchier, Betula, Cercocarpus, Cistus laurifolius, Corylus cornuta, Ericameria nauseosa, Larix sibirica, Lonicera, Pinus sylvestris, Populus tremuloides, Potentilla fruticosa, Prunus domestica, Quercus gambelii, Ribes cereum, Rosa, Salix, on 0.01-0.1cm deep (medium to) strongly decayed wood, more rarely bark, partly +/- detaching, sometimes eroded, slightly to strongly grayed, "green algae sparse or abundant"; altitude: 1083-2980 m; fruiting throughout the year, long-lived
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (live) (8)9-13(15) x (1.7)1.9-2.3(2.6) um, (dead) 8-12 x (1.6)1.8-2.2(2.3) um, "narrowly fusiform to fusiform-clavate", sometimes with +/- cylindric middle part, "apex acute to acuminate, base slightly to medium attenuated (rarely not or strongly so), straight to slightly (or medium) curved", spore bodies (live) (4)5-8(10.5) x (0.6)0.7-1(1.3) -> 4-6(7.5) x 1-1.4 um in situ "(actual length hardly longer)", "(vermiform to) subulate, base not or slightly to medium, rarely strongly inflated, slightly to strongly flexuous, very rarely uncinate"; overmature 4.5-5.5 x 1-1.5 um, "globose with a long filum"^; |asci 16-spored, (live) (52)60-80(92) x (5.5)6-7(7.6) um, (dead) (48)55-75(80) x (5)5.2-6.5(7) um, spores (live) (3)4-seriate, (5)7-9(10) lower spores inverted "(mostly strongly mixed)", pars sporifera (live) (30)35-47(50) um long, apex (dead) "(medium to) strongly truncate (very slightly indented, laterally distinctly inflated or not)", base with short to medium long, +/- thick, flexuous stalk, T-shaped, L-shaped or h-shaped, (exceptionally H-shaped); |paraphyses "apically (slightly to) medium to very strongly capitate-clavate, rarely spathulate or lageniform", terminal cells (live) (6-)10-24 x (2.5)3-5(5.8) um, (dead) 2.8-4 um wide, lower cells (live) (7)8.5-17(19) x (1)1.3-2(2.3) um; "rarely branched at thick upper septum"; |medullary excipulum colorless to pale rose, 15-50 um, of loose to +/- dense textura intricata "with many inflated cells, sharply delimited"; |ectal excipulum colorless to pale rose-orange, of (dead) "thin-walled to slightly gelatinized, vertically oriented" textura angularis(- prismatica) "from base to mid flanks", 20-60 um thick near base, cells (live) 7-21(30) x 6-10.5(16) um; 25-30 um thick "at flanks and margin", near margin of pale to light orange textura prismatica(-porrecta) oriented at a 10-45 degree angle to the surface, marginal cortical cells (live) 6.5-16 x 2.5-5 um; |anchoring hyphae "more or less abundant", (live)2-3.8(4.5) um wide, walls 0.2-0.8 um thick, sometimes forming an up to 12 um thick covering layer "of glassy, undulating hyphae up to the margin"; |KOH-sensitive bodies "in paraphyses and ectal excipulum (near margin) globose", 1-2.5 um in diameter, partly absent, "rarely very few rod-shaped" KOH-sensitive bodies present; |exudate over paraphyses 0.2-1(1.5) um thick, rough, colorless "to pale yellowish-reddish, firmly attached", forming a 0.2-0.5 um thick layer "over margin and flanks"; |anamorph unknown
NAME ORIGIN  "named after the ascospores which partly resemble a dolphin" (Baral(3)); it does not agree with the genus gender because it is a noun
SIMILAR  Orbilia subtrapeziformis is very similar, likewise subalpine-boreal but mainly European and mainly differing in having 8-spored asci. Orbilia maeandrina sharply differs in wider, also slightly shorter, more amygdaliform ascospores (with a markedly lower length/width ratio). Orbilia macrodelphinus is tentatively segregated from O. delphinus based on wider asci and spores. Orbilia multidelphinus [not known from the Pacific Northwest but found in Utah and New Mexico] has 32-spored asci. (Baral(3)).
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
235
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia flavida  Feltgen^  Vorstud Pilzfl. Luxemb., Nachtr. III: 43. 1903
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) a concave to convex, sessile fruitbody that is rose to orange with a crenulate margin, 3) preferential growth on rotten, dry herbaceous stems, but also on rotten hardwood, and 4) microscopic characters including 32-spored asci and ellipsoid-clavate, partially curved spores that contain a lens-shaped, broadly attached spore body.^ |"Orbilia flavida is characterized by 32-spored asci and rather small, ellipsoid-clavate, partially curved ascospores." (Baral(3)). |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^Orbilia flavida was listed by Baral(3) and studied by one of the authors from BC and WA. It was also listed for Luxembourg (holotype), Germany, France, Spain, Croatia (including designated epitype), Turkey, and the Canary Islands.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody rehydrated (0.015)0.02- 0.04(0.05)cm across, 0.009-0.018cm high, "round or sometimes broadly elliptical", "hymenium slightly concave to flat", "disc often finally slightly to medium convex", margin protruding 0-5 um, "irregularly finely crenulate, rarely smooth, thick in young apothecia", exterior bald; "(pale to) light (to bright) rose to orange, very rarely with a shade of yellow (but pale yellow in the type, according to Feltgen), often translucent", dry fruitbody light to deep orange
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  broadly sessile, erumpent between fibres, also seemingly superficial
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "very scattered to medium gregarious", collected on dry ground or 0.05-5m above the ground, 1(?-2) years old, 0.6-3.5cm thick "herbaceous stems, rarely petioles", O. flavida prefers to grow on rotten, dry herbaceous stems, but also occurs on rotten wood and bark of dry branches of different hardwood trees and shrubs; fruiting February to November
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (live) (3.8)5-8(10.5) x (2)2.2-2.8(3.2) um, (dead) 4-7 x 1.7-2.5 um, "ellipsoid to often ellipsoid-clavate, also subcylindrical or fusoid, apex rounded to obtuse, rarely with a tail-like base, straight or quite often slightly to strongly curved near base (comma-shaped)", spore bodies 0.4-0.7(0.9) x 1.2-1.6 um, "lens-shaped, apically broadly attached", with a few minute lipid bodies^; |asci "32-spored, very rarely some asci with only ~ 16 spores", (live) (54)60-85(109) x (6.7)7-8.8(9.3) um, (dead) 49-73(82) x (5.7)6-7(7.5) um, pars sporifera (live) (28)33-49 um long, (dead) 36-46 um (type), "10-16 lower spores inversely oriented", "usually mixed in the middle part only", apex (dead) "slightly to medium (to strongly) (conico-) truncate, hemispherical in profile view", dome (dead) 0.5-0.8(1) to 0.3-0.4 um thick, "with a low apical chamber", base with short or +/- long undulating stalk, T-shaped, L-shaped, h-shaped or rarely H-shaped. |paraphyses "apically uninflated or often slightly to medium or even strongly clavate-capitate, often irregular in shape", terminal cell (live) (5)7-17(22) x (2)2.5-5(5.5) um, (dead) 1.5-3.5(4.5) um wide, lower cells (live) 8-14.5(18) x 1.2- 2(3) um, (dead) 8-12 x 0.8-1.5 um, enlarged to (live) 2-2.5(2.8) um near base and apex, "quite often di(-tri)chotomously branched near apex"; |medullary excipulum pale rose, 20-30 um thick, "of dense textura angularis, indistinctly delimited"; |ectal excipulum "very pale rose", of thin-walled textura globulosa-angularis "from base to mid flanks or margin", 25-40(55) um thick near base, cells (live) 5-15(21) x 5-13(18) um, oriented irregularly or horizontally "(though cells vertically elongate)"; 15-30 um thick "at flanks and margin", oriented at a 0-10 degrees or up to 80 degree angle, cells (live) 6-9 x 6-10 um, "slightly to strongly thick-walled" (common walls (dead) 0.5-1(1.5) um thick), "marginal cortical cells elongate", (live) 5-15 x 3-4.5 um, "cylindric-clavate"; |anchoring hyphae "especially near base, at flanks forming a thin appressed layer", live/dead 2-3.5(4) um wide, walls 0.2- 0.4(0.8) um thick; |KOH-sensitive bodies "globose, in terminal cells of paraphyses" 1.5-3.5 um in diameter, low-refractive, 1(2) per cell, in marginal cortical cells 1.5-3(4) um in diameter; |exudate "pale yellowish(-amber)", over paraphyses 0.3-0.8 up to 1-2(3) um thick, continuous or +/- cloddy, loosely attached, over margin thin; |anamorph: trinacrium-like (from ascospore isolate) [Trinacrium is a genus in Orbiliaceae], conidiophores not observed, conidia Y-shaped, total size (live) 30-36 x 17.5-30.5 um, stem (live) 17.5-25 x 4.3- 5.5 um, 2-3-septate, arms tapering, (live) 9-16.5 x 3-4.3 um, 1-2-septate, "a single unbranched phragmoconidium seen": (live) 37 x 4.5 um, 4-septate
NAME ORIGIN  "from the yellowish colour of the apothecia in the holotype (though recent samples are consistently reddish)", (Baral)
SIMILAR  Orbilia plurilentiformis [found as close as Utah] also has 32-spored asci but has larger live spores measuring (5.8)7-10.5(11.3) x (2.8)3-3.6(4.5) um. |Small-spored populations of Orbilia pleiolentiformis [a species found as close as Utah] "differ from O. flavida mainly in 16-spored asci." |Orbilia myriolentiformis [known from France] "deviates in 64-spored asci, also in larger spores and, therefore, much larger asci." (Baral(3)). |Orbilia multidelphinus [found as close as Utah and New Mexico] also has 32-spored asci, but live spores are (9.5)11-14.7 x 2.3-2.6 um, and spore body is vermiform-subulate to almost filiform.
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
236
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia flexisoma  Baral & G. Marson^  in Baral, Weber & Marson, Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 1095. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) a concave to flat, sessile fruitbody with a finely rough to denticulate margin, 3) growth on dry, rotting branches, and 4) microscopic characters including fusoid to fusoid-clavate spores (sometimes with a tail-like base) containing a vermiform to subulate spore body that is sometimes swollen at the base.^ |"Orbilia flexisoma is tentatively segregated from O. obtusispora based on slightly wider and mostly also longer ascospores, and from O. macrotrapeziformis based on mostly longer spores" with more strongly flexuous spore bodies, "somewhat less acute spore apices, and the partial presence of distinct spore tails, though spore tails were rarely also seen in O. macrotrapeziformis, and finally on much larger apothecia." (Baral(3) with Latin names italicized). |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^Orbilia flexisoma was examined from AZ (including the holotype) and BC.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbodies rehydrated 0.025-0.07(0.09)cm across, 0.014-0.021cm high (receptacle 0.014cm), round (to elliptic), disc +/- concave, soon flat; "light to bright (yellowish-)orange, non-translucent"; margin distinct, protruding 0-80 um, "finely rough to somewhat denticulate, whitish-powdered"; when dry, brick-red
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  "broadly sessile, slightly to deeply immersed"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to subgregarious, collected 1-2.5 m above the ground, decorticated, 0.7-1.9cm thick dry branches of Acer (maple), Cercocarpus ledifolius (Curlleaf Cercocarpus), Juniperus osteosperma (Utah Juniper), Quercus gambelii (Gambel Oak), on 0.05-0.1cm deep very decayed wood, strongly grayed, "with sparse to abundant green algae"; altitude 830-2500 m; also in a boreal humid conifer forest with Populus tremuloides (Black Cottonwood) and Acer in the Canadian Rocky Mountains.
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores live (9)12-17(20.3) x (2.4)2.6-3.2(3.8) um, dead (9)11-15(17.3) x (2.5)2.7-3.2(3.5) um, "fusoid- to fusiform-clavate, rarely also narrowly ellipsoid-obclavate, apex subacute, also acute or obtuse, base not or slightly to mostly medium to strongly attenuated in a tail-like base or a distinct, sometimes basally inflated tail, straight or slightly to sometimes strongly curved near base" spore bodies (4)5-9 x 0.5-1(1.2) um in situ (~6-11 um actual length), "vermiform to subulate, not or slightly (also distinctly) swollen at base, mostly strongly flexuous, sometimes uncinate", with or without some medium-sized lipid bodies, "hymenium pale rose"^; |asci 8-spored, (live) (60)75-100(113) x (6)6.5-7.5(8.8) um, (dead) (55)60-90 x 5.5-6.5(7) um, spores (live) 2-3-seriate, (2)3-5(6) lower spores inverted (often mixed), pars sporifera (live) (30)40-60(80) um long, apex (dead) "strongly truncate (not or very slightly indented, laterally sometimes inflated)", base with short to medium long, thick, flexuous stalk, T-shaped, Y-shaped to h-shaped. |paraphyses "apically slightly to medium clavate, exceptionally spathulate", terminal cells (live) 4.5-13 x (2)2.8-4(?5) um, lower cells (live) 9.5-17 x 1.3-2(2.3) um, unbranched at upper septum; |medullary excipulum 30-70 um thick, pale rose, "of dense textura intricata with many inflated cells, sharply delimited"; |ectal excipulum pale rose, of (dead) "thin-walled to distinctly gelatinized, irregularly vertically oriented" textura globulosa-angularis "from base to mid flanks or submargin", 30-100 um thick near base, cells (live) 6-16(20) x 6-13(15) um; 20 um thick at flanks, 15-30 um near margin, of textura porrecta oriented at a 10-30 degree angle to the surface, upper margin up to 50 um thick if protruding, "with incurved, periphyses-like marginal cortical cells" (dead) 8-14 x 2-3 um; |anchoring hyphae "medium abundant", live/dead 2.5-4 um wide, walls 0.2-0.4 um, "partly covering flanks and margin as a gelatinized layer". |KOH-sensitive bodies in paraphyses and ectal excipulum absent or present, globose; |exudate over paraphyses 0.2-0.8 um thick, finely rough, +/- continuous, +/- firmly attached, "over margin and flanks" 0.2 um thick, "granular to continuous"; |anamorph unknown 
NAME ORIGIN  "named after the flexuous spore bodies" (Baral(3))
SIMILAR  Orbilia spathulata resembles O. flexisoma in spores and spored bodies, but deviates in the apical spores being inversely oriented within the asci, paraphyses with predominantly spathulate apices, and presence of crystalloid KOH-sensitive bodies, (Baral(3)). |"In one of the two samples on Quercus" "a separate population deviated in basally always medium to strongly curved spores and in growing on bark instead of wood. We have segregated this population as a distinct species, O. curvatitrapeziformis." (Baral(3) with Latin italicized). |See also SIMILAR section of Orbilia idahoensis.
SOURCES  Baral(3)
237
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia idahoensis  Baral & G. Marson^  in Baral, Weber & Marson, Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 1094. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) a concave to flat, sessile fruitbody that is orange to brick-red, with a distinct margin, 3) growth on dry, rotting twigs and branches of angiosperms including Ribes, and 4) microscopic characters including long, narrow, fusiform spores containing a subulate spore body with a basal inflation.^ |Orbilia idahoensis "appears to be well characterized by its long and narrow, fusiform ascospores and rather wide, subulate spore bodies" with a +/- bulbous basal inflation. (Baral(3)). |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^The holotype is from ID. It is also known from UT.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbodies rehydrated 0.0180.043cm across, 0.012-0.013cm high, round, "disc slightly concave to flat, margin distinct", 0-10 um protruding, +/- smooth; "light to bright orange to brick-red, scarcely translucent" 
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  broadly sessile, fruitbody superficial to slightly erumpent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  +/- scattered, partially to entirely decorticated, 0.4-1.6cm thick, dry twigs and branches of Amelanchier, Cercocarpus, Ribes cereum, on 0.02-0.05cm deep strongly decayed wood, grayed, no algae, altitude 1750-2570 m
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (live) (12)13-18(19.3) x 1.8-2.5 um, "narrowly fusiform(-clavate), apex acute (to acuminate), base medium attenuated (tail-like), slightly curved near base", spore bodies (live) (5.5)7-10.5 x (0.8)1-1.3(1.5) um, "vermiform to subulate, with slightly to strongly swollen base, straight to medium flexuous"^; |asci 8-spored, live (60)70-75(85) x (5.4)6-7 um, dead (45)55-70 x 5.3-6 um, spores live 3-4-seriate, 3-5 lower spores inverted (often mixed), pars sporifera live 3037 um long; apex (dead) "strongly truncate (slightly indented, laterally slightly widened)", base with short, thick, +/- flexuous stalk, T-shaped, L-shaped, or Y-shaped; |paraphyses "apically (slightly to) medium to very strongly clavate-capitate, rarely moniliform or lageniform", terminal cells (live) 7.5-19 x (3)4-5.3 um, lower cells (live)14-19 x 1.3-2(3) um; rarely branched at upper septum; |medullary excipulum subhyaline, 30-40 um thick, "of loose textura intricata with many inflated cells"; |ectal excipulum pale rose, of medium gelatinized (common walls (dead) 0.5-1.3 um), vertically oriented textura globulosa-angularis "from base to submargin", 20-35 um thick near base, cells (live) 12-21 x 10-15 um; 20 um thick near margin, upper margin of textura prismatica oriented at a 10 degree angle to surface, marginal cortical cells (live) 10-15 x 3.5-5 um. |anchoring hyphae abundant, (live) 2.5-3 um wide, walls 0.2-0.4 um thick, forming a dense, +/- gelatinized, colorless textura intricata up to 40 um thick, covering flanks and margin as a 5-12 um thick layer. |KOH-sensitive bodies in paraphyses and ectal excipulum (upper margin) globose, 1.5-2 um in diameter. |exudate over paraphyses and marginal excipulum 0.2-0.7 um, granular-cloddy, firmly attached. |anamorph unknown
NAME ORIGIN  "named after the state Idaho (USA) in which the type was collected"
SIMILAR  Orbilia subtrapeziformis "differs in shorter and slightly wider spores". |Orbilia flexisoma, and Orbilia macrotrapeziformis [found as close as Arizona and New Mexico] "differ in shorter and/or wider spores". |Orbilia vinosa [known to be as close as Wyoming] might be confused with O. idahoensis, but O. idahoensis has "distinctly longer spore bodies and more acute spore apices, besides thin-walled truncate ascus apices". (Baral(3)). |See also SIMILAR section of Orbilia spathulata.
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
238
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia leucostigma  (Fr.) Fr.^  Summa veg. Scand., Sectio Post. (Stockholm): 357. 1849
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 0.5cm, 2) slightly convex to flat or convex fruitbody that is whitish to pale rosaceous-lilaceous, 3) gregarious growth on rotten wood or moist ground, and 4) microscopic characters including small cashew-shaped, semicircular spores containing a round spore body at one end, and at high power, warts on the dorsal side.^ |The world monograph of Orbiliomycetes used a combined description of this species with Orbilia xanthostigma - morphological details are very similar and some authors have considered them color forms of the same species. DNA study has shown them to be genetically close but separate species (Baral(3)). See Orbilia xanthostigma for the full account. RANGE ^Orbilia leucostigma is common in Europe, and was also listed by Baral(3) from ME, NY, Russia, Ukraine, China, and Australia, but the distribution is probably much wider.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  ^
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  When O. leucostigma is pale chlorinaceous, it "may easily be confused with Hyalorbilia inflatula, and when pale rose-lilaceous it strongly resembles Orbilia sarraziniana or Orbilia rosea. Completely hyaline (whitish) populations of O. leucostigma do not markedly differ macroscopically from species such as Orbilia epipora or whitish populations of Orbilia auricolor." (Baral(3) with Latin italicized). Baral(3) do not include any collections of these species from the Pacific Northwest. Hyalorbilia inflatula is included for Eurasia and also included for Australia and Puerto Rico. Orbilia sarraziniana and Orbilia rosea were included for Eurasia. Orbilia epipora was included for Eurasia and Virginia. Orbilia auricolor was included for California, Texas, Wisconsin, eastern North America, Eurasia, Africa, West Indies, Latin America, Australia and Antarctica!
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
239
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia macrodelphinus  Baral & G. Marson^  in Baral, Weber & Marson, Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 1113. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) a concave to flat fruitbody that is pale to bright yellow-orange or orange, with a margin that is smooth to crenulate, 3) growth on dry, rotting wood of twigs and branches, 4) microscopic characters including fusiform to fusoid-clavate spores containing a vermiform to subulate spore body that may be distinctly inflated at the base.^ |Orbilia macrodelphinus resembles O. delphinus and O. maeandrina in its 16-spored asci, ascospores with +/- acute apices, thick and medium long, subulate spore bodies, and in the predominant absence of crystalloid KOH-sensitive bodies. Those collections assigned to the latter two species are very different from each other concerning their spores, whereas O. macrodelphinus forms an intermediate taxon which is only tentatively separated from both of them. It differs from O. delphinus in a tendency to wider asci and spores, and more distinctly fusiform spores, and from O. maeandrina in longer, basally more tapered and curved spores. However, spore and ascus size overlaps in some of the collections. (Baral(3)). |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^Collections used in Baral(3) are from ID, UT (including holotype), AZ, and the Canary Islands.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody rehydrated (0.015)0.02-0.06(0.09)cm across, 0.011-0.014cm up to 0.019-0.023cm high, round, "disc medium concave to flat, rarely finally convex, margin distinct", protruding 0-20 or sometimes 30-60 um, "smooth to finely rough or crenulate (partly whitish)"; "pale to bright yellowish-orange to orange, rarely rose, scarcely translucent"; when dry bright to dark orange
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  (broadly) sessile, +/- immersed but also superficial
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to subgregarious; found on rotten wood, rarely bark, of dry twigs and branches of both hardwood and conifer trees and shrubs; collected 0.5-2.5 m above the ground, decorticated or +/- corticated, 0.4-1.4cm thick twigs and branches; on 0.02-0.1cm deep "(medium to) strongly decayed wood" and bark, strongly grayed, "a few or many green algae"; altitude 975-2650 m; fully viable for at least nine months; occurring on Baccharis salicifolia, Canotia holacantha, Cytisus supranubius, Juniperus osteosperma, Larrea tridentata, Picea sitchensis, Pseudotsuga menziesii, and Purshia stansburyana; in western North America it occurred in "semiarid pinyon-juniper woodlands" and "boreal humid Douglas fir mixed forests" of the Middle Rocky Mountains and adjacent Columbia Plateau, and also in warm-temperate semiarid paloverde-mixed cacti desert scrubs
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (live) (8)10-12.5(16.5) x (2)2.4-2.8(3.5) um, (dead) (8.5)9-13(14) x 2.1-2.8 um, "fusiform to fusiform-clavate or fusoid-clavate, apex subacute to acute, rarely obtuse, base mostly (medium to) strongly attenuated, rarely with a tail-like base, here mostly slightly to medium (rarely strongly) curved", spore bodies (live) 4.5-6 or 6-7 or 6-12 x 0.8-1.3(1.5) um in situ (~ 5-13 um actual length), "vermiform to subulate, not or often distinctly inflated at base", straight to +/- strongly flexuous^; |asci 16-spored, 65-82(88) x 6-7 or (6.5)7.5-8(8.5) or 8-9.5 um, (dead) (54)60-81(90) x (5.3)5.5-7.5(8.7) um, spores (live) 3-4-seriate, 6-12 lower spores inverted "(rarely mixed)", pars sporifera (live) 46-55 um long, apex (dead) "strongly truncate (not or distinctly indented, laterally not or scarcely widened)", base "with short to medium long", +/- thin, "flexuous stalk", T-shaped, L-shaped, Y-shaped or h-shaped; |paraphyses apically (slightly to) medium to very strongly clavate-capitate, rarely spathulate, terminal cells (live) 5-23 x (2.5)3.3-5(6) um, lower cells (live) 8-19.5 x 1.3-2.3 um; "rarely branched at upper septum"; |medullary excipulum 30-80 um thick, "of dense textura intricata with many inflated cells, sharply delimited"; |ectal excipulum "pale to light orange", of (dead) thin-walled to slightly gelatinized, irregularly oriented textura angularis "from base to (sub) margin", 15-60 um thick near base, cells (live) 7-13(19) x (4)5-10.5 um, (dead) 5-10 x 4-5 um, 15-30 um thick near margin, of textura prismatica-angularis or textura porrecta oriented at a 10-40 degree angle to the surface, marginal cortical cells (dead) (4)8-10 x 2.3-4 um, "at upper margin sometimes protruding as very short hairs"; |anchoring hyphae "rather abundant", (live/dead) 2-3 um wide, walls 0.2(0.3) um thick, "partly covering flanks and extending beyond margin"; KOH-sensitive bodies "in paraphyses and ectal excipulum (near margin) globose", 1-2.7 um in diameter, rarely absent, sometimes a few crystalloid KOH-sensitive bodies present; |exudate "over paraphyses and marginal excipulum" 0.3-2 um thick, "granular-cloddy, firmly attached"; |anamorph unknown
NAME ORIGIN  "similar to O. delphinus but with wider ascospores", (Baral(3))
SIMILAR  Orbilia flexisoma, and Orbilia macrotrapeziformis [found as close as Arizona and New Mexico] differ in 8-spored asci and somewhat larger spores (Baral(3) with Latin italicized). For Orbilia delphinus and Orbilia maeandrina, see NOTES above.
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
240
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia maeandrina  Baral & G. Marson^  in Baral, Weber & Marson, Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 1075. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) a slightly concave to flat, sessile fruitbody that is orange to dirty brick-red, with a smooth or finely rough margin, 3) growth on dry, rotting twigs and branches in desert scrub and montane conifer forest, and 4) microscopic characters including 16-spored asci, almond-shaped to rhomboid spores containing a vermiform spore body, and KOH-sensitive bodies in the paraphyses and ectal excipulum.^ |Orbilia maeandrina is characterized by 16-spored asci, medium-sized, amygdaliform to rhomboid spores with +/- long, vermiform spore bodies, and globose KOH-sensitive bodies, (Baral(3)). |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^Collections used in Baral(3) are from ID, CO, UT (including holotype), AZ, Mongolia, Namibia, and Australia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody rehydrated (0.015)0.025-0.06(0.08)cm across, 0.013-0.023cm high, round, disc (slightly concave to) flat, margin distinct, thin, protruding 5-40 um, +/- smooth "or finely rough by covering hyphae"; "light to bright orange (to dirty brick-red)"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  "sessile, superficial or mostly distinctly erumpent from beneath outer host tissue or immersed in biofilm" 
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to often medium gregarious; mainly from western North America in semiarid Sonoran paloverde-mixed cacti desert scrubs, in pinyon-juniper woodlands, and in "humid ponderosa pine, Douglas fir, and Engelmann spruce forests of Middle and Southern Rocky Mountains"; collected (0)0.1-3 m above the ground, "partially to entirely decorticated", 0.4-3.0cm thick twigs and branches, medium to strongly grayed, "green algae absent or sparse"; altitude 615-2980 m (North America); fully tolerant to desiccation at least 15 months
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (live) (6)7-9.5(11) x (2.3)2.5-3.5(4) um, (dead) (6)7-9(10) x (2)2.2-3.3 um, "fusoid to fusiform, also fusoid-clavate, amygdaliform or tear-shaped, apex subacute to acute (to acuminate), rarely obtuse, base not or slightly to strongly attenuated, never with a distinct tail-like base", "straight to slightly inequilateral, sometimes slightly curved at base", spore bodies (live) (4)5-8(9) x 0.6-1.2 um in situ (~ 4.5-9.5 um actual length), "vermiform to subulate, base not or very slightly inflated, slightly to strongly flexuous, sometimes uncinate"^; |asci (live) 16-spored, (50)60-84(108) x (6)7-8.5(9.7) um, (dead) (50)55-75(88) x (5)5.5-7.5(8) um, spores (live) 2-4-seriate, (3)6-9(10) lower spores inverted "(not or slightly mixed)", pars sporifera (live) (29)35-45(50) um long, (dead) 40-60 um, apex (dead) "(slightly to) medium or strongly truncate (sometimes slightly or strongly indented, laterally strongly inflated or not)", base "with short to long, thick, flexuous stalk", T-shaped, L-shaped or h-shaped; |paraphyses "apically medium to (very) strongly clavate-capitate, sometimes moniliform", terminal cells (live) (4.5)8-21 x (2.5)3-5(6) um, (dead) (2.5)3-5 um wide, lower cells (live) 7-19 x (1)1.5-2(2.5) um, (dead) 0.8-2 um wide; "rarely or not infrequently branched at upper septum", "hymenium pale orange-rose"; |medullary excipulum "very pale orange", 20-50 um thick, "of loose to dense textura intricata, partly horizontally oriented, with many inflated cells, sharply delimited"; |ectal excipulum colorless, (dead, pale rose), of thin-walled, (dead) slightly to medium gelatinized (common walls 0.7-1.3 um), vertically or indistinctly oriented textura (globulosa-)angularis(-prismatica) from base to margin, 30-50(100) um thick near base, cells (live) 8-25(32) x 6-14(17) um, 25-30 um thick at flanks, 20-35 um near margin, irregularly oriented at a 70-90 degree or 10-40 degree angle to the surface, marginal cortical cells (live) 5-11 x (2)3-5(6) um, (dead) 6-10 x 2.5-4 um; |anchoring hyphae very sparse to abundant, live/dead 2-3.8 um wide, walls (live) 0.2-0.4 um thick, (dead) 0.2-0.7 um, forming an up to 50 um thick, dense, medium gelatinized textura intricata, "partly covering flanks and margin" as a 10-20 um thick layer; |KOH-sensitive bodies "in paraphyses and ectal excipulum (near margin) globose", (0.6)1-2.5(3) um in diameter (up to 3.7 um in excipulum); |exudate "over paraphyses and excipulum (margin and flanks)" 0.2-2 um thick, "granular-cloddy", colorless to "very pale yellowish", "loosely attached, often lacking"; |anamorph: trinacrium-like (presumed, from natural substrate) [Trinacrium is a genus in Orbiliaceae], conidiophores not observed, conidia Y-shaped, total size (dead) (20)25-30 x (12.5)32-33 um, stem (dead) 14-20 x 4.5-6 um, 2-septate, arms (dead) (5)16-17 x 4.5-5 um, 2-3-septate, arms and stem "more or less abruptly tapering"
NAME ORIGIN  "named after the flexuous, meandering spore bodies" (Baral(3))
SIMILAR  Orbilia delphinus differs from O. maeandrina in narrower, usually longer spores and appears to be sharply delimited although often growing in association. |Orbilia macrodelphinus differs from O. maeandrina in longer and/ or narrower, partly basally distinctly curved spores, but the distinction is not sharp. (Baral(3)). |See also the SIMILAR section of Orbilia trapeziformis.
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
241
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia ovalis  Baral & G. Marson^  in Baral, Weber & Marson, Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 498. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) a concave to flat fruitbody that is rose-pink to rose-orange or apricot, with a smooth margin, 3) sessile attachment to substrate or with and obconic stem, 4) growth on rotting, dry twigs and branches, and 5) microscopic characters including elliptic-oval spores containing a rod-shaped to ampulliform spore body attached to the wide end of the spore.^ |Orbilia ovalis is characterized by rather small, ellipsoid-ovoid ascospores, with rod-shaped to ampulliform spore bodies that are attached by a +/- wide point, (Baral(3)). |"The Canadian collection on Acer fits well the European specimens, including the holotype," (Baral(3) with Latin italicized). |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^A collection from BC was included in the Baral(3). The holotype is from Spain. Collections were also listed from Austria, France, and Turkey.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody rehydrated (0.02)0.03- 0.09(0.13)cm across, 0.01-0.021cm high, round to slightly undulating, disc slightly concave to flat, margin thin, protruding 0-10 um, very slightly inrolled, smooth; "light to bright rose-pink or rose-orange to apricot"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  broadly sessile, also with an obconical stem up to 150 x 350 um, +/- superficial, also erumpent through holes in periderm
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to subgregarious; collected 0.2-2.5 m above the ground, +/- corticated, 0.3-3.5cm thick twigs and branches, on medium to strongly decayed phloem (periderm rolled aside or removed, also on inner surface of detached bark), more rarely wood, slightly greyed, sometimes blackened, green algae sparsely present; from mixed conifer forests, the Canadian collection from a boreal humid forest with Populus tremuloides and Acer adjacent to conifer forests in a valley of the Canadian Rocky Mountains; altitude 340-1605 m; February-March, August-November (but long-lived)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (live) 3-3.7 or (3.7)4.3-6.5(7.5) x (2.2)2.4-2.8(3.3) um, (dead) 4-5.8 x 2-2.7 um, "subglobose to ellipsoid-obovoid to fusoid-clavate, apex rounded to obtuse, sometimes subacute, rarely with a short tail-like base, straight to inequilateral or basally slightly curved" spore bodies (live) (1)1.4-2.1(2.4) x (0.4)0.5-0.8(0.9) um, rod-shaped, ampulliform, or tear-shaped to narrowly pear-shaped, "lower part mostly distinctly swollen", apically narrowed to a +/- wide, more rarely to a small point, "predominantly straight, sometimes slightly to very strongly geniculate"^; |asci 8-spored, (live) (43)50-65(70) x (4.2)4.7-5.7 um, (dead) 38- 63 x (3.5)4-4.7(5) um, spores obliquely 1-2-seriate, (1)2-4(5) lower spores inverted "(sometimes mixed, very rarely upper spores inverted)", pars sporifera (live) (24)28-34 um long, apex (dead) "medium to strongly truncate (not or very slightly indented, laterally not or slightly inflated)", hemispheric in profile view, thin-walled, base "with short to long, thick or thin, flexuous stalk", T-shaped or h-shaped; |paraphyses "apically slightly to strongly clavate-capitate (rarely uninflated)", terminal cell (live) (10)13-28 x 2.5-5.8 um, lower cells (live) 6-16 x 1.6-2.7 um; "unbranched near apex", "hymenium very pale orange-rose"; |medullary excipulum pale rose, 25-60(120) um thick, of +/- loose or dense textura intricata "with many inflated cells" (also of textura globulosa), "usually sharply delimited"; |ectal excipulum "pale to light rose", of thin-walled, (dead) "slightly to medium gelatinized, (indistinctly) vertically oriented" textura globulosa-angularis(- prismatica) "from base to margin or mid flanks", 30-60(100) um thick near base, cells (live) 8-23(26) x 7-17(20) um, common walls (dead) 0.5-1(2) um; 20-30 um thick near margin, of textura globulosa to textura prismatica oriented at a 30-90 degree angle to the surface, marginal cortical cells (live) 6-18 x 3-6(8) um, (dead) 7-13 x 2.5-4.5 um, slightly thick-walled (dead 0.2-0.4 um), "sometimes with internal low-refractive wall thickening" (1-2 um); |anchoring hyphae "mostly very abundant", (live) 2-4 um wide, walls (live/dead) 0.2-0.7(1.2) um thick, forming a dense colorless textura intricata 20-60 um thick, at flanks a 10 um thick textura porrecta; KOH-sensitive bodies "in paraphyses and cortical cells globose (in the latter partially absent)", glassy processes absent; |exudate over paraphyses 0.1-0.3 um thick, "continuous to granular, firmly attached; over margin and mid flanks" 1-8 um thick, "continuous, granular-cloddy, or cap-like", +/- layered, "partially firmly attached, pale yellow"; |anamorph: dicranidion-like [Dicranidion is a genus in Orbiliaceae], conidiophores not observed, conidia tuning fork shaped, total size (live) 30-48 x 10-13.5(20) or 51-67 x 13-14(17.5) um (Juniperus), stem (live) 5-7(9) x (2.3)2.7- 3.5(4.2) um, "1-celled, arms usually parallel, apically often slightly converging, rarely diverging (nearly Y-shaped)", (live) 21.5-41 or 42-55 x 4.5-6.8 um, 5-10 or 9-13-septate (Juniperus)
NAME ORIGIN  "named after the frequently ovoid spore shape, also referring to the substrate of the type, Amelanchier ovalis", (Baral(3) with Latin name italicized) 
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
242
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia spathulata  Baral & G. Marson^  in Baral, Weber & Marson, Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 1112. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) slightly concave to flat, sessile fruitbody that is light orange-ochraceous, with a nearly smooth or finely rough, 3) growth on dry, rotting wood of Populus (one collection) and dry, rotting bark of Artemisia (two collections), and 4) microscopic characters including long fusoid spores that have a vermiform to subulate spore body sometimes inflated at the base, and paraphyses that contain crystalloid KOH-sensitive bodies.^ |Orbilia spathulata is characterized by rather long ascospores and spore bodies, and by spathulate to lageniform paraphysis apices which contain crystalloid KOH-sensitive bodies; spore orientation in the 8-spored asci is rather variable but shows, as a tendency, the upper spores inverted in all three collections examined, (Baral(3)). |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^The holotype is from UT. Orbilia spathulata was also found near Golden, BC. 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  rehydrated 0.02-0.045cm across, 0.013-0.017cm high, round, disc slightly concave to flat, margin distinct, protruding 10-20 um, nearly smooth or finely rough; "light (yellowish-)orange-ochraceous", +/- translucent
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  "sessile, partly distinctly erumpent between fibres"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to subgregarious in small groups; collected 0.3-0.5-?2 m above the ground, corticated or decorticated, dry, rotting, 1.2-2.0cm thick branches, partly in small clefts; in Utah on bark of Artemisia tridentata in sagebrush and saltbush area at 1700- 1795 m altitude; in British Columbia on wood of Populus tremuloides (Black Cottonwood) in a conifer forest with cottonwood and maple, at 830 m altitude
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (live) (10)11-15(17) x (2.1)2.3-2.6(2.8) um, (dead) 10-14.3 x 2.3-2.7(2.9), fusoid with +/- cylindric middle part, "apex subacute to acute, base not or slightly attenuated", "or fusiform with acute (to acuminate) apex, base medium to strongly attenuated", "mostly slightly to medium curved at base", spore bodies (live) (7)8-10.5(11.5) x 0.7-1(-1.3) um in situ (actual length ~ 8-12 um), "vermiform to subulate, mostly slightly to medium inflated at the base", straight to mostly +/- flexuous, rarely uncinate^; |asci 8-spored, (live) 60-79 x 6.2-7.5 um, (dead) 60-95(105) x 5.8-6.3 um, spores (live) 2-4-seriate, 3-5 spores inverted "(predominantly the upper spores, but sometimes strongly mixed and sometimes only the lower spores)", pars sporifera (live) (26)30-38 um long (dead 39-55 um), apex (dead) "medium to strongly truncate (not indented, somewhat conical or laterally slightly widened)", base with short to medium long, thin or thick, flexuous stalk, T-shaped to L-shaped; |paraphyses "apically spathulate to lageniform", terminal cells (live) (8)10-15(20) x (3.5)4-4.7(5.5) um, (dead) 2.8-4.8 um wide, lower cells (live) (6)9.5-17(20) x 1.3-2(2.5) um; unbranched at upper septum; |medullary excipulum pale orange, 40-60 um thick, of +/- loose "textura intricata with many inflated cells, sharply delimited"; |ectal excipulum light orange, of (dead) thin-walled, vertically oriented textura angularis(-prismatica) "from base to margin", 25 um thick near base, cells (live) 9-19 x 7-11 um, 15-20 um thick at flanks, 20-25 um near margin, marginal cortical cells (dead) 8-15 x 4-4.5 um; |anchoring hyphae medium abundant, (live) 2.2-4 um wide (dead 1.7-3 um), walls 0.2-0.4(0.6) um thick; |KOH-sensitive bodies "in paraphyses and ectal excipulum (near margin)" globose, 1.5-2.3 um in diameter, associated with rod- or ring-shaped KOH-sensitive 2-4.5 um in diameter, hyaline; |exudate "over paraphyses and uppermost excipular cells" forming 0.1-2 um thick, "firmly attached, finely rough, refractive (glassy) caps"; |anamorph: trinacrium-like (presumed, from natural substrate) [Trinacrium is a genus in Orbiliaceae], conidiophores not observed, conidia Y-shaped, total size (live) ~ 28-50 x 32-53 um, with (live) 13-32 x (6.5)7.5-8.3(9) um wide stems and arms
NAME ORIGIN  named after the spathulate paraphyses
SIMILAR  Some similar taxa (Orbilia flexisoma, Orbilia subtrapeziformis, Orbilia idahoensis) mainly differ in the absence of crystalloid KOH-sensitive bodies and in capitate paraphyses.
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
243
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia species^
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Orbilia species have tiny fruitbodies that are typically brightly colored or white, thin, waxy in consistency, and smooth, often appearing translucent/glassy. They have little or no stem and grow on wood, herbaceous stems, or old pyrenomycetes. Microscopically, they are characterized by relatively small spores, and paraphyses that are abruptly swollen at the tips. They usually have spore bodies in the spores, only found in the Class Orbiliomycetes. Orbilia species occur in the Pacific Northwest but are sparsely documented. Baral(3) is a landmark worldwide monograph published in 2020 that sets a new standard. It contains hundreds of species with only a few documented from the Pacific Northwest. Many more species likely occur here. Identification to species needs to be done by experts with access to the monograph and centers on microscopic characters.^ ||Baral(3) lists the following species from BC: |Orbilia brettii (holotype), |Orbilia xanthostigma, |Orbilia canadensis, |Orbilia flavida, |Orbilia flexisoma, |Orbilia ovalis, |Orbilia spathulata, |Orbilia subtrapeziformis, and |Orbilia vibrioides. |The University of British Columbia has collections from BC labeled Orbilia coccinella by R. Bandoni (1959) and J. Reeve (1960), but that species is now known to be limited to Norway. O. Ceska has deposited at UBC collections labeled Orbilia luteorubella, Orbilia leucostigma, Orbilia sarraziniana, Orbilia xanthostigma, Orbilia delicatula (synonym of Orbilia xanthostigma), and Orbilia inflatula (later combined as Hyalorbilia inflatula). Also at UBC are a collection labeled as Orbilia auricolor by S. Redhead (1971), and a collection labeled as Orbilia luteorubella by Kent Brothers (2010). The UBC collections would benefit from comparison with the Baral(3) monograph. ||Baral(3) lists the following species from WA: |Orbilia angiosubvinosa. |Orbilia flavida ||Baral(3) lists the following species from ID: |Orbilia idahoensis (including holotype), |Orbilia coniferarum, |Orbilia delphinus, |Orbilia macrodelphinus, and |Orbilia maeandrina. ||Orbilia eucalypti was described from CA, but other names have been misapplied to the orange (usually) to rose-lilaceous or even whitish species: Orbilia coccinella, Orbilia luteorubella, and Orbilia xanthostigma, (Baral(3)). O. eucalypti is a widespread species that has been collected often in Europe but only a few collections are listed from North America and none from the Pacific Northwest. Orbilia cruenta was described from PA but the type could not be located for Baral(3) who treat is as a nomen dubium. RANGE ^ Distribution of the species mentioned above includes BC, WA, ID, CA, AZ and PA, but the real distribution of Orbilia species in North America is much wider.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  "small and thin, smooth with even margin, appearing waxy to +/- translucent, typically with bright colours"^ (Hansen, L.), usually minute; "membranous, subgelatinous; brightly colored, white, yellow, or red, typically smooth, subcorneous when dry", and again fruitbodies "typically thin and membranous, the substance subcartilaginous and often translucent", (Seaver), "light-coloured, having a waxy consistency and often translucent when fresh", (Dennis)
FLESH  thin^ (Hansen, L.), typically thin (Seaver)
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  sessile or subsessile
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  saprophytic "on wood, herbaceous stems and old stromatic pyrenomycetes"^, (Hansen, L.), mostly on wood or bark, occasionally on woodier herbaceous stems (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores colorless, without septa or rarely with one septum, often containing a spore body^; asci 8-spored, cylindric to clavate, inamyloid; paraphyses "filiform, often with widened, sometimes encrusted tips", epithecium "as a hymenial gel embedding the asci present or absent", (Hansen, L.), spores bacilliform, or elliptic to nearly round, small and often difficult to diagnose; asci "cylindric to clavate, usually 8-spored"; paraphyses filiform, "the apices often clavate to globose", "A number of the species have paraphyses with subglobose or pyriform apices", (Seaver), spores usually small to very small, colorless, non-septate; paraphyses abruptly swollen at the tips, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Hyalorbilia inflatula (P. Karst.) Baral & G. Marson (of which Orbilia inflatula (P. Karst) P. Karst is a synonym) has been reported from the Pacific Northwest, including O. Ceska from BC (collection at University of British Columbia) - according to Hansen, L.(1), the pale orange fruiting bodies on wood or old fungi (especially pyrenomycetes) are 0.05-0.15 across, spores are 4.5-7 x 0.5-1 um, and paraphyses are indistinct and inseparable with epithecium a strongly developed hymenial gel.
SOURCES  Hansen, L.(1), Seaver(2), Dennis(1)
244
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia subtrapeziformis  Baral, E. Weber & G. Marson^  Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 1088. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) a slightly concave to slightly convex fruitbody with a smooth to rough or crenulate margin, the fruitbody color orange to orange-ochraceous, or rarely rose, 3) a sessile attachment, or sometimes a very short stem, 4) growth on more or less rotten wood and bark of dry twigs and branches of hardwood (rarely coniferous) trees and shrubs, and 5) microscopic characters including fusoid to fusiform-clavate spores containing a spore body that is subulate and somewhat flexuous with a sometimes swollen base, the spores sometimes with a tail-like base.^ |Orbilia subtrapeziformis is characterized by medium-sized, fusiform ascospores having acute apices and mostly strongly tapered, often +/- curved bases, and subulate, somewhat flexuous spore bodies being basally +/- distinctly inflated, (Baral(3)). The Latin prologue circumscribes Orbilia subtrapeziformis by saying it is like Orbilia trapeziformis but with shorter spores. |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^Orbilia subtrapeziformis from near Golden BC was used in the monograph of Baral(3). The monograph also lists O. subtrapeziformis from UT and countries in Europe and elsewhere. The holotype is from France.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody rehydrated (0.015)0.02-0.05(0.08)cm across, (0.0085-)0.01-0.015(-0.022)cm high, round, sometimes slightly elliptic, "(pale to) light (to bright) orange(-ochraceous), more rarely rose, non- or slightly to medium translucent"; disc young slightly concave, soon flat, finally slightly convex, margin indistinct or distinct, protruding 0-25 um, smooth to finely or sometimes strongly rough to crenulate; when dry light to bright orange
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  broadly sessile, rarely with a stem 0.003 x 0.007cm, superficial or slightly immersed
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "scattered to medium, sometimes densely gregarious", on +/- rotten wood and bark of dry twigs and branches of various hardwood (exceptionally coniferous) trees and shrubs, collected (0.1)0.3-2.5(4)m above the ground, "corticated to decorticated", 0.4-3.0cm thick twigs and branches, rarely ~ 8-25cm thick trunks, on 0.01-0.02cm deep slightly to strongly decayed wood and bark, scarcely to strongly grayed, "covered by a few to many green algae"; altitude 470-2600 m; probably fruiting throughout the year; in BC at 830 m on maple branch and in UT at 2600 m on willow branch
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (live) (7.7)9-14.5(16) x (1.8)2-2.7(3) um, (dead) 8.5-13.5(15.5) x 2-2.5 um, "(fusoid to) fusiform, also fusiform-clavate, apex acute, rarely obtuse to subacute or acuminate in some spores, base mostly strongly, rarely slightly to medium attenuated, with or without a tail-like base, slightly to medium curved especially near base, rarely straight", spore bodies (live) (4)5-7.5(8) x (0.5)0.6-1(1.2) um in situ (dead ~5-8 um actual length), "subulate (to vermiform), not or sometimes distinctly swollen at base", +/- flexuous, sometimes +/- uncinate, rarely straight, in aged spores 2.5-4.5 x 1.2-1.5 um, "globose with long filum", "germinating spores not observed"^; |asci 8-spored, (live) (45)53-75(90) or 85-100 x 5.7-7(7.7) um, (dead) (40)45-70(79) or 82-96(100) x 5-6.3 um, spores (live) 3-4-seriate, (1)3-5(6) lower spores inverted (rarely mixed), pars sporifera (live) 27-35 to 20 um long, apex (dead) "strongly truncate (very slightly to distinctly indented, laterally inflated or not)", base "with short to very long, thin or thick, flexuous stalk", T-shaped, L-shaped, Y-shaped or h-shaped, exceptionally H-shaped; |paraphyses "apically (slightly to) medium to very strongly (clavate-)capitate, rarely moniliform", terminal cells (live) (5)10-19(25) x (2.5)3.3-5(6) um, (dead) 3-4 um wide, lower cells (live) (5.7)9-14(17) x 1.2-2.3 um; "never branched at upper septum", hymenium nearly colorless; |medullary excipulum pale orange, 30-50 um thick, "of dense textura intricata with many inflated cells, indistinctly to medium sharply delimited" |ectal excipulum nearly colorless to pale orange, of thin-walled, (indistinctly) vertically or horizontally oriented textura prismatica-angularis(-globulosa) "from base to mid flanks", 20-40 um thick near base, cells (live) (5)7-16 x 5-11 um; 25 um thick at flanks, 15-25(30) um at margin, oriented at a 10-45 degree angle to the surface at mid flanks (textura globulosa-angularis) and 0-10 degree at margin (textura prismatica-porrecta), cortical cells (live) 6-7 x 4-5 um at submargin, (live) 7-12 x 3-4 um at upper margin; |anchoring hyphae +/- abundant, live/dead 2-3.3(4) um wide, walls 0.2-0.3(0.5) um thick, "with or without gel sheath", forming a loose textura intricata up to 40 um thick at base, "partly also covering flanks and margin as a thin layer"; |KOH-sensitive bodies "in paraphyses and ectal excipulum (near margin)" globose, (1)1.5-2.5(3) um in diameter; |exudate over paraphyses (0.2)0.5-1.5(2) um thick, colorless, "granular-cloddy or finely rough, soon firmly attached"; over margin and flanks 0.2-1.5 um thick; |anamorph unknown
NAME ORIGIN  in reference to the similar O. trapeziformis (Baral(3))
SIMILAR  Orbilia trapeziformis has shorter spores (Baral(3)). Orbilia idahoensis "resembles O. subtrapeziformis in the spores which have, however, a considerably higher length/ width ratio", (Baral(3) with Latin italicized). See also SIMILAR section of Orbilia delphinus and Orbilia spathulata.
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
245
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia 'trapeziformis'  Baral & G. Marson^  in Baral, Weber & Marson, Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 1055. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) a slightly concave to convex fruitbody with a smooth to rough or crenulate margin, the fruitbody color orange to orange-ochraceous, or orange-rose, 3) a sessile attachment, or sometimes an ill-defined stem, 4) growth on more or less rotten wood and bark of hardwood or coniferous trees and shrubs, and 5) microscopic characters including fusoid to fusiform-clavate spores containing a spore body that is subulate and somewhat flexuous with a somewhat swollen base, the spores sometimes with a tail-like base.^ |Orbilia trapeziformis "is characterized by fusoid(-trapezoid) to fusoid-clavate, rather short, often almost homopolar ascospores with obtuse to mostly subacute apices" and +/- attenuated bases, 8-spored asci, and the absence of crystalloid KOH-sensitive bodies, (Baral(3)). |The description is derived from Baral(3).RANGE ^Orbilia trapeziformis was listed from several European countries. A candidate collected by O. Ceska from BC was mentioned but "not included" in the analysis. "A sample from southwestern Canada on Arbutus studied by O. & A. Ceska (pers. comm.) matches O. trapeziformis in the spores and 8-spored asci, but no further data were taken from the single collected apothecium." (Baral(3)). The holotype is from France.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody rehydrated 0.02-0.04 or 0.03-0.08(0.11)cm across, 0.012-0.032cm high (receptacle 0.010.016cm), "round to broadly ellipsoid", "disc slightly concave to flat, finally medium convex, margin distinct or not", protruding 0-15 um; "(pale to) light to bright orange(- rose),  translucent or not", when dry "bright orange(-red)"; margin smooth to finely rough or (sub)crenulate
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  sessile or with an ill-defined hidden stem up to 0.02 x 0.035cm, slightly immersed or erumpent between fibres
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to +/- gregarious; collected (0)0.8-4(16) m above the ground, on dry, corticated to decorticated, 0.8-3.5(15)cm thick branches, rarely trunks, of a variety of hardwoods as well as juniper and pine, on 0.03-0.2cm deep, slightly to mostly strongly decayed wood and bark, "wood often white-rotten, (strongly) greyed, often eroded, with a few to many green algae"; altitude: 4-1385 m; throughout the year
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (live) (5)6.5-9.5(11) x (2)2.2-2.8(3.2) um, (dead) 6-9(9.5) x 1.8-2.7 um, "(ellipsoid-)fusoid (amygdaliform) to fusoid-clavate (to fusiform), apex obtuse to subacute, rarely acute, base medium to usually strongly attenuated (rarely slightly)", sometimes with a 1-2 um long tail-like base, "straight to slightly, rarely medium to strongly curved near base"; spore bodies (live) (2.5)4-6(9) x (0.3)0.5-0.7(0.9) um in situ [~ (4)5-7(8) um actual length], "subulate, slightly to medium inflated at base, slightly to medium flexuous, rarely uncinate; germinating spores non-septate". ^ |asci 8-spored, (live) (45)50-75(80) x (4.4)4.8-6(7.5) um, (dead) (40)4970(75) x (3.7)4.4-5.2(5.4) um, spores (live) obliquely (1)2-seriate, (1)35(7) lower spores inverted (not or sometimes mixed), pars sporifera (live) (20)23-36(39) to 18-29 um long; apex (dead) "(medium to) strongly truncate (slightly indented, laterally sometimes inflated)"; base with medium long, +/- thin, flexuous stalk, T-shaped, L-shaped, Y-shaped or h-shaped, exceptionally H-shaped; |paraphyses "apically (slightly to) medium to strongly capitate-clavate", terminal cells (live) (4.5)7.5-20(25) x (2.5)3-5(6) um, lower cells (live) 7-16 x 1.4-2.2(2.6) um; "usually very rarely but sometimes more often branched at upper septum"; |medullary excipulum colorless, 50-100 um thick, of +/- dense "textura intricata with many inflated cells, medium to quite sharply delimited from ectal excipulum at flanks" (towards mid flanks by a 10 um thick textura porrecta); |ectal excipulum colorless "or very pale to light rose-orange (especially near margin)", of (live) "thin-walled to slightly gelatinized", vertically oriented textura angularis-prismatica "from base to mid flanks or margin", 25-100 um thick near base, cells (live) (6)10- 22(32) x (5)8-16(20) um; 30-40 um thick at flanks, (12)20-30(50) um near margin, cells (live) 6-12 x 5-10 um, oriented at a 45-90 degree angle to the surface, uppermost margin also of textura porrecta oriented at 25-40 degrees, marginal cortical cells (live) 7-12(?20) x (1.5)3-4(4.5) um; |anchoring hyphae sparse to often abundant, live/dead 1.8-3(3.5) um wide, walls 0.2-0.3(0.4) um thick, "extending to the margin as scattered hyphae" or an up to 15-20 um thick, +/- gelatinized, colorless or yellowish layer; |KOH-sensitive bodies "in paraphyses and marginal cortical cells" globose, 0.8-2(3) um in diameter, more rarely absent; |exudate over paraphyses 0.3-2 um thick, rough to cloddy, +/- colorless to yellow-chlorinaceous, loosely or firmly attached, over margin and flanks 1-2 um thick, granular-cloddy; |anamorph: trinacrium-like (presumed, from natural substrate) [Trinacrium is a genus in Orbiliaceae], conidiophores not seen, conidia Y-shaped, total size (live/dead) 18-32 x 22-34 um, stem 10-15 x 45 um, 2-septate, arms tapering, (live/dead) 11-21 x 4-5.5 um, 2-4-septate 
NAME ORIGIN  "referring to the trapezoid (rhomboid) ascospore shape" (Baral(3))
SIMILAR  Orbilia subtrapeziformis is more montane and "differs in longer spores with more acute apices", (Baral(3)). |Orbilia maeandrina is similar in ascospore characters, but differs in 16-spored asci, (Baral(3)). |Orbilia macrotrapeziformis [found as close as Arizona and New Mexico] is similar in ascospore characters but spores are longer and/or wider spores, and asci are wider, (Baral(3)). |Delimitation from O. obtusispora and O. cylindrosoma, "which mainly differ in more elongate spores" (the latter also in vermiform spore bodies), is not very clear-cut, though a majority of collections could rather clearly be assigned, (Baral(3)). O. cylindrosoma is European. O. obtusispora is European but some similar collections from western North America outside the Pacific Northwest were excluded from the Baral(3) study. 
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
246
FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia vibrioides  Baral, Priou & G. Marson^  in Baral, Weber & Marson, Monogr. Orbiliomycetes: 747. 2020
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 1 mm, 2) concave to disc-shaped, sessile fruitbodies that are orange to rose red, 3) growth on dry, rotting twigs and branches, and 4) microscopic characters including strongly curved, cashew-shaped spores containing a tear-shaped to rounded spore body.^ |Orbilia vibrioides "is well characterized by its small, strongly curved (cashew-shaped) ascospores and thick apical domes." (Baral(3)). |The description is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^The holotype is from AZ. The Baral(3) monograph includes collections from BC and Europe.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody rehydrated 0.014-0.02cm up to 0.02-0.05(0.09)cm across, 0.007-0.018cm high (receptacle 0.007-0.013cm), round, slightly undulating when large, disc flat, margin +/- distinct, 0-5 um rising above disc, smooth; pale to bright orange to rose-red, translucent, when dry bright to deep (pink-)orange to brick-red
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  sessile, rarely with hidden stem 0.009 x 0.01cm, slightly immersed in algal layer
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "scattered to densely gregarious in small groups"; "so far only found on woody substrates: slightly to strongly decayed wood and bark" of dry twigs and branches of both coniferous and hardwood trees and shrubs; collected 0.1-3 m above the ground, corticated to decorticated, 0.25-4.5cm thick twigs and branches, partly on or close to long decorticated old wounds, on 0.01-0.1cm deep, slightly to strongly decayed wood and bark, greyed, covered by green algae; altitude 3-1320 m; throughout the year
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (live) (3.5)3.8-5(5.3) x (1.8)2-2.5(3.3) um, (dead) 3.5-5.5 x 1.8-2.7 um, cashew-shaped, apex rounded to obtuse, base partly slightly attenuated, (very) strongly curved by (90)120-180 degrees, sometimes very slightly helicoid; spore bodies apically attached to spore wall, (live) 1-2(2.2) x 0.7- 1.3 um, broadly tear-shaped to globose, apically narrowed to small point, mostly with a very short filum; with a few minute lipid bodies;^ |asci 8-spored, (live) 33-35 or 42-45 or 57-60 x (5.2)5.5-6(6.8) um, (dead) (20)26-57 x (4)4.5-5.5(6.7) um, orientation irregular, pars sporifera (live) 20-22 um, apex (dead) hemispheric to very slightly conic or truncate, dome (dead) 1.5-2.5(3.5) to 1-2.5 um thick (in KOH thicker than in water), with small apical chamber, IKI very pale reddish-grey (dextrinoid), base with short to long, thick to thin, flexuous stalk, L-shaped, Y-shaped or h-shaped; |paraphyses apically uninflated to slightly clavate-capitate, terminal cells (live) (6)8-12(15) x (1.7)2-3(3.3) um, (dead) 1.5-3 um wide, straight, sometimes +/- flexuous, lower cells (live) (4)5-12 x 1.8-3.2 um; never or sometimes branched at upper septum; |medullary excipulum (very) pale rose, ~10-50 um thick, of dense textura angularis(-intricata), medium sharply delimited; |ectal excipulum "very pale rose, sometimes pale orange near margin, of thin-walled, +/- vertically oriented textura angularis-globulosa from base to mid flanks or margin, 30-40(80) um thick near base, cells (live) 5-15(18) x 5-13(16) um; 15-25 um thick near margin, of textura prismatica-porrecta oriented at a 30-80 degree angle to the surface, outer part also at 10-30 degrees, marginal cortical cells cylindric-clavate, (dead) somewhat thick-walled, live/dead (5)6-12(16) x 2.5-3.5(5) um, glassy processes absent; |anchoring hyphae +/- abundant, (live) 1.8-3 um wide (up to 5 um near insertion), walls 0.2(0.3) um thick. KOH-sensitive bodies "in paraphyses and excipulum absent or often present, globose. |exudate very pale to light chlorinaceous-yellow or sulphur-yellow, over paraphyses (0.3)1-2(4) um thick, continuous to coarsely cloddy, +/- loosely attached, over margin rough-cloddy, (0)1-5(8) um thick. |anamorph unknown
NAME ORIGIN  named after the ascospores which resemble bacteria of the genus Vibrio, (Baral(3))
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Baral(3)*

FAMILY  Orbiliaceae, Order Orbiliales, Class Orbiliomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Orbilia xanthostigma  (Fr.) Fr.^  Summa veg. Scand., Sectio Post. (Stockholm): 357. 1849
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) size less than 0.5cm, 2) slightly convex to flat or convex fruitbody that is pale to bright yellow-orange or yellow to honey yellow, 3) gregarious growth on rotten wood or moist ground, and 4) microscopic characters including small cashew-shaped, semicircular spores containing a single round spore body at one end, and at high power, warts on the dorsal side.^ |The description of Orbilia xanthostigma is given in the world Orbiliomycetes monograph (Baral(3)) as a combined description of Orbilia xanthostigma and Orbilia leucostigma. At one time some authors had regarded them as colour forms of the same species. While genetic study has demonstrated that the two are close but separate species, they are separated morphologically by colour: Orbilia xanthostigma is some shade of yellow or yellow-orange when fresh and Orbilia leucostigma is colorless to watery white or pale rose-lilac when fresh (it has no yellow color pigment). The color tends to fade "with the decades" in the herbarium. The color range can extend to a color that Baral(3) call chlorinaceous. |Species of the xanthostigma-leucostigma complex "are readily recognized under the microscope (oil immersion) by small, cashew-shaped, semicircular" ascospores of about 2.53 um length (in situ), "with distinct warts on the rounded dorsal side" and a single globose spore body at one of the two ends. "However, this species complex varies in apothecial colour between whitish to pale chlorinaceous or pale rosaceous-lilaceous and pale to bright yellow(-orange)." |The combined description below is derived from Baral(3). RANGE ^Orbilia xanthostigma collected in BC by O. Ceska (UBC F26068) and this collection was listed in the Baral(3) monograph as documentation seen. Collections were listed of one or the other species from MA, MD, ME, NJ, NY, and PA. Both species are common in Europe, O. xanthostigma more so than O. leucostigma, and collections of O. xanthostigma were also listed by Baral(3) from Russia, Ukraine, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Japan, China, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, Chile, West Indies, and other oceanic islands.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbodies when fresh (0.02)0.035-0.2(0.45)cm across, 0.0140.035cm high (receptacle 0.011-0.02cm), round to +/- lobate when large, "then sometimes with translucent concentric rings", disc slightly concave to flat, finally sometimes convex, margin thin or +/- thick, protruding 0-10 um, not or often somewhat inrolled, smooth [probably referring to margin]; "mostly pale to bright golden yellow-orange, yellow-ochraceous, or honey-yellow(-amber") (> 150 collections), "more rarely (glassy) watery-white, pale chlorinaceous to yellowish-cream, or even pale isabelline to rosaceous-lilaceous-carneous" (> 50 collections), "centre often translucent (pale to light olivaceous)", when dry "light to deep golden- or honey-yellow (with dark grey-brown centre), rose-orange-red" or cream-ochraceous-isabelline, all colours fading in the herbarium
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  "sessile or with an obconical base", also with a short and broad stem of 0.0020.02 x 0.0150.08cm
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  often densely gregarious, "lying on moist or sometimes wet ground, also in 0.3-0.5 or rarely 1-2 m above the ground (especially when on water-soaked, deeply rotten wood) [sic]", on lower, lateral or upper side, decorticated, rarely corticated, (1-)3-35cm thick branches or often logs, trunks and stumps (often on cut area), also roots, fungi, rarely cones, of a wide variety of hardwood especially beech, oak, and birch, also on conifer wood; throughout the year; "Although O. xanthostigma predominantly forms its apothecia on the upper and lateral sides of the branches and logs and O. leucostigma preferably on the shadowed underside, colourless and bright yellow apothecia grew sometimes together on the exposed upper side", (Baral(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores live (2)2.43(3.3) x (1)1.11.4(1.6) um in situ (excluding warts) (~3.54.2 um actual length), dead (2)2.32.8(3)  (0.8)1-1.3(1.5) um, "(reniform to) cashew-shaped, curved by ~(90)120180 degrees (+/- semicircular), "ends rounded to obtuse, basal end rarely slightly more tapered", dorsal side (and also laterally) with a row of +/- distinct warts, very rarely +/- smooth; spore bodies live (0.4)0.50.7(0.9) um in diameter, "globose, rarely broadly tear-shaped, attachment invisible, rarely a short fine filum seen" (total length 0.8-1 um)^; |asci 8-spored, live (25)30-45(53) x 3.2-4.3 to 40-55  (3.8)4-4.8(5.3) um, 0-5 to 3-10 um projecting beyond asci, dead (24)27-41(45) or 45-52 x (2.5)2.7-3.7(4.3) um, "spores uniseriate, some of the 8 spores inverted (sometimes the basal ones, often oriented in various directions)", pars sporifera live 12-16(-19) to (8)9-12(15) um long; apex (dead) "strongly truncate (sometimes slightly to distinctly indented, laterally indistinctly inflated)", base "with short to long, thin, flexuous stalk, h- to often H-shaped, rarely T-shaped or L-shaped"; |paraphyses "apically slightly or mostly medium to very strongly capitate (rarely clavate or moniliform)", terminal cells live 1525(28) x (2)2.5-4.4(4.7) um, dead 14-23(25) x (1.3)2.2-4(4.5) um, below inflated apex live (1)1.2-1.5 um wide (dead 0.8-1.4 um), lower cells live 4.5-10 x 1.7-2.3(2.8) um, dead 4-10 x (1)1.5-2.1 um; "unbranched at upper septum; contents hyaline or in lower part and near apex light to bright yellow"; |medullary excipulum 35-80(150) um thick, "of a dense, somewhat horizontally oriented", colorless or pale yellow "textura globulosa-angularis-prismatica with some prismatic-hyphoid cells", sometimes with a lower part of loose textura intricata, "sharply delimited from ectal excipulum only towards margin" by a 10-20 um thick layer of textura porrecta; |ectal excipulum colorless to light yellow, of (when dead) thin-walled to slightly gelatinized, vertically oriented textura globulosa-angularis(- prismatica) "from base to margin", 40-120(150) um thick at base, cells live(/dead) (9)12-45(75) x (8)10-30(40) um, 15-60 um thick at lower flanks, 10-15 um at mid-flanks and margin, oriented at a (50)70-90 degree angle, marginal cortical cells (live) 6-11(15) x 4-7(9) um; glassy processes absent; |anchoring hyphae "sparse to abundant", live/dead 2-3.5 um wide, walls 0.2(0.3) um thick, sometimes forming a compact, colorless, small-celled, up to 50-60 um thick (rarely 100-200 um) textura intricata-porrecta or textura angularis at base; |KOH-sensitive cytoplasmic bodies in paraphyses "apparently sometimes present, globose", up to 1 um diameter, in ectal and medullary excipulum usually absent, sometimes sparsely present", globose (or ring-shaped), +/- refractive, 12 um or up to 6.5 um diameter; |refractive vascular bodies "in young paraphyses multiguttulate, medium refractive, later elongate or angular, low-refractive, hyaline or (in yellow apothecia) pale golden to yellow-chlorinaceous, also marginal cells often with pale yellow vacuolar sap; at later stages the pigment concentrates in bright golden yellow(-orange), refractive, groups of small droplets that tremble within the large vacuoles in cells of paraphyses, ectal excipulum, and inflated cells of medullary excipulum; |lipid bodies especially in lower cells of paraphyses and in upper part of medullary excipulum, near septa, small, refractive, in yellow apothecia pale to bright golden yellow(- orange) (carotenoids), staining pale to light (dirty) blue-green in IKI or Melzer's reagent; |exudate over paraphyses, margin and flanks absent or sometimes present as sparse, 0.10.6 um thick granules or clods, also +/- continuous; |anamorph dicranidion-like; conidiophores on natural substrate live/dead 840  1.72.8 um, straight, slightly attenuated above, 03-septate, unbranched or 12  branched, conidia terminally formed; conidiogenous cells live 10-20 x 2-2.5 um; conidia from substrate "predominantly Y-shaped, more rarely almost like a tuning fork, rarely 3-armed, exceptionally 4-armed (twice dichotomously branched), total size live (20)23-36(44) x (5.5)7-17 um, stalk live 7-12 x 2-3 um, (0)1(2)-septate, arms live (10)15-28(32) x 2.4-3.5 um, 2-5-septate; unbranched conidia on natural substrate sparse, live 19-46 x 2.5-3 um, straight, 2-5-septate. |"The yellow pigment occurs in the paraphyses, subhymenium, medullary and ectal excipulum."
NAME ORIGIN  referring to the golden fruitbody color, (Baral)
SIMILAR  Orbilia xanthoflexa from eastern North America, which genetically falls in the leucostigma-xanthostigma clade, and O. renispora from eastern North America, which appears to be related to it but also to O. tremulae (Eurasia), are excluded from the xanthostigma-leucostigma complex because of larger, often less curved ascospores which are consistently completely smooth. (Baral(3) with Latin names italicized). |Other taxa related to the xanthostigma-leucostigma complex but with completely smooth spores are Orbilia fabacearum from Europe, Orbilia subfabacearum from Australia, and Orbilia coccinella (in the sense of the lectotype known only from Norway). "Their spores are partly larger and more variable in shape, with a tendency of some spores to be less curved". Additionally, in O. fabacearum the spore bodies "are inserted at the dorsal side of the spores, and the paraphyses are apically only slightly inflated. O. subfabacearum differs in sometimes having glassy caps on the marginal excipular cells and in a distinct exudate over the paraphyses, also in a tendency of the spores to be curved" by over 180 degrees. "Also O. coccinella has small glassy processes at the margin but deviates from all mentioned species in 16-spored asci.".(Baral(3). with Latin italicized, who do not include any collections of these species from the Pacific Northwest). 
SOURCES  Baral(3)*
248
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Otidea alutacea  (Pers.) Massee  group^  Brit. fung.-fl. 4: 446. 1895
ENGLISH NAME(S)  brown clustered ear cup
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} Features include a lopsided cup-shaped fruitbody with a shorter side that is split lengthwise, an interior spore surface colored tan to grayish brown or yellowish brown, a similarly colored exterior that is often slightly scurfy, brittle yellowish flesh, a short stem-like base (usually present), growth on the ground in woods often along roadsides, and microscopic characters.^ |Kanouse describes a variety microspora with paler and more yellow color and smaller spores (9-10 x 5.5-6.5 um) from Washington and California: it was later raised to species status as Otidea microspora (but see SIMILAR section). |She lists var. typica from WA and CA also. |Olariaga(1) consider Otidea alutacea sensu lato to comprise a species complex. We are using the term Otidea alutacea group to represent this Otidea alutacea complex. Their molecular study resolved several clades. "It appears that the spore sizes within each clade have a fairly narrow range, but overlap exists between the clades. Patterns of continental speciation are suggested as well; two clades have North American specimens (clades 2, 4), and the rest contain samples from Europe and Asia" (Otidea alutacea sensu stricto and clades 1, 3a, and 3b). The two North American clades, with non-overlapping spore lengths, correspond to the two species distinguished by Peterson, E.T.(1) as O. alutacea (clade 2) and O. umbrina (clade 4). "Clades 2 and 4 have spores that overlap with European clades, and it is so far problematic to distinguish them using only morphology and disregarding the geographical origin." |E.T. Peterson(1) distinguished the two on the basis of the color of the hymenium in dried specimens: for the long-spored taxon "tawny olive", "sayal brown", or "raw umber", and for the short-spored taxon "pale horn color", "drab-gray", lighter than "chamois" or "tawny olive". Peterson further distinguished the two by saying that in the long-spored taxon the exterior lost color slowly on drying whereas in the short-spored taxon the exterior lost color quickly on drying.
