Peterson also says (italicizing the Latin names), "O. alutacea tends to be lighter in color and more brittle than O. umbrina and has slightly larger spores", but does not specify whether this refers to fresh or dried specimens. |The Otidea alutacea complex needs more research before names can be assigned to different species. |Olariaga(1) give a detailed description of Otidea alutacea sensu stricto in Europe. The descriptions of Breitenbach(1), Dennis(1), and Hansen, L.(1) would also be describing European members of the group. RANGE ^Collections in the different clades were examined by Olariaga(1) from WA (4 collections), OR (1 collection) (clade 2), OR (10 collections) (clade 4), Denmark, France, Italy, Norway, Spain, and Sweden (O. alutacea s. str.), Denmark and Sweden (clade 1), Norway and Sweden (clade 3a), and Denmark and Sweden (clade 3b). According to Larsen(1), Otidea alutacea is found in WA, ID, AB, and CA. There are collections from BC at the University of British Columbia by Paul Kroeger and Pam Janszen. 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  2-4cm wide, 2-6cm high, "usually cup-shaped but lop-sided (the shorter side split lengthwise or open) and semierect, but often irregularly wavy or contorted with growing in clusters", apex often truncate when growing erect; tan or light brown to grayish brown or brown; smooth^, (Arora), 3-6cm tall, slit on the side, often also elongated on one side, but not distinctly ear-shaped; dark loam-colored to dingy gray-brown, (Breitenbach), 2-4cm across, 3-5cm high, cup-shaped or somewhat elongated on one side, split down the other; clay color or grayish brown, (Dennis), 2-4cm broad, 1-3cm high, the vertical split edges often closely inrolled; yellowish brown or pale brownish, (Hansen), 2-4cm wide, 2-6cm high, truncate, "avellaneous" to "wood brown" (fresh), smooth, bald, drying wrinkled, (Kanouse)
FLESH  brittle (Arora), yellowish (Breitenbach)^, rather thick; yellowish, (Dennis), fragile (Kanouse)
UNDERSIDE  pale to dull brown (or yellowish in one variety), often slightly scurfy^, (Arora), dingy ocher (Breitenbach), fawn; finely scurfy, (Dennis), colored as interior; bald, (Hansen), "tawny olive", "pinkish buff" or "cinnamon buff" to "clay color", "wood brown", (dry)
STEM  "absent or present as a narrowed, whitish, downy base"^, (Arora), subsessile (Dennis), short (Hansen), subsessile or short stipitate (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora)
HABITAT  scattered to densely clustered in humus, usually under conifers^, (Arora), in hardwood forests on the ground, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), often in clusters; on ground in woods, August to September, (Dennis for UK), in hardwood forests on rich soil, often along roadsides, summer to fall, (Hansen for north Europe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-16 x 7-9 um (or smaller in one variety), elliptic, smooth, typically with 2 oil droplets^, (Arora), spores 12.5-17.5 x 6-8 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 2 droplets; asci 250-300 x 8-10 um; paraphyses slender, 3-4 um wide, "tips bent over, slightly thickened, septate and forked at the base", (Breitenbach), spores 12-15 x 6-7 um, with 2 oil drops; asci about 250 x 15 um; paraphyses slender, curved at tip and sometimes slightly lobed, (Dennis), spores 14-16 x 7-9 um, (Hansen), spores 14-16 x 7-9 um, narrowly elliptic, smooth, slightly colored yellowish, with 2 drops, 1-seriate or obliquely arranged in the asci; asci 150-200(250) x 8-10 um, inamyloid; paraphyses filiform, occasionally branched in lower part one or two times, septate, colorless, apices hooked, (Kanouse), spores for clade 2 are 15-18 x 7-8 um, for clade 4 are 12-14.5 x 6.5-8.5 um, for Otidea alutacea sensu stricto are (13.5)14.5-16.5(17.5) x 6.5-7.5(8) um, for clade 1 are 12-13.5 x 5.5-7 um, for clade 3a are 13.5-15 x 6.5-8 um, and for clade 3b are 15.5-17.5 x 7.5-8 um. 
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of soft leather' presumably referring to alutaceous color
SIMILAR  Otidea microspora has smaller spores that measure 9-10 x 5-6.5 um (Kanouse(4)). Harmaja(7) raised this to species status from a variety of O. alutacea with the words "By the virtue of its pale yellow more or less truncate apothecia and very short spores this taxon no doubt deserves to be recognized at the specific level.". However, according to Olariaga(1), considering the two collections that Kanouse designated as the type, A.H. Smith 9351 has far larger spores than stated in the protologue (13-15.5 x 7-8 um versus 9-10 x 5.5-6.5 um) - there are indications that it belongs to the O. alutacea complex. A.H. 17699 has spores that match the original description. Its shape is similar to that of O. rainierensis. A Gen-Bank ITS sequence of a paratype of O. microspora (A.H. Smith 30502) differs by only 1 base pair from the ITS sequence of the holotype of O. rainierensis. Olariaga(1) as a result treat the name Otidea microspora as doubtful for the time being. See also SIMILAR section of Otidea leporina.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Kanouse(4), Arora(1)*, Phillips(1)*, Larsen(1), Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1), Desjardin(6)*, Olariaga(1)*, Peterson, E.T.(1) (color names from Smithe(1975)), Harmaja(7)
249
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Otidea concinna  (Pers.) Sacc.^  Syll. 8: 96. 1889
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} We follow the Olariaga concept of the species which has not been documented to occur in North America. Features include a lemon yellow lop-sided cup that is slit laterally and somewhat inrolled, an inner spore-bearing surface sometimes with reddish tinges, an absent to short stem lighter than the rest of the fruitbody, and microscopic characters.^ | Otidea concinna (Pers.) Sacc. was listed in the online Species Fungorum, accessed May 7, 2015, as a synonym of Flavoscypha cantharella (Fr.) Harmaja, but Harmaja(3)(2009) considered Otidea concinna (Pers.) Sacc. to be a separate species from the original Peziza cantharella Fr. (a taiga species "with a European distribution essentially restricted to the northeastern part of the continent, with some occurrences on the mountains of Central Europe") and lists the two as separate species of Otidea. Also, Liu, C.Y.(1)(2006) presents molecular data indicating that Flavoscypha cantharella represents a genus inseparable from Otidea. At least one of their specimens of Flavoscypha cantharella had been identified as Otidea concinna, suggesting that they were using Harmaja's 1974 concept. To make things more complicated, Harmaja(3) considers the variability of Otidea concinna to have included two other species, Otidea integra (Bres.) Harmaja 1986 and Otidea subconcinna nom. prov., the latter a truncate rather than ear-shaped variation with subtle microscopic differences. Olariaga(1) describe an O. concinna clade that includes O. oregonensis, which they describe as a new species, and O. rainierensis. But in the absence of extant type material for Otidea concinna, they select a particular plate as lectotype, because it most closely resembles Persoon's description, "showing two or more large, convolute, caespitose, sessile, cup-shaped apothecia with a citrine (though light) outer surface." They assign only European collections to their concept. RANGE ^Otidea concinna has been reported in Washington, Idaho, and California, (Larsen), and Washington, Idaho, and Sweden, (Kanouse). One of the Washington specimens examined by Kanouse is however assigned to Otidea pseudoleporina by Olariaga(1) in their description of the latter as a new species, and the Idaho collection was originally assigned to O. leporina. There are collections designated as this species from Washington, Oregon, Idaho, and California at Oregon State University.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1.2-6.6cm wide, 1.7-7.1cm tall, "initially broadly ear-shaped, then soon expanding and becoming deeply cup-shaped, split, often broader above, very rarely entire when young"; pale yellowish ocher to pale grayish ocher, "sometimes with rose stains or spots", when dried light yellowish gray to very pale yellowish ocher^, (Olariaga(1)), to about 5cm tall, "usually slit laterally and somewhat inrolled, not distinctly ear-shaped", (Breitenbach(1), who refer to the fruitbody as bright lemon-yellow but the accompanying photograph shows the exterior dull yellow with hymenium slightly duller and browner - the shape in the photograph is truncate rather than ear-shaped), 2-4cm wide, 2-4cm high, split down on one side; lemon yellow with reddish tinge, (Hansen), 2-3cm high, 3-4cm wide, truncate, strongly folded into convolutions, "pinkish cinnamon" to "Sayal brown" (dry) with "a suggestion of yellow (said to be clear yellow when fresh), concolorous, whitish tomentose below", (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  slightly hygrophanous, bright citrine yellow, sometimes with a greenish hue, in drying slightly paler, fading to brownish ocher when old, when dried yellow; furfuraceous, sometimes warty in young fruitbodies, "sometimes shallowly wrinkled at the base", warts flat to broadly conic, "leaving a reticulum among them, concolorous"^, (Olariaga), bright lemon yellow (Breitenbach(1) whose photograph shows the underside as dull yellow), bright lemon yellow; bald or velvety, (Hansen)
STEM  0.7-0.8cm x 0.4-0.5cm, "not well developed, rooting"^, (Olariaga), lighter in color than rest of fruitbody (Breitenbach), arising from a stout stem-like base, (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  sometimes single but mainly growing in groups and crowded together, in hardwood forests^, under Fagus (beech), on mossy ground, summer to fall, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), often gregarious; in rich soil in hardwood forests, often with Quercus (oak), summer to fall, (Hansen for north Europe), with Quercus and Corylus (hazel) (Harmaja for Finland)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-12 x 5-6 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 2 droplets^; asci 8-spored, 150 x 10 um, inamyloid; paraphyses 3-4 um thick, bent at the tips and with yellow encrustations, (Breitenbach), spores 10-12 x 5.5-6.5 um, (Hansen), spores 10-12(13) x 5-6 um, elliptic, smooth, slightly colored yellowish, with 2 droplets; asci 8-spored, 125-175 x 8-10 um, cylindric, not turning blue in iodine; paraphyses filiform, sometimes forked in lower part, tips hooked or bent, (Kanouse), spores 10-12 x 5-6.5 um (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'skillfully joined, beautiful'
SIMILAR  Otidea onotica has an orange-reddish cast and is elongated on one side and distinctly ear-shaped (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Olariaga(1)*, Breitenbach(1)*, Trudell(4)*, Hansen, L.(1), Larsen(1), Kanouse(4), Harmaja(3), Liu, C.Y.(1)
250
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Otidea leporina  (Batsch) Fuckel^  Jahrb. Nassauischen Vereins Naturk. 23-24: 330, 1870 '1869-1870' - Fig. 4a, 10;  Otidea auricula  (Schaeff.) Sacc.;  Otidea myosotis  Harmaja;  Otidea crassa  W.Y. Zhuang;  Otidea fuckelii  M. Carbone & Van Vooren
ENGLISH NAME(S)  rabbit-ears
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} Otidea leporina is characterized by an ear-shaped fruitbody that is brown inside and out and wide spores. (Olariaga(1)).^ | This name has been used for yellow fruitbodies in North America, but although it can be yellowish brown, the predominant colors are shades of brown - it is probably the most common Otidea species in the coniferous forests of Europe. Harmaja(3) comments (with Latin italicized), "According to Franchi et al. (1999) Peziza leporina Batsch : Fr. should be typified with a fungus that is currently known as Helvella silvicola (Beck ex Sacc.) Harmaja. The former name would be the oldest one for this fungus, and consequently these authors made the new combination Helvella leporina (Batsch : Fr.) Franchi, L. Lami & M. Marchetti. If this is accepted, a valid specific epithet for the present Otidea species should be searched for (if in existence)." RANGE ^Collections were examined from WA, OR, CA, CO, QC, Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Norway, and Sweden, (Olariaga(1)). Distribution may be much wider in North America. Besides var. typicus described below for WA, OR, CO, MD, and NY, Kanouse also records var. minor, with spores 8-11 x 5-6 um and smaller asci, from WA, OR, CA, Michigan, and NY. Olariaga(1) synonymized var. minor (Rehm) Sacc. with Otidea leporina, but it is not clear how they regard the Kanouse collections designated as var. minor.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.4-2.5cm wide, 1.7-5.2cm tall, "narrowly to broadly ear-shaped, split"; yellowish brown, cinnamon brown, pale ocher brown to orange-brown, sometimes dark brown when young, seldom with pale pink stains, bruised margin orange brown, when dried cinnamon brown to rusty brown^, (Olariaga), 1-2.5cm high, ear-shaped to spoon-like; ochraceous to pale reddish brown, (Hansen), up to 5cm high, mostly rather narrow, like a hare's ear, but broader at times; medium brown when fresh (Harmaja for O. leporina sensu auct.)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  hygrophanous, ocher brown, in drying pale ocher brown, when dried yellowish brown; "furfuraceous to finely warty, seldom wrinkled at the base", warts conic to flattened, "gregarious, concolorous, sometimes darker than the background, golden brown"^, (Olariaga), colored as interior, bald, (Hansen)
STEM  with or without a stem, when present 0.4-1.5cm x 0.2-0.8cm; basal tomentum and mycelium abundant, white to cream white, "sometimes very pale brown when dried"^, (Olariaga), short, encrusted with debris (Hansen), basal mycelium white when fresh and when dry (Harmaja for O. leporina sensu auct.)
ODOR  
TASTE  slightly bitter^ (Olariaga)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or cespitose [tufted], for examined collections, under conifers, especially spruce; for examined collections, fruiting August to December^, (Olariaga), among mosses in coniferous forests, fall, (Hansen for north Europe), prefers the company of Picea (spruce), usually in needle litter, at times among mosses, (Harmaja)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (12)12.5-14(15) x 7-8.5 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, sometimes inequilateral, with two large droplets^; asci presumably 8-spored (from the illustrations), 170-215 x 9-10.5 um; paraphyses "curved to hooked, of the same width or slightly enlarged at apices", 2.5-4 um wide, "without notches or with 1-3 low notches, seldom forked at apices", when fresh containing small, refractive, light yellow droplets, and when dried small, refractive, colorless granules; outer surface with broadly conic warts, 50-85 um high, "formed by short, fasciculate, hyphoid hairs, of 2-4 subglobose to elongated cells"; resinous exudates "abundant, yellow brown, sometimes dissolving in part into amber drops" or converting into reddish particles in Melzer's reagent, "dissolving into yellowish reddish grey heterogeneous drops in KOH", (Olariaga), spores 13-15 x 7.5-9 um (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to the hare'
SIMILAR  Otidea pseudoleporina shares ear-shaped fruitbody and resinous exudates on the outer surface that partly convert to heterogeneous reddish droplets in KOH, but differs in the ocher-orange to pinkish orange interior and smaller spores, (Olariaga(1)). Otidea onotica more commonly has a pinkish cast on the inner surface, averages larger, and has narrower spores. Otidea smithii has a grayish brown outer surface (Lincoff). Otidea alutacea [group] has grayish brown inner surface and usually grows in dense clusters, (Lincoff). O. alutacea group has a truncated ear-shape.
SOURCES  Olariaga(1)*, Castellano(1)*, Kanouse(4), Lincoff(2)*, Larsen(1), McKnight(1)*, Miller(14)*, Arora(1), Wehmeyer(1), Harmaja(3)
251
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Otidea microspora  (Kanouse) Harmaja^  Karstenia 15: 32. 1976;  Otidea alutacea var. microspora  Kanouse  Mycologia 41: 668. 1949
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} Otidea microspora has a truncated ear-shape, similar to the commoner Otidea alutacea (but with smaller spores), and the inner color is pale clear yellow.^ | Harmaja(7) raised this to species status from a variety of O. alutacea with the words "By the virtue of its pale yellow more or less truncate apothecia and very short spores this taxon no doubt deserves to be recognized at the specific level.". However, according to Olariaga(1), considering the two collections that Kanouse designated as the type, A.H. Smith 9351 has far larger spores than stated in the protologue (13-15.5 x 7-8 um versus 9-10 x 5.5-6.5 um) - there are indications that it belongs to the O. alutacea complex. A.H. 17699 has spores that match the original description. Its shape is similar to that of O. rainierensis. A Gen-Bank ITS sequence of a paratype of O. microspora (A.H. Smith 30502) differs by only 1 base pair from the ITS sequence of the holotype of O. rainierensis. Olariaga(1) as a result treat the name Otidea microspora as doubtful for the time being. RANGE ^O. microspora is found in WA and CA, (Kanouse).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  5-8cm high, truncate; pale clear yellow when fresh, whitish in lower part, drying "pale buff" to "pinkish buff" [both Ridgeway(1) colors]^, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on ground; 3 collections cited - in August, October, and December^ (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-10 x 5.5-6.5 um^; asci 175-200 x 7-10 um, "frequently with long rooting base"; paraphyses "with narrowly clavate apices, straight or hooked"; hypothecium thick, up to 350 um; excipulum thin, (Kanouse), spores 9-10 x 5-6.5 um (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Otidea alutacea has larger spores.
SOURCES  Kanouse(4), Trudell(4), Harmaja(7), Olariaga(1)
252
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Otidea nannfeldtii  Harmaja^  Karstenia 15: 31. 1976;  Otidea angusta  Harmaja
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} Otidea nannfeldtii "is characterised by ochre to light brown, narrowly ear-shaped apothecia, small spores and resinous exudates on the ectal excipulum turning reddish brown in KOH", (Olariaga). The inner surface is orangish ocher to ocher or pale brown, sometimes with pink tones or entirely pinkish. The outer surface is brown orange to pale brown and has fine warts either the same color or darker than the surface.^ | The description is derived from Olariaga(1). RANGE ^Collections were examined from OR, Finland, France, Italy, and Sweden, (Olariaga(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-1.5cm across, 0.8-3.5cm tall, "initially long, narrowly ear-shaped, sometimes expanding and becoming broadly ear-shaped, split"; ocher, orangish ocher or pale brown, sometimes with pink tones or entirely pinkish, when dried orange-ocher to reddish brown
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  slightly hygrophanous, brown orange to pale brown, in drying ocher, when dried reddish brown; "finely warty, smooth at the base", warts conic, "gregarious, concolorous, sometimes distinctly darker than the background, brown"
STEM  0.4-0.8cm x 0.2-0.3cm or absent; basal tomentum and mycelium abundant, white to light yellow or ocher
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to cespitose [tufted]; in the examined collections under conifers; in the examined collections fruiting in September, October, and December
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (9)9.5-10.5(11.5) x 5.5-6.5(7) um, elliptic, sometimes slightly inequilateral, smooth, colorless, with two large droplets^; asci 8-spored (in illustration), 137-190 x 8-10 um; paraphyses "curved to hooked, of the same width or slightly broader at apices", 2.5-5 um wide, "without notches, rarely with up to two slightly swollen areas or forked at apices", when fresh containing small, refractive, light yellow droplets, when dried colorless to light yellow; warts 45-85 um high, conic to broadly conic, "formed by short, fasciculate, hyphoid hairs", of 2-3(4) subspherical to elongated cells, constricted at septa, 5-9 um wide, "sometimes with a gelatinous sheath"; resinous exudates abundant, yellow brown, dissolving into amber droplets in Melzer's reagent, reddish brown in KOH
NAME ORIGIN  presumably after Professor John Axel Frithiof Nannfeldt, University of Uppsala, who published numerous papers on discomycetes and other fungi
SIMILAR  Otidea tuomikoskii is similar. 1) Warts are higher (55-177 um) and denser on the exterior of O. tuomikoskii than on the exterior of O. nannfeldtii which has warts 45-85 um high. 2) O. tuomikoskii has orange ocher to ocher basal tomentum, whereas O. nannfeldtii lacks orange tones in the basal tomentum which is white to light yellow or ocher. 3) Pink stains do occur in O. tuomikoskii but rarely. (The hymenium of O. nannfeldtii sometimes has pink tones or is entirely pinkish.) 4) In O. tuomikoskii (unlike O. nannfeldtii) the excipulum (exterior layer) turns yellow with KOH under the microscope though sometimes weakly. In recent fresh collections the reaction can be seen macroscopically. 5) The paraphyses of O. tuomikoskii sometimes have up to 2 shallow notches, which has not been observed to occur in O. nannfeldtii (rarely they do have slightly swollen areas). 6) Resinous exudates on surface cells of the exterior of O. tuomikoskii are yellow orange to yellow brown and the color does not change in KOH. Resinous exudates on the surface cells of the exterior of O. nannfeldtii are yellow brown and turn reddish brown in KOH. (Olariaga(1)). Otidea pseudoleporina has an ocher-orange to pinkish orange interior, narrowly to broadly ear-shaped young fruitbodies, and resinous exudates on the exterior dissolve partially to entirely into reddish gray heterogeneous drops in KOH.
SOURCES  Olariaga(1)*
253
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Otidea onotica  (Pers.) Fuckel^  Jahrb. Nassauischen Vereins Naturk. 23-24: 330. 1870. - Fig. 26
ENGLISH NAME(S)  donkey-ears, donkey ears, hare's-ear
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} Otidea onotica is characterized by a comparatively large, spoon-shaped to ear-shaped fruitbody that is ochraceous yellow to yellow brown, usually with pink to rose tints, dots, or stains on the fresh inner spore-bearing surface, a short whitish base, growth in coniferous or hardwood forests, and microscopic characters including the spore dimensions.^ RANGE ^It is found in WA, OR, ID, CA, and CO, (Larsen), MI and NH, (Kanouse), WA, OR, MI, Czech Republic, Denmark, France, Italy, Norway, Spain, and Sweden, (Olariaga(1)). There are collections from BC at the University of British Columbia and at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  (2)4-6cm wide, (more when expanded), (3)5-10cm high, usually spoon-shaped or like an elongated ear (erect with one side open or split), margin inrolled at first; "ochraceous to dull orange to orange-buff or yellowish, often with a pinkish or rosy tint when fresh"; smooth^, (Arora), 1-4(6)cm wide, 6-10cm tall, spoon-shaped to ear-shaped, pale yellow with touches of pink-apricot to rose, (colors not obvious in dried specimens), margin even, (Castellano), 5-6cm wide (wider if expanded), 6-10cm high, elongate, typically spoon-shaped or ear-shaped, margin involute, divided to base on one side; "pinkish cinnamon," "ochraceous buff" to "apricot buff" with tints of rose that are strongly indicated even in dried specimens, (Kanouse), ochraceous tinged with pink, becoming deeper in color as it dries out (Lincoff), pale orange to orange, often with pink tinge (Hansen), up to 6cm wide and 10cm high, soon becoming irregular and ear-shaped; somewhat ochraceous but delicately flushed with pink, the pink tint becoming more pronounced when dried, (Dennis)
FLESH  thin, brittle; pallid^, (Arora), thin; white, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  colored as interior but without pinkish tinge; often slightly scurfy^, (Arora), exterior pale brown-orange to dull yellow (Castellano), externally "ochraceous orange", "cinnamon", "orange-buff" (dry), (Kanouse), at first almost the same color as interior, then clearly ochreous, (Lincoff), dark orange; velvety, (Hansen), ochraceous, sometimes flushed slightly with pink but drying ochraceous; finely scurfy, (Dennis)
STEM  "whitish, narrowed, hairy or downy base that arises from a litter-binding mycelium"^, (Arora), "substipitate to short stipitate", irregular, covered with white to cream hyphae, (Castellano), substipitate to stipitate, arising from a mass of debris held together with mycelium, base white tomentose, (Kanouse), short, pubescent, yellowish white, (Hansen), white at base (Dennis), with or without stem, when present 1.3-2.7cm x 0.4-1.4cm, basal tomentum and mycelium abundant, whitish to light yellow, (Olariaga)
ODOR  none in particular^ (Lincoff)
TASTE  none in particular^ (Lincoff)
EDIBILITY  edible according to some but one study revealed the presence of the toxin MMH, (Arora)
HABITAT  "scattered or more often in groups or clusters under both hardwoods and conifers"^, winter and spring in California, (Arora), associated with forests dominated by Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Castellano), gregarious, often cespitose, on the ground, usually in conifer forests, (Kanouse), in rich soil in hardwood forests (Hansen for north Europe), on ground in woods, especially Quercus (oak), (Dennis), prefers the company of hardwoods (Harmaja), summer and fall (Bacon)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-14 x 6-8 um, elliptic, smooth, with 2 oil droplets^; paraphyses strongly hooked, (Arora), spores (9)11-12(13) x (5.5)6(8.5) um, smooth, with 2 oil droplets; asci 8-spored, inamyloid; paraphyses slender, colorless, typically strongly curved at tip, (Castellano), spores 12-14 x 6-7(8) um, elliptic, smooth, colorless or colored faintly yellowish, with 2 droplets, obliquely 1-seriate; asci 160-200 x 9-11 um, inamyloid; paraphyses filiform, usually strongly hooked, frequently forked in lower part, (Kanouse), 11-14 x 6-7.5 um (Hansen), spores (10)12-13 x 5-6 um, rather broadly elliptic, with 2 oil drops; asci up to 250 x 10 um; paraphyses slender 3 um thick, curved at tip, (Dennis), spores (11)12-13.5(14) x (5.5)6-7 um, elliptic to broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, inequilateral, with two large droplets; asci 138-233 x 9.5-12 um; paraphyses "curved to hooked, of the same width or slightly broader at apices", 2.5-4.5 um wide, "without notches or rarely with a slightly swollen area on the underside", when fresh containing small, refractive, light yellow droplets, when dried colorless to pale yellow droplets; external surface with conic warts 85-105 um high, "formed by short, fasciculate hyphoid hairs, of 2-3 subglobose to elongated cells, constricted at septa", 11-14 um wide; resinous exudates on exterior abundant, yellow, dissolving into amber drops in Melzer's reagent; basal mycelium turning yellow in KOH, (Olariaga(1)) 
NAME ORIGIN  from Greek, meaning "of the donkey"^, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
SIMILAR  Otidea leporina is smaller and less brightly colored (Kanouse), and spores are wider. See also SIMILAR section of Otidea concinna and Otidea unicisa.
SOURCES  Castellano(1)*, Arora(1)*, Kanouse(4), Lincoff(1)*, Larsen(1), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Courtecuisse(1)*, Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1), Harmaja(3), Bacon(1)*, Buczacki(1)*, Olariaga(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
254
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Otidea oregonensis  K. Hansen & Olariaga^  Persoonia 35: 220. 2015
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} Otidea oregonensis produces typically obconic cup-shaped fruitbodies, usually split on one side and characterized by a citrine yellow external surface, often a wrinkled to veined, or shallowly ribbed fruitbody base, and relatively broad spores (Olariaga(1)). The upper (inner) surface is grayish white to pale ocher, sometimes with rose stains or spots.^ | The description is derived from Olariaga(1). RANGE ^Collections were examined from OR and WA, (Olariaga(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  2.3-8.0cm wide, 1.2-4.8cm tall, "shallowly to deeply cup-shaped, sometimes elongated on one side or obconical, split, seldom entire"; grayish white to pale ocher, "sometimes with rose stains or spots", "when dried pale ochre"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  slightly hygrophanous, bright citrine yellow, fading to brownish ocher when old, when dried brownish ocher; furfuraceous, sometimes some fruitbodies "wrinkled-veined at the base, seldom with short ribs reaching up 1/3 to the margin, partly covered by white tomentum from the base", warts "sometimes present toward the base, minute, flat, concolorous"
STEM  sometimes with a stem which is sometimes well developed, cylindric, 0.3-1.8cm x 0.3-1.1cm; basal tomentum and mycelium "abundant, white, when dried very pale yellow"
ODOR  mild
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to cespitose [tufted], under conifers (for examined collections where habitat mentioned), October to December for examined collections
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-11.5 x 5.5-6(6.5) um, narrowly elliptic to elliptic, smooth, colorless, sometimes inequilateral, with two large droplets, "rarely with a few small granules"^; asci 8-spored in illustrations, 171-203 x 9-10.5 um; paraphyses "bent to curved, sometimes straight, subclaviform to capitate at apices", 3-6(8) um wide, without notches, uppermost cell 28-70 um long, when dried containing small, weakly refractive, colorless granules; external surface with low warts, 35-70 um high, "formed by short, fasciculate hyphoid hairs, of 2-4 ovoid cells, constricted at septa", 5-9 um wide; resinous exudates on external surface "often abundant, yellow, dissolving into amber drops" in Melzer's reagent, brighter yellow in KOH
NAME ORIGIN  named after Oregon "where most of the specimens of this species have been collected"
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Otidea rainierensis.
SOURCES  Olariaga(1)*
255
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Otidea propinquata  (P. Karst.) Harmaja^  Karstenia 15: 32. 1976;  Otidea indivisa  Velen.;  Otidea abietina var. nigra  (Rick) Sacc.;  Otidea cochleata sensu Breitenbach & Kranzlin Fung. Switzerland 1: 84 (misapplied name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} Otidea propinquata is unlike other Otidea species in the Pacific Northwest in its stemmed cup fruitbody without a split in the side. The cup is ocher brown to dark reddish brown inside and a similar color outside, the stem appears whitish in the Olariaga(1) illustration, spores are large, and paraphyses are often forked or notched.^ | Some early authors used the name O. abietina, but that name is considered a nomen ambiguum by Olariaga(1). The name O. abietina was also used for the European species Otidea cantharella by Breitenbach(1). The description is derived from Olariaga(1). RANGE ^Collections were examined from WA, Czech Republic, Denmark, France, Italy, and Sweden (Olariaga(1)), but the WA collection was not included in the molecular study.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1.5-3.5cm across, 0.7-2.0cm high, obconic to broadly cup-shaped, "entire, very rarely split, regular or sometimes undulate in the margin"; ocher brown to dark reddish brown, when dried ocher brown
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  "concolorous", slightly hygrophanous, orange-brown, in drying yellowish brown, when dried orange-brown; "furfuraceous to warty, sometimes wrinkled at the base", warts hemispheric [also referred to as conic], "gregarious, concolorous, sometimes darker than the background, brown"
STEM  0.7-1.6cm x 0.2-0.7cm; basal tomentum and mycelium abundant, white to very pale brown, when dried very pale brown
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or cespitose [tufted], spruce forests on calcareous ground in Europe, the Washington collection under fir; August to October in the collections examined 
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (18)19-21 x 10-12.5 um, elliptic "and often narrowing toward the poles", sometimes slightly inequilateral, smooth, colorless, with 2 larger and several smaller droplets^; asci presumably 8-spored, 231-275 x 12-16 um; paraphyses "hooked, of the same width or often enlarged at apices", 3-5 um wide, "often with 1-3 notches or forked at apices", when fresh containing small, refractive, light yellow droplets, when dried colorless; external surface with conic to broadly conic warts 50-75 um high; external surface with abundant resinous exudates "that are yellow-brown to brown, turning brownish red in KOH" and dissolving in Melzer's reagent
NAME ORIGIN  related to 'propinquus' which is Latin for 'near'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Olariaga(1)*, Breitenbach(1) (showing an illustration of this species as Otidea cochleata, and misapplying the name O. abietina to the European Otidea cantharella, both according to Olariaga(1)), Kanouse(4) (as Otidea abietina)
256
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Otidea pseudoleporina  Olariaga & K. Hansen^  Persoonia 35: 188. 2015;  Otidea cantharella  var. minor  sensu Kanouse, Mycologia 41: 667. 1949 (misapplied name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} Otidea pseudoleporina is recognized by broadly ear-shaped fruitbodies, ocher-orange to pinkish orange interior and small spores (Olariaga(1)). The exterior is hygrophanous ocher-brown, furfuraceous to finely warty, and sometimes wrinkled at the base. Stem is present or absent.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from WA, OR, ID, and CA, (Olariaga(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.8-2.2(3.1)cm across, 1.0-3.0(5.0)cm tall, "initially narrowly to broadly ear-shaped, margin rounded, then expanding and sometimes becoming irregularly cup-shaped, split"; ocher-orange to pinkish orange, "sometimes with pink spots or stains", when dried orange-ocher to reddish brown
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  hygrophanous, ocher-brown, in drying yellowish ocher, and when dried yellowish ocher to brownish ocher; "furfuraceous to finely warty, sometimes wrinkled at the base", warts conic to rounded, "gregarious, concolorous, sometimes distinctly darker than the background, reddish brown"
STEM  0.4-1.1cm x 0.3-0.5cm when present, basal tomentum and mycelium abundant, white to pale yellow or ocher
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious under conifers (conifers at least mentioned when habitat specified for collections examined), fruiting from September to November in the collections examined, except for one collection each from March, May, August, and December
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (9.5)10-12(12.5) x 5.5-6.5 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, "sometimes slightly inequilateral", with 2 large droplets, sometimes with up to 4 smaller droplets^; asci presumably 8-spored, 155-231 x 9-10 um; paraphyses "curved to hooked, of the same width or slightly enlarged at apices", 2.5-4.5 um wide, "sometimes with 1-3 notches", apices seldom forked and rarely covered with a colorless coating, "when dried containing small, refractive, yellow granules"; warts 77-115 um high, broadly conic, "formed by short, fasciculate, hyphoid hairs, of 2-3 subglobose to elongated cells, constricted at septa", 6-12 um wide, "sometimes with a gelatinous sheath"; resinous exudates "abundant, yellow-brown", dissolving into amber droplets in Melzer's reagent, "partially to completely dissolving" into reddish gray heterogeneous droplets in KOH
NAME ORIGIN  means false (Otidea) leporina, referring to a close relationship with that species
SIMILAR  Otidea leporina shares an ear-shaped fruitbody and resinous exudates on the outer surface that partly convert to heterogeneous reddish droplets in KOH, but differs in the brown fruitbodies and larger, broadly elliptic spores, (Olariaga(1)). Otidea nannfeldtii has the same general shape and small spores but has narrowly ear-shaped young fruitbodies, most often lacking orange tones, and ectal excipular resinous exudates turn reddish brown in KOH, (Olariaga(1))
SOURCES  Olariaga(1)*
257
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Otidea rainierensis  Kanouse^  Mycologia 41: 674. 1949
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} Otidea rainierensis is characterized by its relatively large size for an Otidea and paraphyses that are slender but enlarge abruptly into an almost spherical head.^ | Olariaga(1) suggest that Otidea kauffmanii Kanouse is a synonym, based on molecular and morphological study of both types. Their ITS sequences of the two types differ by only 4 base pairs. That would be a clue to the fresh colors of Otidea rainierensis, since the fresh outside (underside) of O. kauffmanii was described by Kanouse(4) as "chamois" to "ochraceous", and the fresh hymenium as "cream buff". The fruitbodies of O. kauffmanii were also described as 'yellowish tan to yellowish buff, concolorous', the 'concolorous' apparently referring to the exterior being the same color as the interior. Olariaga(1) believe that O. rainierensis does have yellow tones, as they observed small yellow resinous exudates in the type. Smaller spore size was described by Kanouse for O. kauffmanii - 8-10(12) x 5-6(7) um. Olariaga(1) measured the spore size of the type of O. kauffmanii at 11.5-12.5 x 5.5-6.5 um, the length of which overlaps their measurements for the type of O. rainierensis. RANGE ^Otidea rainierensis was described from a dried collection from WA, and there have been other reports since (Nancy Weber, pers. comm.). If O. kauffmanii is a synonym, it is also found at least in Michigan.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  3-7cm high, nearly as wide as high, split to the base, edges enrolled; inside "avellaneous," "vinaceous buff" to "drab gray" (dried material), creamy white toward base^, (Kanouse)
FLESH  substance thin and fragile when dry^, (Kanouse)
UNDERSIDE  "ochraceous buff", "cinnamon buff" to "wood brown" (dry)^, (Kanouse)
STEM  up to 1cm long, tending to be hollow^, (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious on humus in woods, collections in August and September^, (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-12 x 6-7(8) um, elliptic, smooth, faintly yellowish, with 2 droplets, arranged obliquely in asci^; asci 140-160 x 10 um, cylindric, frequently with a long slender stem-like base, inamyloid; paraphyses very slender, filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, abruptly thickened at tips into broadly clavate, pyriform [pear-shaped], subglobose to globose [nearly spherical to spherical] heads 6-8(10) um wide; "hypothecium composed of hyaline hyphae loosely interwoven, merging gradually into a shallow excipular layer 50-100 um in thickness, exciple composed of large subglobose or elongated cells only faintly colored yellow, irregularly arranged, the outermost layer of which produces a few chains", (Kanouse), spores 11-12 x 6.5-7 um (Olariaga)
NAME ORIGIN  means "from Mt. Rainier", where the type was found
SIMILAR  Otidea oregonensis also has paraphyses with clavate to capitate ends, but the fruitbodies have a citrine yellow exterior. See also SIMILAR section of Otidea alutacea.
SOURCES  Kanouse(4) (colors individually in double parentheses probably from Ridgway(1)), Olariaga(1)
258
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Otidea smithii  Kanouse^  Pap. Mich. Acad. Sci. Arts & Letters 24: 28. 1939
ENGLISH NAME(S)  purple-brown rabbit's-ear
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} Features include spoon-shaped to ear-shaped fruitbodies that are brown to deep purple-brown inside both when fresh and when dry, and somewhat darker purple-brown outside, short off-white base, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Otidea smithii is found in BC, WA, ID, CA, (Larsen), and OR (Castellano). Collections were examined from BC, WA, OR, and CA, (Olariaga).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  3-9cm tall, typically taller than broad; brown to deep purple-brown when fresh, margin even^, (Castellano), up to 8cm high, elongate, ear-shaped, split on one side; "wood brown", drying "vinaceous-buff", (Kanouse), 1.3-4cm across, 3.2-7.0cm tall, "initially narrowly ear-shaped, short or elongated, finally expanding, at late stages becoming deeply cup-shaped, split", (Olariaga)
FLESH  fragile when dry^ (Kanouse)
UNDERSIDE  exterior somewhat darker purple-brown^, (Castellano), "Vandyke brown", "Rood's brown", shading to "vinaceous" toward the base, (Kanouse), "warty, sometimes wrinkled at the base", warts conic, obtuse or acute, "gregarious, dark brown, sometimes slightly darker than the background", (Olariaga)
STEM  "subsessile", covered with off-white hyphae^, (Castellano), "arising from large solid foot-like base of mycelium intermixed with soil", (Kanouse), normally with a short stem, 1.2-2.6cm x 0.5-1.2cm, basal tomentum and mycelium "abundant, whitish to brown", (Olariaga)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious on exposed soil, duff or moss under Populus trichocarpa (Black Cottonwood), Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), and Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), August through December^, (Castellano), on soil under conifers, (Kanouse), gregarious or cespitose; in collections examined fruiting September to December, (Olariaga)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (12)13.5(15.5) x (6)6.5(8) um, narrowly elliptic, smooth, with 2 droplets^; asci 8-spored, inamyloid; paraphyses colorless, curved or hooked at tips, (Castellano), spores 10-12(14) x 6-7 um, narrowly elliptic, smooth, colorless (or faintly yellowish), with 2 droplets; asci 8-spored, 100-160 x 12-14 um, inamyloid; paraphyses with large hooked or bent tips, hooks sometimes ornamented by small irregular protuberances, (Kanouse), spores 12-14(14.5) x 6-7.5 um, elliptic, sometimes fusoid, inequilateral, smooth, colorless, with two large droplets; asci 175-251 x 9-11 um; paraphyses "curved to hooked, of the same width to slightly enlarged at apices", 3-5 um wide, "sometimes with 1-3 notches or with a low notch near the apex", when dried containing refractive, pale yellow droplets; external surface with conic warts, 34-71(102) um high; resinous exudates "rather abundant on the outside, dark brown", partly dissolving and turning reddish in Melzer's reagent, (Olariaga)
NAME ORIGIN  presumably after A.H. Smith who collected this species in California
SIMILAR  Wynnella silvicola is somewhat similar but has larger spores with one large droplet. See also SIMILAR section of Otidea leporina.
SOURCES  Castellano(1)*, Kanouse(4), Larsen(1), Olariaga(1)*, Siegel(2)*
259
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Otidea tuomikoskii  Harmaja^  Karstenia 15: 30. 1976
ENGLISH NAME(S)  tall rabbit's-ear
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} Otidea tuomikoskii is characterized by the narrowly ear-shaped fruitbody, with high warts on the outside, small spores, and the outer layer almost always turning yellow in KOH, together with the ocher to orange-ocher basal tomentum in dried specimens, (Olariaga(1)). The color is yellowish brown on outer and inner surfaces. It is associated with conifers and fruits most often among needle litter or even on very decayed wood.^ | The description is derived from Olariaga(1). RANGE ^Collections were examined from WA, OR, CA, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Norway, Spain, and Sweden, (Olariaga). It has also been found in Asia (Cao et al. 1990).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^"The yellow KOH reaction of the excipulum, especially strong in the subhymenium and ectal excipulum, has been observed to be constant, although weak in some collections. The KOH reaction is stronger in recent collections, and can also be macroscopically observed in fresh apothecia." 
UPPER SURFACE  0.7-3.0cm across, 1.7-6.0cm tall, "long and narrowly ear-shaped, split"; pale whitish ocher to ocher yellow, rarely with pink stains; when dried light ocher yellow to ocher
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  hygrophanous, brownish ocher to yellow brown, in drying ocher yellow, when dried yellowish brown; "warty, rarely wrinkled at the base", warts conic, "gregarious, brown, distinctly darker than the background or rarely lighter"
STEM  0.3-0.6cm x 0.2-0.3cm when present, but may be absent; basal tomentum and mycelium abundant, light ocher to orange ocher
ODOR  faintly aromatic
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to cespitose [tufted], most often among needle litter or even on very decayed wood, in coniferous forests; the type was found on an anthill; in collections examined fruiting August to December
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (9.5)10-11(12) x 5.5-6.5(7) um, elliptic, slightly inequilateral, smooth, colorless, with two large droplets, "and sometimes with 1-4 smaller granules"^; asci 8-spored (in the illustrations), 113-199 x 9-11.5 um; paraphyses "curved to hooked, often broader at apices", 2.5-5(6) um wide, "sometimes with up to two shallow notches or forked at apices", when fresh with small to large, refractive, colorless to pale yellow droplets; surface with conical warts 55-177 um high, formed by fasciculate, short, hyphoid hairs, of 3-8 spherical to elongated cells, constricted at septa, 7-15 um wide, sometimes with a gelatinous sheath; resinous exudates abundant, yellow-orange to yellowish brown, dissolving into amber droplets in Melzer's reagent, unchanged in KOH
NAME ORIGIN  after R. Tuomikoski, the name associated with the type collection
SIMILAR  Otidea nannfeldtii is probably the closest species in appearance. 1) Warts are lower (45-85 um high) and less dense on the exterior of O. nannfeldtii than on the exterior of O. tuomikoskii which has warts 55-177 um high. 2) O. nannfeldtii lacks orange tones in basal tomentum which is white to light yellow or ocher whereas O. tuomikoskii has orange ocher to light ocher basal tomentum. 3) The hymenium sometimes has pink tones or is entirely pinkish in O. nannfeldtii. Pink stains do occur rarely in O. tuomikoskii. 4) In O. nannfeldtii the excipulum (exterior layer) does not turn yellow with KOH under the microscope. 5) The paraphyses of O. nannfeldtii do not have shallow notches (rarely they do have slightly swollen areas). 6) Resinous exudates on the surface cells of the exterior of O. nannfeldtii are yellow brown and turn reddish brown in KOH, whereas resinous exudates on surface cells of the exterior of O. tuomikoskii are yellow orange to yellow brown and the color does not change in KOH. (Olariaga(1))
SOURCES  Olariaga(1)*, Siegel(2)*
260
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Otidea unicisa  (Peck) Harmaja^  Karstenia 26(2): 44. 1986;  Sowerbyella unicisa  (Peck) J. Moravec
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} Otidea unicisa is distinguished from all other species of Otidea by its delicately ornamented spore wall, (Harmaja 1986), but the species has not been established for the Pacific Northwest.^ | This name is being used, following Harmaja(3), as the most likely correct name for records of Otidea grandis (Pers.) Rehm Bull. Soc. mycol. Fr. 9: 111 (1893) or its synonym Scodellina grandis (Pers.) Seaver. According to Harmaja(3), Moravec(1994) considered it a Sowerbyella species, on the basis of that the secondary spore wall was persistent rather than temporary, but Harmaja disagreed, finding the excipular anatomy and split apothecium to be typical of Otidea and noting that it lacks the distinct stipe and hairs on the exterior typical of the Sowerbyella genus. The online Species Fungorum, accessed July 1, 2012, listed the current name as Sowerbyella unicisa (Peck) J. Moravec, Czech Mycol. 47(4): 266 (1995) [1994]. Olariaga(1) say that the name O. grandis has been used for O. unicisa in Kanouse(1949) as well as for O. bufonia, and they regard the name as a nomen dubium and confusum. They also say that O. unicisa has not been recorded outside eastern North America. RANGE ^Otidea grandis has been reported from Washington and Idaho in Larsen(1) (though not verified by either author). Kanouse gives the distribution as NY, NS, MI, and Europe. Phillips lists it for northeastern North America and Seaver(1) for CT to PA and WI as well as Europe. Harmaja saw specimens from MA, NH, NY, PA, and VT. Olariaga(1) examined collections from MA, MI, NC, NH, and WV and say it has not been recorded outside eastern North America. The type is from NY.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-4cm wide, 1-2cm high, cup-shaped when young expanding irregularly with lobed and wavy edges; tan or dark apricot, (Phillips), 1-4cm broad, 1-2cm high, truncate, expanded, split to base, edges of split and top of fruitbody deeply enrolled when dry; pale, "vinaceous fawn", "ochraceous tawny", (dry), frequently with patches of red-orange, the orange red color conspicuous when the cups are revived in water, (Kanouse), reaching 5-6cm across and about half as deep, "shallow cup-shaped, the margin incurved, usually split on one side to near the base and with the split edge rolled inward"; interior hymenium pale yellow, lighter than the outside, (Seaver)
FLESH  fleshy-leathery, drying horny, (Kanouse)
UNDERSIDE  orange-brown or paler, (Phillips), "Van Dyke brown", "liver brown", [this may be the color when dry]; drying mealy, rough; some illustrations have olive green shades in exterior of cups, (Kanouse), external surface yellowish to dark brownish, with a tinge of olive; pruinose in upper part and "whitish tomentose toward the base", (Seaver)
STEM  up to 1cm x 0.5cm, yellowish, (Phillips), up to 1cm long, thick; yellowish, (Kanouse), sessile or substipitate (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Phillips)
HABITAT  single or in clusters on ground in mixed or coniferous woods^, (Phillips), on ground (Kanouse), single or cespitose [in tufts] on soil in coniferous or mixed woods, (Seaver), gregarious to cespitose [tufted], cited collections from eastern North America fruiting in July and August, (Olariaga)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-17 x 6-7 um, elliptic to subfusoid^; asci about 165 x 10 um, (Phillips), spores 14-17 x 6-7 um, long-elliptic to slightly fusoid, smooth outer wall but inner wall becoming minutely roughened when old, with 2 oil droplets, occasionally 2-seriate in upper half of ascus, otherwise 1-seriate; asci 8-spored, 185-200 x 10-12 um; inamyloid; paraphyses filiform, frequently forked in lower part, tips strongly hooked, sometimes clavate, 4-5 um wide, (Kanouse), spores about 15-18 x 8 um, elliptic with ends quite strongly narrowed, smooth or at maturity very minutely roughened, colorless, containing two oil droplets, 1-seriate in ascus, parallel or obliquely disposed; asci 8-spored, up to 280 um long and 12-13 um wide at widest point, cylindric in upper part, gradually tapering in lower part; paraphyses rather stout, reaching a diameter of 7-8 um, strongly curved or hooked at tips and "densely filled with minute granules", (Seaver), "The ornamentation [of the spore wall] is formed in the persistent cyanophilic probably continuous secondary wall and consists of irregular thin winding ridges and warts, which form patches of reticulum in places and are coarsest at the spore ends", where they reach a height of ca. 1 um; the spores measure 12.5-16 x 6.2-7.5 um and are essentially elliptic, (Harmaja(4)), the encrusted matter on the cell walls of the ectal excipulum is responsible for the reddish brown tinge of the external surface of the fruitbody, (Harmaja(3))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with one cut', presumably referring to the split fruitbody
SIMILAR  Macroscopically O. unicisa is fairly similar to Otidea onotica both when fresh and when dry but the fruitbodies of O. unicisa "are probably invariably truncate (not elongated) and their outside is generally slightly darker and more reddish brown when dry". (Harmaja(4)).
SOURCES  Phillips(1)* (as Otidea grandis), Kanouse(4) (as Otidea grandis), Larsen(1) (as Otidea grandis), Seaver(1) (as Scodellina grandis (Pers.) Seaver), Harmaja(3), Harmaja(4), Olariaga(1)
261
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Ovulinia perplexa  (W.H. Lawrence) Seaver^  The North American Cup Fungi.  p65. 1951;  Sclerotinia perplexa  W.H. Lawrence
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Ovulinia perplexa produces one or many flesh-colored fruitbodies from a sclerotium on vegetables, the sclerotium gray to dull black, white within, becoming pink or brown.^ RANGE ^Ovulinia perplexa was described from western WA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody reaching width of 0.2-0.8cm, flesh-colored; one or many from single sclerotium; "conidial stage on or accompanying the sclerotia, consisting of straight, or branched conidiophores often several mm. long"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  stem reaching length of 0.1-0.2cm; sclerotia "gray when young, becoming dull-black, snow-white within", becoming pink or brown when old, depressed-subglobose, reaching 0.1-0.3cm wide, forming thin black crusts of considerable extent
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  one to many from a single sclerotium, on Jerusalem artichoke, onions, cucumber, cabbage, and a large number of cultivated vegetables (at type locality)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10 x 3.5-5 um, subelliptic^; asci 8-spored, reaching 115-145 x 5-7 um, cylindric or subcylindric; paraphyses filiform (thread-like); conidia 8-15 x 6-10.5 um
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2)
262
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pachyella adnata  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Pfister^  Can. J. Bot. 51(11): 2001. 1973 (1974);  == Peziza adnata  Berk. & M.A. Curtis;  == Discina adnata  (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Sacc.;  = Psilopezia trachyspora  Ell. & Everh.;  = Peziza pseudoclypeata  Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include umber to sepia, flat fruiting body that sometimes becomes convoluted or shallowly cup-shaped, and microscopic characters including spores with warts over 1 um high.^ | The description is derived from Pfister(1). RANGE ^Pachyella adnata is found at least in WA, MT, and WY, (Larsen), and WA, MT, NY, OH, PA, Cuba, Puerto Rico, Trinidad, and Japan, (Pfister).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 5cm, flat, sometimes becoming convoluted, appressed, when old sometimes becoming shallow cup-shaped; umber to sepia, black when dried
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  presumably none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or scattered, on rotten, usually water-soaked wood
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores x 18-20 x 10-12(14) um (not including ornamentation), elliptic, ornamented with long blunt warts (exceeding 1 um long), warts sometimes anastomosing, relatively thin-walled, with 2 or sometimes 1 droplet^; asci 387-450 x 18-20 um, diffusely J+; paraphyses extending beyond asci, expanded at the tip to 6-9 um, the apical cells containing large dark granules, not reacting in Melzer's
NAME ORIGIN  means "broadly attached", referring to broad attachment of the fruiting body to the substrate
SIMILAR  Pachyella clypeata (Schweinitz) Le Gal "is macroscopically nearly identical" to P. adnata - its fruitbody is 0.5-4cm across, reddish brown, "later tinted olive then greenish-black and without luster" and it has smooth spores with 1-2 oil droplets that measure 25-35 x 12-14 um (Beug). It is included in Coulter(2) but presence in the Pacific Northwest needs to be established with herbarium specimens. See also description of Adelphella babingtonii which only reaches 2cm across and is usually not more than 1cm across, and has spores that are smooth or with small puncta.
SOURCES  Pfister(1), Larsen(1), Coulter(2) (regarding Pachyella clypeata)
263
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Paragalactinia michelii  (Boud.) Van Vooren^  Ascomycete.org 12(4): 189. 2020;  Peziza michelii  (Boud.) Dennis  British Cup Fungi 15. 1960;  Galactinia michelii  Boud.;  Peziza plebeia  (Le Gal) Nannf.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a fruitbody that is cup-shaped (or more flat with turned-up margin), 2) reddish brown upper surface that may have a lilac tint, 3) exterior that is lighter colored to yellowish brown, and minutely scurfy, 4) absent or short stem, 5) growth on bare ground, and 6) microscopic characters including spores with sparse warts.^ | A violet form of this species occurs in France (Dennis). RANGE ^Paragalactinia michelii is found at least in OR (Larsen), Switzerland (Breitenbach), United Kingdom (Dennis), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen). There is a collection at Oregon State University from OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  2.5-5cm across, cup-shaped to saucer-shaped, with margin distinctly curved upward; spore-bearing upper surface light reddish-brown with faint lilac tint, smooth^, (Breitenbach), up to 5cm across, "cup-shaped, then somewhat expanded with a slightly raised even margin"; spore-bearing upper surface reddish brown, (Dennis), 1-4cm across, disc-shaped to deeply cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface at first violet, then brownish, (Hansen), lilac brown at first then reddish ocher brown (Courtecuisse)
FLESH  fragile, exuding a watery juice when injured, the flesh at the injured spot becoming yellowish after a while^, (Breitenbach), thin; yellowish, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  lighter in color than upper surface; finely furfuraceous^, (Breitenbach), fawn; minutely scurfy toward margin, (Dennis), yellowish brown; bald, (Hansen), lighter in color than upper surface; slightly scurfy, (Courtecuisse)
STEM  without a stem or with a short stem^ (Breitenbach), without stem (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or gregarious on "bare ground on edges of paths and streets, within and outside of forests", July to September^, (Breitenbach), on bare soil in woods (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-17.5 x 8 um, elliptic, with sparsely distributed warts, colorless, usually with two droplets^; asci 8-spored, 235-280 x 11-12 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses cylindric, tips with slight clavate widenings, septate, (Breitenbach), spores 13-17 x 7-9 um, elliptic, with well-defined low warts, with 2 oil droplets; asci up to 280 x 15 um; paraphyses "slightly clavate, straight, with yellowish contents", (Dennis), spores 16-18 x 7.5-8.5 um, elliptic, with irregular warts, with 2 droplets, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Paragalactinia succosa.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Peziza), Dennis(1) (as Peziza), Hansen, L.(1) (as Peziza), Larsen(1) (as Peziza), Courtecuisse(1)* (as Peziza), Buczacki(1)* (as Peziza), Van Vooren(2)
264
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Paragalactinia succosa  (Berk.) Van Vooren ^ Ascomycete.org 12(4): 189. 2020;  Peziza succosa  Berk.  Ann. Mag. Nat. Hist. I. 6: 358. 1841;  Aleuria succosa  Gillet;  Otidea succosa  Thum.;  Galactinia succosa  Sacc.;  Plicaria succosa  Rehm;
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a cup-shaped fruitbody with a gray-brown upper surface, often with an olive tint, 2) finely scurfy exterior lighter in color and sometimes yellowish, 3) whitish flesh that exudes a juice quickly turning yellow, 4) absent stem, 5) growth on soil, and 6) microscopic characters including spores that are coarsely warty to short-ribbed.^ RANGE ^Paragalactinia succosa is found at least in BC, WA, OR, and CA, (Larsen), northeastern North America, west to WI, (Phillips), NY to IA and WI (Seaver), Switzerland (Breitenbach), and the United Kingdom (Dennis).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1.5-6(10)cm, irregularly cup-shaped to saucer-shaped, then expanding; spore-bearing upper surface hazelnut brown to light brown, "smooth and dull, contracted and wrinkled toward the center"^, (Breitenbach), 2-5cm across, permanently cup-shaped, disc gray-bister with slight olivaceous tint, (Dennis), reaching 3-4cm across, at first hemispheric, expanding to shallowly cup-shaped or more rarely somewhat disc-shaped, "regular in outline or irregularly contorted, the margin even or occasionally more or less lobed"; upper surface concave or occasionally nearly flat, even brown, becoming darker when old, "often with an olivaceous tint apparently from the spores which have dusted out over its surface", (Seaver), upper surface gray-brown with a slight olivaceous tint (Phillips)
FLESH  "firm, when injured immediately exuding a juice which quickly turns yellow", (test by dabbing broken piece with white paper or handkerchief)^, (Breitenbach), thin; whitish; yielding copious bright yellow juice, (Dennis), thin; whitish, yielding yellow juice that makes yellow stains on the edges of the cup and flesh, (Phillips)
UNDERSIDE  lighter in color than upper surface, sometimes rather yellowish toward margin; finely brownish-furfuraceous^, (Breitenbach), gray, sometimes yellowish at margin, (Dennis), "whitish or yellowish with a slight shade of olive", (Seaver), whitish, grayish, or yellowish, (Phillips)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach, Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  no (Phillips)
HABITAT  single or gregarious in coniferous and hardwood forests on stony, loamy soil and embankments, June to October^, (Breitenbach), on the ground in woods, July to September, (Dennis), gregarious or scattered, on damp soil in woods (Seaver), June to August (Phillips)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17-21 x 9.5-11.5 um, elliptic, coarsely warty to short-ribbed, colorless, with two droplets^; asci 8-spored, 330 x 15 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses cylindric, septate, tips with slightly clavate widenings to 9 um, sometimes forked, (Breitenbach), spores 17-22 x 9-12 um, with coarse warts and short ridges, with 2 large oil droplets; asci about 350 x 18 um; paraphyses straight, colorless, slightly clavate, (Dennis), spores 16-20 x 8-12 um, elliptic, finally becoming sculptured with rather conspicuous warts 1-2 um wide, colorless or very faintly yellowish (olivaceous in mass), usually containing 2 distinct oil droplets, obliquely uniseriate; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 200-225 um and a width of 12-15 um, cylindric or subcylindric; paraphyses slender, septate, widened in upper part, "filled with yellowish coloring matter", (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'juicy'
SIMILAR  Paragalactinia michelii has yellow flesh and watery juice that does not change color (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Peziza), Dennis(1) (as Peziza), Seaver(1) (as Peziza), Phillips(1)* (as Peziza), Larsen(1) (as Peziza), Van Vooren(2)
265
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Paratrichophaea boudieri  (Grelet) Bronckers^  Sterbeeckia 23: 20. 2003;  Trichophaea boudieri  Grelet  Bull. Soc. Myc. Fr. 33: 94-96. 1917
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features are small, whitish, cup-shaped fruitbodies, thickly covered on the margin and exterior with long brown hairs, absent stem, growth on soil, and microscopic characters.^ | The online Species Fungorum, accessed February 4, 2017, listed Trichophaea boudieri Grelet as a synonym of Paratrichophaea (Grelet) Bronckers, but MycoBank, accessed the same day, gives Trichophaea boudieri as the current name. RANGE ^Paratrichophaea boudieri is found in ID (Larsen as Trichophea boudieri), but its occurrence was not confirmed by either author. Material was used from CA (Perry(2)). Material was examined from WY and MI by Kanouse.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.4cm wide, flat at maturity; whitish, margin fringed with hairs^, (Kanouse), 0.3-0.8cm, "at first hemispherical-bladderlike, then cup-shaped and becoming flat, the ciliated margin always remaining turned upward and sometimes rather sinuous"; gray-white, sometimes rather ocher; smooth; margin thickly covered with long brown hairs, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  covered with hairs^, (Kanouse), thickly covered with long brown hairs, (Breitenbach), 
STEM  none, mycelium frequently present at the base^, (Kanouse), none (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on soil (Kanouse), single to gregarious "on moss-covered ground in floodplain forest", summer, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18.5-19 x 10-12 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, without drops, often with granular contents when young^; asci 8-spored, 220 x 12 um, inamyloid; paraphyses "slender, septate, tips with slight clavate thickenings"; hairs up to 550 x 12 um, "smooth, brown, thick-walled, singly to multiply septate", tip blunt or pointed, base sometimes narrowed (but illustrated widened), (Breitenbach), spores smooth, filled with protoplasmic contents that usually obscure the droplets; asci 8-spored, 200-260 x 16-18 um, inamyloid; paraphyses numerous, exceeding the asci by 35 um, filiform [thread-like], colorless, branched near the base, tip narrowly clavate; marginal hairs up to 900 um, light brown, sparingly septate, tip pointed, base attenuated, "hairs below the margin shorter, basal cell sometimes enlarged, thick-walled, sharply pointed, dark brown, many-septate", other hairs on the lower part of the fruitbody long-flexuous non-septate (or sparingly septate), with blunt tips, less frequent than the other types of hairs, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  probably after Jean Louis Emile Boudier, 1828-1920, a French pharmacist who wrote "Histoire et classification des discomycetes d'Europe"
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Chaetothiersia vernalis.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Trichophaea), Kanouse(5) (as Trichophaea), Larsen(1) (as Trichophaea), Perry(2)
266
FAMILY  Inocybaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pellidiscus pallidus  (Berk. & Broome) Donk^  Persoonia 1: 90. 1959;  == Cyphella pallida  Berk. & Broome;  Cyphella sessilis  Burt;  Pellidiscus subiculosus  W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute, white to pale yellowish brown basidiomycete fruitbody that is cup-shaped to disc-shaped with an upturned margin, white underside that is minutely tomentose, and absent stem. It grows scattered to crowded on rotten bark and wood, dead herbaceous stems, and rotten leaves. Microscopic characters include basidia. Pellidiscus pallidus is recognizable because of flattened, broadly but loosely attached fruitbodies, with only the margin upturned and incurved (when dry), sometimes crisped-lobed along margin, (Donk 1959). RANGE ^It is found in BC, ON, MI, and NJ, (Ginns), and Czechoslovakia, France, Netherlands, Norway, and the United Kingdom, (Redhead).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  usually about 0.1-0.2cm across, sometimes larger, at first cup-shaped, soon disc-shaped with upturned margin, circular, often becoming crenulate [scalloped] to lobed and crisped at margin; upper surface from snow white soon becoming pale yellowish brown, of somewhat waxy appearance, even, smooth to wrinkled^, (Donk), 0.01-0.03cm [may be intended as 0.1-0.3 as more consistent with illustration], centrally or slightly eccentrically attached to substrate, "flattened bowl-shaped"; "inner spore-bearing surface smooth, white then very pale yellow-brown", (Buczacki)
FLESH  evenly thin throughout except at the slightly thicker margin^ (Donk)
UNDERSIDE  white, minutely tomentose^, (Donk), white-cream; finely felted, (Buczacki)
STEM  none^ (Buczacki)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "scattered or somewhat crowded, rarely a few imperfectly confluent", on rotten bark and wood, old woody stems and fallen branches, dead herbaceous stems, and also on rotten leaves of hardwoods, apparently year round^, (Donk), Alnus (alder), Cytisus scoparius (broom), Populus, Pteridium aquilinum (bracken fern), Vicia gigantea (giant vetch), (Ginns), on leaf litter of hardwood trees and shrubs, occasionally on conifer needle litter, "also recorded on stems of broom, gorse, clematis, and stinging nettle", usually in small, scattered groups; fall, winter, spring, (Buczacki)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6.5-9 x 3.5-5.5 um, elliptic, rather elongate, often slightly almond-shaped, minutely but distinctly roughened by punctations, inamyloid, faintly yellowish^; basidia (2-)4-spored, 12-19 x 4.5-6 um, "short-clavate, plump"; marginal hairs "(close to marginal basidia) in clumps, with swollen bases and long drawn-out thinner portions which may be branched", tips obtuse [blunt]; hyphae 2.5-4 um wide, colorless, "not encrusted, thin-walled, rather loosely interwoven towards outside", without clamp connections, (Donk), spore size from Cooke difficult to determine by Cooke's description because in body of description he gives 8.5-9.5 x 3.5-4 um, but in the key just above it 6.5-7 x 3-5 um; in any case they are teardrop-shaped to cylindric flattened on one side, apiculate, at first colorless, becoming light yellow-brown; hymenium formed of clavate basidia 15-20 x 4-7 um, produced in easily separated fascicles (bundles), 4-spored, subhymenial hyphae up to 3 um wide, clamped in some specimens; receptacle surface covered with smooth, thin-walled, colorless, simple-septate, subiculum-like hyphae 3-6 um wide, forming a loose hyphal network; context of loosely arranged colorless hyphae, subhypochnoid, 3-4 um wide, simple septate, (Cooke), spores (5)6-8(9) x (3.2)3.5-4.5(5) um, varying from elliptic to almond-shaped, at first smooth and colorless, becoming pale brown and finally brown and roughened; basidia 2-4-spored, 13-20 x 6-8 um, "more or less clavate, but particularly short and squat"; hairs up to 117 um long and 2-4 um wide, tapering gradually to obtuse apex 1.5-2.2 um wide, thin-walled, colorless, and without encrustation, "Whether one considers the hairs to be branched or whether one considers the branching to be part of the vegetative hyphae from which the hairs are formed, is a matter of personal opinion"; cystidia absent, (Reid), spores 6.5-9 x 3.5-5.5 um, almond-shaped, finely warty-pitted, pale yellow-brown, (Buczacki)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pale'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Donk(1), Reid(4), Cooke(2), Ginns(5), Redhead(21), Buczacki(1)*
267
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Perrotia flammea  (Alb. & Schwein.) Boud.^  Bull. Soc. mycol. Fr. 17: 24. 1901
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny stemless cups on wood that have a reddish brown hymenial surface and are clothed outside with bright orange to deep red hairs. Under the microscope the hairs have walls encrusted with orange to reddish granules that turn violaceous in KOH. Spores are cylindric to allantoid.^ RANGE ^Perrotia flammea is found from PA to MT and CO as well as in Europe (Seaver(1)): it needs further confirmation from the Pacific Northwest, but both Seaver(2) and Dennis(3) considered that the description of the type of Lasiobelonium subflavidum Ellis and Everh. from WA was consistent with Perrotia flammea - Dennis noted that the description on the packet of the type said that the ascospores became 1-3 septate, which was consistent with P. flammea. Collections from northwestern BC are at the Pacific Forestry Centre in Victoria. Haines(1) reported it in his Masters of Science thesis for WA. Zeller(19) reported it from OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching a diameter of 0.2cm, at first nearly spherical, with the margin strongly incurved, becoming scutellate [like a round plate or shield], hymenium concave, reddish, much paler than the outside of the fruitbody^, (Seaver(1)), 0.1-0.2cm across, hymenium reddish brown, (Hansen, L.(1)), 0.1-0.2cm across, saucer-shaped, disc reddish brown, (Dennis(1)), disc orange-red, slightly concave, completely covered by marginal hairs when dry, (Haines)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  clothed with cinnabar-red hairs which impart to the fruitbody a brick-red color, "varying in old specimens to dark brown"^, (Seaver(1)), with bright orange to deep red hairs, (Hansen, L.), receptacle concealed by dense coating of cinnabar red hairs, (Dennis(1))
STEM  none^ (Dennis(1))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or crowded on dead branches and twigs of hardwoods and conifers^, (Seaver), on hardwood (Hansen, L. for northern Europe), scattered on dead twigs and branches, as of Corylus, Ligustrum, Prunus, Salix, (Dennis(1)), on decorticated hardwood (Haines)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores reaching a length of 20 um and a width of 3-4 um, colorless, 2-seriate or irregularly crowded^; asci reaching a length of 100 um and a diameter of 10-12 um, gradually tapering in lower part; paraphyses rather stout, reaching a thickness of 4 um; hairs "flexuous, of nearly uniform thickness throughout their entire length", reaching a diameter of 3-6 um, "sparingly septate, externally densely covered with coarse red granules", (Seaver(1)), spores 10-15 x 2-3 um, "cylindric to allantoid", aseptate; asci 80-100 x 7-10 um; paraphyses 1-2.5 um wide, not exceeding the asci; hairs 50-200 x 4-5 um, cylindric or slightly tapering, +/- thick-walled, brownish, "with orange granules dissolving and turning violaceous in KOH", (Hansen, L.), spores 10-14 x 2.5-3 um, cylindric with rounded ends and often somewhat curved, biseriate, becoming 1-septate; asci 8-spored, 80-100 x 7-10 um, cylindric with rounded tips; paraphyses 2-2.5 um wide, cylindric, no longer than asci; hairs up to 200 x 4-5 um, "rather thick-walled, slightly tapering to a rounded tip", "containing a sap which turns purple in potash solution and having the wall encrusted with coarse orange granules", (Dennis(1)), spores 12-15 x 4-5 um, "broadly allantoid, curved, somewhat thick-walled, clear at first" but later with granular contents "and a single, thin pseudoseptum", "irregularly biseriate in the ascus", (Haines)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(1), Hansen, L.(1), Dennis(1), Seaver(2), Dennis(3), Haines(1), Zeller(19)
268
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pestalopezia brunneopruinosa  (Zeller) Seaver^  Mycologia 34: 300. 1942;  Dermatea brunneopruinosa  Zeller
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute brown cups with a blackish inside surface, absent or short stem, growth on large dead spots on living salal leaves, and microscopic characters. It is associated with the leaf spot caused by Pestalotia gibbosa Harkness which represents the conidial stage, (Seaver).^ RANGE ^Pestalopezia brunneopruinosa is found from WA to northern CA (Seaver) and is common in western OR and WA (Zeller). There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre and at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.06-0.2cm across; closed at first then cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface fuscous black (due to brownish tips of paraphyses)^, (Zeller)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  fawn-color to wood brown; powdery villose^, (Zeller)
STEM  absent or short^ (Zeller)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on large dead spots on living leaves of Gaultheria shallon (salal)^, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-20 x 7-10 um, elliptic, colorless, containing 1 or 2 oil droplets, uniseriate^; asci reaching a length of 120-140 um and a width of 10-14 um, clavate-cylindric, colorless; paraphyses 4-6 um wide at tips, slender, clavate, light brown in upper part, forming an epithecium 130-160 um thick; exterior with brown septate hyphae with swollen cells toward tip; medullary tissues a colorless pseudoparenchyma, thick; hypothecium thin, of interwoven hyphae, (Zeller)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'brown and pruinose'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Pestalopezia tsugae.
SOURCES  Zeller(14) (as Dermatea brunneopruinosa), Seaver(2)
269
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pestalopezia tsugae  A. Funk^  Can. J. Bot. 56(14): 1575. 1978
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny disc-shaped fruitbodies on hemlock, the underside grayish brown and pruinose, the spore-bearing upper surface dark brown, and the stem short or almost absent. Microscopic characters include 4-spored asci.^ RANGE ^Pestalopezia tsugae was described from BC.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.06-0.15cm across, at first spherical "then expanding to broad, round discs, pruinose, greyish brown with dark brown hymenium, marginate"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  grayish brown; pruinose
STEM  subsessile to short-stemmed
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  erumpent, single or in small groups, in stem of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-24 x 10-14 um from 4-spored asci, 30 x 10 um from 2-spored asci, elliptic, dark brown with brittle epispore, with one or two droplets, not septate^; asci 4-spored, occasionally 2-spored, 110 x 15 um, cylindric, pore not staining in iodine; paraphyses filiform, colorless, simple, greatly inflated at tip with brown spherical cells 6-10 um in diameter, forming a dark brown epithecium; narrow hypothecium of yellowish textura intricata, medullary excipulum of white textura globulosa, ectal excipulum of light brown texture globulosa
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Tsuga'
SIMILAR  Other Pestalopezia species including Pestalopezia brunneopruinosa have colorless to light brown spores, and their ascus pore stains blue in iodine, (Funk).
SOURCES  Funk(6)
270
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pezicula corni  Petr.^  Ann. Myc. 20: 197. 1922
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a minute, disc-shaped fruiting body with a mealy brown covering and a flat, yellowish to brownish black upper spore-bearing surface, 2) growth on dogwood (Cornus), and 3) microscopic characters.^ | Seaver's illustrations appear to show 1-septate and 3-septate mature spores, and the granular coating on the upper surface. RANGE ^Pezicula corni is found in ID, CA to OR and ON, (Seaver). Collections from BC were deposited at Pacific Forestry Centre (determined by J. Groves).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbodies "at first rounded, becoming expanding and subdiscoid, with a mealy, brown covering", reaching about 0.05-0.1cm across, spore-bearing surface flat or nearly so, yellowish to dark brownish black^, (Seaver) 
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or cespitose, on Cornus alternifolia (alternate-leaf dogwood), Cornus stolonifera (red-osier dogwood), and unnamed species of Cornus^, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 28-34 x 10-13 um, elliptic, irregularly crowded in the ascus^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 120 um and a width of 27 um, clavate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], slightly enlarged in upper part; accompanied by a Myxosporium that appears to be its conidial stage, the pycnospores 33-36 x 13-15 um, elliptic and densely filled with granules, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Cornus' referring to its host
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2)
271
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pezicula corylina  J.W. Groves^  Mycologia 30: 47. 1938;  Sphaeronema coryli  Peck;  Catinula turgida  Desm.
ENGLISH NAME(S)
