NOTES  Features include 1) minute, pale to bright yellow, soft-waxy fruitbodies, the margin at first forming a delicate lighter border, 2) absent stem, 3) growth emerging from the surface of beaked hazelnut, 4) association with hard black or dark olive conidial fruitbodies, and 5) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Pezicula corylina is found from PA to WA and Canada including ON, and also in Europe, (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.02-0.05cm across, 0.02-0.04cm high, circular, close to sulphur yellow when moist, pale yellow and slightly pruinose when dry, spore-bearing surface at first concave, then flat to convex, pale yellow to slightly reddish, slightly pruinose; margin at first forming a delicate lighter border, later disappearing; conidial fruitbodies "cylindric to cylindric-conic, or compressed when dry and subhysteriform, opening out widely when moist", 0.02-0.05cm across, 0.03-0.05cm high, black or dark olivaceous^, (Seaver)
FLESH  soft-waxy in consistency, more fleshy when moist; conidial fruitbodies hard, brittle, fleshy-leathery when moist^, (Seaver)
UNDERSIDE  close to sulphur yellow when moist, pale yellow and slightly pruinose when dry^, (Seaver)
STEM  none^ (Seaver), without stem, but narrowed in lower part, (Groves)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  erumpent [emerging from surface], scattered, or more or less in rows, separate, or cespitose, sometimes crowded, on Corylus rostrata (Beaked Hazelnut); conidial fruitbodies erumpent, thickly scattered or more or less in rows, mostly separate, sometimes two or three together^, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-27 x 6-10 um, oblong-elliptic, straight or slightly curved, colorless, simple or 1-septate, irregularly biseriate^; asci usually 8-spored, occasionally 4-spored, 85-125 x 15-20 um, cylindric-clavate, short-stemmed; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], 2-2.5 um wide, colorless, simple or branched, septate, the tips swollen to 3.5 um, forming a slight epithecium, (Seaver); conidia 17-27.5 x 8.0-10.5 um, oblong-elliptic, straight or sometimes slightly curved, colorless, 1-celled, "ends rounded, one end with a truncate apiculus"; conidiophores 10-40 x 2.5-5 um, cylindric to conic, colorless, "septate, occasionally branched, sometimes swollen below the point of attachment of the spore", conidia borne terminally, (Groves)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to Corylus', its host
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Groves(5)
272
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pezicula ocellata  (Pers.) Seaver^  North American Cup-fungi, (Inoperculates) (New York): 345. 1951;  Ocellaria ocellata  (Pers.) J. Schroet.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small orange to golden brown fruitbody that bursts out from the bark of hardwoods especially Salix and Populus, remaining embedded in the bark, with a prominent margin that is often notched and whitish, 2) absent stem, and 3) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Seaver lists Pezicula ocellata for NY to MB, WA, and CO. There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre determined by A. Funk and by R. Shoemaker.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.25cm, developing under bark, tearing it open but remaining embedded in it with flat to somewhat concave disc dark orange to orange-brown in color; uneven and rough; margin turned upward^, (Breitenbach), bursting through the bark but not fully erumpent, saucer-shaped; disc flat, up to 0.2cm across, golden brown with prominent margin, (Dennis), up to 0.1-0.2cm across, "breaking through the bark, the broken edges of which form a ragged margin often extending above the margin of the cup", "yellowish, with an irregularly notched margin that is often whitish", spore-bearing upper surface concave, or nearly flat, surrounded by the upturned margin of the fruitbody, yellowish or dull orange, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  sessile, attached to the substrate by a scanty subiculum^, (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious on dead branches and twigs, still with bark, of Populus (poplar), and Salix (willow), spring and fall^, (Breitenbach), scattered on Salix branches in spring, also on Hippophae, Populus, and Rhamnus, (Dennis), singly on branches of Salix petiolaris, Salix discolor and other species of Salix and Populus, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 27-32 x 12-13.5 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with granular contents, with or without droplets, uniseriate to biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 133 x 21 um, iodine colors the pore red-brown; paraphyses cylindric, forked and with slight clavate widenings toward the tips, septate, (Breitenbach), spores 20-30(40) x 8-12(14) um, broadly elliptic, colorless or yellowish, uniseriate or biseriate according to their number, asci 4-spored or 8-spored, up to 130 x 25 um, clavate, thick-walled, the broad pore deep blue with iodine; paraphyses 3 um wide at tip, slender, branched; subiculum of almost colorless hyphae 5-6 um wide, (Dennis), spores 25-30 x 10-12 um, elliptic, granular within, colorless, simple or 1-3-septate, irregularly biseriate; asci reaching a length of 120 um and a width of 24 um, broad-clavate, ending abruptly at base; paraphyses widened in upper part, reaching a width of 5-6 um; conidia "borne on the surface of a fleshy, submerged stroma, large, ellipsoid, densely filled with granular matter, reaching a length of 30-35 um and a width of 10-12 um borne on a conidiophore about the length of the spore itself and strongly swollen just below the point of attachment", (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'having little eyes', 'marked with spots'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Ocellaria ocellata), Dennis(1) (as Ocellaria ocellata), Seaver(2)
273
FAMILY  Dermateaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pezicula pruinosa  (Peck) Farl.^  in Thaxter, Mycologia 14: 102. 1922;  Sphaeronema pruinosum  Peck;  Dermatea pruinosa  Petr.;  Lagynodella pruinosa  Petr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a minute, pale cinnamon brown fruitbody, club-shaped to disc-shaped with a flat or concave spore-bearing upper surface, 2) a short thick white-pruinose stem, 3) growth emerging from serviceberry (Amelanchier), 4) association with black pruinose pycnidia of the conidial stage Sphaeronema, and 5) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Pezicula pruinosa is found in ID, MA, MT, ND, and NY, (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.1cm across, "at first club-shaped, expanding and becoming discoid, or subdiscoid above"; spore-bearing surface flat or concave, pale cinnamon brown (similar in color to exterior of fruitbody); conidial stage (Sphaeronema) "consisting of conical, or spinulose, black, pruinose pycnidia which spring from a stromatic base", reaching a length of 0.1cm^, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale cinnamon brown^, (Seaver)
STEM  short, reaching length of 0.2cm, almost as thick as fruitbody; white-pruinose^ (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered, erumpent, "single or in cespitose clusters of three to five apothecia each springing from a stromatic base", emerging from Amelanchier canadensis, Amelanchier alnifolia, and unnamed species of Amelanchier (serviceberry)^, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 22-25 x 8-9 um, subelliptic, usually slightly curved, simple or becoming 1-3-septate, 1-2-seriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 95-110 um and a width of 18-21 um, clavate; paraphyses reaching a width of 1 um, filiform [thread-like], simple or branched; conidia 20-24 x 8-9 um, broad-elliptic, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pruinose'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2)
274
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza ammophila  Durieu & Lev.  group^  Expl. sci. Algerie: pl. 28, fig. 2 and Atlas. Expl. figs: 10. 1868;  Sarcosphaera ammophila  (Durieu & Lev.) Seaver;  Sarcosphaera funerata  Seaver;  Peziza funerata  Cooke;  Geopyxis ammophila  Sacc.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  sand tulips
NOTES  Features include 1) fruitbodies first appearing as holes in sand with an irregular or star-shaped margin showing, expanding to deeply cup-shaped and finally flattened on the sand surface, 2) the inside spore-bearing surface dark brown, more yellowish toward margin, 3) the pale ochraceous external surface covered with sand and 4) the pseudostem make of sand held together with mycelium.^ | Vizzini(5) presented molecular evidence to show that there are a number of species close to Peziza ammophila. An Oregon collection fell under Peziza deceptiva ad int. (an interim name) and that was the only collection sequenced from the Pacific Northwest. RANGE ^Peziza ammophila group is found at least in OR and CA, (Larsen), FL to CA and MI, probably world-wide in sand-dunes, (Seaver), Denmark and Sweden, (Hansen), United Kingdom (Dennis), and Algeria, (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  at first entirely buried appearing as holes in the ground with the irregular or slightly star-shaped margin appearing above the surface of the sandy soil, nearly spherical and reaching 2-3cm across, spore-bearing surface exposed when mature, dull umber brown^, (Seaver), 3-7cm across, deeply cup-shaped; spore-bearing inner surface brownish, yellowish toward margin; margin often splitting into irregular rays, (Hansen), cup-shaped, finally splitting in a stellate manner and becoming flattened on the sand surface, disc dark brown, (Dennis)
FLESH  0.2-0.3cm thick^ (Hansen)
UNDERSIDE  pitted with particles of encrusted sand^, (Seaver), covered by sand all over (Hansen), pale ochraceous, (Dennis)
STEM  extended below cup into stem-like base made of a column of sand held together with mycelium^, (Seaver), with a stem, in lower part bulb-shaped, containing much sand, (Hansen), pseudostem of sand grains firmly bound together by mycelium, (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in sandy soil, (Seaver), partly buried in pure sand, in coastal areas, fall, (Hansen)^, semi-immersed [partly buried] in sand; in coastal sands, often among Ammophila (beachgrass), September to December
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-18 x 8-9 um, elliptic, smooth^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 275 um and a width of 12-14 um, cylindric; paraphyses slender, slightly enlarged in upper part, clinging together and not very distinct, (Seaver), spores 16-17 x 9-10 um, elliptic, without droplets, (Hansen), spores 14-16 x 10 um, elliptic, smooth; asci about 200 x 15 um, strong blue reaction with iodine; paraphyses slightly enlarged to 7 um at tip, straight, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'loving sand', may also refer to Ammophila (beachgrass) among which it often grows
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as Sarcosphaera ammophila), Hansen, L.(1), Dennis(1), Larsen(1), Vizzini(5), Siegel(2)*
275
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza ampliata  Pers. ex Pers.^  Mycologia europaea 1: 227. 1822
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a cup with the interior light brown to yellowish brown, a dentate margin, thick watery flesh, a pruinose exterior a little paler than the interior, absent stem, growth on wood, and microscopic characters including unstratified flesh with numerous, large, nearly spherical cells. Peziza ampliata is distinguished among brown Pezizas on wood by the relatively thick flesh, large spores, and unstratified flesh.^ | Dennis notes that the traditional identification with Persoon's fungus on bark and tree-roots in fall is somewhat dubious. RANGE ^Peziza ampliata is found at least in OR and AZ, (Larsen), Denmark and Norway, (Hansen), and the United Kingdom (Dennis).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-3cm across, soon widely expanded with flattened disc; spore-bearing upper surface light brown to yellowish brown; margin often dentate [toothed]^, (Dennis), up to 2(3)cm across, at first shallowly cup-shaped; upper surface yellowish brown to brown, sometimes with an olivaceous tint, (Hansen, K.)
FLESH  thick and watery^ (Dennis), thick flesh in comparison with the size of the fruitbody, about 0.1-0.3cm thick, (Hansen, K.)
UNDERSIDE  a little paler than spore-bearing surface; pruinose^, (Dennis)
STEM  sessile (Dennis, Hansen), sessile on a broad base, or broadly substipitate, (Hansen, K.)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on very rotten wood and on soil containing decayed woody debris, May, (Dennis), late spring to early summer (Hansen), on large trunks or smaller pieces of hardwood, (Hansen, K.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17.5-20 x 10-11 um, elliptic, smooth, without droplets^; asci about 250 x 15 um; paraphyses "straight, cylindrical or with some segments slightly inflated, apex rounded, 5-8 um wide"; flesh "not stratified but contains numerous subglobose cells up to 150 um across, joined by short lengths of hyphae 6-12 um wide", (Dennis), spores 17-20 x 9-11 um (Hansen), excipulum may be stratified or not (with hyphal middle layer between 2 layers of globose cells), (Hansen, K.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'enlarged' or 'expanded'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1), Hansen, K.(2), Larsen(1)
276
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza arvernensis  Boud.^  Bull. Soc. bot. Fr. 26: 26. 1879;  Peziza sylvestris  (Boud.) Sacc.;  Aleuria amplissima  Boud.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a large cup that becomes expanded and undulating, with the upper surface light yellowish brown to chestnut brown, 2) thin fragile flesh, 3) exterior lighter in color and almost smooth, 4) growth on ground in woods, and 5) microscopic characters including spores with fine punctate ornamentation.^ RANGE ^Peziza arvernensis is found at least in OR, ID, AB, and UT, (Larsen). P. sylvestris (Boud.) Sacc. & Trott found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, CA, UT, and WY, (Larsen), Switzerland (Breitenbach), United Kingdom (Dennis), Denmark, Finland, and Sweden, (Hansen), and OR, CA, Denmark, and the Netherlands, (Hansen, K.).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  3-10cm, saucer-shaped, bladder-shaped, irregularly undulating; spore-bearing upper surface hazelnut brown to chestnut brown, smooth^, (Breitenbach), up to 4cm, cup-shaped then expanded and undulating; upper spore-bearing surface light yellowish brown, (Dennis)
FLESH  thin, fragile^, (Breitenbach), fragile (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  lighter in color than upper surface and becoming paler toward the margin; finely furfuraceous, almost smooth^, (Breitenbach), paler; almost smooth, (Dennis)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious in beech forests on ground among leaf litter, April to July^, (Breitenbach), on the ground in woods, May to July, (Dennis), on soil, sawdust, and rotting wood, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-17 x 8-9 um, (according to literature 14.5-19 x 8-11 um), broadly elliptic, finely punctate and rough, colorless, without droplets^; asci 8-spored, 180-240 x 11-13 um, positive reaction with iodine; paraphyses cylindric, septate, tips with slight clavate widening to 5-7 um, (Breitenbach), 17-19 x 9-10 um, elliptic, with fine punctate ornamentation, without droplets; paraphyses straight, round at the tip, guttulate [with droplet(s)], (Dennis), spores 15-20 x 9-10 um, lacking large oil droplets, (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  likely refers to Auvergne region of France, named after a Gallic tribe, Arverni, that once inhabited the area
SIMILAR  Peziza varia, Peziza repanda, and Peziza cerea [see Peziza varia group] all have smooth or only extremely weakly punctate spores, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Trudell(4)*, Hansen, L.(1), Hansen, K.(2), Larsen(1), Siegel(2)*, McAdoo(1)*
277
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza brunneoatra  Desm.^  Ann. Sci. Nat. II. 6: 244. 1836
ENGLISH NAME(S)  brown-black cup
NOTES  Features include a disc-like fruitbody that is brown to brownish black, sometimes with an olive tinge, thin brittle brownish flesh, absent or almost absent stem, growth on damp soil, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Peziza brunneoatra is found at least in WA, OR, ID, CA, and CO, (Larsen), and NY, IA, and Europe, (Seaver), including France (Dennis). Collections from BC were deposited at the University of British Columbia determined by B.J. Macdonald and by V.J. Krajina.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-2.5cm across, cup-shaped becoming flattened when old; spore-bearing upper surface brown to brownish black, sometimes with olive tinge, smooth^, (Arora), expanding and when mature becoming scutellate to disc-shaped, not usually exceeding 1-2cm across; spore-bearing upper surface at first concave, becoming flat, finally a little convex, often umbilicate, brownish black with a slight green tinge, (Seaver), up to 1cm across, disc soon flat, with slightly raised even margin; spore-bearing upper surface blackish brown, (Dennis)
FLESH  thin, brittle; brownish^, (Arora), rather thick; reddish brown, (Dennis), thin, fragile; brown, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
UNDERSIDE  colored as upper surface or slightly paler or redder (red-brown)^, (Arora), dark brown, almost smooth, (Dennis)
STEM  absent or present only as a very short narrowed base^, (Arora), without stem (Seaver, Dennis) 
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to gregarious or clustered "on damp soil along roads and paths through the woods, near streams, under trees, etc."^, (Arora), scattered or gregarious on the ground in damp places (Seaver), on bare ground (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-22 x 8-12 um, elliptic, smooth becoming roughened (warty) or partially reticulate when mature, with 1 or 2 oil droplets^, (Arora), spores 20-22 x 10-11 um, at first smooth, developing rather conspicuous warts about 2 um in diameter, very faintly yellowish or olive, with 2 conspicuous oil droplets or more rarely 1, uniseriate or occasionally crowded, parallel with ascus or oblique; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 300-350 um and a width of 15-17 um, cylindric in upper part, tapering rather abruptly in lower part into stem-like base; paraphyses rather strongly widened in upper part, reaching width of 7-8 um at tip, yellowish brown, (Seaver), spores 14-18 x 9-11 um, elliptic, finely warted, packed with numerous small oil droplets; asci up to 300 x 17 um; paraphyses slender, slightly widened in upper part, with oily contents, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means "brownish-black", from Latin, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(1), Arora(1), Dennis(1), Larsen(1), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*
278
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza cerea  Sowerby ex Merat^  Nouvelle Flore Paris 1: 25. 1821
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  We use the term Peziza varia group to cover Peziza varia itself, Peziza 'repanda' collections that are compatible with the description of Peziza varia, and Peziza cerea. We follow Hansen, K.(2) in regarding Peziza cerea as a synonym of Peziza varia, although it is maintained separately in the online Species Fungorum and MycoBank, each accessed February 28, 2018. K. Hansen et al. include Peziza cerea Fr. as a synonym (finding that moniliform paraphyses were a result of moisture and not taxonomically valuable). Features ascribed to Peziza cerea include 1) a fruitbody that is cup-shaped then expanded, the upper surface pale yellowish to saffron or yellowish brown, 2) whitish scurfy-downy exterior, 3) short stem, 4) growth on a variety of specialized substrates, and 5) microscopic characters.^ | Peziza cerea is placed in synonymy with P. varia by K. Hansen et al. (2002), who note that P. cerea Bull. is most likely P. vesiculosa. RANGE ^Peziza cerea is found at least in OR and NV, according to Larsen(1).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 5cm across, cup-shaped becoming expanded; spore-bearing upper surface pale ochraceous or yellowish brown^, (Dennis), 2-7cm across, at first cup-shaped, then expanded, finally often convex; spore-bearing upper surface pale yellowish to saffron, on drying darker, (Hansen, L.(1))
FLESH  firm; white^, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  white; minutely scurfy^, (Dennis), whitish; delicately pubescent, (Hansen, L.(1))
STEM  0.3-1.5cm high, furrowed, gradually widening into the cup, (Hansen, L.(1))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on woody debris, rotting sandbags, and on the soil between paving stones in a damp cellar; all seasons, (Dennis), on limestone, or often on soil mixed with mortar, in wet cellars and garages on plaster covering timber, straw; all year round, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-17 x 8-10 um, elliptic, smooth^; asci up to 350 x 16 um; paraphyses scarcely clavate, straight, (Dennis), spores 15-17 x 9-10 um, elliptic, without droplets, (Hansen, L.(1))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'waxy'
SIMILAR  Peziza varia has its paraphyses described differently: they are septate, with the individual cells "sometimes constricted at the septa, that is, arranged in a row to resemble a chain (moniliform), especially in older specimens", and P. varia has a "distinctly layered trama in which the middle layer of longitudinal hyphae appears under the lens as dark lines", (Breitenbach(1)). The two are considered synonymous by Hansen, K.(2) who write "Collections designated as P. cerea, P. repanda, and Peziza micropus do not differ from P. varia enough to be separable as species, macroscopically, microscopically, or molecularly". Dennis describes the colors of the upper surface of P. varia and P. repanda differently: "light grey-brown at first but soon becoming dark greyish-brown" for P. varia, and "light chestnut brown" for P. repanda, (Dennis). See also SIMILAR section of Peziza arvernensis and Peziza 'repanda'.
SOURCES  Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1), Hansen, K.(2), Dennis(1), Breitenbach(1) (discussing Peziza varia)
279
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza domiciliana  Cooke^  Gard. Chron. 41: 793. 1877;  Peziza adae  Cooke;  Peziza odorata  Peck
ENGLISH NAME(S)  domicile cup fungus, home cup, cellar cup, domestic cup fungus
NOTES  Features include whitish to tan or brown, irregular saucer-shaped cup, the underside the same color or paler, flesh that often turns golden yellow when broken, absent or indistinct stem, growth on a variety of domestic materials, especially alkaline surfaces, and microscopic characters including smooth spores that eventually become weakly punctate.^ | The illustration in Breitenbach(1) is said by K. Hansen et al. to represent Peziza varia. RANGE ^Peziza domiciliana is found at least in BC, WA, OR, CA, UT, (Larsen), NY to IA and MO (Seaver), and AB (Schalkwijk-Barendsen). It is common, found throughout North America, (Phillips), and Denmark and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  2-10cm across or occasionally larger; cup-shaped when young, becoming flattened or wavy when old, but often keeping central depression (umbilicate), outline often irregular or somewhat angular when old; spore-bearing upper surface at first white or buff, often darkening when old to tan or brown, smooth to slightly wrinkled^, (Arora), 1-4cm across, spore-bearing surface yellowish brown with a pink tinge, (Hansen), at first goblet-shaped, flattening; white then soon pale yellow-ocher to brownish buff, (Phillips), up to 4cm across and 4cm tall (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), at first white, becoming dingy buff or brownish, (Seaver)
FLESH  "rather fragile, at times slightly waxy"; "sometimes turning yellow when broken"^, (Arora), "fragile, thin; buff then golden yellow when broken", (Phillips), "when broken turning golden yellow (it is uncertain whether this character is constant but it is very conspicuous in some cases)", (Seaver)
UNDERSIDE  bald (Hansen), the same color as upper surface or paler, (Arora), white (Seaver)
STEM  often a prominent stem when young and inconspicuous or absent when old, short and stout, up to 1cm long; usually whitish^, (Arora)
ODOR  not distinctive^ (Phillips), pungent fragrance of fresh morels (R. Sieger, pers. comm.)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (Phillips)
EDIBILITY  no (Phillips)
HABITAT  single to gregarious or clustered "on a wide range of domestic materials: plaster, cement, sand, gravel, coal dust, carpets, fireplace ashes, etc."; said to favor strongly alkaline substrates; in houses, "cellars, greenhouses, shower stalls, damp closets, under porches, on wet rugs, behind refrigerators, around leaky water beds", in cars^, (Arora), enriched soil, sawdust, etc., (Hansen), usually associated with buildings, often on damp sand, plaster, in cellars, on rotten wood in houses, (Phillips)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-14(15) x 6-9 um, finely warted, with 2 small droplets^, (Hansen, K.), spores 11-15 x 6-10 um, elliptic, "smooth to very slightly roughened, at times with two small oil droplets", (Arora), spores 13-16 x 7-9 um, elliptic, verruculose (with fine warts), with 1 or 2 droplets; excipulum thick, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin meaning "of the house", (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
SIMILAR  Peziza varia and Daleomyces petersii are among other cup fungi that occasionally grow indoors (Arora). P. varia also occurs on damp walls, plaster and mortar, (Hansen, K.). Peziza praetervisa is close and has been regarded as a color form of Peziza domiciliana, and Daleomyces petersii is also close, (Dennis).
SOURCES  Arora(1)*, Seaver(1), Hansen, L.(1), Phillips(1)*, Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Larsen(1), Hansen, K.(2), Dennis(1), Breitenbach(1) (but see NOTES), AroraPocket(1)*
280
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza echinospora  P. Karst.^  Fungi Fenniae Exsiccati, Fasc. 6(nos 501-600): no. 541. 1866;  Aleuria umbrina  Boud.;  Peziza anthracophila  Dennis
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a cup-shaped to saucer-shaped fruitbody with the margin notched and at first inrolled, the upper surface dark brown to gray-brown or yellow-brown, and the scurfy underside lighter brown to whitish, 2) absent stem, 3) growth on burned ground and charcoal, and 4) microscopic characters including finely warted spores.^ RANGE ^Peziza echinospora is found at least in OR, ID, AZ, CO, NM, and UT, (Larsen), United Kingdom (Dennis), and Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen). There is a collection from BC at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  2-10cm across, cup-shaped to saucer-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface dark brown to hazel-brown; margin notched, inrolled when young^, (Breitenbach), up to 8cm across, usually much smaller, cup-shaped; disc dark brown; margin conspicuously incurved and dentate, (Dennis), pale brown upper surface (Arora), 1-7cm across, cup-shaped then often expanded; spore bearing upper surface yellowish brown, (Hansen)
FLESH  fragile; brownish^, (Breitenbach), thin; brown, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  lighter brown than upper surface to almost whitish; strongly furfuraceous to scurfy^, (Breitenbach), light brown or almost white in lower part; scurfy, (Dennis), whitish, coarsely roughened or pimpled, (Arora), pale brownish; delicately scurfy, (Hansen)
STEM  without stem^ (Breitenbach, Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, or fused with each other to form clusters, on places "where charcoal has been prepared, burned places on damp ground or in shady spots, in early stages of succession"; May to October^, (Breitenbach), on burnt soil and charcoal, May to October, (Dennis), on burnt ground 10-120 weeks after the fire, (Hansen), only on burnt ground (Hansen, K.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-16(17) x 7-8 um, elliptic, with fine warts, colorless, without drops^; asci 8-spored, 250-280 x 11-12 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses cylindric-filiform, tips with clavate widenings to 10 um, septate, (Breitenbach), spores 14-18 x 7-9.5 um, rather oblong-elliptic, with fine warts; asci about 300 x 14 um; paraphyses straight, slightly clavate, (Dennis), 14-16 x 6-7.5 um, narrowly elliptic, isolated regular spines (illustrated), without droplets, (Hansen), spores 15.5-17 x 7.5-9 um, with isolated regular spines up to 1 um high, (Hansen, K.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with spiny spores'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1), Hansen, K.(2), Arora(1), Larsen(1)
281
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza fimeti  (Fuckel) E.C. Hansen^  Vidensk. Meddel Dansk Naturhist. Foren. Kjobenhavn: 267. 1876
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small disc-shaped or top-shaped or cup-shaped fruitbody with a scalloped margin, the upper surface pallid brown or yellowish brown, the underside similar in color and furfuraceous to bald, absent stem, growth on herbivore dung, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Peziza fimeti is found at least in WA, OR, CO, and UT, (Larsen), KY to IA and CO, (Seaver), Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen. L.), also NM, Greenland, and Russia, (Hansen, K.), also Germany, Italy, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan, (Medardi)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 2cm across, at first nearly spherical, becoming expanded; spore-bearing upper surface concave to nearly flat, pallid brown^, (Seaver), 0.4-1cm across, disc-shaped to turbinate [top-shaped], regular; spore-bearing upper surface yellowish brown, (Hansen), most often not exceeding 2cm, with crenulate [scalloped margin], (Hansen, K.)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pallid brown, similar in color to upper surface; granulose^, (Seaver), colored as upper surface; bald, (Hansen), nearly smooth to strongly furfuraceous, (Hansen, K.)
STEM  without a stem or substipitate^, (Seaver), subsessile (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered on cow dung^, (Seaver), on dung of herbivores, summer to fall, (Hansen), on dung of cow, horse, sheep, reindeer, (Hansen, K.), on dung of various animals or (at times) on soil or burnt woody remnants (Medardi)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-22 x 9.5-12.5 um, in type 20-22.5 x 10-12 um^, (Hansen, K. et al. who say that Fuckel's measurement of spores 16 x 8 um perpetuated in several sources, is mostly likely a simple mistake), spores elliptic; asci reaching a length of 280 um and a width of 18 um, cylindric or subcylindric; paraphyses abundant, slender, reaching a width of 8 um, (Seaver), spores 15-18 x 7-9 um, elliptic, without droplets, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'on a dung-hill'
SIMILAR  Peziza varia can also occur on dung, and can resemble P. fimeti in color, but P. varia has smaller spores 14-16(17.5) x 9-11(12) um (versus (18)20-22.5 x 10-12 um) and a three layer medullary excipulum (Medardi). Peziza vesiculosa differs in size, shape, spore size, and structure of medullary excipulum (Medardi). Peziza alcis occurs in Europe on moose dung (Medardi).
SOURCES  Seaver(1), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1), Hansen, K.(2), Medardi(1)
282
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza moseri  Aviz.-Hersh. & Nemlich^  Israel J. Bot. 23(3): 157. 1974;  Peziza sublilacina  Svrcek  Ceska Mykol. 30(3-4): 130. 1976
ENGLISH NAME(S)  violet cup
NOTES  This species is in our Geoscypha violacea group and needs to be better established for the Pacific Northwest. Features include 1) a cup-shaped to expanded fruitbody, 2) upper surface that is lilac or violet to violet brown, 3) pruinose/farinose underside that is light gray-violet to grayish or light brown, 4) absent or very short stem, 5) growth on burned ground, including fire pits, and 6) microscopic characters including smooth spores and paraphyses curved near the tip.^ |The relationship between Peziza moseri and Geoscypha violacea is not clear despite the review of Van Vooren(2): they are both smooth-spored violet cups that favor burned soil. Presumably further DNA studies may help determine the relationship. Van Vooren(2) does give Peziza violacea sensu Breitenbach & Kranzlin (1981) as an older name for P. moseri. |There have been difficulties interpreting the names for purple cups that often grow on burn sites (see entries for Geoscypha violacea and Geoscypha tenacella). Svrcek proposed the name P. sublilacina Svrcek for the species with smooth spores. |The current name of Peziza sublilacina in Species Fungorum was Peziza moseri when accessed on February 14, 2022. RANGE ^Peziza moseri has been photographed from WA (accompanying photo by M. Beug)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-3cm across, cup-shaped to expanded, spore-bearing upper surface lilac, violet to brown-violet^, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  thin, fragile; pale violet^, (Breitenbach)
UNDERSIDE  light gray-violet, farinose [mealy]^, (Breitenbach)
STEM  without stem or with very short stem^, (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or in small clusters or gregarious, on old burned places, April to October, but usually in spring^, (Breitenbach), often found in fire pits (M. Beug, pers. comm.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-13.5 x 7-7.5 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 2 small droplets^; asci 240-270 x 9.5-11.5 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses slender, with tips widened to 5 um and usually bent and containing a brown juice, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Geoscypha tenacella (as Peziza praetervisa) has finely warty mature spores and the paraphyses are not or only slightly bent at the ends, (Breitenbach).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as P. violacea), Van Vooren(2) 
283
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza nivalis  (R. Heim & L. Remy) M.M. Moser^  Avizohar-Hershenzon & Nemlich, Israel J. Bot. 23: 162. 1974
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a fruitbody that is cup-shaped to plate-shaped with the margin curved under, 2) upper surface hazelnut brown to chestnut brown, 3) fragile whitish flesh, 4) underside somewhat lighter in color than the upper surface and slightly furfuraceous, 5) absent stem, 6) growth near melting snowbanks often in burned places, and 7) microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Breitenbach(1) except where specified. RANGE ^Peziza nivalis is found at least OR (Nancy Weber pers. comm.), CA (Hansen, K.), and Switzerland (Breitenbach). The accompanying photograph is from WA. There is a collection from BC at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-3cm, "cup-shaped when young, then plate-shaped with the margin curved under", margin somewhat split; spore-bearing upper surface hazelnut brown to chestnut brown, smooth to somewhat wrinkled
FLESH  fragile; whitish
UNDERSIDE  the same color as upper surface but somewhat lighter; slightly furfuraceous
STEM  without stem
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious, on the ground, "commonly in burned places, appearing just when the snow begins to melt, often already developed under the snow", alpine, according to the literature up to 2600m., (Breitenbach), collections in Sierra Nevada always occurred next to decaying grasses, often on burnt ground, (Hansen, K.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-21 x 9-10 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, without droplets^; asci 8-spored, 260-330 x 12-14 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses septate, tip with slight clavate widening, "cells irregularly swollen between the septa and sometimes with small outgrowths"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of snow'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Hansen, K.(2)
284
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza oliviae  J.L. Frank^  Mycotaxon 126: 183-190. 2013
ENGLISH NAME(S)  olive goblet
NOTES  Features include olive to golden brown, stemmed fruitbodies that are goblet-shaped to cup-shaped to slightly convex, with crenulate margin, "associated with dead woody debris embedded in stream bottoms or on saturated wood, at the stream surface or on stream banks". Peziza oliviae is distinguished from other Peziza species by olive-brown pigmentation, growth underwater or on saturated woody substrates, presence of a stem, smooth spores lacking droplets, and distribution in the western U.S. (Frank). RANGE ^The species was described from multiple collections in OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.8-4.0cm across, the stalked cup 0.7-2.5cm tall, "varies from stalked cup or goblet-shape with upturned margin to a nearly sessile slightly convex disc with a short but prominent stalk"; olive to golden brown; margin crenulate
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  olive to golden brown color implied; "external surface roughened, glabrous" [this is in a sentence that starts with the stem measurement but probably applies to the external surface of the cup]
STEM  0.1-1.0cm x 0.3-0.7cm
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "associated with dead woody debris embedded in stream bottoms or on saturated wood, at the stream surface or on stream banks", June through October
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 19.5-24 x 9.5-12 um, elliptic, smooth, without droplets^; asci 8-spored, 250-380 x 16-22 um, cylindric, operculate, amyloid tips; paraphyses 3-5 um wide, tips clavate, enlarged to 5-8 um wide, equal to or extending slightly (3-8 um) beyond the asci, septate with septa 15-40 um apart; subhymenium 15-25 um thick, "composed of small isodiametric cells" 4-10 um; medullary excipulum 500-1800 um thick, composed of large, inflated isodiametric cells 45-110 x 35-85 um; ectal excipulum 50-150 um thick "composed of elongate and contorted cells" 20-40 x 15-35 um "with olive-brown pigmentation"
NAME ORIGIN  "for Doris Olivia for help finding this cryptic cup fungus; also reflecting the olive hue of the ascomata"
SIMILAR  Another stalked Peziza species growing underwater in Oregon appears to be distinct in the molecular study but is not yet described. Pachyella have gelatinous tissues and lack a stem. Cudoniella clavus has smaller spores and inamyloid inoperculate asci. Aquapeziza globispora, not known from the Pacific Northwest, has round spores.
SOURCES  Frank(4)
285
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza ostracoderma  Korf^  Mycologia 52: 650. 1961;  Plicaria fulva  R. Schneider
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small shallow cup with dark brown to black upper surface, thick flesh that yields no juice, absent stem, growth on burnt ground or in mushroom beds where soil has been sterilized, and microscopic characters including spores with a network of ridges, and flesh composed throughout of large rounded cells.^ | The anamorph, Chromelosporium fulvum (Link), Hennebert and Korf, is velvety to floccose, white or yellow, turning to cinnamon when it is actively growing and producing conidia. RANGE ^P. ostracoderma is found at least in WA, OR, (Larsen), Denmark, Norway, Sweden, (Hansen), and the United Kingdom (Dennis). A collection from BC is deposited at Pacific Forestry Centre, determined by J. Dennis.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-2cm across, "shallow cup-shaped becoming flattened"; disc dark brown to blackish^, (Dennis), 0.8-1.6cm across, turbinate [top-shaped] to disc-shaped; spore bearing upper surface dark brownish, (Hansen)
FLESH  relatively thick, but yielding no juice^, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  without stem^ (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on burnt ground or in mushroom-beds, fall^, (Hansen), associated with burning or with sterilized soil casing a mushroom bed, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-14 x 7.5-8 um, elliptic, with a more or less continuous network of prominent ridges^; asci 260 x 11 um; paraphyses cylindric, 3 um wide; flesh composed throughout of large rounded cells, (Dennis), spores 12-15 x 7-10 um, elliptic, irregularly reticulate, with 2 droplets, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'shell-skin'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1), Larsen(1)
286
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza 'repanda'  Pers.^  Icon. pict. sp. fung. 4: 49. 1808: Fr. Syst. mycol. 2: 51-52. 1822
ENGLISH NAME(S)  recurved cup, brown cup, spreading brown cup fungus
NOTES  We use the term Peziza varia group to cover Peziza varia itself, Peziza cerea (which can be considered a synonym of Peziza varia), and Peziza 'repanda' collections that are compatible with the description of Peziza varia. K. Hansen et al. comment about the use of this species concept, "Since the name lacks a type specimen and has been used inconsistently it is best treated as of uncertain application."^ |, and this is elaborated as follows: Persoon described the habitat as "in sylvaticis ad terram" [in the woods on the ground]. Fries used the name for a species on old trunks, primarily of Fagus [beech], but also included blackened soil as the substrate - some authors have followed one and some the other, and still others have used the name for a species occurring on soil and only exceptionally on wood, and in all cases the spores are smooth and are in the size range for Peziza varia. The descriptions below are for Peziza repanda Pers. (Seaver, Dennis), Peziza repanda Pers.: Fr. (Hansen), or authority not given (Arora). Many records of P. repanda can be considered Peziza varia. RANGE ^P. 'repanda' is found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, and also CA, CO, MT, WY, (Larsen for Peziza repanda Pers. ex Pers.), CA (Arora), NY to IA and MD, also Europe, (Seaver), Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden, (Hansen), and United Kingdom (Dennis).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  4-13cm across or occasionally larger, "cup-shaped when young but expanding to nearly flat or often wavy (undulating), the margin often splitting"; spore-bearing upper surface pale brown to medium brown, tan, or when old somewhat darker, "smooth to somewhat wrinkled or convoluted at the center"^, (Arora), reaching 8-10cm across, at first cup-shaped, the margin even or crenate [scalloped], expanding and becoming repand, the margin remaining entire or splitting, regular in outline or irregularly revolute; upper surface concave becoming flat or convex, pale brown, becoming darker when old, (Seaver), occasionally up to 12cm across, "cup-shaped, becoming expanded and undulating"; spore-bearing upper surface light chestnut brown; margin often crenate [scalloped], (Dennis), 1-4cm across, cup-shaped then expanded; upper surface pale brownish, (Hansen)
FLESH  fairly brittle^ (Arora), whitish or fawn (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  pallid^ (Arora), white or whitish (Seaver), whitish or pale fawn toward margin; finely scurfy, (Dennis), grayish; bald to furfuraceous, (Hansen)
STEM  "absent or present only as a short, narrowed base"^, (Arora), when young with a short stout stem usually only a few mm long, but when mature stem is inconspicuous or obsolete, (Seaver), without a stem (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  "said to be edible, but easily confused with look-alikes of unknown edibility", (Arora)
HABITAT  single, gregarious, or in clusters on logs and branches (especially of hardwoods), lignin-rich humus, etc.^, (Arora), on rotten logs or occasionally on soil or chip-piles, (Seaver), on the ground in woods, luxuriant forms on sawdust heaps, (Dennis), on rich soil (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-18 x 8-10 um, elliptic, smooth, without oil droplets^, (Arora), spores 14-16 x 8-10 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless; asci reaching a length of 225 um and a width of 12-15 um, cylindric or subcylindric; paraphyses slender, slightly widened in upper part, yellowish or brownish, (Seaver), spores 15-16 x 9-10 um, elliptic, smooth; asci up to 300 x 13 um; paraphyses very slender, slightly clavate at tip, (Dennis), spores 16-17 x 9-10.5 um, without droplets, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means "wavy", "folded" in Latin^, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
SIMILAR  The flesh of P. repanda is stratified like that of Peziza varia but the disc is a different shade of brown (P. varia being "light grey-brown at first but soon becoming dark greyish-brown") and the peculiar moniliform paraphyses of P. varia are lacking, (Dennis). Peziza varia and Peziza cerea cannot be differentiated clearly on field characters, (Lincoff(2)). Collections designated as P. cerea, P. repanda, and Peziza micropus do not differ from P. varia enough to be separable as species, macroscopically, microscopically, or molecularly, (Hansen, K.). Dennis also describes the colors of the upper surface of P. cerea differently: "pale ochraceous or yellowish-brown" (Dennis).
SOURCES  Arora(1)*, Seaver(1), Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1), Hansen, K.(2), Larsen(1), Lincoff(2)*, Miller(14)*, Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Ammirati(1)*, Desjardin(6)*
287
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza sepiatra  Cooke^  Grevillea 3: 119. 1875
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a cup-shaped to flat fruitbody with a very dark brown upper surface, and with a similar color on the scurfy underside, 2) absent stem, 3) growth on the ground, on burned ground or burned wood, or on rotten cloth, and 4) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Peziza sepiatra is found at least in BC and CO, (Larsen), Switzerland (Breitenbach), United Kingdom (Dennis), and Norway (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-1(2)cm across, "flat and saucer-shaped when young, then plate-shaped with a somewhat projecting flaky and toothed margin"; spore-bearing upper surface gray-brown to black-brown; smooth^, (Breitenbach), about 1-2cm across, shallow cup-shaped then flattened; disc very dark brown, (Dennis), up to 2cm, disc-shaped, blackish brown, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  same color as upper surface to somewhat darker; furfuraceous^, (Breitenbach), same color as upper surface; scurfy, (Dennis)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach, Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single on "ground along the edges of paths, in pastures and fields of tall perennials", according to the literature on burned ground and rotten cloth, summer^, (Breitenbach), on soil, charcoal, and rotting textiles, (Dennis), on burned ground (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 19-22 x 12-13 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, without droplets^; asci 8-spored, 260-280 x 18-20 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses cylindric, tips with clavate widenings to 10 um, (Breitenbach), spores 18-20 x 11-12 um, elliptic, smooth, without droplets; asci 280-300 x 16-18 um; paraphyses straight, simple, tip rounded, 5-8 um wide, (Dennis), spores 18-22 x 11-13 um (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'brown black'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1), Larsen(1)
288
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza spissa  Berk.^  Grevillea 3: 152. 1875
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small fruitbody that is cup-shaped to disc-shaped with the upper surface dark brown, and the underside a similar color, 2) short stem-like base when young, 3) gregarious growth on damp soil, and 4) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Peziza spissa is found at least in WA (Larsen(1) but occurrence not verified by either author). Seaver lists it for WA and AL, (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 1-2cm across, at first shallow cup-shaped, becoming disc-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface concave becoming convex, dark brown^, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  similar color to upper surface^ (Seaver)
STEM  "short stem-like base which is obscured at maturity"^, (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on damp soil^, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 25-27 x 12-14 um, elliptic, smooth then developing minute warts, "usually containing two large oil droplets and often several smaller ones, granular within and slightly yellowish", uniseriate, obliquely or irregularly disposed^; asci reaching a length of 260-275 and a width of 23-24 um, cylindric or nearly cylindric in upper part, tapering in lower part into a stem-like base, becoming spirally twisted when young; paraphyses stout, strongly widened in upper part where they reach 10-12 um, "filled with a mass of dark brown coloring matter which often separates in such a way as to give the tip of the paraphyses a septate or muriform appearance", colorless in lower part, often twisted like the ascus, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'thick, crowded, dense'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(1), Larsen(1)
289
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza sterigmatizans  W. Phillips^  apud Cooke, Mycographia: 175. 1879
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a smooth fruitbody that is shallow cup-shaped, expanded or even repand, with the upper surface dark brown and the underside pale, absent stem, growth on wet ground, and microscopic characters including thick branched paraphyses.^ RANGE ^Peziza sterigmatizans is found WA and OR, (Larsen), and the United Kingdom (Dennis).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  about 2cm across, shallow cup-shaped, soon expanded and even repand; spore-bearing upper surface dark brown^, (Dennis)
FLESH  thin; whitish^, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  pale^ (Dennis)
STEM  without stem^ (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on wet ground; in fall and winter^, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17-20(23) x 9-10(13) um, smooth, without droplets^; asci 250-300 x 13-15 um; paraphyses "rather thick closely septate, straight but commonly forked near the apex or with a short lateral branch, apex clavate, 7-10 um, with brownish oily contents", (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  "named for its thick branched paraphyses"^, (Dennis)
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dennis(1), Larsen(1)

FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza vacini  (Velen.) Svrcek^  Ceska Mykol. 31(2): 70. 1977 [as 'vacinii']
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a disc that is olivaceous then brown with a purple tinge, habitat on burnt ground, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Peziza vacini has been found near Corvallis OR, (Nancy Weber pers. comm.), as well as in Europe (Hansen for Norway).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-0.8cm, disc-shaped; olivaceous then brown with purple tinge
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE

HABITAT  on burnt ground, late summer
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-15 x 9-10.5 um, elliptic, with conspicuous ridges, with two droplets^

291
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza varia  (Hedw.) Alb. & Schwein.  group^  Systema mycologicum 2: 61. 1822
ENGLISH NAME(S)  brown cup
NOTES  Features of Peziza varia include 1) a cup-shaped to flat fruitbody, 2) upper surface that is gray-brown, 3) underside that is furfuraceous and white to gray-brown, 4) flesh distinctly layered under a hand-lens with up to 5 layers, the middle layer often appearing as a dark line, 5) rudimentary stem, 6) growth on buried or rotting wood, and 7) microscopic characters including moniliform paraphyses. Peziza varia group are common in the Pacific Northwest.^ | We use the term Peziza varia group to cover Peziza varia itself, Peziza cerea (which can be considered synonym of Peziza varia), and Peziza 'repanda' collections that are compatible with the description of Peziza varia. K. Hansen et al. comment about the use of the species concept of Peziza repanda, "Since the name lacks a type specimen and has been used inconsistently it is best treated as of uncertain application." K. Hansen et al. include Peziza cerea Fr. as a synonym (finding that moniliform paraphyses were a result of moisture and not taxonomically valuable), and point out the ambiguities in the various concepts of the similar Peziza repanda, a name they treat as "of uncertain application". The molecular study of Medardi(1) showed that collections in a clade representing Peziza varia grew on a wide variety of habitats including herbivore dung. RANGE ^Peziza varia is found at least in ID (Larsen), Switzerland (Breitenbach), United Kingdom (Dennis), Finland and Sweden, (Hansen, L.(1)), Italy and Russia (Medardi), and OR, MA, Denmark, Finland, Russia, and the United Kingdom, (Hansen, K.). There is a Paul Kroeger collection from BC deposited at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  2-6cm across, cup-shaped to saucer-shaped, soon irregularly expanded and flat; spore-bearing upper surface hazelnut-colored to cognac-colored, smooth; margin wavy and weakly notched^, (Breitenbach), seldom more than 5cm when fully expanded, cup-shaped but soon flattened or even convex; upper surface light gray-brown at first but soon becoming dark grayish brown, (Dennis), 2.5-6.0cm, "more or less regularly cup-shaped", margin "regular or somewhat wavy"; "pale brown, pale hazelnut", hygrophanous, "dark brown if wet", gray-brownish to whitish when dry; smooth, (Medardi)
FLESH  "under the hand-lens up to 5 layers are distinctly identifiable in cross-section", not especially fragile; whitish^, (Breitenbach), watery gray to fawn, often with a dark line visible on cross-section under hand lens, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  whitish to gray-brownish; finely furfuraceous^, (Breitenbach), whitish to fawn; scurfy, (Dennis), slightly scurfy (Medardi)
STEM  often with indication of a stem^ (Breitenbach), often with a rudimentary stem (Dennis), sessile or subsessile (Medardi)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or fused together in clusters, in "forests and gardens on buried or rotting wood, roots, and so forth"^, (Breitenbach), on soil rich in humus and in contact with rotting wood, decaying tree roots and the like, June and fall, (Dennis), on rotting wood or occasionally in basements (Arora), "wood (raw or trimmed, sometimes also painted, occasionally buried), sandy or gravelly, calcareous or acid soil, composted loam, between floor tiles, in cellars or caves, on burnt remnants", "on building, textile, or papery residues", and on dung of herbivores, such as equine or bovine or bear (but not recorded from moose dung), (Medardi)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-16 x 8-10 um, elliptic, smooth, sometimes slightly punctate, colorless, without droplets^; asci 8-spored, 250-300 x 12-13 um; paraphyses septate, with cells that are "sometimes constricted at the septa, that is, arranged in a row to resemble a chain (moniliform), especially in older specimens", up to 20 um wide, apical end cells slender; cross-section showing up to 5 layers, with middle layer of longitudinal hyphae, (Breitenbach), spores 14-16 x 9-11 um, elliptic, smooth; asci up to 280 x 14 um; paraphyses "mostly with the lower or middle cells much inflated, up to 20 um wide, apical cells slender, tips slightly clavate"; flesh "conspicuously stratified in five layers, beneath the asci is a subhymenium of small cells, then follows a zone of large subglobose or vertically elongated cells, a zone of slender woven hyphae, a lower zone of large globose cells and finally a surface zone of smaller cells and hyphae", (Dennis), spores 14-16(17.5) x 9-11(12) um, smooth, colorless, without droplets; asci up to 280 um long, cylindric, paraphyses clavate to moniliform; excipulum multi-layered: texture globulosa-angularis subhymenium with 5-12 um broad cells, a 3-layered medullary excipulum (internal or upper texture globulosa-angularis layer with 20-100(110) um broad cells, median textura intricata, external or lower textura angularis layer with 20-45 um broad cells), and ectal texture globulosa excipulum with 15-20 um broad cells, (Medardi)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'different'
SIMILAR  Peziza cerea has different paraphyses (Breitenbach). Dennis describes the color of P. cerea differently as "pale ochraceous or yellowish brown" on the upper surface, (Dennis). Peziza repanda has slightly less gray color and spores are smooth, (Arora). Peziza repanda and Peziza cerea cannot be differentiated clearly in the field (Lincoff(2)). Collections designated as P. cerea, P. repanda, and Peziza micropus do not differ from P. varia enough to be separable as species, macroscopically, microscopically, or molecularly, (Hansen, K.). Dennis also describes the colors of the upper surface of P. repanda differently, as "light chestnut brown" (Dennis). Peziza fimetii resembles P. varia in color but has larger spores measuring (18)20-22.5 x 10-12 um "and a medullary excipulum composed of a single textura globulosa layer" with 50-100 um broad cells, (Medardi). See also SIMILAR section of Peziza arvernensis, Legaliana badia, Peziza domiciliana, and Peziza 'repanda'.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Larsen(1), Arora(1), Hansen, K.(2), Hansen, L.(1), Lincoff(2) (discussing Peziza repanda), Medardi(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
292
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Peziza vesiculosa  Bull.^  Hist. Champ. France: 270. 1791: Fr., Syst. mycol. 2: 52. 1822
ENGLISH NAME(S)  common dung cup, bladder cup, small dung cup, barnyard cup, blistered cup
NOTES  Features include 1) a permanently cup-shaped fruitbody with an incurved margin, 2) light yellowish brown upper surface that may develop wrinkles or blisters centrally, 3) whitish to brown exterior that is minutely roughened or scurfy, 4) absent or short stout stem, 5) growth on manure piles, manured straw or hay, or heavily fertilized soil, and 6) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Peziza vesiculosa is found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, CA, and CO, (Larsen), AB (Schalkwijk-Barendsen), NY to WA, CA, AL, and probably throughout North America, (Seaver), Switzerland (Breitenbach), United Kingdom (Dennis), and Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 10cm across, closed and bladder-like when young with rounded opening that appears by gradual tearing, never expanded when old but always bladder-like to saucer-shaped with incurved and irregularly split margin; spore-bearing upper surface light ocher-brownish, smooth^, (Breitenbach), up to 8cm across, permanently cup-shaped, often with strongly incurved margin; upper surface light yellowish brown, (Dennis), 2-8cm, at first more or less spherical, opening to cup-shaped with inrolled, often crimped or convoluted margin; upper surface yellowish to yellow-brown to pale brown or buff, sometimes darker brown when old; smooth or wrinkled toward center, (Arora), pale brown upper surface, (Seaver), margin remaining incrusted or toothed, whitish, (Courtecuisse)
FLESH  fragile; pale^, (Breitenbach), very brittle; pale fawn, (Dennis), rather fragile and soft, (Arora), juicy, thick, fragile, (Lincoff(1))
UNDERSIDE  ocher to dingy whitish, smooth, furfuraceous^, (Breitenbach), pale fawn; coarsely scurfy, (Dennis), "whitish to buff or pale tan"; minutely rough or scurfy, (Arora), "typically mottled and strong brown at first, fading to light yellowish brown and eventually becoming dingy white as it dries out", (McKnight), grayish yellow (Hansen), darker than upper surface (Seaver)
STEM  absent, or present only "as a narrowed basal point of attachment"^, (Arora), without stem or with a very stout stem-like base, (Seaver)
ODOR  none^ (Lincoff(1))
TASTE  none^ (Lincoff(1))
EDIBILITY  not recommended, one source says it is poisonous unless well-cooked, (Arora)
HABITAT  single or gregarious, "usually fused together in clusters to form large clumps", on "dungheaps, manured ground, commonly on horse manure, in commercial mushroom beds", throughout the year^, (Breitenbach), on manure heaps and richly manured soil, mushroom beds, etc., August to April, (Dennis), restricted to +/- manured straw or hay, richly manured soil and mulched beds, but apparently not or rarely directly on dung, (Hansen, K.), single "or more often gregarious (sometimes in large clusters) on manure, dung, rotting straw, in corrals, around stables, gardens, and other fertilized areas, etc.", (Arora), "on manure heaps and rich manured soil", "June to October; November to February on West Coast", (Lincoff(2)), on droppings of large herbivores or on the ground, all year especially late winter and spring, (Lincoff(1)), "on manure heaps, old straw, or composted soil", (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-23 x 10-13 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, without droplets^; asci 8-spored, 320-370 x 17-24 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses "slender, septate, and slightly constricted at the septa (moniliform)", tip slightly widened, (Breitenbach), spores 20-24 x 11-14 um, elliptic, smooth; asci up to 380 x 25 um; paraphyses "slender, straight, scarcely clavate", (Dennis), spores 18-24 x 10-14 um, elliptic, smooth, without oil droplets, (Arora), ascus tips stain blue in iodine (McKnight)
NAME ORIGIN  "blister-like", coming from the fact that the spore-bearing surface in the center of the cup commonly detaches from underlying flesh to form blisters^, (Dennis)
SIMILAR  Peziza fimeti "also grows in dung, but is smaller (up to 2cm) and dull brown, seldom grows in clusters, and has smaller spores", (Arora). P. fimeti grows on dung and has smooth spores in the same size range, but differs in small disc-shaped fruitbodies and other characters, (Hansen, K.). Phillips(1) says that Peziza bovina is found in the Pacific Northwest: according to Dennis(1), it has "similar ascospores, 19-22 x 9(10) um borne by small (under 1cm diameter) umbilicate-revolute umber-brown apothecia on cow dung". See also SIMILAR section of Legaliana badia.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Arora(1)*, Seaver(1), Trudell(4)*, Lincoff(2)*, Lincoff(1)*, Phillips(1)*, Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Courtecuisse(1)*, McKnight(1)*, Larsen(1), Hansen, K.(2), Bacon(1)*, Buczacki(1)*, Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2)*
293
FAMILY  Lachnaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pezoloma ciliifera  (P. Karst.) Korf^  Phytologia 21(4): 205. 1971;  Ciliatula ciliifera  (P. Karst.) Pouzar;  Hyaloscypha ciliifera  (P. Karst.) Boud.;  Ombrophila ciliifera  (P. Karst.) P. Karst.;  Peziza ciliifera  P. Karst.;  Pseudodiscinella ciliifera  (P. Karst.) Dennis;  Sphagnicola ciliifera  (P. Karst.) Velen.;  Lachnea ciliata  Velen.;  Cyathicula alni  Kauffman and Kanouse
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  The features of Pezoloma ciliifera are 1) small, watery white, cup-shaped fruitbodies with a flat disc and discrete, straight marginal hairs, the outside of the fruitbody gelatinous, a macroscopically visible condition in young specimens, 2) gregarious growth on Sphagnum moss, wet wood, and other damp habitats, and 3) microscopic characters including elliptic spores measuring 10-15 x 3.5-4.5 um, asci 60-115 um long, and an external fruitbody layer that is gelatinized with a thin embedded layer of type textura porrecta.^ RANGE ^The main photograph was taken in OR. Pezoloma ciliifera has been reported from Europe including the Czech Republic, Finland, France, Germany, Sweden, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, and China, (Garcia), and Spain (Galan, but with longer asci than in the key of Garcia(1)). Under the name Cyathicula alni, it was reported from the United States (Garcia).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.4cm across, cup-shaped with flat disc, "surrounded by a narrow erect rim from which arise narrow pointed teeth" about 0.05cm long; fruitbody "watery white throughout"^ (Dennis), up to 0.5cm across, flat- cupshaped, entirely white, hyaline, sometimes with a slight bluish tinge, soon becoming whitish to ochraceous; the margin finely ciliate, especially visible with a lens; sometimes without cilia but marginal outgrowths still visible microscopically, (Garcia), 0.3-0.6(1.5)cm across, cup-shaped to disc-shaped; whitish, (Galan)
FLESH  colorless^ (Garcia)
UNDERSIDE  watery-white; in damp weather "the outer gelatinous sheath may be readily seen by the naked eye" surrounding the fruitbody, (Dennis), white to ochraceous, smooth, shiny, clearly gelatinized especially in young specimens, diminishing with maturity so that it persists only at the base where it may only be visible microscopically, (Garcia), smooth, with the exception of the ciliate margin; white or often becoming pale yellow and appearing gelatinous, (Galan)
STEM  sessile [without a stem]^ (Dennis), substipitate [with a slight stem] then rapidly sessile, (Garcia), sessile (Galan)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on the ground among Sphagnum moss and Carex (sedge), (Dennis), gregarious in wet places, bogs, on Sphagnum, wood, and various kinds of debris; collections examined from April, May, August, October, (Garcia), single or gregarious, (Galan), in OR in Sphagnum bog at the end of May (main photograph)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-15 x 3.5-4.5 um, elliptic, non-septate, usually uniseriate^; asci up to 115 x 8 um; paraphyses numerous but very slender, (Dennis), spores 9-13 x (3)4-5.5 um, cylindric-elliptic, smooth, colorless, very rarely with a central septum, generally uniseriate, asci 8-spored, (67)80-90(120) x (6)8-11 um, cylindric, pleurorhynchous, not reaction to iodine at the tips, but with a detectable amyloid reaction if pretreated with KOH; paraphyses filiform, linear, 1-2 um wide, colorless, may be septate (peu septees), simple or forked at base, slightly or not enlarged at the tip, very rarely with diverticulate outgrowths; outer layer of ectal excipulum gelatinized, inamyloid, the hyphae forming a thin embedded layer of type textura porrecta, loosely tangled, undulating (not spiral), regularly septate with thin transverse septa, ending with a slightly rounded clavate tip that has a width of 2-3 um, having a smooth wall that is slightly thickened in places; the internal layer of ectal excipulum non-gelatinized, consisting or 2-3 layers of hyaline cells of type texture prismatica-angularis; the medullary excipulum non-gelatinized, of type textura intricata; hairs generally with a pyramidal form, 20-30 um wide at the base and about 3 um wide at the tip, giving a total height of 100-175(260) um, (Garcia), spores (8)10-14(15.5) x 4.8-5.8(6.5) um, uniseriate, but biseriate when accumulating at ascal tip; asci 8-spored, (105)120-150(175) x 10-12 um, exceeding the paraphyses by 15-20 um; paraphyses cylindric (1.5-2 um wide) to cylindric-claviform (2.5 um wide), septate, branching at the base and rarely also at the tips, (Galan)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'bearing cilia'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dennis(1) (as Sphagnicola ciliifera), Garcia(1) (in French), Galan(1)* (in Spanish)
294
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Phialina lachnobrachya  (Desm.) Raitv.^  Scripta Mycol. 1: 27. 1970;  Trichopeziza lachnobrachya  (Desm.) Sacc.;  Pezizella lachnobrachya  (Desm.) Hoehn.;  Hyaloscypha lachnobrachya  (Desm.) Nannf.;  Phialoscypha lachnobrachya  (Desm.) Raitv.;  Calycellina lachnobrachya  (Desm.) Baral;  Setoscypha lachnobrachya  (Desm.) Svrcek
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute, bright yellow to white fruitbody with sparse whitish hairs, absent or almost absent stem, growth on leaves, and microscopic characters.^ | The description is from Huhtinen(2). RANGE ^Collections were studied from WA, NT, Austria, Belgium, Algeria, Czech Republic, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Luxembourg, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, Japan, and Tadzhikistan (Huhtinen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody up to 0.08cm across when fresh, cup-shaped when young, cup-shaped to scutellate when mature; disc flat to convex when fresh, often spongy and pitted when mature, vivid yellow to yellow to white when fresh, such variation occurring partly within the same population, the light yellowish discs occasionally showing whitish areas; disc bordered by a thin zone of marginal hairs, which are appressed to the substrate or rise above the disc, margin in larger fruitbodies typically appressed to the substrate and the fruitbodies appearing pulvinate [cushion-shaped]; hair cover sparse, whitish
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  narrowly sessile on ill-defined base or on a 0.003-0.005cm wide base
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on leaves of Betula (birch), Acer (maple), Alnus (alder), Quercus (oak), Salix (willow), Rhododendron, Corylus (hazel), 3 collections from leaf petioles, 2 from capsules of Aesculus (buckeye-horsechestnut); mainly fruiting in fall
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11.0-18.8(22.2) x 2.0-3.5(4.0) um in Melzer's reagent, "mostly fusoid to narrowly fusoid when in asci, after being discharged similar or becoming more broadly fusoid to oblong-elliptic, straight to slightly curved to apically beaked (especially in asci), aseptate in 77% of the populations, frequently one-septate after being discharged in others, rarely while still inside the asci", wall colorless, droplets "prominent and light to lacking when fresh in water"^; asci 4-spored, (rarely 6-spored or 8-spored), 28-52(63) x 5-8(9.7) um in Melzer's reagent with blue apical pore, cylindric-clavate with slightly conic apex, arising from croziers; paraphyses cylindric to clavate, often containing bright yellow amorphous pigment similar to that inside the hairs, first dichotomous branches typically at or below the level of ascal bases, terminal cells 8-34 x (1.3)2.0-3.7 um, clavate apices 2.3-4 um wide, closely septate in lower part, average septal interval 9.2 um; hairs 18-64(130) x 2.5-4.0 um, narrowly conic to slightly lageniform [gourd-like], often with a long filiform [thread-like] tip, flexuose to cincinnate [curled], more rarely straight, one-septate to multiseptate, the basal parts often with bright yellow pigment, tip tapering to 0.4-1.0 um, very rarely inconspicuously solidified, without an apical globule in Melzer's reagent, wall thin and dull, in a few populations somewhat thickened and refractive, but never locally prominently thickened, colorless, smooth in 75% of populations in Melzer's reagent but with scattered minute apical warts in others; ectal excipulum of textura prismatica, inner excipulum of slightly narrower cells, at base composed of brown textura epidermoidea
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with short woolly hairs'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Huhtinen(2)
295
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Phylloscypha phyllogena  (Cooke) Van Vooren^  Ascomycete.org 12(4): 189. 2020;  Peziza phyllogena  Cooke  Mycogr., Vol. 1. Discom. (London) (no. 4): 148, fig. 251. 1877;  Peziza badioconfusa  Korf  Mycologia 46(6): 838. 1954
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Phylloscypha phyllogena produces large cup-shaped, stalkless fruitbodies that are purple-brown to red-brown to olive-brown on the upper surface, paler and scurfy-granular on the lower surface, growing on soil or decaying wood, with finely warty spores.^ |Phylloscypha phyllogena (as P. badio-confusa Korf) was distinguished from P. badia [now Legaliana badia] in 1954 by Korf: speaking of P. badio-confusa Korf, he said, "This species is almost invariably determined in America as Peziza badia [name in italics], and certainly is that figured by Seaver... under this name. It is perhaps our commonest large cup-fungus, and it seems to me that it must have been described before 1897 by some European or American author, but I have seen no types which match it. The true P. badia [name in italics] has reticulate spore-markings, as shown by Le Gal". (Korf(5)). |Elliott & Kaufert in 1974 redescribed both of these species microscopically, refining the distinction between the two species: Peziza phyllogena [now Phylloscypha phyllogena] had spores with "walls finely roughened, with warts about 0.5 um in height, frequently smooth at ends of mature spores as primary wall remains attached (apiculus)", whereas P. badia had spores "ornamented with short predominantly longitudinal ridges which unite to form an incomplete and irregular reticulum, ridges about 0.5 um in height, apiculus not seen" (with the letter mu used for um); if the fruitbody was found on downed wood rather than on the ground it was much more likely to be P. phyllogena although occasional collections of P. badia are found on wood, P. phyllogena was collected from May 18 to July 26 in Canada and from March 28 to June 25 in the US (excluding AK), [although Ginns examined a September 12 collection from ON and cites a September collection from AK], whereas P. badia was collected from July 18 to October 25 in Canada and from June 21 to October 5 in the US. (Elliott, M.E.(2)). RANGE ^Phylloscypha phyllogena was examined (as Peziza phyllogena) from BC, ON, PQ, AK, MA, NY, MD, and PA, (Elliott, M.E.(2)). Phylloscypha phyllogena was reported (as Peziza phyllogena) from BC, WA, OR, ID, CA, and UT, (Larsen as P. badioconfusa).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  3-15cm across, cup-shaped to shallowly cup-shaped; upper surface "purple-brown to reddish brown or olive-brown"; smooth^, (Beug), 2-8cm across, upper surface olivaceous to warm brown, (Hansen, L.)
FLESH  thin, brittle; brownish^, (Beug)
UNDERSIDE  "pale reddish brown to purple-brown"; "scurfy or granular"^, (Beug), in upper part colored like the upper surface, in lower part "becoming pubescent to villose, bluish violet", (Hansen, L.)
STEM  none^ (Beug), without a stem or with a short stem (Hansen, L.)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "scattered, in groups, or in clusters on soil or decaying wood; spring and early summer, also winter and spring in California"^, (Beug), summer to fall, especially on trunks of Salix (willow), (Hansen, L.(1) for northern Europe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-21 x 8-10 um, elliptic, finely verrucose (warty), colorless, "often with thickened polar walls", with two droplets^; asci about 140- x 12 um, with amyloid tips; paraphyses enlarged at tips, (Beug), spores 19-21 x 8-10 um, elliptic, narrow, with 2 droplets, "ornamentation of delicate, elongate warts [illustrated]", (Hansen, L.)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Legaliana badia is very similar but "its spores have a delicate irregular reticulum versus the finely warted spores" of Peziza phyllogena and its synonym Peziza badioconfusa, (Beug(3)). Peziza kalloi Harmaja has also been confused with P. badioconfusa and occurs at least in northern Europe and AK: it differs from P. badioconfusa in the conspicuous bright violet basal mycelium, shorter (15-19 x 7.5-10 um) and elliptic spores, spore ornamentation consisting "of warts that vary somewhat in size throughout the spore", being +/- distinctly larger at the spore ends, "the habitat (usually) in moist or wet rich woods and bushes, especially by brooks", mostly in decaying hardwood, the fruiting in summer and fall, and the pronounced boreal distribution, (Harmaja(4)).
SOURCES  Beug(3)* (as Peziza), Hansen, L.(1) (as Peziza), Korf(5) (as Peziza), Elliott, M.E.(2) (as Peziza), Pfister(5) (note 32) (discussing P. badia and P. badio-confusa in relation to Seaver), Ginns(9) (discussing P. phyllogena as P. badioconfusa), Harmaja(4) (as Peziza), Van Vooren(2)
296
FAMILY  Sarcoscyphaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pithya cupressina  (Fr.) Fuckel^  Symb. Myc. 317. 1869
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Pithya cupressina produces deep orange discs on recently killed foliage of Juniperus, Cupressus, Thuja and Sequoia.^ RANGE ^It is found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, and CA, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  at first nearly spherical, becoming circular or elongated and irregular, flat or slightly concave; deep orange, (Seaver), 0.2-0.5cm wide, disc-shaped to low top-shaped; bright orange, (Hansen), about 0.1cm broad and high, flat; bright orange, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  lighter in color than upper surface; white mycelial threads attach fruitbody to substrate, (Seaver), whitish; tomentose (Hansen), paler than upper surface; smooth, (Dennis)
STEM  short if present^ (Seaver), very short if present (Hansen), with a short stout stem, downy at base, (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on recently killed foliage of various species of Juniperus, Cupressus, Thuja, and Sequoia^, (Seaver), on twigs and needles of Juniperus, late fall to spring, (Hansen), on dead leaves of Juniperus (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores reaching 10-12 um in diameter, round, granular within and usually containing one large oil-droplet, 1-seriate^; asci reaching length of 250 um and width of 15 um; paraphyses branched in lower part, only slightly enlarged in upper part, reaching width of 2-3 um at tip, (Seaver), spores 9-12 um in diameter, round, (Hansen), spores 9-10 um in diameter, round, smooth, 1-seriate; asci 8-spored, 210 x 12 um; paraphyses cylindric, very slightly enlarged up to 4 um at tip, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to Cupressus'
SIMILAR  Pithya vulgaris grows on Abies and Sequoia and reaches a larger size, up to 1.5cm.
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as cupressi), Dennis(1), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1), Desjardin(6)*
297
FAMILY  Sarcoscyphaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pithya vulgaris  Fuckel^  Symb. Myc. 317. 1869
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Pithya vulgaris produces bright orange discs on wet, dead, usually detached branch tips of Abies and Sequoia, often near snowbanks in spring.^ RANGE ^It is found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, and CA, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-1.5cm wide, at first somewhat cylindric, becoming cushion-shaped to disc-shaped, flat to slightly convex; bright orange^, (Castellano), reaching 1.2cm wide, at first nearly spherical, becoming nearly disc-shaped, becoming irregular in form when old, surface flat or convex; bright orange; margin free or touching substrate, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  tinged with color of upper surface at margin and paler and whiter towards base; bald near margin, "with white anchoring hyphae toward the base"^, (Castellano), whitish or yellowish white, surrounded at base by growth of white mycelium, (Seaver)
STEM  short if present^ (Castellano)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "on wet, dead, usually detached branch tips (with needles) and twigs of Abies and Sequoia, in montane areas often within several yards of snowbanks or within a few weeks of snowmelt", March to May, also in fall^, (Castellano), gregarious on foliage and bark on Abies, Sequoia, and Libocedrus, (Seaver), on branches and needles of Abies, more rarely Picea, (Hansen, for Europe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-14 um in diameter, round, colorless, without droplets^; asci to 300-325 um long, inamyloid, (Castellano), spores reaching 12-14 um in diameter, round, at first granular within, later with one large oil-drop, 1-seriate; asci reaching length of 300-325 um, and diameter of 15 um; paraphyses slightly enlarged in upper part, reaching width of 3-4 um at tip, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'common'
SIMILAR  Pithya cupressina occurs on foliage of Juniperus, Cupressus, Thuja, and Sequoia, (Seaver), and is 0.2-0.5cm in width.
SOURCES  Castellano(1)*, Seaver(1), Breitenbach(1)*, Larsen(1)
298
FAMILY  Sarcosomataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Plectania melastoma  (Sowerby ex Fr.) Fuckel  group^  Jahrb. Nass. Vereins Naturkunde 23-24: 324. 1870;  Bulgaria melastoma  (Sowerby) Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  jellylike black urn, black cup-fungus, orange-dusted cup
