NOTES  The Plectania melastoma group has three members, two of them being found in the Pacific Northwest: P. harnischii and P. melastoma. Many or most of the PNW collections are P. harnischii. Features include 1) a cup-shaped fruitbody up to 3cm wide, 2) an incurved cup margin, 3) a blackish inner surface, 4) a black and wrinkled outer surface with fine exterior orange granules especially near the margin, 5) tough flesh, 6) absent stem or a short narrowed base, 7) growth on the ground or on sticks and other debris of both hardwoods and conifers in spring, and 8) microscopic characters including elliptic or spindle-shaped spores and inamyloid asci.^ |The group is defined by among Plectania species by very minutely verrucose spores at 100X under oil immersion in cotton blue, and a tendency to have orange granules near the cup margin. The third member is Plectania zugazae, so far only known from Spain, Greece, and Cyprus, and differentiated morphologically by having mature spores greater than 12 um wide. P. zugazae may lack orange granules and when present they are often restricted to the margin. The main morphological difference between the two Pacific Northwest species is also spore width, 8-10(11) um for P. harnischii and 10-12(12.5) um for P. melastoma. |The main illustration here is Plectania harnischii TUR-A 209455, collected and photographed in Oregon and sequenced for the phylogenetic tree in Carbone(3). The other illustrations could be either species. |Of the collections in the phylogenetic tree from the Pacific Northwest including Montana, six were P. harnischii. Under "Studied and/or sequenced collections" two collections were cited from Washington, although other sequences from elsewhere in the USA are found in the phylogenetic tree. RANGE ^Plectania harnischii was sequenced from MT (holotype), WA, and OR, (Carbone(3)). Plectania melastoma was sequenced from USA including at least 2 from WA, Canada (one from uncultured Pezizomycotina in British Columbia, the other from uncultured fungus clone in Alberta), Europe (many countries), Mexico, Japan, and China. (Carbone). Prior to the description of Plectania harnischii, members of this group were identified as Plectania melastoma at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, CA, and CO, (Larsen), WA, MB, ME, United Kingdom, West Indies, Australia, and New Zealand, (Seaver), ME to BC, south to FL and Mexico, (Lincoff), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-2.5cm across and 1-3(4)cm high, at first nearly spherical, becoming cup-shaped, margin usually incurved for a long time but sometimes splitting in places; spore-bearing upper surface black or deep brownish black, smooth or sometimes with vein-like markings when dry, "often glistening when wet", (Arora), up to 3cm across, cup-shaped, black or nearly black, (Castellano), up "nearly spherical at first, at maturity expanding and becoming cup-shaped", up to 1.5(2)cm across and 0.8(1)cm high, hymenium blackish to grayish brown^, (Carbone), 1-2.5cm across and 1-3(4)cm high, at first nearly spherical, becoming cup-shaped, margin usually incurved for a long time but sometimes splitting in places; spore-bearing upper surface black or deep brownish black, smooth or sometimes with vein-like markings when dry, "often glistening when wet", (Arora), up to 3cm across, (Castellano)
FLESH  rubbery; grayish^, (Carbone), tough or cartilaginous, not brittle, "but with a semi-gelatinous inner layer when wet", (Arora), relatively thick-fleshed but interior not gelatinous, (Castellano)
UNDERSIDE  external surface more or less colored like the hymenium, "rough, with often indistinct, pale orange to orange-reddish granules, more frequent at the cup margin, but also present in the entire external surface"; margin "more or less even to occasionally serrate, with a concentration of pale orange to reddish-orange or brownish granules"^, (Carbone), black, but often with rusty-orange near margin from minute orange granules; "minutely hairy, strongly wrinkled or veined", (Arora), when young, may have orange to rust-colored granules around rim, (Castellano)
STEM  attached to the substrate by a black tomentum^, (Carbone), absent or a short stout narrowed base, colored like exterior and continuous with it, "the base often with wiry black mycelial threads that extend into the substrate", (Arora), when present 0.5-1cm long and wide, (Lincoff)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  Plectania harnischii has been found under conifers so far (all 6 collections), sometimes on decaying wood, from May to August; Plectania melastoma has been found under hardwoods or conifers or the decaying wood of either^, (Carbone), single or more often in small groups or clusters "on decaying sticks and other debris of both hardwoods and conifers", mainly fruiting in spring, (Arora), usually associated with decaying woody debris of relatively small diameter (often less than 7.5-10cm), fruiting in spring, (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20.2-24.8 x 8.1-11.2 um, elliptic, colorless, with tiny low and narrow warts (< 0.5 um) "visible only in lactic cotton blue mounts, lacking oil drops but filled with granular content, presenting thick walls and sometimes covered with a thin gelatinous sheath, especially while still inside the ascus"^; asci 8-spored, on average 330-370 x 10-13 um, cylindric, operculate, inamyloid, with walls up to 1 um thick and tapered, flexuous, "arising from a simple septum (no crozier)"; paraphyses not exceeding length of asci, 1.5-2.5 um wide, cylindric, "septate, sometimes anastomosing, branched at the base, with a simple or lobed apex, pale brownish at low magnification, presenting a gluey extracellular brown pigment in the upper part of dried specimens observed in water mounts"; hymenial hairs cylindric, "similar in length to paraphyses", 3-4 um wide, "with a simple apex, and a single septum at the very base, generally pale brown but sometimes also with a brownish gluey pigment in the upper part". subhymenium "arranged as a dense textura intricata" made of cylindric, frequently septate, brownish hyphae; medullary excipulum "arranged as a textura intricata" composed of cylindric, septate, yellowish hyphae 2.5-5(-6) um wide, "immersed in a gelatinous matrix, arranged more or less parallel with the hymenium near the ectal excipulum, showing inflated or globose elements"; ectal excipulum "of textura angularis" made up of elements up to 20 um wide, "very dark brown due to the thick walls presenting an incrusting pigment"; external hairs cylindric, septate, 5-7(-8) um wide, up to 600 um long, "straight, sometimes notched, smooth, originating in the deeper layers of the ectal excipulum, brown in color due to an epimembranaceous pigmentation", with walls thickened 0.5-0.8(-1) um; crystals "present among hairs and in the outer surface of the ectal excipulum, amber red or amber orange in color", (Carbone), spores 20-28 x 8-12 um, elliptic or spindle-shaped, smooth, with oil droplets when immature, (Arora, presumably including both P. harnischii and P. melastoma), spores 21-24 x 8-10 um, elliptic, smooth; asci long, narrow, with curving base, thick-walled, operculate, inamyloid; paraphyses "up to 4 um wide, branched, anastomosing around asci", (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  Plectania harnischii is "dedicated to our Canadian friend Johannes Harnisch, who first brought this species to our attention and who miraculously survived the attack of a Grizzly". 'Melastoma' means 'with a black mouth'.
SIMILAR  Plectania milleri has a stellate margin (with star-like points), and no orange granules, (Arora). P. milleri "differs from P. melastoma in its stellate margin, dark hyphae penetrating the medullary excipulum, and smooth tomentum hyphae. In P. melastoma the margin is entire or slightly split but is never stellate, the tomentum hyphae are encrusted with orange granules, and there are no dark hyphae in the medullary excipulum", (Paden). P. milleri has spores that are smooth even at 100X in oil immersion, measuring 22-31 x (8)9-11 um, with "dark hyphae running from the external layer into the medullary excipulum", (Carbone). |Pseudoplectania nigrella and Pseudoplectania melaena have round spores and no orange granules. |See also SIMILAR section of Donadinia nigrella.
SOURCES  Carbone(3)* (for Plectania harnischii), Castellano(2)*, Seaver(1) (as Bulgaria melastoma), Dennis(1), Arora(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1), Paden(1) (discussing Plectania milleri), Trudell(4), Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2)*, Marrone(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
299
FAMILY  Sarcosomataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Plectania milleri  Paden & Tylutki^  Mycologia 61(4): 683. 1969
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Plectania milleri produces a black cup with little or no stem, stellate margin, hairy exterior, and distinctive microscopic characters including black hyphae that penetrate the medullary excipulum.^ RANGE ^Plectania milleri is found at least in OR and ID, (Larsen). There are collections from BC at the University of British Columbia. There are collections from WA, OR, and CA at Oregon State University.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 1-4cm broad, 0.5-1cm high, sessile [without stem] or with short thick stem, cup-shaped when young, becoming nearly disc-shaped when old, gelatinous in consistency at maturity; spore-bearing upper surface dark brown to purple brown when fresh, drying black; margin stellate^, (Paden), 1-4cm wide, 0.5-2cm in profile, cup-shaped to broadly bowl-shaped or when old nearly disc-shaped; dark brown to purple-brown or nearly black, drying black, (Castellano), cup with a toothed edge (Trudell), margin like reversed scallops (I. Gibson, pers. comm.)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  black, hirsute, covered with appressed dark brown to black hyphae, lacking orange granules near margin^, (Castellano)
STEM  has at most a short stem^ (Trudell)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to crowded, saprophytic in plant debris, fruiting during May and June^, (Paden), associated with mixed conifers (Castellano)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 21-25.5 x 9-10.5 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, without droplets^; asci 8-spored, 380-425 x 12-15 um, long cylindric, suboperculate; paraphyses 1.5-3 um wide, thread-like, occasionally branched; hyphae on exterior "dark-walled, smooth, occasionally branched, sparingly septate"; "hypothecium of textura intricata with dark cell walls, appearing as a dark zone beneath the hymenium; medullary excipulum up to 1.2 mm thick, of hyaline textura intricata in a gelatinous matrix, penetrated by dark, branched, septate hyphae that originate in the ectal excipulum, ramify though the medullary excipulum, and terminate below the hypothecium; ectal excipulum 100-200 um thick, of textura angularis with dark cell walls, the outer cells giving rise to the tomentum hyphae", (Paden), spores (24.4)26.3-27.6(28.9) x 10.5-12.5 um (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  named after Orson K. Miller, who collected the type material
SIMILAR  "Plectania milleri differs from P. melastoma in its stellate margin, dark hyphae penetrating the medullary excipulum, and smooth tomentum hyphae. In P. melastoma the margin is entire or slightly split but is never stellate, the tomentum hyphae are encrusted with orange granules, and there are no dark hyphae in the medullary excipulum", (Paden). Pseudoplectania melaena differs in having round spores, and fruiting on dead twigs and branches of conifers in early spring. With immature specimens this species is very similar to round-spored Pseudoplectania nigrella, but at this stage spores may not be obtainable: with mature specimens the larger cup size and stellate margin of P. milleri and the marginal hairs of P. nigrella are sufficient to distinguish them, (Maguire). Donadinia nigrella has a long stem, a cup that lacks the toothed edge, an exterior that is less hairy, and spores that are slightly larger, (Trudell). Urnula padeniana and Pseudosarcosoma latahense are more gelatinized.
SOURCES  Paden(1), Castellano(1)*, Larsen(1), Trudell(4), Maguire(1), Siegel(2)*
300
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Plicaria carbonaria  Fuckel^  Jb. nassau. Ver. Naturk. 23-24: 326 (1870) [1869-70];  Plicaria anthracina  (Cooke) Boud;  Plicaria trachycarpa  var. muricata  Grelet
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a cup-shaped to flat fruitbody, the upper surface dark brown to blackish and dull, the exterior dark gray-brown and finely furfuraceous, 2) gregarious growth on burned ground, and 3) microscopic characters including round spores with spike-like warts.^ | The online Species Fungorum, accessed January 1, 2014, indicated that this taxon has Plicaria anthracina (Cooke) Boud. as a synonym, and Hansen, L.(1) referred in the Plicaria carbonaria description to B & K 33 which is Plicaria anthracina. RANGE ^Plicaria carbonaria is found at least in OR and AB (Larsen(1)). The PezWeb preliminary checklist of North American Pezizales (which emphasizes western species) does not include either name. A collection of Plicaria anthracina (Cooke) Boud by M. Denison from OR is deposited at Oregon State University. It is found at least in Denmark, Norway, and Finland, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-3cm across, cup-shaped, soon becoming expanded and flat; spore-bearing surface dark brown to blackish and dull^, (Breitenbach), spore-bearing surface black, somewhat granular or rough, (Hansen)
FLESH  "relatively thick and firm"^, (Breitenbach)
UNDERSIDE  margin and outer surface dark gray-brown, finely furfuraceous^, (Breitenbach), furfuraceous in upper part, colored as upper surface (black) or brownish, (Hansen)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on burned ground, September to May^, (Breitenbach), on burned ground, fruiting 10-200 weeks after fire, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11-14 um in diameter (not including ornamentation), round, with coarse, blunt, spike-like, colorless warts, spores pale brownish when mature, sometimes with one droplet^; asci 8-spored, to 270 x 20 um, I+; paraphyses cylindric, septate, tips thickened to 10 um and encrusted with brown, (Breitenbach), spores 11.5-13 um, with prominent, irregular 2 um high spines or warts (illustrated), (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to charcoal'
SIMILAR  Lamprospora trachycarpa has fine instead of spike-like warts on the spores (Breitenbach(1)). Plicaria endocarpoides has smooth spores.
SOURCES  Larsen(1), Breitenbach(1)* (as Plicaria anthracina), Hansen, L.(1), PezWeb(1) (does not include)
301
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Plicaria endocarpoides  (Berk.) Rifai^  Verhandelingen der Koninklijke Nederlandse Akademie van Wetenschappen, Afd. Natuurkunde, Tweede Reeks 57(3): 255. 1968;  Plicaria leiocarpa  (Curr.) Boud.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  smooth fairy cup
NOTES  Features include 1) a cup-shaped to flattened fruitbody with the upper surface dark brown to black, and the underside the same color or paler, 2) absent stem, 3) growth on burnt ground, and 4) microscopic characters including smooth spores.^ RANGE ^Plicaria endocarpoides is found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, CA, and MT, (Larsen), New Zealand and the United Kingdom, (Dennis), and Denmark, Finland, and Norway, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-7cm across, "at first cup-shaped but soon becoming flattened or undulating"; spore-bearing upper surface dark brown to black, smooth or rough, sometimes wrinkled^, (Arora), reaching 2-3cm across, at first spherical expanding to shallow cup-shaped, regular or cochleate and occasionally incised and Otidea-like, finally scutellate or somewhat disc-shaped; upper surface reddish brown to brownish black with slight olive tinge, smooth and even or undulating and lobed, (Seaver), up to 7cm across, cup-shaped then spreading flat, upper surface dark brown, (Tylutki), 2-8cm across, cup-shaped, upper surface dark grayish brown to brown, (Hansen)
FLESH  rather brittle; "usually paler or browner than the upper surface"^, (Arora), brittle (Tylutki), thin (Hansen), becoming yellowish when cut and exuding a yellow juice, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  same color as upper surface or paler; smooth or roughened^, (Arora), reddish brown to brownish black with slight olive tinge, a little lighter than upper surface; often strongly roughened, (Seaver), paler than upper surface, smooth, (Tylutki), grayish brown; bald or delicately furfuraceous in upper part, (Hansen)
STEM  absent or rudimentary^, (Arora)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora)
HABITAT  single to gregarious "on burnt ground, old campfire sites, etc.; usually but not always fruiting in the spring"^, (Arora), scattered to gregarious on burned soil in spring, (Tylutki), on burned ground, 20-130 weeks after fire, all through the year, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-10 um in diameter, "round, smooth, typically with several small oil droplets"^, (Arora), spores reaching 10-12 um in diameter, smooth, colorless or slightly yellowish, rather thick-walled, usually containing one large central oil droplet, 2-seriate becoming 1-seriate; asci reaching a length of 350 um and a diameter or 15-18 um, cylindric or subcylindric in upper part, tapering in lower part into stem-like base; paraphyses, slender, rather abruptly widened in upper part, densely granular within, reaching width of 7 um, showing a tendency to stick together in bundles, (Seaver), spores 8-10 um in diameter, round, smooth, with granular contents; asci 190-200 x 9.5-11 um, J+; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], slightly expanded at tip, up to 4 um wide and covered by an amorphous yellow-brown incrustation; medullary excipulum of textura globulosa and filamentous cells, up to 2 um wide, ectal excipulum of textura globulosa, the cells smaller than in medullary excipulum, (Tylutki), spores 8.5-9.5 um in diameter, smooth, (Hansen), spores 8-9 um in diameter, smooth, colorless or faintly brownish, containing numerous small oil droplets, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Lamprospora trachycarpa is a smaller (up to 2.5cm across) warted species with larger, roughened spores, (Arora). P. tachycarpa is smaller, has an upper surface that is blackish rather than brown, becomes disc-shaped earlier in development, and has finely warted spores, (Tylutki). See also SIMILAR section of Plicaria carbonaria.
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as Lamprospora leiocarpa), Kanouse(6) (as Lamprospora leiocarpa), Arora(1)*, Larsen(1), Tylutki(2), Hansen, L.(1), Dennis(1) (as Plicaria leiocarpa), Trudell(4)*, Desjardin(6)*
302
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Plicaria trachycarpa  (Curr.) Boud.^  Bull. Soc. mycol. France 1: 102. 1885;  Lamprospora trachycarpa  (Curr.) Seaver  Mycologia 6(1): 19. 1914
ENGLISH NAME(S)  rough fairy cup
NOTES  Features include 1) a small, cup-shaped to flattened fruitbody with the upper surface dark brown to blackish, and the underside scurfy and the same color or paler, 2) absent stem, 3) growth on burnt ground, and 4) microscopic characters including spores with 1 um high warts.^ | the online Species Fungorum, accessed October 21, 2018, gave the current name as Lamprospora trachycarpa (Curr.) Seaver, as did MycoBank, accessed the same day, but by November 3, 2021, both had changed to Plicaria trachycarpa. RANGE ^Lamprospora trachycarpa is found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, and CO, (Larsen), NH to CO, and the United Kingdom, (Seaver), United Kingdom (Dennis), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  from a few mm to 2cm, at first nearly spherical, expanding and becoming shallow cup-shaped with margin elevated and incurved, or more rarely scutellate and closely adhering to substrate, "regular in form or cochleate and becoming very irregular from mutual pressure"; spore-bearing upper surface dark reddish brown or slightly olivaceous, becoming black when old or dried, smooth or convoluted^, (Seaver), up to 2cm across, disc-shaped; upper surface blackish, rough with small warts, (Tylutki), upper surface brown becoming blackish, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  paler than upper surface; usually rough and scabrous, (Seaver), dark brown, scurfy, (Tylutki), dark gray; finely scurfy, (Dennis)
STEM  without stem^, (Tylutki)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  untested (Tylutki)
HABITAT  gregarious or densely crowded, often forming continuous masses over a space of several centimeters, on burned ground and charcoal beds^, (Seaver), scattered to gregarious on burned soil, spring and fall, (Tylutki), on burned ground and on sterilized soil, October to May, (Dennis), on burned ground, 10-130 weeks after fire, the whole year, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-11 um in diameter, with low, rounded, regular, 1 um high warts, (Hansen with illustration of spores), spores reaching 15-18 um in diameter, at first smooth, developing minute warts or short interrupted ridges, uniseriate, (Seaver)^, becoming pale yellow or smoky; asci reaching a length of 250-300 um and a width of 14-16(18) um, cylindric or subcylindric in upper part; paraphyses about 3-4 um wide in lower part, sparingly branched, widened at tips where they reach 8 um wide, sticking together, yellowish brown, (Seaver), spores 12-16 um in diameter, round, finely warted, colorless to pale brown; asci 320-350 x 17-20 um, J+; paraphyses "clavate, the tips up to 8.5 um wide, encrusted with a yellowish amorphous material"; medullary excipulum "a mix of hyphal cells and globose to polyhedral cells", ectal excipulum "of smaller globose to polyhedral cells", (Tylutki), spores 11-15 um in diameter, round, covered with minute colorless warts, colorless then becoming pale brown; asci about 200-250 x 14-18 um; paraphyses slender, slightly clavate and up to 8 um wide at tip, apical cell with brown oily contents and coated with a thin brown epithecial crust, (Dennis), spores 10-16 um, round, finely warted, (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Plicaria carbonaria, reported in Larsen(1) for OR, is macroscopically similar but spores are 11.5-13 um in diameter, with prominent, irregular, 2 um high spines or warts, (Hansen, with illustration of spores: note that the differentiation by spore size will not hold with spore measurements for P. trachycarpa given by Seaver, Tylutki, and Dennis). Plicaria endocarpoides has smooth spores, and usually a larger, thinner fruitbody, (Dennis). P. endocarpoides is larger with a dark brown rather than blackish upper surface, stays cup-shaped for longer, and has smooth spores, (Tylutki).
SOURCES  Seaver(1), Larsen(1) (as Plicaria trachycarpa), Tylutki(2) (as Plicaria trachycarpa), Hansen, L.(1) (as Plicaria trachycarpa), Dennis(1) (as Plicaria trachycarpa), Trudell(4) (as Plicaria trachycarpa)
303
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Podophacidium xanthomelum  (Pers.) Kavina^  Crypt. Cech. Exsicc. 217. 1936.;  Podophacidium terrestre  Niessl in Rab.;  Aleuria xanthomela  Gillet;  Humaria xanthomela  Sacc.;  Urnula terrestris  Sacc.;  Melachroia xanthomela  Boud.;  Melachroia terrestris  Boud.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a sulphur-yellow to gold yellow cup or disc with a black toothed margin, a dark brown scurfy exterior, absent stem, and growth that is gregarious or tightly clustered on the ground.^ RANGE ^Podophacidium xanthomelum is found from WA to NY, ON, PQ, and Europe. A collection by R. Outerbridge from BC is deposited at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.4cm wide, lens-shaped to irregularly disc-shaped, without stem; sulphur-yellow to gold-yellow, smooth; margin distinctly brown lobed and notched^, (Breitenbach), reaching 0.3-0.4cm wide, bright yellow with a slightly olive tint, surrounded with a dark brown or almost black laciniate border, (Seaver), up to 0.4cm wide, cup-shaped or obconic with small base, disc flat; sulphur-yellow; prominent black toothed margin (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  brown; scurfy, (Breitenbach), dark brownish or nearly black (Seaver)^, almost black with a minutely scurfy surface, (Dennis)
STEM  contracted at the base (Seaver) but without a stem (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or tightly clustered, on bare or needle-covered or moss-covered ground in coniferous forests, more rarely in hardwood forests^, (Breitenbach), thickly gregarious, occasionally a few closely crowded, on soil in coniferous woods, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-13 x 5.5-6 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 2 drops^; asci 8-spored, irregularly uniseriate, 115-148 x 8.5-11 um, amyloid; paraphyses "filiform, sparsely septate, tips forked and bent", (Breitenbach), spores 10-17 x 5-6 um, elliptic, the ends slightly narrowed, usually with 2 oil droplets; asci reaching 90-125 x 7-9 um, clavate; paraphyses very slender, branched, (Seaver), spores 13-15 x 5-6, elliptic-fusiform, with two large oil droplets; asci 150 x 10 um, cylindroclavate with long stalks, rather broad pore deep blue with iodine; paraphyses slender, about 2.5 um wide at tips, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means "yellow-black"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Seaver(2), Dennis(1)
304
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Polydesmia pruinosa  (Jerdon in Berk. & Broome) Boud.^  Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 1: 113. 1885;  == Helotium pruinosum  Jerdon in Berk. & Broome;  == Pseudohelotium jerdonii  Sacc.;  == Belonidium pruinosum  (Jerdon in Berk. & Broome) Rehm;  Belonium pruinosum  (Jerdon in Berk. & Broome) Hoehn.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, whitish cups that are pruinose on the disc and downy on the exterior, growth on pyrenomycetes, and microscopic characters including branching paraphyses.^ RANGE ^Polydesmia pruinosa is found in BC, WA, and also NY, PA, TN, Canary Islands, and Madeira; it is common and widespread in the United Kingdom and Europe on many different pyrenomycetes; it can be common in the Pacific Northwest, but is rarely collected, (Korf).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  rarely exceeding 0.05cm, whitish, spore-bearing upper surface distinctly pruinose under a hand-lens^, (Korf), 0.03-0.05cm, turbinate to cushion-like, spore-bearing surface white and farinose (from projecting paraphyses); margin white and finely felty, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white to dirty white; downy under a hand lens^, (Korf), white; finely felty, (Breitenbach)
STEM  with short stem or stem nearly absent^, (Korf), without a stem (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  often confluent, on different pyrenomycetes^, (Korf), single to cespitose or crowded together, growing on Sphaeriales on dead branches, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (13.9)14.6-20.5(22.0) x 3.7-5.1 um, "often slightly curved, shorter at the ascus apex, longer toward base of ascus", aseptate at first, soon 3-septate (evident in KOH-phloxine-glycerine or lactic acid - cotton blue, but many authors have failed to see septa)^; asci (78)80-110 x (8.0)8.8-10.2(11.0) um, with pore blue in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses filiform but apically deformed and propoloid, (Korf), spores 15-21 x 4-4.5 um, elliptic-fusiform, sometimes slightly bent, smooth, colorless, usually with 4 droplets, biseriate, sometimes with indistinct septum; asci 8-spored, 105-120 x 11 um, positive reaction in iodine; paraphyses filiform, cylindric, and strongly forked at tips, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pruinose' probably referring to appearance of spore-bearing surface
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Korf(4), Breitenbach(1)*
305
FAMILY  Porotheleaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Porotheleum fimbriatum  (Pers.) Fr.^  Obs. Mycol. 1: 272. 1818;  == Poria fimbriata  Pers.;  == Stromatoscypha fimbriata  (Pers.) Donk;  == Stigmatolemma fimbriatum  (Pers.) Pouzar
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Porotheleum fimbriatum forms a whitish tube layer with rhizomorphs at the margin, developing from papillae that rupture at the top; if a well-developed pore layer is examined under a lens it is usually possible to see areas near the margin where there are still isolated basidiomycete cups, (Reid 1964).^ RANGE ^Porotheleum fimbriatum is found in WA, ID, MB, NS, ON, AL, AR, AZ, CA, CO, CT, FL, GA, IL, IN, KY, LA, MA, MD, ME, MI, MN, MT, NH, SC, NC, NY, OH, PA, TN, TX, VA, VT, WI, WV, and circumglobally, (Gilbertson). It is also found in PE, PQ, MO, Brazil, Guadeloupe, Venezuela, Austria, Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Luxembourg, Portugal, Russia, Sweden, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom, (Cooke), and in NB, IA, NM, (Ginns).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  pores developing by the formation of "an apical pore in isolated papillae which later become crowded or confluent to form typical tube layer"; margin conspicuously rhizomorphic, often up to 2-3cm wide^, (Gilbertson & Ryvarden), receptacles at first papillate, becoming punctate, superficial to sunken, 0.03-0.1cm across, 0.03-0.1cm high, opening into crowded, often confluent cups, new papillae may be inserted among older cup; margin white, fimbriate [fringed] or torn, (Cooke), layer easily separable from wood; white margin up to 1cm and either byssoid or fringed with conspicuous rhizomorphic strands, (Reid), 3-5 per mm in mature specimens, circular to angular, thick-walled; tube layer up to 0.05cm thick, distinct from flesh, ivory to pale tan, (Gilbertson & Ryvarden), toward center 4-5 cups per mm, toward the margin 2-3 cups per mm, cream toward center, fading to "Naples yellow", tan, brown, or resinous brown, (Cooke), white or cream when fresh, more deeply colored when dried, (Reid)
FLESH  up to 0.1cm thick, soft-fibrous, not zoned; white to cream^, (Gilbertson & Ryvarden), up to 0.05cm thick (Cooke)
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  mild^ (Gilbertson & Ryvarden)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  annual, on dead conifers and hardwoods, associated with a spongy white rot^, (Gilbertson & Ryvarden), on dead wood of hardwood and coniferous trees and rarely even on bare soil, (Reid)
SPORE DEPOSIT  white^ (Reid)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4.5-5 x 2-3 um, short-cylindric to elliptic, smooth, inamyloid, colorless^; basidia 4-spored, 20-30 x 5-6 um, cylindric to narrowly clavate, with basal clamp connection; cystidia absent; hyphae dimitic, generative hyphae of subiculum 2.5-3.5 um wide, colorless in KOH, "thin-walled, rarely branched, with clamps", skeletal hyphae of subiculum 1.5-2.5 um wide, "thick-walled, nonseptate, rarely branched"; hyphae of trama similar, (Gilbertson & Ryvarden), spores 3-5(6) x 1.5-3.5 um, elliptic, flattened on one side, smooth, colorless, apiculate; basidia 4-spored, 17-19 x 4.5-5.5 um, clamp connection at base; cystidia not found; hymenium 20-25 um thick; subiculum of tightly packed, colorless, "septate hyphae, rarely incrusted, arranged parallel to irregularly interwoven"; clamp connections on hyphae of subhymenial tissue, not seen on hyphae of subiculum, (Cooke), spores 4-5.2 x 2.2-3.2 um from spore deposit, elliptic, colorless, thin-walled, with oil droplet; generative hyphae bear clamp connections, these hyphae may be difficult to demonstrate but most easily seen near cups and near growing margins, (Reid)
NAME ORIGIN  means "fringed, with a border of hairs"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Gilbertson(1) (as Stromatoscypha), Cooke(1) (as Stromatoscypha), Reid(4) (as Stromatoscypha fimbriata), Ginns(5)
306
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudaleuria quinaultiana  Lusk^  Mycotaxon 30: 419. 1987
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) more or less disc-shaped, red-orange fruiting bodies that are firm fleshy to rubbery, the underside lighter than or colored like the upper surface, with flexuous [wavy] hairs forming a felty layer, 2) little or no stem, 3) growth on wood or soil in spring, and 4) microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Lusk(1). RANGE ^Pseudaleuria quinaultiana is found in WA (Lusk), and OR (Castellano).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.7-3.5cm wide, 0.05-0.15cm at least thick, disc-shaped to slightly concave or repand [having a waved edge that is turned back], larger specimens often with a central depression, often margin enrolled; bright reddish orange, drying to a dull reddish brown
FLESH  firm fleshy to rubbery, becoming corky when dry
UNDERSIDE  lighter than or colored as upper surface, with long flexuous [wavy] hyphoid [cobwebby] hairs forming a felty layer
STEM  sessile to substipitate, centrally attached
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered or in clusters, near the butt end of fallen conifers, on wood or soil, in spring^, (Lusk), primarily in old growth forest with Picea sitchensis (Sitka Spruce), Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock), and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir), (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15.5-19.5 x 7.5-10.5 um, elliptic, smooth, without droplets, with one nucleus^; asci 8-spored, operculate, cylindric, 200-300 x 8.0-12.5 um, narrowing to base; paraphyses slender, 240-320 x 2.0-3.5 um, slightly to greatly and abruptly enlarged in upper part, apices 4.5-11.5 x 4.5-9.5 um, straight, containing carotenoid granules, septate, rarely branching, branching in top half; the single most distinctive feature of the species is the hairs which are hyphoid, thin-walled, colorless when fresh, arise from external thick-walled cells, non-fasciculate, long (to at least 1000 um) and interwoven, and form an apparent layer external to the ectal excipulum, (Lusk), spores 15.5-21.5 x 7.5-10.5 um, elliptic, smooth, (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to Lake Quinault, Washington, where type was collected
SIMILAR  Sarcoscypha coccinea is similar but Pseudaleuria quinaultiana is distinguished by the lack of a stem, the typically non-cup-shaped form, and more orange color. Aleuria aurantia has thinner more brittle flesh, is orange rather than red-orange, tends to be cup-shaped rather than saucer-shaped, occurs in large groups, fruits in fall, and has different spores.
SOURCES  Lusk(1), Castellano(1)*, Trudell(4)*
307
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudociboria umbrina  Kanouse^  Mycologia 36: 460. 1944;  Helotium umbrinum  (Kanouse) Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a tiny, dark brown cup tapering to a short stem, 2) growth on decaying leaves of alder without stroma, 3) both colored and colorless paraphyses, and 4) the mounting solution becoming bright pinkish red in KOH.^ RANGE ^Pseudociboria umbrina is found from NY to WA, (Seaver). A collection was examined from WA (Schumacher).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.03-0.1cm, disc-shaped, arising from blackened stromatized areas of the leaf surface, gradually tapering to short stem; dark brown, (Schumacher); 0.075-0.1cm, dark brown to black-brown, "disc plane remaining expanded on drying"; margin minutely crenulate [scalloped], (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  externally longitudinally striate, dark brown to brownish black, (Seaver)
STEM  0.05-0.15cm x 0.05cm, short, (Schumacher), 0.1cm long, 0.05cm wide, expanding rather abruptly into fruiting body; dark brown to black-brown; externally longitudinally striate, (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  arising from leaf-blades or veins, on decaying leaves of alder, without stroma, (Kanouse, repeated by Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 6-9 x 3.3-4.2 um, elliptic, with slightly pointed ends, colorless, 1-celled, with 2 more or less equal internal polar droplets^; asci 8-spored, 55-90 x 6-7 um, subcylindric, uniseriate to partly biseriate; two types of paraphyses: ordinary paraphyses filiform, about 1 um wide, straight, septate, partly branched from midway up, tips inflated to 1.5-2 um, in between there are numerous dark brown, broad and cylindric non-septate paraphyses filled with dark brown matter, broken into short bead-like sections, along the entire length of the filaments, (Schumacher), spores 5-7 x 3.5-4 um, elliptic to subovoid, typically obliquely uniseriate, colorless, 1-celled; asci 8-spored, 55-70 x 6-7 um, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses of 2 types, 1) narrow 1 um in diameter and colorless, not septate, and 2) stout 4-4.5 um in diameter and "filled completely with dark-brown coloring matter", not septate, the apices rounded; fruiting body not staining blue with iodine; dark brown cell contents soluble in KOH, solution becomes stained quickly a bright pinkish red, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  probably referring to brown color of fruitbody
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(2), Seaver(2), Schumacher(1)
308
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudombrophila cervaria  (W. Phillips) Brumm.^  A World-Monograph of the Genus Pseudombrophila (Pezizales, Ascomycotina), Libri Botanici 14 (Eching bei Munchen): 27. 1995;  Fimaria cervaria  (W. Phillips) Brumm.;  Ascophanus cervarius  (W. Phillips) Boud.;  Humaria cervaria  (W. Phillips) Sacc.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny brown cups on deer dung, the undersides brown and smooth with a network of brown hyphae, stem absent or short, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Pseudombrophila cervaria is found in WA (Kanouse), NY and the United Kingdom, (Brummelen(2)), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen, L.). Oluna Ceska has reported Pseudombrophila cervaria (W. Phillips) Brumm. from Vancouver Island in BC on deer dung.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.15-0.3cm across, about 0.1cm high, at first nearly spherical then more or less scutellate; chestnut brown or purplish brown; margin "thin, crenulate or fimbriate"^, (Brummelen), 0.15-0.3cm across, cup-shaped; chestnut brown or purplish brown, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  chestnut brown or purplish brown, smooth and covered with a network of brown hyphae^, (Brummelen), "with very pale, adnate hairs", (Hansen, L.)
STEM  without a stem or with a short, stem-like base, (Brummelen), sessile or stem 0.1cm long; no sclerotium, (Hansen, L.)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious, superficial, on dung of deer^, (Brummelen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14.4-17.0 x 7.0-8.5 um, elliptic or oblong-elliptic, smooth, at first colorless, often finally with pale yellowish brown contents, without oil droplets or granules when mature, uniseriate in ascus^; asci 8-spored, 150-175 x 10-12.5 um, cylindric with very short stalk, wall not blue with Melzer's reagent; paraphyses about 2 um thick, filiform, not or only very slightly enlarged, 2-3 um thick at tip, colorless "but near the tip often with pale brownish walls, with intercellular, amorphous, purplish-brown pigment covering the tips", septate, branched especially in the upper parts; hymenium about 150 um thick, hypothecium about 25 um thick, of closely compacted cells 4-10 x 3-7 um; flesh up to 900 um thick in central part, of small isodiametric cells 7-14 um in diameter and of large oblong cells 19-53 x 5-12 um, colorless; excipulum of subglobular, angular or slightly elongated cells 8-20 um in diameter (textura angularis or textura globulosa), near the base up to 75 um thick, (Brummelen), spores 14.5-18.5 x 7-9.5 um, (Hansen, L.), spores 15-17 x 7-9 um, colorless; paraphyses filiform, not enlarged at tips, colorless, often branched in upper part; asci abruptly attenuated at apices, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to deer'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Pseudombrophila deerrata and Pseudombrophila hepatica.
SOURCES  Brummelen(2) (as Fimaria cervaria), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6) (as Ascophanus cervarius)
309
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudombrophila deerrata  (P. Karst.) Seaver^  North American Cup-fungi, (Operculates): 141. 1928;  Peziza deerrata  P. Karst.;  Humaria deerrata  (P. Karst.) Sacc.;  Ascophanus deerratus  (P. Karst.) Boud.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include disc-shaped or shallow cup-shaped fruitbody up to 1cm across, colored gray-violet to reddish on upper surface, similarly colored on lower surface but dotted with darker tufts of fine hairs that appear scale-like, short stem, growth on rotting remains of plants, and microscopic characters.^ | This species has been spelled Pseudombrophila deerata (by Breitenbach(1) and Dennis(1) for instance), but not by Hansen, L.(1), not by the online Species Fungorum, accessed December 16, 2015, and not by Saccardo in Syll. fung. 8: 140. 1889. The modern consensus seems to be that 'deerata' is a misspelling. Seaver(1) had 'deerrata' in the body of the text and 'deerata' in the index. Hansen, L.(1) lists it as a synonym of Pseudombrophila merdaria (Fr.) Brumm. RANGE ^The distribution of P. deerrata includes ND and also Europe including Finland, (Seaver(1)), Switzerland (Breitenbach(1)), and the United Kingdom (Dennis(1)). Harold Larsen has collected and photographed it (176A) in WA (pers. comm.).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-1cm across, lens-shaped to spherical-conic when young, then convex, "finally flat and saucer-shaped, regularly rounded, undulating when old", margin "somewhat bent over when old"; spore-bearing upper surface dark gray-violet, "paling to light violet to reddish when older, always (even when dry) with a weak rose-purplish tint"^, (Breitenbach), reaching 0.3-0.4cm across, at first closed and nearly spherical, "opening and becoming discoid or shallow cup-shaped"; spore-bearing (upper) surface "pale-reddish or reddish-purple", (Seaver), up to 1cm across, convex, margin often undulating, reflexed; disc light gray with pink or purplish tints, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  colored the same as upper surface but "dotted with somewhat darker scales"^, (Breitenbach), dark brownish; "subtomentose or squamulose", (Seaver), colored as upper surface but dotted with dark brown tufts of downy hairs, (Dennis)
STEM  "base ending in a short stalk and, especially when young, covered with a dense white felty subiculum"^, (Breitenbach), short-stemmed (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on rotting remains of plants according to literature, April-July (October)^, (Breitenbach, whose collection was on needles and twigs covered with bird droppings), on dead herbaceous stems, especially on Brassicaceae, (Seaver), on plant debris, including decaying bracken, flax, rotting stems of Heracleum, Cirsium, Lupinus, and Brassica and on rotting swedes, May to November, (Dennis), Pseudombrophila habitat given as dung or manured soil, a habitat also suggested by 'merdaria', (Hansen, L.), collection on soil, dead grass & weeds and dead apple twigs in the weed control strip between apple trees, (H. Larsen, pers. comm.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (11)13-15 x (6)7-8 um, elliptic, colorless, "appearing smooth on superficial examination but revealing an obliquely transverse sinuous structure under oil immersion when stained with cotton blue"^; asci 8-spored, 150-160 x 10-11 um, iodine negative; paraphyses uniformly about 2 um thick, filiform and branched, septate, some with dark granular contents; excipulum with hair-like tufted hyphal outgrowths to 100 um long; subiculum hyphae 2-3 um wide, colorless, "sometimes branched and with clavate thickenings at the ends, septate", (Breitenbach), spores 12-14 x 8-9 um, elliptic, colorless or slightly yellowish, "1-seriate, parallel with the ascus and apparently adhering together but easily detached, occasionally containing one central oil-drop"; asci 8-spored; paraphyses slender, rather strongly enlarged in distal part, where they reach a diameter of 4 um, (Seaver), spores 12-16 x 8-9 um, elliptic, smooth, without oil droplets; asci up to 150-14 um [sic]; paraphyses "slender, colourless, scarcely thickened above"; hairs 80-120 x 4-5 um, cylindric, thin-walled, obtuse, 1-septate or 2 septate, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Pseudombrophila cervaria (W. Phillips) Brumm. == Fimaria cervaria (W. Phillips) Brumm. == Ascophanus cervarius (W. Phillips) Boud., reported from WA by Kanouse on dung, has smaller spores 14.5-18.5 x 7-9.5 um, cup 0.15-0.3cm across, upper surface chestnut brown or purplish brown, underside with very pale, adnate hairs, without a stem or with stem 0.1cm high, asci abruptly attenuated at top, negative reaction to iodine, paraphyses filiform, not enlarged at tips, colorless, often branched in upper part, (Hansen combined with Kanouse), Oluna Ceska has reported Pseudombrophila cervaria (W. Phillips) Brumm. from Vancouver Island in BC on deer dung
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Seaver(1), Hansen, L.(1), Dennis(1)
310
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudombrophila hepatica  (Batsch ex Fr.) Brumm.^  Libri Bot. 14:37. 1995;  Fimaria hepatica  (Batsch ex Fr.) Brumm.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute fruitbody that is reddish brown or pale purplish brown on the upper surface, darker on the exterior and covered with pale brownish to almost colorless hairs, growth on dung or manured soil, and spores 22-35 x 10-13 um.^ RANGE ^Pseudombrophila hepatica is found in OR and CO (Larsen, though occurrence not confirmed by either author), and Denmark (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.3cm across, spore-bearing upper surface reddish brown or pale purplish brown^, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  darker than upper surface; covered with pale brownish to almost colorless hairs^, (Hansen)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  members of this genus fruit on dung or on manured soil^ (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 22-35 x 10-13 um^, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to the liver'
SIMILAR  Pseudombrophila cervaria has been reported from WA by Kanouse on dung: it has 1) smaller spores 14.5-18.5 x 7-9.5 um, 2) a cup 0.15-0.3cm across, 3) upper surface chestnut brown or purplish brown, 4) underside with very pale, adnate hairs, 5) absent stem or stem 0.1cm high, 6) asci abruptly attenuated at top, 7) negative reaction to iodine, and 8) paraphyses filiform, not enlarged at tips, colorless, often branched in upper part, (Hansen combined with Kanouse). Oluna Ceska has reported Pseudombrophila cervaria from Vancouver Island in BC on deer dung. 
SOURCES  Larsen(1) (as Fimaria), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6) (discussing Pseudombrophila cervaria)
311
FAMILY  Drepanopezizaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudopeziza medicaginis  (Lib.) Sacc.^  Malpighia 1: 455. 1887;  Phacidium medicaginis  Lib.  
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, ochraceous brown disc-shaped fruitbodies seated on nearly round yellowish spots on living and dying leaves of Medicago, Trigonella, and Melilotus, and microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Seaver(2). Schuepp treats this as a forma specialis of P. trifolii (Dennis(1)). RANGE ^Pseudopeziza medicaginis is found throughout North America or wherever the hosts Medicago, Trigonella and Melilotus are grown. There are collections from BC, OR, and CO deposited at University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.1cm across, expanded and subdiscoid [nearly disc-shaped], upper surface ochraceous brown
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  seated on yellowish suborbicular [nearly round] spots, "opening with a laciniate aperture through the epidermis"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on living or dying leaves of species of Medicago (medick), Trigonella and Melilotus (sweet clover)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-11 x 4-6 um, ovoid, colorless, simple, biseriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 75-80 um and a width of 10 um, subcylindric, narrowed in upper part, with stem; paraphyses filiform-clavate
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Medicago'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Dennis(1)
312
FAMILY  Drepanopezizaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudopeziza trifolii  (Biv.) Fuckel^  Symb. Myc. 290. 1869
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, saucer-shaped to disc-shaped fruitbodies breaking out of brown spots on clover leaves, with olive-brown to yellowish-gray upper surface and brown exterior, clinging closely to the leaf, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Pseudopeziza trifolii is found probably throughout North America where clover grows, and also Europe including Switzerland and the United Kingdom. There are collections from BC deposited at the Pacific Forestry Centre and the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05cm, developing out of dark spots under the surface of the leaf, breaking them open, and then delicately bordered by remains of epidermis; disc-shaped to cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface olive-brownish^, (Breitenbach), about 0.05cm across, erumpent from small dead spots of leaf tissue, saucer-shaped, closely appressed to leaf; disc flat, yellowish-gray, smooth, (Dennis), 0.03-0.05cm wide, submerged, becoming erumpent, at first closed, opening and becoming nearly flat; brownish, waxy, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  brown^ (Dennis)
STEM  "embedded in the epidermis of the upper side of the leaf", "clinging closely to the tissue of the leaf"^, (Breitenbach), on brown spots 0.1-0.3cm across (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to cespitose, on upper sides of green leaves of Trifolium spp. (clover), in fall^, (Breitenbach), on living leaves of Trifolium spp., May to November, (Dennis), gregarious to cespitose, on living leaves of species of Trifolium (clover), (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-14(16) x 4.5-5 um, irregularly oval, smooth, colorless, with 2 droplets, biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 70 x 13 um, negative reaction to iodine; paraphyses cylindric, septate, sometimes forked, with slight clavate widenings to 4 um toward tips, (Breitenbach), spores 10-12 x 5-5.5 um, slightly ovoid, non-septate, with a small oil-drop near each end, irregularly biseriate; asci 8-spored, up to 80 x 14 um, cylindric-clavate, pore not turning blue with iodine; paraphyses about 3-4 um wide at tip; no true cellular excipulum flanking the hymenium, (Dennis), spores 10-15 x 5-7 um, elliptic or oval, simple, usually with one oil drop; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 60-80 um and a width of 10-14 um, clavate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], widened in upper part, 3-4 um wide, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Trifolium (clover)', referring to its host
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Dennis(1), Breitenbach(1)*
313
FAMILY  Sarcoscyphaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudopithyella minuscula  (Boud. & Torrend) Seaver^  North American Cup-Fungi (Operculates). p153. 1928;  Sarcoscypha minuscula  Boud. & Torrend
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute scarlet cups that are whitish and tomentose on the outside, growing on decaying foliage of Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), and microscopic characters including the ascus with a thickened ring at the apex that gives it a "shouldered" appearance.^ RANGE ^Pseudopithyella minuscula is found at least in OR and CA (Larsen(1)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  not exceeding 0.1-0.2cm in diameter, at first nearly spherical, becoming concave to flat, scarlet, becoming paler when dry^, (Seaver), 0.1-0.3cm (Larsen(2))
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  whitish and more or less tomentose^ (Seaver)
STEM  usually with a stem, "slender and very variable in length, when springing from the under side of the substratum, short or almost wanting, seldom exceeding 1 mm. in length, gradually expanding above into the apothecium"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on decaying foliage of cedar (Seaver for Bermuda and Portugal), on foliage of Libocedrus decurrens (Incense-cedar), (Larsen(2))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-17 x 10-11 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, containing 2 oil droplets^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 600 um and a width of 12-15 um, "marked by two little ear-like protuberances where the thickened ring passes around near the apex, the point of dehiscence about 3 um inside of the ring; operculum circular, 3-4 um in diameter"; paraphyses filiform, scarcely enlarged near tip, branched, reaching 2 um wide near tip, (Seaver), ascus with a thickened ring at the apex that gives it a "shouldered" appearance, (Larsen(2))
NAME ORIGIN  means 'very small'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(1), Larsen(2), Larsen(1)
314
FAMILY  Sarcosomataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudoplectania melaena  (Fr. ) Sacc.^  Syll. fung., 8: 165. 1889;  Pseudoplectania vogesiaca  (Pers.) Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Pseudoplectania melaena is a dark brown to blackish cup sparingly clothed with straight or slightly flexuous [wavy] hairs, with a stem of variable length up to 3cm, growing on wood under conifers, and with microscopic characters including smooth, round spores and paraphyses that are hooked or coiled at the tips.^ | This taxon has also been known in North America as Pseudoplectania vogesiaca (Pers.) Seaver, but Van Vooren(1) make a strong case for the name we are using. Carbone(1) gives molecular evidence for the separation of Pseudoplectania (including Pseudoplectania melaena) from Plectania. The online Species Fungorum and MycoBank, accessed March 18, 2018, gave Pseudoplectania melaena as a synonym of Plectania melaena (Fr.) Paden, in Korf, Mycotaxon 14(1): 1 (1982), and Pseudoplectania vogesiaca is listed separately, but it is not clear why the two are separately listed or why Pseudoplectania melaena has reverted to Plectania. RANGE ^Pseudoplectania melaena is found at least in BC, WA, OR, and ID, (Larsen), VT to WA, and Europe, (Seaver), Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Sweden (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  2-4(8)cm, cup-shaped to saucer-shaped, margin remaining incurved for a long time; spore-bearing upper surface dark olive-brown to black-brown^, (Breitenbach), reaching 2-3cm across and 1-2cm deep, cup-shaped or occasionally nearly flat, margin often wavy; upper surface concave or nearly flat, dark olivaceous brown, (Seaver), cup usually rather shallow, medium to deep olivaceous brown at first, when old the entire cup becomes black, (Trudell), yellow-brown to olive-brown when young but blackens when old (Arora)
FLESH  subcartilaginous [somewhat cartilaginous]^, (Seaver)
UNDERSIDE  darker than upper surface to black and slightly felty with black appressed hairs^, (Breitenbach), black or blackish; very sparingly tomentose, becoming strongly wrinkled when dry, (Seaver)
STEM  "resting on the wood with a +/- long stalk"^, (Breitenbach), "stem very variable in length but occasionally reaching 2-3cm" and about 0.3cm wide, black, attached at base by dense mass of coarse, dark brown hairs, (Seaver), usually present but never as long as in Donadinia nigrella, (Trudell)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious on "rotting trunks and branches of Abies alba (silver fir) which lie on the ground, also on buried wood", March to May^, (Breitenbach), gregarious or scattered, on decaying wood in coniferous woods, especially among Sphagnum, (Seaver), "on twigs and other woody debris, usually of conifers", late winter or early spring, (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-12 um in diameter, round, smooth, colorless, with 1 large droplet^; asci 8-spored, 320 x 13 um, negative reaction to iodine; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], "with few septa, tips simple to spirally curved and some of them forked", up to 3 um wide, with dark contents; hairs up to 120 x 7 um, cylindric, black-brown, "smooth, with few septa, thin-walled, tips blunt, some cells widened and bulging, base with bristle-like outgrowths", (Breitenbach), spores reaching 12-14 um in diameter, round, smooth, becoming very pale brown, containing 1 large oil droplet, uniseriate; asci reaching a length of 200-275 um and a width of 16-18 um, cylindric in upper part, with very long stem-like base; paraphyses slender, slightly widened in upper part and coiled or hooked at tips, reaching width of 3-4 um; tomentum "consisting of short, brown, flexuous [wavy], sparingly septate hairs", (Seaver), spores 10-17 um, round, smooth, with one large oil droplet, (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Pseudoplectania nigrella has no stem, and paraphyses do not have spirally curved ends, (Breitenbach). P. nigrella has a short stem or no stem, and is densely clothed with coiled hairs, whereas P. melaena has a long stem, and is sparingly clothed with straight or slightly flexuous [wavy] hairs, (Seaver). P. nigrella also averages smaller. Plectania species have elliptic spores: Plectania melastoma and Plectania milleri have no distinct stem, Plectania melastoma usually has orange granules on the margin, and Donadinia nigrella always has distinct stem that is always longer than that of Pseudoplectania melaena and usually fruits near melting snowbanks.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Pseudoplectania vogesiaca), Seaver(1) (as Pseudoplectania vogesiaca), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1), Trudell(4)* (as Pseudoplectania vogesiaca), Arora(1), Van Vooren(1), Carbone(1), Beug(3)* (as Pseudoplectania vogesiaca), Marrone(1)*
315
FAMILY  Sarcosomataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudoplectania nigrella  (Pers. ex Fr.) Fuckel^  Symb. Myc. 324. 1869;  Plectania nigrella  (Pers.) P. Karst.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  hairy black cup
NOTES  Features include 1) a small, blackish cup densely clothed with coiled hairs that give the exterior a tomentose appearance, 2) absent (or sometimes short) stem, 3) growth on wood or ground under conifers, and 4) microscopic characters including smooth, round spores and forked paraphyses that are not thickened or coiled at the tips.^ | This is not to be confused with Donadinia nigrella (= Plectania nannfeldtii) which is based on a different type collection. RANGE ^Pseudoplectania nigrella is found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, CA, CO, UT, and WY, (Larsen), NJ to MB, WI, AL, Jamaica, Europe, and Australia, (Seaver), Switzerland (Breitenbach), United Kingdom (Dennis), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1.5-2.5(3)cm, irregularly cup-shaped to flat and saucer-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface brownish black, smooth, shiny; margin somewhat darker and felty with black appressed hairs^, (Breitenbach), reaching 0.5-1.5cm, at first closed and nearly spherical, expanding to shallow cup-shaped or disc-shaped, "margin often wavy and slightly incurved"; upper surface concave or nearly flat, brownish black, smooth, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  somewhat darker than upper surface and felty with black appressed hairs^, (Breitenbach), black or blackish, clothed with fine hairs that are coiled and twisted, giving a woolly appearance, (Seaver)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach), sessile or substipitate (short-stipitate), (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, gregarious, or clustered, "in cushion-like low mosses on very rotten conifer stumps, on path embankments on bare sandy ground", according to the literature also on ground covered with needle litter, April to May^, (Breitenbach), "gregarious or occasionally closely crowded", on "decaying wood in coniferous woods, especially among Sphagnum", (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-12(13) um in diameter, round, smooth, colorless, sometimes with 1 large droplet^; asci 8-spored, 250-300 x 11-13 um, negative reaction to iodine; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], "multiply septate, tips straight and not clavate, but forked with lateral outgrowths"; hairs cylindric, dark brown, "smooth, with few septa, thin-walled, with few branches, woven together and felt-like", (Breitenbach), spores reaching 12-14 um in diameter, round, smooth, usually containing one large oil droplet and several smaller ones; asci reaching a length of 300-325 um and a width of 15 um, cylindric or subcylindric with long stem-like base; paraphyses enlarged at tips and filled with brown coloring matter, reaching 4 um wide; hairs reaching 4-6 um and of nearly uniform width throughout their length, very long but usually coiled and twisted, pale brown, sparingly septate, (Seaver), spores 10-12 um in diameter, round, smooth, filled with numerous small oil droplets, uniseriate; asci up to 350 x 16 um; paraphyses slender, forked, not widened at tip, brown, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'little and black'
SIMILAR  Pseudoplectania melaena has a long stem, and is sparingly clothed with straight or slightly flexuous [wavy] hairs, whereas P. nigrella has a short stem or no stem, and is densely clothed with coiled hairs, (Seaver). P. melaena also averages larger. Plectania species have elliptic spores: Plectania melastoma usually has orange granules on the margin and Donadinia nigrella has a distinct stem and usually fruits near melting snowbanks. See also SIMILAR section of Plectania milleri.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1), Lincoff(2)*, Seaver(1), Larsen(1), Desjardin(6)*, Marrone(1)*
316
FAMILY  Chorioactidaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pseudosarcosoma latahense  (Paden & Tylutki) M. Carbone, Agnello & P. Alvarado^  Ascomycete.org 5(1): 6. 2013;  Sarcosoma latahense  Paden & Tylutki  Mycologia 61(4): 686. 1969
ENGLISH NAME(S)  black rubber cup
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly category. Features include 1) the shape that is top-shaped becoming cup-shaped to disc-shaped, 2) dark purple to black spore-bearing upper surface, 3) gelatinous texture at least when young, 4) exterior that is gray and matted-hairy, and 5) microscopic characters including large spores without droplets.^ | Although this species was described as Sarcosoma latahensis (using a feminine form for the adjective), "soma" is a neuter Greek noun and should use the neuter form of the adjective, "latahense"; RANGE ^Pseudosarcosoma latahense is found at least in WA, OR, and ID, (Larsen), and BC (Carbone). A collection from BC determined by B. Callan was deposited at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 7.5cm but often smaller, at first top-shaped and highly gelatinous, becoming disc-shaped, often losing much of the gelatinous texture but some fruitbodies remaining gelatinous; spore-bearing upper surface at first deep purple, becoming black^, (Paden), "several mm thick when young but relatively plane, becoming discoid with age and thinner", (Castellano), up to about 4cm across (Trudell)
FLESH  gelatinous at first becoming tough^ (Lincoff), gelatin diminishing greatly as fruitbodies age (Trudell)
UNDERSIDE  grayish to black, clothed with extensive tomentum [matted hairs]^, (Paden)
STEM  substipitate (with somewhat of a stem)^, (Paden)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious, saprophytic on decaying wood, litter, and bare soil, April, May, and June, often near or beneath melting snow^, (Paden)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 24-38 x 9-12 um, elliptic, with blunt to rounded ends, smooth, colorless, containing a few small oil drops when young but none at maturity^; asci 8-spored, 380-470 x 10-14 um, cylindric, narrowing basally, the bases sometimes forked, asci suboperculate; paraphyses 3.2-5.2 um broad at tip, 2.8-3.5 um broad in lower part, filiform [thread-like] to slightly clavate, "branched, anastomosing, closely septate", "often bent or irregularly lobed, containing a homogeneous, olive-brown pigment, embedded in an amorphous brownish material"; hypothecium of textura intricata, the hyphae 2.8-5.2 um wide, medullary excipulum of textura intricata, the hyphae 5-10 um wide, colorless, ectal excipulum of textura angularis, the inner cells colorless, the outer cells with dark brown walls, usually isodiametric and up to 20 um wide, at times up to 50 x 35 um and oriented with long axes perpendicular to the exterior; hyphae of tomentum up to 400 um long, 4-8.5 um wide, slightly tapered, colorless to olive brown, (if pigmented paler in distal end), branched, septate, smooth except for occasional dark granules near basal end, at times with globoid swellings, (Paden), paraphyses with irregular apices, sometimes curved, slender, much branched, (Castellano), spores 24-37 x 9-12 um (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Latah County', where type was collected
SIMILAR  Urnula padeniana has a usually larger fruitbody, spores containing oil droplets, and dark, encrusted tomentum hyphae, (Paden). U. padeniana has a well-developed and persistent gelatinous interior, has spores 23-34 x 10-14 um, has heavily pigmented hairs on the exterior, and occurs from November to April, whereas S. latahense lacks a highly gelatinized interior, has spores 24-38 x 9-12 um, has hairs on the exterior that are almost colorless to olive, and fruits from April to May, (Castellano). U. padeniana is larger, up to about 10cm, is more gelatinous, has cups with a black rather than gray exterior, and has spores 23-24 x 10-14 um, (Trudell). See also SIMILAR section of Bulgaria inquinans.
SOURCES  Paden(1) (as Sarcosoma latahensis), Castellano(1)* (as Sarcosoma latahense), Arora(1)* (as Sarcosoma latahensis), Lincoff(2)* (as Sarcosoma latahensis), Larsen(1) (as Sarcosoma latahensis), Trudell(4) (as Sarcosoma latahensis), Carbone(1)*, Marrone(1)*
317
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pulvinula archeri  (Berk. in Hook.) Rifai^  Verh. K. Akad. Wet., tweede sect. 57(3): 213. 1968;  = Lamprospora pyrophila  Snyder
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Pulvinula archeri produces an orange, convex disc up to 0.7cm wide with even margins, featuring its microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^The description is derived from Pfister(7). It is found in BC, WA, OR, and ID, (Larsen), and Europe including Austria (Pfister).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.7cm wide, convex, margins more or less even; orange
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to scattered
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 9-10.5(11.5) um in diameter, round, smooth-walled, generally with a single large oil droplet^; asci 8-spored or fewer, 135-145 x 10-11 um, with or without prominent croziers, tapering towards the base; paraphyses slender 1-2 um wide, "circinate and pigment-filled, mostly branched apically"; hymenium less than 150 um thick; ectal excipulum relatively small-celled, cells (10)13-15 um in diameter, globose to subglobose, medullary excipulum of textura intricata, hyphae 2 um wide 
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Pfister(7), Seaver(1) (as Lamprospora gemmea), Larsen(1)
318
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pulvinula carbonaria  (Fuckel) Boud.^  Hist. Class. Discom. Eur. p.70. 1907;  Lamprospora carbonaria  (Fuckel) Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Pulvinula carbonaria produces a pale orange disc or cup found on mossy burned ground and featuring its microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Seaver(1). RANGE ^Pulvinula carbonaria is found in OR, CA, and MT, (Larsen), and Europe including Germany (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.4cm, pale orange, the spore bearing surface a little darker than the outside; at first spherical, "becoming expanded and scutellate to discoid, the margin even or wavy", becoming flat or slightly concave, roughened by protruding asci
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or crowded on "soil among mosses in places which have been burned but subsequently overgrown with mosses"
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores up to 15-18 um in diameter, round, smooth, colorless, containing one oil droplet that almost fills the spore^; asci cylindric or nearly so, reaching 225 x 18-20 um; paraphyses filiform [thread-like] or slightly enlarged at tips, reaching 3-4 um wide at tips, "extending far beyond the young asci and strongly curved or hooked" 
NAME ORIGIN  refers to habitat on burned ground
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as Lamprospora carbonaria), Larsen(1), Kanouse(6) (as Lamprospora carbonaria)
319
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pulvinula convexella  (P. Karst.) Pfister^  Occ. Pap. Farlow Herb. Crypt. Bot. 9: 9. 1976;  Pulvinula constellatio  (Berk. & Broome) Rehm
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, reddish, cushion-shaped fruitbodies, lighter underside, short stem, growth on ground or burned ground, and microscopic characters.^ | Larsen(1) gives P. constellatio (Berk. & Broome) Rehm as a synonym of P. convexella (Karst.) Pfister. Hansen describes P. constellatio (Berk. & Broome) Boud. separately from P. convexella (P. Karst.) Pfister, but says, "The delimitation of P. constellatio and P. convexella is far from clear". RANGE ^Pulvinula convexella is found in OR, AK, CA, CO, and MT, (Larsen), and Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach). Kanouse reported Lamprospora haemastigma, which has been given as a synonym of this species, from WA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-1.2cm wide, cushion-shaped to disc-shaped; orange to reddish, (Hansen for P. convexella), 0.1-0.3cm wide, cushion-shaped; pink to scarlet, (Hansen for P. constellatio)^, (0.1)0.3-1(1.2)cm, turbinate [top-shaped] to cushion-like, margin "smooth and often strongly sinuous"; spore-bearing upper surface bright orange red; sometimes wavy, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  lighter than spore-bearing surface, to whitish pink^, (Breitenbach)
STEM  outer surface often drawn together into a short stem^ (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in sandy soil, along brooklets, etc., (Hansen for P. convexella), on rich mull, burnt ground and in pure limestone, (Hansen for P. constellatio)^, single to gregarious or in clusters on bare sandy ground on roadsides and pathsides, or among mosses, or on burned ground, (Breitenbach)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17-18 um in diameter, round, with many droplets, (Hansen for P. convexella), spores 16-17 um in diameter, round, with one large and several small droplets, (Hansen for P. constellatio), spores 13-17 um in diameter, round, smooth, colorless, with one or several droplets, (Breitenbach)^; asci 8-spored, 200-250 x 18 um, inamyloid; paraphyses "cylindrical, slender, tips bent over like a cane and not thickened, not septate but forked", (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'small and convex'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Pulvinula constellatio), Seaver(1) (as Lamprospora constellatio and L. haemastigma), Dennis(1) (as Pulvinula constellatio), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6) (as Lamprospora haemastigma)
320
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pulvinula laeterubra  (Rehm) Pfister^  Occ. Pap. Farlow Herb. crypt. Bot. 9: 11. 1976
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Pulvinula laeterubra produces minute, pale yellow discs on mossy burnt ground, and is characterized by microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Seaver(1). RANGE ^It is found in BC and AB, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  scarcely exceeding 0.1cm wide, at first spherical or nearly so, becoming disc-shaped or nearly so; pale yellow
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale yellow, similar in color to upper surface
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "on the ground and on burnt ground which has been overrun by mosses"
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores round, never exceeding 10 um in diameter and often smaller, smooth, colorless, granular within but not containing conspicuous oil drops, at first partly biseriate or irregularly crowded, finally becoming uniseriate^; asci reaching 150-175 x 12-14 um; paraphyses filiform, 1.5-2 um wide, slightly thickened in upper part and strongly curved at tip, sparingly branched, filled with colorless granules
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pleasant - red'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as Lamprospora wisconsinensis), Larsen(1)
321
FAMILY  Ploettnerulaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pyrenopeziza benesuada  (Tul.) Gremmen^  Fungus, Wageningen 28: 42, 1958;  Mollisia benesuada  (Tul.) W. Phillips
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a saucer-shaped to irregularly disc-shaped, grayish fruitbody that may have an ocher or olive tint, smooth exterior, absent stem, gregarious to clustered growth on hardwood, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Pyrenopeziza benesuada (Tul.) W. Phillips was reported from WA and MI by Kanouse. Seaver said he had not seen American collections except one doubtfully determined from Pennsylvania, (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.15cm, saucer-shaped to irregularly disc-shaped; grayish, also with ocher or olive tint, sometimes lighter toward margin; smooth^, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  the same color as upper surface and brownish toward the base; smooth^, (Breitenbach)
STEM  resting stemless on substrate, sometimes emerging through clefts in bark^, (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to clustered on "dead branches of Salix (willow) still with bark and attached or lying on the ground", according to the literature on Alnus; summer^, (Breitenbach), on dead wet sticks (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 1.5-2 um, elliptic to fusiform-clavate, smooth, colorless, without droplets, uniseriate to biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 50-70 x 5-5.5 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses "cylindric, septate, some of them forked toward the base", (Breitenbach), spores 8-10 x 2-2.5 um, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Seaver describes 22 Pyrenopeziza species for North America, differentiated by host (leaves, herbaceous plant tissue, and Carex), and spore size. Mollisia caespiticia has smaller spores and smaller asci, (Breitenbach). Seaver(2) lists 39 Mollisia species for North America, plus another 11 doubtful species - it is likely that some of these occur in the Pacific Northwest and are similar to Pyrenopeziza benesuada: they are generally up to 1mm in size, usually blackish to grayish or brownish or whitish, and identifiable only with a microscope and with knowledge of the host. According to Seaver, Mollisia species are differentiated from Pyrenopeziza species by the erumpent character of the latter "which is very difficult to recognize" when mature, (Seaver).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Mollisia benesuada), Kanouse(6) (as Mollisia benesuada), Seaver(2) (discussing Mollisia)
322
FAMILY  Ploettnerulaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pyrenopeziza revincta  (P. Karst.) Gremmen^  Fungus, Wageningen 28: 42. 1958;  Mollisia revincta  P. Karst.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) minute, cup-shaped to irregularly disc-shaped fruitbody having the upper surface blue-gray with an ocher to whitish marginal zone, 2) brownish exterior, 3) absent stem, 4) growth on rotting herbaceous stems or Rubus canes, and 5) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Pyrenopeziza revincta is found in WA (Kanouse), and Switzerland, (Breitenbach).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.03-0.08cm, cup-shaped to irregularly saucer-shaped to disc-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface blue-gray with ocher marginal zone^, (Breitenbach), gray spore-bearing upper surface, whitish margin, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  brownish^, (Breitenbach), brownish (Kanouse)
STEM  resting stemless on substrate^ (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregariously on rotting stems of Filipendula ulmaria (meadowsweet), (Breitenbach, for Switzerland), on herbaceous stems or Rubus canes, (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8 x 2 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, irregularly biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 40-50 x 5 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses filiform, cylindric, (Breitenbach), 8-11 x 1.5-2 um, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Seaver describes 22 species in this genus for North America, differentiated by host (leaves, herbaceous plant tissue, and Carex), and spore size. Seaver(2) also lists 39 Mollisia species for North America, plus another 11 doubtful species - it is likely that some of these occur in the Pacific Northwest and are similar to Pyrenopeziza revincta: they are generally up to 1mm in size, usually blackish to grayish or brownish or whitish, and identifiable only with a microscope and with knowledge of the host. According to Seaver, Mollisia species are differentiated from Pyrenopeziza species by the erumpent character of the latter "which is very difficult to recognize" when mature, (Seaver).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Mollisia revincta), Kanouse(6) (as Mollisia revincta), Seaver(2) (discussing Mollisia)
323
FAMILY  Ploettnerulaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pyrenopeziza rubi  (Fr.) Rehm^  Ascom. 416. 1878
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, brownish black, cup-shaped fruitbodies emerging through the surface of dead canes of Rubus, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Pyrenopeziza rubi is found from DE to OR and WA, and in Europe, (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.03-0.1cm across, fruitbody at first immersed, rounded, finally erumpent [emerging] through ruptured epidermis, expanding and becoming cup-shaped, the margin inrolled when dry; brownish black
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or occasionally crowded, on dead canes of Rubus
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-9 x 1.5-2.5 um, elongate-clavate, or almost cylindric^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 45-55 um and width of 6-8 um, clavate; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], 1.5 um wide
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Seaver describes 21 other species in this genus for North America, differentiated by host (leaves, herbaceous plant tissue, and Carex), and spore size. Pyrenopeziza lacerata is described on Rubus odoratus from NY and WV, with spores 12-13 um long, (Seaver). Mollisia species are differentiated from Pyrenopeziza species by the erumpent character of the latter "which is very difficult to recognize" when mature, (Seaver).
SOURCES  Seaver(2)
324
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pyronema domesticum  (Sowerby) Sacc.^  Syll. fung. (Abellini) 8: 109. 1889
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Pyronema domesticum forms tiny top-shaped to lens-shaped, stemless fruitbodies which coalesce to form crowded masses. The fruitbodies tend to be salmon-pink but range from red to red-orange to salmon-pink to whitish. They grow on burned ground, fireplaces, steam-sterilized soil (in greenhouses for example), and wet plaster. Microscopically they are distinguished by larger spores than Pyronema omphalodes and microscopic hairs.^ RANGE ^widespread, including WA (vouchered by O. Ceska and S. Krstic), Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden, (Hansen, L.), Switzerland (Breitenbach), and the United Kingdom (Dennis).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.1cm across, turbinate [top-shaped] to lens-shaped; orange-red to the color of smoked salmon^, (Breitenbach), P. domesticum "is highly variable in color, often ranging from red to pink, salmon, ivory, and pure white within a single collection.
