It is characterized by definite hairs on the exterior surface of the fruitbodies, particularly near the margin." (Beug)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  absent, but fruitbody develops "from a white cobwebby mycelial feltwork"^, (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "crowded together to form lumpy coatings" over a few square decimeters, growing on burned ground (usually developing in the beginning stage of the recovery)^, (Breitenbach), on burnt ground, steam-sterilized soil, and wet plaster, (Dennis), in North America the Pyronema that invades greenhouses is Pyronema domesticum, although P. omphalodes has been found in greenhouses in Japan, (Beug), recorded in Washington from campground fireplaces on burned wood as well as on soil and on pebbles in the fireplaces, (I. Gibson, pers. comm.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-17 x 10-11.5 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, without droplets^; asci 8-spored, 170-200 x 13-14 um, iodine negative; paraphyses cylindric, septate, "with slight clavate thickenings toward the tips", (Breitenbach), spores 16-20 x 10-12 um; fruitbody with microscopic pointed hairs, (Hansen, L.), spores 15-18 x 9.5-12 um (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Pyronema omphalodes differs especially by smaller spores 11-15 x 6.5-8.5 um, (Breitenbach). P. omphalodes has smaller spores 14-16.5 x 8-9.5 um, and fruitbody lacks hairs, (Hansen, L.(1)), P. omphalodes has smaller spores 11-15 x 6.5-8.5 um (Dennis). Iodophanus carneus is usually on dung, wet rags, etc. but according to Beug(3) occurs in burn areas. I. carneus is whitish, yellowish, or pinkish, has a pubescent exterior that later becomes bald, and has delicately warted [use oil immersion] or wrinkled spores that measure 17-22 x 10-12 um, (Beug(3)). I. carneus has hymenium and ascal walls that turn blue with iodine; the fine punctation of the spores "can be observed with certainty only under oil-immersion", (Breitenbach(1)). I. carneus has a rough surface on the hymenium - the hymenial surface appears smoother on P. domesticum.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Hansen, L.(1), Dennis(1), Beug(3)
325
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Pyronema omphalodes  (Bull. ex St.-Amans) Fuckel^  Jahrb. Nass. Vereins Naturkunde 23/24: 319. 1870
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include confluent masses of minute orange cushion-shaped fruitbodies surrounded by cobwebby mycelium, growth on burned or sterilized soil, and microscopic characters.^ | Hansen, L.(1) gives this as synonym of Pyronema confluens (Pers.) Tul. & C. Tul. RANGE ^Pyronema omphalodes is found in BC, WA, ID, AB, CA, and UT, (Larsen), Europe, Australia, and probably world-wide (Seaver), and specifically in the United Kingdom (Dennis), and Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen, L.).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  usually not over 0.1-0.2cm, usually convex, pale orange (slightly yellowish to bright orange, sometimes with a purplish tinge), soon becoming confluent and forming congested masses several centimeters in diameter, "surrounded by a dense superficial white mycelial growth"^, (Seaver), up to 0.1cm across but often confluent in large patches, pulvinate [cushion-shaped], light red to reddish orange, without a raised margin, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  bald^ (Hansen, L.)
STEM  none (Hansen, L.), surrounded by a conspicuous cobweb-like white mycelium, (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on burned places, in greenhouses on steamed soil or soil that has been sterilized by dry heat, (Seaver), on burned ground, throughout the year, (Dennis)^, already one to two weeks after a burn, fruiting all year, (Hansen, L.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-13 x 5-8 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, 1-seriate^, asci 8-spored, cylindric or nearly cylindric, 150 x 10-14 um; paraphyses "rather stout, very slightly enlarged above, reaching a diameter of 6-7 um at their apices, filled with orange granules", (Seaver), spores 11-15 x 6.5-8.5 um, elliptic, smooth, without oil droplets; asci up to 150 x 15 um, not turning blue with iodine; paraphyses simple, slightly clavate, tips 3-4 um wide, (Dennis), spores 11-15 x 6.5-8.5 um (Breitenbach), spores 14-16.5 x 8-9.5 um, fruitbodies without hairs, (Hansen, L.)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Pyronema domesticum differs especially by larger spores 15-17 x 10-11.5 um. Its color tends toward salmon-pink (but varies from orange-red to smoked-salmon-color), (Breitenbach(1)). P. domesticum has larger spores 16-20 x 10-12 um, and apothecia have microscopic pointed hairs, (Hansen, L.(1)). P. domesticum "is highly variable in color, often ranging from red to pink, salmon, ivory, and pure white within a single collection. It is characterized by definite hairs on the exterior surface of the fruitbodies, particularly near the margin." (Beug(3)). In North America the greenhouse invader is Pyronema domesticum, although P. omphalodes has been found in greenhouses in Japan, (Beug(3)). Iodophanus carneus is usually on dung, wet rags, etc. but according to Beug(3) occurs in burn areas. I. carneus is whitish, yellowish, or pinkish, has a pubescent exterior that later becomes bald, and has delicately warted [use oil immersion] or wrinkled spores that measure 17-22 x 10-12 um, (Beug(3)). Anthracobia species have tufts of brown hairs on the exterior, may be closely packed but are not confluent, and lack the conspicuous white cobwebby subiculum of P. omphalodes. See also SIMILAR section of Anthracobia macrocystis and Anthracobia melaloma.
SOURCES  Seaver(1), Dennis(1), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1) (as P. confluens, giving P. omphalodes as a synonym), Courtecuisse(1)*, Buczacki(1)*, Desjardin(6)*, Beug(3)*, Breitenbach(1)
326
FAMILY  Uncertain, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Rectipilus idahoensis  (W.B. Cooke) Agerer^  Persoonia 7(3): 424. 1973;  == Solenia idahoensis  W.B. Cooke  Beih. Sydowia 4: 24. 1961
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) minute basidiomycete fruiting bodies that are somewhat cylindric to discoid and that when dry are white, 2) exterior with flexuous [wavy] colorless smooth fine hairs, 3) growth on Western White Pine and 4) microscopic characters including basidia.^ RANGE ^Rectipilus idahoensis is found at least in ID (Cooke) and Venezuela (Agerer).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.015-0.03cm in diameter, 0.03-0.05cm tall, somewhat cylindric to discoid; white when dry^, (Cooke), 0.02-0.04cm high, single to grouped, [illustrated as pendant], bluntly barrel-shaped, white, woolly, (Agerer)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  with flexuous [wavy] colorless smooth fine surface hairs^, (Cooke)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  type on wood of Pinus monticola (Western White Pine)^, (Cooke)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 3.5-7.0 x 2.5-4.0 um, ovate, smooth, apiculate, colorless^; basidia 20-23 x 4-7 um, 4-spored, surface hairs flexuous [wavy], smooth, colorless, 125-250 x 3-4 um, (Cooke), spores 4-5.5 x 3-5 um, oval-elliptic to drop-shaped, inamyloid; basidia 13-19 x 6-8 um, with clamp connection, (Agerer)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Idaho'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Cooke(2) (as Solenia idahoensis), Agerer(1) (in German)
327
FAMILY  Pleurotaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Resupinatus poriaeformis (Pers.) Thorn, Moncalvo & Redhead^  in Thorn, Moncalvo, Redhead, Lodge & Martn  Mycologia 97(5): 1148. (2006) [2005];  Stigmatolemma poriaeforme  (Pers.) Singer  Sydowia, Beih. 4: 128. 1961;  Stigmatolemma poriaeforme  (Pers.) W.B. Cooke  Beih. Sydowia 4: 128 (1961);  Porotheleum poriaeforme  (Pers. ex Fr.) W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute grayish, tomentose-powdery, cylindric or cup-shaped fruitbodies crowded together on a grayish mat and microscopic characters including round spores, basidia, gelatinous context, clamp connections, and diverticulate hairs and crystals.^ | Some authors call the epithet "poriiforme", based on Article 60.8 of the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature (2000) which appears to suggest that the compound should be corrected, but Thorn(4) provides the rationale that Article 60G.1(b) allows the compounding form "ae" to indicate the origin of the name, being a reference to the genus Poria rather than porus. Resupinatus poriaeformis has been recorded from BC, also AL, MD, MN, NC, NJ, SC, France, Germany, Sweden, New Zealand, according to Redhead who notes concerning the BC record, "Cooke (1957) has recorded this species from British Columbia. However, Donk (1962) was of the opinion that a number of taxa other than S. poriaeforme had been placed in synonymy by Cooke, e.g., S. incanum Kalchbr. and S. conspersum (Pers.) Donk. Until the collections examined by Cooke are rechecked, the exact identity of the one collection from British Columbia will not be known.". Redhead goes on to illustrate hyphal ends on the cup margin of a BC collection of this species in the sense of Donk, (see MICROSCOPIC). (Redhead(21)). RANGE ^R. poriaeforme is found in NC, Venezuela, South Africa, (Cooke(1)), ON, (Thorn, who gives distribution as widespread in Europe and North America and recorded in New Zealand, South Africa, and South America), AZ (Gilbertson), and QC, DE, GA, IA, LA, MA, ME, MO, NH, NY, OH, PA, VA, and WI, (Ginns).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  "consisting of a gray subiculum with scattered to crowded gray cupules" 0.02-0.03cm across, apical pore conspicuous; subiculum "tomentose to cottony or very thin and arachnoid, sometimes white at margin"^, (Gilbertson), forming "incrusting non-removable patches, variable in size and irregular in outline, which more often fuse to make much-elongated areas"; cups 4-5 to a millimeter and about 0.01cm deep, circular or somewhat flattened, nearly touching when expanded; cups smooth inside; margin of cups incurved and partly closing the cups when dry, (Cooke(1)), 0.018-0.025cm across, about 0.03cm tall, nearly cylindric or goblet-shaped, crowded on felty subiculum, (Thorn), 0.03-0.05cm across, urn-shaped or cup-shaped, inner surface smooth, gray, margin fibrous or hairy; growing in masses several centimeters in extent, (Buczacki)
FLESH  thin; gray^, (Buczacki)
UNDERSIDE  outer surface of cupules appearing granular under 30 X lens^, (Gilbertson), covered over outside with "white, granular, easily removed crystals like a powder", when powder rubbed off, seen to be brown in contrast to the "white incrusted felt in which they are seated", in other fruitings the cups may be reddish brown when the crystalline covering is weak, or blackish where the cups are very mature, (Cooke(1)), "smooth on outside but with whitish incrustation" (Buczacki)
STEM  absent, but mycelial threads at base^ (Buczacki)
ODOR  indistinct^ (Buczacki)
TASTE  indistinct^ (Buczacki)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  annual, on dead hardwoods^, associated with a white rot, (Gilbertson), associated with a soft brown rot (Ginns), on rotting hardwood, typically on large fallen branches or trunks in old hardwood woodland, massed together "in irregular patches and easily mistaken for a lichen", summer to all year, (Buczacki), spring, summer, fall, winter
SPORE DEPOSIT  white^ (Buczacki)
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4.5-6 um, round, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, thin-walled^; basidia 4-spored, 20-30 x 5.5-6.5 um, with basal clamp; cystidia absent; hyphae monomitic, hyphae of subiculum 2-3 um wide, colorless, thin-walled, nodose-septate, with occasional branching; at apex of cupules "profusely branched and contorted dendrohyphidia", these from hyphae 2-2.5 um wide, branches 1 um wide or less, (Gilbertson), spores (4)5-7.5(8) x (1)3.5-4(5) um, round to ovate, when strictly round 3.5-6 um, more or less flattened on one side, smooth, colorless, apiculate; basidia 4-spored, 14-18 x 3.5-7 um, clavate; walls of cups about 30-40 um thick, the hymenium occupying a little less than half; "special hairs may form a palisade around margin of receptacle, 20-40 x 1-2.5 um, straight to branched like dendrophyses", (Cooke(1)), hyphal ends on the cup margin (coralloid hairs) bear peculiar lecythiform branches with extremely slender necks, (Redhead(21)), spores (3.0)3.7-5.5 x (3.0)3.3-4.5 um, nearly round or round, smooth, inamyloid, colorless; basidia 4-spored, (12)15-18(22) x 6-8 um, broadly clavate or spheropedunculate, colorless; cystidia confined to rim of cup, 12-17 x 3.5-5.0 um, clavate or fusoid, diverticulate, colorless; trama dark brown in KOH, densely interwoven, (10)20-30(50) um deep including poorly defined subhymenium; gelatinous zone below trama proper, nearly colorless and continuous to base and forming a colorless gelatinous subiculum 20-50 um thick; all hyphae including trama and cuticle, with clamps; cups externally clothed with colorless glossy hairs 1.5-3.0 (4.0) um wide, "some with gelatinised walls, and inflated, others thin-walled, irregularly warted and lobed, with fine secretory pegs", coated with large (5-20 um) "pale brown blocky crystals that in fact are masses of rhombic crystals 5-12 x 1-2 um"; subiculum also covered with diverticulate hairs and crystalline material, (Thorn)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with porous form'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Resupinatus urceolatus.
SOURCES  Cooke(1) (as Porothelium), Gilbertson(1) (as Stigmatolemma), Redhead(21) (as Stigmatolemma), Redhead(5) (as Stigmatolemma), Thorn(2) (as Stigmatolemma), Ginns(5) (as Stigmatolemma), Cooke(2) (as Stigmatolemma), Thorn(4), Buczacki(1)*
328
FAMILY  Pleurotaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Resupinatus urceolatus  (Wallr. ex Fr.) Thorn, Moncalvo & Redhead^  in Thorn, Moncalvo, Redhead, Lodge & Martn, Mycologia 97(5): 1148 (2006) [2005];  == Stigmatolemma urceolatum (Wallr. ex Fr.) Donk;  == Solenia urceolata  Wallr. ex Fr.;  = Stigmatolemma farinaceum  (Kalchbr. & Cooke) D.A. Reid;  = Cyphella farinacea  Kalchbr. & Cooke;  Phaeoglabrotricha farinacea  (Kalchbr. & Cooke)  W.B. Cooke
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Resupinatus urceolatus features 1) gregarious, grayish, spherical to vase-shaped fruiting bodies 0.03-0.15cm in diam, externally farinaceous with short, incrusted hairs, 2) underlying subiculum sparse and wispy or lacking, and 3) round to nearly round spores 4.5-6 um in diam.^ RANGE ^Resupinatus urceolatus has been recorded from BC, (combining Thorn(4) with Redhead(21)), likely occurs elsewhere in North America, and is also found in Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach) and South Africa (Cooke).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody about 0.03cm in diameter, spherical, urceolate [small mouth in relation to body], inner surface (with the spore bearing surface) gray, smooth; margin finely floccose-fringed^, (Breitenbach), 0.03-0.15cm when dry, "discoid, becoming flattened, with inrolled margin when dry", spore-bearing surface olivaceous to cinereous or black-brown, (Cooke)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  gray-brown; smooth, "incrusted with fine whitish material, with hyphae attached to it toward the base"^, (Breitenbach), composed of grayish-white meal "consisting of crystals enmeshed among surface hyphae", (Cooke)
STEM  up to dozens +/- crowded and stalkless on open-textured, light-colored subiculum^, (Breitenbach), cups gregarious, often touching one another, sessile to subsessile [without a stem or almost without a stem], (Cooke)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on dead hardwood^, (Breitenbach), on rotting wood (Cooke)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 4.5-5.5 um, round, smooth, inamyloid, colorless, with droplets [one in the illustration]^; basidia 2-4-spored, 25-30 x 6-8.5 um, clavate, with basal clamp connection; cystidia not seen; hyphal system monomitic, hyphae in the wall of the cups 1-5-2.5 um across, brownish, thin-walled, in part slightly gelatinized, with clamp connections, hyphae in margin "branched like dendrophyses to drawn out into a beak and ventricose", (Breitenbach), spores 5.5-7 um in diameter, round to nearly round, "smooth, granular inside, appearing minutely punctate, yellowish"; basidia 4-spored, 15-20 x 6-8 um, in tight palisade, clamped at base; cystidia absent; hyphae 1.5-3 um wide, colorless to yellowish, with simple septa, simple clamp connections, and medallion clamp connections, subgelatinous 1.4-1.8 um wide in subhymenial area, (Cooke)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'urceolate' (having the shape of a pitcher with large body and small mouth)
SIMILAR  Resupinatus poriaeformis has fruitbodies seated in a distinct, white to grayish, felty to membranous subiculum, resembling a crustose lichen (Stigmatolemma poriaeforme is a synonymous name which had been applied to Cooke's 1957 BC collection of Resupinatus urceolatus), (Thorn(4)).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(2)*, Cooke(2) (as Phaeoglabrotricha farinacea), Thorn(4), Redhead(21)
329
FAMILY  Rhizinaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Rhizina undulata  Fr.^  Observ. mycol. (Havniae) 1: 161. 1815;  = Rhizina inflata  (Schaeff.) P. Karst.;  = Rhizina zonata  Berk.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  rooting fairy cup, crustlike cup, doughnut fungus, pine fire fungus
NOTES  Also listed in Morels etc. category. Features include a chestnut to blackish brown fruitbody with a pale border, lying flat but undulating, the underside ocher to yellow with conspicuous rhizoids, growing on the ground in coniferous forests, especially on burned ground, and microscopic characters including spores with appendages at both ends.^ RANGE ^Rhizina undulata is found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, also AB, MB, NB, NF, NT, ON, SK, AK, U.K., and the Netherlands, and is known from Asia, (Abbott). It occurs also in OR (Larsen), and MT (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 10cm wide, disc-shaped to convex and reflexed, sometimes fused with adjacent fruitbodies; medium to dark red-brown fresh to blackish brown dried, undulating and wrinkled, typically with a distinct white to yellow or yellow brown marginal zone^, (Abbott), 2-10cm wide, (or sometimes fruitbodies confluent and covering several square decimeters), flat to cushion-like, hollow, lying on ground, undulating, folded, with bosses; chestnut-brown to black-brown, when young with whitish margin; when young smooth, dull to shining, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  fragile, spongy, when old tough; light brownish^, (Breitenbach)
UNDERSIDE  "white to pallid brown, finely pubescent, with several to many white, yellow or pallid gray brown rhizoid-like projections" that extend to substrate and are ingrown with debris, up to 3cm long^, (Abbott), ocher to yellow "with conspicuous, forked, rootlike outgrowths (rhizoids), to which plant remains usually adhere", (Breitenbach)
STEM  none^ (Abbott)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious or numerous and scattered "on soil, duff or woody debris, typically in recently burned areas under conifers", March to November; a pathogen of conifer seedlings^, (Abbott), gregarious in coniferous forests, "clearcuts, tree farms of young spruces, commonly in or near burned ground, on mossy ground", May to October, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 30-45 x 8-15 um, narrowly fusoidal, rough, colorless, with 2 to 4 droplets^; asci 375-450 x 12.4-19.9 um; paraphyses clavate, 5.4-7.9 um wide at tip, colorless, with brown encrusted pigment, contents finely granular; setae 6.6-8.1 um in lower part, widening gradually to 8.8-10.9 um at tip, sometimes lobed, brown, thick-walled except tip thin-walled, aseptate, (Abbott), spores (28)30-40 x 7-10 um not including appendages, fusiform-navicular [spindle-boat-shaped], "finely warty to rough, sometimes connected transversely to form ridges", with 2 drops and colorless pointed appendages on both ends, appendages 3-5 um long, spores in part biseriate; asci 8-spored, 300-400 x 15-20 um, inamyloid; paraphyses "cylindrical and with slight clavate thickenings to 5-8 um, tips encrusted with amorphous brownish substance, with few septa"; setae "brownish, thick-walled, not septate, tips blunt, lighter, arising from deep within medulla and reaching to the surface of the hymenium", (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'undulating' or 'wavy'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Abbott(1), Breitenbach(1)*, Larsen(1), Seaver(1) (as Rhizina inflata), Lincoff(2)*, Courtecuisse(1)*, McKnight(1)*
330
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Rhodotarzetta rosea  (Rea) Dissing & Sivertsen^  Mycotaxon 16(2): 456. 1983;  Tarzetta rosea  (Rea) Dennis;  Pustularia rosea  Rea;  Pustularia bolarioides  Ramsb. ex Bagchee
ENGLISH NAME(S)  pink burn cup
NOTES  Features include bright pink fruitbodies that are permanently cup-shaped, the margin splitting slightly, the exterior minutely downy, gregarious growth on burned ground, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Rhodotarzetta rosea is widely distributed in North America (Lincoff). There is a collection at Oregon State University from BC according to Larsen(1), and two collections from WA at Oregon State University. It has been recorded in WA by Buck McAdoo (pers. comm.).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 1.5cm across, permanently cup-shaped, the margin splitting slightly; bright pink throughout^, (Dennis), 0.5-1.2cm across, at first cup-shaped, then expanded to disc-shaped, margin distinct; hymenium [spore-bearing upper surface] pink, (Hansen, L.), 0.5-1.5cm wide and high, cup-shaped, margin often splitting; bright pink to red, (Lincoff), 0.3-2cm wide, 0.3-1.5cm high, cup-shaped, often distorted; hymenium bright red to pinkish red, smooth, (Bessette), hymenium pink to reddish (Arora)
FLESH  brittle^ (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  exterior minutely downy with loose colorless hyphae, (Dennis), bald; pale pink, (Hansen, L.), pinkish red, lacking conspicuous white hairs, (Bessette)
STEM  sessile^ (Hansen, L.), stem absent or rudimentary (Arora), stem when present short, whitish, (Lincoff), usually without stem or with rudimentary stem (Bessette)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Bessette)
HABITAT  gregarious on burned ground^, September to October (Dennis for United Kingdom), growing in masses on burned ground, June to September, (Lincoff), on burned ground, summer to fall (Hansen for Scandinavia), in groups or clusters on burned ground, June to September, (Bessette), found in burned areas (Arora)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17-20 x 9-11 um; broadly elliptic with 2 large oil droplets^; asci about 250 x 13 um; paraphyses cylindric, very slightly enlarged upward but not clavate, about 6 um thick, "with pinkish granules in their upper parts", (Dennis), spores 16.5-20 x 7.5-10 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with two droplets; excipulum two-layered, (Hansen, L.), spores 17-20 x 9-11 um, elliptic, smooth, with 2 large oil droplets, (Lincoff), spores 16-20 x 9-11 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 2 large oil droplets, (Bessette)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dennis(1) (as Tarzetta), Hansen, L.(1) (as Tarzetta), Lincoff(2)* (as Tarzetta), Bessette(2) (as Tarzetta), Arora(1) (as Tarzetta), Larsen(1) (as Tarzetta)
331
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Roseodiscus subcarneus  (Sacc.) Baral^  in Baral & Krieglsteiner, Acta Mycologica, Warszawa 41(1): 17. 2006;  Hymenoscyphus subcarneus  (Cooke & Peck) Kuntze;  Hymenoscyphus subcarneus  (Sacc.) Kuntze;  Phialea subcarnea  Sacc.;  Helotium destructor  W.L. White
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Roseodiscus subcarneus most easily found by observing the dead patches of liverworts or mosses it produces by growing on them. Other features include a pink-colored, cup-shaped fruitbody, relatively long stem, and microscopic characters including clavate spores.^ | Hengstmengel(1) explains some of the nomenclatural history of this species and a different species that grows mainly on decorticated wood or chips of deciduous trees, Hymenoscyphus subcarneus (Schumach.) J. Schroet., now called Phaeohelotium carneum (Fr.) Hengstm. RANGE ^Roseodiscus subcarneus is found at least in WA, (Kanouse), AB, MI, NH, and NY, (Seaver), ON, (White), Poland, and reported in Slovakia, PQ, (in Baral). There is a BC collection labeled Helotium destructor at Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody (0.04)0.05-0.13(0.15)cm across fresh, shallowly cup-shaped to saucer-shaped; whitish but with a distinct pale pink tint^, (Baral), up to 0.05cm across disc but usually considerably smaller, up to 0.1cm high, when young papillate, then elongating, enlarging at top, becoming nearly spherical with a rather deep pore; disc becoming shallowly funnel-shaped, finally saucer-shaped with turned up margin, when dried similar in color to exterior and stem or sometimes more opaque creamy yellow; margin smooth, elevated, obtuse [blunt], (White), reaching 0.05cm across, but often much smaller, (scarcely visible to the naked eye), gradually expanding and becoming nearly spherical, at maturity concave with upturned margin; "hymenium similar in color to the outside of the apothecium" [but does not mention what this color is], (Seaver)
FLESH  waxy-cartilaginous when dried^ (White)
UNDERSIDE  implies that the fruitbody as a whole is "whitish but with a distinct pale pink tint"; margin of large fruitbodies "often undulating to somewhat irregular"^, (Baral), in dry condition pale yellow or hyaline-yellow; smooth, not wrinkled in drying, (White), smooth (Seaver), "ochraceous-buff" (probably Ridgway color) when fresh, (Kanouse)
STEM  0.06-0.12cm x 0.02-0.035cm, abruptly delimited from cup, concolorous, pale ochraceous toward base, exterior nearly smooth under a hand lens, at higher magnification delicately pubescent, especially near margin^, (Baral), about 0.03-0.05cm long, long for size of fruitbody, cylindric, slightly widened at juncture with disc, rather firm, not wrinkled in drying; hyaline-yellow in dried material; entirely smooth or more rarely with a thin scattering of white cottony hyphae around base, (White), relatively long, reaching length of 0.03-0.05cm, slender and slightly broadened at junction with cup, (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  growing on and apparently killing various species of liverworts and mosses: Jungermania sp., Dicranum flagellare^, (Seaver), on a liverwort on a log, parasitic on liverworts and mosses, (Kanouse), single, sparse, or rather numerous, growing on and apparently killing various species of Jungermaniaceous liverworts and mosses, originating from the leafy branches, all collections in September except once in July, (White)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores free (5.2)6-8.5(10) x (1.8)2-2.6(3) um, in KOH about 6-8 x 2-2.3 um, of variable length, slightly to mainly strongly clavate or pyriform or even somewhat cuneate (triangular), smooth, colorless, biseriate within living asci^; asci 52-66 x 6.5-7.5(10) um, in KOH 42-57 x (5.5)6-7(7.5) um, 8-spored, apex strongly conic, apical ring deep blue in IKI, of the Calycina-type ("rather thick in optical section, widest in its upper part which extends to the very apex"), 0.6-1 um high and 0.9-1.1 um wide (dead state), base attenuated or rather broad, arising from croziers; paraphyses cylindric to slightly clavate, even in dead state 3-7 um shorter than the asci, terminal cell (11)16-37 x 2.8-3.5(4) um, in living state multiguttulate in the upper 25-40 um by spherical refractive vacuolar bodies, these vacuolar bodies disappearing in KOH and invisible in dead cells; medullary excipulum near ectal excipulum of a broad textura porrecta, in center of a small region of dense textura intricata (individual cells here in KOH 12-25 x 3-4 um), ectal excipulum of a horizontally (10-20 degrees) oriented colorless textura prismatica of thin-walled cells, individual cells (12)20-45(67) x (6)10-13(16) um, externally covered by a loose network of 3-5 um wide eguttulate hyphae, towards margin of textura porrecta oriented at about 10 degrees, cells (in KOH) 13-18 x 2.5-4 um, "not differentiated from covering hyphae which terminate here in somewhat projecting hair-like ends" that contain in the living state low-refractive droplets, in stem of textura porrecta, (Baral), spores 4.5-6 x 2-2.5 um, pyriform [pear-shaped], biseriate, content not granular; asci 40-50 x 5-6 um; paraphyses simple [unbranched] or once or twice forked, scarcely or not at all widened at tip, 3-3.5 um wide, (White), spores 4.5-6 x 2-2.5 um, clavate, the narrow end directed downward, biseriate; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 40-50 um and width of 5-6 um, clavate; paraphyses "simple, or occasionally branched, scarcely enlarged above, 3-3.5 um in diameter", (Seaver), excipulum "composed of broad parallel hyphae, with thin-walled cells about 20-30 x 10 um, lying at a very low angle to the surface and covering a flesh formed of more slender loosely wavy hyphae", ascus pore turns blue with iodine, (Dennis(2))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Roseodiscus rhodoleucus and Roseodiscus equisetinus grow on dead Equisetum and should be watched for in the Pacific Northwest. The spores of the former measure 9-12 x 5-6 and are non-septate (Dennis(1)). The spores of the latter measure 8-13 x 2.5-3 um and are 1-septate at maturity (Dennis(1)). There is a collection from WA deposited as Hymenoscyphus rhodoleucus at the University of Washington. At least one species of small pink discomycete occurs on dead Equisetum in British Columbia, but Stamnaria is another genus that may produce pink fruitbodies on dead Equisetum (collection listed as Stamnaria persoonii at the University of British Columbia, although spores were measured at (14)15-18 x 4-5 um, narrower than some measurements such as 15-18 x 5-8 in Dennis(1)). Psilachnum inquilinum (P. Karst.) Dennis was identified by Haines(1) with seven collections examined from Washington on Equisetum during the course of his Master's thesis. These are not pink but white to cream-colored. He says the sessile to short-stemmed cups are up to 0.1(0.15)cm across, the exterior "sparsely covered with hairs which appear white under the dissecting scope, disc often slightly darker than the exterior", the spores 7-8 x 2-2.5 um, clavate-cylindric, the paraphyses narrowly filiform-lanceolate, up to 2 um wide, exceeding asci by no more than 8 um; the hairs 3-4.5 um wide and up to 50 um long, colorless, smooth, thin-walled, irregularly cylindric, septate, slightly constricted at the septa, cells 10-15 um long.
SOURCES  Baral(1), Kanouse(6) (as Helotium destructor), Seaver(2) (as Helotium destructor), White, W.L.(1) (as Helotium destructor), Dennis(2), Dennis(1), Hengstmengel(1), Haines(1)
332
FAMILY  Rutstroemiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Rutstroemia sydowiana  (Rehm) W.L. White^  Lloydia 4: 200. 1941;  Ciboria sydowiana  Rehm;  Ombrophila sydowiana  Rehm;  Poculum sydowianum  (Rehm) Dumont
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) small, stemmed fruitbodies growing on fallen oak leaves, the fruitbodies becoming cup-shaped to flat, 2) spore-bearing surface that is reddish brown to light brown, 3) margin that is finely scalloped, 4) underside that is pale cinnamon or brownish yellow and longitudinally striate under a lens, 5) black discoloration sometimes around the places of attachment, and 6) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Two collections were examined from OR, collections were also examined from Germany and the United Kingdom, and the species is reported also from Austria and Czechoslovakia, (White). There is a collection from BC at the University of British Columbia identified by Oluna Ceska (on petioles of oak leaves). 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching a width of 0.3cm and a height of 0.25cm though usually smaller, "when very young papilliform, becoming erect, cylindric, columnar, with a minute pore appearing at the apex as this part enlarges into a head which expands as the pore increases in size", disc becoming infundibuliform [funnel-shaped] then cup-shaped, finally nearly flat, "rather thick, wrinkling slightly on drying but scarcely changing shape"; spore-bearing surface hazel or pale leather-colored, in dried specimens dark reddish brown and very hard; margin circular, formed by the extension of excipular hyphae slightly above spore-bearing surface "where tips are closely agglutinated and the margin split at close and regular intervals" to form a minutely crenulate [scalloped] edge^, (White, W.L.), 0.15-0.3cm across, hemispheric and urceolate [goblet-shaped] when young, then cup-shaped to saucer-shaped; spore-bearing surface olive-brown to reddish brown, smooth; margin somewhat darker and slightly scurfy, (Breitenbach), disc 0.1-0.3cm across, cup-shaped to flat, reddish brown, (Hansen, L.)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale cinnamon or brownish yellow, slightly darker on drying, "under lens minutely longitudinally striate with reddish brown hyphae running superficially over a more lightly colored underlying tissue" and often ending below margin to give a squamulose effect [finely scaly effect] to the upper part of the exterior^, (White, W.L.), sometimes rather lighter in color than spore-bearing surface, (Breitenbach)
STEM  stem short, subcylindric [somewhat cylindric], marked and colored like the exterior (underside) in upper part, becoming smooth and much darker toward base^, (White, W.L.), 0.1-0.3cm long, reddish brown to dark brown, substrate "usually discolored blackish around the places of attachment", (Breitenbach), 0.05-0.6cm x 0.05-0.1cm, (Hansen, L.)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered, growing singly, erumpent from beneath the surface on petioles, midribs, lateral veins and blades of fallen overwintered leaves of Quercus (oak), the leaves not showing evidence of stromatization, in Oregon two collections said by collector to be on Quercus garryana in November and Acer sp. in September, in England and Germany September to December^, (White, W.L.), on "oak leaves lying on the ground in damp places, principally on the petioles but also on the ribs", August to September, usually single, but also up to 3 fruitbodies on a leaf, (Breitenbach), 1-3 from stromatized areas of petioles and leaf nerves of Quercus leaves, fruiting in the fall, (Hansen, L.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 11.5-15 x 5.5-6.5 um, broadly obovoid-reniform, "not known to become septate", usually containing a large central oil droplet and much broken up oily material, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 115-130 x 10-12 um, clavate, truncate at tip; paraphyses 3-4.2 um wide, slightly clavately enlarged at apex; in section showing a very complex structure with 5 distinct zones beneath hymenium, (White, W.L.), spores 12-13.5 x 6-6.5 um, irregularly broadly elliptic to reniform [kidney-shaped], smooth, colorless, with 1 to 2 large droplets and several small droplets, spores uniseriate; asci 8-spored, 120-130 x 10 um, iodine positive; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], "septate, forked toward the base, tips with slight clavate thickenings", (Breitenbach), spores 11.5-13.5 x 5-6.5 um, elliptic, loaf-shaped, unicellular; asci 110-130 x 9-11 um, (Hansen, L.)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Rutstroemia petiolorum (Roberge) W.L. White is another widespread species that also grows on oak leaves and has been found in IA, ME, NC, NY, and WI, as well as Europe, (described in White, W.L.(2) and Breitenbach(1)). R. petiolorum has spores 14-17 x 4.5-5.5 um, and fruits mostly from petioles, usually of Quercus or Fagus, whereas R. sydowiana has smaller spores and fruits on the leaf blade or veins rather than the petioles of Quercus leaves, (White, W.L.). R. petiolorum has long-stemmed fruitbodies that grow singly or several at a time from stromatized areas of petiole and leaf nerves of Fagus or Quercus leaves in early summer: the disc is 0.1-0.4cm across and medium brown, the stem 0.2-2cm x 0.05-0.1cm, the spores 14-17 x 4.5-6 um, elliptic, loaf-shaped, unicellular to tetracellular, and the asci 95-120 x 9-12 um, (Hansen, L.).
SOURCES  White, W.L.(2), Breitenbach(1)*, Hansen, L.(1)
333
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Saccobolus depauperatus  (Berk. & Broome) Rehm^  Vidensk Medd. Copenhagen: 293. 1876;  Saccobolus neglectus  Boud.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) minute fruitbodies on dung that are white to pale wine-colored to violet, dotted with dark purplish tips of asci, 2) smooth exterior that is white then pale violet, 3) absent stem, and 4) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Saccobolus depauperatus is found at least in OR, ID, AK, and CO, (Larsen). Collections were examined from OR, ON, PQ, CO, CT, MA, NJ, NY, Argentina, Brazil, Ecuador, Venezuela, Austria, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Sweden, United Kingdom, and Pakistan, (Brummelen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.01-0.02(0.025)cm across, 0.01-0.03cm high, at first nearly spherical, then more expanded and becoming pulvinate [cushion-shaped] or turbinate-hemispheric, often with a narrow base, disc convex, white, then pale vinous to violet, dotted with dark purplish protruding tips of asci; margin not differentiated^, (Brummelen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  white, then pale violet; smooth^, (Brummelen)
STEM  none^ (Brummelen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered or gregarious on dung of horse, cow, sheep, deer, porcupine, moose, rabbit, hare, also on mud plaster of a wall^, (Brummelen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-14.5 x 5-7.5 um, elliptic or fusiform-elliptic, sometimes somewhat asymmetric, with blunt ends, smooth or extremely fine granular, at first colorless then pinkish violet, finally dark violet or purplish brown, pigment in a thin or thick layer (0.5-1.1 um thick), spores clustered^; asci 8-spored, 60-95 x (12)15-20 um (the longer ones near the margin of the disc), broadly clavate, gradually narrowing downwards into a rather thick base, with abruptly truncate apex, the wall deep blue in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses sometimes rather scarce, 1.5-3.2 um thick, filiform [thread-like], simple, septate, colorless or faintly colored, slightly enlarged up to 4-5(6) um at tip, often slightly curved in upper part, without mucus, (Brummelen)
NAME ORIGIN  means "poorly developed"^, (Brummelen)
SIMILAR  Saccobolus versicolor is sometimes difficult to distinguish and several fruitbodies of different ages should be examined: S. depauperatus has smaller fruitbodies, asci, and ascospores, and only rarely forms a small amount of intercellular pigment, (Brummelen). Saccobolus glaber Pers.: Fr. was recorded from Washington state by Kanouse, but her description does not fit well with Brummelen's modern description.
SOURCES  Brummelen(1), Seaver(1), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6) (discussing S. glaber)
334
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Saccobolus versicolor  (P. Karst.) P. Karst.^  Fungus Fenniae no. 659. 1867;  Saccobolus violascens  Boud.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) minute fruitbodies on dung with the spore-bearing upper surface convex, pale violet, and dotted with dark violet or blackish tips of asci, 2) exterior that is pale violet and smooth, 3) absent stem, and 4) microscopic characters.^ | Saccobolus versicolor is variable in size, pigmentation, spore size and ornamentation. RANGE ^It is found at least in OR, ID, CA, and CO, (Larsen). Collections were examined from OR, ID, ON, CA, CO, CT, HI, ME, NJ, NY, TX, Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Romania, Sweden, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom, (Brummelen). There is a collection from BC at the University of British Columbia identified by R. Bandoni in 1960 (as Saccobolus violascens) on elk dung.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  (0.01)0.02-0.1(0.2)cm across, at first spherical, then hemispheric, and finally often pulvinate [cushion-shaped] or lens-shaped; disc convex or flat-convex, pale violet, dotted with dark violet or almost black protruding tips of asci; margin not differentiated^, (Brummelen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale violet, becoming darker when old; smooth^, (Brummelen)
STEM  absent^ (Brummelen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered or gregarious on dung of cow, caribou, horse, goat, sheep, deer, hare, rabbit, lemming, muskrat, and mouse, also on rotten stems of cabbage and on pasteboard^, (Brummelen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-21.5(23.5) x 6.5-9.5(10) um, elliptic-fusiform or more rarely fusiform-elliptic, very rarely nearly round or round, "often asymmetrical, subtrigonal or ventricose, with blunt ends", "smooth, finely warted or with small pits and short more or less reticulating fissures", "with common or individual, lateral, mucilaginous substance", at first colorless, then pinkish violet, finally violet, purplish brown or purplish gray, spores clustered^; asci 8-spored, (80)100-145 x 22-37 um, broadly clavate, the wall deep blue in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses 2-3 um thick, filiform [thread-like], branched, septate, not, slightly, or strongly enlarged in upper part, up to 7.5 um wide at tip, colorless, often with amorphous violet intercellular pigment between the upper parts; amorphous intracellular violaceous pigment of variable amount between cells of excipulum, but excipulum may be poorly developed, (Brummelen)
NAME ORIGIN  "from Latin, versicolor, of changeable color"^, (Brummelen)
SIMILAR  Saccobolus depauperatus is sometimes difficult to distinguish and several fruitbodies of different ages should be examined: S. depauperatus has smaller fruitbodies, asci, and ascospores, and only rarely forms a small amount of intercellular pigment, (Brummelen). Saccobolus glaber Pers.: Fr. was recorded from Washington state by Kanouse, but her description does not fit well with Brummelen's modern description.
SOURCES  Brummelen(1), Seaver(1) (as Saccobolus violascens), Larsen(1), Tylutki(2), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6) (discussing S. glaber)
335
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sageria tsugae  A. Funk^  Can. J. Bot. 53: 1196-1199. 1975
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) tiny, circular, dark brown, pruinose fruitbodies on hemlock, 2) spore-bearing surface that is flat, light brown, and ringed by a narrow whitish band, 3) soft consistency, 4) short or absent stem, 5) habit that is single or cespitose in clusters of 2 or 3, and 6) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Sageria tsugae was described from coastal BC, (Funk(7)) and this description is derived from the original description.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.04-0.07cm across, 0.04-0.06cm high, circular; dark brown; pruinose; spore-bearing surface "flat, light brown, ringed by a narrow whitish band"
FLESH  soft
UNDERSIDE  dark brown, pruinose
STEM  sessile [without a stem] or short-stemmed
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or cespitose in clusters of 2 or 3, on stem and branches of Tsuga heterophylla (Western Hemlock)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 36-45(56) x 8-11(14) um, elliptic-fusiform, colorless, usually 3-septate or 7-septate, occasionally muriform [cells arranged like bricks in a wall, with longitudinal and transverse septa]^; asci 8-spored or irregular, 132-165 x 18-22 um, clavate, inoperculate, pore staining blue in iodine; paraphyses "usually brown, filiform or flail-like, simple, tips obtuse or rounded, forming a loose epithecium"; ectal excipulum "of parallel and intertwined hyphae (textura porrecta), dark brown"; medullary excipulum of colorless, isodiametric cells (textura angularis); "originating from a pseudoparenchymatous hypostroma"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Tsuga', referring to habitat
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Nipterella tsugae.
SOURCES  Funk(7)
336
FAMILY  Geoglossaceae, Order Geoglossales, Class Geoglossomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sarcoleotia globosa  (Sommerf.) Korf^  Phytologia 21(4): 206. 1971
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Also listed in Clubs category. Sarcoleotia globosa is a distinctive species with a nearly spherical, dark brown to black head and a comparatively long brownish stem, growing in disturbed places or open plant communities, typically with moss.^ | This species is not to be confused with Sarcosoma globosa, a black cup from eastern North America. RANGE ^Sarcoleotia globosa has been recorded by Jumpponen et al. from WA, OR, and CO, and occurs also in Europe.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 2.5cm tall with stem, the head 0.15-0.35cm tall and 0.15-0.8cm wide, subspherical, larger specimens somewhat flattened or depressed at center of disc, the margin of the spore-bearing upper surface at first strongly recurved and touching the stem, when old expanding to leave a gap between the stem and the margin, spore-bearing surface deep brown to black^, (Jumpponen), spherical or hemispheric, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  grayish brown^, (Jumpponen)
STEM  0.3-2.5cm x 0.05-0.2cm, round in cross-section to compressed with a longitudinal depression on one or two sides; dark grayish brown with a lighter base; bald to floccose or finely scaly^, (Jumpponen), pale brownish, delicately furfuraceous (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or occasionally single, usually in disturbed habitats or in open plant communities, typically with moss, August and September^, (Jumpponen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (18)20-34(36) x 3-5 um, clavate, slightly curved or straight, smooth, colorless, with 0-1(3) septa, uniseriate becoming biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 80-140 x 7-11 um, clavate, inoperculate with distinctly amyloid pore walls; paraphyses about 2 um wide, the tips slightly enlarged to 3-3.5 um, curved or hooked up to 120 degrees, occasionally straight, the paraphyses with colorless or light brown walls, unbranched, septate; subhymenium of compact, somewhat interwoven hyphae, (Jumpponen), 
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the spherical head on the fruiting body
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Hansen, L.(1), Jumpponen(2)
337
FAMILY  Sarcoscyphaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sarcoscypha coccinea  (Jacq. ex Gray) Lambotte^  Mem. Soc. Roy. Sciences Liege II 14: 302. 1887
ENGLISH NAME(S)  scarlet cup fungus, scarlet cup
NOTES  Sarcoscypha coccinea is a bright red cup with whitish downy to granular exterior, and usually a white stem connecting it to fallen or buried hardwood sticks and branches.^ RANGE ^It is found at least in BC, WA, OR, and CA (Larsen). It is limited in North America to west of the Rocky Mountains, but common in Europe, (Harrington), including Switzerland (Breitenbach), United Kingdom (Dennis), Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  2-5(6)cm wide, cup-shaped usually with incurved margin; bright red to scarlet, sometimes fading to reddish orange; smooth^, (Arora), 1-5(8)cm, goblet-shaped then cup-shaped to saucer-shaped, circular to oval in outline from above, "margin remaining turned inward for a long time"; bright red, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  thin but not particularly brittle^ (Arora)
UNDERSIDE  whitish, covered with minute hairs^, (Arora), pink to ocher, with whitish granular flakes, (Breitenbach), white, floccose with more or less matted colorless hairs, (Dennis)
STEM  absent or more often present, up to 4cm long and 0.3-0.7cm wide, narrowing downward; white; minutely hairy^, (Arora), stem short to sometimes very long (on deeply buried wood), (Breitenbach)
ODOR  none in particular^ (Lincoff(1))
TASTE  none in particular^ (Lincoff(1))
EDIBILITY  said to be edible (Arora), mediocre (Lincoff(1))
HABITAT  single or in groups on buried or fallen hardwood sticks or branches, winter and early spring^, (Arora), singly to gregariously on branches of hardwood trees covered with earth or moss, February to May, (Breitenbach for Europe), hardwood twigs and branchlets that have started to decompose and are partly buried within the top 5cm of soil and forest litter, (Harrington)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 24-40 x 10-14 um, elliptic, smooth^, (Arora), spores 29-39 x 9-11(13) um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, usually with many small droplets in both ends, 1-seriate; asci 8-spored, 398-450 x (11.5)13.5 - 15(17) um, inamyloid; paraphyses thin, cylindric, sparsely septate, with red granular contents that turn green in iodine, (Breitenbach), spores 24-32(40) x 12-14 um, elliptic-cylindric with obtuse ends, usually with small oil droplets in two clusters, one at each end; asci to 400 x 16 um; paraphyses slender, 3 um wide, not enlarged near tip, forking near base, with red granular contents, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin meaning "vermilion"^, (Lincoff)
SIMILAR  Prior to 1984 all of the large specimens of Sarcoscypha in North America were identified as Sarcoscypha coccinea but two other species have been recognized, Sarcoscypha dudleyi (Peck) Baral and Sarcoscypha austriaca (Beck ex Sacc.) Boud. These two are not known to occur in the Pacific Northwest, nor is the smaller (0.5-2cm) Sarcoscypha occidentalis (Schw.) Sacc. which fruits in the summer months, (Harrington). Pseudaleuria quinaultiana is more or less disc-shaped typically, is more reddish orange than red, and lacks a stem.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Harrington(1), Dennis(1), Arora(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Lincoff(1)*, Seaver(1), Hansen, L.(1), Larsen(1), Courtecuisse(1)*, Desjardin(6)*, Marrone(1)*
338
FAMILY  Sarcosomataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sarcosoma globosum  (Schmidel) Casp.^  in Winter, Rabenh. Krypt.-Fl., Edn 2 (Leipzig) 1.3(lief. 35): 497 (1891) [1896];  Bulgaria globosa  (Schmidel) Fr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  jelly-pots, witch's-cauldron
NOTES  Also included in Jelly category. Features include a fairly large, irregularly rounded to broadly cylindric fruitbody with the wrinkled dark reddish brown to dark blackish brown exterior incurved over the dark brown spore-bearing surface. The inside of the fruitbody is gelatinous and copious when fresh.^ | The description is derived from Beug(3) except where noted. RANGE ^Several people including Stanford Howells are known to have observed this species on separate occasions in BC. It is widespread but not common. Sarcosoma globosum also occurs in Sweden and Finland (Hansen, L.(1)). MyCoPortal shows herbarium records from many locations including WA, OR, ID, CA, NB, ON, QC, MI, MN, MT, NC, PA, VA, Czech Republic, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Norway, Poland, Russian Federation, Sweden, and the Philippines.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 4.5-12cm wide, "irregularly rounded, dense and heavy", "outer surface incurved over the inner surface" so that the inner surface occurs in a well-defined depression at the top of the fruitbody; inner surface cup-shaped, blackish brown, smooth to finely cracked^, (Beug), spore-bearing surface "even, dark brownish to black", (Hansen, L.)
FLESH  "interior gelatinous with a copious amount of water when fresh"
UNDERSIDE  "deeply wrinkled and folded, roughened, fibrous-tough and elastic"; "dark reddish brown to blackish brown when wet", "pinkish brown to yellowish brown or dingy brown when dry", "often mottled and streaked as the fruitbody dries out"
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, scattered, or in groups "on needle debris or among mosses, in conifer woods", "spring and early summer"^, (Beug), in "deep moss in old coniferous forests", winter to early summer, (Hansen, L.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (20)23-30 x 7-12 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, uniseriate in ascus^; asci "cylindric to subcylindric"; "paraphyses slender, adhering together in masses, dark brown, with enlarged tips", (Beug), spores 20-30 x 7-10 um, without droplets, (Hansen, L.)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'spherical'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Beug(3)*, Hansen, L.(1)
339
FAMILY  Pezizaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sarcosphaera coronaria  (Jacq. ex Cooke) Boud.^  Icones Mycologicae (Paris): pl. 302. 1893;  Sarcosphaera crassa  (Santi) Pouzar;  Sarcosphaera eximia  (Durieu & Lev.) Maire;  Sarcosphaera dargelasii  (Gachel) Nannf.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  violet star cup, pink crown, crown fungus, violet crowncup
NOTES  Also listed in Truffles category. Features include 1) hollow spherical fruitbodies developing at or below ground level, 2) the outer layer splitting from above into 6-10 rays, revealing the interior that is whitish to grayish then pinkish to purplish, 3) the exterior whitish roughened and dirt-encrusted, and 4) sometimes a short stem-like base.^ RANGE ^Sarcosphaera coronaria is found at least in BC, WA, OR, ID, and also AB, AZ, CA, CO, NM, UT, (Larson). It also occurs in MI, NY, (Lincoff(2)), Switzerland (Breitenbach), United Kingdom (Dennis), Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen). See a note on p.17 Pfister(5) concerning the authority.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  at first a spherical to flattened or lobed ball 3-10cm across, usually with soft spot or slight depression at top, the wall splitting downward from this spot to form pointed segments or rays (usually 6-10) that open up part way to form deep cup, 5-20cm across; spore-bearing inner (upper) surface "usually whitish to grayish at first, but becoming grayish-pink to pinkish, lilac, purple, or purple-brown in age", smooth or breaking into fine scales^, (Arora), 3-10(20)cm across, when young forming a hollow ball, embedded in ground, then opening at top to form a rounded hole with margin that later splits to form star-shape; inner surface pale violet when young, then violet to brown-violet, smooth, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  rather thick but brittle; whitish^, (Arora)
UNDERSIDE  whitish to creamy; scurfy or rough, usually dirt-incrusted^, (Arora), whitish to gray-white, (Breitenbach), grayish white with violaceous tinge, (Hansen)
STEM  usually but not always present as a short thick narrowed base up to 3cm long, (Arora), without stem (Breitenbach)
ODOR  none in particular^ (Lincoff(1))
TASTE  none in particular^ (Lincoff(1))
EDIBILITY  not recommended: a few people are adversely affected by it, (Arora), edible cooked, but indigestible for some, poisonous raw, (Lincoff(1))
HABITAT  single to gregarious in clusters of 2-5, developing at or below ground level, but usually exposed or partly exposed when mature, common under western conifers, found in spring but also summer and fall^, (Arora), single or clustered in hardwood and coniferous forest, park grounds, path borders, ground, street gravel, needle litter, (Breitenbach), in spring, often near melting snow, (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores "14-22 x 7-9 um, elliptic with blunt or truncate ends, smooth or very slightly roughened, with 1-3 (usually 2) oil droplets"^, (Arora), spores 13.5-18 x 7-8.5 um, broadly elliptic with blunt ends, smooth, colorless, with 2 oil droplets; asci 8-spored, 300-360 x 10-13 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses cylindric, septate, some forked at base, tips with slight clavate widening to 5-6(7) um, (Breitenbach), spores 15-22 x 7-9 um, smooth to minutely verrucose, (Castellano), spores 15-16.5 x 8-10 um, verruculose under oil immersion; asci cylindric, (Hansen), spores 13-15 x 7-8 um, broadly elliptic with rather abruptly truncated ends, colorless, with 2 oil drops; asci about 300-360 x 12-13 um, stained blue at tip by iodine; paraphyses septate constricted at septa, often once or twice branched in upper part, "the apical cell up to 7 um wide, with brownish sap", (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to a crown'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Arora(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Breitenbach(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Trudell(4)*, Castellano(2)*, Phillips(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Miller(14)* (as Sarcosphaeria crassa), Ammirati(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Lincoff(2)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Lincoff(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Courtecuisse(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), McKnight(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Dennis(1) (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Hansen, L.(1), Larsen(1), Pfister(5), AroraPocket(1)* (as Sarcosphaera crassa), Buczacki(1)*, Desjardin(6)*, Marrone(1)*, McAdoo(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
340
FAMILY  Trapeliaceae, Order Baeomycetales, Class Lecanoromycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sarea resinae  (Fr.) Kuntze^  Revis. gen. pl. (Leipzig) 3(2): 515. 1898;  Biatorella resinae (Fr.) Th. Fr.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Fruitbodies grow on resinous exudates of conifers. They are tiny and plate-shaped with upturned margins, pale orange with a paler margin, and smooth. Each ascus contains innumerable small round spores.^ | The conidial stage, known under the name Pycnidiella resinae (Fr.) v. Hoehn., is more common than the ascus stage. Its place in the classification of fungi is uncertain - Dictionary of the Fungi Tenth Edition has ?Leotiomycetes. RANGE ^The species is widespread, including Europe. There are numerous collections from BC at the Canadian Forestry Centre. There are collections from BC and MI at the University of British Columbia, a collection from WA at the University of Washington, and collections from OR and CA at Oregon State University.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.1cm across, goblet-shaped becoming plate-shaped with margin bent up; pale orange, margin somewhat lighter; smooth^, (Breitenbach), up to 0.15cm across, cup-shaped, "disc flat or slightly convex with a low margin"; orange; smooth, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  pale orange; smooth^, (Breitenbach), orange (Dennis)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach, Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to densely crowded, on "resinous exudates of conifers"^ (Breitenbach), on "resinous exudations on the bark on conifers, often associated with the conidial state", "and on coniferous stumps, in winter and spring", (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores +/- 2 um, rounded, smooth^; asci 90 x 20 um, many-spored, thick-walled; paraphyses cylindric, "with few septa, sometimes forked and slightly thickened at the tips", (Breitenbach), spores 2-3 um across, round, colorless; asci up to 100 x 20 um, (turning deep blue in iodine), clavate, broadly rounded in upper part, thick-walled, packed with innumerable spores that are "slightly yellowish in the mass"; paraphyses "slender, sometimes forked, swollen at the tips", (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to its growth on resin
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Biatorella resinae), Dennis(1) (as Biatorella resinae)
341
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sclerotinia juncigena  (Ellis & Everh.) Whetzel^  Farlowia 2: 432. 1946;  Ciboria juncigena  Ellis & Everh.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Sclerotinia juncigena produces small reddish brown stemmed cups growing in culms of Juncus (reed).^ RANGE ^It was described from WA. The description is derived from Seaver(2).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.4-0.5cm wide, cup-shaped, shallow, somewhat umbilicate, thin membranous; reddish brown
FLESH  thin
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  reaching 1cm x 0.1cm, attached in lower part to a spreading dark hyphal mat, sclerotia reaching 1.5cm x 0.2cm, "one, possibly more within a diseased culm, slender, cylindric, and truncate, slightly rounded ends", "externally black, sulcate, internally white when mature, enclosed in a cavity in the pith region of the culm"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  in culms of Juncus, usually one fruitbody from each sclerotium
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-9 x 1-1.5 um, allantoid (curved sausage-shaped), slender, colorless^; asci 8-spored, reaching 60 x 4-5 um, clavate-cylindric, paraphyses not seen
NAME ORIGIN  refers to host Juncus
SIMILAR  Another cup species apparently limited to Juncus is Lachnum apalum (Berk. & Broome) Nannf. Haines(1) reported this species from the University of Washington Arboretum in his Masters of Science thesis (as Dasyscyphus hapalus which should be Dasyscyphus apalus). He says it is up to 0.1cm across, up to 0.15cm high, white with a slight reddish tinge, covered by hairs when dry. The stem is up to 0.1cm x 0.02cm. Spores measuring 30-40 x 1.5 um are colorless, 1-septate or more, filled with refractive droplets, 6-8 spores parallel in an ascus that measures 50-65 x 5-7 um. Paraphyses are lanceolate, colorless, usually without refractive droplets, up to 20 um longer than asci, 2.5-3 um at widest point. Colorless hairs are 2.5-3 um wide, up to 100 um long, 0-2-septate, and densely covered with minute granules. The excipulum is composed of colorless, relatively thin-walled prismatic cells measuring approximately 12 x 8 um. It is also described on dead Juncus in Dennis(1) as very common in Britain. Dennis(1) says Dasyscyphus diminutus with spores 10-15 um long and Dasyscyphus fugiens with spores 6-8 um long also occur on dead Juncus. A number of other Sclerotinia species occur in the Pacific Northwest: the herbarium at the University of British Columbia has collections from BC named as Sclerotinia sclerotiorum (6) and Sclerotinia trifoliorum (2) (as well as several now considered to be in other genera).
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Kroeger(5), Haines(1) (regarding Lachnum apalum), Dennis(1) (regarding various species)
342
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sclerotinia veratri  E.K. Cash & R.W. Davidson^  Mycologia 25(4): 267. 1933
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Sclerotinia veratri produces small, yellow-brown to red-brown to vinaceous-brown stemmed cups on Veratrum spp. growing from a blackish crust or a rice-grain-shaped sclerotium.^ RANGE ^It is reported at least from BC on Veratrum viride (Kroeger(5)), from CA (MykoWeb), and from CO (type on Veratrum californicum, in Davidson, R.W.(3)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  usually 0.3-0.7cm across, sometimes larger up to 1cm, reddish brown, cup-shaped at first, with inrolled margins, becoming almost flat; spore-bearing surface brown becoming lighter grayish brown when mature; wrinkled when dry, (Davidson, R.W.), 0.15-1cm across, shallowly cup-shaped; ochre-brown to dull vinaceous-brown; moist, bald, margin lacking hairs (MykoWeb)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  similar to interior^ (MykoWeb)
STEM  0.5-1cm x 0.05-0.1cm, "black, swollen toward the base"; sclerotia are "flat, elliptical to irregularly elongate, embedded in stems and, when infection is severe, diffused over considerable area, dark reddish brown to black, white within, 3-7 mm. long by 1-3 mm. broad and 1 mm. thick", (Davidson, R.W.), up to 2.5cm long, 0.05-0.1cm wide, equal or widened at top; tan, ocher-brown to dark reddish brown; bald to inconspicuously patchy-tomentose; "arising from a blackish crust or rice-grain-shaped sclerotium", (MykoWeb)
ODOR  not distinctive^ (MykoWeb)
TASTE  not distinctive^ (MykoWeb)
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious on stems of rotting Veratrum spp. (corn-lily), fruiting in the spring shortly after snow melt^, (MykoWeb(1)), type on Veratrum californicum in Colorado: the sclerotia were often observed on old stems but cups seldom found, (Davidson, R.W.)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 15-17.6 x 5-6.5 um, oblong-elliptic, colorless, unicellular, with 2 droplets, irregularly 1-seriate^; asci 140-150 x 11-13 um, cylindric, "attenuated near base, wall thickened at apex"; paraphyses 2-2.5 um wide at apex, "filiform, septate, simple or branched near the base, pale brown", (Davidson, R.W.), spores 14.5-19.0 x 5.5-6.5 um, elliptic, "smooth, thin-walled with two to several oil droplets"; asci 8-spored, uniseriate, (MykoWeb)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Veratrum', referring to the host
SIMILAR  A number of other Sclerotinia species occur in the Pacific Northwest: the herbarium at the University of British Columbia has collections from BC named as Sclerotinia sclerotiorum (6), and Sclerotinia trifoliorum (2) (as well as several now considered to be in other genera).
SOURCES  Davidson, R.W.(3), MykoWeb(1), Kroeger(5), Desjardin(6)*
343
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scutellinia crucipila  (Cooke & W. Phillips in Cooke) J. Moravec^  Ces. Mykol. 38: 149. 1984;  Cheilymenia crucipila  (Cooke & W Phillips) Le Gal;  Patella crucipila  (Cooke & W. Phillips in Cooke) Seaver;  Cheilymenia calvescens  Boud.;  = Humaria stellata  Kanouse
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a saucer-shaped to disc-shaped fruiting body with a bright orange to orange-red spore-bearing upper surface, abundant hairs of two types on the exterior (branched brownish ones at the base of the cup), growth on soil, and microscopic characters.^ | The fungus described as Humaria crucipila (Cke. & Phil.) Kanouse differs in color (pale ocher-yellow) and growth on sticks, and could be a new species. RANGE ^Scutellinia crucipila is found at least in WA and ID, (Larsen as Cheilymenia), WA (Seaver as Patella), and WA, NY, and Great Britain (Denison as Cheilymenia).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.4cm, saucer-shaped to disc-shaped, bright orange to orange-red, fading slightly on drying^, (Denison), 0.2-0.8(1)cm across, conic when young, "then flat and saucer-shaped, expanded", margin turned somewhat upward; bright orange to orange-red, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  hairs abundant, of two types, the marginal ones unbranched, those lower down mostly stellate branched^, (Denison), paler than upper surface, loosely set with inconspicuous light brownish hairs, margin sparsely ciliated with similar hairs, (Breitenbach)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered on soil^ (Denison), single to crowded together in troops, on damp bare ground, on path edges, in ruts, under grasses and herbs; June to August, (Breitenbach), "among mosses or on bare ground under grasses and other herbaceous plants", (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (13)15-18(20) x (7)8-9(10) um, elliptic, appearing smooth at low magnification, but with fine warts under oil immersion, without oil droplets^; asci 180-220 um long, cylindric, not blueing in iodine; paraphyses slender, 2-3 um wide with subclavate apices 4-7 um wide; marginal hairs unbranched 100-200(500) x 8-13 um, 2-5 septate, tapering upward to pointed or rounded tip, rooting in the medullary excipulum but with a single root, the lower ones "similar but mostly stellately branched, with 2-5 divergent arms 75-150 um long", (Denison), spores 17-19 x 9-10 um, narrowly elliptic, "dotted with fine warts, some connected with ridges", colorless, without drops; asci 8-spored, 240 x 10 um, iodine negative; paraphyses cylindric, tips with clavate thickenings to 10 um, septate and forked; hairs on margin and upper part of the fruitbody to 280 x 25 um, "straight, ending in a blunt tip, multiply septate, some with forked to lobed roots on the base, light brownish, with light tips", hairs toward the base of the fruitbody branched into 2-5 arms, also light brownish, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with cross-like hairs'
SIMILAR  The basal hairs are similar to those of Cheilymenia stercorea, but that species is smaller, grows on dung, is ciliated with bristles on the margin, and has smooth spores, (Breitenbach). See also SIMILAR section of Cheilymenia fimicola, Cheilymenia theleboloides, and Scutellinia scutellata.
SOURCES  Denison(1) (as Cheilymenia), Seaver(1) (as Patella), Breitenbach(1)* (as Cheilymenia), Trudell(4), Larsen(1) (as Cheilymenia), Moravec(1)
344
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scutellinia erinaceus  (Schwein.) Kuntze^  Rev. Gen. Pl. 2: 869. 1891;  == Trichophaea erinaceus  (Schwein.) Le Gal;  == Lachnea erinaceus  (Schwein.) Sacc.;  = Patella setosa  sensu Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a disc-shaped to slightly concave, stemless fruitbody, dull orange color with overtones of yellow or brown, dense dark brown hairs on the exterior, gregarious growth on rotten wood, and microscopic characters.^ | "erinaceus" keeps its masculine ending because it is a noun. RANGE ^Scutellinia erinaceus is found in ID, UT, (Larsen), WA (Kanouse), and ON, CO, ME, MO, NC, ND, NY, OH, PA, VT, WV, Nicaragua, and Panama, (Denison).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.3(0.4)cm, disc-shaped to slightly concave; dull orange with overtones of yellow or brown rather than red, fading to whitish on drying^, (Denison)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  densely clothed with hairs^ (Seaver)
STEM  none^ (Denison)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  intensely gregarious, but rarely so crowded as to be distorted by mutual pressure, on well rotted deciduous wood, July to December^, (Denison)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (14)17-21(26) x (9)11.5(15) um, average length to width ratio 1.7, long elliptic, smooth, "cytoplasmic granules sometimes giving the illusion of very fine markings under an oil-immersion objective"^; asci 8-spored, 270-325 x 12-15 um; paraphyses clavate or subclavate, 2-5 um wide at tops, filled with orange granules when fresh; rooting hairs (with rootlets at base) abundant, (100)400-600(700) um long and (20)28(40) um wide at base, inconspicuously septate, dark brown, pointed at tip, or rarely blunt or with a constriction, "many collections having some hairs that are distinctly crooked or that have short prong-like lateral branchlets; superficial hairs lacking or very inconspicuous", (Denison)
NAME ORIGIN  from "erinaceus" meaning "hedgehog"
SIMILAR  Scutellinia scutellata is redder, has some longer hairs, and has broader spores with barely visible warts, (Denison).
SOURCES  Denison(2), Seaver(1) (as Patella erinaceus), Larsen(1), Kanouse(6) (as Humaria erinacea)
345
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scutellinia scutellata  (L. ex Fr.) Lambotte^  Fl. Myc. Belge Suppl. 1: 299. 1887;  Humaria scutellata  (L. ex Fr.) Fuckel;  Lachnea scutellata  (L. ex Fr.) Gillet;  Patella scutellata  (L. ex Fr.) Morgan;  = Scutellinia lusatiae  (Cooke) Kuntze;  = Patella lusatiae  (Cooke) Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  eyelash pixie cup, eyelash cup, eyelash fungus, common eyelash
NOTES  Features include a bright red to orange shallow cup-shaped stemless fruiting body with dark brown bristle-like hairs on the margin and exterior, growth on wood or soil, and microscopic characters including hairs with rootlets at the base.^ RANGE ^Scutellinia scutellata is found in BC, WA, OR, ID, and also AB, AK, CA, CO, and NM, (Larsen), AL, IN, IA, LA, MI, NC, NY, VA, United Kingdom, Germany, and Sweden, (Denison).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-1.2cm wide, cup-shaped becoming shallowly concave or disc-shaped; orange to red, rarely paler with a pinkish or salmon cast^, (Denison), 0.5-1(2)cm wide, "spherical and knoblike when young, then conical to saucer-shaped, expanded at maturity to become flat and disk-shaped with a turned-up margin"; bright scarlet; margin thickly fringed with dark brown bristle-like hairs, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  very thin^ (Arora)
UNDERSIDE  covered with dark brown bristle-like hairs^ (Breitenbach), paler on lower surface (Lincoff(1)), light brown, clothed with stiff dark brown or blackish hairs, (Dennis)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  no (Phillips)
HABITAT  scattered to gregarious "on rotten wood, bark, or soil; less often on a variety of other substrates: e.g., wood ashes, decaying leaves, and rotting sporophores of Fomes spp.; throughout the growing season"^, (Denison), gregarious to thickly clustered, sometimes single, on damp rotten wood, (Breitenbach), spring, summer, fall, (Bacon)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (15)17-19(23) x (9)11-14(17) um, average length/width 1.5, "sculpturing small, 0.1-1.0 um broad, freely anastomosing warts, not visible in optical section", containing one or more droplets^; asci 8-spored, 240-320 x 15-20 um; paraphyses subcylindric to narrowly clavate, 3-5 um wide in lower part, 5-9 um wide in upper part, simple or rarely branched in lower part; rooting hairs abundant to scattered (100)200-700(1300) um long, "the longest ones concentrated at the margin, 2-12-septate, dark brown, pointed, straight or slightly curved at the base, not abruptly crooked, simple; superficial hairs usually present", (Denison), spores 19-21 x 13-13.5 um, broadly elliptic, colorless, with granular dots, with many small droplets when young; asci 8-spored, 253-266 x 18-20 um, inamyloid; paraphyses clavate, up to 10 um wide at tip; hairs to 1000(2000) um x 45 um, dark brown, thick-walled, with multiple thin septa, ending in sharp point, base with rootlets, (Breitenbach), hairs up to 1000 um with forked bases rooted in the flesh, sap of paraphyses green in iodine, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin meaning "bowl-shaped" or "flat", (Lincoff(1)), "scutella" is Latin for "a little dish", (Denison), "scutellate" is a botanical term means 'shaped like a shield or platter'
SIMILAR  Scutellinia umbrarum has larger spores with distinct rounded warts evenly spread over the spore (Denison). Scutellinia verrucipolaris has spores with warts concentrated at poles (Denison). Scutellinia crucipila has hairs of two types (unbranched and stellately branched) (Denison). Scutellinia erinaceus has orange to yellow color, smooth spores, and short hairs (Denison). The hairs with rootlets are shared by Cheilymenia species, but the spores of Cheilymenia species are smooth and without oil droplets, (Denison). Melastiza chateri is a little larger, with less dense smaller hairs of a different structure, and spores with a conspicuous network; under a hand lens, the hairs of S. scutellata are stiff, brown, and bristle-like, whereas the hairs of M. chateri can be seen as soft, shorter, brown, and matted together, giving a streaky rather than spiny appearance, (McKnight).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Denison(2), Dennis(1), Arora(1)*, Phillips(1)*, Miller(14)*, Lincoff(2)*, Lincoff(1)*, Larsen(1), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Courtecuisse(1)*, McKnight(1) (and discussing Melastiza chateri), Bacon(1)*, Buczacki(1)*, Desjardin(6)*, Marrone(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
346
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scutellinia umbrarum  (Fr.) Lambotte^;  Scutellinia umbrorum  (Fr.) Lambotte  Fl. Myc. Belge. Supp. 1: 300. 1887;  Humaria umbrorum  (Fr.) Fuckel;  Patella umbrorum  (Fr.) Seaver;  Lachnea umbrorum  (Fr.) Gillet
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a saucer-shaped, orange-red, stemless fruitbody with dark brown, bristle-like hairs on the margin and on the exterior, growth on soil or occasionally on wood or plant debris, and microscopic characters including hairs with rootlets and warted spores.^ | If the species epithet is derived from 'umbra', "umbrorum" would appear to be a mistaken masculine plural genitive, used instead of the correct feminine ending "umbrarum", but see also NAME ORIGIN section. Both the online Species Fungorum and MycoBank, accessed February 3, 2017, give the current name as Scutellinia umbrorum. RANGE ^Scutellinia umbrarum is found in BC, ID, AK, AZ, CA, CO, and NM, (Larsen), and MI, NY, WV, France, and Germany, (Denison).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.8-2cm, shallow cup-shaped to disc-shaped or contorted; orange to red, (Denison), 0.3-0.8(1)cm, becoming saucer-shaped and spread out flat, sometimes rather umbilicate; dull orange red; thick fringe of dark brown bristle-like hairs on margin, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  "thickly ciliate" with dark brown bristle-like hairs^ (Breitenbach), appearing dark brown (Phillips)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to single on soil or trash, rarely on fragments of rotten wood embedded in moist soil, May to November^, (Denison), singly to cespitose and in troops on damp bare ground, rotten wet wood and plant debris, May to October, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (19)20-24(26) x (12)14-16(18) um, average length to width ration 1.4, with distinct rounded warts 0.5-1.5 um wide and high, scattered over surface, when mature spores with one, less often two droplets^; asci 8-spored, 240-320 x 15-20 um; paraphyses almost cylindric to narrowly clavate, 3.5 um wide in lower part, 5-9 um wide near tip, simple or rarely branched in lower part; rooting hairs abundant, rather short (75)150-700(900), 2-8-septate, dark brown, pointed; superficial hairs absent or inconspicuous, when present often heavy walled, stout, and very short, (Denison), spores 19-20 x 13-14 um (not including warts), warts projecting 0.5-1 um; asci 8-spored, 240-270 x 19-21 um, inamyloid; paraphyses "cylindrical, septate and forked at the base, tips with clavate thickenings to 8 um"; hairs "260-400 x 19 um, individual hairs to 920 x 23 um, brown, thick-walled, relatively sparsely septate, almost cylindrical, ending in a sharp point, base with simple to forked roots", (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin "umbra" = "shade", meaning 'of the shadows'; 'umbrorum' would mean 'of the Umbri' (a people of central Italy)
SIMILAR  Scutellinia scutellata has smaller smoother spores and longer hairs (Denison). Scutellinia verrucipolaris has narrower spores with the warts concentrated at the ends, (Denison).
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Denison(2), Seaver(1) (as Patella umbrorum), Larsen(1), Phillips(1)* (as Scutellinia umbrorum)
347
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Scutellinia verrucipolaris  Denison^  Mycologia 51: 621. 1959
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small, stemless, red cup growing on soil, with relatively short hairs, and microscopic characters including spores that have warts distributed at the poles of the spore.^ | The description is derived from Denison(2). RANGE ^Scutellinia verrucipolaris was described originally from NY and is found also in WA (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.8cm, concave; "scarlet" to "grenadine red", 
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  rooting hairs moderately abundant, superficial hairs also present, especially abundant toward base
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on soil and occasionally wood
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (17)19-22(24) x (7.5)9-11 um, average length to width ratio 2.0, with discrete rounded or subtruncate warts reaching a height and width of 1 um, "the largest warts most numerous toward the poles, in the equatorial region most of the warts much smaller, 0.15-0.5 um broad, and barely visible in optical section", two droplets present in spores^; asci 8-spored, 240-300 um long; paraphyses 2-3 um wide at base, enlarging to 6-9 um just below tip, narrowly clavate to subfusiform; rooting hairs [with rootlets at base] 100-400(500) um long, septate, dark brown, pointed, a few bent or crooked; superficial hairs colorless, 2-3-septate
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with warts at poles', referring to spores
SIMILAR  Scutellinia umbrarum also has red color and warts on spores, but has warts evenly distributed on spores that are wider. See also SIMILAR section of Scutellinia scutellata.
SOURCES  Denison(2), Larsen(1)
348
FAMILY  Sarcosomataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Selenaspora guernisacii  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan) R. Heim & Le Gal^  Rev. Mycol. (Paris) 18: 88. 1953;  == Ascobolus guernisacii  P. Crouan & H. Crouan;  == Humaria guernisacii  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan) Quel.;  == Ascophanus guernisacii  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan) Sacc.;  Selenaspora batava  R. Heim & Le Gal
