ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include charcoal-gray fruiting body at first covered with a grayish veil that leaves remnants at the margin, absent stem, growth among mosses in a burned area, and microscopic characters including spore shape in side view like a section of an orange.^ RANGE ^Selenaspora guernisacii has been found in OR and France, and reported from the Netherlands.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.15-0.35cm, from above regular to mutually compressed, in side view nearly columnar to slightly flaring, 0.15-0.3cm tall at maturity, when young truncate-pulvinate to rounded-pulvinate; medium to dark charcoal-gray; veil covering immature spore-bearing upper surface, charcoal to brownish gray, membranous, after rupture remnants persisting as more or less fleeting flanges of tissue, no marginal hairs
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  dark brownish gray in upper part, paler to grayish white toward base; bald in upper part, giving rise to contorted brown anchoring hyphae near base
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "In Oregon cespitose to gregarious, rarely scattered, among mosses (especially Funaria hygrometrica Hedw.) on soil where logging slash had been burned 12-16 months earlier", from France "on old walls and slaty slopes, among small mosses", from Netherlands "sur fiente animal, entre les mousses sur une place a charbon"
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 34.8-52.0 x 15.6-23.4 um for one collection, 37.7-49.4 x 16.3-20.1 um for another, in face view elliptic, in side view shaped like a lima-bean or half-moon or section of an orange, smooth, colorless to (sometimes) very pale brown when discharged, with variable number of droplets, often two prominent droplets, one near each end, and many small ones, spores irregularly overlapping and nearly filling asci at maturity^; asci 8-spored, 270-286(306) x 18.2-23.4(29.7) um, with apical to (rarely) very eccentric operculum, iodine -, with "paired basal inconspicuous scars then a short neck expanding into a broad sporogenous zone and a broad truncate apex; with walls slightly but distinctly thickened, hyaline or occasionally very pale brown when collapsed"; paraphyses straight, narrowly clavate to irregular, 2.6-5.2(10.4) um near top, 2.6-3.9 um lower down, forking and anastomosing at all levels, pale brown near top, sometimes paler toward base, septate, cells with 2-4 nuclei
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Weber(2)

FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Smardaea planchonis  (Dunal ex Boud.) Korf & W.Y. Zhuang^  Mycotaxon 40: 427. 1991;  == Plicaria planchonis  Dunal ex Boud.;  == Lamprospora planchonis  (Dunal ex Boud.) Seaver;  == Pulparia planchonis  (Dunal ex Boud.) Korf, Pfister & J.K. Rogers;  = Marcelleina atroviolacea  (Delile ex De Seynes) Brumm.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include cup to disc shape, dark purple color, sometimes scalloped margin, exterior that is darker purple and minutely warted, growth on sandy soil, and microscopic characters.^ | The description is derived from Seaver. RANGE ^It is found in WA (Larsen), and Bermuda (very common) and Europe (Seaver).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.5-0.8cm wide, concave-hemispheric or nearly disc-shaped, regular or irregularly contorted; dark purple; margin crenate [scalloped] or even
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  dark purple or almost black (upper surface a little paler); minutely warted
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious or scattered on sandy soil by roadsides, hillsides and on sand-dunes
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores reaching a diameter of 10-12 um, round or nearly round, smooth or very minutely sculptured at maturity with minute warts that barely roughen the surface of the spore, spores at first colorless, becoming pale purplish, containing one to several oil drops, uniseriate^; asci reaching a length of 200 um and a width of 13-15 um; paraphyses clavate, reaching 6 um wide at tip, filled with purple granules
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as Lamprospora planchonis (Dun.) Seaver, giving Plicaria planchonis Dun.; Boud. as synonym, that name was given by online Species Fungorum, accessed Oct. 2, 2005, as synonym of this species), Larsen(1) (as Pulparia plachonis, given as Pulparia planchonis by Pfister as new name for Lamprospora planchonis (Dun.) Seaver)

FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Sowerbyella rhenana  (Fuckel) J. Moravec^  Mycol. Helv. 2: 93-102.  1988;  Aleuria rhenana  Fuckel
ENGLISH NAME(S)  stalked orange-peel fungus
NOTES  Features include a stemmed cup that is orange to yellow-orange with pale orange to white underside and stem, and guttulate reticulate spores that lack an apiculus.^ | (Castellano). RANGE ^It is found in WA, ID, CA and known from Europe and Japan, (Castellano). There are collections from OR deposited at Oregon State University. It was photographed by Kem Luther on Vancouver Island in BC.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 1-2.5cm wide, shallowly broadly cup-shaped to nearly flat when old, compressed to regular; bright orange to yellow-orange, margin incurved becoming straight to flaring when old, sometimes cracking when old, lacking prominent hairs^, (Castellano)
FLESH  thin, brittle^, (Arora)
UNDERSIDE  pale orange to white, typically with inconspicuous colorless appressed hairs^, (Castellano)
STEM  up to 0.5-2cm in length and 0.2-0.5cm in width, narrowing downwards, often several stems together; colored as exterior; also with hairs^, (Castellano), 1-3cm x 0.2-0.5cm, equal or narrowing downward; colored like exterior; base often arising from dense mass of white mycelium that may bind several stems together, (Arora)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to gregarious or cespitose in duff of moist, relatively undisturbed, older coniferous forests^, (Castellano), gregarious, often in small clusters, on ground or moss in woods (usually under conifers), (Arora)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 18-23.6(26.3) x 9-11.8 um (not including ornamentation), "ornamented with a reticulum, the meshes 1.5 to 4 um broad, mostly 6-sided, ridges to 1.5 um tall, apiculus absent", guttulate^; asci 8-spored, thin-walled; paraphyses "curved or straight, containing orange granules, fleetingly green when mounted in Melzer's reagent", (Castellano), spores 20-23 x 11-13 um, elliptic, coarsely reticulate at maturity, (Arora)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Neottiella rutilans is a similar moss-inhabiting species with slightly larger spores and longer hairs on the underside, (Arora).
SOURCES  Castellano(1)*, Arora(1)* (as Aleuria rhenana), Trudell(4)* (as Aleuria rhenana), Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2)*
351
FAMILY  Stictidaceae, Order Ostropales, Class Lecanoromycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Stictis chrysopsis  Ellis & Everh.^  Proc. Acad. nat. Sci. Philad. 46(3): 353. 1894
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Stictis chrysopsis forms tiny goblets immersed in the surface of woody plants in dry regions, with a whitish ring-shaped pruinose margin that emerges from the substrate, the spore-bearing surface on the floor of the goblet dark ochraceous.^ | The description is derived from Sherwood(2). RANGE ^Stictis chrysopsis is from western North America - collections were examined from WA (holotype), OR, and CA, (Sherwood).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.15-0.25cm in diameter, "with an annulate margin and an dark ochraceous disc", fruitbodies "at first immersed, remaining for a long time closed and covered by a dome-shaped white-pruinose peridium which separates from the surrounding wood, finally opening by a longitudinal slit (rarely by a pore)"; the spore-bearing disc dark ochraceous
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  immersed in the substrate
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on a variety of woody plants, apparently characteristic of dry interior regions
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 250-275 x 2.0 um, septate, the cells 5-7 um long^, asci 8-spored, 300 x 6-7 um long; paraphyses numerous, filiform, 1.0 um wide below, enlarged to 2.0 um at the apex, often branched
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Stictis radiata and Stictis ostropoides also occur on Lonicera (Sherwood). There are many other Stictis species beyond those included here, some of which probably occur in the Pacific Northwest. Several have been recorded from CA and another from MT in the Sherwood(2) monograph.
SOURCES  Sherwood(2)
352
FAMILY  Stictidaceae, Order Ostropales, Class Lecanoromycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Stictis ostropoides  Sherwood^  Mycotaxon 5(1): 220. 1977.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Stictis ostropoides forms tiny somewhat elongate goblets immersed in Lonicera or Scrophularia plant material, with a pale gray-pruinose margin that emerges and opens by a longitudinal slit, the spore-bearing surface on the floor of the goblet pale ochraceous.^ | The description is derived from Sherwood(2). It is apparently quite common (Sherwood). RANGE ^The distribution is in western North America and collections were examined from OR (including holotype) and CA (Sherwood)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody about 0.08-0.1 x 0.1-0.15 um ("elongate"), "at first immersed, opening by splitting the overlying bark into irregular lobes", "pale gray-pruinose", "the margin remaining for a long time closed and finally opening by a longitudinal slit, the disc deeply urceolate, pale ochraceous"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  immersed in host
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on Lonicera and Scrophularia
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 190-200 x 2.0 um, the cells 2.5-3.5 um long^; asci 8-spored, 200-220 x 6(8) um, paraphyses numerous, filiform, 1.0 um wide in lower part, "simple, colorless, not enlarged above", iodine negative; margin in cross section about 80 um thick, "consisting of tightly packed, gelatinous, branched periphysoids" measuring 80 x 1.5-2.0 um
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Stictis radiata and Stictis chrysopsis also occur on Lonicera (Sherwood). There are many other Stictis species beyond those included here, some of which probably occur in the Pacific Northwest. Several have been recorded from CA and another from MT in the Sherwood(2) monograph.
SOURCES  Sherwood(2)
353
FAMILY  Stictidaceae, Order Ostropales, Class Lecanoromycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Stictis polycocca  (P. Karst.) P. Karst.^  Acta Soc. Fauna Flora fenn. 2(no. 6): 166 (1885) [1881-1885]
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Stictis polycocca forms tiny goblets immersed in herbaceous stems (or rarely wood), with a thick, dark gray pruinose margin that bulges upward and splits to form lobes, the spore-bearing surface on the floor of the goblet colored brown.^ |The description is derived from Sherwood(2). RANGE ^Stictis polycocca is distributed in Europe, Asia, and western North America - collections were examined from BC, Austria, Finland, Luxemburg, Norway, and Pakistan, (Sherwood)
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.025 x 0.05cm across, "at first immersed, opening by a pore and becoming partially erumpent", "the margin thick, stellately divided, occasionally somewhat annulate, dark grey pruinose, the disc deeply urceolate, brown"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious, on herbaceous debris, rarely on wood
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 150-170 x 1.0-1.2 um, septate, the cells 4-5 um long^; asci 8-spored, 160-180 x 4 um; paraphyses "numerous, filiform", 0.8-1.0 um wide, "sometimes branched, not obviously circinate", iodine negative; periphysoids "numerous, filiform", 20-25 x 1.5-2.0 um, somewhat gelatinous, usually unbranched
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  There are many other Stictis species beyond those included here, some of which probably occur in the Pacific Northwest. Several have been recorded from CA and another from MT in the Sherwood(2) monograph.
SOURCES  Sherwood(2)
354
FAMILY  Stictidaceae, Order Ostropales, Class Lecanoromycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Stictis radiata  (L.) Pers.^  Observ. mycol. (Lipsiae) 2: 73 (1800) [1799]
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Stictis radiata forms tiny goblets immersed in wood (or occasionally herbaceous stems), with a thick, whitish pruinose margin that bulges upward and splits to form lobes, the spore-bearing surface on the floor of the goblet yellow to red when fresh.^ | The description is derived from Sherwood(2). RANGE ^There are collections of Stictis radiata from BC at the University of British Columbia. It is found "throughout the humid parts of the world", accounting for more than half of Stictis collections from temperate areas, and somewhat less common in the tropics. Collections were examined from OR, CA, OH, PA, NL, Mexico, Bermuda, Jamaica, Panama, Brazil, Ecuador, Peru, Venezuela, France, Germany, Italy, Sweden, United Kingdom, Tristan da Cunha, Canary Islands, South Africa, Japan, Java, India, and Pakistan, (Sherwood(2)). 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^Breitenbach(1) says the base of the hymenium stains blue, and Dennis(1) days the upper part of the hymenium stains deep blue with iodine
UPPER SURFACE  0.04-0.08cm across, irregularly rounded, spore-bearing surface entirely embedded in the wood, "yolk-yellow to bright orange-red", "margin whitish, bulging upward and thickened and splitting to form lobes", (Breitenbach), fruitbodies 0.04-0.10(0.12)cm across, "at first immersed, opening broadly by a pore but not becoming erumpent", "the margin thick, white-pruinose, entire to more commonly lacerate, the disc deeply immersed, pale ochraceous", (Sherwood)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  embedded in wood
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "On bark, decorticated wood, herbaceous stems, and even conifer needles and old leather", (Sherwood), gregarious on wounds on living hardwood trees, fruiting in fall and winter, (Breitenbach), on woody twigs, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores "nearly as long as the asci", 2.0-2.5 um wide, "not sheathing or coiling, septate", the cells 4-6 um long^; asci 8-spored, 120-150 x 5.5-6(8) um; "paraphyses numerous, filiform", 1.0 um thick below, enlarged to 1.5-2.0 um above, "somewhat irregularly branched", iodine positive (rarely iodine negative); periphysoids 15-30 x 1.0-1.5 um, "not markedly gelatinous, branched", (Sherwood), spores 180-200 x 2 um, threadlike, smooth, colorless, "with many droplets, multiply septate when mature"; asci 8-spored, 200-220 x 7-10 um, iodine negative, spores parallel; paraphyses threadlike, some forked toward the tips, (Breitenbach), spores 2-2.5 um wide (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'radiating'
SIMILAR  There are many other Stictis species beyond those described here, some of which probably occur in the Pacific Northwest. Several have been recorded from CA and another from MT in the Sherwood(2) monograph. Stictis stellata, a similar widespread common species examined from Europe, New Jersey, Ohio, Louisiana, Mexico, and South America, grows on herbaceous plants (occasionally wood), but compared with S. radiata it has wider unbranched periphysoids (the only reliable differentiation, 1.5-2.0 um wide), narrower spores (but overlapping at 1.5-2.5 um wide), and a hymenium that does not turn blue in iodine (but S. radiata can be iodine negative), (Sherwood). Sphaerobolus stellatus has empty receptacles that are somewhat reminiscent - Sphaerobolus rosaceus and Sphaerobolus corii are actually two of the synonyms of S. radiata listed in Sherwood(2).
SOURCES  Sherwood(2), Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1)
355
FAMILY  Stictidaceae, Order Ostropales, Class Lecanoromycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Stictis serpentaria  Ellis & Everh.^  Bull. Torrey bot. Club 24(10): 469. 1897
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Stictis serpentaria forms tiny goblets immersed in wood, with a thick, gray-pruinose margin that bulges upward and may split, the spore-bearing surface on the floor of the goblet also gray-pruinose.^ | The description is derived from Sherwood(2). This species is apparently quite rare (Sherwood). RANGE ^The distribution of this species is given as western North American, and an isotype from WA was examined, (Sherwood).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.15-0.3cm across, orbicular, fruitbodies "at first immersed, opening by a pore and becoming somewhat erumpent", "margin thick, grey-pruinose, entire to lacerate, the disc moderately deeply urceolate, also grey-pruinose"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  immersed in substrate
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on wood
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores nearly as long as the asci, 4-5(6) um wide, "sheathed, coiling when freed from the ascus", the cells 3-5 um long^; asci 8-spored, 350-400 x 12-14(20) um; paraphyses "numerous, filiform", 1.0 um wide below, 1.5-2.0 um wide at the tip, once or twice branched apically", iodine-positive, "imbedded in brown amorphous material and forming an epithecium"; periphysoids 40-50 x 1.0-1.5 um, "branched, imbedded in a gelatinous matrix", iodine-negative
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  There are many other Stictis species, some of which probably occur in the Pacific Northwest. Several have been recorded from CA and another from MT in the Sherwood(2) monograph.
SOURCES  Sherwood(2)
356
FAMILY  Sarcosomataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Strobiloscypha keliae  N.S. Weber & Denison^  Mycotaxon 54: 130. 1995.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small bowl-shaped to flat, dull olive-tan to olive-gray fruiting body with light to medium brown underside that is bald apart for a few scattered minute pustules, absent stem, growth on decaying partly buried cones of Chamaecyparis lawsonia or Sequoiadendron giganteum in February, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^It was originally described from OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.15-0.5(0.7)cm, up to 0.2cm high, somewhat turbinate [top-shaped] when young, becoming shallowly bowl-shaped to nearly flat, margin entire, thick, fleshy, slightly raised, not distinctively ornamented; spore-bearing upper surface dull olive tan to olive gray
FLESH  fleshy but not gelatinous
UNDERSIDE  light to medium brown, +/- bald except for a few small appressed hyphal tips near margin that form scattered minute pustules
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on damp decaying cones of Chamaecyparis lawsonia (Port-Orford-cedar) and on cones of Sequoiadendron giganteum (Giant Sequoia), the old cones in each case partly worked into the ground, each fruiting in February
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (18.7)21.0-23.7 x (11.8)12.5-13.2(15.1) um, elliptic, under oil immersion verruculose [finely warty] as viewed in cotton blue in lactic acid, smooth at lower magnifications, colorless, with refractive-granular contents but no distinct large droplets at maturity, obliquely to more often strictly uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 316-368 x 14.5-18.4 um, iodine negative, operculum round and apical to slightly eccentric, apex truncate-rounded, base slender, bearing 1 or 2 well-separated scars, expanding and subflexuous [somewhat wavy] to the spore region, walls distinctly thicker than those of paraphyses; paraphyses straight, narrowly clavate, 5.3-6.6(7.8) um near top, 2.6-3.9 um lower down, septate, forking and anastomosing especially common in lower half, colorless, top cells typically with glassy-refractive contents in water
NAME ORIGIN  honors Keli Kuykendall who made the first collection
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Weber(1)
357
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Stromatinia gladioli  (Massey) Whetzel^  Mycologia 37: 674. 1945;  Sclerotium gladioli  Massey;  Sclerotinia gladioli  Drayton
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Stromatinia gladioli produces umbilicate, convex-discoid, or sometimes convoluted brown fruitbodies with a stem, growing in clusters on Gladiolus, Freesia, and Crocus.^ RANGE ^It is found in the US, Canada, Europe, and New Zealand. A collection from BC is deposited at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-0.7cm wide, 0.6-1cm high, "umbilicate, convex-discoid, sometimes convolute", cinnamon-brown
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  chestnut-brown; growing from sclerotium that is black and 0.009-0.03cm in diameter
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  densely cespitose [in tufts], parasitic on Gladiolus, Freesia, and Crocus
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 10-16 x 5.6-9.5 um, elliptic, colorless, usually with one oil droplet, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching 190-235 x 8-10 um, cylindric to cylindric-clavate; paraphyses abundant, 2.8-3.2 um in diameter at tip, filiform, slightly clavate; microconidia 1.2-1.8 um wide, apparently functioning as spermatia
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Gladiolus'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2)
358
FAMILY  Marasmiaceae, Order Agaricales, Class Agaricomycetes, Phylum Basidiomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Stromatocyphella conglobata  (Burt) W.B. Cooke^  Beih. Sydowia 4: 104. 1961;  == Cyphella conglobata  Burt
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Stromatocyphella conglobata produces minute basidiomycete cups that are densely gregarious on a common stem, (pendant clusters on gelatinous trunk), protruding from lenticels or cracks in the bark of dead branches, usually of alder.^ RANGE ^It is found at least in BC, NB, ON, PQ, MI, NH, NY, and PA, (Ginns).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.3cm diameter, 0.2-0.3cm high, somewhat cup-like dark gray receptacles arising from lenticels, 2-16 to a cluster, fused in lower part or even to the upper edge, arising from a common sclerotic structure 0.1-0.2cm in diameter on the wood or cambium, (Cooke), 0.04-0.12cm in diameter, approximately hemispheric reddish caramel cups, densely gregarious on a common stem, erupting in groups of 5-25 from lenticels in the bark; spore-bearing inner surface concave, reddish caramel like cap or paler honey brown, smooth and satiny; when wet margins appear bald or finely pruinose, (Thorn)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  hairs on outer surface of receptacle brown, (Cooke), reddish caramel; on drying the margins roll inward and the whole fruit body becomes silvery, the exterior appearing pruinose to tomentose, (Thorn)
STEM  rarely short-stemmed or subsessile (Cooke), bases of cups darker, and more coarsely pruinose to tomentose with brown hairs, (Thorn)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  arising from within lenticels on bark of Alnus, Betula, and Juglans cinerea^ (Cooke)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-10 x 3-3.5 um, cylindric, smooth, apiculate, colorless^; basidia appearing at first as fusiform (spindle-shaped) structures with granular contents, finally 20-25 x 7-9 um, 4-spored, with sterigmata 6-7 um long; clamp connections present in subhymenial tissue, surface hairs irregular in length, granule incrusted, with clamp connections, (Cooke), (6.0)8.0-10.0 x 3.0-3.8 um, cylindric, dented on one side or slightly curved, smooth, inamyloid; basidia 4-spored, 23-28 x 6-7.5 um, colorless, clavate; cystidia not seen, (Thorn)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'conglobate' which means 'massed into a ball or (with stem) fused together making a fleshy mass'
SIMILAR  Calathella eruciformis has longer regular colorless surface hairs and smaller basidia and spores.
SOURCES  Cooke(2), Thorn(2), Ginns(5)
359
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Strossmayeria atriseda  (Saut.) Iturr.^  Mycotaxon 36(2): 404. 1990;  == Tapesia atriseda  (Saut.) Poetsch & Schied.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Strossmayeria atriseda produces a minute brown fruitbody growing singly to gregariously on old moist wood, identified by microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^A specimen was examined from BC (Iturriaga).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05 to slightly more than 0.1cm across; disc brown, colored as exterior
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  brown, glossy
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious (but growing individually), on old moist wood that it covers in stellate [star-shaped] fashion, and on barkless wood of Corylus avellana (Common Hazel), (Iturriaga)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (26)30-37 x (3.7)4.4-7.3 um, subfusoid [somewhat spindle-shaped], slightly clavate, J+, colorless, (1)4-5(7)-septate, gel sheath smooth and 0.7(1.5) um wide, generally biseriate but rarely triseriate^; asci 8-spored, (122)131-150(154) x 13-19 um, clavate with long stem tapering down to a fine base, "with brown dextrinoid cytoplasmic contents when young, arising from croziers"; paraphyses exceeding asci by 7.3 um, long and filiform [thread-like], "simple or divided, septate", tip slightly swollen in clavate or irregular shape, 1.5 um wide in the middle, (1.5)2.2 um wide at the tip; ectal excipulum "of textura oblita with very glassy walls, 12-16 um wide in median section, J+ with a strong blue reaction, cells rectangular and elongate", 8-14(18) x (1.5)2.2-2.9 um, apical cells with rounded tips; medullary excipulum and subhymenium not evident; base of fruitbody "composed of brown irregular cells, from which also arise conidiophores of Pseudospiropes", conidiophore "brown, septate, with large scars and a zig-zag shape due to the scars left by the secession of the conidia during sympodial conidiogenesis", (7.3)9.5-15(18) um, "young conidiophores without scars, straight and thin, 7.3 um wide, base slightly swollen", conidiogenous cell "terminal, lighter than the rest of the conidiophore, thin-walled with a round apex less than 0.7 um wide, 21 x 8.8-10 um", conidia (28)33-42 x (10)11-13(18) um, basal scar thickened at the edges, (3.7)4.4-5.9(6.6) um, (3)7(8)-septate, frequently septa very light and difficult to see, "apical and/or basal cells sometimes darker"
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin, meaning "with a black subiculum"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Iturriaga(1)
360
FAMILY  Mollisiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tapesia fusca  (Pers.) Fuckel^  Symb. Myc. 302. 1869;  Mollisia fusca  Karst.;  Tapesia cinerella  Rehm;  Tapesia vincta  Sacc.;  Tapesia subiculata  Sacc.;  Tapesia griseopulveracea  Sacc.;  Tapesia rhois  Fairm.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Some mycologists consider this to be the same species as Mollisia cinerea, in which case Mollisia cinerea is the correct name, Mollisia being conserved against Tapesia. Features include a minute, urn-shaped to saucer-shaped, blue-gray to ocher-gray fruitbody resting on a network of brown filaments on bark and rotting wood, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Tapesia fusca is found from NY to OR and NC, and is probably widely distributed, (Seaver). It is also found in Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach). It has been reported from BC by O. Ceska (pers. comm.).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.2cm across, urceolate [small mouth in relation to body] when young, then cup-shaped to saucer-shaped, later expanded and undulating; spore-bearing upper surface blue-gray to ocher-gray, smooth; margin somewhat lighter in color than upper surface^, (Breitenbach), reaching 0.1cm across, at first urn-shaped, expanding; spore-bearing inner surface pallid-cinereous to pale yellowish, (Seaver)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  blue-gray to ocher-gray, the same color as upper surface^, (Breitenbach), at first black, becoming cinereous-brown or cinereous-yellow, (Seaver)
STEM  absent stem, fruitbody rest on a black-brown felty hyphal network^, (Breitenbach), seated on a widely densely spread out subiculum of brown filaments, (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to cespitose on various kinds of bark and rotting wood, but usually on hardwood trees, spring to fall^, (Breitenbach), scattered or gregarious on wood and bark of various kinds, (Seaver)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 8-12 x 1.8-2.2 um, cylindric-fusiform [cylindric - spindle-shaped], smooth, colorless, without drops or septa, biseriate^; asci 8-spored, 45-50 x 5-7 um, positive reaction to iodine; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], sometimes septate, with slight clavate widening toward tip; subiculum of hyphae 4-7 um wide, dark brown, multiply septate, thick-walled, (Breitenbach), spores 12-14 x 2-3 um, fusoid, usually simple but occasionally doubtfully 1-septate; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 55-68 um and a width of 6-8 um, fusoid-clavate; paraphyses filiform, 2-4 um wide, (Seaver)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'fuscous' color
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Breitenbach(1)*
361
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tarzetta catinus  (Holmsk.) Korf & J.K. Rogers^  in Korf: Phytologia 21(4): 206;  Pustularia catinus  (Holmsk.) Fuckel
ENGLISH NAME(S)  brown bowl fungus
NOTES  Features include cup-shape, cream to pale ochraceous color, scalloped margin, downy felty exterior that is lighter in color, growth on ground, and microscopic characters.^ | The Breitenbach description is for T. catinus (Holmsk. ex Fr.) Korf & J.K. Rogers sensu Dennis (1978). RANGE ^Tarzetta catinus is found in WA, OR, CA, and CO, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  1-4cm, remaining cup-shaped to saucer-shaped for a long time, sometimes becoming expanded and flat when old, or splitting into lobes; cream to hazelnut brown; margin slightly notched when old^, (Breitenbach), 2-5cm, permanently cup-shaped, with somewhat crenate [scalloped] margin; cream to pale ochraceous, (Dennis), dentate serrated margin (Lincoff)
FLESH  thin, fragile^, (Breitenbach), thin, brittle, (Dennis)
UNDERSIDE  same color or somewhat lighter than upper surface; downy-felty^, (Breitenbach), downy with short colorless hairs (Dennis), finely granular (Lincoff)
STEM  usually with +/- long stem embedded in ground^, (Breitenbach), "either sessile with base slightly sunk in soil or seated on a short stout stalk", (Dennis)
ODOR  none in particular^ (Lincoff)
TASTE  none in particular^ (Lincoff)
EDIBILITY  mediocre (Lincoff)
HABITAT  several to gregarious "on the ground in gardens, mulch beds under hardwoods and conifers"; "spring, summer, and fall during wet weather"^, (Miller), single or more rarely crowded together, in forests, in gardens, on roadsides, or on soil, June to September, (Breitenbach for Switzerland), single or in clusters, in woods, especially of Fagus, (Dennis for UK)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-24 x 11-13 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 2 large droplets^; asci 8-spored, 280 x 16 um; inamyloid; paraphyses "slender, septate, and forked toward base, tips slightly thickened to 4 um or lobed", (Breitenbach), spores 20-24 x 11-13 um, elliptic, with 2 large oil drops; asci about 350 x 20 um; paraphyses "slender, septate, often branched below, tips not clavate but often lobed, 3-4 um wide", (Dennis), spores 18-24 x 10-13.5 um (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  from Latin meaning "small bowl", from the shape^, (Lincoff(1))
SIMILAR  Tarzetta cupularis is distinguished by somewhat wider spores, as well as generally smaller size, (Breitenbach following Dennis). T. cupularis has a smaller cup with a shorter stem (Trudell). T. cupularis may also be grayer and lobed tips of paraphyses are not noted. Geopyxis vulcanalis is yellowish, without oil droplets in the spores.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Lincoff(1)*, Miller(14)*, Seaver(1), Larsen(1), Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Courtecuisse(1)*, Trudell(4), Buczacki(1)*
362
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tarzetta cupularis  (L. ex Fr.) Lambotte^  Mem. Soc. roy. Sci. Liege. Ser. 2. 14: 325. 1888;  Pustularia cupularis  (L. ex Fr.) Fuckel
ENGLISH NAME(S)  elf cup, grey goblet
NOTES  Features include small size, goblet to cup shape, grayish ochraceous color, scalloped margin, lighter exterior due to pale down, growth on the ground, and microscopic characters.^ | The Breitenbach description is for T. cupularis (L. ex Fr.) Lambotte sensu Dennis (1978). RANGE ^Tarzetta cupularis is found in BC, WA, OR, ID, CA, and CO, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-1.5(2)cm wide, remaining goblet-shaped to cup-shaped for a long time; gray-whitish to gray-ocher; smooth; margin finely toothed and when young can have a cobwebby appearance^, (Breitenbach), less than 2cm, permanently cup-shaped with crenate [scalloped] margin; grayish ochraceous, (Dennis), 1-2cm wide, tightly cup-shaped even when mature; pale gray-buff, margin irregularly and finely toothed, (Phillips), 1-2cm wide and high, cup-shaped; grayish tan; with rounded-toothed margin, (Lincoff)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  appears lighter due to its covering of fine, pale down^, (Phillips), with brownish pustules (Breitenbach), minutely downy (Dennis)
STEM  indistinct to very distinct, buried in ground^, (Breitenbach), sessile or nearly so (Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  not edible (Phillips)
HABITAT  on burned ground, damp soil, and moss in coniferous woods, June to September^, (Phillips), usually single, but also gregarious, on "loamy streetsides and embankments, under trees, bushes, and herbs, usually on bare ground", April to October, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-22 x 13-15 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, with 2 large droplets^; asci 8-spored, 250-280 x 15-16 um, inamyloid; paraphyses "slender, septate, and forked at the base, tips slightly thickened", (Breitenbach), spores 19-21 x 13-15 um, broadly elliptic, with two large oil droplets; asci about 300 x 15 um; paraphyses "slender, septate, colorless, slightly enlarged upwards", (Dennis), spores 19-23 x 10-15 um, with two large oil droplets, (Trudell)
NAME ORIGIN  means "like a small mug" from Greek^, (Schalkwijk-Barendsen)
SIMILAR  Tarzetta catinus has narrower spores and generally larger size, (Breitenbach following Dennis). T. catinus has a larger cup and a longer stem (Trudell). Note also the lobed tips on paraphyses in T. catinus, and lack of grayish shading. Geopyxis vulcanalis is yellowish, without oil droplets in the spores.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Seaver(1) (as Geopyxis cupularis), Larsen(1), Phillips(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Schalkwijk-Barendsen(1)*, Dennis(1), Trudell(4)
363
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tatraea macrospora  (Peck) Baral^  in Baral, Galan, Krisai-Greilhuber, Matocec & Palmer, Osterreichische Zeitschrift fur Pilzkunde 8: 80. 1999;  Rutstroemia macrospora  (Peck) Kanouse;  Calycina macrospora  (Peck) Seaver;  Helotium macrosporum Peck;  Ciboria peckiana (Cooke) Korf
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small size, dirty white or grayish stemmed discs on wood, and microscopic characters including elongate spores.^ RANGE ^Tatraea macrospora is common and widely distributed in North America, and is found in WA, OR, CT, DC, DE, IA, KY, LA, ME, MI, MN, MO, NC, ND, NY, OH, PA, SC, TN, VA, WV, and WI, and in addition reported from CO, IN, KS, and NJ, (White, W.L.).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-1.5cm across, up to 1.5cm high, "convex with maximum moisture, often somewhat depressed in center, becoming saucer-shaped with loss of water, sometimes very dark on drying"; dirty white or grayish, drying brownish; margin not elevated in mature discs, rather acute, turning upward on drying, "the excipular hyphae protruding above the hymenium to form a thin sterile margin"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  colored as upper surface, minutely furfuraceous, more obviously so on drying
STEM  "v-shaped or papilliform when short, cylindric below or somewhat tapering when long, smooth or rarely minutely furfuraceous"
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or more rarely in crowded clusters of 6-12, on hard parts of decaying stumps, logs, and fallen limbs of hardwood species, also reported on conifer wood
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 22-34 x 6-8 um, "elongate, narrow oblong-fusoid, typically somewhat flattened on one side and tending to be slightly pointed toward the ends, obtuse", 1-celled, "obliquely uniseriate with ends slightly overlapping", or subbiseriate [somewhat biseriate], "sometimes containing a row of 4-8 large oil globules, especially in fresh condition, a septum finally appearing between the globules", "tubules appearing typically at the ends, often on the intercalary cells, from which are extruded spermatia until all content is used leaving only the collapsed spore wall"^; asci 155-185 x 11-16 um, cylindric; paraphyses 2-3 um wide, simple [unbranched], colorless, not enlarged at tip; spermatia 2.2-2.8 um in diameter, spherical or nearly so, "bearing a minute apiculus and a single, eccentric, refractive oil drop", "known to be produced only from ascospores"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'with large spores'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  White, W.L.(2) (as Rutstroemia macrospora)
364
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Thecotheus cinereus  (H. Crouan & P. Crouan) Chenant.^  Bull. Trimestriel Soc. Mycol. France 34: 39. 1918
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute fruitbodies on dung that are white at first and become purple-brown, and microscopic characters including 8-spored asci with large spores that have prominent apiculi at each end and punctate ornamentation.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from OR, CA, NY, UT, Bermuda, Czech Republic, and Germany, (Kimbrough). It is found in OR, ID, CA, CO, and UT, (Larsen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 0.1-0.2cm across, conic expanding to become turbinate [top-shaped], at first white, becoming lilaceous to purple-brown^, (Kimbrough)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on dung of animals including cow, goat, horse^, (Kimbrough)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 30-42 x 15-18 um, elliptic, "with walls of 2 layers, the inner thick (4 um) layer and a thin (1 um or less) outer layer which stains intensely in cotton blue and bears prominent polar apiculi and punctate ornaments over the remainder of the wall"^; asci 8-spored, 250-400 x 30-40 um, cylindric, long-stemmed, "dome-shaped above a well-marked operculum", the wall turning blue its entire length in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], septate, branched or unbranched, 1.5-2.5 um in lower part, inflated to 6-8 um at tip, colorless in lower part, with purple-brown incrustation at tip; ectal excipulum of two types, a textura angularis forming a palisade of cells with longitudinal axes perpendicular to the surface, larger cells 20-25 x 10-12 um, and rooting hyphae, 2.0-2.5 um wide which begin several layers deep and end on the surface with a 6-10 um wide bulb that becomes slightly thick-walled and with purple-brown pigments; medullary excipulum of textura globulosa, cells reaching 25 um across, with scattered interwoven hyphae, (Kimbrough)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Thecotheus pelletieri also starts out white and cone-shaped and becomes purple-brown and turbinate, but it has 32 spores per ascus, (Kimbrough). Other Thecotheus species with 8-spored asci have smaller spores, (Kimbrough). See also SIMILAR section of Thecotheus keithii.
SOURCES  Kimbrough(5), Seaver(1) (as Ascophanus cinereus and A. isabellinus), Larsen(1), Tylutki(2)
365
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Thecotheus crustaceus  (Starback) Aas & N. Lundq.^  A World-Monograph of the Genus Thecotheus (Ascomycetes, Pezizales), Thesis (Doctor Scientiarum), Botanical Institute, University of Bergen, Norway (Bergen): 70. 1992;  Thecotheus agranulosus  Kimbr.  Mycologia 61: 112. 1969
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, purple brown, top-shaped fruitbodies with incurved margins, growth on animal dung, and microscopic characters including smooth spores, and 8-spored asci that turn blue in Melzer's reagent.^ | The online Species Fungorum, accessed February 4, 2017, listed Thecotheus agranulosus Kimbr. as a synonym of Thecotheus crustaceus (Starback) Aas & N. Lundq., but MycoBank, accessed the same day, listed them separately. RANGE ^Thecotheus crustaceus is found at least in OR and YT, (Larsen); YT and TN, (Kimbrough).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.15-0.2cm across, at first subconic, becoming turbinate [top-shaped], with incurved margins, purple-brown^, (Kimbrough)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on dung of animals, including horse, moose^, (Kimbrough)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-22 x 8.0-10.0 um, unequally elliptic, smooth, colorless, "with a thick (2.5-3 um) inner wall layer, and a thin (less than 1.0 um) outer wall layer that stains intensely in cotton blue, each spore surrounded by a thick mucilaginous perispore"^; asci 8-spored, 175-225 x 15-20 um, narrowly cylindric, with a short stem, tapering to narrow dome at top, "line of dehiscence at operculum indistinct", wall turning blue for entire length in Melzer's reagent; paraphyses extending 10-12 um beyond asci, filiform [thread-like], 2.0-2.2 um wide in lower part, swollen to 3.0-3.2 um at tips, colorless, septate, branched or unbranched; ectal excipulum of a texture angularis, 10-18 x 6-10 um with purple-brown pigments, rooting hyphae 2-3 um wide originate several layers below and end with a 6-7 um wide bulbous tip on exterior surface; medullary excipulum of a textura globulosa, cells reaching 25 um across, interspersed with filamentous hyphae, (Kimbrough)
NAME ORIGIN  means "without granules", referring to spores without granular markings^, (Kimbrough)
SIMILAR  Other members of the genus have more than 8 spores per ascus or have roughened spores.
SOURCES  Kimbrough(5) (as Thecotheus agranulosus), Larsen(1) (as Thecotheus agranulosus)
366
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Thecotheus keithii  (W. Phillips) Aas^  A World-Monograph of the Genus Thecotheus (Ascomycetes, Pezizales), Thesis (Doctor Scientiarum), Botanical Institute, University of Bergen, Norway (Bergen): 110. 1992;  Thecotheus apiculatus  Kimbr.  Mycologia 61: 110. 1969
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute fruitbodies on dung that are white or yellowish at first, purple-brown when mature, and microscopic characters including spores with smooth lateral walls and a long narrow apiculus at each end.^ | The online Species Fungorum, accessed February 4, 2017, synonymized Thecotheus apiculatus Kimbr. with Thecotheus keithii (W. Phillips) Aas but MycoBank, accessed the same day, listed them separately. RANGE ^Thecotheus keithii is found at least in OR, ON, and MI, (Kimbrough).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.15cm across, fruitbody at first spherical or pear-shaped, becoming doliform [barrel-shaped] to turbinate [top-shaped], white or yellowish at first, purple-brown when mature^, (Kimbrough)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on dung of animals including horse^, (Kimbrough)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 16-20 x 8-12 um, "each with a thick (3 um) inner and thin (approx. 0.8 um) outer wall layer surrounded by a mucilaginous perisporic layer, narrow apiculi present on the outer wall at each end of the spore, lateral walls smooth, apiculi and outer wall layer staining strongly in cotton blue", uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, 150-250 x 18-25 um, narrowly cylindric, the entire length turning blue with Melzer's reagent, line of dehiscence at operculum indistinct; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um wide in lower part, reaching 2.5 um at tip, filiform [thread-like], septate, colorless; ectal excipulum of a textura angularis, cells 12-18 x 6-10 um, longitudinal axes somewhat perpendicular to outer surface, rooting hyphae 1.5-2.5 um wide originating several cells deep, ending with a 4.0-6.0 um wide bulbous tip that becomes incrusted with purple-brown pigments when old; medullary excipulum predominantly of a textura globulosa with interspersed hyphae, larger cells 16-22 um across, (Kimbrough)
NAME ORIGIN  "from Latin, apiculus, for the apiculate spores"^, (Kimbrough)
SIMILAR  Spores of Thecotheus keithii (as T. apiculatus) are smaller than in other Thecotheus species, "but most important is their smooth lateral wall with long, narrow, polar apiculi". Apiculi are also found in Thecotheus cinereus but those spores are much larger with punctate markings over the entire surface, (Kimbrough).
SOURCES  Kimbrough(5) (as Thecotheus apiculatus), Larsen(1) (as Thecotheus apiculatus)
367
FAMILY  Ascobolaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Thecotheus pelletieri  (H. Crouan and P. Crouan) Boud.^  Annls Sci. Nat., Bot., ser. 5 10: 235. 1869
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute fruitbodies on dung that are white becoming rosy or grayish then purple-brown, and microscopic characters including 32-spore asci.^ RANGE ^Thecotheus pelletieri is reported from WA and OR, (Larsen(1) but occurrence not verified by either author), and ON, PQ, NY, FL, and France, (Kimbrough).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 0.1-0.2cm across, at first obconic becoming doliform [barrel-shaped], finally turbinate [top-shaped], at first glistening white, becoming rosaceous or cinereous, finally purple-brown^, (Kimbrough)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on dung of animals including cow and horse^, (Kimbrough)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 32-40 x 20-24 um, thick-walled (3-4 um), "with 3 wall layers, a thick inner layer, a thin outer layer that stains intensely in cotton blue and usually smooth but sometimes with short polar granulation, and a mucilaginous perisporic layer", biseriate to 4-seriate or irregularly disposed in ascus; ascus 32-spored^, 300-450 x 45-60 um, turning blue their entire length in Melzer's reagent, slightly thick-walled when young, but becoming thin-walled and with a well-marked operculum when mature; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um wide in lower part, widened to 6.0-8.0 um wide in upper part, branched, septate, colorless, incrusted with purple-brown pigments in upper part; ectal excipulum of 2 types, a textura angularis, cells 20-25 x 15-20 um, "their longitudinal axes perpendicular to outer surface", and rooting cells developing several cells deep to the surface and ending on the surface with a bulb 2-4 um wide in lower part, widened to 6-10 um at tip and usually encrusted with purple-brown pigments and becoming thick-walled; medullary excipulum predominantly of a textura globulosa, cells reaching 25-30 um across, with scattered filamentous hyphae 12-15 um across, (Kimbrough)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Thecotheus cinereus.
SOURCES  Kimbrough(5), Larsen(1), Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1)
368
FAMILY  Thelebolaceae, Order Thelebolales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Thelebolus stercoreus  Tode ex Fr.^  Summa mycologicum 2: 306. 1823;  Ryparobius monascus  Mouton;  Thelebolus nanus  Heimerl.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include minute, yellowish to brownish, spherical to ovoid fruitbodies on dung usually containing only one ascus with more than 1000 spores.^ RANGE ^Thelebolus stercoreus is found in BC, CA, and WY, (Larsen, but occurrence not confirmed by either author) and not included in the PezWeb preliminary checklist of North American Pezizales (which emphasizes western species). Collections were examined from BC, AB, ON, PQ, SK, CA, NY, and WY, (Kimbrough for Thelebolus stercoreus group), NY (Seaver), Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen), and the United Kingdom (Dennis).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.02-0.03cm across, at first spherical, then broad-ovoid, closed then bursting open by a rupture through which the ascus protrudes^, (Seaver), less than 0.05cm across, ovoid, partly embedded in substrate, (Dennis), 0.005-0.03cm across, immersed, spherical to turbinate [top-shaped], (Hansen), 0.013-0.03cm high, immersed or semi-immersed, ovate, at first closed and spherical to ovoid, (Kimbrough)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  yellowish to brown; smooth^, (Seaver), yellowish brown; smooth, (Dennis), yellowish brown (Hansen), yellowish to olive-brown; smooth (Kimbrough)
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on dung of all kinds, throughout the year^, (Dennis), gregarious or scattered; on dung of various kinds, especially abundant on goat dung; more rarely on wood, (Seaver), scattered, somewhat gregarious, or sometimes clustered, (Kimbrough)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-9 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic, colorless, a large number of spores in each ascus hard to estimate but exceeding 100^; asci reaching a length of 200-260 um and a width of 150-175 um, usually one ascus per fruitbody, occasionally 2 or 3, "ellipsoid to ovoid, often slightly constricted near the upper end and with a faint suggestion of a ring"; paraphyses slender, septate, (Seaver), spores 5-7 x 3-4 um, elliptic; asci up to 230 x 140 um, ellipsoid, containing about 1000 spores, wall 5-10 um thick below the annular zone, (Dennis), spores 6-7 x 3-4 um, 1000-2500 spores per ascus, one ascus per fruitbody; asci clavate, rupturing in upper part when mature, (Hansen), spores 5.0-7.0 x 3.0-4.5 um, walls about 0.8 um thick when mature, contents granular and homogeneous, number of spores per ascus variable but with 1-ascus forms may approach 2500; asci 140-260 x 80-175 um, usually one per fruitbody but sometimes 2 or 3, thick-walled; paraphyses 2 um wide, very delicate, filiform [thread-like], colorless, sometimes branched, closely surrounding the ascus in a mucilaginous sheath when young, but disappearing when mature; wall of fruitbody made up of several layers of cells, but when mature the innermost layers are crushed and indistinct, the outermost cells, usually in 3-5 layers, "are polygonal, 6-14 um wide, thick-walled, and contain a dark olive-brown pigment", (Kimbrough)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'relating to dung'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(1) (as Ryparobius monascus), Dennis(1), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1), Kimbrough(4) (Thelebolus stercoreus group), PezWeb(1) (does not include)
369
FAMILY  Triblidiaceae, Order Triblidiales, Class Uncertain, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Triblidium caliciforme  Rebent.^  [as 'Tryblidium caliciiforme'], Index plantarum circum Berolinum sponte nascentium adiectis aliquot fungorum descriptionibus (Berolini): 40. 1805
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include tiny, stemless, black, spherical cups erumpent from wood, tearing open by several irregular teeth, the spore-bearing surface deeply concave and gray. Triblidium spp. have large spores with both transverse and longitudinal cross-walls.^ | The accompanying photographs were from a BC collection on the bark of a dead Quercus garryana branch. The exterior would be hard to describe as smooth as given by the description below derived from Dennis(1) - it is possible that another species of Triblidium or related genus is represented in the photographs. RANGE ^The accompanying photographs were from a BC collection. Dennis(1) is listing it from the United Kingdom (as rare).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.3cm across, fruitbody spherical, leathery, "erumpent singly", "tearing open by several irregular teeth", "disc deeply concave, grey"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  black, smooth
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  collection on bark of Quercus (oak) in fall (Dennis), BC collection also on oak bark but in February
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 30-48 x 12-20 um, broadly elliptic, colorless or slightly yellowish, "with a thick outer wall, about seven to nine cross walls, each locule further subdivided by up to three longitudinal walls"^, asci 4-spored, up to 270 x 25 um, clavate, "thick-walled, rounded above, contents deep red in iodine, no blue reaction", spores uniseriate in ascus; paraphyses "slender, forked near the tip, colourless"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'cup-shaped'
SIMILAR  The initial description in Kauffman(5) of Triblidium fatiscens Kauffman [as 'Tryblidium'], Pap. Mich. Acad. Sci. 11: 157 (1930) [1929] was from Oregon. Kauffman says that it differs from T. caliciforme by its cylindric and larger asci (240-270 x 15-18 um) and the mostly hemispherical-convex apothecia. Note that his measurements of the asci fall within the measurements above for T. caliciforme.
SOURCES  Dennis(1), Kauffman(5)
370
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tricharina gilva  (Boud. ex Cooke) Eckblad^  in Nytt Magasin for Botanik 15: 60. 1968
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a small cup that is yellow orange at first, becoming fawn or light ocher, the exterior similarly colored but covered with stiff light reddish brown hairs, absent stem, growth on bare or mossy burned ground, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Tricharina gilva is found at least in OR and ID, (Larsen). A collection from BC determined by N. Weber is deposited at the Pacific Forestry Centre. Desjardin(6) illustrated it for CA.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.5cm wide, saucer-shaped with flat disc; pale fawn^, (Dennis), 0.2-0.5cm, cup-shaped when young, with outwardly bending margin when old; yellow-orange when young, paling to light ocher when old; margin with short brown hairs, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  colored as inner surface, covered with stiff, light reddish-brown hairs^, (Dennis), weakly furfuraceous (Breitenbach)
STEM  none^ (Dennis, Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on burnt ground and cinder heaps, especially after they have become overgrown with moss^, (Dennis for UK), cespitose to clustered on bare and mossy burned ground, April to July, (Breitenbach for Switzerland)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-19 x 9-10 um, elliptic, smooth^; asci up to 250 x 15 um; paraphyses slender, slightly club-shaped, about 4 um wide; hairs up to 200 x 10 um, smooth, thin-walled, sparingly septate, tapered to a rounded point, (Dennis), spores 14-16 x 8-10 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, without droplets; asci 8-spored, 170-180 x 14-16 um, inamyloid; paraphyses slender with tips slightly thickened to 4 um wide; hairs 150-190 x 3-5 um, base to 10 um thick, multiseptate, not very thick-walled, tips slightly rounded off, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  means "pale yellow"
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Dennis(1), Breitenbach(1)*, Larsen(1), Desjardin(6)*
371
FAMILY  Ascodesmidaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Trichobolus zukalii  (Heimerl) Kimbr.^  in Kimbrough & Korf, Am. J. Bot. 54: 21. 1967;  Thelebolus zukalii  Heimerl
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Trichobolus zukalii produces a minute fruitbody on deer dung that consists of an ascus containing 5800-7200 spores per ascus, more than in any other ascomycete. It is barely visible to the naked eye but under low magnification reveals an ovoid structure that is white in the upper one third and yellowish to olive-brown in the lower part, with setae extending in all directions.^ | Spore liberation is by an irregular tear at the top of the ascus. RANGE ^Trichobolus zukalii is found in BC, AB, MB, ON, MA, and NY, (Kimbrough(4)), and Denmark and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.03-0.045cm across and 0.033-0.054cm high, barely visible to the naked eye, but under low magnification an ovoid structure white in upper one third and yellowish to olive-brown in lower part, with setae extending in all directions^, (Kimbrough(3))
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on 12 North American collections, 11 occurred on deer dung, the remaining one on moose dung, reported in Europe on goat dung and deer dung^, (Kimbrough(3))
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  fruitbody composed of a 4-cell to 8-cell thick layer of hyphae enclosing a single ovoid to pyriform [pear-shaped] ascus, 310-525 x 275-440 um, containing about 5800 to 7200 spores per ascus; each spore 9.7-10.5 x 7.0-7.6 um, oval, smooth, thin-walled, in some media containing a prominent gaseous vacuole (deBary bubble) 4.5 x 3 um, cytoplasm granular^; ascus wall "relatively thick (4.6-5.5 um) but gradually becomes thinner (2.4-3.0 um) at the pear-shaped ascus apex", the wall has three layers that can be differentially stained with 2% aqueous congo red; paraphyses more prominent when young, a single layer of narrow (2.5 um wide) filaments extending from the base of the ascus to its apex, pressing close together in a mucilaginous matrix completely enclosing the ascus; setae about 15-20 per fruitbody, 90-600 um long (average 325 um), up to 12-15 um wide at base, the setae containing 3-5, occasionally 10 or more, thin septa, the thick walls becoming thinner as they extend into the basal cell, (Kimbrough(3))
NAME ORIGIN  in honor of the mycologist H. Zukal
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kimbrough(3), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1), Kimbrough(4)
372
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Trichophaea abundans  (P. Karst.) Boud.^  Hist. Class. Discom. Eur. 61. 1907;  Patella abundans  (P. Karst.) Seaver;  Anthracobia humillima  Malencon
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small, cup-shaped to disc-shaped fruitbody, 2) upper surface almost black to almost white, 3) margin fringed with pale downy hairs, 4) exterior with short dark hairs, 5) absent stem, 6) growth on burned ground and charred wood, and 7) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Trichophaea abundans is found in OR, ID, CA, and CO, (Larsen), and Denmark, Finland, and Norway, (Hansen). There is a collection from BC by O. Ceska at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.3cm wide, flat at maturity; grayish white, with short marginal hairs^, (Kanouse), 0.2-0.5cm wide, top-shaped to disc-shaped, dark grayish brown at first, maturing light grayish brown, (Hansen), up to 0.2cm wide, cup-shaped, disc concave then flat; almost white to almost black, margin fringed with pale downy hairs, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  with hairs longer than those at margin^ (Kanouse), colored as interior in lower part, grayish white at the distinct margin, (Hansen), light brown to dark gray, bearing short dark hairs, (Dennis)
STEM  none^ (Kanouse, Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on peat moss on burned soil; on sterilized soil in a greenhouse^, (Kanouse), on burnt ground, very soon after the burning, (Hansen), on charred wood and burnt ground, spring and fall, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-15 x 6-8 um, elliptic, ends narrowed, smooth, faintly yellow, with central droplet, uniseriate with ends overlapping^; asci 8-spored, 120-150 x 8-10 um, inamyloid; paraphyses filiform (thread-like), colorless, tip slightly clavate, 6-7 um wide; marginal hairs 40-60 x 8 um, dilute brown to colorless, darker in lower part, thin-walled, 1-3-septate, tip pointed, arising from the tip ends of chains of excipular cells, hairs below the margin long 120-250 x 6 um, scattered, pale brown, sparingly septate, even in width throughout, tip pointed or blunt, (Kanouse), spores 13-14 x 6-7 um, elliptic, smooth, with 2 drops, with de Bary bubbles; marginal hairs 50-80 x 4-7 um, almost colorless, 1-5-septate, pointed, arising from bulbose cells up to 16 um wide, exterior hairs longer, 80-150 x 4-7 um, brown, thick-walled, (Hansen), spores 11-15 x 6.5-8 um, elliptic, smooth, with 2 droplets; asci up to 160 x 11 um; paraphyses "slender, clavate, 5-8 um thick at the tip"; marginal hairs up to 70 um long, base enlarged up to 15 um wide, elsewhere tapered from 5-7 um wide to a sharply pointed tip, hairs below margin up to 200 x 7 um, dark brown, septate, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'abundant, overflowing'
SIMILAR  See also SIMILAR section of Trichophaea contradicta.
SOURCES  Kanouse(5), Seaver(1) (as Patella abundans), Larsen(1), Hansen, L.(1), Dennis(1)
373
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Trichophaea bullata  Kanouse^  Mycologia 50: 131. 1958
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) disc-shaped fruitbodies with whitish interior, 2) margin crowded with hairs, 3) exterior pale brown with longer hairs than on margin, 4) dark brown mycelium frequently at the base, 5) absent stem, and 6) microscopic characters including marginal hairs that arise from large bulbous cells.^ | The description is derived from Kanouse. RANGE ^Trichophaea bullata is found in WA, OR, CO, and WY, (Larsen, but occurrence not confirmed by either author) and not included in the PezWeb preliminary checklist of North American Pezizales (which emphasizes western species). Material was examined by Kanouse from OR, CO, ME, MI, and TN.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-0.4cm wide, flat at maturity; whitish, margin crowded with hairs
FLESH  fleshy
UNDERSIDE  pale brown, covered with hairs
STEM  none, dark brown mycelium frequently present at the base
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered to gregarious on soil among mosses, on cellar floor, on wet earth and humus
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 20-22 x 12-14 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with one large droplet, pseudoamyloid^; asci 8-spored, 250-325 x 18-20 um, inamyloid; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], colorless, slightly broadened at tip, clinging together in bundles; marginal hairs 100-125 x 15-20 um, "arising from large conspicuous subglobose or fusoid-ventricose basal cells 30-35 um or more in diameter, with a septum between the swollen base and the sword-shaped portion, sparingly septate above, often non-septate", tips sharply pointed, pale brown to nearly colorless, tinted darker brown at base, short hairs present usually with blunt tips, hairs lower down on exterior are "long, 300 x 6-7 um, dark brown, thin-walled, many-septate, scattered singly, arising from small dark-colored cells"
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(5), Larsen(1), PezWeb(1) (does not include)
374
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Trichophaea contradicta  (Seaver) H.J. Larsen^  Mycotaxon 11(1): 370. 1980;  == Patella contradicta  Seaver
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a tiny, lens-shaped, light to dark brown fruitbody, 2) short light-colored marginal hairs (each with a nearly spherical basal cell), 3) long, brown, flexuous [wavy] hairs scattered over the undersurface, 4) growth on burned soil or charcoal in late spring or early summer, and 5) smooth, broadly elliptic spores.^ | The anamorphic state is assigned to Dichobotrys. RANGE ^Trichophaea contradicta is known from two collections found in BC and NY.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.25cm across, lenticular [lens-shaped], "early becoming slightly concave but flattened at maturity"; spore-bearing surface isabelline to sepia brown with the "margin darker, elevated, and clothed with an inconspicuous fringe of hairs"
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  dark brown, lower margin and exterior clothed with scattered hairs that are longer and darker than those on the margin
STEM  sessile (without stem)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to crowded, on burned soil or charcoal in late spring or early summer, (on burned soil and litter at the edge of a forest fire site, beside highway in Glacier National Park, BC, June 26, 1971, and on burnt ground, New York Botanical Garden, NY, June 27, 1916)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores (12)14.5-16(18) x (8.5)9.0-10.5(11) um, broadly elliptic to occasionally nearly round, smooth, containing 1 or usually 2 oil droplets and a large deBary bubble when mounted in lactic acid, lactophenol, or Melzer's reagent, uniseriate in the ascus^; asci 8-spored, 150-170 x 11-14 um, cylindric, operculate, not turning blue in iodine; paraphyses 150-170 x 1.5-2.5 um, septate, unbranched, tips enlarged to 5-8 um wide, "usually clavate to spatulate, with the apical cell brownish and containing numerous small oil droplets"; medullary excipulum 60-100 um thick, of textura intricata with cells 5-8 um in diameter; ectal excipulum 180-230 um thick at base, narrowing to 60 um thick toward the margin, composed of textura globulosa toward the base with cells (10)25-60 um in diameter "and the outermost cells brownish walled", grading into textura angularis for the upper half of the ectal excipulum, with the 15-40 x (5)10-15(20) um cells "oriented with their long axis perpendicular to the outer surface"; excipular hairs of the upper margin "typically single but occasionally grouped in small fascicles, very short", 20-45(65) x 4-6 um, colorless to very light brown, thin-walled, (1)2-4-celled, narrowing quickly above the 8-10 um diameter swollen basal cell and ending in a narrowly obtuse to acuminate tip; "excipular hairs of the lower margin and flank longer", 80-115(140) x 5-7 um, 3-5-celled, umber brown, "more flexuous, also arising from a swollen outer excipular basal cell but more gradually tapering to a narrowly obtuse tip"
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Trichophaea contradicta is similar to the dark variant of Trichophaea abundans but differs in the greater width of its spores and in the blunt tips of the hairs on the lower exterior, (Larsen).
SOURCES  Larsen(3)
375
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Trichophaea gregaria  (Rehm) Boud.^  Hist. Class. Discom. Eu. 60. 1907;  Trichophaea hybrida  (Sowerby) T. Schumach.  Mycotaxon 33: 166. 1988 (proposed corrected name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a cup-shaped to flat fruitbody, 2) gray-white upper surface, 3) upturned margin and exterior both with short dark brown hairs, 4) absent stem, and 5) microscopic characters. |Schumacher(3) corrected the name to Trichophaea hybrida in 1988, citing a collection from England and writing (with Latin names italicized), "The above cited authentic material represents Trichophaea gregaria (Rehm) Boud. as currently circumscribed. Since Peziza hybrida Sow. provides an older name, the necessary new combination is made." Nevertheless, the online Species Fungorum and Mycobank, both accessed September 12, 2022, maintained them as separate species. RANGE ^Trichophaea gregaria is found in OR, CO, and WY, (Larsen, but occurrence not confirmed by either author) and not included in the PezWeb preliminary checklist of North American Pezizales (which emphasizes western species). Material was examined by Kanouse from NS, CO, DE, MI, SD, and WY. There is a collection as Trichophaea hybrida from BC by O. Ceska deposited at the University of British Columbia.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.3-0.8cm, "at first hemispherical-bladderlike, then remaining cup-shaped for a long time and later becoming flat, the ciliated margin always remaining turned upward"; gray-white, sometimes with a bluish tint; sometimes rather wrinkled; margin thickly covered with short dark brown hairs^, (Breitenbach), 0.3-0.4cm, flat at maturity, drying cup-shaped; whitish to bluish grayish white, (Kanouse)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  thickly covered with short dark-brown hairs^, (Breitenbach), brownish, pale in upper part, hairs and dark cells giving a mottled appearance, (Kanouse)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious on bare sandy ground on the edges of paths, also (less often) on burned places, July-September^, (Breitenbach), on soil, rotting wood and decayed leaves, (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 23-25.5 x 9-10 um, narrowly elliptic to somewhat fusiform, smooth (but warty in type material), colorless, with many small droplets or one large droplet^; asci 8-spored, 200 x 13 um, (according to Maas Geesteranus 1969 276-290 x 13-17 um), inamyloid; paraphyses slender, cylindric, slightly thickened toward tip, septate; hairs 225 x 10 um, (according to Maas Geesteranus 1969 to 650 x 6-12 um), dark brown, relatively thick-walled (2.5 um), multiply septate, tapering to a point, (Breitenbach), spores 20-22(24) x 10-12 um, fusiform, smooth at first becoming finely roughened, yellowish, with 1 large central droplet, often with smaller ones, 1-seriate with ends overlapping; asci 8-spored, 150-275 x 12 um, inamyloid; paraphyses copious, filiform [thread-like], flexuous [wavy], colorless, tips abruptly clavate-thickened, 5-6 um wide; hairs arise from small dark-colored subglobose cells that from small bunches over the upper part of the exterior, the "hairs forming the marginal fringe arise from cells below the margin, submarginal hairs rigid, in fascicles 20-30, or less, 150-300 x 7-8 um, (some shorter), pale brown at the apices, pointed, sparingly septate, basal cell frequently a short, stem-like attenuation, hairs below the margin area arising singly from small dark-colored cells, very short, stout, 15-45 um (or longer), adpressed, sparingly septate", hairs and dark cells giving a mottled appearance to the exterior, (Kanouse)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to a flock or herd', presumably referring to gregarious habit
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Kanouse(5), Seaver(1) (as Patella gregaria), Larsen(1), PezWeb(1) (does not include), Schumacher(3) 
376
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Trichophaea hemisphaerioides  (Mouton) Graddon^  Trans. Br. mycol. Soc. 43: 689. 1960
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a small cup with white to gray to black interior, 2) margin fringed with hairs, 3) outside brownish with light brown stiff hairs, 4) growth among Funaria on burned ground and burned wood, and 5) microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Trichophaea hemisphaerioides is found in OR (Larsen). There are 8 collections from WA by S. Carpenter at Oregon State University.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-1(1.5)cm wide, at first "hemispherical-bladderlike, then remaining cup-shaped for a long time and later becoming flat, the ciliated margin always remaining turned upward"; "white to gray-whitish, sometimes with bluish tint", margin with brown hairs^, (Breitenbach), 0.5-1.2cm wide, cup-shaped, grayish white, (Hansen), up to 1.5cm wide, usually smaller, saucer-shaped with concave disc; white, (Dennis)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  with brown hairs^, (Breitenbach), brownish, with stiff brown hairs, (Hansen), light brown, clothed with short, stiff, light brown hairs, (Dennis)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach, Dennis)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single to gregarious "on burned ground, commonly among the burned-ground moss (Funaria stage of succession) and on burned pieces of wood", April-October^, (Breitenbach), on burnt ground, 20-50 weeks after the burning, all year, (Hansen), on burnt ground amongst Funaria in woods, April to September, (Dennis)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 13-18 x 5-7 um, narrowly elliptic, colorless, some finely punctate and rough, with 2 droplets^; asci 8-spored, 175-200 x 7-8 um; inamyloid; paraphyses slender, forked at base, septate, tip slightly thickened; hairs 200-400 x 10-17 um, dark brown, thick-walled, multiseptate, narrowing to a point, (Breitenbach), spores 13-16 x 7-8 um, smooth or minutely verruculose, with 2 small droplets; exterior hairs 200-400 x 5-15 um, multiseptate, (Hansen), spores 13-16 x 7-8 um, elliptic, smooth, with a small oil droplet near each end; paraphyses "slender, slightly clavate and up to 6 um thick at the tip, colourless"; hairs up to 450 um long, 6-10 um wide in lower part, "tapering to a sharp point, walls 1-2 um thick, smooth, septa numerous", (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Hansen, L.(1), Dennis(1), Larsen(1)
377
FAMILY  Pyronemataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Trichophaeopsis bicuspis  (Boud.) Korf & Erb^  Phytologia 24(1): 18. 1972;  Ciliaria bicuspis  Boud.;  Trichophaea bicuspis  (Boud.) Boud.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) small cup-shaped to flat fruitbodies with a smooth, gray-white upper surface, but without a stem, 2) a lower (outer) surface that has brown bristles usually attached by their sides, 3) a dark margin, 4) growth in spring through fall on decaying leaves, barkless hardwood, twigs. branches, or less commonly soil, and 5) microscopic characters including the unusual bristles and an ectal excipulum formed of vertically oriented rows of cells.^ RANGE ^Perry(2) and Perry(5) use a sequence of the collection from OR by Nancy Smith-Webber. Kanouse(5) examined material from CO, CT, KS, and MI. The species is also found in Europe including Switzerland (Breitenbach) and France (Boudier).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 0.3-0.5cm across, "saucer-shaped to flat and plate-shaped"; upper (spore-bearing) surface gray-white, smooth^, (Breitenbach), 0.1-0.3cm across, flat when moist, inrolled when dry, the upper surface white, (Kanouse, who us examining collections made by others), when fresh, the fruitbodies open wide to expose the white spore-bearing surface but on drying they close up so that the bristles cover the hymenium, (Korf)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  lower (outer) surface lighter than inner surface but with "well-separated long brown bristles", which are "usually attached by their sides (as if glued on laterally) and come to points at both ends"; margin forming a dark ring^, (Breitenbach), "pale brown outside, intensified by the color of dark brown hairs" which are inconspicuous but some extending beyond the margin, (Kanouse)
STEM  none^ (Breitenbach, Kanouse) 
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious and crowded together, on "damp dead barkless branches" of hardwood, according to the literature also on damp ground, fruiting August to October, (Breitenbach), on wet aspen leaves, on rotten wood, May, August, and September, (Kanouse), the fruitbodies "were originally described from soil, but most of the collections are either on decaying leaves or on decorticated wood, or twigs or branches", predominantly of various species of Populus, (Korf)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 14-17 x 11-12 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, "with small groups of little drops"^; asci 8-spored, 220-240 um, iodine negative; paraphyses "filiform, multiply septate, tips uneven to somewhat nodulose"; hairs "brown, thick-walled, multiply septate", attachment point on the side of the hair, "coming to points at both ends", (Breitenbach), |spores 14-18 x 10-13 um, smooth, colorless, without droplets, "in one row in the upper part of the ascus"; asci 200-300 x 16-18 um, cylindric, "the lower part frequently a long collapsed hypha-like stem", 6-8 um at the basal end, "suboperculate, not turning blue in iodine"; paraphyses "copious, flexuous", colorless, branched, 3-4 um wide at the apices; "exciple composed of parallel rows of cubical cells extending from the base" of the fruitbody to the margin, "cells below the margin to a depth of 5 or 6 are subglobose, light brown"; hairs "sparse, evenly scattered, all of one kind (seta-like), rich dark brown", "thick-walled, with or without septa, usually branched once, bifurcate, often the mature branch indistinguishable in shape or size from the primary hair, frequently the two grow to appear like one straight or curved hair having two pointed ends", hair and spur 400-600 x 14-18 um, attachment to exciple by a small colorless cell (or row of two or three cells), (Kanouse), |the youngest spores "are usually without any granulations, but soon there appear irregular masses of material, either distinctly granular or of an amorphous nature, usually towards the poles"; the spore matures and becomes distinctly refringent, and the contents take on a yellowish cast - in mature spores one can also make out 2 non-oily globules, sometimes 4, more rarely 3 or many; ectal excipulum 'very characteristic, being composed of vertically oriented rows of cells, the individual cells rather short, glued together to form a one-cell-thick tissue or "skin" seen as large, plate-like structures in squash mounts'; the dark brown setae are diagnostic - the stiff, upward-pointing end (105-800 x 12-22 um), "is prolonged below into usually a short to rather long spur or branch", ((0)43-250(430) x 12-22 um), "borne nearly in direct line with the apical part, so that at first glance the seta appears to be pointed at both ends" - on rare occasions "the seta may lack a basal prong, or even have two such spurs"; in addition to the setae there are other hairs "of varying color from collection to collection", nearly colorless in some specimens, "but brown to almost black in others" - they are "much narrower than the setae", measuring (75)150-400(535) x (2)3-5(6) um, (Korf)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to the hairs which go in two directions from the attachment - the Latin description calls the hair "bicuspidatis"
SIMILAR  Humaria hemispherica, Chaetothiersia vernalis, and Trichophaea spp. have similarities but the first two are larger at maturity, and all have different ectal excipulum structure and lack the hairs that appear as if attached by their sides.
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)*, Korf(7), Kanouse(5), Boudier(1) (in French)
378
FAMILY  Tympanidaceae, Order Phacidiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tympanis alnea  (Pers.) Fr.^  Syst. Myc. 2: 174. 1822
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, hard, black cups that emerge from dead branches of alder, usually in clusters on a black mycelial stroma, the surfaces lightly to intensely grayish-pruinose, absent or short stem, and microscopic characters.^ | The asci of species of Tympanis are usually filled with many small secondary spores: 8 well-developed ascospores are found extremely rarely (Breitenbach & Kranzlin). RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, AB, NB, NF, ON, PQ, ME, MN, ND, NY, WV, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, and Germany, (Ouellette), ID, NF, NS, PQ, ON, AK, CT, NH, NY, VT, WV, Denmark, and Germany, (Groves, but note a few of these might now be considered segregate species by Ouellette & Pirozynski (see SIMILAR)), and Switzerland (Breitenbach).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  up to 0.03-0.1cm across, (usually in clusters up to 0.3cm long and 0.05-0.2cm high), circular or distorted by crowding, narrowed in lower part or suburceolate [somewhat pitcher-like with small mouth]; spore-bearing upper surface concave to flat, more fleshy than the exterior, black or sometimes grayish-pruinose; margin "thick, more or less inrolled, persistent"; conidial fruitbodies 0.02-0.04cm across, nearly spherical to ovoid, "erumpent, gregarious, cespitose in clusters of up to 30 or more", which are up to 0.3cm long and 0.1cm high, occasionally single, black, bald or grayish-pruinose, "sometimes the basal stroma only slightly developed and the pycnidia seated on it"^, (Groves, but note that Ouellette(1) includes the grayish pruinose and excludes the black), 0.05-0.1cm, erupting from under the bark, spherical when young, then cup-shaped; spore-bearing upper surface black and granular-rough; margin whitish, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  hard, horny, becoming more cartilaginous when moist, conidial fruitbodies similar^, (Groves), cartilaginous and horn-like (Breitenbach)
UNDERSIDE  black; bald or densely grayish pruinose, (Groves but note that Ouellette(1) excludes the bald ones), black with white furfuraceous coating, (Breitenbach)
STEM  without stem, tapering in lower part; conidial fruitbodies also without stem, tapering in lower part^, (Groves), tapering into short stem, the individual fruiting bodies resting on a blackish stroma in groups of 5 to 30, (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY
