HABITAT  usually cespitose in clusters of 10-20 or more, occasionally single, on Alnus (alder) and Betula (birch)^, (Groves), in groups of 5-30, on "dead branches of Alnus (alder) still attached to the tree and with bark, as well as small trunks", according to the literature also on Betula (birch); spring, (Breitenbach), occasionally on Abies (Ouellette)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  primary ascospores 5-6 x 4-5 um, broadly elliptic to nearly round, colorless, 1-celled, uniseriate, secondary ascospores 3-4 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, colorless, 1-celled^; asci at first 8-spored, finally multispored, (110)135-190(215) x (14)18-22(25) um, cylindric, obtuse at apex, narrowed in lower part to a short stem, at first with thick gelatinized walls that become thinner when mature; paraphyses about 2-3 um wide, filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, simple or branched, the tips slightly swollen and embedded in a brownish gelatinous matrix, forming an epithecium; conidia 3-5 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, colorless, 1-celled, borne at tip and along sides of the conidiophores; conidiophores lining the pycnidial cavities, about 20-75 x 1.5-2 um, filiform, colorless, simple or branched, septate; pycnidial cavities "variable, more or less ovoid in the separate pycnidia and about 120-300 um in diameter, sometimes lobed and more irregular in the larger stromata", (Groves), spores 3-4 x 1-1.5 um, cylindric, somewhat curved, smooth, colorless; asci many-spored, 209-220 x 23-25 um, thick-walled, negative reaction to iodine; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], with slight clavate widening toward tip, surrounded with brownish amorphous material, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  referring to Alnus (alder)
SIMILAR  Tympanis hysterioides, considered by Groves as a variety of T. alnea, occurs on the same host (alder), but T. hysterioides differs "in having one-septate ascospores and ultimate cells which are intermediate in size between those of T. alnea and T. pseudoalnea. The apothecia are pale brown when sectioned and hysteriform in outline; this, however, is mainly due to their gregarious habit: the few solitary apothecia remain orbicular.", (Ouellette). Other species of Tympanis with collections from the Pacific Northwest in Groves(1) or Ouellette(1) are either not growing on alder or are not grayish-pruinose. Tympanis pseudoalnea Ouellette & Pirozynski was separated from the Groves concept of T. alnea by Ouellette(1), macroscopically differentiated as forming black, bald (as opposed to pruinose) fruiting bodies on Alnus (alder): collections were examined by Ouellette & Pirozynski from PQ and NY, (Ouellette).
SOURCES  Groves(1), Ouellette(1), Breitenbach(1)*
379
FAMILY  Tympanidaceae, Order Phacidiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tympanis amelanchieris  J.W. Groves^  Can. J. Bot. 30: 617. 1952
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, hard, black cups that emerge from Amelanchier spp., singly or in clusters, absent stem, and microscopic characters.^ | The asci of species of Tympanis are usually filled with many small secondary spores: 8 well-developed ascospores are found extremely rarely, (Breitenbach & Kranzlin). RANGE ^Tympanis amelanchieris is found in ID and ON, (Groves).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 0.04-0.1cm across, 0.03-0.05cm high, erumpent [emerging from substrate], circular or undulate; spore-bearing upper surface concave to flat, more fleshy than exterior, black or grayish-pruinose; margin thick, raised, persistently inrolled; conidial fruiting bodies usually arising on the same stroma as the apothecial fruitbodies, 0.01-0.02cm across, ovoid, containing an ovoid cavity, opening at the top, black or grayish-pruinose^, (Groves) 
FLESH  hard, horny, becoming more cartilaginous when moist^, (Groves)
UNDERSIDE  usually grayish-pruinose, sometimes black and bald^, (Groves)
STEM  sessile, slightly narrowed in lower part^, (Groves)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious to scattered cespitose in small clusters of 2 to 8, occasionally single, on Amelanchier spp. (serviceberry, shadbush)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  primary ascospores 4.0-5.0 x 3.0-4.0 um, broadly elliptic to nearly round, colorless, 1-celled, uniseriate, secondary ascospores 2.5-4 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, colorless, 1-celled^; asci at first 4-spored to 8-spored, finally multispored, (90)110-150(160) x (14)15-17 um, cylindric, obtuse at top, narrowed in lower part to a short stem, at first with walls thickened and gelatinized, becoming thinner when mature; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um wide, filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, simple or branched, the tips slightly swollen and embedded in a brownish gelatinous matrix forming an epithecium; conidia 2.5-4 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, colorless, 1-celled, borne at the tip and long the sides of the conidiophore; conidiophores lining the cavity, about 25-40 x 2.0-2.5 um, filiform, colorless, septate, simple, (Groves)
NAME ORIGIN  refers to its host Amelanchier (serviceberry)
SIMILAR  Tympanis conspersa and Tympanis prunicola differ in having larger "ultimate cells", and differ in host, but these minor differences need to be reassessed, (Ouellette).
SOURCES  Groves(1), Ouellette(1), Breitenbach(1) (discussing Tympanis alnea)
380
FAMILY  Tympanidaceae, Order Phacidiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tympanis confusa  Nyl.^  Obs. Pex. Fenn. p. 69. 1868
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, hard, black cups that emerge from pine, singly or in clusters, absent or very short stem, and microscopic characters including spore that are more than 2-septate. The asci of species of Tympanis are usually filled with many small secondary spores: 8 well-developed ascospores are found extremely rarely, (Breitenbach & Kranzlin).^ RANGE ^Tympanis confusa is found in OR, ID, ON, CT, NY, Denmark, and Finland, (Groves), and MI, PQ, and Switzerland, (Ouellette).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.15cm across, 0.04-0.2cm high, erumpent [emerging from substrate], "circular or slightly undulate"; spore-bearing upper surface concave to flat, dull black or shiny black, more fleshy than exterior; "at first with a thick, somewhat infolded margin which may later disappear"; conidial fruitbodies 0.02-0.03cm across, spherical to ovoid, in upper part containing spherical to ovoid cavity lined with conidiophores, (Groves)
FLESH  hard, horny, "becoming more cartilaginous-fleshy when moist"; conidial fruitbodies with similar consistency^, (Groves)
UNDERSIDE  black, bald; conidial fruitbodies black, bald^, (Groves)
STEM  sessile [without a stem] to substipitate, narrowed in lower part; conidial fruitbody without stem or sometimes on long, branched, cylindric or irregular stems 0.01-0.03cm wide and up to 0.02cm long^, (Groves)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "gregarious, separate, or cespitose, usually with less than six in a cluster but occasionally in large clusters of 15 or more", on pine; conidial fruitbodies erumpent, scattered to gregarious, separate or cespitose^, (Groves)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  primary ascospores 13-20 x 2-4 um, elongate-fusoid to clavate-fusoid, colorless, 1-celled to several-celled, occasionally muriform [divided in more than one plane], irregularly biseriate to uniseriate, secondary ascospores 2.0-3.0 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, colorless, 1-celled^; asci at first 1-4-(8)-spored, finally multispored, (80)85-120(150) x (10)12-16(21) um, cylindric to cylindric-clavate, short-stemmed, "at first with the walls thickened and gelatinized", becoming thinner when mature; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um wide, filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, simple or branched, "the tips slightly swollen to 3.0 um and embedded in a gelatinous matrix forming a brownish epithecium"; conidia 2.0-4.0 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, colorless, 1-celled, borne at tip and along sides of conidiophore; conidiophore 25-60 x 2.0-2.5 um, filiform, colorless, septate, simple, (Groves), ascospores clavate, invariably more than 2-septate, (Ouellette)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Tympanis laricina has similar fruitbodies and similar clavate spores, but spores are 1-septate or occasionally 2-septate, whereas in T. confusa they are invariably more than 2-septate, (with each cell germinating into one or more ovoid or pyriform primary cells), (Ouellette). T. hypopodia grows on pine but primary ascospores are one-celled or two-celled.
SOURCES  Groves(1), Ouellette(1), Breitenbach(1) (discussing Tympanis alnea)
381
FAMILY  Tympanidaceae, Order Phacidiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tympanis hypopodia  Nyl.^  Obs. Pez. Fenn.: 72. 1868;  Tympanis piceina  J.W. Groves
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, hard, black cups that emerge from pine, singly or in clusters, absent or very short stem, and microscopic characters. The asci of species of Tympanis are usually filled with many small secondary spores: 8 well-developed ascospores are found extremely rarely, (Breitenbach & Kranzlin).^ RANGE ^Tympanis hypopodia is found in ID, NB, NS, PQ, SK, MA, CT, Austria, Finland, Germany, Sweden, Switzerland, and Japan, (Ouellette), and ON (Groves).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.1cm across, 0.03-0.15cm high, circular or undulate; spore-bearing upper surface concave to flat, more fleshy than exterior, black; "at first with a thick, somewhat infolded margin which later may disappear"; conidial fruiting bodies 0.01-0.03cm across, 0.01-0.03cm high, spherical to ovoid or cylindric, in the upper part containing a spherical to ovoid cavity lined with conidiophores and tearing open at the top^, (Groves)
FLESH  hard, horny, becoming more cartilaginous-fleshy when moist; conidial fruitbodies similar in consistency^, (Groves)
UNDERSIDE  black; bald^; conidial fruitbodies black, bald, (Groves)
STEM  without a stem to substipitate; conidial fruitbodies without a stem^ (Groves)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious, separate to cespitose with usually less than 6 in a cluster, erumpent [emerging], on Pinus spp. (pine); conidial fruitbodies also gregarious to scattered, separate or cespitose, erumpent^, (Groves), may occur also on Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), or hemlock (at least on Tsuga canadensis in eastern North America)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  primary ascospores (6)8-10(12) x 2.0-4.0 um, fusiform, colorless, one-celled or two-celled, irregularly biseriate, secondary ascospores 2.0-3.0 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid [curved sausage-shaped], colorless, one-celled^; asci at first 8-spored, finally multispored, (60)70-90(110) x (8.5)9.0-12.0(14.0) um, cylindric to cylindric-clavate, short-stemmed, "at first with the walls thickened and gelatinized becoming thinner with maturity"; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um wide, filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, simple or branched, the tips slightly swollen up to 3.0 um wide and embedded in a gelatinous matrix forming a brown epithecium; conidia 2.0-4.0 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, colorless, one-celled, borne at the tip and along the sides of the conidiophore; conidiophore 25-70 x 2.0-2.5 um, filiform, colorless, septate, simple, (Groves), ascospores may be fewer than 8 in an ascus, vary considerably in size, and are elliptic-fusoid, sometimes subclavate and curved, narrow or wide, and bud off ovoid cells from each tip during germination, first cells formed are often slightly larger, ultimate cells allantoid, apparently slightly large than T. laricina, epithecium is greenish black, (Ouellette)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Tympanis confusa also grows on pine but primary ascospores are more than 2-septate. Tympanis laricina can also occur pine, fir, and spruce, but spores are characteristically clavate, sometimes very narrowly so, and germinate at each end into tufts of subglobose, ovoid, or pyriform cells, producing short, allantoid, almost rod-shaped ultimate cells, whereas T. hypopodia spores are elliptic-fusoid, sometimes subclavate and curved, narrow or wide, and bud off ovoid cells from each tip during germination, the ultimate cells allantoid and apparently slightly longer than those of T. laricina, (Ouellette). When T. hypopodia occurs on Abies it can be confused also with Tympanis truncatula (primary ascospores broadly elliptic to nearly round).
SOURCES  Groves(1), Ouellette(1), Breitenbach(1) (discussing Tympanis alnea)
382
FAMILY  Tympanidaceae, Order Phacidiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tympanis hysterioides  Rehm^  Rabenh. Kr.-Fl. 1,3: [Lief.31] 268. 1889;  Tympanis alnea var. hysterioides  (Rehm) Rehm
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, hard, black cups that emerge from dead branches of alder, single or in clusters, absent or short stem, and microscopic characters including one-septate ascospores. The asci of species of Tympanis are usually filled with many small secondary spores: 8 well-developed ascospores are found extremely rarely, (Breitenbach & Kranzlin).^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, NF, NS, ON, PQ, NY, Denmark, Finland, and Germany, (Ouellette). Collections were examined from NS, ON, PQ, NY, and Germany, (Groves).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 0.08-0.2cm across, 0.05-0.1cm high, "circular to undulate, often more or less elongated to almost hysteriform", black^, (Groves)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single (Groves), cespitose (Ouellette), on Alnus (alder)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 5-6 x 4.5 um^; asci (110)135-190(215) x (14)18-22(25) um, (Ouellette), microscopic characters as in T. alnea (Groves, but see note in SIMILAR) 
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Tympanis alnea occurs on the same host (alder), but T. hysterioides differs "in having one-septate ascospores and ultimate cells which are intermediate in size between those of T. alnea and T. pseudoalnea. The apothecia are pale brown when sectioned and hysteriform in outline; this, however, is mainly due to their gregarious habit; the few solitary apothecia remain orbicular." The ultimate cells, the last in the series of buddings from the germinating spore are less than 1 um in diameter in T. pseudoalnea. (Ouellette).
SOURCES  Groves(1), Ouellette(1), Breitenbach(1) (discussing Tympanis alnea)
383
FAMILY  Tympanidaceae, Order Phacidiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tympanis laricina  (Fuckel) Sacc.^  Syll. fung. (Abellini) 8: 583. 1889;  = Tympanis juniperina  (Sacc.) Sacc.;  = Tympanis abietina  J.W. Groves;  = Tympanis rehmiana  J.W. Groves
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) small, hard, black cups that emerge from larch or other conifers, single or in clusters, 2) upper surface black or greenish when moist, 3) stem absent or short, and 4) microscopic characters. The asci of species of Tympanis are usually filled with many small secondary spores: 8 well-developed ascospores are found extremely rarely, (Breitenbach & Kranzlin).^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, AB, MB, NB, NF, ON, PQ, ME, NY, UT, WY, France, Switzerland, and Japan, (Ouellette). Collections were examined from ID, ON, MA, NH, and Austria, (Groves). There are two collections from WA at Oregon State University.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.1cm across, 0.04-0.13cm high, circular or undulate; spore-bearing upper surface at first concave, becoming flat to convex, black or greenish when moist, more fleshy than exterior; at first with a thick raised margin which later may almost disappear; pycnidia 0.02-0.03cm across, nearly spherical to ovoid, containing a singly spherical to ovoid cavity, opening at top^, (Groves)
FLESH  hard, horny, becoming more cartilaginous when moist; pycnidia similar, (Groves)
UNDERSIDE  black, bald; pycnidia black, bald^, (Groves)
STEM  "sessile, narrowed below to substipitate"^, (Groves)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  scattered, separate or cespitose, erumpent [emerging] "in small usually more or less elongated clusters", on Larix spp. (larch); conidial fruitbodies "erumpent, cespitose, in clusters of up to 12-15, occasionally single", the clusters 0.05-0.1cm across and 0.04-0.1cm high^, (Groves), on Larix (larch), Abies (fir), Picea (spruce), Pinus (pine), and Thuja (Red-cedar), (Ouellette)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  primary ascospores 7-10 x 3-4 um, "ellipsoid-fusiform", colorless, one-celled or two-celled, irregularly biseriate to uniseriate; secondary ascospores 2.0-3.0 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, colorless, one-celled^; asci at first 8-spored, finally multispored, (70)80-110(120) x (11)13-15(17) um, cylindric, obtuse at top, narrowed in lower part to a short stem, at first ascus with walls thickened and gelatinized, becoming thinner when mature; paraphyses about 1.5-2.5 um wide, filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, simple or branched, "the tips slightly swollen and embedded in a brownish, gelatinous matrix, forming an epithecium"; conidia 2.0-3.0 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, colorless, one-celled, "borne at the tip and along the sides of the conidiophore", conidiophores lining the cavity, about 15-50 x 1.5-2.0 um, filiform, colorless, septate, not observed branching, (Groves), ascospores are characteristically clavate, sometimes very narrowly so, straight or curved, rather than ellipsoid-fusiform as described by Groves, (Ouellette)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'pertaining to Larix (larch)'
SIMILAR  When T. laricina occurs on pine, it can be confused with Tympanis confusa (which has primary ascospores more than 2-septate), and with Tympanis hypopodia (see below). When T. laricina occurs on Abies, it can be confused with Tympanis truncatula (primary ascospores broadly elliptic to nearly round) and T. hypopodia (see below). When T. laricina occurs on Picea, it can be confused with T. hypopodia, but spores are of T. laricina are characteristically clavate, sometimes very narrowly so, and germinate at each end into tufts of subglobose, ovoid, or pyriform cells, producing short, allantoid, almost rod-shaped ultimate cells, whereas T. hypopodia spores are elliptic-fusoid, sometimes subclavate and curved, narrow or wide, and bud off ovoid cells from each tip during germination, the ultimate cells allantoid and apparently slightly longer than those of T. laricina. (Ouellette).
SOURCES  Groves(1), Ouellette(1), Breitenbach(1) (discussing Tympanis alnea)
384
FAMILY  Tympanidaceae, Order Phacidiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tympanis spermatiospora  (Nyl.) Nyl.^  Not. Soc. Fauna Fl. Fenn. 10: 70. 1869;  Cenangium spermatiosporum  (Nyl.) Sacc.;  Tympanis populina  (Fuckel) Sacc.;  Cenangium populinum  Fuckel
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) small, hard, black cups that emerge from dead branches of Populus spp., separately or in clusters, 2) spore-bearing surface black or greenish when moist, 3) absent or very short stem, and 4) microscopic characters. The asci of species of Tympanis are usually filled with many small secondary spores: 8 well-developed ascospores are found extremely rarely, (Breitenbach & Kranzlin).^ RANGE ^Tympanis spermatiospora is found from NF to NY, in ID, CO and IA, and also in Europe, (Seaver). It is also found in Finland and Sweden, (Hansen). Collections were examined from BC, ID, MB, NS, ON, PQ, CT, ME, NH, VT, Austria, and Germany, (Groves). A collection was examined also from NF (Ouellette).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.05-0.08(0.1)cm across, 0.03-0.05cm high, circular to undulate; spore-bearing surface concave to flat or sometimes convex, black or greenish when moist, more fleshy than the exterior; "at first with a thick, raised margin which later may disappear"; conidial fruiting bodies 0.02-0.04cm across, 0.04-0.1cm high, ovoid to nearly spherical or sometimes conic, containing a more or less ovoid cavity opening at the top^, (Groves), reaching 0.1cm across, at first closed and knob-like, opening and gradually expanding to shallow cup-shaped or turbinate [top-shaped]; upper surface brownish black, (Seaver), fruitbody 0.05-0.1cm across, 0.03-0.05cm high, circular to undulate, black, (Hansen)
FLESH  hard, horny, becoming more cartilaginous when moist; conidial fruitbodies similar^, (Groves)
UNDERSIDE  black; bald; conidial fruitbodies also black, bald^, (Groves), black (Seaver), bald (Hansen)
STEM  without stem, slightly narrowed in lower part^, (Groves), erumpent from substrate, then short stemmed, (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious, separate, or cespitose in clusters of about 2-8, erumpent; on Populus spp.; conidial fruitbodies "erumpent, gregarious, cespitose in clusters of up to 15, occasionally single"^, (Groves), single or more often in dense cespitose clusters, on dead branches of Populus, especially Populus tremuloides (quaking aspen), (Seaver), erumpent, separate or cespitose, on Populus or Salix, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  primary ascospores 5-8 x 3-4 um, broadly elliptic to nearly round, colorless, one-celled or two-celled, uniseriate, secondary ascospores 2.0-4.0 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid [curved sausage-shaped], colorless, one-celled^; asci at first 8-spored, finally multispored, (55)70-90(100) x (9)10-13(15) um, cylindric, obtuse at top, short-stemmed, at first with walls thickened and gelatinized, becoming thinner when mature; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um wide, filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, simple or branched, "the tips slightly swollen and embedded in a brownish, gelatinous matrix, forming an epithecium"; conidia 2.0-5.0 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, colorless, one-celled, borne at tip and along sides of conidiophore, conidiophores lining the cavity, filiform, colorless, septate, simple or branched, (Groves), spore-like bodies 3-3.5 um x 1 um, densely filling asci that reach a length of 75-80 um and a width of 12 um, clavate; paraphyses slender, widened in upper part, the ends adhering and forming a brown epithecium, (Seaver), primary spores 5-8 x 3-4 um, elliptic; asci 70-90 x 10-13 um, (Hansen), ascospores "broadly ellipsoid-fusoid to subglobose", "becoming one-septate during germination and producing at each end a group of pyriform to subglobose cells", (Ouellette)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Groves(1), Ouellette(1), Seaver(2), Hansen, L.(1), Breitenbach(1) (discussing Tympanis alnea)
385
FAMILY  Tympanidaceae, Order Phacidiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Tympanis truncatula  (Pers. ex Fr.) Rehm^  Rabenh. Kr.-Fl. I.3: [Lief. 32] 277. 1890;  = Tympanis pithya  (P. Karst.) P. Karst.;  = Tympanis acericola  J.W. Groves;  = Tympanis sorbi  J.W. Groves
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, hard, black cups that emerge from Abies spp. (fir), singly or more often in clusters, absent or short stem, and microscopic characters. The asci of species of Tympanis are usually filled with many small secondary spores: 8 well-developed ascospores are found extremely rarely, (Breitenbach & Kranzlin).^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from NB, NF, ON, PQ, NY, Finland, and France, (Ouellette). Groves lists two collections from ID: one of these has been reassigned by Ouellette to T. hypopodia and the rest of the collections that Groves examined are from further east: NF, NS, ON, MI, NH, NY, and France.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.04-0.12cm across, 0.04-0.1cm high, "narrowed below, sometimes somewhat turbinate, circular or undulate"; spore-bearing upper surface concave to flat, grayish-pruinose or black, more fleshy than exterior; margin "slightly paler and usually more or less inrolled, sometimes disappearing when old"^; conidial fruitbodies 0.01-0.02cm across and up to 0.03cm high, nearly spherical to ovoid, black, bald, containing a single ellipsoid to ovoid cavity, opening at the top, (Groves), Ouellette says that Groves described fruitbodies as usually grayish pruinose "obviously to account for the few collections from Abies which are T. alnea", and that fruitbodies of T. truncatula are "typically convex, light brown and translucent when sectioned", (Ouellette)
FLESH  hard, horny, becoming more cartilaginous when moist; conidial fruitbodies similar^, (Groves)
UNDERSIDE  "usually grayish-pruinose, sometimes black and glabrous", (Groves), but Ouellette says that Groves described them as usually grayish pruinose "obviously to account for the few collections from Abies which are T. alnea", (Ouellette)
STEM  without stem, narrowed in lower part^, (Groves), "usually stalked" (Ouellette)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious, cespitose, or occasionally single; erumpent on Abies spp. (fir); conidial fruitbodies "usually scarce, erumpent, cespitose or single"^, (Groves)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  primary ascospores 5.0-7.0 x 3.0-4.0 um, broadly elliptic to nearly round, colorless, one-celled or two-celled, uniseriate, secondary ascospores 2.0-3.0 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, colorless, one-celled^; asci at first 8-spored, finally multispored, (85)100-130(150) x (10)12-15(18) um, cylindric, obtuse at tip, narrowed in lower part to short stem, ascus "at first with the walls thickened and gelatinized, becoming thinner with maturity"; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um wide, filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, simple or branched, "the tips slightly swollen and embedded in a brownish, gelatinous matrix, forming an epithecium"; conidia 2.0-3.0 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, colorless, one-celled, borne at tip and along sides of the conidiophore; conidiophores lining the cavity, about 15-30 x 1.5-2.0 um, filiform, colorless, septate, simple, not observed branching, (Groves)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Tympanis hypopodia and Tympanis laricina can occur on Abies, but the primary ascospores are elliptic-fusoid or sometimes subclavate in the former and characteristically clavate in the latter, whereas in T. truncatula they are typically round or nearly round, (Ouellette).
SOURCES  Groves(1), Ouellette(1), Seaver(2) (as Tympanis pinastri (Pers.) Tul.), Breitenbach(1) (discussing Tympanis alnea)
386
FAMILY  Hyaloscyphaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Unguiculella oregonensis  (Kanouse) Dennis^  Kew Bull. 17, 2, p.356. 1963;  Unguicularia oregonensis  Kanouse
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a minute white cup clothed with colorless, smooth hairs that are distinctly recurved at the tip, absent or nearly absent stem, growth on the stroma of a Eutypa sp., and microscopic characters include paraphyses that are curved at the tips.^ | Dennis placed the taxon in Unguiculella due to the recurved nature of the slender hair tips - within that genus the large asci and broad ascospores were said to be distinctive, (Dennis(3)). RANGE ^Unguiculella oregonensis was described from OR.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.03-0.038cm across, cup-shaped, white^, (Kanouse)
FLESH  soft waxy^ (Kanouse)
UNDERSIDE  white, clothed with colorless smooth hairs that are distinctly recurved at tip^, (Kanouse)
STEM  sessile to substipitate^ (Kanouse)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  growing superficially on the stroma of a Eutypa sp.^, (Kanouse)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 7-8 x 3-3.5 um, elliptic, smooth, colorless, 1-celled^; asci 8-spored, 35-50 x 7-8 um, cylindric-clavate; paraphyses filiform, curved at tips, colorless, (Kanouse), spores 7-9 x 3.5-4 um, (Dennis)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'from Oregon'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Kanouse(1) (as Unguicularia oregonensis), Dennis(3)
387
FAMILY  Sarcosomataceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Urnula padeniana  M. Carbone, Agnello, A.D. Parker & P. Alvarado^  Ascomycete.org 5(1): 14. 2012;  Sarcosoma mexicanum  (Ellis & Holw.) Paden & Tylutki  Mycologia 61: 689. 1969 (misapplied name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  starving man's licorice, giant gel cup, black jelly-jug
NOTES  Also listed in Jelly category. Features include large black highly gelatinous fruitbodies that are top-shaped to cup-shaped, short gelatinous stem, growth particularly in spring on wood and duff under conifers, and microscopic characters.^ | Carbone(2) call this species Urnula padeniana M. Carbone, Agnello, A.D. Parker & P. Alvarado and consider the name Sarcosoma mexicanum (Ellis & Holw.) Paden & Tylutki to be misapplied, as well as recombining that species as Urnula mexicana (Ellis & Holw.) M. Carbone, Agnello, A.D. Parker & P. Alvarado. Incidentally, although this was described as Sarcosoma mexicana (using a feminine form for the adjective), "soma" is a neuter Greek noun and should use the neuter form of the adjective, "mexicanum". RANGE ^Urnula padeniana is found at least in BC, WA, OR, and ID, (Larsen), WA, OR, CA, Mexico, and India, (Castellano), and Mexico to BC, (Paden).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  5-10(20)cm across and 3-10(15)cm high, sometimes cup-shaped but often more or less top-shaped, margin often lobed; spore-bearing upper surface black or sometimes dark brown^, (Arora), fruitbody up to 9cm across and high, at first turbinate [top-shaped] becoming discoid; spore-bearing upper surface more or less flat to moderately concave, black; margin raised, entire, (Paden), up to 11cm across, wedge-shaped [top-shaped]; spore-bearing upper surface black, (Castellano)
FLESH  rubbery overall; interior flesh a watery-gelatinous mass, clear gray to black or brownish^, (Arora), thick, when old becoming thinner from collapse of the gelatinous interior, (Castellano)
UNDERSIDE  dark gray to black; finely velvety, especially in upper part^, (Arora), dark gray to black; often deeply wrinkled, especially in lower part, covered with an extensive dark tomentum, (Paden), black with heavily pigmented hairs, (Castellano), often roughened with dark granules (Phillips)
STEM  fruitbody usually narrowed in lower part to from a thick stem "which is often deeply wrinkled or ribbed or has large pockets"^, (Arora), with a short gelatinous stem, (Paden), substipitate (Castellano)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  unknown (Arora)
HABITAT  single to gregarious or clustered "on rotting wood or duff under conifers, fruiting in the late winter, spring, summer, and early fall"^, (Arora), single to gregarious or cespitose, on decaying wood and litter, January to September, (Paden), single to gregarious on or near decaying wood, or on litter and soil, in coniferous forests from low to high elevation, November through May, (Castellano), February to September (Phillips), on wet ground or wood, in spring, often in the mountains shortly after snowmelt, (Trudell)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 23-34 x 10-14 um, elliptic to somewhat sausage-shaped, smooth, with 1-3 oil droplets^, (Arora), spores 23-34 x 10-14 um, germinating readily, elliptic to suballantoid, smooth, colorless, containing 1-3 oil droplets; asci "nominally 8-spored but sometimes only 6 or 7 spores attaining maturity", 500-570 x 12-15 um, suboperculate, long-cylindric, gradually narrowing basally; paraphyses cylindric or with tips slightly widened, (2.8-3 um wide in lower part, 3-5 um wide at tips), "closely septate, often slightly constricted at the septa, branched, anastomosing", "embedded in a dark green, amorphous material, rounded or irregularly lobed"; hypothecium of densely woven textura intricata, the hyphae 3.5-5 um wide, "with green pigmented cell walls, forming a dark green zone beneath the hymenium", medullary excipulum of textura intricata in a highly gelatinous matrix, the hyphae 3.5-5 um wide, colorless, ectal excipulum of textura angularis, the cell walls dark brown; hyphae of tomentum up to 6 um wide, "dark green or brown, somewhat irregular, often roughened with dark brown granules", (Paden), spores 23-26 x 10-14 um, elliptic, smooth; asci 8-spored, curved at base, operculate, inamyloid, (Castellano)
NAME ORIGIN  in honor of the American mycologist, John Wilburn Paden, the major researcher who treated this species
SIMILAR  Pseudosarcosoma latahense is smaller (2-7.5cm across), purple-brown to black, grows particularly at high elevations, and spores lack oil droplets at maturity, (Arora). P. latahense has usually smaller fruitbodies, has spores that lack oil droplets, and has tomentum hyphae that are smooth except for occasional dark granules and usually light in color, (Paden). P. latahense is smaller (up to about 4cm instead of up to 10cm), "less gelatinous, with the gelatin diminishing greatly as the fruitbodies age", the cups "with a gray, rather than black, exterior", and has spores 24-37 x 9-12 um and lacking oil droplets at maturity, (Trudell). Sarcosoma globosum (jelly pots) has been reported from "In the rain forests of Sugarbowl-Grizzly Den Provincial Park, British Columbia" by Curtis Randall Bjork who posted a video on Facebook seen June 25, 2017. He wrote "This ascomycete has a more or less spherical stalk that is filled with a liquid gel. The spore-bearing part is the disc on top. This species is rare in Europe." In the comments about this posting, Andy McKinnon noted, " I've seen this species once before, about three decades ago, just outside Prince George [BC]. It's distinctive and remarkable." The appearance in the video does not closely resemble other photos that depict a hymenium located in a depression on the upper part of the fruitbody. In the video some of the fruitbodies have developed an everted disc. In addition to its occurrence in Europe, Sarcosoma globosum (the same as Bulgaria globosa but not Sarcoleotia globosa) is said to be rare in northeastern North America. See also SIMILAR section of Bulgaria inquinans. 
SOURCES  Paden(1) (as Sarcosoma mexicana), Arora(1) (as Sarcosoma mexicana), Castellano(1)* (as Sarcosoma mexicana), Larsen(1) (as Sarcosoma mexicana), Phillips(1)* (as Sarcosoma mexicana), Miller(14)* (as Sarcosoma mexicana), Trudell(4)* (as Sarcosoma mexicana), Carbone(2)*, Desjardin(6)*, Siegel(2)*, Marrone(1)*, MacKinnon(1)*
388
FAMILY  Sclerotiniaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Valdensinia heterodoxa  Peyronel^  Nuovo Giorn. Bot. Ital. 59: 184. 1953
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Valdensinia heterodoxa causes a common brown concentrically ringed leaf spot on salal, mountain huckleberry, and Alaskan blueberry, identified microscopically by star-like propagules found on the leaves. Small stemmed brown fruiting bodies on the leaves are rarely found.^ | A gradual increase in turgor forces the propagule's radial arms against the leaf and propels it (with sufficient force for it to rise 20cm vertically) to other uninfected tissue. RANGE ^It is common in BC, WA, and OR, (Lorelei Norvell, pers. comm.), and found in PQ (Redhead(44)).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.15-0.35cm wide, up to 0.7cm high, disc-shaped, concave at first becoming funnel-shaped then flat and umbilicate or convex, margins often rolled under; pale brown^, (Redhead(61))
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  colored as upper surface; furfuraceous^, (Redhead(61))
STEM  flaring toward the disc, colored the same as upper surface or darker toward base^, (Redhead(61))
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  found on Gaultheria shallon (salal), Vaccinium membranaceum (mountain huckleberry), Vaccinium alaskaense (Alaskan blueberry), and other species (Acer macrophyllum (big-leaf maple), Dryopteris austriaca (spinulose wood fern), Malus fusca (Pacific crab-apple), Menziesia ferruginea (false azalea), Polystichum munitum (sword fern), Pteridium aquilinum (bracken fern), Rubus parviflorus (thimbleberry), Rubus pedatus (trailing raspberry), Rubus ursinus (pacific dewberry), (Ginns for BC)), other species elsewhere
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  identified by the unique multicellular stellate [star-like] propagules, also called conidial "staurospores", attached to hyphae in the host tissue by a central pedicel, (Norvell), spores "(15.5-) 11-9.5 x 4-4.5 (-6)" um, smooth, colorless, inamyloid in mass, thin-walled, "mainly non-septate, becoming symmetrically or asymmetrically 1-2 septate with age, not constricted at the septa, the second septum always asymmetrically placed", mainly with two droplets, (Redhead(61))^; asci 8-spored, 97-110 x 6-10 um, cylindric to slightly clavate, inoperculate, thin-walled, tapering at base; prominent croziers present at the base of some asci; paraphyses 2-3.5 um wide, filamentous, slightly enlarged at top, septate, (Redhead(61))
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Norvell(5), Ginns(20), Redhead(44), Redhead(61)
389
FAMILY  Helotiaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Velutarina rufo-olivacea  (Alb. & Schwein. ex Pers.) Korf^  Mycologia 45: 476. 1953;  Velutaria rufo-olivacea  (Alb. & Schwein.) Fuckel;  Lachnella rufo-olivacea  W. Phillips;  Humaria rufo-olivacea  Quel.;  Schweinitzia rufo-olivacea  Massee & Crossl.;  Cenangium rubi  Baumler;  Phaeangium rubi  Sacc. & P. Syd.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small, cup-shaped fruitbodies with a dark olive green upper surface, rusty brown powder on exterior, and growth on dead twigs and branches of deciduous trees and shrubs.^ RANGE ^Velutarina rufo-olivacea is found from NJ to OR, and also in Europe, (Seaver), including Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen), and the United Kingdom (Dennis). There are collections from BC deposited at the Pacific Forestry Centre.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  reaching 0.1-0.3cm across, erumpent [emerging from substrate] and soon becoming apparently superficial; spore-bearing upper surface concave or nearly flat, dark-colored, slightly olivaceous to black^, (Seaver), erumpent, cup-shaped with an inrolled margin; disc up to 0.3cm across, olive-green or almost black, (Dennis), up to 0.3cm across, upper surface dark olive green, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  with dense coat of hairs giving a mealy appearance^, (Seaver), covered with rusty brown or tan powder, (Dennis), with rusty brown powder (Hansen)
STEM  subsessile^ (Dennis), without a stem (Hansen)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or several together in dense clusters on dead branches of various kinds: Quercus (oak), Betula (birch), Andromeda, Sassafras, and Rubus^, (Seaver), single or in small clusters on dead twigs and branches, Acer (maple), Fagus (beech), Fraxinus (ash), Rosa (rose), Rubus, Ulex (gorse), December to May, (Dennis), single or in small clusters, on deciduous trees and shrubs e.g. Salix (willow), (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 12-15 x 6-8 um, elliptic, colorless or faintly colored, uniseriate^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 110-120 um and a width of 12-14 um, subcylindric; paraphyses filiform [thread-like], rather strongly widened in upper part; hairs "poorly developed and more or less disjuncted", often each with a large spherical tip which gives the mealy appearance, (Seaver), spores 10-14 x 6-7 um, elliptic with obtusely rounded ends, colorless at first becoming pale brown, containing 1 or 2 large oil droplets, uniseriate; asci 8-spored, up to 160 x 12 um, cylindric-clavate, the broad pore turning blue with iodine; paraphyses 3 um wide, widening to 5 um wide at the greenish brown tip; external powder "formed of thick-walled, loose, irregularly lobed cells", (Dennis), spores 10-14 x 6-8 um, asci 120-160 x 10-15 um, with amyloid pore, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'rufous-olivaceous'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Velutaria), Dennis(1), Hansen, L.(1)
390
FAMILY  Tympanidaceae, Order Phacidiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Vexillomyces atrovirens  (Pers.) Baral, Quijada & G. Marson^ in Baral & Quijada, Index Fungorum 454: 1. 2020;  Claussenomyces atrovirens  (Pers.) Korf & Abawi  Can. J. Bot. 49(11): 1882. 1971
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include 1) a tiny, dark green, lens-shaped to cushion-shaped, gelatinous fruitbody, slightly even on the surface and shiny when wet, 2) absent stem, 3) growth on rotten hardwood, and 4) cylindric to fusiform spores which quickly form secondary spores.^ | This collection with three illustrations was probably identified on the basis of its similarity to the description in Breitenbach(1), including similar primary spore size and the presence of secondary spores. Breitenbach(1) mention that their primary spore size was shorter than other measurements in the literature, "During the formation of secondary spores in the ascus, typical for C. atrovirens, the eight primary spores break up. The primary spores measured by us fall significantly short of the measurements given in the lit. (Rehm 1896: 15-25 x 3.5-5 um, Grelet 1932 - 1959: 20-35 x 4-5 um, Dennis 1956: 15-28 x 3.5-5 um). The formation of secondary spores nevertheless allows, in our opinion, no other interpretation (poorly developed spores?)." (Latin names italicized, mu used instead of u in measurement unit). The description here is derived from Breitenbach(1). RANGE ^The illustrated collection from BC was deposited at the University of British Columbia (F24156).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.03-0.06cm across, "lens-shaped to cushionlike", resting without a stem on the wood; dark green; slightly uneven, shiny when wet; clavate conidial stage not present
FLESH  gelatinous and soft
UNDERSIDE  dark green; slightly uneven, shiny when wet
STEM  none
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  on wet, very rotten hardwood; April to October in Europe
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  primary spores 7-9 x 2-2.5 um, fusiform-elliptic, smooth, colorless, with indistinct multiple septa, quickly forming secondary spores of 2-3 x 1 um^; asci 110-123 x 11-11.5 um, iodine negative, "at first eight spored, then many-spored"; paraphyses "filiform, septate, tips multiply branched"
NAME ORIGIN  means 'black-greenish' or 'black becoming green'
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Breitenbach(1)* (as Claussenomyces atrovirens)
391
FAMILY  Tympanidaceae, Order Phacidiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Vexillomyces pseudotsugae  (J.W. Groves) Baral^  in Baral & Quijada, Index Fungorum 454: 1. 2020;  Claussenomyces pseudotsugae  (J.W. Groves) Ouell. & Piroz.  Can. J. Bot. 52: 1909. 1974;  == Tympanis pseudotsugae  J.W. Groves
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include small hard blackish or greenish fruitbodies on Douglas-fir, without a stem or substipitate, and microscopic characters.^ RANGE ^Collections were examined from BC, OR, and CA, (Groves). There are collections from BC at the Pacific Forestry Centre determined by A. Funk.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.4cm across, 0.03-0.3cm high, circular to slightly elongated or undulate, erumpent, hard, horny; spore-bearing upper surface concave to flat, more fleshy than exterior, black or greenish when moist; "at first with a thick, raised, more or less infolded margin which later may disappear"; conidial fruiting bodies 0.03-0.07cm across, 0.05-0.01cm high, erumpent, separate or cespitose, sometimes arising from same stroma as fruiting bodies, containing a single spherical to ovoid cavity opening at top^, (Groves)
FLESH  hard and horny in consistency, becoming more cartilaginous when moist^, (Groves)
UNDERSIDE  black, sometimes slightly greenish pulverulent [powdery]; bald^, (Groves)
STEM  sessile or substipitate, fruitbody narrowed in lower part^, (Groves)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious, separate or cespitose in clusters of up to 10, on Pseudotsuga menziesii (Douglas-fir)^, (Groves)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  primary ascospores 15-25 x 4-6 um, elliptic-fusiform, colorless, several-septate to muriform, uniseriate, secondary ascospores 2.0-4.0 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, one-celled, colorless^; asci at first 8-spored, becoming multispored, (175)190-240(260) x (18)20-23(25) um, cylindric, narrowed in lower part to a short stem, obtuse at top, at first with walls thickened and gelatinized, becoming thinner when mature; paraphyses 1.5-2.0 um wide, filiform [thread-like], colorless, septate, simple or branched, the tips slightly swollen and embedded in a brownish gelatinous matrix, forming an epithecium; conidia 2.0-4.0 x 1.0-1.5 um, cylindric to allantoid, one-celled, borne at tip and along sides of conidiophore; conidiophores lining the cavity of conidial fruitbody, 15-45 x 1.5-2.0 um, filiform, septate, colorless, simple, (Groves)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'of Pseudotsuga'
SIMILAR  Tympanis species are mostly smaller and differ microscopically.
SOURCES  Groves(1) (as Tympanis pseudotsugae), Ouellette(1) (as Claussenomyces pseudotsugae)
392
FAMILY  Vibrisseaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Vibrissea decolorans  (Saut.) A. Sanchez & Korf^  in Sanchez, J. Agric. Univ. Puerto Rico 51: 83. 1967;  Apostemidium vibrisseoides  (Peck) Boud.;  Apostemidium leptospora  (Berk. & Broome) Boud.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include very small, top-shaped, stemless fruitbodies that vary from bluish-pallid to yellowish or ochraceous, gregarious growth on decaying sticks lying in water, and microscopic characters, including long thread-like multiseptate spores.^ |The two synonymies are given by an online resource associated with www.mycokey.com, and the second is also given by Hansen, L.(1). RANGE ^Vibrissea decolorans was recorded by Kanouse from WA. It is also found from NH to NY, (Seaver), Switzerland (Breitenbach), and Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.2-0.3cm, turbinate [top-shaped], spore-bearing upper surface flat to convex; varying from bluish-pallid to yellowish, or ochraceous^, (Seaver), spore-bearing surface pale gray to "deep olive buff" when fresh, (Kanouse), 0.05-0.2cm across, spherical when young, then disc-shaped to lens-shaped, spore-bearing upper surface "pale yellow to olive-yellow, sometimes also with an orange tint"; margin projecting and usually with fine brown-black teeth, (Breitenbach), fruitbody 0.05-0.25(0.4)cm across; spore-bearing upper surface yellowish gray; margin blackish, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  black-brown, smooth, dull^, (Breitenbach), blackish (Hansen)
STEM  sessile^ (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  gregarious on decaying sticks lying in the water^, (Seaver), on a wet stick (Kanouse), gregarious to cespitose on damp barkless wood of hardwoods lying in wet places, according to literature commonly on wood of Rosaceae; March to June, (Breitenbach), on hardwood soaked in water, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores about 250 x 1 um, long-filiform [thread-like], colorless, multiseptate, parallel in ascus^; asci 8-spored, reaching a length of 275-300 um and width of 5-6 um; paraphyses not numerous, about as long as the asci, slender, 1-1.5 um wide in lower part, simple or occasionally forked, the apical part clavate-thickened, colored, up to 6 um wide, (Seaver), paraphyses with colored tips, (Kanouse), spores 270-300 x 1.5-2 um, filiform, smooth, colorless, multiply septate, lying parallel in asci; asci 8-spored, 275-315 x 7 um, positive reaction in iodine; paraphyses projecting beyond the asci, cylindric, "septate, sometimes forked, tips with slight clavate thickenings", (Breitenbach), spores 250-350 x 1-2 um; asci 270-370 x 7 um, with amyloid pore, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Apostemidium guernisaci (a synonym of Vibrissea filisporia) has paraphyses with colorless tips, (Kanouse). Vibrissea filisporia has asci with a non-amyloid pore (Hansen).
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Apostemidium vibrisseoides), Kanouse(6) (as Apostemidium vibrisseoides), Breitenbach(1)* (as Apostemidium leptospora), Hansen, L.(1)
393
FAMILY  Vibrisseaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Vibrissea filisporia  (Bonord.) Korf & A. Sanchez^;  Vibrissea guernisacii  P. Crouan & H. Crouan [as guernisaci];  Apostemidium guernisacii  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan) Boud. [as guernisaci];  Gorgoniceps guernisacii  (P. Crouan & H. Crouan) Sacc. [as guernisaci];  Gorgoniceps turbinulata  Rehm
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  Features include a very small, top-shaped to convex, stemless fruitbody that is bluish-pallid to orange-ochraceous with a dark brownish, somewhat furfuraceous underside, growth on dead sticks and wood in water, and microscopic characters including thread-like multiseptate spores.^ | Forma fiscella (P. Karst) A. Sanchez has been known as Apostemidium fiscellum (Karst.) P. Karst. and is described and illustrated in Breitenbach(1). RANGE ^Vibrissea filisporia is found in NY and New England to WA, (Seaver), and Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, (Hansen). Tanney(2) refer to a sequenced collection from OR (GenBank JX415338): their phylogenetic tree showed it in a different clade from V. truncorum. V. filisporia was not clearly differentiated from several other names in Vibrissea, but the study was not designed to do that specifically. 
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.1-0.4cm, turbinate or convex with spore-bearing upper surface flat to convex; bluish-pallid to orange-ochraceous; even or sometimes wrinkled, often with dimple in center^, (Seaver), fruitbody 0.05-0.12cm across, spore-bearing surface grayish; margin brownish, (Hansen)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  dark brownish; somewhat furfuraceous^, (Seaver), brownish (Hansen)
STEM  sessile by a rather broad base^ (Seaver)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single or gregarious, on dead sticks and wood in water^, (Seaver), on deciduous wood and culms of Phragmites reed soaked in water, (Hansen)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 200-250 x 1 um, slenderly filiform [thread-like], multiseptate, parallel in ascus^; asci reaching a length of 225-300 um and width of 5-6 um, apex rounded; paraphyses numerous, longer than asci, filiform, colorless, the apical part (about as much as projects beyond asci) repeatedly forked or fasciculately branched, the tips abruptly pyriform-thickened, colorless, 4-5 um thick, (Seaver), spores 100-210 x 1-2 um; asci 165-200 x 5-7 um, inamyloid; paraphyses branched; forma fiscella has simple [unbranched] paraphyses; forma boudieri Korf & A. Sanchez has spores 210-315 um long, (Hansen)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  Vibrissea decolorans (= Apostemidium vibrisseoides (Pack) Boud.) was recorded from WA by Kanouse, who says it differs from A. guernisaci (Cr.) Boud. in having colored tips on the paraphyses: the hymenium is pale gray to "deep olive buff" when fresh, (Kanouse). V. decolorans has the ascus with an amyloid pore (Hansen).
SOURCES  Seaver(2) (as Apostemidium guernisaci), Hansen, L.(1), Kanouse(6) (as Apostemidium guernisaci), Breitenbach(1) (discussing Apostemidium fiscellum)
394
FAMILY  Vibrisseaceae, Order Helotiales, Class Leotiomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Vibrissea truncorum  (Alb. & Schwein.) Fr.  group^  Syst. Myc. 2: 31. 1822;  Vibrissea foliorum  Thaxt.
ENGLISH NAME(S)  aquatic earth-tongue, water club
NOTES  Also listed in Clubs category. Features include small size, pinkish buff to yellowish or orange, somewhat gelatinous, convex, knob-like cap, whitish to grayish or brownish stem, growth on sticks in running water, and microscopic characters.^ |According to Beug(6), "There are two species and both may need a new name." RANGE ^Vibrissea truncorum is found from NF to AK and WV, Europe, (Seaver), WA, ON, PQ, CT, MI, NH, and NY, (Mains), and NS (Wehmeyer). There are collections from BC deposited at the Pacific Forestry Centre and the University of British Columbia. A collection from OR is deposited at Oregon State University. It is reported from ID by Andrew Parker, pers. comm.
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  fruitbody 0.3-0.5cm across, 0.4-0.5cm high, hemispheric-convex, margin obtuse; yellow, orange, or reddish-orange, rarely pallid^, (Seaver), fruitbody 0.3-2cm high, spore-bearing upper part 0.2-0.5cm wide, convex, thin, flesh-colored, pinkish buff or yellowish buff, with spore-bearing part on upper surface, margin frequently involute, (Mains), fruitbody 1-1.5(2)cm tall, divided into head and stem, head up to 0.6cm wide, oval to lens-shaped; yolk-yellow to orange-yellow, (Breitenbach)
FLESH  fleshy to subgelatinous^ (Mains)
UNDERSIDE  
STEM  up to 1.5cm long, 0.1-0.2cm wide, white to bluish-gray, or brownish, rather darker in lower part; minutely squamulose [finely scaly]^, (Seaver), 0.1-0.2cm wide, round in cross-section; white; minutely tomentose, frequently matted and appearing smooth, (Mains), stem tapering downwards, pubescent with short, downy, blackish hairs, (Dennis), 0.2-0.4cm wide, cylindric; white, gray-whitish to brown-blackish; sometimes slightly downy and dark-scaled toward the base (blackish hairs), (Breitenbach)
ODOR  
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  single, gregarious, or in clusters of 2 or 3 each, on wholly or partly submerged sticks etc., in brooks, mostly at higher altitudes^, (Seaver), gregarious, cespitose [in tufts] or scattered, on decaying wood, leaves etc. in cold wet places, often in streams, (Mains), the ascospores, when mature, project and vibrate in the running water above the fertile area giving the fruiting body a white silky appearance, (Tylutki), gregarious on wood and remains of roots that are very wet or under water, in ditches among Sphagnum, or in small streams, commonly montane to alpine, (Breitenbach for Europe)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores up to 250 um x 1 um, slenderly filiform [thread-like], slightly narrowed toward each end, nearly as long as ascus, in a parallel fascicle in the ascus, multiseptate^; asci 8-spored, up to 200-325 um long and 5-6 um wide, slender-cylindric, apex rounded, not blue with iodine; paraphyses thread-like, occasionally forked, the apices somewhat clavate-thickened and colored, (Seaver), ascospores very variable in length, (80)125-250(275) x 1 um, filiform [thread-like], multiseptate; asci variable in length, 175-325 x 5-6 um, narrowly clavate, gradually narrowing from near the apex; paraphyses straight, simple or branched, filiform in lower part, enlarged at apices, (Mains), spores 185-190 x 1.5 um, filiform, colorless, smooth, multiply septate; asci 8-spored, 200-250 x 6-9 um; paraphyses filiform, forked and slightly clavate toward tips, septate, (Breitenbach)
NAME ORIGIN  
SIMILAR  
SOURCES  Seaver(2), Mains(1), Barron(1)*, Lincoff(2)*, Bessette(2)*, Tylutki(1)*, Breitenbach(1)*, Dennis(1), Wehmeyer(1), MacKinnon(1)*
395
FAMILY  Helvellaceae, Order Pezizales, Class Pezizomycetes, Phylum Ascomycota
LATIN NAME(S)  Wynnella silvicola  (Beck) Nannf.^  Ann. Bot. Fenn. 3: 309. 1966;  Helvella silvicola  (Beck ex Sacc.) Harmaja;  Otidea silvicola  Beck;  Midotis lingua Fr., Elench. fung. (Greifswald) 2: 30. 1828 (proposed current name)
ENGLISH NAME(S)  
NOTES  {See also Otidea Table.} Features include an Otidea-like fruiting body [like a vertically elongated cup with an opening down the side], dark purplish red brown to dark brown color on the inside surface and medium red brown exterior, short stem, growth in duff under conifers, and microscopic characters.^ |Hansen, K.(6) proposed in 2019 the older name Midotis lingua Fr. for this species and designated a neotype. On June 2, 2022, the online Species Fungorum and MycoBank had not yet listed this name as the current one for Wynnella silvicola, although they had accepted combinations in Dissingia and Barssia made in the same paper. |The description is derived from Abbott(1). RANGE ^Wynnella silvicola is found at least in BC, AB, MB, PQ, YT, MT, and Romania, and is reported from eastern North America, Europe, and Asia, (Abbott). It is also found in WA and ID, (Larsen). A collection from OR was used by O'Donnell(2).
CHEMICAL REACTIONS  ^
UPPER SURFACE  0.5-2.3cm in diameter, 1-6cm high (up to 5cm x 8cm fresh), ear-shaped or rarely irregularly cup-shaped with one enlarged lobe, margin inrolled at first, expanding and rarely somewhat reflexed when old; dark purplish red brown to dark brown when fresh, blackish brown when dry; smooth or rarely slightly wavy-wrinkled when very old^, (Abbott)
FLESH  
UNDERSIDE  medium red brown or pale red brown to white near base; bald^, (Abbott)
STEM  0.2-1cm x 0.2-0.9cm (up to 0.8cm x 2cm fresh), narrowing to base or nearly equal; "yellow brown to pale yellow or white at base"; "shallowly fluted or ribbed", sulcate [grooved] and solid or with central chamber^, (Abbott)
ODOR  unique strong odor when dried, but not detected fresh^, (Abbott)
TASTE  
EDIBILITY  
HABITAT  "solitary to gregarious or scattered and numerous on duff, rarely in burned areas, under conifers", June to September^, (Abbott)
SPORE DEPOSIT  
MICROSCOPIC  spores 17-24 x 11.5-17 um, broadly elliptic, smooth, colorless, with one droplet^; asci 200 x 15-19 um; paraphyses clavate, 5-6 um wide at apex, brown, contents finely granular, (Abbott), spores 22-25 um long (Arora)
NAME ORIGIN  means 'living in the forest'
SIMILAR  Otidea smithii can be somewhat similar but has smaller spores with two large droplets.
SOURCES  Abbott(1) (as Helvella), Larsen(1), Arora(1), O'Donnell(2), Hansen, K.(6) (as Midotis lingua)
